CHAPTER IV\n\n    CHAPTER V\n\n    CHAPTER VI\n\n    CHAPTER VII\n\n    CHAPTER VIII\n\n    CHAPTER IX\n\n    CHAPTER X\n\n    CHAPTER XI\n\n    CHAPTER XII\n\n    CHAPTER XIII\n\n    CHAPTER XIV\n\n    CHAPTER XV\n\n    CHAPTER XVI\n\n\n    SECOND EPILOGUE\n\n    CHAPTER I\n\n    CHAPTER II\n\n    CHAPTER III\n\n    CHAPTER IV\n\n    CHAPTER V\n\n    CHAPTER VI\n\n    CHAPTER VII\n\n    CHAPTER VIII\n\n    CHAPTER IX\n\n    CHAPTER X\n\n    CHAPTER XI\n\n    CHAPTER XII\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBOOK ONE: 1805\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER I\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Prince, so Genoa and Lucca are now just family estates of the\nBuonapartes. But I warn you, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t tell me that this means war,\nif you still try to defend the infamies and horrors perpetrated by that\nAntichrist\xe2\x80\x94I really believe he is Antichrist\xe2\x80\x94I will have nothing\nmore to do with you and you are no longer my friend, no longer my\n\xe2\x80\x98faithful slave,\xe2\x80\x99 as you call yourself! But how do you do? I see I\nhave frightened you\xe2\x80\x94sit down and tell me all the news.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIt was in July, 1805, and the speaker was the well-known Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\nSch\xc3\xa9rer, maid of honor and favorite of the Empress M\xc3\xa1rya F\xc3\xabdorovna.\nWith these words she greeted Prince Vas\xc3\xadli Kur\xc3\xa1gin, a man of high\nrank and importance, who was the first to arrive at her reception. Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna had had a cough for some days. She was, as she said, suffering\nfrom la grippe; grippe being then a new word in St. Petersburg, used\nonly by the elite.\n\nAll her invitations without exception, written in French, and delivered\nby a scarlet-liveried footman that morning, ran as follows:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you have nothing better to do, Count (or Prince), and if the\nprospect of spending an evening with a poor invalid is not too terrible,\nI shall be very charmed to see you tonight between 7 and 10\xe2\x80\x94Annette\nSch\xc3\xa9rer.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeavens! what a virulent attack!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the prince, not in the\nleast disconcerted by this reception. He had just entered, wearing an\nembroidered court uniform, knee breeches, and shoes, and had stars on\nhis breast and a serene expression on his flat face. He spoke in that\nrefined French in which our grandfathers not only spoke but thought, and\nwith the gentle, patronizing intonation natural to a man of importance\nwho had grown old in society and at court. He went up to Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna,\nkissed her hand, presenting to her his bald, scented, and shining head,\nand complacently seated himself on the sofa.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFirst of all, dear friend, tell me how you are. Set your friend\xe2\x80\x99s\nmind at rest,\xe2\x80\x9d said he without altering his tone, beneath the\npoliteness and affected sympathy of which indifference and even irony\ncould be discerned.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan one be well while suffering morally? Can one be calm in times\nlike these if one has any feeling?\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are\nstaying the whole evening, I hope?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the fete at the English ambassador\xe2\x80\x99s? Today is Wednesday. I\nmust put in an appearance there,\xe2\x80\x9d said the prince. \xe2\x80\x9cMy daughter is\ncoming for me to take me there.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought today\xe2\x80\x99s fete had been canceled. I confess all these\nfestivities and fireworks are becoming wearisome.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf they had known that you wished it, the entertainment would have\nbeen put off,\xe2\x80\x9d said the prince, who, like a wound-up clock, by force\nof habit said things he did not even wish to be believed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t tease! Well, and what has been decided about Novos\xc3\xadltsev\xe2\x80\x99s\ndispatch? You know everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can one say about it?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the prince in a cold, listless\ntone. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat has been decided? They have decided that Buonaparte has\nburnt his boats, and I believe that we are ready to burn ours.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli always spoke languidly, like an actor repeating a stale\npart. Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna Sch\xc3\xa9rer on the contrary, despite her forty years,\noverflowed with animation and impulsiveness. To be an enthusiast had\nbecome her social vocation and, sometimes even when she did not\nfeel like it, she became enthusiastic in order not to disappoint the\nexpectations of those who knew her. The subdued smile which, though it\ndid not suit her faded features, always played round her lips expressed,\nas in a spoiled child, a continual consciousness of her charming defect,\nwhich she neither wished, nor could, nor considered it necessary, to\ncorrect.\n\nIn the midst of a conversation on political matters Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna burst\nout:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, don\xe2\x80\x99t speak to me of Austria. Perhaps I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand\nthings, but Austria never has wished, and does not wish, for war. She\nis betraying us! Russia alone must save Europe. Our gracious sovereign\nrecognizes his high vocation and will be true to it. That is the one\nthing I have faith in! Our good and wonderful sovereign has to perform\nthe noblest role on earth, and he is so virtuous and noble that God will\nnot forsake him. He will fulfill his vocation and crush the hydra of\nrevolution, which has become more terrible than ever in the person of\nthis murderer and villain! We alone must avenge the blood of the just\none.... Whom, I ask you, can we rely on?... England with her commercial\nspirit will not and cannot understand the Emperor Alexander\xe2\x80\x99s\nloftiness of soul. She has refused to evacuate Malta. She wanted to\nfind, and still seeks, some secret motive in our actions. What answer\ndid Novos\xc3\xadltsev get? None. The English have not understood and cannot\nunderstand the self-abnegation of our Emperor who wants nothing for\nhimself, but only desires the good of mankind. And what have they\npromised? Nothing! And what little they have promised they will not\nperform! Prussia has always declared that Buonaparte is invincible, and\nthat all Europe is powerless before him.... And I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe a\nword that Hardenburg says, or Haugwitz either. This famous Prussian\nneutrality is just a trap. I have faith only in God and the lofty\ndestiny of our adored monarch. He will save Europe!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe suddenly paused, smiling at her own impetuosity.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think,\xe2\x80\x9d said the prince with a smile, \xe2\x80\x9cthat if you had been\nsent instead of our dear Wintzingerode you would have captured the King\nof Prussia\xe2\x80\x99s consent by assault. You are so eloquent. Will you give me\na cup of tea?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn a moment. \xc3\x80 propos,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, becoming calm again, \xe2\x80\x9cI am\nexpecting two very interesting men tonight, le Vicomte de Mortemart, who\nis connected with the Montmorencys through the Rohans, one of the best\nFrench families. He is one of the genuine \xc3\xa9migr\xc3\xa9s, the good ones. And\nalso the Abb\xc3\xa9 Morio. Do you know that profound thinker? He has been\nreceived by the Emperor. Had you heard?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be delighted to meet them,\xe2\x80\x9d said the prince. \xe2\x80\x9cBut\ntell me,\xe2\x80\x9d he added with studied carelessness as if it had only just\noccurred to him, though the question he was about to ask was the chief\nmotive of his visit, \xe2\x80\x9cis it true that the Dowager Empress wants\nBaron Funke to be appointed first secretary at Vienna? The baron by all\naccounts is a poor creature.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli wished to obtain this post for his son, but others were\ntrying through the Dowager Empress M\xc3\xa1rya F\xc3\xabdorovna to secure it for\nthe baron.\n\nAnna P\xc3\xa1vlovna almost closed her eyes to indicate that neither she nor\nanyone else had a right to criticize what the Empress desired or was\npleased with.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBaron Funke has been recommended to the Dowager Empress by her\nsister,\xe2\x80\x9d was all she said, in a dry and mournful tone.\n\nAs she named the Empress, Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s face suddenly assumed an\nexpression of profound and sincere devotion and respect mingled with\nsadness, and this occurred every time she mentioned her illustrious\npatroness. She added that Her Majesty had deigned to show Baron Funke\nbeaucoup d\xe2\x80\x99estime, and again her face clouded over with sadness.\n\nThe prince was silent and looked indifferent. But, with the womanly and\ncourtierlike quickness and tact habitual to her, Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\nwished both to rebuke him (for daring to speak as he had done of a man\nrecommended to the Empress) and at the same time to console him, so she\nsaid:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow about your family. Do you know that since your daughter came\nout everyone has been enraptured by her? They say she is amazingly\nbeautiful.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe prince bowed to signify his respect and gratitude.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI often think,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued after a short pause, drawing nearer\nto the prince and smiling amiably at him as if to show that political\nand social topics were ended and the time had come for intimate\nconversation\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI often think how unfairly sometimes the joys of life\nare distributed. Why has fate given you two such splendid children?\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t speak of Anatole, your youngest. I don\xe2\x80\x99t like him,\xe2\x80\x9d she\nadded in a tone admitting of no rejoinder and raising her eyebrows.\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo such charming children. And really you appreciate them less than\nanyone, and so you don\xe2\x80\x99t deserve to have them.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd she smiled her ecstatic smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t help it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the prince. \xe2\x80\x9cLavater would have said I\nlack the bump of paternity.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t joke; I mean to have a serious talk with you. Do you know\nI am dissatisfied with your younger son? Between ourselves\xe2\x80\x9d (and her\nface assumed its melancholy expression), \xe2\x80\x9che was mentioned at Her\nMajesty\xe2\x80\x99s and you were pitied....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe prince answered nothing, but she looked at him significantly,\nawaiting a reply. He frowned.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have me do?\xe2\x80\x9d he said at last. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know I did all\na father could for their education, and they have both turned out fools.\nHippolyte is at least a quiet fool, but Anatole is an active one. That\nis the only difference between them.\xe2\x80\x9d He said this smiling in a way\nmore natural and animated than usual, so that the wrinkles round\nhis mouth very clearly revealed something unexpectedly coarse and\nunpleasant.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why are children born to such men as you? If you were not a\nfather there would be nothing I could reproach you with,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna, looking up pensively.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am your faithful slave and to you alone I can confess that my\nchildren are the bane of my life. It is the cross I have to bear. That\nis how I explain it to myself. It can\xe2\x80\x99t be helped!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe said no more, but expressed his resignation to cruel fate by a\ngesture. Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna meditated.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you never thought of marrying your prodigal son Anatole?\xe2\x80\x9d she\nasked. \xe2\x80\x9cThey say old maids have a mania for matchmaking, and though I\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t feel that weakness in myself as yet, I know a little person who\nis very unhappy with her father. She is a relation of yours, Princess\nMary Bolk\xc3\xb3nskaya.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli did not reply, though, with the quickness of memory and\nperception befitting a man of the world, he indicated by a movement of\nthe head that he was considering this information.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know,\xe2\x80\x9d he said at last, evidently unable to check the sad\ncurrent of his thoughts, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Anatole is costing me forty thousand\nrubles a year? And,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on after a pause, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat will it be in\nfive years, if he goes on like this?\xe2\x80\x9d Presently he added: \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s\nwhat we fathers have to put up with.... Is this princess of yours\nrich?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer father is very rich and stingy. He lives in the country. He is\nthe well-known Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski who had to retire from the army under\nthe late Emperor, and was nicknamed \xe2\x80\x98the King of Prussia.\xe2\x80\x99 He is\nvery clever but eccentric, and a bore. The poor girl is very unhappy.\nShe has a brother; I think you know him, he married Lise Meinen lately.\nHe is an aide-de-camp of Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s and will be here tonight.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, dear Annette,\xe2\x80\x9d said the prince, suddenly taking Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s hand and for some reason drawing it downwards. \xe2\x80\x9cArrange\nthat affair for me and I shall always be your most devoted slave-slafe\nwith an f, as a village elder of mine writes in his reports. She is rich\nand of good family and that\xe2\x80\x99s all I want.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd with the familiarity and easy grace peculiar to him, he raised the\nmaid of honor\xe2\x80\x99s hand to his lips, kissed it, and swung it to and fro\nas he lay back in his armchair, looking in another direction.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAttendez,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna, reflecting, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll speak to\nLise, young Bolk\xc3\xb3nski\xe2\x80\x99s wife, this very evening, and perhaps the\nthing can be arranged. It shall be on your family\xe2\x80\x99s behalf that I\xe2\x80\x99ll\nstart my apprenticeship as old maid.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER II\n\nAnna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s drawing room was gradually filling. The highest\nPetersburg society was assembled there: people differing widely in age\nand character but alike in the social circle to which they belonged.\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s daughter, the beautiful H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, came to take her\nfather to the ambassador\xe2\x80\x99s entertainment; she wore a ball dress and\nher badge as maid of honor. The youthful little Princess Bolk\xc3\xb3nskaya,\nknown as la femme la plus s\xc3\xa9duisante de P\xc3\xa9tersbourg, * was also there.\nShe had been married during the previous winter, and being pregnant did\nnot go to any large gatherings, but only to small receptions. Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s son, Hippolyte, had come with Mortemart, whom he introduced.\nThe Abb\xc3\xa9 Morio and many others had also come.\n\n     * The most fascinating woman in Petersburg.\n\nTo each new arrival Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna said, \xe2\x80\x9cYou have not yet seen my\naunt,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cYou do not know my aunt?\xe2\x80\x9d and very gravely conducted\nhim or her to a little old lady, wearing large bows of ribbon in her\ncap, who had come sailing in from another room as soon as the guests\nbegan to arrive; and slowly turning her eyes from the visitor to her\naunt, Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna mentioned each one\xe2\x80\x99s name and then left them.\n\nEach visitor performed the ceremony of greeting this old aunt whom not\none of them knew, not one of them wanted to know, and not one of them\ncared about; Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna observed these greetings with mournful and\nsolemn interest and silent approval. The aunt spoke to each of them in\nthe same words, about their health and her own, and the health of Her\nMajesty, \xe2\x80\x9cwho, thank God, was better today.\xe2\x80\x9d And each visitor,\nthough politeness prevented his showing impatience, left the old woman\nwith a sense of relief at having performed a vexatious duty and did not\nreturn to her the whole evening.\n\nThe young Princess Bolk\xc3\xb3nskaya had brought some work in a\ngold-embroidered velvet bag. Her pretty little upper lip, on which a\ndelicate dark down was just perceptible, was too short for her teeth,\nbut it lifted all the more sweetly, and was especially charming when she\noccasionally drew it down to meet the lower lip. As is always the case\nwith a thoroughly attractive woman, her defect\xe2\x80\x94the shortness of her\nupper lip and her half-open mouth\xe2\x80\x94seemed to be her own special and\npeculiar form of beauty. Everyone brightened at the sight of this pretty\nyoung woman, so soon to become a mother, so full of life and health, and\ncarrying her burden so lightly. Old men and dull dispirited young ones\nwho looked at her, after being in her company and talking to her a\nlittle while, felt as if they too were becoming, like her, full of life\nand health. All who talked to her, and at each word saw her bright smile\nand the constant gleam of her white teeth, thought that they were in a\nspecially amiable mood that day.\n\nThe little princess went round the table with quick, short, swaying\nsteps, her workbag on her arm, and gaily spreading out her dress sat\ndown on a sofa near the silver samovar, as if all she was doing was a\npleasure to herself and to all around her. \xe2\x80\x9cI have brought my work,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid she in French, displaying her bag and addressing all present.\n\xe2\x80\x9cMind, Annette, I hope you have not played a wicked trick on me,\xe2\x80\x9d\nshe added, turning to her hostess. \xe2\x80\x9cYou wrote that it was to be quite\na small reception, and just see how badly I am dressed.\xe2\x80\x9d And she\nspread out her arms to show her short-waisted, lace-trimmed, dainty gray\ndress, girdled with a broad ribbon just below the breast.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSoyez tranquille, Lise, you will always be prettier than anyone\nelse,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know,\xe2\x80\x9d said the princess in the same tone of voice and still in\nFrench, turning to a general, \xe2\x80\x9cmy husband is deserting me? He is going\nto get himself killed. Tell me what this wretched war is for?\xe2\x80\x9d she\nadded, addressing Prince Vas\xc3\xadli, and without waiting for an answer she\nturned to speak to his daughter, the beautiful H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a delightful woman this little princess is!\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli to Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna.\n\nOne of the next arrivals was a stout, heavily built young man with\nclose-cropped hair, spectacles, the light-colored breeches fashionable\nat that time, a very high ruffle, and a brown dress coat. This stout\nyoung man was an illegitimate son of Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov, a well-known\ngrandee of Catherine\xe2\x80\x99s time who now lay dying in Moscow. The young man\nhad not yet entered either the military or civil service, as he had only\njust returned from abroad where he had been educated, and this was his\nfirst appearance in society. Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna greeted him with the nod she\naccorded to the lowest hierarchy in her drawing room. But in spite of\nthis lowest-grade greeting, a look of anxiety and fear, as at the sight\nof something too large and unsuited to the place, came over her face\nwhen she saw Pierre enter. Though he was certainly rather bigger than\nthe other men in the room, her anxiety could only have reference to\nthe clever though shy, but observant and natural, expression which\ndistinguished him from everyone else in that drawing room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very good of you, Monsieur Pierre, to come and visit a poor\ninvalid,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna, exchanging an alarmed glance with her\naunt as she conducted him to her.\n\nPierre murmured something unintelligible, and continued to look round as\nif in search of something. On his way to the aunt he bowed to the little\nprincess with a pleased smile, as to an intimate acquaintance.\n\nAnna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s alarm was justified, for Pierre turned away from the\naunt without waiting to hear her speech about Her Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s health.\nAnna P\xc3\xa1vlovna in dismay detained him with the words: \xe2\x80\x9cDo you know the\nAbb\xc3\xa9 Morio? He is a most interesting man.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I have heard of his scheme for perpetual peace, and it is very\ninteresting but hardly feasible.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think so?\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna in order to say something\nand get away to attend to her duties as hostess. But Pierre now\ncommitted a reverse act of impoliteness. First he had left a lady before\nshe had finished speaking to him, and now he continued to speak to\nanother who wished to get away. With his head bent, and his big feet\nspread apart, he began explaining his reasons for thinking the abb\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x99s\nplan chimerical.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will talk of it later,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna with a smile.\n\nAnd having got rid of this young man who did not know how to behave, she\nresumed her duties as hostess and continued to listen and watch, ready\nto help at any point where the conversation might happen to flag. As\nthe foreman of a spinning mill, when he has set the hands to work, goes\nround and notices here a spindle that has stopped or there one that\ncreaks or makes more noise than it should, and hastens to check the\nmachine or set it in proper motion, so Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna moved about her\ndrawing room, approaching now a silent, now a too-noisy group, and by a\nword or slight rearrangement kept the conversational machine in steady,\nproper, and regular motion. But amid these cares her anxiety about\nPierre was evident. She kept an anxious watch on him when he approached\nthe group round Mortemart to listen to what was being said there, and\nagain when he passed to another group whose center was the abb\xc3\xa9.\n\nPierre had been educated abroad, and this reception at Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s was the first he had attended in Russia. He knew that all\nthe intellectual lights of Petersburg were gathered there and, like a\nchild in a toyshop, did not know which way to look, afraid of missing\nany clever conversation that was to be heard. Seeing the self-confident\nand refined expression on the faces of those present he was always\nexpecting to hear something very profound. At last he came up to Morio.\nHere the conversation seemed interesting and he stood waiting for an\nopportunity to express his own views, as young people are fond of doing.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER III\n\nAnna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s reception was in full swing. The spindles hummed\nsteadily and ceaselessly on all sides. With the exception of the aunt,\nbeside whom sat only one elderly lady, who with her thin careworn face\nwas rather out of place in this brilliant society, the whole company had\nsettled into three groups. One, chiefly masculine, had formed round\nthe abb\xc3\xa9. Another, of young people, was grouped round the beautiful\nPrincess H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s daughter, and the little Princess\nBolk\xc3\xb3nskaya, very pretty and rosy, though rather too plump for her age.\nThe third group was gathered round Mortemart and Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna.\n\nThe vicomte was a nice-looking young man with soft features and polished\nmanners, who evidently considered himself a celebrity but out of\npoliteness modestly placed himself at the disposal of the circle in\nwhich he found himself. Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna was obviously serving him up as\na treat to her guests. As a clever ma\xc3\xaetre d\xe2\x80\x99h\xc3\xb4tel serves up as a\nspecially choice delicacy a piece of meat that no one who had seen it in\nthe kitchen would have cared to eat, so Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna served up to\nher guests, first the vicomte and then the abb\xc3\xa9, as peculiarly choice\nmorsels. The group about Mortemart immediately began discussing the\nmurder of the Duc d\xe2\x80\x99Enghien. The vicomte said that the Duc d\xe2\x80\x99Enghien\nhad perished by his own magnanimity, and that there were particular\nreasons for Buonaparte\xe2\x80\x99s hatred of him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes! Do tell us all about it, Vicomte,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna,\nwith a pleasant feeling that there was something \xc3\xa0 la Louis XV in the\nsound of that sentence: \xe2\x80\x9cContez nous \xc3\xa7ela, Vicomte.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe vicomte bowed and smiled courteously in token of his willingness to\ncomply. Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna arranged a group round him, inviting everyone to\nlisten to his tale.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe vicomte knew the duc personally,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna to\none of the guests. \xe2\x80\x9cThe vicomte is a wonderful raconteur,\xe2\x80\x9d said she\nto another. \xe2\x80\x9cHow evidently he belongs to the best society,\xe2\x80\x9d said she\nto a third; and the vicomte was served up to the company in the choicest\nand most advantageous style, like a well-garnished joint of roast beef\non a hot dish.\n\nThe vicomte wished to begin his story and gave a subtle smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome over here, H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna to the\nbeautiful young princess who was sitting some way off, the center of\nanother group.\n\nThe princess smiled. She rose with the same unchanging smile with which\nshe had first entered the room\xe2\x80\x94the smile of a perfectly beautiful\nwoman. With a slight rustle of her white dress trimmed with moss\nand ivy, with a gleam of white shoulders, glossy hair, and sparkling\ndiamonds, she passed between the men who made way for her, not looking\nat any of them but smiling on all, as if graciously allowing each the\nprivilege of admiring her beautiful figure and shapely shoulders,\nback, and bosom\xe2\x80\x94which in the fashion of those days were very much\nexposed\xe2\x80\x94and she seemed to bring the glamour of a ballroom with her as\nshe moved toward Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna. H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne was so lovely that not only\ndid she not show any trace of coquetry, but on the contrary she even\nappeared shy of her unquestionable and all too victorious beauty. She\nseemed to wish, but to be unable, to diminish its effect.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow lovely!\xe2\x80\x9d said everyone who saw her; and the vicomte lifted his\nshoulders and dropped his eyes as if startled by something extraordinary\nwhen she took her seat opposite and beamed upon him also with her\nunchanging smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame, I doubt my ability before such an audience,\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\nsmilingly inclining his head.\n\nThe princess rested her bare round arm on a little table and considered\na reply unnecessary. She smilingly waited. All the time the story was\nbeing told she sat upright, glancing now at her beautiful round arm,\naltered in shape by its pressure on the table, now at her still more\nbeautiful bosom, on which she readjusted a diamond necklace. From time\nto time she smoothed the folds of her dress, and whenever the story\nproduced an effect she glanced at Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna, at once adopted just\nthe expression she saw on the maid of honor\xe2\x80\x99s face, and again relapsed\ninto her radiant smile.\n\nThe little princess had also left the tea table and followed H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a moment, I\xe2\x80\x99ll get my work.... Now then, what are you\nthinking of?\xe2\x80\x9d she went on, turning to Prince Hippolyte. \xe2\x80\x9cFetch me my\nworkbag.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThere was a general movement as the princess, smiling and talking\nmerrily to everyone at once, sat down and gaily arranged herself in her\nseat.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow I am all right,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, and asking the vicomte to begin, she\ntook up her work.\n\nPrince Hippolyte, having brought the workbag, joined the circle and\nmoving a chair close to hers seated himself beside her.\n\nLe charmant Hippolyte was surprising by his extraordinary resemblance\nto his beautiful sister, but yet more by the fact that in spite of\nthis resemblance he was exceedingly ugly. His features were like his\nsister\xe2\x80\x99s, but while in her case everything was lit up by a joyous,\nself-satisfied, youthful, and constant smile of animation, and by the\nwonderful classic beauty of her figure, his face on the contrary\nwas dulled by imbecility and a constant expression of sullen\nself-confidence, while his body was thin and weak. His eyes, nose, and\nmouth all seemed puckered into a vacant, wearied grimace, and his arms\nand legs always fell into unnatural positions.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not going to be a ghost story?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, sitting down beside\nthe princess and hastily adjusting his lorgnette, as if without this\ninstrument he could not begin to speak.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy no, my dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the astonished narrator, shrugging\nhis shoulders.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I hate ghost stories,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Hippolyte in a tone\nwhich showed that he only understood the meaning of his words after he\nhad uttered them.\n\nHe spoke with such self-confidence that his hearers could not be sure\nwhether what he said was very witty or very stupid. He was dressed in\na dark-green dress coat, knee breeches of the color of cuisse de nymphe\neffray\xc3\xa9e, as he called it, shoes, and silk stockings.\n\nThe vicomte told his tale very neatly. It was an anecdote, then current,\nto the effect that the Duc d\xe2\x80\x99Enghien had gone secretly to Paris to\nvisit Mademoiselle George; that at her house he came upon Bonaparte,\nwho also enjoyed the famous actress\xe2\x80\x99 favors, and that in his presence\nNapoleon happened to fall into one of the fainting fits to which he was\nsubject, and was thus at the duc\xe2\x80\x99s mercy. The latter spared him, and\nthis magnanimity Bonaparte subsequently repaid by death.\n\nThe story was very pretty and interesting, especially at the point\nwhere the rivals suddenly recognized one another; and the ladies looked\nagitated.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCharming!\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna with an inquiring glance at the\nlittle princess.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCharming!\xe2\x80\x9d whispered the little princess, sticking the needle into\nher work as if to testify that the interest and fascination of the story\nprevented her from going on with it.\n\nThe vicomte appreciated this silent praise and smiling gratefully\nprepared to continue, but just then Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna, who had kept a\nwatchful eye on the young man who so alarmed her, noticed that he was\ntalking too loudly and vehemently with the abb\xc3\xa9, so she hurried to the\nrescue. Pierre had managed to start a conversation with the abb\xc3\xa9 about\nthe balance of power, and the latter, evidently interested by the young\nman\xe2\x80\x99s simple-minded eagerness, was explaining his pet theory. Both\nwere talking and listening too eagerly and too naturally, which was why\nAnna P\xc3\xa1vlovna disapproved.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe means are ... the balance of power in Europe and the rights of\nthe people,\xe2\x80\x9d the abb\xc3\xa9 was saying. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is only necessary for one\npowerful nation like Russia\xe2\x80\x94barbaric as she is said to be\xe2\x80\x94to place\nherself disinterestedly at the head of an alliance having for its object\nthe maintenance of the balance of power of Europe, and it would save the\nworld!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how are you to get that balance?\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre was beginning.\n\nAt that moment Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna came up and, looking severely at Pierre,\nasked the Italian how he stood Russian climate. The Italian\xe2\x80\x99s\nface instantly changed and assumed an offensively affected, sugary\nexpression, evidently habitual to him when conversing with women.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am so enchanted by the brilliancy of the wit and culture of the\nsociety, more especially of the feminine society, in which I have had\nthe honor of being received, that I have not yet had time to think of\nthe climate,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\nNot letting the abb\xc3\xa9 and Pierre escape, Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna, the more\nconveniently to keep them under observation, brought them into the\nlarger circle.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IV\n\nJust then another visitor entered the drawing room: Prince Andrew\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski, the little princess\xe2\x80\x99 husband. He was a very handsome young\nman, of medium height, with firm, clearcut features. Everything about\nhim, from his weary, bored expression to his quiet, measured step,\noffered a most striking contrast to his quiet, little wife. It was\nevident that he not only knew everyone in the drawing room, but had\nfound them to be so tiresome that it wearied him to look at or listen to\nthem. And among all these faces that he found so tedious, none seemed\nto bore him so much as that of his pretty wife. He turned away from\nher with a grimace that distorted his handsome face, kissed Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and screwing up his eyes scanned the whole company.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are off to the war, Prince?\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeneral Kut\xc3\xbazov,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bolk\xc3\xb3nski, speaking French and stressing\nthe last syllable of the general\xe2\x80\x99s name like a Frenchman, \xe2\x80\x9chas been\npleased to take me as an aide-de-camp....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Lise, your wife?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe will go to the country.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you not ashamed to deprive us of your charming wife?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAndr\xc3\xa9,\xe2\x80\x9d said his wife, addressing her husband in the same\ncoquettish manner in which she spoke to other men, \xe2\x80\x9cthe vicomte has\nbeen telling us such a tale about Mademoiselle George and Buonaparte!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew screwed up his eyes and turned away. Pierre, who from\nthe moment Prince Andrew entered the room had watched him with glad,\naffectionate eyes, now came up and took his arm. Before he looked round\nPrince Andrew frowned again, expressing his annoyance with whoever was\ntouching his arm, but when he saw Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s beaming face he gave him an\nunexpectedly kind and pleasant smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere now!... So you, too, are in the great world?\xe2\x80\x9d said he to\nPierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew you would be here,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pierre. \xe2\x80\x9cI will come to supper\nwith you. May I?\xe2\x80\x9d he added in a low voice so as not to disturb the\nvicomte who was continuing his story.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew, laughing and pressing\nPierre\xe2\x80\x99s hand to show that there was no need to ask the question. He\nwished to say something more, but at that moment Prince Vas\xc3\xadli and his\ndaughter got up to go and the two young men rose to let them pass.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must excuse me, dear Vicomte,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Vas\xc3\xadli to the\nFrenchman, holding him down by the sleeve in a friendly way to prevent\nhis rising. \xe2\x80\x9cThis unfortunate fete at the ambassador\xe2\x80\x99s deprives me\nof a pleasure, and obliges me to interrupt you. I am very sorry to leave\nyour enchanting party,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, turning to Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna.\n\nHis daughter, Princess H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, passed between the chairs, lightly\nholding up the folds of her dress, and the smile shone still more\nradiantly on her beautiful face. Pierre gazed at her with rapturous,\nalmost frightened, eyes as she passed him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery lovely,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre.\n\nIn passing Prince Vas\xc3\xadli seized Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s hand and said to Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna: \xe2\x80\x9cEducate this bear for me! He has been staying with me\na whole month and this is the first time I have seen him in society.\nNothing is so necessary for a young man as the society of clever\nwomen.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nAnna P\xc3\xa1vlovna smiled and promised to take Pierre in hand. She knew his\nfather to be a connection of Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s. The elderly lady who\nhad been sitting with the old aunt rose hurriedly and overtook Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli in the anteroom. All the affectation of interest she had assumed\nhad left her kindly and tear-worn face and it now expressed only anxiety\nand fear.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow about my son Bor\xc3\xads, Prince?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, hurrying after him into\nthe anteroom. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t remain any longer in Petersburg. Tell me what\nnews I may take back to my poor boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAlthough Prince Vas\xc3\xadli listened reluctantly and not very politely\nto the elderly lady, even betraying some impatience, she gave him an\ningratiating and appealing smile, and took his hand that he might not go\naway.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would it cost you to say a word to the Emperor, and then he\nwould be transferred to the Guards at once?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBelieve me, Princess, I am ready to do all I can,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it is difficult for me to ask the Emperor. I should\nadvise you to appeal to Rumy\xc3\xa1ntsev through Prince Gol\xc3\xadtsyn. That would\nbe the best way.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe elderly lady was a Princess Drubetsk\xc3\xa1ya, belonging to one of the\nbest families in Russia, but she was poor, and having long been out of\nsociety had lost her former influential connections. She had now come to\nPetersburg to procure an appointment in the Guards for her only son.\nIt was, in fact, solely to meet Prince Vas\xc3\xadli that she had obtained an\ninvitation to Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s reception and had sat listening to\nthe vicomte\xe2\x80\x99s story. Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s words frightened her, an\nembittered look clouded her once handsome face, but only for a moment;\nthen she smiled again and clutched Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s arm more tightly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen to me, Prince,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cI have never yet asked you\nfor anything and I never will again, nor have I ever reminded you of my\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s friendship for you; but now I entreat you for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake to\ndo this for my son\xe2\x80\x94and I shall always regard you as a benefactor,\xe2\x80\x9d\nshe added hurriedly. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, don\xe2\x80\x99t be angry, but promise! I have asked\nGol\xc3\xadtsyn and he has refused. Be the kindhearted man you always were,\xe2\x80\x9d\nshe said, trying to smile though tears were in her eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa, we shall be late,\xe2\x80\x9d said Princess H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, turning her\nbeautiful head and looking over her classically molded shoulder as she\nstood waiting by the door.\n\nInfluence in society, however, is a capital which has to be economized\nif it is to last. Prince Vas\xc3\xadli knew this, and having once realized\nthat if he asked on behalf of all who begged of him, he would soon be\nunable to ask for himself, he became chary of using his influence. But\nin Princess Drubetsk\xc3\xa1ya\xe2\x80\x99s case he felt, after her second appeal,\nsomething like qualms of conscience. She had reminded him of what was\nquite true; he had been indebted to her father for the first steps in\nhis career. Moreover, he could see by her manners that she was one of\nthose women\xe2\x80\x94mostly mothers\xe2\x80\x94who, having once made up their minds,\nwill not rest until they have gained their end, and are prepared if\nnecessary to go on insisting day after day and hour after hour, and even\nto make scenes. This last consideration moved him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna,\xe2\x80\x9d said he with his usual familiarity and\nweariness of tone, \xe2\x80\x9cit is almost impossible for me to do what you\nask; but to prove my devotion to you and how I respect your father\xe2\x80\x99s\nmemory, I will do the impossible\xe2\x80\x94your son shall be transferred to the\nGuards. Here is my hand on it. Are you satisfied?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear benefactor! This is what I expected from you\xe2\x80\x94I knew your\nkindness!\xe2\x80\x9d He turned to go.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait\xe2\x80\x94just a word! When he has been transferred to the Guards...\xe2\x80\x9d\nshe faltered. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are on good terms with Michael Ilari\xc3\xb3novich\nKut\xc3\xbazov ... recommend Bor\xc3\xads to him as adjutant! Then I shall be at\nrest, and then...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli smiled.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I won\xe2\x80\x99t promise that. You don\xe2\x80\x99t know how Kut\xc3\xbazov is pestered\nsince his appointment as Commander in Chief. He told me himself that\nall the Moscow ladies have conspired to give him all their sons as\nadjutants.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but do promise! I won\xe2\x80\x99t let you go! My dear benefactor...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa,\xe2\x80\x9d said his beautiful daughter in the same tone as before,\n\xe2\x80\x9cwe shall be late.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, au revoir! Good-by! You hear her?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen tomorrow you will speak to the Emperor?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; but about Kut\xc3\xbazov, I don\xe2\x80\x99t promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo promise, do promise, Vas\xc3\xadli!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna as he\nwent, with the smile of a coquettish girl, which at one time probably\ncame naturally to her, but was now very ill-suited to her careworn face.\n\nApparently she had forgotten her age and by force of habit employed\nall the old feminine arts. But as soon as the prince had gone her face\nresumed its former cold, artificial expression. She returned to the\ngroup where the vicomte was still talking, and again pretended to\nlisten, while waiting till it would be time to leave. Her task was\naccomplished.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER V\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what do you think of this latest comedy, the coronation at\nMilan?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna, \xe2\x80\x9cand of the comedy of the people of\nGenoa and Lucca laying their petitions before Monsieur Buonaparte, and\nMonsieur Buonaparte sitting on a throne and granting the petitions of\nthe nations? Adorable! It is enough to make one\xe2\x80\x99s head whirl! It is as\nif the whole world had gone crazy.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew looked Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna straight in the face with a\nsarcastic smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Dieu me la donne, gare \xc3\xa0 qui la touche!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x99 * They say he was\nvery fine when he said that,\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked, repeating the words in\nItalian: \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Dio mi l\xe2\x80\x99ha dato. Guai a chi la tocchi!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x99\n\n     * God has given it to me, let him who touches it beware!\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope this will prove the last drop that will make the glass run\nover,\xe2\x80\x9d Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna continued. \xe2\x80\x9cThe sovereigns will not be able to\nendure this man who is a menace to everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe sovereigns? I do not speak of Russia,\xe2\x80\x9d said the vicomte, polite\nbut hopeless: \xe2\x80\x9cThe sovereigns, madame... What have they done for Louis\nXVII, for the Queen, or for Madame Elizabeth? Nothing!\xe2\x80\x9d and he became\nmore animated. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd believe me, they are reaping the reward of their\nbetrayal of the Bourbon cause. The sovereigns! Why, they are sending\nambassadors to compliment the usurper.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd sighing disdainfully, he again changed his position.\n\nPrince Hippolyte, who had been gazing at the vicomte for some time\nthrough his lorgnette, suddenly turned completely round toward the\nlittle princess, and having asked for a needle began tracing the Cond\xc3\xa9\ncoat of arms on the table. He explained this to her with as much gravity\nas if she had asked him to do it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cB\xc3\xa2ton de gueules, engr\xc3\xaal\xc3\xa9 de gueules d\xe2\x80\x99azur\xe2\x80\x94maison Cond\xc3\xa9,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid he.\n\nThe princess listened, smiling.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Buonaparte remains on the throne of France a year longer,\xe2\x80\x9d the\nvicomte continued, with the air of a man who, in a matter with which\nhe is better acquainted than anyone else, does not listen to others but\nfollows the current of his own thoughts, \xe2\x80\x9cthings will have gone too\nfar. By intrigues, violence, exile, and executions, French society\xe2\x80\x94I\nmean good French society\xe2\x80\x94will have been forever destroyed, and\nthen....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe shrugged his shoulders and spread out his hands. Pierre wished to\nmake a remark, for the conversation interested him, but Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna,\nwho had him under observation, interrupted:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Emperor Alexander,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, with the melancholy which\nalways accompanied any reference of hers to the Imperial family, \xe2\x80\x9chas\ndeclared that he will leave it to the French people themselves to choose\ntheir own form of government; and I believe that once free from the\nusurper, the whole nation will certainly throw itself into the arms\nof its rightful king,\xe2\x80\x9d she concluded, trying to be amiable to the\nroyalist emigrant.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is doubtful,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur le Vicomte quite\nrightly supposes that matters have already gone too far. I think it will\nbe difficult to return to the old regime.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom what I have heard,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, blushing and breaking into\nthe conversation, \xe2\x80\x9calmost all the aristocracy has already gone over to\nBonaparte\xe2\x80\x99s side.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the Buonapartists who say that,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the vicomte without\nlooking at Pierre. \xe2\x80\x9cAt the present time it is difficult to know the\nreal state of French public opinion.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBonaparte has said so,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Prince Andrew with a sarcastic\nsmile.\n\nIt was evident that he did not like the vicomte and was aiming his\nremarks at him, though without looking at him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I showed them the path to glory, but they did not follow\nit,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Prince Andrew continued after a short silence, again quoting\nNapoleon\xe2\x80\x99s words. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I opened my antechambers and they crowded\nin.\xe2\x80\x99 I do not know how far he was justified in saying so.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot in the least,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the vicomte. \xe2\x80\x9cAfter the murder of the\nduc even the most partial ceased to regard him as a hero. If to some\npeople,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, turning to Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna, \xe2\x80\x9che ever was a hero,\nafter the murder of the duc there was one martyr more in heaven and one\nhero less on earth.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBefore Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna and the others had time to smile their\nappreciation of the vicomte\xe2\x80\x99s epigram, Pierre again broke into the\nconversation, and though Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna felt sure he would say something\ninappropriate, she was unable to stop him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe execution of the Duc d\xe2\x80\x99Enghien,\xe2\x80\x9d declared Monsieur Pierre,\n\xe2\x80\x9cwas a political necessity, and it seems to me that Napoleon\nshowed greatness of soul by not fearing to take on himself the whole\nresponsibility of that deed.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDieu! Mon Dieu!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna in a terrified whisper.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, Monsieur Pierre... Do you consider that assassination shows\ngreatness of soul?\xe2\x80\x9d said the little princess, smiling and drawing her\nwork nearer to her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! Oh!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed several voices.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCapital!\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Hippolyte in English, and began slapping his\nknee with the palm of his hand.\n\nThe vicomte merely shrugged his shoulders. Pierre looked solemnly at his\naudience over his spectacles and continued.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say so,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued desperately, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause the Bourbons fled\nfrom the Revolution leaving the people to anarchy, and Napoleon alone\nunderstood the Revolution and quelled it, and so for the general good,\nhe could not stop short for the sake of one man\xe2\x80\x99s life.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you come over to the other table?\xe2\x80\x9d suggested Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna.\n\nBut Pierre continued his speech without heeding her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, becoming more and more eager, \xe2\x80\x9cNapoleon is great\nbecause he rose superior to the Revolution, suppressed its abuses,\npreserved all that was good in it\xe2\x80\x94equality of citizenship and freedom\nof speech and of the press\xe2\x80\x94and only for that reason did he obtain\npower.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, if having obtained power, without availing himself of it to\ncommit murder he had restored it to the rightful king, I should have\ncalled him a great man,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the vicomte.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe could not do that. The people only gave him power that he might\nrid them of the Bourbons and because they saw that he was a great\nman. The Revolution was a grand thing!\xe2\x80\x9d continued Monsieur Pierre,\nbetraying by this desperate and provocative proposition his extreme\nyouth and his wish to express all that was in his mind.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? Revolution and regicide a grand thing?... Well, after that...\nBut won\xe2\x80\x99t you come to this other table?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cRousseau\xe2\x80\x99s Contrat Social,\xe2\x80\x9d said the vicomte with a tolerant\nsmile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not speaking of regicide, I am speaking about ideas.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes: ideas of robbery, murder, and regicide,\xe2\x80\x9d again interjected an\nironical voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose were extremes, no doubt, but they are not what is most\nimportant. What is important are the rights of man, emancipation from\nprejudices, and equality of citizenship, and all these ideas Napoleon\nhas retained in full force.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLiberty and equality,\xe2\x80\x9d said the vicomte contemptuously, as if at\nlast deciding seriously to prove to this youth how foolish his words\nwere, \xe2\x80\x9chigh-sounding words which have long been discredited. Who does\nnot love liberty and equality? Even our Saviour preached liberty and\nequality. Have people since the Revolution become happier? On the\ncontrary. We wanted liberty, but Buonaparte has destroyed it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew kept looking with an amused smile from Pierre to the\nvicomte and from the vicomte to their hostess. In the first moment of\nPierre\xe2\x80\x99s outburst Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna, despite her social experience, was\nhorror-struck. But when she saw that Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s sacrilegious words\nhad not exasperated the vicomte, and had convinced herself that it was\nimpossible to stop him, she rallied her forces and joined the vicomte in\na vigorous attack on the orator.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, my dear Monsieur Pierre,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9chow do you explain the\nfact of a great man executing a duc\xe2\x80\x94or even an ordinary man who\xe2\x80\x94is\ninnocent and untried?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like,\xe2\x80\x9d said the vicomte, \xe2\x80\x9cto ask how monsieur explains\nthe 18th Brumaire; was not that an imposture? It was a swindle, and not\nat all like the conduct of a great man!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the prisoners he killed in Africa? That was horrible!\xe2\x80\x9d said the\nlittle princess, shrugging her shoulders.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s a low fellow, say what you will,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Prince Hippolyte.\n\nPierre, not knowing whom to answer, looked at them all and smiled. His\nsmile was unlike the half-smile of other people. When he smiled,\nhis grave, even rather gloomy, look was instantaneously replaced by\nanother\xe2\x80\x94a childlike, kindly, even rather silly look, which seemed to\nask forgiveness.\n\nThe vicomte who was meeting him for the first time saw clearly that\nthis young Jacobin was not so terrible as his words suggested. All were\nsilent.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you expect him to answer you all at once?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince\nAndrew. \xe2\x80\x9cBesides, in the actions of a statesman one has to distinguish\nbetween his acts as a private person, as a general, and as an emperor.\nSo it seems to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, of course!\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre chimed in, pleased at the arrival of\nthis reinforcement.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne must admit,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Prince Andrew, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Napoleon as a man\nwas great on the bridge of Arcola, and in the hospital at Jaffa where he\ngave his hand to the plague-stricken; but ... but there are other acts\nwhich it is difficult to justify.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew, who had evidently wished to tone down the awkwardness of\nPierre\xe2\x80\x99s remarks, rose and made a sign to his wife that it was time to\ngo.\n\nSuddenly Prince Hippolyte started up making signs to everyone to attend,\nand asking them all to be seated began:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was told a charming Moscow story today and must treat you to it.\nExcuse me, Vicomte\xe2\x80\x94I must tell it in Russian or the point will be\nlost....\xe2\x80\x9d And Prince Hippolyte began to tell his story in such Russian\nas a Frenchman would speak after spending about a year in Russia.\nEveryone waited, so emphatically and eagerly did he demand their\nattention to his story.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is in Moscow a lady, une dame, and she is very stingy. She must\nhave two footmen behind her carriage, and very big ones. That was her\ntaste. And she had a lady\xe2\x80\x99s maid, also big. She said....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHere Prince Hippolyte paused, evidently collecting his ideas with\ndifficulty.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe said.... Oh yes! She said, \xe2\x80\x98Girl,\xe2\x80\x99 to the maid, \xe2\x80\x98put on a\nlivery, get up behind the carriage, and come with me while I make some\ncalls.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHere Prince Hippolyte spluttered and burst out laughing long before his\naudience, which produced an effect unfavorable to the narrator. Several\npersons, among them the elderly lady and Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna, did however\nsmile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe went. Suddenly there was a great wind. The girl lost her hat and\nher long hair came down....\xe2\x80\x9d Here he could contain himself no\nlonger and went on, between gasps of laughter: \xe2\x80\x9cAnd the whole world\nknew....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd so the anecdote ended. Though it was unintelligible why he had told\nit, or why it had to be told in Russian, still Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna and the\nothers appreciated Prince Hippolyte\xe2\x80\x99s social tact in so agreeably\nending Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s unpleasant and unamiable outburst. After the anecdote\nthe conversation broke up into insignificant small talk about the last\nand next balls, about theatricals, and who would meet whom, and when and\nwhere.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VI\n\nHaving thanked Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna for her charming soiree, the guests began\nto take their leave.\n\nPierre was ungainly. Stout, about the average height, broad, with huge\nred hands; he did not know, as the saying is, how to enter a drawing\nroom and still less how to leave one; that is, how to say something\nparticularly agreeable before going away. Besides this he was\nabsent-minded. When he rose to go, he took up instead of his own, the\ngeneral\xe2\x80\x99s three-cornered hat, and held it, pulling at the plume,\ntill the general asked him to restore it. All his absent-mindedness and\ninability to enter a room and converse in it was, however, redeemed by\nhis kindly, simple, and modest expression. Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna turned toward\nhim and, with a Christian mildness that expressed forgiveness of his\nindiscretion, nodded and said: \xe2\x80\x9cI hope to see you again, but I also\nhope you will change your opinions, my dear Monsieur Pierre.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nWhen she said this, he did not reply and only bowed, but again everybody\nsaw his smile, which said nothing, unless perhaps, \xe2\x80\x9cOpinions are\nopinions, but you see what a capital, good-natured fellow I am.\xe2\x80\x9d And\neveryone, including Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna, felt this.\n\nPrince Andrew had gone out into the hall, and, turning his shoulders\nto the footman who was helping him on with his cloak, listened\nindifferently to his wife\xe2\x80\x99s chatter with Prince Hippolyte who had also\ncome into the hall. Prince Hippolyte stood close to the pretty, pregnant\nprincess, and stared fixedly at her through his eyeglass.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo in, Annette, or you will catch cold,\xe2\x80\x9d said the little princess,\ntaking leave of Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is settled,\xe2\x80\x9d she added in a low\nvoice.\n\nAnna P\xc3\xa1vlovna had already managed to speak to Lise about the match she\ncontemplated between Anatole and the little princess\xe2\x80\x99 sister-in-law.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI rely on you, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna, also in a low tone.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWrite to her and let me know how her father looks at the matter. Au\nrevoir! \xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and she left the hall.\n\nPrince Hippolyte approached the little princess and, bending his face\nclose to her, began to whisper something.\n\nTwo footmen, the princess\xe2\x80\x99 and his own, stood holding a shawl and\na cloak, waiting for the conversation to finish. They listened to\nthe French sentences which to them were meaningless, with an air of\nunderstanding but not wishing to appear to do so. The princess as usual\nspoke smilingly and listened with a laugh.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very glad I did not go to the ambassador\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince\nHippolyte \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x94so dull\xe2\x80\x94. It has been a delightful evening, has it\nnot? Delightful!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey say the ball will be very good,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the princess, drawing\nup her downy little lip. \xe2\x80\x9cAll the pretty women in society will be\nthere.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot all, for you will not be there; not all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Hippolyte\nsmiling joyfully; and snatching the shawl from the footman, whom he\neven pushed aside, he began wrapping it round the princess. Either from\nawkwardness or intentionally (no one could have said which) after the\nshawl had been adjusted he kept his arm around her for a long time, as\nthough embracing her.\n\nStill smiling, she gracefully moved away, turning and glancing at her\nhusband. Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s eyes were closed, so weary and sleepy did he\nseem.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you ready?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked his wife, looking past her.\n\nPrince Hippolyte hurriedly put on his cloak, which in the latest fashion\nreached to his very heels, and, stumbling in it, ran out into the porch\nfollowing the princess, whom a footman was helping into the carriage.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrincesse, au revoir,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, stumbling with his tongue as well\nas with his feet.\n\nThe princess, picking up her dress, was taking her seat in the dark\ncarriage, her husband was adjusting his saber; Prince Hippolyte, under\npretense of helping, was in everyone\xe2\x80\x99s way.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllow me, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew in Russian in a cold,\ndisagreeable tone to Prince Hippolyte who was blocking his path.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am expecting you, Pierre,\xe2\x80\x9d said the same voice, but gently and\naffectionately.\n\nThe postilion started, the carriage wheels rattled. Prince Hippolyte\nlaughed spasmodically as he stood in the porch waiting for the vicomte\nwhom he had promised to take home.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, mon cher,\xe2\x80\x9d said the vicomte, having seated himself beside\nHippolyte in the carriage, \xe2\x80\x9cyour little princess is very nice, very\nnice indeed, quite French,\xe2\x80\x9d and he kissed the tips of his fingers.\nHippolyte burst out laughing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, you are a terrible chap for all your innocent airs,\xe2\x80\x9d\ncontinued the vicomte. \xe2\x80\x9cI pity the poor husband, that little officer\nwho gives himself the airs of a monarch.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHippolyte spluttered again, and amid his laughter said, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd you were\nsaying that the Russian ladies are not equal to the French? One has to\nknow how to deal with them.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre reaching the house first went into Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s study like\none quite at home, and from habit immediately lay down on the sofa, took\nfrom the shelf the first book that came to his hand (it was Caesar\xe2\x80\x99s\nCommentaries), and resting on his elbow, began reading it in the middle.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you done to Mlle Sch\xc3\xa9rer? She will be quite ill now,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid Prince Andrew, as he entered the study, rubbing his small white\nhands.\n\nPierre turned his whole body, making the sofa creak. He lifted his eager\nface to Prince Andrew, smiled, and waved his hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat abb\xc3\xa9 is very interesting but he does not see the thing in the\nright light.... In my opinion perpetual peace is possible but\xe2\x80\x94I do not\nknow how to express it ... not by a balance of political power....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIt was evident that Prince Andrew was not interested in such abstract\nconversation.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne can\xe2\x80\x99t everywhere say all one thinks, mon cher. Well, have\nyou at last decided on anything? Are you going to be a guardsman or a\ndiplomatist?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Prince Andrew after a momentary silence.\n\nPierre sat up on the sofa, with his legs tucked under him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, I don\xe2\x80\x99t yet know. I don\xe2\x80\x99t like either the one or the\nother.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you must decide on something! Your father expects it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre at the age of ten had been sent abroad with an abb\xc3\xa9 as tutor,\nand had remained away till he was twenty. When he returned to Moscow\nhis father dismissed the abb\xc3\xa9 and said to the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cNow go\nto Petersburg, look round, and choose your profession. I will agree to\nanything. Here is a letter to Prince Vas\xc3\xadli, and here is money. Write\nto me all about it, and I will help you in everything.\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre had\nalready been choosing a career for three months, and had not decided\non anything. It was about this choice that Prince Andrew was speaking.\nPierre rubbed his forehead.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he must be a Freemason,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, referring to the abb\xc3\xa9 whom\nhe had met that evening.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is all nonsense.\xe2\x80\x9d Prince Andrew again interrupted him, \xe2\x80\x9clet\nus talk business. Have you been to the Horse Guards?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I have not; but this is what I have been thinking and wanted\nto tell you. There is a war now against Napoleon. If it were a war for\nfreedom I could understand it and should be the first to enter the army;\nbut to help England and Austria against the greatest man in the world is\nnot right.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew only shrugged his shoulders at Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s childish words.\nHe put on the air of one who finds it impossible to reply to such\nnonsense, but it would in fact have been difficult to give any other\nanswer than the one Prince Andrew gave to this na\xc3\xafve question.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf no one fought except on his own conviction, there would be no\nwars,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that would be splendid,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre.\n\nPrince Andrew smiled ironically.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery likely it would be splendid, but it will never come about....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, why are you going to the war?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat for? I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. I must. Besides that I am going....\xe2\x80\x9d He\npaused. \xe2\x80\x9cI am going because the life I am leading here does not suit\nme!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VII\n\nThe rustle of a woman\xe2\x80\x99s dress was heard in the next room. Prince\nAndrew shook himself as if waking up, and his face assumed the look it\nhad had in Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s drawing room. Pierre removed his feet from\nthe sofa. The princess came in. She had changed her gown for a house\ndress as fresh and elegant as the other. Prince Andrew rose and politely\nplaced a chair for her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is it,\xe2\x80\x9d she began, as usual in French, settling down briskly\nand fussily in the easy chair, \xe2\x80\x9chow is it Annette never got married?\nHow stupid you men all are not to have married her! Excuse me for saying\nso, but you have no sense about women. What an argumentative fellow you\nare, Monsieur Pierre!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I am still arguing with your husband. I can\xe2\x80\x99t understand why he\nwants to go to the war,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pierre, addressing the princess\nwith none of the embarrassment so commonly shown by young men in their\nintercourse with young women.\n\nThe princess started. Evidently Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s words touched her to the\nquick.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that is just what I tell him!\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t\nunderstand it; I don\xe2\x80\x99t in the least understand why men can\xe2\x80\x99t live\nwithout wars. How is it that we women don\xe2\x80\x99t want anything of the kind,\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t need it? Now you shall judge between us. I always tell him: Here\nhe is Uncle\xe2\x80\x99s aide-de-camp, a most brilliant position. He is so\nwell known, so much appreciated by everyone. The other day at the\nApr\xc3\xa1ksins\xe2\x80\x99 I heard a lady asking, \xe2\x80\x98Is that the famous Prince\nAndrew?\xe2\x80\x99 I did indeed.\xe2\x80\x9d She laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is so well received\neverywhere. He might easily become aide-de-camp to the Emperor. You know\nthe Emperor spoke to him most graciously. Annette and I were speaking of\nhow to arrange it. What do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre looked at his friend and, noticing that he did not like the\nconversation, gave no reply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen are you starting?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, don\xe2\x80\x99t speak of his going, don\xe2\x80\x99t! I won\xe2\x80\x99t hear it spoken\nof,\xe2\x80\x9d said the princess in the same petulantly playful tone in which\nshe had spoken to Hippolyte in the drawing room and which was so plainly\nill-suited to the family circle of which Pierre was almost a member.\n\xe2\x80\x9cToday when I remembered that all these delightful associations\nmust be broken off ... and then you know, Andr\xc3\xa9...\xe2\x80\x9d (she looked\nsignificantly at her husband) \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m afraid, I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid!\xe2\x80\x9d she\nwhispered, and a shudder ran down her back.\n\nHer husband looked at her as if surprised to notice that someone besides\nPierre and himself was in the room, and addressed her in a tone of\nfrigid politeness.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it you are afraid of, Lise? I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, what egotists men all are: all, all egotists! Just for a whim\nof his own, goodness only knows why, he leaves me and locks me up alone\nin the country.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith my father and sister, remember,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew gently.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlone all the same, without my friends.... And he expects me not to\nbe afraid.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHer tone was now querulous and her lip drawn up, giving her not a\njoyful, but an animal, squirrel-like expression. She paused as if she\nfelt it indecorous to speak of her pregnancy before Pierre, though the\ngist of the matter lay in that.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI still can\xe2\x80\x99t understand what you are afraid of,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince\nAndrew slowly, not taking his eyes off his wife.\n\nThe princess blushed, and raised her arms with a gesture of despair.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Andrew, I must say you have changed. Oh, how you have....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour doctor tells you to go to bed earlier,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew.\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou had better go.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe princess said nothing, but suddenly her short downy lip quivered.\nPrince Andrew rose, shrugged his shoulders, and walked about the room.\n\nPierre looked over his spectacles with na\xc3\xafve surprise, now at him and\nnow at her, moved as if about to rise too, but changed his mind.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should I mind Monsieur Pierre being here?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the little\nprincess suddenly, her pretty face all at once distorted by a tearful\ngrimace. \xe2\x80\x9cI have long wanted to ask you, Andrew, why you have changed\nso to me? What have I done to you? You are going to the war and have no\npity for me. Why is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLise!\xe2\x80\x9d was all Prince Andrew said. But that one word expressed\nan entreaty, a threat, and above all conviction that she would herself\nregret her words. But she went on hurriedly:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou treat me like an invalid or a child. I see it all! Did you behave\nlike that six months ago?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLise, I beg you to desist,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew still more\nemphatically.\n\nPierre, who had been growing more and more agitated as he listened to\nall this, rose and approached the princess. He seemed unable to bear the\nsight of tears and was ready to cry himself.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCalm yourself, Princess! It seems so to you because.... I assure you\nI myself have experienced ... and so ... because ... No, excuse me!\nAn outsider is out of place here.... No, don\xe2\x80\x99t distress yourself....\nGood-by!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew caught him by the hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, wait, Pierre! The princess is too kind to wish to deprive me of\nthe pleasure of spending the evening with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he thinks only of himself,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the princess without\nrestraining her angry tears.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLise!\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew dryly, raising his voice to the pitch\nwhich indicates that patience is exhausted.\n\nSuddenly the angry, squirrel-like expression of the princess\xe2\x80\x99 pretty\nface changed into a winning and piteous look of fear. Her beautiful eyes\nglanced askance at her husband\xe2\x80\x99s face, and her own assumed the timid,\ndeprecating expression of a dog when it rapidly but feebly wags its\ndrooping tail.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMon Dieu, mon Dieu!\xe2\x80\x9d she muttered, and lifting her dress with one\nhand she went up to her husband and kissed him on the forehead.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood night, Lise,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, rising and courteously kissing her hand\nas he would have done to a stranger.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VIII\n\nThe friends were silent. Neither cared to begin talking. Pierre\ncontinually glanced at Prince Andrew; Prince Andrew rubbed his forehead\nwith his small hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go and have supper,\xe2\x80\x9d he said with a sigh, going to the door.\n\nThey entered the elegant, newly decorated, and luxurious dining room.\nEverything from the table napkins to the silver, china, and glass bore\nthat imprint of newness found in the households of the newly married.\nHalfway through supper Prince Andrew leaned his elbows on the table and,\nwith a look of nervous agitation such as Pierre had never before seen on\nhis face, began to talk\xe2\x80\x94as one who has long had something on his mind\nand suddenly determines to speak out.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever, never marry, my dear fellow! That\xe2\x80\x99s my advice: never marry\ntill you can say to yourself that you have done all you are capable of,\nand until you have ceased to love the woman of your choice and have seen\nher plainly as she is, or else you will make a cruel and irrevocable\nmistake. Marry when you are old and good for nothing\xe2\x80\x94or all that is\ngood and noble in you will be lost. It will all be wasted on trifles.\nYes! Yes! Yes! Don\xe2\x80\x99t look at me with such surprise. If you marry\nexpecting anything from yourself in the future, you will feel at every\nstep that for you all is ended, all is closed except the drawing\nroom, where you will be ranged side by side with a court lackey and an\nidiot!... But what\xe2\x80\x99s the good?...\xe2\x80\x9d and he waved his arm.\n\nPierre took off his spectacles, which made his face seem different and\nthe good-natured expression still more apparent, and gazed at his friend\nin amazement.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy wife,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Prince Andrew, \xe2\x80\x9cis an excellent woman, one\nof those rare women with whom a man\xe2\x80\x99s honor is safe; but, O God, what\nwould I not give now to be unmarried! You are the first and only one to\nwhom I mention this, because I like you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAs he said this Prince Andrew was less than ever like that Bolk\xc3\xb3nski\nwho had lolled in Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s easy chairs and with half-closed\neyes had uttered French phrases between his teeth. Every muscle of his\nthin face was now quivering with nervous excitement; his eyes, in which\nthe fire of life had seemed extinguished, now flashed with brilliant\nlight. It was evident that the more lifeless he seemed at ordinary\ntimes, the more impassioned he became in these moments of almost morbid\nirritation.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t understand why I say this,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it is\nthe whole story of life. You talk of Bonaparte and his career,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nhe (though Pierre had not mentioned Bonaparte), \xe2\x80\x9cbut Bonaparte when\nhe worked went step by step toward his goal. He was free, he had nothing\nbut his aim to consider, and he reached it. But tie yourself up with\na woman and, like a chained convict, you lose all freedom! And all you\nhave of hope and strength merely weighs you down and torments you with\nregret. Drawing rooms, gossip, balls, vanity, and triviality\xe2\x80\x94these are\nthe enchanted circle I cannot escape from. I am now going to the war,\nthe greatest war there ever was, and I know nothing and am fit for\nnothing. I am very amiable and have a caustic wit,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Prince\nAndrew, \xe2\x80\x9cand at Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s they listen to me. And that stupid\nset without whom my wife cannot exist, and those women.... If you only\nknew what those society women are, and women in general! My father is\nright. Selfish, vain, stupid, trivial in everything\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s what\nwomen are when you see them in their true colors! When you meet them\nin society it seems as if there were something in them, but there\xe2\x80\x99s\nnothing, nothing, nothing! No, don\xe2\x80\x99t marry, my dear fellow; don\xe2\x80\x99t\nmarry!\xe2\x80\x9d concluded Prince Andrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems funny to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you, you should\nconsider yourself incapable and your life a spoiled life. You have\neverything before you, everything. And you....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe did not finish his sentence, but his tone showed how highly he\nthought of his friend and how much he expected of him in the future.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can he talk like that?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Pierre. He considered his\nfriend a model of perfection because Prince Andrew possessed in the\nhighest degree just the very qualities Pierre lacked, and which might\nbe best described as strength of will. Pierre was always astonished at\nPrince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s calm manner of treating everybody, his extraordinary\nmemory, his extensive reading (he had read everything, knew everything,\nand had an opinion about everything), but above all at his capacity for\nwork and study. And if Pierre was often struck by Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s lack\nof capacity for philosophical meditation (to which he himself was\nparticularly addicted), he regarded even this not as a defect but as a\nsign of strength.\n\nEven in the best, most friendly and simplest relations of life, praise\nand commendation are essential, just as grease is necessary to wheels\nthat they may run smoothly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy part is played out,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the use of\ntalking about me? Let us talk about you,\xe2\x80\x9d he added after a silence,\nsmiling at his reassuring thoughts.\n\nThat smile was immediately reflected on Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what is there to say about me?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, his face relaxing\ninto a careless, merry smile. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat am I? An illegitimate son!\xe2\x80\x9d\nHe suddenly blushed crimson, and it was plain that he had made a great\neffort to say this. \xe2\x80\x9cWithout a name and without means... And it\nreally...\xe2\x80\x9d But he did not say what \xe2\x80\x9cit really\xe2\x80\x9d was. \xe2\x80\x9cFor the\npresent I am free and am all right. Only I haven\xe2\x80\x99t the least idea what\nI am to do; I wanted to consult you seriously.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew looked kindly at him, yet his glance\xe2\x80\x94friendly and\naffectionate as it was\xe2\x80\x94expressed a sense of his own superiority.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am fond of you, especially as you are the one live man among our\nwhole set. Yes, you\xe2\x80\x99re all right! Choose what you will; it\xe2\x80\x99s all the\nsame. You\xe2\x80\x99ll be all right anywhere. But look here: give up visiting\nthose Kur\xc3\xa1gins and leading that sort of life. It suits you so\nbadly\xe2\x80\x94all this debauchery, dissipation, and the rest of it!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have, my dear fellow?\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pierre, shrugging\nhis shoulders. \xe2\x80\x9cWomen, my dear fellow; women!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t understand it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cWomen who are\ncomme il faut, that\xe2\x80\x99s a different matter; but the Kur\xc3\xa1gins\xe2\x80\x99 set of\nwomen, \xe2\x80\x98women and wine\xe2\x80\x99 I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre was staying at Prince Vas\xc3\xadli Kur\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x99s and sharing the\ndissipated life of his son Anatole, the son whom they were planning to\nreform by marrying him to Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s sister.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, as if suddenly struck by a happy\nthought, \xe2\x80\x9cseriously, I have long been thinking of it.... Leading such\na life I can\xe2\x80\x99t decide or think properly about anything. One\xe2\x80\x99s head\naches, and one spends all one\xe2\x80\x99s money. He asked me for tonight, but I\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t go.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou give me your word of honor not to go?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn my honor!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IX\n\nIt was past one o\xe2\x80\x99clock when Pierre left his friend. It was a\ncloudless, northern, summer night. Pierre took an open cab intending\nto drive straight home. But the nearer he drew to the house the more he\nfelt the impossibility of going to sleep on such a night. It was light\nenough to see a long way in the deserted street and it seemed more like\nmorning or evening than night. On the way Pierre remembered that Anatole\nKur\xc3\xa1gin was expecting the usual set for cards that evening, after which\nthere was generally a drinking bout, finishing with visits of a kind\nPierre was very fond of.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like to go to Kur\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d thought he.\n\nBut he immediately recalled his promise to Prince Andrew not to go\nthere. Then, as happens to people of weak character, he desired so\npassionately once more to enjoy that dissipation he was so accustomed to\nthat he decided to go.
