The thought immediately occurred to him that his\npromise to Prince Andrew was of no account, because before he gave it\nhe had already promised Prince Anatole to come to his gathering;\n\xe2\x80\x9cbesides,\xe2\x80\x9d thought he, \xe2\x80\x9call such \xe2\x80\x98words of honor\xe2\x80\x99 are\nconventional things with no definite meaning, especially if\none considers that by tomorrow one may be dead, or something so\nextraordinary may happen to one that honor and dishonor will be all the\nsame!\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre often indulged in reflections of this sort, nullifying\nall his decisions and intentions. He went to Kur\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x99s.\n\nReaching the large house near the Horse Guards\xe2\x80\x99 barracks, in which\nAnatole lived, Pierre entered the lighted porch, ascended the stairs,\nand went in at the open door. There was no one in the anteroom; empty\nbottles, cloaks, and overshoes were lying about; there was a smell of\nalcohol, and sounds of voices and shouting in the distance.\n\nCards and supper were over, but the visitors had not yet dispersed.\nPierre threw off his cloak and entered the first room, in which were the\nremains of supper. A footman, thinking no one saw him, was drinking on\nthe sly what was left in the glasses. From the third room came sounds of\nlaughter, the shouting of familiar voices, the growling of a bear, and\ngeneral commotion. Some eight or nine young men were crowding anxiously\nround an open window. Three others were romping with a young bear, one\npulling him by the chain and trying to set him at the others.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI bet a hundred on Stevens!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted one.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMind, no holding on!\xe2\x80\x9d cried another.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI bet on D\xc3\xb3lokhov!\xe2\x80\x9d cried a third. \xe2\x80\x9cKur\xc3\xa1gin, you part our\nhands.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, leave Bruin alone; here\xe2\x80\x99s a bet on.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt one draught, or he loses!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted a fourth.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cJacob, bring a bottle!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the host, a tall, handsome fellow\nwho stood in the midst of the group, without a coat, and with his fine\nlinen shirt unfastened in front. \xe2\x80\x9cWait a bit, you fellows.... Here is\nP\xc3\xa9tya! Good man!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, addressing Pierre.\n\nAnother voice, from a man of medium height with clear blue eyes,\nparticularly striking among all these drunken voices by its sober\nring, cried from the window: \xe2\x80\x9cCome here; part the bets!\xe2\x80\x9d This was\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov, an officer of the Sem\xc3\xabnov regiment, a notorious gambler and\nduelist, who was living with Anatole. Pierre smiled, looking about him\nmerrily.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t understand. What\xe2\x80\x99s it all about?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a bit, he is not drunk yet! A bottle here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole, and\ntaking a glass from the table he went up to Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFirst of all you must drink!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre drank one glass after another, looking from under his brows at\nthe tipsy guests who were again crowding round the window, and listening\nto their chatter. Anatole kept on refilling Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s glass while\nexplaining that D\xc3\xb3lokhov was betting with Stevens, an English naval\nofficer, that he would drink a bottle of rum sitting on the outer ledge\nof the third floor window with his legs hanging out.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, you must drink it all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole, giving Pierre the last\nglass, \xe2\x80\x9cor I won\xe2\x80\x99t let you go!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, pushing Anatole aside, and he went up\nto the window.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov was holding the Englishman\xe2\x80\x99s hand and clearly and distinctly\nrepeating the terms of the bet, addressing himself particularly to\nAnatole and Pierre.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov was of medium height, with curly hair and light-blue eyes. He\nwas about twenty-five. Like all infantry officers he wore no mustache,\nso that his mouth, the most striking feature of his face, was clearly\nseen. The lines of that mouth were remarkably finely curved. The middle\nof the upper lip formed a sharp wedge and closed firmly on the firm\nlower one, and something like two distinct smiles played continually\nround the two corners of the mouth; this, together with the resolute,\ninsolent intelligence of his eyes, produced an effect which made it\nimpossible not to notice his face. D\xc3\xb3lokhov was a man of small means\nand no connections. Yet, though Anatole spent tens of thousands of\nrubles, D\xc3\xb3lokhov lived with him and had placed himself on such a\nfooting that all who knew them, including Anatole himself, respected him\nmore than they did Anatole. D\xc3\xb3lokhov could play all games and nearly\nalways won. However much he drank, he never lost his clearheadedness.\nBoth Kur\xc3\xa1gin and D\xc3\xb3lokhov were at that time notorious among the rakes\nand scapegraces of Petersburg.\n\nThe bottle of rum was brought. The window frame which prevented anyone\nfrom sitting on the outer sill was being forced out by two footmen, who\nwere evidently flurried and intimidated by the directions and shouts of\nthe gentlemen around.\n\nAnatole with his swaggering air strode up to the window. He wanted to\nsmash something. Pushing away the footmen he tugged at the frame, but\ncould not move it. He smashed a pane.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a try, Hercules,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, turning to Pierre.\n\nPierre seized the crossbeam, tugged, and wrenched the oak frame out with\na crash.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake it right out, or they\xe2\x80\x99ll think I\xe2\x80\x99m holding on,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the Englishman bragging?... Eh? Is it all right?\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFirst-rate,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, looking at D\xc3\xb3lokhov, who with a bottle\nof rum in his hand was approaching the window, from which the light of\nthe sky, the dawn merging with the afterglow of sunset, was visible.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov, the bottle of rum still in his hand, jumped onto the window\nsill. \xe2\x80\x9cListen!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, standing there and addressing those in the\nroom. All were silent.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI bet fifty imperials\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he spoke French that the Englishman might\nunderstand him, but he did not speak it very well\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI bet fifty\nimperials ... or do you wish to make it a hundred?\xe2\x80\x9d added he,\naddressing the Englishman.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, fifty,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the latter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right. Fifty imperials ... that I will drink a whole bottle of\nrum without taking it from my mouth, sitting outside the window on this\nspot\xe2\x80\x9d (he stooped and pointed to the sloping ledge outside the window)\n\xe2\x80\x9cand without holding on to anything. Is that right?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman.\n\nAnatole turned to the Englishman and taking him by one of the buttons\nof his coat and looking down at him\xe2\x80\x94the Englishman was short\xe2\x80\x94began\nrepeating the terms of the wager to him in English.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xc3\xb3lokhov, hammering with the bottle on the window\nsill to attract attention. \xe2\x80\x9cWait a bit, Kur\xc3\xa1gin. Listen! If\nanyone else does the same, I will pay him a hundred imperials. Do you\nunderstand?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe Englishman nodded, but gave no indication whether he intended to\naccept this challenge or not. Anatole did not release him, and though\nhe kept nodding to show that he understood, Anatole went on translating\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s words into English. A thin young lad, an hussar of the\nLife Guards, who had been losing that evening, climbed on the window\nsill, leaned over, and looked down.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! Oh! Oh!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered, looking down from the window at the\nstones of the pavement.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShut up!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xc3\xb3lokhov, pushing him away from the window. The\nlad jumped awkwardly back into the room, tripping over his spurs.\n\nPlacing the bottle on the window sill where he could reach it easily,\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov climbed carefully and slowly through the window and lowered\nhis legs. Pressing against both sides of the window, he adjusted himself\non his seat, lowered his hands, moved a little to the right and then to\nthe left, and took up the bottle. Anatole brought two candles and\nplaced them on the window sill, though it was already quite light.\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s back in his white shirt, and his curly head, were lit\nup from both sides. Everyone crowded to the window, the Englishman in\nfront. Pierre stood smiling but silent. One man, older than the others\npresent, suddenly pushed forward with a scared and angry look and wanted\nto seize hold of D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s shirt.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, this is folly! He\xe2\x80\x99ll be killed,\xe2\x80\x9d said this more sensible\nman.\n\nAnatole stopped him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t touch him! You\xe2\x80\x99ll startle him and then he\xe2\x80\x99ll be killed.\nEh?... What then?... Eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov turned round and, again holding on with both hands, arranged\nhimself on his seat.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf anyone comes meddling again,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, emitting the words\nseparately through his thin compressed lips, \xe2\x80\x9cI will throw him down\nthere. Now then!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nSaying this he again turned round, dropped his hands, took the bottle\nand lifted it to his lips, threw back his head, and raised his free hand\nto balance himself. One of the footmen who had stooped to pick up some\nbroken glass remained in that position without taking his eyes from the\nwindow and from D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s back. Anatole stood erect with staring\neyes. The Englishman looked on sideways, pursing up his lips. The man\nwho had wished to stop the affair ran to a corner of the room and threw\nhimself on a sofa with his face to the wall. Pierre hid his face, from\nwhich a faint smile forgot to fade though his features now expressed\nhorror and fear. All were still. Pierre took his hands from his eyes.\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov still sat in the same position, only his head was thrown\nfurther back till his curly hair touched his shirt collar, and the hand\nholding the bottle was lifted higher and higher and trembled with the\neffort. The bottle was emptying perceptibly and rising still higher\nand his head tilting yet further back. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy is it so long?\xe2\x80\x9d thought\nPierre. It seemed to him that more than half an hour had elapsed.\nSuddenly D\xc3\xb3lokhov made a backward movement with his spine, and his arm\ntrembled nervously; this was sufficient to cause his whole body to slip\nas he sat on the sloping ledge. As he began slipping down, his head and\narm wavered still more with the strain. One hand moved as if to clutch\nthe window sill, but refrained from touching it. Pierre again covered\nhis eyes and thought he would never open them again. Suddenly he was\naware of a stir all around. He looked up: D\xc3\xb3lokhov was standing on the\nwindow sill, with a pale but radiant face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s empty.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe threw the bottle to the Englishman, who caught it neatly. D\xc3\xb3lokhov\njumped down. He smelt strongly of rum.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell done!... Fine fellow!... There\xe2\x80\x99s a bet for you!... Devil take\nyou!\xe2\x80\x9d came from different sides.\n\nThe Englishman took out his purse and began counting out the money.\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov stood frowning and did not speak. Pierre jumped upon the\nwindow sill.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, who wishes to bet with me? I\xe2\x80\x99ll do the same thing!\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe suddenly cried. \xe2\x80\x9cEven without a bet, there! Tell them to bring me a\nbottle. I\xe2\x80\x99ll do it.... Bring a bottle!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him do it, let him do it,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov, smiling.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat next? Have you gone mad?... No one would let you!... Why, you go\ngiddy even on a staircase,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed several voices.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll drink it! Let\xe2\x80\x99s have a bottle of rum!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Pierre,\nbanging the table with a determined and drunken gesture and preparing to\nclimb out of the window.\n\nThey seized him by his arms; but he was so strong that everyone who\ntouched him was sent flying.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you\xe2\x80\x99ll never manage him that way,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole. \xe2\x80\x9cWait a\nbit and I\xe2\x80\x99ll get round him.... Listen! I\xe2\x80\x99ll take your bet tomorrow,\nbut now we are all going to \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome on then,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Pierre. \xe2\x80\x9cCome on!... And we\xe2\x80\x99ll take Bruin\nwith us.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd he caught the bear, took it in his arms, lifted it from the ground,\nand began dancing round the room with it.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER X\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli kept the promise he had given to Princess Drubetsk\xc3\xa1ya\nwho had spoken to him on behalf of her only son Bor\xc3\xads on the evening of\nAnna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s soiree. The matter was mentioned to the Emperor, an\nexception made, and Bor\xc3\xads transferred into the regiment of Sem\xc3\xabnov\nGuards with the rank of cornet. He received, however, no appointment\nto Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s staff despite all Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna\xe2\x80\x99s endeavors and\nentreaties. Soon after Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s reception Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna\nreturned to Moscow and went straight to her rich relations, the\nRost\xc3\xb3vs, with whom she stayed when in the town and where her darling\nB\xc3\xb3ry, who had only just entered a regiment of the line and was being\nat once transferred to the Guards as a cornet, had been educated from\nchildhood and lived for years at a time. The Guards had already left\nPetersburg on the tenth of August, and her son, who had remained in\nMoscow for his equipment, was to join them on the march to Radziv\xc3\xadlov.\n\nIt was St. Natalia\xe2\x80\x99s day and the name day of two of the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x94the\nmother and the youngest daughter\xe2\x80\x94both named Nataly. Ever since\nthe morning, carriages with six horses had been coming and going\ncontinually, bringing visitors to the Countess Rost\xc3\xb3va\xe2\x80\x99s big house on\nthe Povarsk\xc3\xa1ya, so well known to all Moscow. The countess herself and\nher handsome eldest daughter were in the drawing room with the visitors\nwho came to congratulate, and who constantly succeeded one another in\nrelays.\n\nThe countess was a woman of about forty-five, with a thin Oriental type\nof face, evidently worn out with childbearing\xe2\x80\x94she had had twelve.\nA languor of motion and speech, resulting from weakness, gave her a\ndistinguished air which inspired respect. Princess Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna\nDrubetsk\xc3\xa1ya, who as a member of the household was also seated in the\ndrawing room, helped to receive and entertain the visitors. The young\npeople were in one of the inner rooms, not considering it necessary to\ntake part in receiving the visitors. The count met the guests and saw\nthem off, inviting them all to dinner.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very, very grateful to you, mon cher,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cma ch\xc3\xa8re\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he\ncalled everyone without exception and without the slightest variation\nin his tone, \xe2\x80\x9cmy dear,\xe2\x80\x9d whether they were above or below him in\nrank\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you for myself and for our two dear ones whose name\nday we are keeping. But mind you come to dinner or I shall be offended,\nma ch\xc3\xa8re! On behalf of the whole family I beg you to come, mon cher!\xe2\x80\x9d\nThese words he repeated to everyone without exception or variation, and\nwith the same expression on his full, cheerful, clean-shaven face, the\nsame firm pressure of the hand and the same quick, repeated bows. As\nsoon as he had seen a visitor off he returned to one of those who were\nstill in the drawing room, drew a chair toward him or her, and jauntily\nspreading out his legs and putting his hands on his knees with the air\nof a man who enjoys life and knows how to live, he swayed to and\nfro with dignity, offered surmises about the weather, or touched on\nquestions of health, sometimes in Russian and sometimes in very bad but\nself-confident French; then again, like a man weary but unflinching in\nthe fulfillment of duty, he rose to see some visitors off and, stroking\nhis scanty gray hairs over his bald patch, also asked them to dinner.\nSometimes on his way back from the anteroom he would pass through the\nconservatory and pantry into the large marble dining hall, where tables\nwere being set out for eighty people; and looking at the footmen, who\nwere bringing in silver and china, moving tables, and unfolding damask\ntable linen, he would call Dm\xc3\xadtri Vas\xc3\xadlevich, a man of good family and\nthe manager of all his affairs, and while looking with pleasure at the\nenormous table would say: \xe2\x80\x9cWell, Dm\xc3\xadtri, you\xe2\x80\x99ll see that things are\nall as they should be? That\xe2\x80\x99s right! The great thing is the serving,\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s it.\xe2\x80\x9d And with a complacent sigh he would return to the\ndrawing room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cM\xc3\xa1rya Lv\xc3\xb3vna Kar\xc3\xa1gina and her daughter!\xe2\x80\x9d announced the\ncountess\xe2\x80\x99 gigantic footman in his bass voice, entering the drawing\nroom. The countess reflected a moment and took a pinch from a gold\nsnuffbox with her husband\xe2\x80\x99s portrait on it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m quite worn out by these callers. However, I\xe2\x80\x99ll see her and\nno more. She is so affected. Ask her in,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to the footman in a\nsad voice, as if saying: \xe2\x80\x9cVery well, finish me off.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nA tall, stout, and proud-looking woman, with a round-faced smiling\ndaughter, entered the drawing room, their dresses rustling.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Countess, what an age... She has been laid up, poor child ...\nat the Razum\xc3\xb3vski\xe2\x80\x99s ball ... and Countess Apr\xc3\xa1ksina ... I was\nso delighted...\xe2\x80\x9d came the sounds of animated feminine voices,\ninterrupting one another and mingling with the rustling of dresses and\nthe scraping of chairs. Then one of those conversations began which last\nout until, at the first pause, the guests rise with a rustle of dresses\nand say, \xe2\x80\x9cI am so delighted... Mamma\xe2\x80\x99s health... and Countess\nApr\xc3\xa1ksina...\xe2\x80\x9d and then, again rustling, pass into the anteroom, put\non cloaks or mantles, and drive away. The conversation was on the chief\ntopic of the day: the illness of the wealthy and celebrated beau of\nCatherine\xe2\x80\x99s day, Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov, and about his illegitimate son\nPierre, the one who had behaved so improperly at Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s\nreception.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am so sorry for the poor count,\xe2\x80\x9d said the visitor. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is in\nsuch bad health, and now this vexation about his son is enough to kill\nhim!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the countess as if she did not know what the\nvisitor alluded to, though she had already heard about the cause of\nCount Bez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s distress some fifteen times.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what comes of a modern education,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the visitor.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems that while he was abroad this young man was allowed to do\nas he liked, now in Petersburg I hear he has been doing such terrible\nthings that he has been expelled by the police.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t say so!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the countess.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe chose his friends badly,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna.\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s son, he, and a certain D\xc3\xb3lokhov have, it is said,\nbeen up to heaven only knows what! And they have had to suffer for it.\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov has been degraded to the ranks and Bez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s son sent\nback to Moscow. Anatole Kur\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x99s father managed somehow to get his\nson\xe2\x80\x99s affair hushed up, but even he was ordered out of Petersburg.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what have they been up to?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the countess.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are regular brigands, especially D\xc3\xb3lokhov,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\nvisitor. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is a son of M\xc3\xa1rya Iv\xc3\xa1novna D\xc3\xb3lokhova, such a worthy\nwoman, but there, just fancy! Those three got hold of a bear somewhere,\nput it in a carriage, and set off with it to visit some actresses! The\npolice tried to interfere, and what did the young men do? They tied\na policeman and the bear back to back and put the bear into the Moyka\nCanal. And there was the bear swimming about with the policeman on his\nback!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a nice figure the policeman must have cut, my dear!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted\nthe count, dying with laughter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, how dreadful! How can you laugh at it, Count?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nYet the ladies themselves could not help laughing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was all they could do to rescue the poor man,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the\nvisitor. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd to think it is Cyril Vlad\xc3\xadmirovich Bez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s son\nwho amuses himself in this sensible manner! And he was said to be so\nwell educated and clever. This is all that his foreign education has\ndone for him! I hope that here in Moscow no one will receive him, in\nspite of his money. They wanted to introduce him to me, but I quite\ndeclined: I have my daughters to consider.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you say this young man is so rich?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the countess,\nturning away from the girls, who at once assumed an air of inattention.\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis children are all illegitimate. I think Pierre also is\nillegitimate.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe visitor made a gesture with her hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should think he has a score of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrincess Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna intervened in the conversation, evidently\nwishing to show her connections and knowledge of what went on in\nsociety.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fact of the matter is,\xe2\x80\x9d said she significantly, and also in a\nhalf whisper, \xe2\x80\x9ceveryone knows Count Cyril\xe2\x80\x99s reputation.... He has\nlost count of his children, but this Pierre was his favorite.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow handsome the old man still was only a year ago!\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the\ncountess. \xe2\x80\x9cI have never seen a handsomer man.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is very much altered now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, as\nI was saying, Prince Vas\xc3\xadli is the next heir through his wife, but the\ncount is very fond of Pierre, looked after his education, and wrote to\nthe Emperor about him; so that in the case of his death\xe2\x80\x94and he is\nso ill that he may die at any moment, and Dr. Lorrain has come from\nPetersburg\xe2\x80\x94no one knows who will inherit his immense fortune, Pierre\nor Prince Vas\xc3\xadli. Forty thousand serfs and millions of rubles! I know\nit all very well for Prince Vas\xc3\xadli told me himself. Besides, Cyril\nVlad\xc3\xadmirovich is my mother\xe2\x80\x99s second cousin. He\xe2\x80\x99s also my B\xc3\xb3ry\xe2\x80\x99s\ngodfather,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, as if she attached no importance at all to the\nfact.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrince Vas\xc3\xadli arrived in Moscow yesterday. I hear he has come on\nsome inspection business,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the visitor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but between ourselves,\xe2\x80\x9d said the princess, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is a\npretext. The fact is he has come to see Count Cyril Vlad\xc3\xadmirovich,\nhearing how ill he is.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut do you know, my dear, that was a capital joke,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count;\nand seeing that the elder visitor was not listening, he turned to the\nyoung ladies. \xe2\x80\x9cI can just imagine what a funny figure that policeman\ncut!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd as he waved his arms to impersonate the policeman, his portly form\nagain shook with a deep ringing laugh, the laugh of one who always eats\nwell and, in particular, drinks well. \xe2\x80\x9cSo do come and dine with us!\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe said.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XI\n\nSilence ensued. The countess looked at her callers, smiling affably,\nbut not concealing the fact that she would not be distressed if they\nnow rose and took their leave. The visitor\xe2\x80\x99s daughter was already\nsmoothing down her dress with an inquiring look at her mother, when\nsuddenly from the next room were heard the footsteps of boys and girls\nrunning to the door and the noise of a chair falling over, and a girl\nof thirteen, hiding something in the folds of her short muslin frock,\ndarted in and stopped short in the middle of the room. It was evident\nthat she had not intended her flight to bring her so far. Behind her in\nthe doorway appeared a student with a crimson coat collar, an officer\nof the Guards, a girl of fifteen, and a plump rosy-faced boy in a short\njacket.\n\nThe count jumped up and, swaying from side to side, spread his arms wide\nand threw them round the little girl who had run in.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, here she is!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cMy pet, whose name day\nit is. My dear pet!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMa ch\xc3\xa8re, there is a time for everything,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess with\nfeigned severity. \xe2\x80\x9cYou spoil her, Ily\xc3\xa1,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, turning to her\nhusband.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you do, my dear? I wish you many happy returns of your name\nday,\xe2\x80\x9d said the visitor. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a charming child,\xe2\x80\x9d she added,\naddressing the mother.\n\nThis black-eyed, wide-mouthed girl, not pretty but full of life\xe2\x80\x94with\nchildish bare shoulders which after her run heaved and shook her\nbodice, with black curls tossed backward, thin bare arms, little legs\nin lace-frilled drawers, and feet in low slippers\xe2\x80\x94was just at that\ncharming age when a girl is no longer a child, though the child is not\nyet a young woman. Escaping from her father she ran to hide her flushed\nface in the lace of her mother\xe2\x80\x99s mantilla\xe2\x80\x94not paying the least\nattention to her severe remark\xe2\x80\x94and began to laugh. She laughed, and in\nfragmentary sentences tried to explain about a doll which she produced\nfrom the folds of her frock.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you see?... My doll... Mimi... You see...\xe2\x80\x9d was all Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nmanaged to utter (to her everything seemed funny). She leaned against\nher mother and burst into such a loud, ringing fit of laughter that even\nthe prim visitor could not help joining in.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow then, go away and take your monstrosity with you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\nmother, pushing away her daughter with pretended sternness, and turning\nto the visitor she added: \xe2\x80\x9cShe is my youngest girl.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, raising her face for a moment from her mother\xe2\x80\x99s mantilla,\nglanced up at her through tears of laughter, and again hid her face.\n\nThe visitor, compelled to look on at this family scene, thought it\nnecessary to take some part in it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said she to Nat\xc3\xa1sha, \xe2\x80\x9cis Mimi a relation of\nyours? A daughter, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha did not like the visitor\xe2\x80\x99s tone of condescension to childish\nthings. She did not reply, but looked at her seriously.\n\nMeanwhile the younger generation: Bor\xc3\xads, the officer, Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna\xe2\x80\x99s son; Nicholas, the undergraduate, the count\xe2\x80\x99s eldest\nson; S\xc3\xb3nya, the count\xe2\x80\x99s fifteen-year-old niece, and little P\xc3\xa9tya,\nhis youngest boy, had all settled down in the drawing room and were\nobviously trying to restrain within the bounds of decorum the excitement\nand mirth that shone in all their faces. Evidently in the back rooms,\nfrom which they had dashed out so impetuously, the conversation had\nbeen more amusing than the drawing room talk of society scandals, the\nweather, and Countess Apr\xc3\xa1ksina. Now and then they glanced at one\nanother, hardly able to suppress their laughter.\n\nThe two young men, the student and the officer, friends from childhood,\nwere of the same age and both handsome fellows, though not alike. Bor\xc3\xads\nwas tall and fair, and his calm and handsome face had regular, delicate\nfeatures. Nicholas was short with curly hair and an open expression.\nDark hairs were already showing on his upper lip, and his whole face\nexpressed impetuosity and enthusiasm. Nicholas blushed when he entered\nthe drawing room. He evidently tried to find something to say, but\nfailed. Bor\xc3\xads on the contrary at once found his footing, and related\nquietly and humorously how he had known that doll Mimi when she was\nstill quite a young lady, before her nose was broken; how she had aged\nduring the five years he had known her, and how her head had cracked\nright across the skull. Having said this he glanced at Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\nShe turned away from him and glanced at her younger brother, who was\nscrewing up his eyes and shaking with suppressed laughter, and unable\nto control herself any longer, she jumped up and rushed from the room as\nfast as her nimble little feet would carry her. Bor\xc3\xads did not laugh.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were meaning to go out, weren\xe2\x80\x99t you, Mamma? Do you want the\ncarriage?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked his mother with a smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, go and tell them to get it ready,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered,\nreturning his smile.\n\nBor\xc3\xads quietly left the room and went in search of Nat\xc3\xa1sha. The plump\nboy ran after them angrily, as if vexed that their program had been\ndisturbed.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XII\n\nThe only young people remaining in the drawing room, not counting the\nyoung lady visitor and the countess\xe2\x80\x99 eldest daughter (who was four\nyears older than her sister and behaved already like a grown-up person),\nwere Nicholas and S\xc3\xb3nya, the niece. S\xc3\xb3nya was a slender little\nbrunette with a tender look in her eyes which were veiled by long\nlashes, thick black plaits coiling twice round her head, and a tawny\ntint in her complexion and especially in the color of her slender but\ngraceful and muscular arms and neck. By the grace of her movements,\nby the softness and flexibility of her small limbs, and by a certain\ncoyness and reserve of manner, she reminded one of a pretty, half-grown\nkitten which promises to become a beautiful little cat. She evidently\nconsidered it proper to show an interest in the general conversation by\nsmiling, but in spite of herself her eyes under their thick long lashes\nwatched her cousin who was going to join the army, with such passionate\ngirlish adoration that her smile could not for a single instant impose\nupon anyone, and it was clear that the kitten had settled down only to\nspring up with more energy and again play with her cousin as soon as\nthey too could, like Nat\xc3\xa1sha and Bor\xc3\xads, escape from the drawing room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh yes, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, addressing the visitor and\npointing to Nicholas, \xe2\x80\x9chis friend Bor\xc3\xads has become an officer, and\nso for friendship\xe2\x80\x99s sake he is leaving the university and me, his\nold father, and entering the military service, my dear. And there was a\nplace and everything waiting for him in the Archives Department! Isn\xe2\x80\x99t\nthat friendship?\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the count in an inquiring tone.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut they say that war has been declared,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the visitor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve been saying so a long while,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cand\nthey\xe2\x80\x99ll say so again and again, and that will be the end of it. My\ndear, there\xe2\x80\x99s friendship for you,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s joining\nthe hussars.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe visitor, not knowing what to say, shook her head.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not at all from friendship,\xe2\x80\x9d declared Nicholas, flaring\nup and turning away as if from a shameful aspersion. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is not from\nfriendship at all; I simply feel that the army is my vocation.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe glanced at his cousin and the young lady visitor; and they were both\nregarding him with a smile of approbation.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSchubert, the colonel of the P\xc3\xa1vlograd Hussars, is dining with us\ntoday. He has been here on leave and is taking Nicholas back with him.\nIt can\xe2\x80\x99t be helped!\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, shrugging his shoulders and\nspeaking playfully of a matter that evidently distressed him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have already told you, Papa,\xe2\x80\x9d said his son, \xe2\x80\x9cthat if you\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t wish to let me go, I\xe2\x80\x99ll stay. But I know I am no use anywhere\nexcept in the army; I am not a diplomat or a government clerk.\xe2\x80\x94I\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know how to hide what I feel.\xe2\x80\x9d As he spoke he kept glancing\nwith the flirtatiousness of a handsome youth at S\xc3\xb3nya and the young\nlady visitor.\n\nThe little kitten, feasting her eyes on him, seemed ready at any moment\nto start her gambols again and display her kittenish nature.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, all right!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old count. \xe2\x80\x9cHe always flares up!\nThis Buonaparte has turned all their heads; they all think of how he\nrose from an ensign and became Emperor. Well, well, God grant it,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nadded, not noticing his visitor\xe2\x80\x99s sarcastic smile.\n\nThe elders began talking about Bonaparte. Julie Kar\xc3\xa1gina turned to\nyoung Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a pity you weren\xe2\x80\x99t at the Arkh\xc3\xa1rovs\xe2\x80\x99 on Thursday. It was so\ndull without you,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, giving him a tender smile.\n\nThe young man, flattered, sat down nearer to her with a coquettish\nsmile, and engaged the smiling Julie in a confidential conversation\nwithout at all noticing that his involuntary smile had stabbed the heart\nof S\xc3\xb3nya, who blushed and smiled unnaturally. In the midst of his talk\nhe glanced round at her. She gave him a passionately angry glance, and\nhardly able to restrain her tears and maintain the artificial smile\non her lips, she got up and left the room. All Nicholas\xe2\x80\x99 animation\nvanished. He waited for the first pause in the conversation, and then\nwith a distressed face left the room to find S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow plainly all these young people wear their hearts on their\nsleeves!\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, pointing to Nicholas as he went out.\n\xe2\x80\x9cCousinage\xe2\x80\x94dangereux voisinage,\xe2\x80\x9d * she added.\n\n     * Cousinhood is a dangerous neighborhood.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess when the brightness these young people had\nbrought into the room had vanished; and as if answering a question no\none had put but which was always in her mind, \xe2\x80\x9cand how much suffering,\nhow much anxiety one has had to go through that we might rejoice in\nthem now! And yet really the anxiety is greater now than the joy. One is\nalways, always anxious! Especially just at this age, so dangerous both\nfor girls and boys.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt all depends on the bringing up,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the visitor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you\xe2\x80\x99re quite right,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the countess. \xe2\x80\x9cTill now I\nhave always, thank God, been my children\xe2\x80\x99s friend and had their full\nconfidence,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, repeating the mistake of so many parents who\nimagine that their children have no secrets from them. \xe2\x80\x9cI know I shall\nalways be my daughters\xe2\x80\x99 first confidante, and that if Nicholas, with\nhis impulsive nature, does get into mischief (a boy can\xe2\x80\x99t help it), he\nwill all the same never be like those Petersburg young men.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, they are splendid, splendid youngsters,\xe2\x80\x9d chimed in the count,\nwho always solved questions that seemed to him perplexing by deciding\nthat everything was splendid. \xe2\x80\x9cJust fancy: wants to be an hussar.\nWhat\xe2\x80\x99s one to do, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a charming creature your younger girl is,\xe2\x80\x9d said the visitor;\n\xe2\x80\x9ca little volcano!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, a regular volcano,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count. \xe2\x80\x9cTakes after me! And\nwhat a voice she has; though she\xe2\x80\x99s my daughter, I tell the truth\nwhen I say she\xe2\x80\x99ll be a singer, a second Salomoni! We have engaged an\nItalian to give her lessons.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t she too young? I have heard that it harms the voice to train\nit at that age.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no, not at all too young!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, our\nmothers used to be married at twelve or thirteen.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd she\xe2\x80\x99s in love with Bor\xc3\xads already. Just fancy!\xe2\x80\x9d said the\ncountess with a gentle smile, looking at Bor\xc3\xads and went on, evidently\nconcerned with a thought that always occupied her: \xe2\x80\x9cNow you see if I\nwere to be severe with her and to forbid it ... goodness knows what they\nmight be up to on the sly\xe2\x80\x9d (she meant that they would be kissing),\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut as it is, I know every word she utters. She will come running to\nme of her own accord in the evening and tell me everything. Perhaps I\nspoil her, but really that seems the best plan. With her elder sister I\nwas stricter.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I was brought up quite differently,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the handsome\nelder daughter, Countess V\xc3\xa9ra, with a smile.\n\nBut the smile did not enhance V\xc3\xa9ra\xe2\x80\x99s beauty as smiles generally do;\non the contrary it gave her an unnatural, and therefore unpleasant,\nexpression. V\xc3\xa9ra was good-looking, not at all stupid, quick at\nlearning, was well brought up, and had a pleasant voice; what she said\nwas true and appropriate, yet, strange to say, everyone\xe2\x80\x94the visitors\nand countess alike\xe2\x80\x94turned to look at her as if wondering why she had\nsaid it, and they all felt awkward.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeople are always too clever with their eldest children and try to\nmake something exceptional of them,\xe2\x80\x9d said the visitor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the good of denying it, my dear? Our dear countess was too\nclever with V\xc3\xa9ra,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what of that? She\xe2\x80\x99s\nturned out splendidly all the same,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, winking at V\xc3\xa9ra.\n\nThe guests got up and took their leave, promising to return to dinner.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat manners! I thought they would never go,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess,\nwhen she had seen her guests out.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIII\n\nWhen Nat\xc3\xa1sha ran out of the drawing room she only went as far as the\nconservatory. There she paused and stood listening to the conversation\nin the drawing room, waiting for Bor\xc3\xads to come out. She was already\ngrowing impatient, and stamped her foot, ready to cry at his not coming\nat once, when she heard the young man\xe2\x80\x99s discreet steps approaching\nneither quickly nor slowly. At this Nat\xc3\xa1sha dashed swiftly among the\nflower tubs and hid there.\n\nBor\xc3\xads paused in the middle of the room, looked round, brushed a little\ndust from the sleeve of his uniform, and going up to a mirror examined\nhis handsome face. Nat\xc3\xa1sha, very still, peered out from her ambush,\nwaiting to see what he would do. He stood a little while before the\nglass, smiled, and walked toward the other door. Nat\xc3\xa1sha was about to\ncall him but changed her mind. \xe2\x80\x9cLet him look for me,\xe2\x80\x9d thought she.\nHardly had Bor\xc3\xads gone than S\xc3\xb3nya, flushed, in tears, and muttering\nangrily, came in at the other door. Nat\xc3\xa1sha checked her first impulse\nto run out to her, and remained in her hiding place, watching\xe2\x80\x94as\nunder an invisible cap\xe2\x80\x94to see what went on in the world. She was\nexperiencing a new and peculiar pleasure. S\xc3\xb3nya, muttering to herself,\nkept looking round toward the drawing room door. It opened and Nicholas\ncame in.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xb3nya, what is the matter with you? How can you?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, running\nup to her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s nothing, nothing; leave me alone!\xe2\x80\x9d sobbed S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, I know what it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if you do, so much the better, and you can go back to her!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xb3-o-onya! Look here! How can you torture me and yourself like that,\nfor a mere fancy?\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas taking her hand.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya did not pull it away, and left off crying. Nat\xc3\xa1sha, not stirring\nand scarcely breathing, watched from her ambush with sparkling eyes.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat will happen now?\xe2\x80\x9d thought she.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xb3nya! What is anyone in the world to me? You alone are\neverything!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd I will prove it to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t like you to talk like that.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, I won\xe2\x80\x99t; only forgive me, S\xc3\xb3nya!\xe2\x80\x9d He drew her to him\nand kissed her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, how nice,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nat\xc3\xa1sha; and when S\xc3\xb3nya and Nicholas had\ngone out of the conservatory she followed and called Bor\xc3\xads to her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBor\xc3\xads, come here,\xe2\x80\x9d said she with a sly and significant look. \xe2\x80\x9cI\nhave something to tell you. Here, here!\xe2\x80\x9d and she led him into the\nconservatory to the place among the tubs where she had been hiding.\n\nBor\xc3\xads followed her, smiling.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the something?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he.\n\nShe grew confused, glanced round, and, seeing the doll she had thrown\ndown on one of the tubs, picked it up.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cKiss the doll,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\n\nBor\xc3\xads looked attentively and kindly at her eager face, but did not\nreply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you want to? Well, then, come here,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, and\nwent further in among the plants and threw down the doll. \xe2\x80\x9cCloser,\ncloser!\xe2\x80\x9d she whispered.\n\nShe caught the young officer by his cuffs, and a look of solemnity and\nfear appeared on her flushed face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd me? Would you like to kiss me?\xe2\x80\x9d she whispered almost inaudibly,\nglancing up at him from under her brows, smiling, and almost crying from\nexcitement.\n\nBor\xc3\xads blushed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow funny you are!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, bending down to her and blushing still\nmore, but he waited and did nothing.\n\nSuddenly she jumped up onto a tub to be higher than he, embraced him so\nthat both her slender bare arms clasped him above his neck, and, tossing\nback her hair, kissed him full on the lips.\n\nThen she slipped down among the flowerpots on the other side of the tubs\nand stood, hanging her head.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1sha,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know that I love you, but....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are in love with me?\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha broke in.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I am, but please don\xe2\x80\x99t let us do like that.... In another four\nyears ... then I will ask for your hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha considered.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThirteen, fourteen, fifteen, sixteen,\xe2\x80\x9d she counted on her slender\nlittle fingers. \xe2\x80\x9cAll right! Then it\xe2\x80\x99s settled?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nA smile of joy and satisfaction lit up her eager face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSettled!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bor\xc3\xads.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cForever?\xe2\x80\x9d said the little girl. \xe2\x80\x9cTill death itself?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe took his arm and with a happy face went with him into the adjoining\nsitting room.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIV\n\nAfter receiving her visitors, the countess was so tired that she gave\norders to admit no more, but the porter was told to be sure to invite to\ndinner all who came \xe2\x80\x9cto congratulate.\xe2\x80\x9d The countess wished to have\na t\xc3\xaate-\xc3\xa0-t\xc3\xaate talk with the friend of her childhood, Princess Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, whom she had not seen properly since she returned from\nPetersburg. Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, with her tear-worn but pleasant face,\ndrew her chair nearer to that of the countess.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith you I will be quite frank,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\nare not many left of us old friends! That\xe2\x80\x99s why I so value your\nfriendship.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna looked at V\xc3\xa9ra and paused. The countess pressed her\nfriend\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cV\xc3\xa9ra,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to her eldest daughter who was evidently not a\nfavorite, \xe2\x80\x9chow is it you have so little tact? Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see you are\nnot wanted here? Go to the other girls, or...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe handsome V\xc3\xa9ra smiled contemptuously but did not seem at all hurt.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you had told me sooner, Mamma, I would have gone,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied\nas she rose to go to her own room.\n\nBut as she passed the sitting room she noticed two couples sitting,\none pair at each window. She stopped and smiled scornfully. S\xc3\xb3nya was\nsitting close to Nicholas who was copying out some verses for her, the\nfirst he had ever written. Bor\xc3\xads and Nat\xc3\xa1sha were at the other window\nand ceased talking when V\xc3\xa9ra entered. S\xc3\xb3nya and Nat\xc3\xa1sha looked at\nV\xc3\xa9ra with guilty, happy faces.\n\nIt was pleasant and touching to see these little girls in love; but\napparently the sight of them roused no pleasant feeling in V\xc3\xa9ra.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow often have I asked you not to take my things?\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\nhave a room of your own,\xe2\x80\x9d and she took the inkstand from Nicholas.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn a minute, in a minute,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, dipping his pen.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou always manage to do things at the wrong time,\xe2\x80\x9d continued V\xc3\xa9ra.\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou came rushing into the drawing room so that everyone felt ashamed\nof you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThough what she said was quite just, perhaps for that very reason no one\nreplied, and the four simply looked at one another. She lingered in the\nroom with the inkstand in her hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd at your age what secrets can there be between Nat\xc3\xa1sha and\nBor\xc3\xads, or between you two? It\xe2\x80\x99s all nonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, V\xc3\xa9ra, what does it matter to you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha in defense,\nspeaking very gently.\n\nShe seemed that day to be more than ever kind and affectionate to\neveryone.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery silly,\xe2\x80\x9d said V\xc3\xa9ra. \xe2\x80\x9cI am ashamed of you. Secrets indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll have secrets of their own,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Nat\xc3\xa1sha, getting warmer.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t interfere with you and Berg.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should think not,\xe2\x80\x9d said V\xc3\xa9ra, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause there can never be\nanything wrong in my behavior. But I\xe2\x80\x99ll just tell Mamma how you are\nbehaving with Bor\xc3\xads.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1lya Ilyn\xc3\xadchna behaves very well to me,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Bor\xc3\xads. \xe2\x80\x9cI\nhave nothing to complain of.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t, Bor\xc3\xads! You are such a diplomat that it is really\ntiresome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha in a mortified voice that trembled slightly.\n(She used the word \xe2\x80\x9cdiplomat,\xe2\x80\x9d which was just then much in vogue\namong the children, in the special sense they attached to it.) \xe2\x80\x9cWhy\ndoes she bother me?\xe2\x80\x9d And she added, turning to V\xc3\xa9ra, \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll\nnever understand it, because you\xe2\x80\x99ve never loved anyone. You have no\nheart! You are a Madame de Genlis and nothing more\xe2\x80\x9d (this nickname,\nbestowed on V\xc3\xa9ra by Nicholas, was considered very stinging), \xe2\x80\x9cand\nyour greatest pleasure is to be unpleasant to people! Go and flirt with\nBerg as much as you please,\xe2\x80\x9d she finished quickly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall at any rate not run after a young man before visitors...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now you\xe2\x80\x99ve done what you wanted,\xe2\x80\x9d put in Nicholas\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9csaid\nunpleasant things to everyone and upset them. Let\xe2\x80\x99s go to the\nnursery.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAll four, like a flock of scared birds, got up and left the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe unpleasant things were said to me,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked V\xc3\xa9ra, \xe2\x80\x9cI said\nnone to anyone.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame de Genlis! Madame de Genlis!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted laughing voices\nthrough the door.\n\nThe handsome V\xc3\xa9ra, who produced such an irritating and unpleasant\neffect on everyone, smiled and, evidently unmoved by what had been\nsaid to her, went to the looking glass and arranged her hair and scarf.\nLooking at her own handsome face she seemed to become still colder and\ncalmer.\n\n\nIn the drawing room the conversation was still going on.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, \xe2\x80\x9cmy life is not all roses\neither. Don\xe2\x80\x99t I know that at the rate we are living our means won\xe2\x80\x99t\nlast long? It\xe2\x80\x99s all the Club and his easygoing nature. Even in the\ncountry do we get any rest? Theatricals, hunting, and heaven knows what\nbesides! But don\xe2\x80\x99t let\xe2\x80\x99s talk about me; tell me how you managed\neverything. I often wonder at you, Annette\xe2\x80\x94how at your age you\ncan rush off alone in a carriage to Moscow, to Petersburg, to those\nministers and great people, and know how to deal with them all! It\xe2\x80\x99s\nquite astonishing. How did you get things settled? I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t possibly\ndo it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my love,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, \xe2\x80\x9cGod grant you never\nknow what it is to be left a widow without means and with a son you love\nto distraction! One learns many things then,\xe2\x80\x9d she added with a certain\npride. \xe2\x80\x9cThat lawsuit taught me much. When I want to see one of those\nbig people I write a note: \xe2\x80\x98Princess So-and-So desires an interview\nwith So and-So,\xe2\x80\x99 and then I take a cab and go myself two, three, or\nfour times\xe2\x80\x94till I get what I want. I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind what they think of\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and to whom did you apply about B\xc3\xb3ry?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the countess.\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see yours is already an officer in the Guards, while my Nicholas\nis going as a cadet. There\xe2\x80\x99s no one to interest himself for him. To\nwhom did you apply?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Prince Vas\xc3\xadli. He was so kind. He at once agreed to everything,\nand put the matter before the Emperor,\xe2\x80\x9d said Princess Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna enthusiastically, quite forgetting all the humiliation she\nhad endured to gain her end.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas Prince Vas\xc3\xadli aged much?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the countess. \xe2\x80\x9cI have not\nseen him since we acted together at the Rumy\xc3\xa1ntsovs\xe2\x80\x99 theatricals. I\nexpect he has forgotten me. He paid me attentions in those days,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nthe countess, with a smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is just the same as ever,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna,\n\xe2\x80\x9coverflowing with amiability. His position has not turned his head\nat all. He said to me, \xe2\x80\x98I am sorry I can do so little for you, dear\nPrincess. I am at your command.\xe2\x80\x99 Yes, he is a fine fellow and a very\nkind relation. But, Nataly, you know my love for my son: I would do\nanything for his happiness! And my affairs are in such a bad way that my\nposition is now a terrible one,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, sadly,\ndropping her voice. \xe2\x80\x9cMy wretched lawsuit takes all I have and makes no\nprogress. Would you believe it, I have literally not a penny and don\xe2\x80\x99t\nknow how to equip Bor\xc3\xads.\xe2\x80\x9d She took out her handkerchief and began to\ncry. \xe2\x80\x9cI need five hundred rubles, and have only one twenty-five-ruble\nnote. I am in such a state.... My only hope now is in Count Cyril\nVlad\xc3\xadmirovich Bez\xc3\xbakhov. If he will not assist his godson\xe2\x80\x94you know\nhe is B\xc3\xb3ry\xe2\x80\x99s godfather\xe2\x80\x94and allow him something for his maintenance,\nall my trouble will have been thrown away.... I shall not be able to\nequip him.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe countess\xe2\x80\x99 eyes filled with tears and she pondered in silence.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI often think, though, perhaps it\xe2\x80\x99s a sin,\xe2\x80\x9d said the princess,\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat here lives Count Cyril Vlad\xc3\xadmirovich Bez\xc3\xbakhov so rich, all\nalone... that tremendous fortune... and what is his life worth? It\xe2\x80\x99s a\nburden to him, and B\xc3\xb3ry\xe2\x80\x99s life is only just beginning....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely he will leave something to Bor\xc3\xads,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeaven only knows, my dear! These rich grandees are so selfish.\nStill, I will take Bor\xc3\xads and go to see him at once, and I shall speak\nto him straight out. Let people think what they will of me, it\xe2\x80\x99s\nreally all the same to me when my son\xe2\x80\x99s fate is at stake.\xe2\x80\x9d The\nprincess rose. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s now two o\xe2\x80\x99clock and you dine at four. There\nwill just be time.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd like a practical Petersburg lady who knows how to make the most of\ntime, Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna sent someone to call her son, and went into the\nanteroom with him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-by, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said she to the countess who saw her to the\ndoor, and added in a whisper so that her son should not hear, \xe2\x80\x9cWish me\ngood luck.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you going to Count Cyril Vlad\xc3\xadmirovich, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d said the\ncount coming out from the dining hall into the anteroom, and he added:\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he is better, ask Pierre to dine with us. He has been to the\nhouse, you know, and danced with the children. Be sure to invite him, my\ndear. We will see how Tar\xc3\xa1s distinguishes himself today. He says Count\nOrl\xc3\xb3v never gave such a dinner as ours will be!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XV\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Bor\xc3\xads,\xe2\x80\x9d said Princess Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna to her son as\nCountess Rost\xc3\xb3va\xe2\x80\x99s carriage in which they were seated drove over the\nstraw covered street and turned into the wide courtyard of Count Cyril\nVlad\xc3\xadmirovich Bez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s house. \xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Bor\xc3\xads,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\nmother, drawing her hand from beneath her old mantle and laying\nit timidly and tenderly on her son\xe2\x80\x99s arm, \xe2\x80\x9cbe affectionate and\nattentive to him. Count Cyril Vlad\xc3\xadmirovich is your godfather after\nall, and your future depends on him. Remember that, my dear, and be nice\nto him, as you so well know how to be.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf only I knew that anything besides humiliation would come of\nit...\xe2\x80\x9d answered her son coldly. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I have promised and will do it\nfor your sake.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAlthough the hall porter saw someone\xe2\x80\x99s carriage standing at the\nentrance, after scrutinizing the mother and son (who without asking to\nbe announced had passed straight through the glass porch between the\nrows of statues in niches) and looking significantly at the lady\xe2\x80\x99s old\ncloak, he asked whether they wanted the count or the princesses, and,\nhearing that they wished to see the count, said his excellency was worse\ntoday, and that his excellency was not receiving anyone.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe may as well go back,\xe2\x80\x9d said the son in French.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed his mother imploringly, again laying her hand\non his arm as if that touch might soothe or rouse him.\n\nBor\xc3\xads said no more, but looked inquiringly at his mother without taking\noff his cloak.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna in gentle tones, addressing\nthe hall porter, \xe2\x80\x9cI know Count Cyril Vlad\xc3\xadmirovich is very ill...\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s why I have come... I am a relation. I shall not disturb him,\nmy friend... I only need see Prince Vas\xc3\xadli Serg\xc3\xa9evich: he is staying\nhere, is he not? Please announce me.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe hall porter sullenly pulled a bell that rang upstairs, and turned\naway.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrincess Drubetsk\xc3\xa1ya to see Prince Vas\xc3\xadli Serg\xc3\xa9evich,\xe2\x80\x9d he called\nto a footman dressed in knee breeches, shoes, and a swallow-tail coat,\nwho ran downstairs and looked over from the halfway landing.\n\nThe mother smoothed the folds of her dyed silk dress before a large\nVenetian mirror in the wall, and in her trodden-down shoes briskly\nascended the carpeted stairs.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to her son, once more stimulating him by a\ntouch, \xe2\x80\x9cyou promised me!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe son, lowering his eyes, followed her quietly.\n\nThey entered the large hall, from which one of the doors led to the\napartments assigned to Prince Vas\xc3\xadli.\n\nJust as the mother and son, having reached the middle of the hall, were\nabout to ask their way of an elderly footman who had sprung up as they\nentered, the bronze handle of one of the doors turned and Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\ncame out\xe2\x80\x94wearing a velvet coat with a single star on his breast,\nas was his custom when at home\xe2\x80\x94taking leave of a good-looking,\ndark-haired man. This was the celebrated Petersburg doctor, Lorrain.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen it is certain?\xe2\x80\x9d said the prince.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrince, humanum est errare, * but...\xe2\x80\x9d replied the doctor,\nswallowing his r\xe2\x80\x99s, and pronouncing the Latin words with a French\naccent.\n\n     * To err is human.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, very well...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nSeeing Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna and her son, Prince Vas\xc3\xadli dismissed the\ndoctor with a bow and approached them silently and with a look of\ninquiry. The son noticed that an expression of profound sorrow suddenly\nclouded his mother\xe2\x80\x99s face, and he smiled slightly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Prince! In what sad circumstances we meet again! And how is our\ndear invalid?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, as though unaware of the cold offensive look\nfixed on her.\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli stared at her and at Bor\xc3\xads questioningly and perplexed.\nBor\xc3\xads bowed politely. Prince Vas\xc3\xadli without acknowledging the bow\nturned to Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, answering her query by a movement of the\nhead and lips indicating very little hope for the patient.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, how awful!\nIt is terrible to think.... This is my son,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, indicating\nBor\xc3\xads. \xe2\x80\x9cHe wanted to thank you himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBor\xc3\xads bowed again politely.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBelieve me, Prince, a mother\xe2\x80\x99s heart will never forget what you\nhave done for us.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am glad I was able to do you a service, my dear Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Vas\xc3\xadli, arranging his lace frill, and in\ntone and manner, here in Moscow to Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna whom he had placed\nunder an obligation, assuming an air of much greater importance than he\nhad done in Petersburg at Anna Sch\xc3\xa9rer\xe2\x80\x99s reception.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTry to serve well and show yourself worthy,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, addressing\nBor\xc3\xads with severity. \xe2\x80\x9cI am glad.... Are you here on leave?\xe2\x80\x9d he went\non in his usual tone of indifference.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am awaiting orders to join my new regiment, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d\nreplied Bor\xc3\xads, betraying neither annoyance at the prince\xe2\x80\x99s brusque\nmanner nor a desire to enter into conversation, but speaking so quietly\nand respectfully that the prince gave him a searching glance.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you living with your mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am living at Countess Rost\xc3\xb3va\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bor\xc3\xads, again\nadding, \xe2\x80\x9cyour excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is, with Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v who married Nataly Shinshin\xc3\xa1,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know, I know,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Prince Vas\xc3\xadli in his monotonous voice.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never could understand how Nataly made up her mind to marry that\nunlicked bear! A perfectly absurd and stupid fellow, and a gambler too,\nI am told.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut a very kind man, Prince,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna with a\npathetic smile, as though she too knew that Count Rost\xc3\xb3v deserved this\ncensure, but asked him not to be too hard on the poor old man. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\ndo the doctors say?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the princess after a pause, her worn face\nagain expressing deep sorrow.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey give little hope,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the prince.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I should so like to thank Uncle once for all his kindness to me\nand Bor\xc3\xads. He is his godson,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, her tone suggesting that\nthis fact ought to give Prince Vas\xc3\xadli much satisfaction.\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli became thoughtful and frowned. Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna saw that\nhe was afraid of finding in her a rival for Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s fortune,\nand hastened to reassure him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it were not for my sincere affection and devotion to Uncle,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid she, uttering the word with peculiar assurance and unconcern, \xe2\x80\x9cI\nknow his character: noble, upright ... but you see he has no one with\nhim except the young princesses.... They are still young....\xe2\x80\x9d She bent\nher head and continued in a whisper: \xe2\x80\x9cHas he performed his final duty,\nPrince? How priceless are those last moments! It can make things no\nworse, and it is absolutely necessary to prepare him if he is so ill.\nWe women, Prince,\xe2\x80\x9d and she smiled tenderly, \xe2\x80\x9calways know how to say\nthese things. I absolutely must see him, however painful it may be for\nme. I am used to suffering.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nEvidently the prince understood her, and also understood, as he had done\nat Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s, that it would be difficult to get rid of Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould not such a meeting be too trying for him, dear Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna?\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us wait until evening. The doctors are\nexpecting a crisis.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut one cannot delay, Prince, at such a moment! Consider that the\nwelfare of his soul is at stake. Ah, it is awful: the duties of a\nChristian...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nA door of one of the inner rooms opened and one of the princesses, the\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s niece, entered with a cold, stern face. The length of her\nbody was strikingly out of proportion to her short legs. Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\nturned to her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, how is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill the same; but what can you expect, this noise...\xe2\x80\x9d said the\nprincess, looking at Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna as at a stranger.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear, I hardly knew you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna with a\nhappy smile, ambling lightly up to the count\xe2\x80\x99s niece. \xe2\x80\x9cI have come,\nand am at your service to help you nurse my uncle. I imagine what you\nhave gone through,\xe2\x80\x9d and she sympathetically turned up her eyes.\n\nThe princess gave no reply and did not even smile, but left the room as\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna took off her gloves and, occupying the position she\nhad conquered, settled down in an armchair, inviting Prince Vas\xc3\xadli to\ntake a seat beside her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBor\xc3\xads,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to her son with a smile, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall go in to see\nthe count, my uncle; but you, my dear, had better go to Pierre meanwhile\nand don\xe2\x80\x99t forget to give him the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 invitation. They ask him\nto dinner. I suppose he won\xe2\x80\x99t go?\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, turning to the\nprince.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the prince, who had plainly become\ndepressed, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall be only too glad if you relieve me of that young\nman.... Here he is, and the count has not once asked for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe shrugged his shoulders. A footman conducted Bor\xc3\xads down one flight of\nstairs and up another, to Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s rooms.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVI\n\nPierre, after all, had not managed to choose a career for himself in\nPetersburg, and had been expelled from there for riotous conduct and\nsent to Moscow. The story told about him at Count Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s was true.\nPierre had taken part in tying a policeman to a bear. He had now been\nfor some days in Moscow and was staying as usual at his father\xe2\x80\x99s\nhouse. Though he expected that the story of his escapade would be\nalready known in Moscow and that the ladies about his father\xe2\x80\x94who were\nnever favorably disposed toward him\xe2\x80\x94would have used it to turn the\ncount against him, he nevertheless on the day of his arrival went to\nhis father\xe2\x80\x99s part of the house. Entering the drawing room, where the\nprincesses spent most of their time, he greeted the ladies, two of whom\nwere sitting at embroidery frames while a third read aloud. It was the\neldest who was reading\xe2\x80\x94the one who had met Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna. The\ntwo younger ones were embroidering: both were rosy and pretty and they\ndiffered only in that one had a little mole on her lip which made her\nmuch prettier. Pierre was received as if he were a corpse or a leper.\nThe eldest princess paused in her reading and silently stared at him\nwith frightened eyes; the second assumed precisely the same expression;\nwhile the youngest, the one with the mole, who was of a cheerful and\nlively disposition, bent over her frame to hide a smile probably evoked\nby the amusing scene she foresaw. She drew her wool down through the\ncanvas and, scarcely able to refrain from laughing, stooped as if trying\nto make out the pattern.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you do, cousin?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t recognize\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI recognize you only too well, too well.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is the count? Can I see him?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pierre, awkwardly as usual,\nbut unabashed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count is suffering physically and mentally, and apparently you\nhave done your best to increase his mental sufferings.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan I see the count?\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre again asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHm.... If you wish to kill him, to kill him outright, you can see\nhim... Olga, go and see whether Uncle\xe2\x80\x99s beef tea is ready\xe2\x80\x94it is\nalmost time,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, giving Pierre to understand that they were\nbusy, and busy making his father comfortable, while evidently he,\nPierre, was only busy causing him annoyance.\n\nOlga went out. Pierre stood looking at the sisters; then he bowed and\nsaid: \xe2\x80\x9cThen I will go to my rooms. You will let me know when I can see\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd he left the room, followed by the low but ringing laughter of the\nsister with the mole.\n\nNext day Prince Vas\xc3\xadli had arrived and settled in the count\xe2\x80\x99s house.\nHe sent for Pierre and said to him: \xe2\x80\x9cMy dear fellow, if you are going\nto behave here as you did in Petersburg, you will end very badly; that\nis all I have to say to you. The count is very, very ill, and you must\nnot see him at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nSince then Pierre had not been disturbed and had spent the whole time in\nhis rooms upstairs.\n\nWhen Bor\xc3\xads appeared at his door Pierre was pacing up and down his room,\nstopping occasionally at a corner to make menacing gestures at the wall,\nas if running a sword through an invisible foe, and glaring savagely\nover his spectacles, and then again resuming his walk, muttering\nindistinct words, shrugging his shoulders and gesticulating.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEngland is done for,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, scowling and pointing his finger\nat someone unseen. \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Pitt, as a traitor to the nation and to the\nrights of man, is sentenced to...\xe2\x80\x9d But before Pierre\xe2\x80\x94who at that\nmoment imagined himself to be Napoleon in person and to have just\neffected the dangerous crossing of the Straits of Dover and captured\nLondon\xe2\x80\x94could pronounce Pitt\xe2\x80\x99s sentence, he saw a well-built and\nhandsome young officer entering his room. Pierre paused. He had left\nMoscow when Bor\xc3\xads was a boy of fourteen, and had quite forgotten him,\nbut in his usual impulsive and hearty way he took Bor\xc3\xads by the hand\nwith a friendly smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you remember me?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Bor\xc3\xads quietly with a pleasant smile.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have come with my mother to see the count, but it seems he is not\nwell.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it seems he is ill. People are always disturbing him,\xe2\x80\x9d\nanswered Pierre, trying to remember who this young man was.\n\nBor\xc3\xads felt that Pierre did not recognize him but did not consider\nit necessary to introduce himself, and without experiencing the least\nembarrassment looked Pierre straight in the face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount Rost\xc3\xb3v asks you to come to dinner today,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, after a\nconsiderable pause which made Pierre feel uncomfortable.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Count Rost\xc3\xb3v!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Pierre joyfully. \xe2\x80\x9cThen you are his\nson, Ily\xc3\xa1? Only fancy, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know you at first. Do you remember\nhow we went to the Sparrow Hills with Madame Jacquot?... It\xe2\x80\x99s such an\nage...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bor\xc3\xads deliberately, with a bold and\nslightly sarcastic smile. \xe2\x80\x9cI am Bor\xc3\xads, son of Princess Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna Drubetsk\xc3\xa1ya. Rost\xc3\xb3v, the father, is Ily\xc3\xa1, and his son is\nNicholas. I never knew any Madame Jacquot.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre shook his head and arms as if attacked by mosquitoes or bees.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh dear, what am I thinking about? I\xe2\x80\x99ve mixed everything up. One\nhas so many relatives in Moscow! So you are Bor\xc3\xads? Of course. Well, now\nwe know where we are. And what do you think of the Boulogne expedition?\nThe English will come off badly, you know, if Napoleon gets across the\nChannel. I think the expedition is quite feasible. If only Villeneuve\ndoesn\xe2\x80\x99t make a mess of things!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBor\xc3\xads knew nothing about the Boulogne expedition; he did not read the\npapers and it was the first time he had heard Villeneuve\xe2\x80\x99s name.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe here in Moscow are more occupied with dinner parties and scandal\nthan with politics,\xe2\x80\x9d said he in his quiet ironical tone. \xe2\x80\x9cI know\nnothing about it and have not thought about it. Moscow is chiefly busy\nwith gossip,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued. \xe2\x80\x9cJust now they are talking about you and\nyour father.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre smiled in his good-natured way as if afraid for his companion\xe2\x80\x99s\nsake that the latter might say something he would afterwards regret.\nBut Bor\xc3\xads spoke distinctly, clearly, and dryly, looking straight into\nPierre\xe2\x80\x99s eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMoscow has nothing else to do but gossip,\xe2\x80\x9d Bor\xc3\xads went on.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverybody is wondering to whom the count will leave his fortune,\nthough he may perhaps outlive us all, as I sincerely hope he will...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it is all very horrid,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Pierre, \xe2\x80\x9cvery horrid.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre was still afraid that this officer might inadvertently say\nsomething disconcerting to himself.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it must seem to you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bor\xc3\xads flushing slightly, but not\nchanging his tone or attitude, \xe2\x80\x9cit must seem to you that everyone is\ntrying to get something out of the rich man?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo it does,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I just wish to say, to avoid misunderstandings, that you are\nquite mistaken if you reckon me or my mother among such people. We are\nvery poor, but for my own part at any rate, for the very reason that\nyour father is rich, I don\xe2\x80\x99t regard myself as a relation of his, and\nneither I nor my mother would ever ask or take anything from him.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nFor a long time Pierre could not understand, but when he did, he jumped\nup from the sofa, seized Bor\xc3\xads under the elbow in his quick, clumsy\nway, and, blushing far more than Bor\xc3\xads, began to speak with a feeling\nof mingled shame and vexation.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, this is strange! Do you suppose I... who could think?... I know\nvery well...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBut Bor\xc3\xads again interrupted him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am glad I have spoken out fully. Perhaps you did not like it? You\nmust excuse me,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, putting Pierre at ease instead of being put\nat ease by him, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I hope I have not offended you. I always make it\na rule to speak out... Well, what answer am I to take? Will you come to\ndinner at the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Bor\xc3\xads, having apparently relieved himself of an onerous duty and\nextricated himself from an awkward situation and placed another in it,\nbecame quite pleasant again.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but I say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, calming down, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are a wonderful\nfellow! What you have just said is good, very good. Of course you\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know me. We have not met for such a long time... not since we\nwere children. You might think that I... I understand, quite understand.\nI could not have done it myself, I should not have had the courage, but\nit\xe2\x80\x99s splendid. I am very glad to have made your acquaintance. It\xe2\x80\x99s\nqueer,\xe2\x80\x9d he added after a pause, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you should have suspected\nme!\xe2\x80\x9d He began to laugh. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what of it! I hope we\xe2\x80\x99ll get better\nacquainted,\xe2\x80\x9d and he pressed Bor\xc3\xads\xe2\x80\x99 hand. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, I have not\nonce been in to see the count. He has not sent for me.... I am sorry for\nhim as a man, but what can one do?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so you think Napoleon will manage to get an army across?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\nBor\xc3\xads with a smile.\n\nPierre saw that Bor\xc3\xads wished to change the subject, and being of the\nsame mind he began explaining the advantages and disadvantages of the\nBoulogne expedition.\n\nA footman came in to summon Bor\xc3\xads\xe2\x80\x94the princess was going. Pierre, in\norder to make Bor\xc3\xads\xe2\x80\x99 better acquaintance, promised to come to dinner,\nand warmly pressing his hand looked affectionately over his spectacles\ninto Bor\xc3\xads\xe2\x80\x99 eyes. After he had gone Pierre continued pacing up and\ndown the room for a long time, no longer piercing an imaginary foe with\nhis imaginary sword, but smiling at the remembrance of that pleasant,\nintelligent, and resolute young man.\n\nAs often happens in early youth, especially to one who leads a lonely\nlife, he felt an unaccountable tenderness for this young man and made up\nhis mind that they would be friends.\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli saw the princess off. She held a handkerchief to her eyes\nand her face was tearful.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is dreadful, dreadful!\xe2\x80\x9d she was saying, \xe2\x80\x9cbut cost me what it\nmay I shall do my duty. I will come and spend the night. He must not be\nleft like this. Every moment is precious. I can\xe2\x80\x99t think why his nieces\nput it off. Perhaps God will help me to find a way to prepare him!...\nAdieu, Prince! May God support you...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdieu, ma bonne,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Prince Vas\xc3\xadli turning away from her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he is in a dreadful state,\xe2\x80\x9d said the mother to her son when\nthey were in the carriage. \xe2\x80\x9cHe hardly recognizes anybody.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t understand, Mamma\xe2\x80\x94what is his attitude to Pierre?\xe2\x80\x9d\nasked the son.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe will will show that, my dear; our fate also depends on it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why do you expect that he will leave us anything?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear! He is so rich, and we are so poor!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that is hardly a sufficient reason, Mamma...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Heaven! How ill he is!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the mother.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVII\n\nAfter Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna had driven off with her son to visit Count Cyril\nVlad\xc3\xadmirovich Bez\xc3\xbakhov, Countess Rost\xc3\xb3va sat for a long time all\nalone applying her handkerchief to her eyes. At last she rang.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter with you, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d she said crossly to the maid\nwho kept her waiting some minutes. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you wish to serve me? Then\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll find you another place.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe countess was upset by her friend\xe2\x80\x99s sorrow and humiliating poverty,\nand was therefore out of sorts, a state of mind which with her always\nfound expression in calling her maid \xe2\x80\x9cmy dear\xe2\x80\x9d and speaking to her\nwith exaggerated politeness.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very sorry, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the maid.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAsk the count to come to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe count came waddling in to see his wife with a rather guilty look as\nusual.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, little countess? What a saut\xc3\xa9 of game au mad\xc3\xa8re we are to\nhave, my dear! I tasted it. The thousand rubles I paid for Tar\xc3\xa1s were\nnot ill-spent. He is worth it!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe sat down by his wife, his elbows on his knees and his hands ruffling\nhis gray hair.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are your commands, little countess?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, my dear... What\xe2\x80\x99s that mess?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, pointing to his\nwaistcoat. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the saut\xc3\xa9, most likely,\xe2\x80\x9d she added with a smile.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you see, Count, I want some money.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHer face became sad.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, little countess!\xe2\x80\x9d ... and the count began bustling to get out\nhis pocketbook.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want a great deal, Count! I want five hundred rubles,\xe2\x80\x9d and taking\nout her cambric handkerchief she began wiping her husband\xe2\x80\x99s waistcoat.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, immediately, immediately!
