Hey, who\xe2\x80\x99s there?\xe2\x80\x9d he called out\nin a tone only used by persons who are certain that those they call will\nrush to obey the summons. \xe2\x80\x9cSend Dm\xc3\xadtri to me!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDm\xc3\xadtri, a man of good family who had been brought up in the count\xe2\x80\x99s\nhouse and now managed all his affairs, stepped softly into the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is what I want, my dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count to the\ndeferential young man who had entered. \xe2\x80\x9cBring me...\xe2\x80\x9d he reflected\na moment, \xe2\x80\x9cyes, bring me seven hundred rubles, yes! But mind, don\xe2\x80\x99t\nbring me such tattered and dirty notes as last time, but nice clean ones\nfor the countess.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Dm\xc3\xadtri, clean ones, please,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, sighing\ndeeply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen would you like them, your excellency?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Dm\xc3\xadtri. \xe2\x80\x9cAllow\nme to inform you... But, don\xe2\x80\x99t be uneasy,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, noticing that\nthe count was beginning to breathe heavily and quickly which was always\na sign of approaching anger. \xe2\x80\x9cI was forgetting... Do you wish it\nbrought at once?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes; just so! Bring it. Give it to the countess.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a treasure that Dm\xc3\xadtri is,\xe2\x80\x9d added the count with a smile when\nthe young man had departed. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is never any \xe2\x80\x98impossible\xe2\x80\x99 with\nhim. That\xe2\x80\x99s a thing I hate! Everything is possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, money, Count, money! How much sorrow it causes in the world,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid the countess. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I am in great need of this sum.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, my little countess, are a notorious spendthrift,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\ncount, and having kissed his wife\xe2\x80\x99s hand he went back to his study.\n\nWhen Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna returned from Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s the money, all\nin clean notes, was lying ready under a handkerchief on the countess\xe2\x80\x99\nlittle table, and Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna noticed that something was agitating\nher.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the countess.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, what a terrible state he is in! One would not know him, he is so\nill! I was only there a few moments and hardly said a word...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnnette, for heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake don\xe2\x80\x99t refuse me,\xe2\x80\x9d the countess\nbegan, with a blush that looked very strange on her thin, dignified,\nelderly face, and she took the money from under the handkerchief.\n\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna instantly guessed her intention and stooped to be\nready to embrace the countess at the appropriate moment.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is for Bor\xc3\xads from me, for his outfit.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna was already embracing her and weeping. The countess\nwept too. They wept because they were friends, and because they were\nkindhearted, and because they\xe2\x80\x94friends from childhood\xe2\x80\x94had to think\nabout such a base thing as money, and because their youth was over....\nBut those tears were pleasant to them both.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVIII\n\nCountess Rost\xc3\xb3va, with her daughters and a large number of guests, was\nalready seated in the drawing room. The count took the gentlemen into\nhis study and showed them his choice collection of Turkish pipes. From\ntime to time he went out to ask: \xe2\x80\x9cHasn\xe2\x80\x99t she come yet?\xe2\x80\x9d They\nwere expecting M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna Akhros\xc3\xadmova, known in society as le\nterrible dragon, a lady distinguished not for wealth or rank, but for\ncommon sense and frank plainness of speech. M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna was known\nto the Imperial family as well as to all Moscow and Petersburg, and both\ncities wondered at her, laughed privately at her rudenesses, and told\ngood stories about her, while none the less all without exception\nrespected and feared her.\n\nIn the count\xe2\x80\x99s room, which was full of tobacco smoke, they talked\nof the war that had been announced in a manifesto, and about the\nrecruiting. None of them had yet seen the manifesto, but they all knew\nit had appeared. The count sat on the sofa between two guests who were\nsmoking and talking. He neither smoked nor talked, but bending his head\nfirst to one side and then to the other watched the smokers with evident\npleasure and listened to the conversation of his two neighbors, whom he\negged on against each other.\n\nOne of them was a sallow, clean-shaven civilian with a thin and wrinkled\nface, already growing old, though he was dressed like a most fashionable\nyoung man. He sat with his legs up on the sofa as if quite at home and,\nhaving stuck an amber mouthpiece far into his mouth, was inhaling the\nsmoke spasmodically and screwing up his eyes. This was an old bachelor,\nShinsh\xc3\xadn, a cousin of the countess\xe2\x80\x99, a man with \xe2\x80\x9ca sharp tongue\xe2\x80\x9d\nas they said in Moscow society. He seemed to be condescending to\nhis companion. The latter, a fresh, rosy officer of the Guards,\nirreproachably washed, brushed, and buttoned, held his pipe in the\nmiddle of his mouth and with red lips gently inhaled the smoke, letting\nit escape from his handsome mouth in rings. This was Lieutenant Berg, an\nofficer in the Sem\xc3\xabnov regiment with whom Bor\xc3\xads was to travel to join\nthe army, and about whom Nat\xc3\xa1sha had teased her elder sister V\xc3\xa9ra,\nspeaking of Berg as her \xe2\x80\x9cintended.\xe2\x80\x9d The count sat between them and\nlistened attentively. His favorite occupation when not playing boston, a\ncard game he was very fond of, was that of listener, especially when he\nsucceeded in setting two loquacious talkers at one another.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, old chap, mon tr\xc3\xa8s honorable Alphonse K\xc3\xa1rlovich,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid Shinsh\xc3\xadn, laughing ironically and mixing the most ordinary Russian\nexpressions with the choicest French phrases\xe2\x80\x94which was a peculiarity\nof his speech. \xe2\x80\x9cVous comptez vous faire des rentes sur l\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\xa9tat; *\nyou want to make something out of your company?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n     * You expect to make an income out of the government.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Peter Nikol\xc3\xa1evich; I only want to show that in the cavalry\nthe advantages are far less than in the infantry. Just consider my own\nposition now, Peter Nikol\xc3\xa1evich...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBerg always spoke quietly, politely, and with great precision. His\nconversation always related entirely to himself; he would remain calm\nand silent when the talk related to any topic that had no direct bearing\non himself. He could remain silent for hours without being at all put\nout of countenance himself or making others uncomfortable, but as\nsoon as the conversation concerned himself he would begin to talk\ncircumstantially and with evident satisfaction.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cConsider my position, Peter Nikol\xc3\xa1evich. Were I in the cavalry I\nshould get not more than two hundred rubles every four months, even\nwith the rank of lieutenant; but as it is I receive two hundred and\nthirty,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, looking at Shinsh\xc3\xadn and the count with a joyful,\npleasant smile, as if it were obvious to him that his success must\nalways be the chief desire of everyone else.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides that, Peter Nikol\xc3\xa1evich, by exchanging into the Guards\nI shall be in a more prominent position,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Berg, \xe2\x80\x9cand\nvacancies occur much more frequently in the Foot Guards. Then just think\nwhat can be done with two hundred and thirty rubles! I even manage to\nput a little aside and to send something to my father,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on,\nemitting a smoke ring.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLa balance y est... * A German knows how to skin a flint, as the\nproverb says,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Shinsh\xc3\xadn, moving his pipe to the other side\nof his mouth and winking at the count.\n\n      * So that squares matters.\n\nThe count burst out laughing. The other guests seeing that Shinsh\xc3\xadn\nwas talking came up to listen. Berg, oblivious of irony or indifference,\ncontinued to explain how by exchanging into the Guards he had already\ngained a step on his old comrades of the Cadet Corps; how in wartime\nthe company commander might get killed and he, as senior in the company,\nmight easily succeed to the post; how popular he was with everyone in\nthe regiment, and how satisfied his father was with him. Berg evidently\nenjoyed narrating all this, and did not seem to suspect that others,\ntoo, might have their own interests. But all he said was so prettily\nsedate, and the na\xc3\xafvet\xc3\xa9 of his youthful egotism was so obvious, that\nhe disarmed his hearers.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my boy, you\xe2\x80\x99ll get along wherever you go\xe2\x80\x94foot or\nhorse\xe2\x80\x94that I\xe2\x80\x99ll warrant,\xe2\x80\x9d said Shinsh\xc3\xadn, patting him on the\nshoulder and taking his feet off the sofa.\n\nBerg smiled joyously. The count, followed by his guests, went into the\ndrawing room.\n\nIt was just the moment before a big dinner when the assembled guests,\nexpecting the summons to zak\xc3\xbaska, * avoid engaging in any long\nconversation but think it necessary to move about and talk, in order\nto show that they are not at all impatient for their food. The host and\nhostess look toward the door, and now and then glance at one another,\nand the visitors try to guess from these glances who, or what, they are\nwaiting for\xe2\x80\x94some important relation who has not yet arrived, or a dish\nthat is not yet ready.\n\n     * Hors d\xe2\x80\x99oeuvres.\n\nPierre had come just at dinnertime and was sitting awkwardly in the\nmiddle of the drawing room on the first chair he had come across,\nblocking the way for everyone. The countess tried to make him talk,\nbut he went on na\xc3\xafvely looking around through his spectacles as if in\nsearch of somebody and answered all her questions in monosyllables. He\nwas in the way and was the only one who did not notice the fact. Most of\nthe guests, knowing of the affair with the bear, looked with curiosity\nat this big, stout, quiet man, wondering how such a clumsy, modest\nfellow could have played such a prank on a policeman.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have only lately arrived?\xe2\x80\x9d the countess asked him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOui, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, looking around him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have not yet seen my husband?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNon, madame.\xe2\x80\x9d He smiled quite inappropriately.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have been in Paris recently, I believe? I suppose it\xe2\x80\x99s very\ninteresting.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery interesting.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe countess exchanged glances with Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna. The latter\nunderstood that she was being asked to entertain this young man, and\nsitting down beside him she began to speak about his father; but he\nanswered her, as he had the countess, only in monosyllables. The other\nguests were all conversing with one another. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Razum\xc3\xb3vskis... It\nwas charming... You are very kind... Countess Apr\xc3\xa1ksina...\xe2\x80\x9d was heard\non all sides. The countess rose and went into the ballroom.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cM\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna?\xe2\x80\x9d came her voice from there.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHerself,\xe2\x80\x9d came the answer in a rough voice, and M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\nentered the room.\n\nAll the unmarried ladies and even the married ones except the very\noldest rose. M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna paused at the door. Tall and stout,\nholding high her fifty-year-old head with its gray curls, she stood\nsurveying the guests, and leisurely arranged her wide sleeves as if\nrolling them up. M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna always spoke in Russian.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHealth and happiness to her whose name day we are keeping and to her\nchildren,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, in her loud, full-toned voice which drowned all\nothers. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, you old sinner,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on, turning to the count\nwho was kissing her hand, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re feeling dull in Moscow, I daresay?\nNowhere to hunt with your dogs? But what is to be done, old man? Just\nsee how these nestlings are growing up,\xe2\x80\x9d and she pointed to the girls.\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must look for husbands for them whether you like it or not....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9chow\xe2\x80\x99s my Cossack?\xe2\x80\x9d (M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\nalways called Nat\xc3\xa1sha a Cossack) and she stroked the child\xe2\x80\x99s arm as\nshe came up fearless and gay to kiss her hand. \xe2\x80\x9cI know she\xe2\x80\x99s a scamp\nof a girl, but I like her.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe took a pair of pear-shaped ruby earrings from her huge reticule and,\nhaving given them to the rosy Nat\xc3\xa1sha, who beamed with the pleasure\nof her saint\xe2\x80\x99s-day fete, turned away at once and addressed herself to\nPierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, eh, friend! Come here a bit,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, assuming a soft high\ntone of voice. \xe2\x80\x9cCome here, my friend...\xe2\x80\x9d and she ominously tucked\nup her sleeves still higher. Pierre approached, looking at her in a\nchildlike way through his spectacles.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome nearer, come nearer, friend! I used to be the only one to tell\nyour father the truth when he was in favor, and in your case it\xe2\x80\x99s my\nevident duty.\xe2\x80\x9d She paused. All were silent, expectant of what was to\nfollow, for this was clearly only a prelude.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA fine lad! My word! A fine lad!... His father lies on his deathbed\nand he amuses himself setting a policeman astride a bear! For shame,\nsir, for shame! It would be better if you went to the war.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe turned away and gave her hand to the count, who could hardly keep\nfrom laughing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I suppose it is time we were at table?\xe2\x80\x9d said M\xc3\xa1rya\nDm\xc3\xadtrievna.\n\nThe count went in first with M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna, the countess followed\non the arm of a colonel of hussars, a man of importance to them because\nNicholas was to go with him to the regiment; then came Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna\nwith Shinsh\xc3\xadn. Berg gave his arm to V\xc3\xa9ra. The smiling Julie Kar\xc3\xa1gina\nwent in with Nicholas. After them other couples followed, filling the\nwhole dining hall, and last of all the children, tutors, and governesses\nfollowed singly. The footmen began moving about, chairs scraped, the\nband struck up in the gallery, and the guests settled down in their\nplaces. Then the strains of the count\xe2\x80\x99s household band were replaced\nby the clatter of knives and forks, the voices of visitors, and the\nsoft steps of the footmen. At one end of the table sat the countess with\nM\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna on her right and Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna on her left, the\nother lady visitors were farther down. At the other end sat the count,\nwith the hussar colonel on his left and Shinsh\xc3\xadn and the other male\nvisitors on his right. Midway down the long table on one side sat the\ngrown-up young people: V\xc3\xa9ra beside Berg, and Pierre beside Bor\xc3\xads; and\non the other side, the children, tutors, and governesses. From behind\nthe crystal decanters and fruit vases, the count kept glancing at his\nwife and her tall cap with its light-blue ribbons, and busily filled\nhis neighbors\xe2\x80\x99 glasses, not neglecting his own. The countess in turn,\nwithout omitting her duties as hostess, threw significant glances from\nbehind the pineapples at her husband whose face and bald head seemed\nby their redness to contrast more than usual with his gray hair. At the\nladies\xe2\x80\x99 end an even chatter of voices was heard all the time, at the\nmen\xe2\x80\x99s end the voices sounded louder and louder, especially that of the\ncolonel of hussars who, growing more and more flushed, ate and drank so\nmuch that the count held him up as a pattern to the other guests. Berg\nwith tender smiles was saying to V\xc3\xa9ra that love is not an earthly but\na heavenly feeling. Bor\xc3\xads was telling his new friend Pierre who the\nguests were and exchanging glances with Nat\xc3\xa1sha, who was sitting\nopposite. Pierre spoke little but examined the new faces, and ate a\ngreat deal. Of the two soups he chose turtle with savory patties and\nwent on to the game without omitting a single dish or one of the wines.\nThese latter the butler thrust mysteriously forward, wrapped in a\nnapkin, from behind the next man\xe2\x80\x99s shoulders and whispered: \xe2\x80\x9cDry\nMadeira\xe2\x80\x9d... \xe2\x80\x9cHungarian\xe2\x80\x9d... or \xe2\x80\x9cRhine wine\xe2\x80\x9d as the case might\nbe. Of the four crystal glasses engraved with the count\xe2\x80\x99s monogram\nthat stood before his plate, Pierre held out one at random and drank\nwith enjoyment, gazing with ever-increasing amiability at the other\nguests. Nat\xc3\xa1sha, who sat opposite, was looking at Bor\xc3\xads as girls of\nthirteen look at the boy they are in love with and have just kissed for\nthe first time. Sometimes that same look fell on Pierre, and that funny\nlively little girl\xe2\x80\x99s look made him inclined to laugh without knowing\nwhy.\n\nNicholas sat at some distance from S\xc3\xb3nya, beside Julie Kar\xc3\xa1gina, to\nwhom he was again talking with the same involuntary smile. S\xc3\xb3nya wore\na company smile but was evidently tormented by jealousy; now she turned\npale, now blushed and strained every nerve to overhear what Nicholas\nand Julie were saying to one another. The governess kept looking round\nuneasily as if preparing to resent any slight that might be put upon the\nchildren. The German tutor was trying to remember all the dishes, wines,\nand kinds of dessert, in order to send a full description of the dinner\nto his people in Germany; and he felt greatly offended when the butler\nwith a bottle wrapped in a napkin passed him by. He frowned, trying to\nappear as if he did not want any of that wine, but was mortified because\nno one would understand that it was not to quench his thirst or from\ngreediness that he wanted it, but simply from a conscientious desire for\nknowledge.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIX\n\nAt the men\xe2\x80\x99s end of the table the talk grew more and more animated.\nThe colonel told them that the declaration of war had already appeared\nin Petersburg and that a copy, which he had himself seen, had that day\nbeen forwarded by courier to the commander in chief.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why the deuce are we going to fight Bonaparte?\xe2\x80\x9d remarked\nShinsh\xc3\xadn. \xe2\x80\x9cHe has stopped Austria\xe2\x80\x99s cackle and I fear it will be\nour turn next.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe colonel was a stout, tall, plethoric German, evidently devoted to\nthe service and patriotically Russian. He resented Shinsh\xc3\xadn\xe2\x80\x99s remark.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is for the reasson, my goot sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, speaking with a\nGerman accent, \xe2\x80\x9cfor the reasson zat ze Emperor knows zat. He\ndeclares in ze manifessto zat he cannot fiew wiz indifference ze danger\nvreatening Russia and zat ze safety and dignity of ze Empire as vell\nas ze sanctity of its alliances...\xe2\x80\x9d he spoke this last word with\nparticular emphasis as if in it lay the gist of the matter.\n\nThen with the unerring official memory that characterized him he\nrepeated from the opening words of the manifesto:\n\n... and the wish, which constitutes the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s sole and absolute\naim\xe2\x80\x94to establish peace in Europe on firm foundations\xe2\x80\x94has now decided\nhim to despatch part of the army abroad and to create a new condition\nfor the attainment of that purpose.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cZat, my dear sir, is vy...\xe2\x80\x9d he concluded, drinking a tumbler of\nwine with dignity and looking to the count for approval.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cConnaissez-vous le Proverbe:* \xe2\x80\x98Jerome, Jerome, do not roam, but\nturn spindles at home!\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d said Shinsh\xc3\xadn, puckering his brows and\nsmiling. \xe2\x80\x9cCela nous convient \xc3\xa0 merveille.*(2) Suv\xc3\xb3rov now\xe2\x80\x94he knew\nwhat he was about; yet they beat him \xc3\xa0 plate couture,*(3) and where\nare we to find Suv\xc3\xb3rovs now? Je vous demande un peu,\xe2\x80\x9d *(4) said he,\ncontinually changing from French to Russian.\n\n     *Do you know the proverb?\n\n     *(2) That suits us down to the ground.\n\n     *(3) Hollow.\n\n     *(4) I just ask you that.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVe must vight to the last tr-r-op of our plood!\xe2\x80\x9d said the colonel,\nthumping the table; \xe2\x80\x9cand ve must tie for our Emperor, and zen all vill\npe vell. And ve must discuss it as little as po-o-ossible\xe2\x80\x9d... he dwelt\nparticularly on the word possible... \xe2\x80\x9cas po-o-ossible,\xe2\x80\x9d he ended,\nagain turning to the count. \xe2\x80\x9cZat is how ve old hussars look at it, and\nzere\xe2\x80\x99s an end of it! And how do you, a young man and a young hussar,\nhow do you judge of it?\xe2\x80\x9d he added, addressing Nicholas, who when he\nheard that the war was being discussed had turned from his partner with\neyes and ears intent on the colonel.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am quite of your opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Nicholas, flaming up, turning\nhis plate round and moving his wineglasses about with as much decision\nand desperation as though he were at that moment facing some great\ndanger. \xe2\x80\x9cI am convinced that we Russians must die or conquer,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nconcluded, conscious\xe2\x80\x94as were others\xe2\x80\x94after the words were uttered\nthat his remarks were too enthusiastic and emphatic for the occasion and\nwere therefore awkward.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you said just now was splendid!\xe2\x80\x9d said his partner Julie.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya trembled all over and blushed to her ears and behind them and\ndown to her neck and shoulders while Nicholas was speaking.\n\nPierre listened to the colonel\xe2\x80\x99s speech and nodded approvingly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s fine,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe young man\xe2\x80\x99s a real hussar!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the colonel, again\nthumping the table.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you making such a noise about over there?\xe2\x80\x9d M\xc3\xa1rya\nDm\xc3\xadtrievna\xe2\x80\x99s deep voice suddenly inquired from the other end of the\ntable. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you thumping the table for?\xe2\x80\x9d she demanded of the\nhussar, \xe2\x80\x9cand why are you exciting yourself? Do you think the French\nare here?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am speaking ze truce,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the hussar with a smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all about the war,\xe2\x80\x9d the count shouted down the table. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\nknow my son\xe2\x80\x99s going, M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna? My son is going.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have four sons in the army but still I don\xe2\x80\x99t fret. It is all\nin God\xe2\x80\x99s hands. You may die in your bed or God may spare you in a\nbattle,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\xe2\x80\x99s deep voice, which easily\ncarried the whole length of the table.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nOnce more the conversations concentrated, the ladies\xe2\x80\x99 at the one end\nand the men\xe2\x80\x99s at the other.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou won\xe2\x80\x99t ask,\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s little brother was saying; \xe2\x80\x9cI know\nyou won\xe2\x80\x99t ask!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\nHer face suddenly flushed with reckless and joyous resolution. She half\nrose, by a glance inviting Pierre, who sat opposite, to listen to what\nwas coming, and turning to her mother:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma!\xe2\x80\x9d rang out the clear contralto notes of her childish voice,\naudible the whole length of the table.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the countess, startled; but seeing by her\ndaughter\xe2\x80\x99s face that it was only mischief, she shook a finger at her\nsternly with a threatening and forbidding movement of her head.\n\nThe conversation was hushed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma! What sweets are we going to have?\xe2\x80\x9d and Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s voice\nsounded still more firm and resolute.\n\nThe countess tried to frown, but could not. M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna shook her\nfat finger.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCossack!\xe2\x80\x9d she said threateningly.\n\nMost of the guests, uncertain how to regard this sally, looked at the\nelders.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou had better take care!\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma! What sweets are we going to have?\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha again cried\nboldly, with saucy gaiety, confident that her prank would be taken in\ngood part.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya and fat little P\xc3\xa9tya doubled up with laughter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see! I have asked,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Nat\xc3\xa1sha to her little brother\nand to Pierre, glancing at him again.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIce pudding, but you won\xe2\x80\x99t get any,\xe2\x80\x9d said M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha saw there was nothing to be afraid of and so she braved even\nM\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cM\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna! What kind of ice pudding? I don\xe2\x80\x99t like ice\ncream.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCarrot ices.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! What kind, M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna? What kind?\xe2\x80\x9d she almost screamed;\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to know!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nM\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna and the countess burst out laughing, and all the\nguests joined in. Everyone laughed, not at M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\xe2\x80\x99s answer\nbut at the incredible boldness and smartness of this little girl who had\ndared to treat M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna in this fashion.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha only desisted when she had been told that there would be\npineapple ice. Before the ices, champagne was served round. The band\nagain struck up, the count and countess kissed, and the guests, leaving\ntheir seats, went up to \xe2\x80\x9ccongratulate\xe2\x80\x9d the countess, and reached\nacross the table to clink glasses with the count, with the children, and\nwith one another. Again the footmen rushed about, chairs scraped, and\nin the same order in which they had entered but with redder faces, the\nguests returned to the drawing room and to the count\xe2\x80\x99s study.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XX\n\nThe card tables were drawn out, sets made up for boston, and the\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s visitors settled themselves, some in the two drawing rooms,\nsome in the sitting room, some in the library.\n\nThe count, holding his cards fanwise, kept himself with difficulty from\ndropping into his usual after-dinner nap, and laughed at everything.\nThe young people, at the countess\xe2\x80\x99 instigation, gathered round the\nclavichord and harp. Julie by general request played first. After she\nhad played a little air with variations on the harp, she joined the\nother young ladies in begging Nat\xc3\xa1sha and Nicholas, who were noted for\ntheir musical talent, to sing something. Nat\xc3\xa1sha, who was treated as\nthough she were grown up, was evidently very proud of this but at the\nsame time felt shy.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall we sing?\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The Brook,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d suggested Nicholas.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, let\xe2\x80\x99s be quick. Bor\xc3\xads, come here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where is S\xc3\xb3nya?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe looked round and seeing that her friend was not in the room ran to\nlook for her.\n\nRunning into S\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s room and not finding her there, Nat\xc3\xa1sha ran to\nthe nursery, but S\xc3\xb3nya was not there either. Nat\xc3\xa1sha concluded that\nshe must be on the chest in the passage. The chest in the passage was\nthe place of mourning for the younger female generation in the Rost\xc3\xb3v\nhousehold. And there in fact was S\xc3\xb3nya lying face downward on Nurse\xe2\x80\x99s\ndirty feather bed on the top of the chest, crumpling her gauzy pink\ndress under her, hiding her face with her slender fingers, and sobbing\nso convulsively that her bare little shoulders shook. Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s\nface, which had been so radiantly happy all that saint\xe2\x80\x99s day, suddenly\nchanged: her eyes became fixed, and then a shiver passed down her broad\nneck and the corners of her mouth drooped.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xb3nya! What is it? What is the matter?... Oo... Oo... Oo...!\xe2\x80\x9d And\nNat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s large mouth widened, making her look quite ugly, and she\nbegan to wail like a baby without knowing why, except that S\xc3\xb3nya was\ncrying. S\xc3\xb3nya tried to lift her head to answer but could not, and\nhid her face still deeper in the bed. Nat\xc3\xa1sha wept, sitting on the\nblue-striped feather bed and hugging her friend. With an effort S\xc3\xb3nya\nsat up and began wiping her eyes and explaining.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNicholas is going away in a week\xe2\x80\x99s time, his... papers... have\ncome... he told me himself... but still I should not cry,\xe2\x80\x9d and she\nshowed a paper she held in her hand\xe2\x80\x94with the verses Nicholas had\nwritten, \xe2\x80\x9cstill, I should not cry, but you can\xe2\x80\x99t... no one can\nunderstand... what a soul he has!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd she began to cry again because he had such a noble soul.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all very well for you... I am not envious... I love you and\nBor\xc3\xads also,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on, gaining a little strength; \xe2\x80\x9che is nice...\nthere are no difficulties in your way.... But Nicholas is my cousin...\none would have to... the Metropolitan himself... and even then it\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t be done. And besides, if she tells Mamma\xe2\x80\x9d (S\xc3\xb3nya looked upon\nthe countess as her mother and called her so) \xe2\x80\x9cthat I am spoiling\nNicholas\xe2\x80\x99 career and am heartless and ungrateful, while truly... God\nis my witness,\xe2\x80\x9d and she made the sign of the cross, \xe2\x80\x9cI love her so\nmuch, and all of you, only V\xc3\xa9ra... And what for? What have I done\nto her? I am so grateful to you that I would willingly sacrifice\neverything, only I have nothing....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya could not continue, and again hid her face in her hands and in\nthe feather bed. Nat\xc3\xa1sha began consoling her, but her face showed that\nshe understood all the gravity of her friend\xe2\x80\x99s trouble.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xb3nya,\xe2\x80\x9d she suddenly exclaimed, as if she had guessed the true\nreason of her friend\xe2\x80\x99s sorrow, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure V\xc3\xa9ra has said something\nto you since dinner? Hasn\xe2\x80\x99t she?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, these verses Nicholas wrote himself and I copied some others,\nand she found them on my table and said she\xe2\x80\x99d show them to Mamma, and\nthat I was ungrateful, and that Mamma would never allow him to marry\nme, but that he\xe2\x80\x99ll marry Julie. You see how he\xe2\x80\x99s been with her all\nday... Nat\xc3\xa1sha, what have I done to deserve it?...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd again she began to sob, more bitterly than before. Nat\xc3\xa1sha lifted\nher up, hugged her, and, smiling through her tears, began comforting\nher.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xb3nya, don\xe2\x80\x99t believe her, darling! Don\xe2\x80\x99t believe her! Do you\nremember how we and Nicholas, all three of us, talked in the sitting\nroom after supper? Why, we settled how everything was to be. I don\xe2\x80\x99t\nquite remember how, but don\xe2\x80\x99t you remember that it could all be\narranged and how nice it all was? There\xe2\x80\x99s Uncle Shinsh\xc3\xadn\xe2\x80\x99s brother\nhas married his first cousin. And we are only second cousins, you know.\nAnd Bor\xc3\xads says it is quite possible. You know I have told him all about\nit. And he is so clever and so good!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t\nyou cry, S\xc3\xb3nya, dear love, darling S\xc3\xb3nya!\xe2\x80\x9d and she kissed her and\nlaughed. \xe2\x80\x9cV\xc3\xa9ra\xe2\x80\x99s spiteful; never mind her! And all will come right\nand she won\xe2\x80\x99t say anything to Mamma. Nicholas will tell her himself,\nand he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t care at all for Julie.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha kissed her on the hair.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya sat up. The little kitten brightened, its eyes shone, and it\nseemed ready to lift its tail, jump down on its soft paws, and begin\nplaying with the ball of worsted as a kitten should.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think so?... Really? Truly?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, quickly smoothing her\nfrock and hair.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, truly!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Nat\xc3\xa1sha, pushing in a crisp lock that had\nstrayed from under her friend\xe2\x80\x99s plaits.\n\nBoth laughed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, let\xe2\x80\x99s go and sing \xe2\x80\x98The Brook.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome along!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, that fat Pierre who sat opposite me is so funny!\xe2\x80\x9d said\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, stopping suddenly. \xe2\x80\x9cI feel so happy!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd she set off at a run along the passage.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya, shaking off some down which clung to her and tucking away the\nverses in the bosom of her dress close to her bony little chest, ran\nafter Nat\xc3\xa1sha down the passage into the sitting room with flushed face\nand light, joyous steps. At the visitors\xe2\x80\x99 request the young people\nsang the quartette, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Brook,\xe2\x80\x9d with which everyone was delighted.\nThen Nicholas sang a song he had just learned:\n\n   At nighttime in the moon\xe2\x80\x99s fair glow\n     How sweet, as fancies wander free,\n   To feel that in this world there\xe2\x80\x99s one\n     Who still is thinking but of thee!\n\n   That while her fingers touch the harp\n     Wafting sweet music o\xe2\x80\x99er the lea,\n   It is for thee thus swells her heart,\n     Sighing its message out to thee...\n\n   A day or two, then bliss unspoilt,\n     But oh! till then I cannot live!...\n\nHe had not finished the last verse before the young people began to\nget ready to dance in the large hall, and the sound of the feet and the\ncoughing of the musicians were heard from the gallery.\n\n\nPierre was sitting in the drawing room where Shinsh\xc3\xadn had engaged him,\nas a man recently returned from abroad, in a political conversation in\nwhich several others joined but which bored Pierre. When the music began\nNat\xc3\xa1sha came in and walking straight up to Pierre said, laughing and\nblushing:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma told me to ask you to join the dancers.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid of mixing the figures,\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre replied; \xe2\x80\x9cbut if you\nwill be my teacher...\xe2\x80\x9d And lowering his big arm he offered it to the\nslender little girl.\n\nWhile the couples were arranging themselves and the musicians tuning up,\nPierre sat down with his little partner. Nat\xc3\xa1sha was perfectly happy;\nshe was dancing with a grown-up man, who had been abroad. She was\nsitting in a conspicuous place and talking to him like a grown-up lady.\nShe had a fan in her hand that one of the ladies had given her to hold.\nAssuming quite the pose of a society woman (heaven knows when and where\nshe had learned it) she talked with her partner, fanning herself and\nsmiling over the fan.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear, dear! Just look at her!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the countess as she\ncrossed the ballroom, pointing to Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha blushed and laughed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, really, Mamma! Why should you? What is there to be surprised\nat?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nIn the midst of the third \xc3\xa9cossaise there was a clatter of chairs being\npushed back in the sitting room where the count and M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\nhad been playing cards with the majority of the more distinguished and\nolder visitors. They now, stretching themselves after sitting so long,\nand replacing their purses and pocketbooks, entered the ballroom. First\ncame M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna and the count, both with merry countenances. The\ncount, with playful ceremony somewhat in ballet style, offered his\nbent arm to M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna. He drew himself up, a smile of debonair\ngallantry lit up his face and as soon as the last figure of the\n\xc3\xa9cossaise was ended, he clapped his hands to the musicians and shouted\nup to their gallery, addressing the first violin:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSem\xc3\xabn! Do you know the Daniel Cooper?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThis was the count\xe2\x80\x99s favorite dance, which he had danced in his youth.\n(Strictly speaking, Daniel Cooper was one figure of the anglaise.)\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook at Papa!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Nat\xc3\xa1sha to the whole company, and quite\nforgetting that she was dancing with a grown-up partner she bent her\ncurly head to her knees and made the whole room ring with her laughter.\n\nAnd indeed everybody in the room looked with a smile of pleasure at the\njovial old gentleman, who standing beside his tall and stout partner,\nM\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna, curved his arms, beat time, straightened his\nshoulders, turned out his toes, tapped gently with his foot, and, by\na smile that broadened his round face more and more, prepared the\nonlookers for what was to follow. As soon as the provocatively gay\nstrains of Daniel Cooper (somewhat resembling those of a merry peasant\ndance) began to sound, all the doorways of the ballroom were suddenly\nfilled by the domestic serfs\xe2\x80\x94the men on one side and the women on\nthe other\xe2\x80\x94who with beaming faces had come to see their master making\nmerry.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust look at the master! A regular eagle he is!\xe2\x80\x9d loudly remarked\nthe nurse, as she stood in one of the doorways.\n\nThe count danced well and knew it. But his partner could not and did not\nwant to dance well. Her enormous figure stood erect, her powerful arms\nhanging down (she had handed her reticule to the countess), and only her\nstern but handsome face really joined in the dance. What was expressed\nby the whole of the count\xe2\x80\x99s plump figure, in M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna found\nexpression only in her more and more beaming face and quivering nose.\nBut if the count, getting more and more into the swing of it, charmed\nthe spectators by the unexpectedness of his adroit maneuvers and\nthe agility with which he capered about on his light feet, M\xc3\xa1rya\nDm\xc3\xadtrievna produced no less impression by slight exertions\xe2\x80\x94the least\neffort to move her shoulders or bend her arms when turning, or stamp\nher foot\xe2\x80\x94which everyone appreciated in view of her size and habitual\nseverity. The dance grew livelier and livelier. The other couples could\nnot attract a moment\xe2\x80\x99s attention to their own evolutions and did not\neven try to do so. All were watching the count and M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna.\nNat\xc3\xa1sha kept pulling everyone by sleeve or dress, urging them to\n\xe2\x80\x9clook at Papa!\xe2\x80\x9d though as it was they never took their eyes off the\ncouple. In the intervals of the dance the count, breathing deeply, waved\nand shouted to the musicians to play faster. Faster, faster, and faster;\nlightly, more lightly, and yet more lightly whirled the count, flying\nround M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna, now on his toes, now on his heels; until,\nturning his partner round to her seat, he executed the final pas,\nraising his soft foot backwards, bowing his perspiring head, smiling\nand making a wide sweep with his arm, amid a thunder of applause and\nlaughter led by Nat\xc3\xa1sha. Both partners stood still, breathing heavily\nand wiping their faces with their cambric handkerchiefs.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s how we used to dance in our time, ma ch\xc3\xa8re,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\ncount.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was a Daniel Cooper!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna, tucking up\nher sleeves and puffing heavily.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XXI\n\nWhile in the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 ballroom the sixth anglaise was being danced,\nto a tune in which the weary musicians blundered, and while tired\nfootmen and cooks were getting the supper, Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov had a\nsixth stroke. The doctors pronounced recovery impossible. After a mute\nconfession, communion was administered to the dying man, preparations\nmade for the sacrament of unction, and in his house there was the bustle\nand thrill of suspense usual at such moments. Outside the house, beyond\nthe gates, a group of undertakers, who hid whenever a carriage drove up,\nwaited in expectation of an important order for an expensive funeral.\nThe Military Governor of Moscow, who had been assiduous in sending\naides-de-camp to inquire after the count\xe2\x80\x99s health, came himself\nthat evening to bid a last farewell to the celebrated grandee of\nCatherine\xe2\x80\x99s court, Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov.\n\nThe magnificent reception room was crowded. Everyone stood up\nrespectfully when the Military Governor, having stayed about half an\nhour alone with the dying man, passed out, slightly acknowledging their\nbows and trying to escape as quickly as possible from the glances fixed\non him by the doctors, clergy, and relatives of the family. Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli, who had grown thinner and paler during the last few days,\nescorted him to the door, repeating something to him several times in\nlow tones.\n\nWhen the Military Governor had gone, Prince Vas\xc3\xadli sat down all alone\non a chair in the ballroom, crossing one leg high over the other,\nleaning his elbow on his knee and covering his face with his hand. After\nsitting so for a while he rose, and, looking about him with frightened\neyes, went with unusually hurried steps down the long corridor leading\nto the back of the house, to the room of the eldest princess.\n\nThose who were in the dimly lit reception room spoke in nervous\nwhispers, and, whenever anyone went into or came from the dying man\xe2\x80\x99s\nroom, grew silent and gazed with eyes full of curiosity or expectancy at\nhis door, which creaked slightly when opened.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe limits of human life ... are fixed and may not be\no\xe2\x80\x99erpassed,\xe2\x80\x9d said an old priest to a lady who had taken a seat\nbeside him and was listening na\xc3\xafvely to his words.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder, is it not too late to administer unction?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the\nlady, adding the priest\xe2\x80\x99s clerical title, as if she had no opinion of\nher own on the subject.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, madam, it is a great sacrament,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the priest, passing\nhis hand over the thin grizzled strands of hair combed back across his\nbald head.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho was that? The Military Governor himself?\xe2\x80\x9d was being asked at\nthe other side of the room. \xe2\x80\x9cHow young-looking he is!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and he is over sixty. I hear the count no longer recognizes\nanyone. They wished to administer the sacrament of unction.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew someone who received that sacrament seven times.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe second princess had just come from the sickroom with her eyes red\nfrom weeping and sat down beside Dr. Lorrain, who was sitting in a\ngraceful pose under a portrait of Catherine, leaning his elbow on a\ntable.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeautiful,\xe2\x80\x9d said the doctor in answer to a remark about the\nweather. \xe2\x80\x9cThe weather is beautiful, Princess; and besides, in Moscow\none feels as if one were in the country.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the princess with a sigh. \xe2\x80\x9cSo he may have\nsomething to drink?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nLorrain considered.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas he taken his medicine?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe doctor glanced at his watch.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake a glass of boiled water and put a pinch of cream of tartar,\xe2\x80\x9d\nand he indicated with his delicate fingers what he meant by a pinch.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDere has neffer been a gase,\xe2\x80\x9d a German doctor was saying to an\naide-de-camp, \xe2\x80\x9cdat one liffs after de sird stroke.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what a well-preserved man he was!\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the aide-de-camp.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who will inherit his wealth?\xe2\x80\x9d he added in a whisper.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt von\xe2\x80\x99t go begging,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the German with a smile.\n\nEveryone again looked toward the door, which creaked as the second\nprincess went in with the drink she had prepared according to\nLorrain\xe2\x80\x99s instructions. The German doctor went up to Lorrain.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think he can last till morning?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the German,\naddressing Lorrain in French which he pronounced badly.\n\nLorrain, pursing up his lips, waved a severely negative finger before\nhis nose.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTonight, not later,\xe2\x80\x9d said he in a low voice, and he moved away\nwith a decorous smile of self-satisfaction at being able clearly to\nunderstand and state the patient\xe2\x80\x99s condition.\n\nMeanwhile Prince Vas\xc3\xadli had opened the door into the princess\xe2\x80\x99 room.\n\nIn this room it was almost dark; only two tiny lamps were burning before\nthe icons and there was a pleasant scent of flowers and burnt pastilles.\nThe room was crowded with small pieces of furniture, whatnots,\ncupboards, and little tables. The quilt of a high, white feather bed was\njust visible behind a screen. A small dog began to bark.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, is it you, cousin?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe rose and smoothed her hair, which was as usual so extremely smooth\nthat it seemed to be made of one piece with her head and covered with\nvarnish.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas anything happened?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked. \xe2\x80\x9cI am so terrified.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, there is no change. I only came to have a talk about business,\nCatiche,\xe2\x80\x9d * muttered the prince, seating himself wearily on the chair\nshe had just vacated. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have made the place warm, I must say,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nremarked. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, sit down: let\xe2\x80\x99s have a talk.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n     *Catherine.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought perhaps something had happened,\xe2\x80\x9d she said with her\nunchanging stonily severe expression; and, sitting down opposite the\nprince, she prepared to listen.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wished to get a nap, mon cousin, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Vas\xc3\xadli, taking her hand and bending it\ndownwards as was his habit.\n\nIt was plain that this \xe2\x80\x9cwell?\xe2\x80\x9d referred to much that they both\nunderstood without naming.\n\nThe princess, who had a straight, rigid body, abnormally long for her\nlegs, looked directly at Prince Vas\xc3\xadli with no sign of emotion in her\nprominent gray eyes. Then she shook her head and glanced up at the icons\nwith a sigh. This might have been taken as an expression of sorrow\nand devotion, or of weariness and hope of resting before long. Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli understood it as an expression of weariness.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I?\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cdo you think it is easier for me? I am as worn\nout as a post horse, but still I must have a talk with you, Catiche, a\nvery serious talk.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli said no more and his cheeks began to twitch nervously,\nnow on one side, now on the other, giving his face an unpleasant\nexpression which was never to be seen on it in a drawing room. His eyes\ntoo seemed strange; at one moment they looked impudently sly and at the\nnext glanced round in alarm.\n\nThe princess, holding her little dog on her lap with her thin bony\nhands, looked attentively into Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s eyes evidently\nresolved not to be the first to break silence, if she had to wait till\nmorning.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you see, my dear princess and cousin, Catherine Sem\xc3\xabnovna,\xe2\x80\x9d\ncontinued Prince Vas\xc3\xadli, returning to his theme, apparently not\nwithout an inner struggle; \xe2\x80\x9cat such a moment as this one must think\nof everything. One must think of the future, of all of you... I love you\nall, like children of my own, as you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe princess continued to look at him without moving, and with the same\ndull expression.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then of course my family has also to be considered,\xe2\x80\x9d Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli went on, testily pushing away a little table without looking at\nher. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know, Catiche, that we\xe2\x80\x94you three sisters, M\xc3\xa1montov, and\nmy wife\xe2\x80\x94are the count\xe2\x80\x99s only direct heirs. I know, I know how hard\nit is for you to talk or think of such matters. It is no easier for\nme; but, my dear, I am getting on for sixty and must be prepared for\nanything. Do you know I have sent for Pierre? The count,\xe2\x80\x9d pointing to\nhis portrait, \xe2\x80\x9cdefinitely demanded that he should be called.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli looked questioningly at the princess, but could not make\nout whether she was considering what he had just said or whether she was\nsimply looking at him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is one thing I constantly pray God to grant, mon cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d she\nreplied, \xe2\x80\x9cand it is that He would be merciful to him and would allow\nhis noble soul peacefully to leave this...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, of course,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Prince Vas\xc3\xadli impatiently,\nrubbing his bald head and angrily pulling back toward him the little\ntable that he had pushed away. \xe2\x80\x9cBut... in short, the fact is... you\nknow yourself that last winter the count made a will by which he left\nall his property, not to us his direct heirs, but to Pierre.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has made wills enough!\xe2\x80\x9d quietly remarked the princess. \xe2\x80\x9cBut he\ncannot leave the estate to Pierre. Pierre is illegitimate.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Vas\xc3\xadli suddenly, clutching the little\ntable and becoming more animated and talking more rapidly: \xe2\x80\x9cwhat if\na letter has been written to the Emperor in which the count asks for\nPierre\xe2\x80\x99s legitimation? Do you understand that in consideration of the\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s services, his request would be granted?...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe princess smiled as people do who think they know more about the\nsubject under discussion than those they are talking with.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can tell you more,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Prince Vas\xc3\xadli, seizing her hand,\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat letter was written, though it was not sent, and the Emperor knew\nof it. The only question is, has it been destroyed or not? If not, then\nas soon as all is over,\xe2\x80\x9d and Prince Vas\xc3\xadli sighed to intimate what he\nmeant by the words all is over, \xe2\x80\x9cand the count\xe2\x80\x99s papers are opened,\nthe will and letter will be delivered to the Emperor, and the petition\nwill certainly be granted. Pierre will get everything as the legitimate\nson.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd our share?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the princess smiling ironically, as if\nanything might happen, only not that.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, my poor Catiche, it is as clear as daylight! He will then be the\nlegal heir to everything and you won\xe2\x80\x99t get anything. You must know,\nmy dear, whether the will and letter were written, and whether they have\nbeen destroyed or not. And if they have somehow been overlooked, you\nought to know where they are, and must find them, because...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat next?\xe2\x80\x9d the princess interrupted, smiling sardonically and not\nchanging the expression of her eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cI am a woman, and you think we\nare all stupid; but I know this: an illegitimate son cannot inherit...\nun b\xc3\xa2tard!\xe2\x80\x9d* she added, as if supposing that this translation of the\nword would effectively prove to Prince Vas\xc3\xadli the invalidity of his\ncontention.\n\n     * A bastard.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, really, Catiche! Can\xe2\x80\x99t you understand! You are so\nintelligent, how is it you don\xe2\x80\x99t see that if the count has written a\nletter to the Emperor begging him to recognize Pierre as legitimate, it\nfollows that Pierre will not be Pierre but will become Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov,\nand will then inherit everything under the will? And if the will and\nletter are not destroyed, then you will have nothing but the consolation\nof having been dutiful et tout ce qui s\xe2\x80\x99ensuit!* That\xe2\x80\x99s certain.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n     * And all that follows therefrom.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know the will was made, but I also know that it is invalid;\nand you, mon cousin, seem to consider me a perfect fool,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\nprincess with the expression women assume when they suppose they are\nsaying something witty and stinging.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Princess Catherine Sem\xc3\xabnovna,\xe2\x80\x9d began Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\nimpatiently, \xe2\x80\x9cI came here not to wrangle with you, but to talk about\nyour interests as with a kinswoman, a good, kind, true relation. And I\ntell you for the tenth time that if the letter to the Emperor and the\nwill in Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s favor are among the count\xe2\x80\x99s papers, then, my dear\ngirl, you and your sisters are not heiresses! If you don\xe2\x80\x99t believe me,\nthen believe an expert. I have just been talking to Dm\xc3\xadtri On\xc3\xbafrich\xe2\x80\x9d\n(the family solicitor) \xe2\x80\x9cand he says the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAt this a sudden change evidently took place in the princess\xe2\x80\x99 ideas;\nher thin lips grew white, though her eyes did not change, and her voice\nwhen she began to speak passed through such transitions as she herself\nevidently did not expect.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat would be a fine thing!\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cI never wanted anything\nand I don\xe2\x80\x99t now.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe pushed the little dog off her lap and smoothed her dress.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this is gratitude\xe2\x80\x94this is recognition for those who have\nsacrificed everything for his sake!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s splendid!\nFine! I don\xe2\x80\x99t want anything, Prince.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but you are not the only one. There are your sisters...\xe2\x80\x9d\nreplied Prince Vas\xc3\xadli.\n\nBut the princess did not listen to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I knew it long ago but had forgotten. I knew that I could expect\nnothing but meanness, deceit, envy, intrigue, and ingratitude\xe2\x80\x94the\nblackest ingratitude\xe2\x80\x94in this house...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you or do you not know where that will is?\xe2\x80\x9d insisted Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli, his cheeks twitching more than ever.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I was a fool! I still believed in people, loved them, and\nsacrificed myself. But only the base, the vile succeed! I know who has\nbeen intriguing!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe princess wished to rise, but the prince held her by the hand. She\nhad the air of one who has suddenly lost faith in the whole human race.\nShe gave her companion an angry glance.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is still time, my dear. You must remember, Catiche, that it was\nall done casually in a moment of anger, of illness, and was afterwards\nforgotten. Our duty, my dear, is to rectify his mistake, to ease his\nlast moments by not letting him commit this injustice, and not to let\nhim die feeling that he is rendering unhappy those who...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho sacrificed everything for him,\xe2\x80\x9d chimed in the princess, who\nwould again have risen had not the prince still held her fast, \xe2\x80\x9cthough\nhe never could appreciate it. No, mon cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d she added with a sigh,\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall always remember that in this world one must expect no reward,\nthat in this world there is neither honor nor justice. In this world one\nhas to be cunning and cruel.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow come, come! Be reasonable. I know your excellent heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I have a wicked heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know your heart,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the prince. \xe2\x80\x9cI value your friendship\nand wish you to have as good an opinion of me. Don\xe2\x80\x99t upset yourself,\nand let us talk sensibly while there is still time, be it a day or be it\nbut an hour.... Tell me all you know about the will, and above all where\nit is. You must know. We will take it at once and show it to the\ncount. He has, no doubt, forgotten it and will wish to destroy it.\nYou understand that my sole desire is conscientiously to carry out his\nwishes; that is my only reason for being here. I came simply to help him\nand you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow I see it all! I know who has been intriguing\xe2\x80\x94I know!\xe2\x80\x9d cried\nthe princess.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s not the point, my dear.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s that prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9 of yours, that sweet Princess Drubetsk\xc3\xa1ya,\nthat Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna whom I would not take for a housemaid... the\ninfamous, vile woman!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not let us lose any time...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, don\xe2\x80\x99t talk to me! Last winter she wheedled herself in here and\ntold the count such vile, disgraceful things about us, especially about\nSophie\xe2\x80\x94I can\xe2\x80\x99t repeat them\xe2\x80\x94that it made the count quite ill and he\nwould not see us for a whole fortnight. I know it was then he wrote this\nvile, infamous paper, but I thought the thing was invalid.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve got to it at last\xe2\x80\x94why did you not tell me about it\nsooner?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s in the inlaid portfolio that he keeps under his pillow,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid the princess, ignoring his question. \xe2\x80\x9cNow I know! Yes; if I have\na sin, a great sin, it is hatred of that vile woman!\xe2\x80\x9d almost shrieked\nthe princess, now quite changed. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd what does she come worming\nherself in here for? But I will give her a piece of my mind. The time\nwill come!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XXII\n\nWhile these conversations were going on in the reception room and the\nprincess\xe2\x80\x99 room, a carriage containing Pierre (who had been sent for)\nand Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna (who found it necessary to accompany him) was\ndriving into the court of Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s house. As the wheels\nrolled softly over the straw beneath the windows, Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna,\nhaving turned with words of comfort to her companion, realized that\nhe was asleep in his corner and woke him up. Rousing himself, Pierre\nfollowed Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna out of the carriage, and only then began\nto think of the interview with his dying father which awaited him. He\nnoticed that they had not come to the front entrance but to the back\ndoor. While he was getting down from the carriage steps two men, who\nlooked like tradespeople, ran hurriedly from the entrance and hid in the\nshadow of the wall. Pausing for a moment, Pierre noticed several other\nmen of the same kind hiding in the shadow of the house on both sides.\nBut neither Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna nor the footman nor the coachman, who\ncould not help seeing these people, took any notice of them. \xe2\x80\x9cIt seems\nto be all right,\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre concluded, and followed Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna.\nShe hurriedly ascended the narrow dimly lit stone staircase, calling to\nPierre, who was lagging behind, to follow. Though he did not see why it\nwas necessary for him to go to the count at all, still less why he had\nto go by the back stairs, yet judging by Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna\xe2\x80\x99s air\nof assurance and haste, Pierre concluded that it was all absolutely\nnecessary. Halfway up the stairs they were almost knocked over by\nsome men who, carrying pails, came running downstairs, their boots\nclattering. These men pressed close to the wall to let Pierre and Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna pass and did not evince the least surprise at seeing them\nthere.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs this the way to the princesses\xe2\x80\x99 apartments?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna of one of them.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied a footman in a bold loud voice, as if anything were\nnow permissible; \xe2\x80\x9cthe door to the left, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps the count did not ask for me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre when he reached\nthe landing. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d better go to my own room.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna paused and waited for him to come up.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my friend!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, touching his arm as she had done her\nson\xe2\x80\x99s when speaking to him that afternoon, \xe2\x80\x9cbelieve me I suffer no\nless than you do, but be a man!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut really, hadn\xe2\x80\x99t I better go away?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, looking kindly at\nher over his spectacles.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear friend! Forget the wrongs that may have been done you.\nThink that he is your father ... perhaps in the agony of death.\xe2\x80\x9d She\nsighed. \xe2\x80\x9cI have loved you like a son from the first. Trust yourself to\nme, Pierre. I shall not forget your interests.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre did not understand a word, but the conviction that all this had\nto be grew stronger, and he meekly followed Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna who was\nalready opening a door.\n\nThis door led into a back anteroom. An old man, a servant of the\nprincesses, sat in a corner knitting a stocking. Pierre had never been\nin this part of the house and did not even know of the existence of\nthese rooms. Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, addressing a maid who was hurrying past\nwith a decanter on a tray as \xe2\x80\x9cmy dear\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cmy sweet,\xe2\x80\x9d asked\nabout the princess\xe2\x80\x99 health and then led Pierre along a stone passage.\nThe first door on the left led into the princesses\xe2\x80\x99 apartments. The\nmaid with the decanter in her haste had not closed the door (everything\nin the house was done in haste at that time), and Pierre and Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna in passing instinctively glanced into the room, where\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli and the eldest princess were sitting close together\ntalking. Seeing them pass, Prince Vas\xc3\xadli drew back with obvious\nimpatience, while the princess jumped up and with a gesture of\ndesperation slammed the door with all her might.\n\nThis action was so unlike her usual composure and the fear depicted on\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s face so out of keeping with his dignity that Pierre\nstopped and glanced inquiringly over his spectacles at his guide. Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna evinced no surprise, she only smiled faintly and sighed, as\nif to say that this was no more than she had expected.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe a man, my friend. I will look after your interests,\xe2\x80\x9d said she in\nreply to his look, and went still faster along the passage.\n\nPierre could not make out what it was all about, and still less what\n\xe2\x80\x9cwatching over his interests\xe2\x80\x9d meant, but he decided that all these\nthings had to be. From the passage they went into a large, dimly\nlit room adjoining the count\xe2\x80\x99s reception room. It was one of those\nsumptuous but cold apartments known to Pierre only from the front\napproach, but even in this room there now stood an empty bath, and water\nhad been spilled on the carpet. They were met by a deacon with a censer\nand by a servant who passed out on tiptoe without heeding them. They\nwent into the reception room familiar to Pierre, with two Italian\nwindows opening into the conservatory, with its large bust and full\nlength portrait of Catherine the Great. The same people were still\nsitting here in almost the same positions as before, whispering to one\nanother. All became silent and turned to look at the pale tear-worn Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna as she entered, and at the big stout figure of Pierre who,\nhanging his head, meekly followed her.\n\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna\xe2\x80\x99s face expressed a consciousness that the decisive\nmoment had arrived. With the air of a practical Petersburg lady she now,\nkeeping Pierre close beside her, entered the room even more boldly than\nthat afternoon. She felt that as she brought with her the person the\ndying man wished to see, her own admission was assured. Casting a rapid\nglance at all those in the room and noticing the count\xe2\x80\x99s confessor\nthere, she glided up to him with a sort of amble, not exactly bowing yet\nseeming to grow suddenly smaller, and respectfully received the blessing\nfirst of one and then of another priest.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod be thanked that you are in time,\xe2\x80\x9d said she to one of the\npriests; \xe2\x80\x9call we relatives have been in such anxiety. This young\nman is the count\xe2\x80\x99s son,\xe2\x80\x9d she added more softly. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a terrible\nmoment!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHaving said this she went up to the doctor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear doctor,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cthis young man is the count\xe2\x80\x99s son. Is\nthere any hope?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe doctor cast a rapid glance upwards and silently shrugged his\nshoulders. Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna with just the same movement raised her\nshoulders and eyes, almost closing the latter, sighed, and moved away\nfrom the doctor to Pierre. To him, in a particularly respectful and\ntenderly sad voice, she said:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrust in His mercy!\xe2\x80\x9d and pointing out a small sofa for him to sit\nand wait for her, she went silently toward the door that everyone was\nwatching and it creaked very slightly as she disappeared behind it.\n\nPierre, having made up his mind to obey his monitress implicitly, moved\ntoward the sofa she had indicated. As soon as Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna had\ndisappeared he noticed that the eyes of all in the room turned to him\nwith something more than curiosity and sympathy. He noticed that they\nwhispered to one another, casting significant looks at him with a kind\nof awe and even servility. A deference such as he had never before\nreceived was shown him. A strange lady, the one who had been talking to\nthe priests, rose and offered him her seat; an aide-de-camp picked up\nand returned a glove Pierre had dropped; the doctors became respectfully\nsilent as he passed by, and moved to make way for him. At first Pierre\nwished to take another seat so as not to trouble the lady, and also to\npick up the glove himself and to pass round the doctors who were not\neven in his way; but all at once he felt that this would not do, and\nthat tonight he was a person obliged to perform some sort of awful\nrite which everyone expected of him, and that he was therefore bound\nto accept their services. He took the glove in silence from the\naide-de-camp, and sat down in the lady\xe2\x80\x99s chair, placing his huge hands\nsymmetrically on his knees in the na\xc3\xafve attitude of an Egyptian statue,\nand decided in his own mind that all was as it should be, and that in\norder not to lose his head and do foolish things he must not act on his\nown ideas tonight, but must yield himself up entirely to the will of\nthose who were guiding him.\n\nNot two minutes had passed before Prince Vas\xc3\xadli with head erect\nmajestically entered the room. He was wearing his long coat with three\nstars on his breast. He seemed to have grown thinner since the morning;\nhis eyes seemed larger than usual when he glanced round and noticed\nPierre. He went up to him, took his hand (a thing he never used to do),\nand drew it downwards as if wishing to ascertain whether it was firmly\nfixed on.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCourage, courage, my friend! He has asked to see you. That is\nwell!\xe2\x80\x9d and he turned to go.\n\nBut Pierre thought it necessary to ask: \xe2\x80\x9cHow is...\xe2\x80\x9d and hesitated,\nnot knowing whether it would be proper to call the dying man \xe2\x80\x9cthe\ncount,\xe2\x80\x9d yet ashamed to call him \xe2\x80\x9cfather.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe had another stroke about half an hour ago. Courage, my\nfriend...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre\xe2\x80\x99s mind was in such a confused state that the word \xe2\x80\x9cstroke\xe2\x80\x9d\nsuggested to him a blow from something. He looked at Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\nin perplexity, and only later grasped that a stroke was an attack of\nillness. Prince Vas\xc3\xadli said something to Lorrain in passing and went\nthrough the door on tiptoe. He could not walk well on tiptoe and his\nwhole body jerked at each step. The eldest princess followed him, and\nthe priests and deacons and some servants also went in at the door.\nThrough that door was heard a noise of things being moved about, and\nat last Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, still with the same expression, pale but\nresolute in the discharge of duty, ran out and touching Pierre lightly\non the arm said:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe divine mercy is inexhaustible! Unction is about to be\nadministered. Come.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre went in at the door, stepping on the soft carpet, and noticed\nthat the strange lady, the aide-de-camp, and some of the servants, all\nfollowed him in, as if there were now no further need for permission to\nenter that room.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XXIII\n\nPierre well knew this large room divided by columns and an arch, its\nwalls hung round with Persian carpets. The part of the room behind the\ncolumns, with a high silk-curtained mahogany bedstead on one side and\non the other an immense case containing icons, was brightly illuminated\nwith red light like a Russian church during evening service. Under\nthe gleaming icons stood a long invalid chair, and in that chair\non snowy-white smooth pillows, evidently freshly changed, Pierre\nsaw\xe2\x80\x94covered to the waist by a bright green quilt\xe2\x80\x94the familiar,\nmajestic figure of his father, Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov, with that gray mane of\nhair above his broad forehead which reminded one of a lion, and the deep\ncharacteristically noble wrinkles of his handsome, ruddy face. He lay\njust under the icons; his large thick hands outside the quilt. Into the\nright hand, which was lying palm downwards, a wax taper had been thrust\nbetween forefinger and thumb, and an old servant, bending over from\nbehind the chair, held it in position. By the chair stood the priests,\ntheir long hair falling over their magnificent glittering vestments,\nwith lighted tapers in their hands, slowly and solemnly conducting the\nservice. A little behind them stood the two younger princesses holding\nhandkerchiefs to their eyes, and just in front of them their eldest\nsister, Catiche, with a vicious and determined look steadily fixed on\nthe icons, as though declaring to all that she could not answer for\nherself should she glance round. Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, with a meek,\nsorrowful, and all-forgiving expression on her face, stood by the door\nnear the strange lady. Prince Vas\xc3\xadli in front of the door, near the\ninvalid chair, a wax taper in his left hand, was leaning his left arm on\nthe carved back of a velvet chair he had turned round for the purpose,\nand was crossing himself with his right hand, turning his eyes upward\neach time he touched his forehead. His face wore a calm look of piety\nand resignation to the will of God. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you do not understand these\nsentiments,\xe2\x80\x9d he seemed to be saying, \xe2\x80\x9cso much the worse for you!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBehind him stood the aide-de-camp, the doctors, and the menservants;\nthe men and women had separated as in church. All were silently crossing\nthemselves, and the reading of the church service, the subdued chanting\nof deep bass voices, and in the intervals sighs and the shuffling of\nfeet were the only sounds that could be heard. Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, with\nan air of importance that showed that she felt she quite knew what she\nwas about, went across the room to where Pierre was standing and gave\nhim a taper. He lit it and, distracted by observing those around him,\nbegan crossing himself with the hand that held the taper.\n\nSophie, the rosy, laughter-loving, youngest princess with the mole,\nwatched him. She smiled, hid her face in her handkerchief, and remained\nwith it hidden for awhile; then looking up and seeing Pierre she\nagain began to laugh. She evidently felt unable to look at him\nwithout laughing, but could not resist looking at him: so to be out of\ntemptation she slipped quietly behind one of the columns. In the midst\nof the service the voices of the priests suddenly ceased, they whispered\nto one another, and the old servant who was holding the count\xe2\x80\x99s hand\ngot up and said something to the ladies. Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna stepped\nforward and, stooping over the dying man, beckoned to Lorrain from\nbehind her back. The French doctor held no taper; he was leaning\nagainst one of the columns in a respectful attitude implying that he,\na foreigner, in spite of all differences of faith, understood the full\nimportance of the rite now being performed and even approved of it. He\nnow approached the sick man with the noiseless step of one in full vigor\nof life, with his delicate white fingers raised from the green quilt the\nhand that was free, and turning sideways felt the pulse and reflected\na moment. The sick man was given something to drink, there was a\nstir around him, then the people resumed their places and the service\ncontinued. During this interval Pierre noticed that Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\nleft the chair on which he had been leaning, and\xe2\x80\x94with an air\nwhich intimated that he knew what he was about and if others did not\nunderstand him it was so much the worse for them\xe2\x80\x94did not go up to the\ndying man, but passed by him, joined the eldest princess, and moved\nwith her to the side of the room where stood the high bedstead with its\nsilken hangings. On leaving the bed both Prince Vas\xc3\xadli and the princess\npassed out by a back door, but returned to their places one after the\nother before the service was concluded. Pierre paid no more attention\nto this occurrence than to the rest of what went on, having made up his\nmind once for all that what he saw happening around him that evening was\nin some way essential.\n\nThe chanting of the service ceased, and the voice of the priest was\nheard respectfully congratulating the dying man on having received the\nsacrament. The dying man lay as lifeless and immovable as before. Around\nhim everyone began to stir: steps were audible and whispers, among which\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna\xe2\x80\x99s was the most distinct.\n\nPierre heard her say:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly he must be moved onto the bed; here it will be\nimpossible...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe sick man was so surrounded by doctors, princesses, and servants\nthat Pierre could no longer see the reddish-yellow face with its gray\nmane\xe2\x80\x94which, though he saw other faces as well, he had not lost sight\nof for a single moment during the whole service. He judged by the\ncautious movements of those who crowded round the invalid chair that\nthey had lifted the dying man and were moving him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCatch hold of my arm or you\xe2\x80\x99ll drop him!\xe2\x80\x9d he heard one of the\nservants say in a frightened whisper. \xe2\x80\x9cCatch hold from underneath.\nHere!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed different voices; and the heavy breathing of the\nbearers and the shuffling of their feet grew more hurried, as if the\nweight they were carrying were too much for them.\n\nAs the bearers, among whom was Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, passed the young man\nhe caught a momentary glimpse between their heads and backs of the dying\nman\xe2\x80\x99s high, stout, uncovered chest and powerful shoulders, raised by\nthose who were holding him under the armpits, and of his gray, curly,\nleonine head. This head, with its remarkably broad brow and cheekbones,\nits handsome, sensual mouth, and its cold, majestic expression, was\nnot disfigured by the approach of death. It was the same as Pierre\nremembered it three months before, when the count had sent him to\nPetersburg. But now this head was swaying helplessly with the uneven\nmovements of the bearers, and the cold listless gaze fixed itself upon\nnothing.\n\nAfter a few minutes\xe2\x80\x99 bustle beside the high bedstead, those who had\ncarried the sick man dispersed. Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna touched Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s\nhand and said, \xe2\x80\x9cCome.\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre went with her to the bed on which the\nsick man had been laid in a stately pose in keeping with the ceremony\njust completed. He lay with his head propped high on the pillows. His\nhands were symmetrically placed on the green silk quilt, the palms\ndownward. When Pierre came up the count was gazing straight at him, but\nwith a look the significance of which could not be understood by mortal\nman. Either this look meant nothing but that as long as one has eyes\nthey must look somewhere, or it meant too much. Pierre hesitated,\nnot knowing what to do, and glanced inquiringly at his guide. Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna made a hurried sign with her eyes, glancing at the sick\nman\xe2\x80\x99s hand and moving her lips as if to send it a kiss. Pierre,\ncarefully stretching his neck so as not to touch the quilt, followed her\nsuggestion and pressed his lips to the large boned, fleshy hand. Neither\nthe hand nor a single muscle of the count\xe2\x80\x99s face stirred. Once more\nPierre looked questioningly at Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna to see what he was to\ndo next. Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna with her eyes indicated a chair that stood\nbeside the bed. Pierre obediently sat down, his eyes asking if he were\ndoing right. Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna nodded approvingly. Again Pierre fell\ninto the na\xc3\xafvely symmetrical pose of an Egyptian statue, evidently\ndistressed that his stout and clumsy body took up so much room and doing\nhis utmost to look as small as possible. He looked at the count, who\nstill gazed at the spot where Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s face had been before he sat\ndown. Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna indicated by her attitude her consciousness of\nthe pathetic importance of these last moments of meeting between the\nfather and son. This lasted about two minutes, which to Pierre seemed an\nhour. Suddenly the broad muscles and lines of the count\xe2\x80\x99s face began\nto twitch. The twitching increased, the handsome mouth was drawn to one\nside (only now did Pierre realize how near death his father was), and\nfrom that distorted mouth issued an indistinct, hoarse sound. Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna looked attentively at the sick man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, trying to\nguess what he wanted; she pointed first to Pierre, then to some drink,\nthen named Prince Vas\xc3\xadli in an inquiring whisper, then pointed to the\nquilt. The eyes and face of the sick man showed impatience. He made an\neffort to look at the servant who stood constantly at the head of the\nbed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWants to turn on the other side,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered the servant, and got up\nto turn the count\xe2\x80\x99s heavy body toward the wall.\n\nPierre rose to help him.\n\nWhile the count was being turned over, one of his arms fell back\nhelplessly and he made a fruitless effort to pull it forward.
