And not only\nexternally was all in order, but had it pleased the commander in chief\nto look under the uniforms he would have found on every man a clean\nshirt, and in every knapsack the appointed number of articles, \xe2\x80\x9cawl,\nsoap, and all,\xe2\x80\x9d as the soldiers say. There was only one circumstance\nconcerning which no one could be at ease. It was the state of the\nsoldiers\xe2\x80\x99 boots. More than half the men\xe2\x80\x99s boots were in holes. But\nthis defect was not due to any fault of the regimental commander, for\nin spite of repeated demands boots had not been issued by the Austrian\ncommissariat, and the regiment had marched some seven hundred miles.\n\nThe commander of the regiment was an elderly, choleric, stout, and\nthick-set general with grizzled eyebrows and whiskers, and wider from\nchest to back than across the shoulders. He had on a brand-new uniform\nshowing the creases where it had been folded and thick gold epaulettes\nwhich seemed to stand rather than lie down on his massive shoulders. He\nhad the air of a man happily performing one of the most solemn duties of\nhis life. He walked about in front of the line and at every step pulled\nhimself up, slightly arching his back. It was plain that the commander\nadmired his regiment, rejoiced in it, and that his whole mind was\nengrossed by it, yet his strut seemed to indicate that, besides military\nmatters, social interests and the fair sex occupied no small part of his\nthoughts.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Michael M\xc3\xadtrich, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, addressing one of the\nbattalion commanders who smilingly pressed forward (it was plain that\nthey both felt happy). \xe2\x80\x9cWe had our hands full last night. However, I\nthink the regiment is not a bad one, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe battalion commander perceived the jovial irony and laughed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would not be turned off the field even on the Tsar\xc3\xadtsin\nMeadow.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the commander.\n\nAt that moment, on the road from the town on which signalers had been\nposted, two men appeared on horse back. They were an aide-de-camp\nfollowed by a Cossack.\n\nThe aide-de-camp was sent to confirm the order which had not been\nclearly worded the day before, namely, that the commander in chief\nwished to see the regiment just in the state in which it had been on\nthe march: in their greatcoats, and packs, and without any preparation\nwhatever.\n\nA member of the Hofkriegsrath from Vienna had come to Kut\xc3\xbazov the day\nbefore with proposals and demands for him to join up with the army of\nthe Archduke Ferdinand and Mack, and Kut\xc3\xbazov, not considering this\njunction advisable, meant, among other arguments in support of his view,\nto show the Austrian general the wretched state in which the troops\narrived from Russia. With this object he intended to meet the regiment;\nso the worse the condition it was in, the better pleased the commander\nin chief would be. Though the aide-de-camp did not know these\ncircumstances, he nevertheless delivered the definite order that the\nmen should be in their greatcoats and in marching order, and that the\ncommander in chief would otherwise be dissatisfied. On hearing this the\nregimental commander hung his head, silently shrugged his shoulders, and\nspread out his arms with a choleric gesture.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA fine mess we\xe2\x80\x99ve made of it!\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere now! Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I tell you, Michael M\xc3\xadtrich, that if it was said\n\xe2\x80\x98on the march\xe2\x80\x99 it meant in greatcoats?\xe2\x80\x9d said he reproachfully to\nthe battalion commander. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d he added, stepping resolutely\nforward. \xe2\x80\x9cCompany commanders!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted in a voice accustomed to\ncommand. \xe2\x80\x9cSergeants major!... How soon will he be here?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked\nthe aide-de-camp with a respectful politeness evidently relating to the\npersonage he was referring to.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn an hour\xe2\x80\x99s time, I should say.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we have time to change clothes?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know, General....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe regimental commander, going up to the line himself, ordered the\nsoldiers to change into their greatcoats. The company commanders ran off\nto their companies, the sergeants major began bustling (the greatcoats\nwere not in very good condition), and instantly the squares that had up\nto then been in regular order and silent began to sway and stretch and\nhum with voices. On all sides soldiers were running to and fro, throwing\nup their knapsacks with a jerk of their shoulders and pulling the straps\nover their heads, unstrapping their overcoats and drawing the sleeves on\nwith upraised arms.\n\nIn half an hour all was again in order, only the squares had become gray\ninstead of black. The regimental commander walked with his jerky steps\nto the front of the regiment and examined it from a distance.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhatever is this? This!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted and stood still. \xe2\x80\x9cCommander\nof the third company!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCommander of the third company wanted by the general!... commander to\nthe general... third company to the commander.\xe2\x80\x9d The words passed along\nthe lines and an adjutant ran to look for the missing officer.\n\nWhen the eager but misrepeated words had reached their destination in\na cry of: \xe2\x80\x9cThe general to the third company,\xe2\x80\x9d the missing officer\nappeared from behind his company and, though he was a middle-aged man\nand not in the habit of running, trotted awkwardly stumbling on his\ntoes toward the general. The captain\xe2\x80\x99s face showed the uneasiness of\na schoolboy who is told to repeat a lesson he has not learned. Spots\nappeared on his nose, the redness of which was evidently due to\nintemperance, and his mouth twitched nervously. The general looked the\ncaptain up and down as he came up panting, slackening his pace as he\napproached.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will soon be dressing your men in petticoats! What is this?\xe2\x80\x9d\nshouted the regimental commander, thrusting forward his jaw and pointing\nat a soldier in the ranks of the third company in a greatcoat of bluish\ncloth, which contrasted with the others. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you been after?\nThe commander in chief is expected and you leave your place? Eh? I\xe2\x80\x99ll\nteach you to dress the men in fancy coats for a parade.... Eh...?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe commander of the company, with his eyes fixed on his superior,\npressed two fingers more and more rigidly to his cap, as if in this\npressure lay his only hope of salvation.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, why don\xe2\x80\x99t you speak? Whom have you got there dressed up as a\nHungarian?\xe2\x80\x9d said the commander with an austere gibe.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, your excellency, what? Your excellency! But what about your\nexcellency?... nobody knows.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency, it\xe2\x80\x99s the officer D\xc3\xb3lokhov, who has been reduced\nto the ranks,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain softly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell? Has he been degraded into a field marshal, or into a soldier?\nIf a soldier, he should be dressed in regulation uniform like the\nothers.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency, you gave him leave yourself, on the march.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGave him leave? Leave? That\xe2\x80\x99s just like you young men,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\nregimental commander cooling down a little. \xe2\x80\x9cLeave indeed.... One says\na word to you and you... What?\xe2\x80\x9d he added with renewed irritation, \xe2\x80\x9cI\nbeg you to dress your men decently.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd the commander, turning to look at the adjutant, directed his jerky\nsteps down the line. He was evidently pleased at his own display of\nanger and walking up to the regiment wished to find a further excuse for\nwrath. Having snapped at an officer for an unpolished badge, at another\nbecause his line was not straight, he reached the third company.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cH-o-o-w are you standing? Where\xe2\x80\x99s your leg? Your leg?\xe2\x80\x9d shouted\nthe commander with a tone of suffering in his voice, while there were\nstill five men between him and D\xc3\xb3lokhov with his bluish-gray uniform.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov slowly straightened his bent knee, looking straight with his\nclear, insolent eyes in the general\xe2\x80\x99s face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy a blue coat? Off with it... Sergeant major! Change his coat...\nthe ras...\xe2\x80\x9d he did not finish.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeneral, I must obey orders, but I am not bound to endure...\xe2\x80\x9d\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov hurriedly interrupted.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo talking in the ranks!... No talking, no talking!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot bound to endure insults,\xe2\x80\x9d D\xc3\xb3lokhov concluded in loud, ringing\ntones.\n\nThe eyes of the general and the soldier met. The general became silent,\nangrily pulling down his tight scarf.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI request you to have the goodness to change your coat,\xe2\x80\x9d he said as\nhe turned away.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER II\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s coming!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the signaler at that moment.\n\nThe regimental commander, flushing, ran to his horse, seized the stirrup\nwith trembling hands, threw his body across the saddle, righted himself,\ndrew his saber, and with a happy and resolute countenance, opening\nhis mouth awry, prepared to shout. The regiment fluttered like a bird\npreening its plumage and became motionless.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAtt-ention!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the regimental commander in a soul-shaking\nvoice which expressed joy for himself, severity for the regiment, and\nwelcome for the approaching chief.\n\nAlong the broad country road, edged on both sides by trees, came a high,\nlight blue Viennese cal\xc3\xa8che, slightly creaking on its springs and drawn\nby six horses at a smart trot. Behind the cal\xc3\xa8che galloped the suite\nand a convoy of Croats. Beside Kut\xc3\xbazov sat an Austrian general, in\na white uniform that looked strange among the Russian black ones. The\ncal\xc3\xa8che stopped in front of the regiment. Kut\xc3\xbazov and the Austrian\ngeneral were talking in low voices and Kut\xc3\xbazov smiled slightly as\ntreading heavily he stepped down from the carriage just as if those two\nthousand men breathlessly gazing at him and the regimental commander did\nnot exist.\n\nThe word of command rang out, and again the regiment quivered, as with a\njingling sound it presented arms. Then amidst a dead silence the\nfeeble voice of the commander in chief was heard. The regiment roared,\n\xe2\x80\x9cHealth to your ex... len... len... lency!\xe2\x80\x9d and again all became\nsilent. At first Kut\xc3\xbazov stood still while the regiment moved; then he\nand the general in white, accompanied by the suite, walked between the\nranks.\n\nFrom the way the regimental commander saluted the commander in chief and\ndevoured him with his eyes, drawing himself up obsequiously, and from\nthe way he walked through the ranks behind the generals, bending forward\nand hardly able to restrain his jerky movements, and from the way he\ndarted forward at every word or gesture of the commander in chief,\nit was evident that he performed his duty as a subordinate with even\ngreater zeal than his duty as a commander. Thanks to the strictness and\nassiduity of its commander the regiment, in comparison with others that\nhad reached Braunau at the same time, was in splendid condition. There\nwere only 217 sick and stragglers. Everything was in good order except\nthe boots.\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov walked through the ranks, sometimes stopping to say a few\nfriendly words to officers he had known in the Turkish war, sometimes\nalso to the soldiers. Looking at their boots he several times shook his\nhead sadly, pointing them out to the Austrian general with an expression\nwhich seemed to say that he was not blaming anyone, but could not help\nnoticing what a bad state of things it was. The regimental commander\nran forward on each such occasion, fearing to miss a single word of the\ncommander in chief\xe2\x80\x99s regarding the regiment. Behind Kut\xc3\xbazov, at a\ndistance that allowed every softly spoken word to be heard, followed\nsome twenty men of his suite. These gentlemen talked among themselves\nand sometimes laughed. Nearest of all to the commander in chief walked\na handsome adjutant. This was Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski. Beside him was his\ncomrade Nesv\xc3\xadtski, a tall staff officer, extremely stout, with a\nkindly, smiling, handsome face and moist eyes. Nesv\xc3\xadtski could hardly\nkeep from laughter provoked by a swarthy hussar officer who walked\nbeside him. This hussar, with a grave face and without a smile or a\nchange in the expression of his fixed eyes, watched the regimental\ncommander\xe2\x80\x99s back and mimicked his every movement. Each time the\ncommander started and bent forward, the hussar started and bent forward\nin exactly the same manner. Nesv\xc3\xadtski laughed and nudged the others to\nmake them look at the wag.\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov walked slowly and languidly past thousands of eyes which were\nstarting from their sockets to watch their chief. On reaching the\nthird company he suddenly stopped. His suite, not having expected this,\ninvoluntarily came closer to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Tim\xc3\xb3khin!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, recognizing the red-nosed captain who had\nbeen reprimanded on account of the blue greatcoat.\n\nOne would have thought it impossible for a man to stretch himself\nmore than Tim\xc3\xb3khin had done when he was reprimanded by the regimental\ncommander, but now that the commander in chief addressed him he drew\nhimself up to such an extent that it seemed he could not have sustained\nit had the commander in chief continued to look at him, and so Kut\xc3\xbazov,\nwho evidently understood his case and wished him nothing but good,\nquickly turned away, a scarcely perceptible smile flitting over his\nscarred and puffy face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnother Ismail comrade,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cA brave officer! Are you\nsatisfied with him?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked the regimental commander.\n\nAnd the latter\xe2\x80\x94unconscious that he was being reflected in the hussar\nofficer as in a looking glass\xe2\x80\x94started, moved forward, and answered:\n\xe2\x80\x9cHighly satisfied, your excellency!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe all have our weaknesses,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kut\xc3\xbazov smiling and walking away\nfrom him. \xe2\x80\x9cHe used to have a predilection for Bacchus.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe regimental commander was afraid he might be blamed for this and did\nnot answer. The hussar at that moment noticed the face of the red-nosed\ncaptain and his drawn-in stomach, and mimicked his expression and pose\nwith such exactitude that Nesv\xc3\xadtski could not help laughing. Kut\xc3\xbazov\nturned round. The officer evidently had complete control of his face,\nand while Kut\xc3\xbazov was turning managed to make a grimace and then assume\na most serious, deferential, and innocent expression.\n\nThe third company was the last, and Kut\xc3\xbazov pondered, apparently trying\nto recollect something. Prince Andrew stepped forward from among the\nsuite and said in French:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou told me to remind you of the officer D\xc3\xb3lokhov, reduced to the\nranks in this regiment.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is D\xc3\xb3lokhov?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Kut\xc3\xbazov.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov, who had already changed into a soldier\xe2\x80\x99s gray greatcoat,\ndid not wait to be called. The shapely figure of the fair-haired\nsoldier, with his clear blue eyes, stepped forward from the ranks, went\nup to the commander in chief, and presented arms.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you a complaint to make?\xe2\x80\x9d Kut\xc3\xbazov asked with a slight frown.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is D\xc3\xb3lokhov,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Kut\xc3\xbazov. \xe2\x80\x9cI hope this will be a lesson to you. Do your\nduty. The Emperor is gracious, and I shan\xe2\x80\x99t forget you if you deserve\nwell.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe clear blue eyes looked at the commander in chief just as boldly as\nthey had looked at the regimental commander, seeming by their expression\nto tear open the veil of convention that separates a commander in chief\nso widely from a private.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne thing I ask of your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d D\xc3\xb3lokhov said in his firm,\nringing, deliberate voice. \xe2\x80\x9cI ask an opportunity to atone for my fault\nand prove my devotion to His Majesty the Emperor and to Russia!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov turned away. The same smile of the eyes with which he had\nturned from Captain Tim\xc3\xb3khin again flitted over his face. He turned\naway with a grimace as if to say that everything D\xc3\xb3lokhov had said to\nhim and everything he could say had long been known to him, that he was\nweary of it and it was not at all what he wanted. He turned away and\nwent to the carriage.\n\nThe regiment broke up into companies, which went to their appointed\nquarters near Braunau, where they hoped to receive boots and clothes and\nto rest after their hard marches.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou won\xe2\x80\x99t bear me a grudge, Prokh\xc3\xb3r Ign\xc3\xa1tych?\xe2\x80\x9d said the\nregimental commander, overtaking the third company on its way to its\nquarters and riding up to Captain Tim\xc3\xb3khin who was walking in front.\n(The regimental commander\xe2\x80\x99s face now that the inspection was happily\nover beamed with irrepressible delight.) \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s in the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s\nservice... it can\xe2\x80\x99t be helped... one is sometimes a bit hasty on\nparade... I am the first to apologize, you know me!... He was very\npleased!\xe2\x80\x9d And he held out his hand to the captain.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t mention it, General, as if I\xe2\x80\x99d be so bold!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\ncaptain, his nose growing redder as he gave a smile which showed where\ntwo front teeth were missing that had been knocked out by the butt end\nof a gun at Ismail.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd tell Mr. D\xc3\xb3lokhov that I won\xe2\x80\x99t forget him\xe2\x80\x94he may be quite\neasy. And tell me, please\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve been meaning to ask\xe2\x80\x94how is he\nbehaving himself, and in general...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs far as the service goes he is quite punctilious, your excellency;\nbut his character...\xe2\x80\x9d said Tim\xc3\xb3khin.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what about his character?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the regimental commander.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s different on different days,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cOne\nday he is sensible, well educated, and good-natured, and the next he\xe2\x80\x99s\na wild beast.... In Poland, if you please, he nearly killed a Jew.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, well, well!\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the regimental commander. \xe2\x80\x9cStill, one\nmust have pity on a young man in misfortune. You know he has important\nconnections... Well, then, you just...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tim\xc3\xb3khin, showing by his smile that\nhe understood his commander\xe2\x80\x99s wish.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, of course, of course!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe regimental commander sought out D\xc3\xb3lokhov in the ranks and, reining\nin his horse, said to him:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter the next affair... epaulettes.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov looked round but did not say anything, nor did the mocking\nsmile on his lips change.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that\xe2\x80\x99s all right,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the regimental commander. \xe2\x80\x9cA\ncup of vodka for the men from me,\xe2\x80\x9d he added so that the soldiers\ncould hear. \xe2\x80\x9cI thank you all! God be praised!\xe2\x80\x9d and he rode past that\ncompany and overtook the next one.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, he\xe2\x80\x99s really a good fellow, one can serve under him,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nTim\xc3\xb3khin to the subaltern beside him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn a word, a hearty one...\xe2\x80\x9d said the subaltern, laughing (the\nregimental commander was nicknamed King of Hearts).\n\nThe cheerful mood of their officers after the inspection infected the\nsoldiers. The company marched on gaily. The soldiers\xe2\x80\x99 voices could be\nheard on every side.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd they said Kut\xc3\xbazov was blind of one eye?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so he is! Quite blind!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, friend, he is sharper-eyed than you are. Boots and leg bands...\nhe noticed everything...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen he looked at my feet, friend... well, thinks I...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that other one with him, the Austrian, looked as if he were\nsmeared with chalk\xe2\x80\x94as white as flour! I suppose they polish him up as\nthey do the guns.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, F\xc3\xa9deshon!... Did he say when the battles are to begin? You\nwere near him. Everybody said that Buonaparte himself was at Braunau.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBuonaparte himself!... Just listen to the fool, what he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t\nknow! The Prussians are up in arms now. The Austrians, you see, are\nputting them down. When they\xe2\x80\x99ve been put down, the war with Buonaparte\nwill begin. And he says Buonaparte is in Braunau! Shows you\xe2\x80\x99re a fool.\nYou\xe2\x80\x99d better listen more carefully!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat devils these quartermasters are! See, the fifth company is\nturning into the village already... they will have their buckwheat\ncooked before we reach our quarters.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me a biscuit, you devil!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did you give me tobacco yesterday? That\xe2\x80\x99s just it, friend! Ah,\nwell, never mind, here you are.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey might call a halt here or we\xe2\x80\x99ll have to do another four miles\nwithout eating.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWasn\xe2\x80\x99t it fine when those Germans gave us lifts! You just sit still\nand are drawn along.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd here, friend, the people are quite beggarly. There they all\nseemed to be Poles\xe2\x80\x94all under the Russian crown\xe2\x80\x94but here they\xe2\x80\x99re\nall regular Germans.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSingers to the front\xe2\x80\x9d came the captain\xe2\x80\x99s order.\n\nAnd from the different ranks some twenty men ran to the front. A\ndrummer, their leader, turned round facing the singers, and flourishing\nhis arm, began a long-drawn-out soldiers\xe2\x80\x99 song, commencing with the\nwords: \xe2\x80\x9cMorning dawned, the sun was rising,\xe2\x80\x9d and concluding: \xe2\x80\x9cOn\nthen, brothers, on to glory, led by Father K\xc3\xa1menski.\xe2\x80\x9d This song had\nbeen composed in the Turkish campaign and now being sung in Austria, the\nonly change being that the words \xe2\x80\x9cFather K\xc3\xa1menski\xe2\x80\x9d were replaced by\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather Kut\xc3\xbazov.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHaving jerked out these last words as soldiers do and waved his arms\nas if flinging something to the ground, the drummer\xe2\x80\x94a lean, handsome\nsoldier of forty\xe2\x80\x94looked sternly at the singers and screwed up his\neyes. Then having satisfied himself that all eyes were fixed on him,\nhe raised both arms as if carefully lifting some invisible but precious\nobject above his head and, holding it there for some seconds, suddenly\nflung it down and began:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my bower, oh, my bower...!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my bower new...!\xe2\x80\x9d chimed in twenty voices, and the castanet\nplayer, in spite of the burden of his equipment, rushed out to the front\nand, walking backwards before the company, jerked his shoulders and\nflourished his castanets as if threatening someone. The soldiers,\nswinging their arms and keeping time spontaneously, marched with long\nsteps. Behind the company the sound of wheels, the creaking of springs,\nand the tramp of horses\xe2\x80\x99 hoofs were heard. Kut\xc3\xbazov and his suite were\nreturning to the town. The commander in chief made a sign that the\nmen should continue to march at ease, and he and all his suite showed\npleasure at the sound of the singing and the sight of the dancing\nsoldier and the gay and smartly marching men. In the second file\nfrom the right flank, beside which the carriage passed the company,\na blue-eyed soldier involuntarily attracted notice. It was D\xc3\xb3lokhov\nmarching with particular grace and boldness in time to the song and\nlooking at those driving past as if he pitied all who were not at that\nmoment marching with the company. The hussar cornet of Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s\nsuite who had mimicked the regimental commander, fell back from the\ncarriage and rode up to D\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\nHussar cornet Zherk\xc3\xb3v had at one time, in Petersburg, belonged to\nthe wild set led by D\xc3\xb3lokhov. Zherk\xc3\xb3v had met D\xc3\xb3lokhov abroad as a\nprivate and had not seen fit to recognize him. But now that Kut\xc3\xbazov had\nspoken to the gentleman ranker, he addressed him with the cordiality of\nan old friend.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear fellow, how are you?\xe2\x80\x9d said he through the singing, making\nhis horse keep pace with the company.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow am I?\xe2\x80\x9d D\xc3\xb3lokhov answered coldly. \xe2\x80\x9cI am as you see.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe lively song gave a special flavor to the tone of free and easy\ngaiety with which Zherk\xc3\xb3v spoke, and to the intentional coldness of\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s reply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how do you get on with the officers?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Zherk\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right. They are good fellows. And how have you wriggled onto the\nstaff?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was attached; I\xe2\x80\x99m on duty.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBoth were silent.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe let the hawk fly upward from her wide right sleeve,\xe2\x80\x9d went the\nsong, arousing an involuntary sensation of courage and cheerfulness.\nTheir conversation would probably have been different but for the effect\nof that song.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it true that Austrians have been beaten?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil only knows! They say so.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad,\xe2\x80\x9d answered D\xc3\xb3lokhov briefly and clearly, as the song\ndemanded.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, come round some evening and we\xe2\x80\x99ll have a game of faro!\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid Zherk\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, have you too much money?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo come.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t. I\xe2\x80\x99ve sworn not to. I won\xe2\x80\x99t drink and won\xe2\x80\x99t play till\nI get reinstated.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that\xe2\x80\x99s only till the first engagement.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThey were again silent.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome if you need anything. One can at least be of use on the\nstaff...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov smiled. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t trouble. If I want anything, I won\xe2\x80\x99t\nbeg\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll take it!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, never mind; I only...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I only...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-by.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood health...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n        \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a long, long way.\n        To my native land...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nZherk\xc3\xb3v touched his horse with the spurs; it pranced excitedly from\nfoot to foot uncertain with which to start, then settled down, galloped\npast the company, and overtook the carriage, still keeping time to the\nsong.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER III\n\nOn returning from the review, Kut\xc3\xbazov took the Austrian general into\nhis private room and, calling his adjutant, asked for some papers\nrelating to the condition of the troops on their arrival, and the\nletters that had come from the Archduke Ferdinand, who was in command of\nthe advanced army. Prince Andrew Bolk\xc3\xb3nski came into the room with the\nrequired papers. Kut\xc3\xbazov and the Austrian member of the Hofkriegsrath\nwere sitting at the table on which a plan was spread out.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!...\xe2\x80\x9d said Kut\xc3\xbazov glancing at Bolk\xc3\xb3nski as if by this\nexclamation he was asking the adjutant to wait, and he went on with the\nconversation in French.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll I can say, General,\xe2\x80\x9d said he with a pleasant elegance\nof expression and intonation that obliged one to listen to each\ndeliberately spoken word. It was evident that Kut\xc3\xbazov himself listened\nwith pleasure to his own voice. \xe2\x80\x9cAll I can say, General, is that if\nthe matter depended on my personal wishes, the will of His Majesty the\nEmperor Francis would have been fulfilled long ago. I should long\nago have joined the archduke. And believe me on my honour that to me\npersonally it would be a pleasure to hand over the supreme command\nof the army into the hands of a better informed and more skillful\ngeneral\xe2\x80\x94of whom Austria has so many\xe2\x80\x94and to lay down all this heavy\nresponsibility. But circumstances are sometimes too strong for us,\nGeneral.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Kut\xc3\xbazov smiled in a way that seemed to say, \xe2\x80\x9cYou are quite at\nliberty not to believe me and I don\xe2\x80\x99t even care whether you do or\nnot, but you have no grounds for telling me so. And that is the whole\npoint.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe Austrian general looked dissatisfied, but had no option but to reply\nin the same tone.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in a querulous and angry tone that\ncontrasted with his flattering words, \xe2\x80\x9con the contrary, your\nexcellency\xe2\x80\x99s participation in the common action is highly valued by\nHis Majesty; but we think the present delay is depriving the splendid\nRussian troops and their commander of the laurels they have been\naccustomed to win in their battles,\xe2\x80\x9d he concluded his evidently\nprearranged sentence.\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov bowed with the same smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that is my conviction, and judging by the last letter with which\nHis Highness the Archduke Ferdinand has honored me, I imagine that the\nAustrian troops, under the direction of so skillful a leader as General\nMack, have by now already gained a decisive victory and no longer need\nour aid,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kut\xc3\xbazov.\n\nThe general frowned. Though there was no definite news of an Austrian\ndefeat, there were many circumstances confirming the unfavorable rumors\nthat were afloat, and so Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s suggestion of an Austrian victory\nsounded much like irony. But Kut\xc3\xbazov went on blandly smiling with the\nsame expression, which seemed to say that he had a right to suppose\nso. And, in fact, the last letter he had received from Mack\xe2\x80\x99s army\ninformed him of a victory and stated strategically the position of the\narmy was very favorable.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me that letter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kut\xc3\xbazov turning to Prince Andrew.\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease have a look at it\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and Kut\xc3\xbazov with an ironical smile\nabout the corners of his mouth read to the Austrian general the\nfollowing passage, in German, from the Archduke Ferdinand\xe2\x80\x99s letter:\n\nWe have fully concentrated forces of nearly seventy thousand men with\nwhich to attack and defeat the enemy should he cross the Lech. Also,\nas we are masters of Ulm, we cannot be deprived of the advantage of\ncommanding both sides of the Danube, so that should the enemy not\ncross the Lech, we can cross the Danube, throw ourselves on his line\nof communications, recross the river lower down, and frustrate his\nintention should he try to direct his whole force against our faithful\nally. We shall therefore confidently await the moment when the Imperial\nRussian army will be fully equipped, and shall then, in conjunction with\nit, easily find a way to prepare for the enemy the fate he deserves.\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov sighed deeply on finishing this paragraph and looked at the\nmember of the Hofkriegsrath mildly and attentively.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you know the wise maxim your excellency, advising one to expect\nthe worst,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Austrian general, evidently wishing to have done\nwith jests and to come to business. He involuntarily looked round at the\naide-de-camp.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, General,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Kut\xc3\xbazov, also turning to Prince\nAndrew. \xe2\x80\x9cLook here, my dear fellow, get from Kozl\xc3\xb3vski all the\nreports from our scouts. Here are two letters from Count Nostitz and\nhere is one from His Highness the Archduke Ferdinand and here are\nthese,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, handing him several papers, \xe2\x80\x9cmake a neat memorandum\nin French out of all this, showing all the news we have had of the\nmovements of the Austrian army, and then give it to his excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew bowed his head in token of having understood from the\nfirst not only what had been said but also what Kut\xc3\xbazov would have\nliked to tell him. He gathered up the papers and with a bow to both,\nstepped softly over the carpet and went out into the waiting room.\n\nThough not much time had passed since Prince Andrew had left Russia, he\nhad changed greatly during that period. In the expression of his face,\nin his movements, in his walk, scarcely a trace was left of his former\naffected languor and indolence. He now looked like a man who has time\nto think of the impression he makes on others, but is occupied with\nagreeable and interesting work. His face expressed more satisfaction\nwith himself and those around him, his smile and glance were brighter\nand more attractive.\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov, whom he had overtaken in Poland, had received him very kindly,\npromised not to forget him, distinguished him above the other adjutants,\nand had taken him to Vienna and given him the more serious commissions.\nFrom Vienna Kut\xc3\xbazov wrote to his old comrade, Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s father.\n\nYour son bids fair to become an officer distinguished by his industry,\nfirmness, and expedition. I consider myself fortunate to have such a\nsubordinate by me.\n\nOn Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s staff, among his fellow officers and in the army\ngenerally, Prince Andrew had, as he had had in Petersburg society, two\nquite opposite reputations. Some, a minority, acknowledged him to be\ndifferent from themselves and from everyone else, expected great things\nof him, listened to him, admired, and imitated him, and with them Prince\nAndrew was natural and pleasant. Others, the majority, disliked him and\nconsidered him conceited, cold, and disagreeable. But among these people\nPrince Andrew knew how to take his stand so that they respected and even\nfeared him.\n\nComing out of Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s room into the waiting room with the papers in\nhis hand Prince Andrew came up to his comrade, the aide-de-camp on duty,\nKozl\xc3\xb3vski, who was sitting at the window with a book.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Prince?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Kozl\xc3\xb3vski.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am ordered to write a memorandum explaining why we are not\nadvancing.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew shrugged his shoulders.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny news from Mack?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it were true that he has been beaten, news would have come.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cProbably,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew moving toward the outer door.\n\nBut at that instant a tall Austrian general in a greatcoat, with the\norder of Maria Theresa on his neck and a black bandage round his head,\nwho had evidently just arrived, entered quickly, slamming the door.\nPrince Andrew stopped short.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCommander in Chief Kut\xc3\xbazov?\xe2\x80\x9d said the newly arrived general\nspeaking quickly with a harsh German accent, looking to both sides and\nadvancing straight toward the inner door.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe commander in chief is engaged,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kozl\xc3\xb3vski, going\nhurriedly up to the unknown general and blocking his way to the door.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom shall I announce?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe unknown general looked disdainfully down at Kozl\xc3\xb3vski, who was\nrather short, as if surprised that anyone should not know him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe commander in chief is engaged,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Kozl\xc3\xb3vski calmly.\n\nThe general\xe2\x80\x99s face clouded, his lips quivered and trembled. He took\nout a notebook, hurriedly scribbled something in pencil, tore out the\nleaf, gave it to Kozl\xc3\xb3vski, stepped quickly to the window, and threw\nhimself into a chair, gazing at those in the room as if asking, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy\ndo they look at me?\xe2\x80\x9d Then he lifted his head, stretched his neck as\nif he intended to say something, but immediately, with affected\nindifference, began to hum to himself, producing a queer sound which\nimmediately broke off. The door of the private room opened and Kut\xc3\xbazov\nappeared in the doorway. The general with the bandaged head bent forward\nas though running away from some danger, and, making long, quick strides\nwith his thin legs, went up to Kut\xc3\xbazov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVous voyez le malheureux Mack,\xe2\x80\x9d he uttered in a broken voice.\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s face as he stood in the open doorway remained perfectly\nimmobile for a few moments. Then wrinkles ran over his face like a wave\nand his forehead became smooth again, he bowed his head respectfully,\nclosed his eyes, silently let Mack enter his room before him, and closed\nthe door himself behind him.\n\nThe report which had been circulated that the Austrians had been beaten\nand that the whole army had surrendered at Ulm proved to be correct.\nWithin half an hour adjutants had been sent in various directions with\norders which showed that the Russian troops, who had hitherto been\ninactive, would also soon have to meet the enemy.\n\nPrince Andrew was one of those rare staff officers whose chief interest\nlay in the general progress of the war. When he saw Mack and heard the\ndetails of his disaster he understood that half the campaign was lost,\nunderstood all the difficulties of the Russian army\xe2\x80\x99s position, and\nvividly imagined what awaited it and the part he would have to\nplay. Involuntarily he felt a joyful agitation at the thought of the\nhumiliation of arrogant Austria and that in a week\xe2\x80\x99s time he might,\nperhaps, see and take part in the first Russian encounter with the\nFrench since Suv\xc3\xb3rov met them. He feared that Bonaparte\xe2\x80\x99s genius\nmight outweigh all the courage of the Russian troops, and at the same\ntime could not admit the idea of his hero being disgraced.\n\nExcited and irritated by these thoughts Prince Andrew went toward his\nroom to write to his father, to whom he wrote every day. In the corridor\nhe met Nesv\xc3\xadtski, with whom he shared a room, and the wag Zherk\xc3\xb3v;\nthey were as usual laughing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you so glum?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Nesv\xc3\xadtski noticing Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s\npale face and glittering eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s nothing to be gay about,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Bolk\xc3\xb3nski.\n\nJust as Prince Andrew met Nesv\xc3\xadtski and Zherk\xc3\xb3v, there came toward\nthem from the other end of the corridor, Strauch, an Austrian general\nwho was on Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s staff in charge of the provisioning of the Russian\narmy, and the member of the Hofkriegsrath who had arrived the previous\nevening. There was room enough in the wide corridor for the generals to\npass the three officers quite easily, but Zherk\xc3\xb3v, pushing Nesv\xc3\xadtski\naside with his arm, said in a breathless voice,\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re coming!... they\xe2\x80\x99re coming!... Stand aside, make way,\nplease make way!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe generals were passing by, looking as if they wished to avoid\nembarrassing attentions. On the face of the wag Zherk\xc3\xb3v there suddenly\nappeared a stupid smile of glee which he seemed unable to suppress.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said he in German, stepping forward and\naddressing the Austrian general, \xe2\x80\x9cI have the honor to congratulate\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe bowed his head and scraped first with one foot and then with the\nother, awkwardly, like a child at a dancing lesson.\n\nThe member of the Hofkriegsrath looked at him severely but, seeing the\nseriousness of his stupid smile, could not but give him a moment\xe2\x80\x99s\nattention. He screwed up his eyes showing that he was listening.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have the honor to congratulate you. General Mack has arrived, quite\nwell, only a little bruised just here,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, pointing with a\nbeaming smile to his head.\n\nThe general frowned, turned away, and went on.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGott, wie naiv!\xe2\x80\x9d * said he angrily, after he had gone a few steps.\n\n     * \xe2\x80\x9cGood God, what simplicity!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nNesv\xc3\xadtski with a laugh threw his arms round Prince Andrew, but\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski, turning still paler, pushed him away with an angry look and\nturned to Zherk\xc3\xb3v. The nervous irritation aroused by the appearance\nof Mack, the news of his defeat, and the thought of what lay before the\nRussian army found vent in anger at Zherk\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s untimely jest.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you, sir, choose to make a buffoon of yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d he said\nsharply, with a slight trembling of the lower jaw, \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t prevent\nyour doing so; but I warn you that if you dare to play the fool in my\npresence, I will teach you to behave yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNesv\xc3\xadtski and Zherk\xc3\xb3v were so surprised by this outburst that they\ngazed at Bolk\xc3\xb3nski silently with wide-open eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter? I only congratulated them,\xe2\x80\x9d said Zherk\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not jesting with you; please be silent!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bolk\xc3\xb3nski,\nand taking Nesv\xc3\xadtski\xe2\x80\x99s arm he left Zherk\xc3\xb3v, who did not know what to\nsay.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, what\xe2\x80\x99s the matter, old fellow?\xe2\x80\x9d said Nesv\xc3\xadtski trying to\nsoothe him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Prince Andrew standing still in\nhis excitement. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you understand that either we are officers\nserving our Tsar and our country, rejoicing in the successes and\ngrieving at the misfortunes of our common cause, or we are merely\nlackeys who care nothing for their master\xe2\x80\x99s business. Quarante mille\nhommes massacr\xc3\xa9s et l\xe2\x80\x99arm\xc3\xa9e de nos alli\xc3\xa9s d\xc3\xa9truite, et vous\ntrouvez l\xc3\xa0 le mot pour rire,\xe2\x80\x9d * he said, as if strengthening his\nviews by this French sentence. \xe2\x80\x9cC\xe2\x80\x99est bien pour un gar\xc3\xa7on de rien\ncomme cet individu dont vous avez fait un ami, mais pas pour vous, pas\npour vous. *(2) Only a hobbledehoy could amuse himself in this\nway,\xe2\x80\x9d he added in Russian\xe2\x80\x94but pronouncing the word with a French\naccent\xe2\x80\x94having noticed that Zherk\xc3\xb3v could still hear him.\n\n     * \xe2\x80\x9cForty thousand men massacred and the army of our allies\n     destroyed, and you find that a cause for jesting!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n     * (2) \xe2\x80\x9cIt is all very well for that good-for-nothing fellow\n     of whom you have made a friend, but not for you, not for\n     you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nHe waited a moment to see whether the cornet would answer, but he turned\nand went out of the corridor.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IV\n\nThe P\xc3\xa1vlograd Hussars were stationed two miles from Braunau. The\nsquadron in which Nicholas Rost\xc3\xb3v served as a cadet was quartered in\nthe German village of Salzeneck. The best quarters in the village were\nassigned to cavalry-captain Den\xc3\xadsov, the squadron commander, known\nthroughout the whole cavalry division as V\xc3\xa1ska Den\xc3\xadsov. Cadet Rost\xc3\xb3v,\never since he had overtaken the regiment in Poland, had lived with the\nsquadron commander.\n\nOn October 11, the day when all was astir at headquarters over the news\nof Mack\xe2\x80\x99s defeat, the camp life of the officers of this squadron was\nproceeding as usual. Den\xc3\xadsov, who had been losing at cards all night,\nhad not yet come home when Rost\xc3\xb3v rode back early in the morning from\na foraging expedition. Rost\xc3\xb3v in his cadet uniform, with a jerk to his\nhorse, rode up to the porch, swung his leg over the saddle with a supple\nyouthful movement, stood for a moment in the stirrup as if loathe to\npart from his horse, and at last sprang down and called to his orderly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Bondar\xc3\xa9nko, dear friend!\xe2\x80\x9d said he to the hussar who rushed up\nheadlong to the horse. \xe2\x80\x9cWalk him up and down, my dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d he\ncontinued, with that gay brotherly cordiality which goodhearted young\npeople show to everyone when they are happy.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Ukrainian gaily, tossing his\nhead.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMind, walk him up and down well!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnother hussar also rushed toward the horse, but Bondar\xc3\xa9nko had already\nthrown the reins of the snaffle bridle over the horse\xe2\x80\x99s head. It was\nevident that the cadet was liberal with his tips and that it paid to\nserve him. Rost\xc3\xb3v patted the horse\xe2\x80\x99s neck and then his flank, and\nlingered for a moment.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSplendid! What a horse he will be!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought with a smile, and\nholding up his saber, his spurs jingling, he ran up the steps of the\nporch. His landlord, who in a waistcoat and a pointed cap, pitchfork in\nhand, was clearing manure from the cowhouse, looked out, and his face\nimmediately brightened on seeing Rost\xc3\xb3v. \xe2\x80\x9cSch\xc3\xb6n gut Morgen! Sch\xc3\xb6n\ngut Morgen!\xe2\x80\x9d * he said winking with a merry smile, evidently pleased\nto greet the young man.\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cA very good morning! A very good morning!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSchon fleissig?\xe2\x80\x9d * said Rost\xc3\xb3v with the same gay brotherly smile\nwhich did not leave his eager face. \xe2\x80\x9cHoch Oestreicher! Hoch Russen!\nKaiser Alexander hoch!\xe2\x80\x9d *(2) said he, quoting words often repeated by\nthe German landlord.\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cBusy already?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n    * (2) \xe2\x80\x9cHurrah for the Austrians! Hurrah for the Russians!\n     Hurrah for Emperor Alexander!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nThe German laughed, came out of the cowshed, pulled off his cap, and\nwaving it above his head cried:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnd die ganze Welt hoch!\xe2\x80\x9d *\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cAnd hurrah for the whole world!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v waved his cap above his head like the German and cried laughing,\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnd vivat die ganze Welt!\xe2\x80\x9d Though neither the German cleaning his\ncowshed nor Rost\xc3\xb3v back with his platoon from foraging for hay had any\nreason for rejoicing, they looked at each other with joyful delight and\nbrotherly love, wagged their heads in token of their mutual affection,\nand parted smiling, the German returning to his cowshed and Rost\xc3\xb3v\ngoing to the cottage he occupied with Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat about your master?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked Lavr\xc3\xbashka, Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s orderly,\nwhom all the regiment knew for a rogue.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHasn\xe2\x80\x99t been in since the evening. Must have been losing,\xe2\x80\x9d\nanswered Lavr\xc3\xbashka. \xe2\x80\x9cI know by now, if he wins he comes back early to\nbrag about it, but if he stays out till morning it means he\xe2\x80\x99s lost and\nwill come back in a rage. Will you have coffee?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, bring some.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nTen minutes later Lavr\xc3\xbashka brought the coffee. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s coming!\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid he. \xe2\x80\x9cNow for trouble!\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v looked out of the window and\nsaw Den\xc3\xadsov coming home. Den\xc3\xadsov was a small man with a red face,\nsparkling black eyes, and black tousled mustache and hair. He wore an\nunfastened cloak, wide breeches hanging down in creases, and a crumpled\nshako on the back of his head. He came up to the porch gloomily, hanging\nhis head.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLavw\xc3\xbaska!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted loudly and angrily, \xe2\x80\x9ctake it off,\nblockhead!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I am taking it off,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Lavr\xc3\xbashka\xe2\x80\x99s voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you\xe2\x80\x99re up already,\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov, entering the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLong ago,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rost\xc3\xb3v, \xe2\x80\x9cI have already been for the hay,\nand have seen Fr\xc3\xa4ulein Mathilde.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWeally! And I\xe2\x80\x99ve been losing, bwother. I lost yesterday like a\ndamned fool!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Den\xc3\xadsov, not pronouncing his r\xe2\x80\x99s. \xe2\x80\x9cSuch ill\nluck! Such ill luck. As soon as you left, it began and went on. Hullo\nthere! Tea!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPuckering up his face though smiling, and showing his short strong\nteeth, he began with stubby fingers of both hands to ruffle up his thick\ntangled black hair.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what devil made me go to that wat?\xe2\x80\x9d (an officer nicknamed\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe rat\xe2\x80\x9d) he said, rubbing his forehead and whole face with both\nhands. \xe2\x80\x9cJust fancy, he didn\xe2\x80\x99t let me win a single cahd, not one\ncahd.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe took the lighted pipe that was offered to him, gripped it in his\nfist, and tapped it on the floor, making the sparks fly, while he\ncontinued to shout.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe lets one win the singles and collahs it as soon as one doubles it;\ngives the singles and snatches the doubles!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe scattered the burning tobacco, smashed the pipe, and threw it away.\nThen he remained silent for a while, and all at once looked cheerfully\nwith his glittering, black eyes at Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf at least we had some women here; but there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing foh one\nto do but dwink. If we could only get to fighting soon. Hullo, who\xe2\x80\x99s\nthere?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, turning to the door as he heard a tread of heavy\nboots and the clinking of spurs that came to a stop, and a respectful\ncough.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe squadron quartermaster!\xe2\x80\x9d said Lavr\xc3\xbashka.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s face puckered still more.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWetched!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered, throwing down a purse with some gold in it.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWost\xc3\xb3v, deah fellow, just see how much there is left and shove the\npurse undah the pillow,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, and went out to the quartermaster.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v took the money and, mechanically arranging the old and new coins\nin separate piles, began counting them.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! Tely\xc3\xa1nin! How d\xe2\x80\x99ye do? They plucked me last night,\xe2\x80\x9d came\nDen\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s voice from the next room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere? At Bykov\xe2\x80\x99s, at the rat\xe2\x80\x99s... I knew it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied a piping\nvoice, and Lieutenant Tely\xc3\xa1nin, a small officer of the same squadron,\nentered the room.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v thrust the purse under the pillow and shook the damp little hand\nwhich was offered him. Tely\xc3\xa1nin for some reason had been transferred\nfrom the Guards just before this campaign. He behaved very well in the\nregiment but was not liked; Rost\xc3\xb3v especially detested him and was\nunable to overcome or conceal his groundless antipathy to the man.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, young cavalryman, how is my Rook behaving?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. (Rook\nwas a young horse Tely\xc3\xa1nin had sold to Rost\xc3\xb3v.)\n\nThe lieutenant never looked the man he was speaking to straight in the\nface; his eyes continually wandered from one object to another.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw you riding this morning...\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he\xe2\x80\x99s all right, a good horse,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rost\xc3\xb3v, though the\nhorse for which he had paid seven hundred rubbles was not worth half\nthat sum. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s begun to go a little lame on the left foreleg,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nadded.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe hoof\xe2\x80\x99s cracked! That\xe2\x80\x99s nothing. I\xe2\x80\x99ll teach you what to do\nand show you what kind of rivet to use.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, please do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll show you, I\xe2\x80\x99ll show you! It\xe2\x80\x99s not a secret. And it\xe2\x80\x99s a\nhorse you\xe2\x80\x99ll thank me for.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I\xe2\x80\x99ll have it brought round,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v wishing to avoid\nTely\xc3\xa1nin, and he went out to give the order.\n\nIn the passage Den\xc3\xadsov, with a pipe, was squatting on the threshold\nfacing the quartermaster who was reporting to him. On seeing Rost\xc3\xb3v,\nDen\xc3\xadsov screwed up his face and pointing over his shoulder with his\nthumb to the room where Tely\xc3\xa1nin was sitting, he frowned and gave a\nshudder of disgust.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUgh! I don\xe2\x80\x99t like that fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, regardless of the\nquartermaster\xe2\x80\x99s presence.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v shrugged his shoulders as much as to say: \xe2\x80\x9cNor do I, but\nwhat\xe2\x80\x99s one to do?\xe2\x80\x9d and, having given his order, he returned to\nTely\xc3\xa1nin.\n\nTely\xc3\xa1nin was sitting in the same indolent pose in which Rost\xc3\xb3v had\nleft him, rubbing his small white hands.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell there certainly are disgusting people,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Rost\xc3\xb3v as he\nentered.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you told them to bring the horse?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Tely\xc3\xa1nin, getting up\nand looking carelessly about him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go ourselves. I only came round to ask Den\xc3\xadsov about\nyesterday\xe2\x80\x99s order. Have you got it, Den\xc3\xadsov?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot yet. But where are you off to?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to teach this young man how to shoe a horse,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nTely\xc3\xa1nin.\n\nThey went through the porch and into the stable. The lieutenant\nexplained how to rivet the hoof and went away to his own quarters.\n\nWhen Rost\xc3\xb3v went back there was a bottle of vodka and a sausage on the\ntable. Den\xc3\xadsov was sitting there scratching with his pen on a sheet of\npaper. He looked gloomily in Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s face and said: \xe2\x80\x9cI am witing\nto her.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe leaned his elbows on the table with his pen in his hand and,\nevidently glad of a chance to say quicker in words what he wanted to\nwrite, told Rost\xc3\xb3v the contents of his letter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, my fwiend,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwe sleep when we don\xe2\x80\x99t love. We\nare childwen of the dust... but one falls in love and one is a God, one\nis pua\xe2\x80\x99 as on the fihst day of cweation... Who\xe2\x80\x99s that now? Send him\nto the devil, I\xe2\x80\x99m busy!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted to Lavr\xc3\xbashka, who went up to\nhim not in the least abashed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho should it be? You yourself told him to come. It\xe2\x80\x99s the\nquartermaster for the money.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov frowned and was about to shout some reply but stopped.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWetched business,\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cHow much is left in\nthe puhse?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, turning to Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeven new and three old imperials.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it\xe2\x80\x99s wetched! Well, what are you standing there for, you\nsca\xe2\x80\x99cwow? Call the quahtehmasteh,\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted to Lavr\xc3\xbashka.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease, Den\xc3\xadsov, let me lend you some: I have some, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid Rost\xc3\xb3v, blushing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t like bowwowing from my own fellows, I don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d growled\nDen\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if you won\xe2\x80\x99t accept money from me like a comrade, you will\noffend me. Really I have some,\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v repeated.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Den\xc3\xadsov went to the bed to get the purse from under the pillow.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere have you put it, Wost\xc3\xb3v?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnder the lower pillow.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not there.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov threw both pillows on the floor. The purse was not there.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a miwacle.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait, haven\xe2\x80\x99t you dropped it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v, picking up the\npillows one at a time and shaking them.\n\nHe pulled off the quilt and shook it. The purse was not there.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me, can I have forgotten? No, I remember thinking that you kept\nit under your head like a treasure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v. \xe2\x80\x9cI put it just\nhere. Where is it?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, turning to Lavr\xc3\xbashka.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t been in the room. It must be where you put it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it isn\xe2\x80\x99t?...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re always like that; you thwow a thing down anywhere and forget\nit. Feel in your pockets.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, if I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t thought of it being a treasure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v,\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut I remember putting it there.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nLavr\xc3\xbashka turned all the bedding over, looked under the bed and under\nthe table, searched everywhere, and stood still in the middle of the\nroom. Den\xc3\xadsov silently watched Lavr\xc3\xbashka\xe2\x80\x99s movements, and when the\nlatter threw up his arms in surprise saying it was nowhere to be found\nDen\xc3\xadsov glanced at Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWost\xc3\xb3v, you\xe2\x80\x99ve not been playing schoolboy twicks...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v felt Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s gaze fixed on him, raised his eyes, and\ninstantly dropped them again. All the blood which had seemed congested\nsomewhere below his throat rushed to his face and eyes. He could not\ndraw breath.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd there hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been anyone in the room except the lieutenant and\nyourselves. Den\xc3\xadsov paused, thought\na moment, and, evidently understanding what Rost\xc3\xb3v hinted at, seized\nhis arm.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, and the veins on his forehead and neck stood\nout like cords. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are mad, I tell you. I won\xe2\x80\x99t allow it.\nThe purse is here! I\xe2\x80\x99ll flay this scoundwel alive, and it will be\nfound.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know who has taken it,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Rost\xc3\xb3v in an unsteady voice,\nand went to the door.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I tell you, don\xe2\x80\x99t you dahe to do it!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Den\xc3\xadsov,\nrushing at the cadet to restrain him.\n\nBut Rost\xc3\xb3v pulled away his arm and, with as much anger as though\nDen\xc3\xadsov were his worst enemy, firmly fixed his eyes directly on his\nface.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you understand what you\xe2\x80\x99re saying?\xe2\x80\x9d he said in a trembling\nvoice. \xe2\x80\x9cThere was no one else in the room except myself. So that if it\nis not so, then...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe could not finish, and ran out of the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, may the devil take you and evewybody,\xe2\x80\x9d were the last words\nRost\xc3\xb3v heard.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v went to Tely\xc3\xa1nin\xe2\x80\x99s quarters.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe master is not in, he\xe2\x80\x99s gone to headquarters,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nTely\xc3\xa1nin\xe2\x80\x99s orderly. \xe2\x80\x9cHas something happened?\xe2\x80\x9d he added, surprised\nat the cadet\xe2\x80\x99s troubled face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve only just missed him,\xe2\x80\x9d said the orderly.\n\nThe headquarters were situated two miles away from Salzeneck, and\nRost\xc3\xb3v, without returning home, took a horse and rode there. There was\nan inn in the village which the officers frequented. Rost\xc3\xb3v rode up to\nit and saw Tely\xc3\xa1nin\xe2\x80\x99s horse at the porch.\n\nIn the second room of the inn the lieutenant was sitting over a dish of\nsausages and a bottle of wine.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you\xe2\x80\x99ve come here too, young man!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, smiling and\nraising his eyebrows.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v as if it cost him a great deal to utter the\nword; and he sat down at the nearest table.\n\nBoth were silent. There were two Germans and a Russian officer in the\nroom. No one spoke and the only sounds heard were the clatter of knives\nand the munching of the lieutenant.\n\nWhen Tely\xc3\xa1nin had finished his lunch he took out of his pocket a double\npurse and, drawing its rings aside with his small, white, turned-up\nfingers, drew out a gold imperial, and lifting his eyebrows gave it to\nthe waiter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease be quick,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\nThe coin was a new one. Rost\xc3\xb3v rose and went up to Tely\xc3\xa1nin.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllow me to look at your purse,\xe2\x80\x9d he said in a low, almost\ninaudible, voice.\n\nWith shifting eyes but eyebrows still raised, Tely\xc3\xa1nin handed him the\npurse.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it\xe2\x80\x99s a nice purse. Yes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, growing suddenly\npale, and added, \xe2\x80\x9cLook at it, young man.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v took the purse in his hand, examined it and the money in it, and\nlooked at Tely\xc3\xa1nin. The lieutenant was looking about in his usual way\nand suddenly seemed to grow very merry.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we get to Vienna I\xe2\x80\x99ll get rid of it there but in these wretched\nlittle towns there\xe2\x80\x99s nowhere to spend it,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, let me\nhave it, young man, I\xe2\x80\x99m going.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v did not speak.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you? Are you going to have lunch too? They feed you quite\ndecently here,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Tely\xc3\xa1nin. \xe2\x80\x9cNow then, let me have it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe stretched out his hand to take hold of the purse. Rost\xc3\xb3v let go of\nit. Tely\xc3\xa1nin took the purse and began carelessly slipping it into the\npocket of his riding breeches, with his eyebrows lifted and his mouth\nslightly open, as if to say, \xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, I am putting my purse in my\npocket and that\xe2\x80\x99s quite simple and is no one else\xe2\x80\x99s business.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, young man?\xe2\x80\x9d he said with a sigh, and from under his lifted\nbrows he glanced into Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s eyes.\n\nSome flash as of an electric spark shot from Tely\xc3\xa1nin\xe2\x80\x99s eyes to\nRost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s and back, and back again and again in an instant.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v, catching hold of Tely\xc3\xa1nin\xe2\x80\x99s arm and\nalmost dragging him to the window. \xe2\x80\x9cThat money is Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s; you\ntook it...\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered just above Tely\xc3\xa1nin\xe2\x80\x99s ear.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? What? How dare you? What?\xe2\x80\x9d said Tely\xc3\xa1nin.\n\nBut these words came like a piteous, despairing cry and an entreaty for\npardon. As soon as Rost\xc3\xb3v heard them, an enormous load of doubt\nfell from him. He was glad, and at the same instant began to pity the\nmiserable man who stood before him, but the task he had begun had to be\ncompleted.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeaven only knows what the people here may imagine,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered\nTely\xc3\xa1nin, taking up his cap and moving toward a small empty room. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\nmust have an explanation...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it and shall prove it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nEvery muscle of Tely\xc3\xa1nin\xe2\x80\x99s pale, terrified face began to quiver, his\neyes still shifted from side to side but with a downward look not rising\nto Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s face, and his sobs were audible.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount!... Don\xe2\x80\x99t ruin a young fellow... here is this wretched money,\ntake it...\xe2\x80\x9d He threw it on the table. \xe2\x80\x9cI have an old father and\nmother!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v took the money, avoiding Tely\xc3\xa1nin\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, and went out of the\nroom without a word. But at the door he stopped and then retraced his\nsteps. \xe2\x80\x9cO God,\xe2\x80\x9d he said with tears in his eyes, \xe2\x80\x9chow could you do\nit?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount...\xe2\x80\x9d said Tely\xc3\xa1nin drawing nearer to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t touch me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v, drawing back. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you need it,\ntake the money,\xe2\x80\x9d and he threw the purse to him and ran out of the inn.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER V\n\nThat same evening there was an animated discussion among the\nsquadron\xe2\x80\x99s officers in Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s quarters.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I tell you, Rost\xc3\xb3v, that you must apologize to the colonel!\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid a tall, grizzly-haired staff captain, with enormous mustaches and\nmany wrinkles on his large features, to Rost\xc3\xb3v who was crimson with\nexcitement.\n\nThe staff captain, K\xc3\xadrsten, had twice been reduced to the ranks for\naffairs of honor and had twice regained his commission.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will allow no one to call me a liar!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Rost\xc3\xb3v. \xe2\x80\x9cHe told\nme I lied, and I told him he lied. And there it rests. He may keep me\non duty every day, or may place me under arrest, but no one can make\nme apologize, because if he, as commander of this regiment, thinks it\nbeneath his dignity to give me satisfaction, then...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou just wait a moment, my dear fellow, and listen,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted\nthe staff captain in his deep bass, calmly stroking his long mustache.\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou tell the colonel in the presence of other officers that an\nofficer has stolen...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not to blame that the conversation began in the presence of\nother officers. Perhaps I ought not to have spoken before them, but I am\nnot a diplomatist. That\xe2\x80\x99s why I joined the hussars, thinking that here\none would not need finesse; and he tells me that I am lying\xe2\x80\x94so let him\ngive me satisfaction...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all right. No one thinks you a coward, but that\xe2\x80\x99s not the\npoint. Ask Den\xc3\xadsov whether it is not out of the question for a cadet to\ndemand satisfaction of his regimental commander?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov sat gloomily biting his mustache and listening to the\nconversation, evidently with no wish to take part in it. He answered the\nstaff captain\xe2\x80\x99s question by a disapproving shake of his head.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou speak to the colonel about this nasty business before other\nofficers,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the staff captain, \xe2\x80\x9cand Bogd\xc3\xa1nich\xe2\x80\x9d (the\ncolonel was called Bogd\xc3\xa1nich) \xe2\x80\x9cshuts you up.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe did not shut me up, he said I was telling an untruth.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, have it so, and you talked a lot of nonsense to him and must\napologize.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot on any account!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not expect this of you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the staff captain seriously and\nseverely. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t wish to apologize, but, man, it\xe2\x80\x99s not only to\nhim but to the whole regiment\xe2\x80\x94all of us\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99re to blame all round.\nThe case is this: you ought to have thought the matter over and\ntaken advice; but no, you go and blurt it all straight out before the\nofficers. Now what was the colonel to do? Have the officer tried and\ndisgrace the whole regiment? Disgrace the whole regiment because of one\nscoundrel? Is that how you look at it? We don\xe2\x80\x99t see it like that. And\nBogd\xc3\xa1nich was a brick: he told you you were saying what was not true.\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s not pleasant, but what\xe2\x80\x99s to be done, my dear fellow? You landed\nyourself in it. And now, when one wants to smooth the thing over, some\nconceit prevents your apologizing, and you wish to make the whole\naffair public. You are offended at being put on duty a bit, but why not\napologize to an old and honorable officer? Whatever Bogd\xc3\xa1nich may\nbe, anyway he is an honorable and brave old colonel! You\xe2\x80\x99re quick at\ntaking offense, but you don\xe2\x80\x99t mind disgracing the whole regiment!\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe staff captain\xe2\x80\x99s voice began to tremble. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have been in the\nregiment next to no time, my lad, you\xe2\x80\x99re here today and tomorrow\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll be appointed adjutant somewhere and can snap your fingers when\nit is said \xe2\x80\x98There are thieves among the P\xc3\xa1vlograd officers!\xe2\x80\x99 But\nit\xe2\x80\x99s not all the same to us! Am I not right, Den\xc3\xadsov? It\xe2\x80\x99s not the\nsame!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov remained silent and did not move, but occasionally looked with\nhis glittering black eyes at Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou value your own pride and don\xe2\x80\x99t wish to apologize,\xe2\x80\x9d continued\nthe staff captain, \xe2\x80\x9cbut we old fellows, who have grown up in and, God\nwilling, are going to die in the regiment, we prize the honor of the\nregiment, and Bogd\xc3\xa1nich knows it. Oh, we do prize it, old fellow! And\nall this is not right, it\xe2\x80\x99s not right! You may take offense or not but\nI always stick to mother truth. It\xe2\x80\x99s not right!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd the staff captain rose and turned away from Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s twue, devil take it!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Den\xc3\xadsov, jumping up. \xe2\x80\x9cNow\nthen, Wost\xc3\xb3v, now then!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v, growing red and pale alternately, looked first at one officer\nand then at the other.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, gentlemen, no... you mustn\xe2\x80\x99t think... I quite understand.\nYou\xe2\x80\x99re wrong to think that of me... I... for me... for the honor of\nthe regiment I\xe2\x80\x99d... Ah well, I\xe2\x80\x99ll show that in action, and for me\nthe honor of the flag... Well, never mind, it\xe2\x80\x99s true I\xe2\x80\x99m to blame,\nto blame all round. Well, what else do you want?...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, that\xe2\x80\x99s right, Count!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the staff captain, turning\nround and clapping Rost\xc3\xb3v on the shoulder with his big hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Den\xc3\xadsov, \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s a fine fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s better, Count,\xe2\x80\x9d said the staff captain, beginning to\naddress Rost\xc3\xb3v by his title, as if in recognition of his confession.\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo and apologize, your excellency. Yes, go!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, I\xe2\x80\x99ll do anything. No one shall hear a word from me,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid Rost\xc3\xb3v in an imploring voice, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I can\xe2\x80\x99t apologize, by God I\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t, do what you will! How can I go and apologize like a little boy\nasking forgiveness?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov began to laugh.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99ll be worse for you. Bogd\xc3\xa1nich is vindictive and you\xe2\x80\x99ll pay\nfor your obstinacy,\xe2\x80\x9d said K\xc3\xadrsten.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, on my word it\xe2\x80\x99s not obstinacy! I can\xe2\x80\x99t describe the feeling.\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it\xe2\x80\x99s as you like,\xe2\x80\x9d said the staff captain. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd what has\nbecome of that scoundrel?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has weported himself sick, he\xe2\x80\x99s to be stwuck off the list\ntomowwow,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is an illness, there\xe2\x80\x99s no other way of explaining it,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nthe staff captain.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIllness or not, he\xe2\x80\x99d better not cwoss my path. I\xe2\x80\x99d kill him!\xe2\x80\x9d\nshouted Den\xc3\xadsov in a bloodthirsty tone.\n\nJust then Zherk\xc3\xb3v entered the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat brings you here?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the officers turning to the newcomer.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re to go into action, gentlemen! Mack has surrendered with his\nwhole army.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not true!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve seen him myself!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? Saw the real Mack? With hands and feet?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cInto action! Into action! Bring him a bottle for such news! But how\ndid you come here?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been sent back to the regiment all on account of that devil,\nMack. An Austrian general complained of me. I congratulated him on\nMack\xe2\x80\x99s arrival... What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter, Rost\xc3\xb3v? You look as if you\xe2\x80\x99d\njust come out of a hot bath.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my dear fellow, we\xe2\x80\x99re in such a stew here these last two\ndays.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe regimental adjutant came in and confirmed the news brought by\nZherk\xc3\xb3v. They were under orders to advance next day.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re going into action, gentlemen!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, thank God! We\xe2\x80\x99ve been sitting here too long!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VI\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov fell back toward Vienna, destroying behind him the bridges over\nthe rivers Inn (at Braunau) and Traun (near Linz). On October 23 the\nRussian troops were crossing the river Enns. At midday the Russian\nbaggage train, the artillery, and columns of troops were defiling\nthrough the town of Enns on both sides of the bridge.\n\nIt was a warm, rainy, autumnal day. The wide expanse that opened out\nbefore the heights on which the Russian batteries stood guarding the\nbridge was at times veiled by a diaphanous curtain of slanting rain, and\nthen, suddenly spread out in the sunlight, far-distant objects could\nbe clearly seen glittering as though freshly varnished. Down below,\nthe little town could be seen with its white, red-roofed houses, its\ncathedral, and its bridge, on both sides of which streamed jostling\nmasses of Russian troops. At the bend of the Danube, vessels, an island,\nand a castle with a park surrounded by the waters of the confluence of\nthe Enns and the Danube became visible, and the rocky left bank of the\nDanube covered with pine forests, with a mystic background of green\ntreetops and bluish gorges. The turrets of a convent stood out beyond a\nwild virgin pine forest, and far away on the other side of the Enns the\nenemy\xe2\x80\x99s horse patrols could be discerned.\n\nAmong the field guns on the brow of the hill the general in command of\nthe rearguard stood with a staff officer, scanning the country through\nhis fieldglass. A little behind them Nesv\xc3\xadtski, who had been sent to\nthe rearguard by the commander in chief, was sitting on the trail of a\ngun carriage. A Cossack who accompanied him had handed him a knapsack\nand a flask, and Nesv\xc3\xadtski was treating some officers to pies and real\ndoppelk\xc3\xbcmmel. The officers gladly gathered round him, some on their\nknees, some squatting Turkish fashion on the wet grass.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the Austrian prince who built that castle was no fool. It\xe2\x80\x99s\na fine place! Why are you not eating anything, gentlemen?\xe2\x80\x9d Nesv\xc3\xadtski\nwas saying.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you very much, Prince,\xe2\x80\x9d answered one of the officers, pleased\nto be talking to a staff officer of such importance. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a lovely\nplace! We passed close to the park and saw two deer... and what a\nsplendid house!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook, Prince,\xe2\x80\x9d said another, who would have dearly liked to take\nanother pie but felt shy, and therefore pretended to be examining the\ncountryside\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSee, our infantrymen have already got there. Look there\nin the meadow behind the village, three of them are dragging something.\nThey\xe2\x80\x99ll ransack that castle,\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked with evident approval.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo they will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nesv\xc3\xadtski. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, but what I should like,\xe2\x80\x9d\nadded he, munching a pie in his moist-lipped handsome mouth, \xe2\x80\x9cwould be\nto slip in over there.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe pointed with a smile to a turreted nunnery, and his eyes narrowed and\ngleamed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat would be fine, gentlemen!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe officers laughed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust to flutter the nuns a bit. They say there are Italian girls\namong them. On my word I\xe2\x80\x99d give five years of my life for it!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey must be feeling dull, too,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the bolder officers,\nlaughing.\n\nMeanwhile the staff officer standing in front pointed out something to\nthe general, who looked through his field glass.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, so it is, so it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said the general angrily, lowering the\nfield glass and shrugging his shoulders, \xe2\x80\x9cso it is! They\xe2\x80\x99ll be fired\non at the crossing. And why are they dawdling there?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nOn the opposite side the enemy could be seen by the naked eye, and from\ntheir battery a milk-white cloud arose. Then came the distant report of\na shot, and our troops could be seen hurrying to the crossing.\n\nNesv\xc3\xadtski rose, puffing, and went up to the general, smiling.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould not your excellency like a little refreshment?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a bad business,\xe2\x80\x9d said the general without answering him,\n\xe2\x80\x9cour men have been wasting time.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHadn\xe2\x80\x99t I better ride over, your excellency?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Nesv\xc3\xadtski.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, please do,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the general, and he repeated the order\nthat had already once been given in detail: \xe2\x80\x9cand tell the hussars\nthat they are to cross last and to fire the bridge as I ordered; and the\ninflammable material on the bridge must be reinspected.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Nesv\xc3\xadtski.\n\nHe called the Cossack with his horse, told him to put away the knapsack\nand flask, and swung his heavy person easily into the saddle.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll really call in on the nuns,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the officers who\nwatched him smilingly, and he rode off by the winding path down the\nhill.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow then, let\xe2\x80\x99s see how far it will carry, Captain. Just try!\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid the general, turning to an artillery officer. \xe2\x80\x9cHave a little fun\nto pass the time.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCrew, to your guns!\xe2\x80\x9d commanded the officer.\n\nIn a moment the men came running gaily from their campfires and began\nloading.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne!\xe2\x80\x9d came the command.\n\nNumber one jumped briskly aside. The gun rang out with a deafening\nmetallic roar, and a whistling grenade flew above the heads of our\ntroops below the hill and fell far short of the enemy, a little smoke\nshowing the spot where it burst.\n\nThe faces of officers and men brightened up at the sound.
