Everyone got\nup and began watching the movements of our troops below, as plainly\nvisible as if but a stone\xe2\x80\x99s throw away, and the movements of the\napproaching enemy farther off. At the same instant the sun came fully\nout from behind the clouds, and the clear sound of the solitary shot\nand the brilliance of the bright sunshine merged in a single joyous and\nspirited impression.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VII\n\nTwo of the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s shots had already flown across the bridge, where\nthere was a crush. Halfway across stood Prince Nesv\xc3\xadtski, who had\nalighted from his horse and whose big body was jammed against the\nrailings. He looked back laughing to the Cossack who stood a few\nsteps behind him holding two horses by their bridles. Each time Prince\nNesv\xc3\xadtski tried to move on, soldiers and carts pushed him back again\nand pressed him against the railings, and all he could do was to smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a fine fellow you are, friend!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Cossack to a convoy\nsoldier with a wagon, who was pressing onto the infantrymen who were\ncrowded together close to his wheels and his horses. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a fellow!\nYou can\xe2\x80\x99t wait a moment! Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see the general wants to pass?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBut the convoyman took no notice of the word \xe2\x80\x9cgeneral\xe2\x80\x9d and shouted\nat the soldiers who were blocking his way. \xe2\x80\x9cHi there, boys! Keep to\nthe left! Wait a bit.\xe2\x80\x9d But the soldiers, crowded together shoulder to\nshoulder, their bayonets interlocking, moved over the bridge in a dense\nmass. Looking down over the rails Prince Nesv\xc3\xadtski saw the rapid, noisy\nlittle waves of the Enns, which rippling and eddying round the piles of\nthe bridge chased each other along. Looking on the bridge he saw equally\nuniform living waves of soldiers, shoulder straps, covered shakos,\nknapsacks, bayonets, long muskets, and, under the shakos, faces with\nbroad cheekbones, sunken cheeks, and listless tired expressions, and\nfeet that moved through the sticky mud that covered the planks of the\nbridge. Sometimes through the monotonous waves of men, like a fleck of\nwhite foam on the waves of the Enns, an officer, in a cloak and with\na type of face different from that of the men, squeezed his way along;\nsometimes like a chip of wood whirling in the river, an hussar on foot,\nan orderly, or a townsman was carried through the waves of infantry;\nand sometimes like a log floating down the river, an officers\xe2\x80\x99 or\ncompany\xe2\x80\x99s baggage wagon, piled high, leather covered, and hemmed in on\nall sides, moved across the bridge.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s as if a dam had burst,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Cossack hopelessly. \xe2\x80\x9cAre\nthere many more of you to come?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA million all but one!\xe2\x80\x9d replied a waggish soldier in a torn coat,\nwith a wink, and passed on followed by another, an old man.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he\xe2\x80\x9d (he meant the enemy) \xe2\x80\x9cbegins popping at the bridge now,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid the old soldier dismally to a comrade, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ll forget to\nscratch yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThat soldier passed on, and after him came another sitting on a cart.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere the devil have the leg bands been shoved to?\xe2\x80\x9d said an\norderly, running behind the cart and fumbling in the back of it.\n\nAnd he also passed on with the wagon. Then came some merry soldiers who\nhad evidently been drinking.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then, old fellow, he gives him one in the teeth with the butt\nend of his gun...\xe2\x80\x9d a soldier whose greatcoat was well tucked up said\ngaily, with a wide swing of his arm.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the ham was just delicious...\xe2\x80\x9d answered another with a loud\nlaugh. And they, too, passed on, so that Nesv\xc3\xadtski did not learn who\nhad been struck on the teeth, or what the ham had to do with it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah! How they scurry. He just sends a ball and they think they\xe2\x80\x99ll\nall be killed,\xe2\x80\x9d a sergeant was saying angrily and reproachfully.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs it flies past me, Daddy, the ball I mean,\xe2\x80\x9d said a young soldier\nwith an enormous mouth, hardly refraining from laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cI felt like\ndying of fright. I did, \xe2\x80\x98pon my word, I got that frightened!\xe2\x80\x9d said\nhe, as if bragging of having been frightened.\n\nThat one also passed. Then followed a cart unlike any that had gone\nbefore. It was a German cart with a pair of horses led by a German, and\nseemed loaded with a whole houseful of effects. A fine brindled cow with\na large udder was attached to the cart behind. A woman with an unweaned\nbaby, an old woman, and a healthy German girl with bright red cheeks\nwere sitting on some feather beds. Evidently these fugitives were\nallowed to pass by special permission. The eyes of all the soldiers\nturned toward the women, and while the vehicle was passing at foot pace\nall the soldiers\xe2\x80\x99 remarks related to the two young ones. Every face\nbore almost the same smile, expressing unseemly thoughts about the\nwomen.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust see, the German sausage is making tracks, too!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSell me the missis,\xe2\x80\x9d said another soldier, addressing the German,\nwho, angry and frightened, strode energetically along with downcast\neyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee how smart she\xe2\x80\x99s made herself! Oh, the devils!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, Fed\xc3\xb3tov, you should be quartered on them!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have seen as much before now, mate!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d asked an infantry officer who was eating an\napple, also half smiling as he looked at the handsome girl.\n\nThe German closed his eyes, signifying that he did not understand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake it if you like,\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer, giving the girl an apple.\n\nThe girl smiled and took it. Nesv\xc3\xadtski like the rest of the men on the\nbridge did not take his eyes off the women till they had passed. When\nthey had gone by, the same stream of soldiers followed, with the same\nkind of talk, and at last all stopped. As often happens, the horses of\na convoy wagon became restive at the end of the bridge, and the whole\ncrowd had to wait.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why are they stopping? There\xe2\x80\x99s no proper order!\xe2\x80\x9d said the\nsoldiers. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you shoving to? Devil take you! Can\xe2\x80\x99t you wait?\nIt\xe2\x80\x99ll be worse if he fires the bridge. See, here\xe2\x80\x99s an officer jammed\nin too\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94different voices were saying in the crowd, as the men looked\nat one another, and all pressed toward the exit from the bridge.\n\nLooking down at the waters of the Enns under the bridge, Nesv\xc3\xadtski\nsuddenly heard a sound new to him, of something swiftly approaching...\nsomething big, that splashed into the water.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust see where it carries to!\xe2\x80\x9d a soldier near by said sternly,\nlooking round at the sound.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEncouraging us to get along quicker,\xe2\x80\x9d said another uneasily.\n\nThe crowd moved on again. Nesv\xc3\xadtski realized that it was a cannon ball.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHey, Cossack, my horse!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, then, you there! get out\nof the way! Make way!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nWith great difficulty he managed to get to his horse, and shouting\ncontinually he moved on. The soldiers squeezed themselves to make way\nfor him, but again pressed on him so that they jammed his leg, and those\nnearest him were not to blame for they were themselves pressed still\nharder from behind.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNesv\xc3\xadtski, Nesv\xc3\xadtski! you numskull!\xe2\x80\x9d came a hoarse voice from\nbehind him.\n\nNesv\xc3\xadtski looked round and saw, some fifteen paces away but separated\nby the living mass of moving infantry, V\xc3\xa1ska Den\xc3\xadsov, red and shaggy,\nwith his cap on the back of his black head and a cloak hanging jauntily\nover his shoulder.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell these devils, these fiends, to let me pass!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Den\xc3\xadsov\nevidently in a fit of rage, his coal-black eyes with their bloodshot\nwhites glittering and rolling as he waved his sheathed saber in a small\nbare hand as red as his face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, V\xc3\xa1ska!\xe2\x80\x9d joyfully replied Nesv\xc3\xadtski. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s up with\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe squadwon can\xe2\x80\x99t pass,\xe2\x80\x9d shouted V\xc3\xa1ska Den\xc3\xadsov, showing his\nwhite teeth fiercely and spurring his black thoroughbred Arab, which\ntwitched its ears as the bayonets touched it, and snorted, spurting\nwhite foam from his bit, tramping the planks of the bridge with his\nhoofs, and apparently ready to jump over the railings had his rider let\nhim. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is this? They\xe2\x80\x99re like sheep! Just like sheep! Out of the\nway!... Let us pass!... Stop there, you devil with the cart! I\xe2\x80\x99ll hack\nyou with my saber!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted, actually drawing his saber from its\nscabbard and flourishing it.\n\nThe soldiers crowded against one another with terrified faces, and\nDen\xc3\xadsov joined Nesv\xc3\xadtski.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow\xe2\x80\x99s it you\xe2\x80\x99re not drunk today?\xe2\x80\x9d said Nesv\xc3\xadtski when the\nother had ridden up to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey don\xe2\x80\x99t even give one time to dwink!\xe2\x80\x9d answered V\xc3\xa1ska\nDen\xc3\xadsov. \xe2\x80\x9cThey keep dwagging the wegiment to and fwo all day. If they\nmean to fight, let\xe2\x80\x99s fight. But the devil knows what this is.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a dandy you are today!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nesv\xc3\xadtski, looking at\nDen\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s new cloak and saddlecloth.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov smiled, took out of his sabretache a handkerchief that diffused\na smell of perfume, and put it to Nesv\xc3\xadtski\xe2\x80\x99s nose.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course. I\xe2\x80\x99m going into action! I\xe2\x80\x99ve shaved, bwushed my teeth,\nand scented myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe imposing figure of Nesv\xc3\xadtski followed by his Cossack, and\nthe determination of Den\xc3\xadsov who flourished his sword and shouted\nfrantically, had such an effect that they managed to squeeze through\nto the farther side of the bridge and stopped the infantry. Beside the\nbridge Nesv\xc3\xadtski found the colonel to whom he had to deliver the order,\nand having done this he rode back.\n\nHaving cleared the way Den\xc3\xadsov stopped at the end of the bridge.\nCarelessly holding in his stallion that was neighing and pawing the\nground, eager to rejoin its fellows, he watched his squadron draw\nnearer. Then the clang of hoofs, as of several horses galloping,\nresounded on the planks of the bridge, and the squadron, officers in\nfront and men four abreast, spread across the bridge and began to emerge\non his side of it.\n\nThe infantry who had been stopped crowded near the bridge in the\ntrampled mud and gazed with that particular feeling of ill-will,\nestrangement, and ridicule with which troops of different arms usually\nencounter one another at the clean, smart hussars who moved past them in\nregular order.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSmart lads! Only fit for a fair!\xe2\x80\x9d said one.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat good are they? They\xe2\x80\x99re led about just for show!\xe2\x80\x9d remarked\nanother.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t kick up the dust, you infantry!\xe2\x80\x9d jested an hussar whose\nprancing horse had splashed mud over some foot soldiers.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d like to put you on a two days\xe2\x80\x99 march with a knapsack! Your\nfine cords would soon get a bit rubbed,\xe2\x80\x9d said an infantryman, wiping\nthe mud off his face with his sleeve. \xe2\x80\x9cPerched up there, you\xe2\x80\x99re more\nlike a bird than a man.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere now, Z\xc3\xadkin, they ought to put you on a horse. You\xe2\x80\x99d look\nfine,\xe2\x80\x9d said a corporal, chaffing a thin little soldier who bent under\nthe weight of his knapsack.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake a stick between your legs, that\xe2\x80\x99ll suit you for a horse!\xe2\x80\x9d\nthe hussar shouted back.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VIII\n\nThe last of the infantry hurriedly crossed the bridge, squeezing\ntogether as they approached it as if passing through a funnel. At last\nthe baggage wagons had all crossed, the crush was less, and the last\nbattalion came onto the bridge. Only Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s squadron of hussars\nremained on the farther side of the bridge facing the enemy, who could\nbe seen from the hill on the opposite bank but was not yet visible from\nthe bridge, for the horizon as seen from the valley through which the\nriver flowed was formed by the rising ground only half a mile away.\nAt the foot of the hill lay wasteland over which a few groups of our\nCossack scouts were moving. Suddenly on the road at the top of the high\nground, artillery and troops in blue uniform were seen. These were the\nFrench. A group of Cossack scouts retired down the hill at a trot. All\nthe officers and men of Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s squadron, though they tried to talk\nof other things and to look in other directions, thought only of what\nwas there on the hilltop, and kept constantly looking at the patches\nappearing on the skyline, which they knew to be the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s troops.\nThe weather had cleared again since noon and the sun was descending\nbrightly upon the Danube and the dark hills around it. It was calm, and\nat intervals the bugle calls and the shouts of the enemy could be heard\nfrom the hill. There was no one now between the squadron and the enemy\nexcept a few scattered skirmishers. An empty space of some seven hundred\nyards was all that separated them. The enemy ceased firing, and that\nstern, threatening, inaccessible, and intangible line which separates\ntwo hostile armies was all the more clearly felt.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne step beyond that boundary line which resembles the line dividing\nthe living from the dead lies uncertainty, suffering, and death. And\nwhat is there? Who is there?\xe2\x80\x94there beyond that field, that tree, that\nroof lit up by the sun? No one knows, but one wants to know. You fear\nand yet long to cross that line, and know that sooner or later it must\nbe crossed and you will have to find out what is there, just as you will\ninevitably have to learn what lies the other side of death. But you are\nstrong, healthy, cheerful, and excited, and are surrounded by other such\nexcitedly animated and healthy men.\xe2\x80\x9d So thinks, or at any rate\nfeels, anyone who comes in sight of the enemy, and that feeling gives\na particular glamour and glad keenness of impression to everything that\ntakes place at such moments.\n\nOn the high ground where the enemy was, the smoke of a cannon rose,\nand a ball flew whistling over the heads of the hussar squadron. The\nofficers who had been standing together rode off to their places. The\nhussars began carefully aligning their horses. Silence fell on the whole\nsquadron. All were looking at the enemy in front and at the squadron\ncommander, awaiting the word of command. A second and a third cannon\nball flew past. Evidently they were firing at the hussars, but the balls\nwith rapid rhythmic whistle flew over the heads of the horsemen and fell\nsomewhere beyond them. The hussars did not look round, but at the sound\nof each shot, as at the word of command, the whole squadron with its\nrows of faces so alike yet so different, holding its breath while the\nball flew past, rose in the stirrups and sank back again. The soldiers\nwithout turning their heads glanced at one another, curious to see their\ncomrades\xe2\x80\x99 impression. Every face, from Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s to that of the\nbugler, showed one common expression of conflict, irritation, and\nexcitement, around chin and mouth. The quartermaster frowned, looking\nat the soldiers as if threatening to punish them. Cadet Mir\xc3\xb3nov ducked\nevery time a ball flew past. Rost\xc3\xb3v on the left flank, mounted on his\nRook\xe2\x80\x94a handsome horse despite its game leg\xe2\x80\x94had the happy air of a\nschoolboy called up before a large audience for an examination in which\nhe feels sure he will distinguish himself. He was glancing at everyone\nwith a clear, bright expression, as if asking them to notice how calmly\nhe sat under fire. But despite himself, on his face too that same\nindication of something new and stern showed round the mouth.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x99s that curtseying there? Cadet Miw\xc3\xb3nov! That\xe2\x80\x99s not wight!\nLook at me,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Den\xc3\xadsov who, unable to keep still on one spot,\nkept turning his horse in front of the squadron.\n\nThe black, hairy, snub-nosed face of V\xc3\xa1ska Den\xc3\xadsov, and his whole\nshort sturdy figure with the sinewy hairy hand and stumpy fingers in\nwhich he held the hilt of his naked saber, looked just as it usually\ndid, especially toward evening when he had emptied his second bottle; he\nwas only redder than usual. With his shaggy head thrown back like birds\nwhen they drink, pressing his spurs mercilessly into the sides of his\ngood horse, Bedouin, and sitting as though falling backwards in the\nsaddle, he galloped to the other flank of the squadron and shouted in\na hoarse voice to the men to look to their pistols. He rode up to\nK\xc3\xadrsten. The staff captain on his broad-backed, steady mare came at a\nwalk to meet him. His face with its long mustache was serious as always,\nonly his eyes were brighter than usual.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what about it?\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Den\xc3\xadsov. \xe2\x80\x9cIt won\xe2\x80\x99t come to a\nfight. You\xe2\x80\x99ll see\xe2\x80\x94we shall retire.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil only knows what they\xe2\x80\x99re about!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Wost\xc3\xb3v,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried noticing the cadet\xe2\x80\x99s bright face,\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ve got it at last.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd he smiled approvingly, evidently pleased with the cadet. Rost\xc3\xb3v\nfelt perfectly happy. Just then the commander appeared on the bridge.\nDen\xc3\xadsov galloped up to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency! Let us attack them! I\xe2\x80\x99ll dwive them off.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAttack indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d said the colonel in a bored voice, puckering up his\nface as if driving off a troublesome fly. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd why are you stopping\nhere? Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see the skirmishers are retreating? Lead the squadron\nback.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe squadron crossed the bridge and drew out of range of fire without\nhaving lost a single man. The second squadron that had been in the front\nline followed them across and the last Cossacks quitted the farther side\nof the river.\n\nThe two P\xc3\xa1vlograd squadrons, having crossed the bridge, retired up the\nhill one after the other. Their colonel, Karl Bogd\xc3\xa1nich Schubert, came\nup to Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s squadron and rode at a footpace not far from Rost\xc3\xb3v,\nwithout taking any notice of him although they were now meeting for the\nfirst time since their encounter concerning Tely\xc3\xa1nin. Rost\xc3\xb3v, feeling\nthat he was at the front and in the power of a man toward whom he now\nadmitted that he had been to blame, did not lift his eyes from the\ncolonel\xe2\x80\x99s athletic back, his nape covered with light hair, and his red\nneck. It seemed to Rost\xc3\xb3v that Bogd\xc3\xa1nich was only pretending not\nto notice him, and that his whole aim now was to test the cadet\xe2\x80\x99s\ncourage, so he drew himself up and looked around him merrily; then it\nseemed to him that Bogd\xc3\xa1nich rode so near in order to show him his\ncourage. Next he thought that his enemy would send the squadron on a\ndesperate attack just to punish him\xe2\x80\x94Rost\xc3\xb3v. Then he imagined how,\nafter the attack, Bogd\xc3\xa1nich would come up to him as he lay wounded and\nwould magnanimously extend the hand of reconciliation.\n\nThe high-shouldered figure of Zherk\xc3\xb3v, familiar to the P\xc3\xa1vlograds as\nhe had but recently left their regiment, rode up to the colonel.\nAfter his dismissal from headquarters Zherk\xc3\xb3v had not remained in the\nregiment, saying he was not such a fool as to slave at the front when he\ncould get more rewards by doing nothing on the staff, and had succeeded\nin attaching himself as an orderly officer to Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n. He now\ncame to his former chief with an order from the commander of the rear\nguard.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cColonel,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, addressing Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s enemy with an air of\ngloomy gravity and glancing round at his comrades, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is an order\nto stop and fire the bridge.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn order to who?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the colonel morosely.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t myself know \xe2\x80\x98to who,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d replied the cornet in a\nserious tone, \xe2\x80\x9cbut the prince told me to \xe2\x80\x98go and tell the colonel\nthat the hussars must return quickly and fire the bridge.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nZherk\xc3\xb3v was followed by an officer of the suite who rode up to the\ncolonel of hussars with the same order. After him the stout Nesv\xc3\xadtski\ncame galloping up on a Cossack horse that could scarcely carry his\nweight.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow\xe2\x80\x99s this, Colonel?\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted as he approached. \xe2\x80\x9cI told you\nto fire the bridge, and now someone has gone and blundered; they are all\nbeside themselves over there and one can\xe2\x80\x99t make anything out.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe colonel deliberately stopped the regiment and turned to Nesv\xc3\xadtski.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou spoke to me of inflammable material,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cbut you said\nnothing about firing it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, my dear sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nesv\xc3\xadtski as he drew up, taking off his\ncap and smoothing his hair wet with perspiration with his plump hand,\n\xe2\x80\x9cwasn\xe2\x80\x99t I telling you to fire the bridge, when inflammable material\nhad been put in position?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not your \xe2\x80\x98dear sir,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr. Staff Officer, and you did not tell\nme to burn the bridge! I know the service, and it is my habit orders\nstrictly to obey. You said the bridge would be burned, but who would\nburn it, I could not know by the holy spirit!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that\xe2\x80\x99s always the way!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nesv\xc3\xadtski with a wave of the\nhand. \xe2\x80\x9cHow did you get here?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, turning to Zherk\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the same business. But you are damp! Let me wring you out!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were saying, Mr. Staff Officer...\xe2\x80\x9d continued the colonel in an\noffended tone.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cColonel,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the officer of the suite, \xe2\x80\x9cYou must be\nquick or the enemy will bring up his guns to use grapeshot.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe colonel looked silently at the officer of the suite, at the stout\nstaff officer, and at Zherk\xc3\xb3v, and he frowned.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will the bridge fire,\xe2\x80\x9d he said in a solemn tone as if to announce\nthat in spite of all the unpleasantness he had to endure he would still\ndo the right thing.\n\nStriking his horse with his long muscular legs as if it were to blame\nfor everything, the colonel moved forward and ordered the second\nsquadron, that in which Rost\xc3\xb3v was serving under Den\xc3\xadsov, to return to\nthe bridge.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, it\xe2\x80\x99s just as I thought,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\nwishes to test me!\xe2\x80\x9d His heart contracted and the blood rushed to his\nface. \xe2\x80\x9cLet him see whether I am a coward!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought.\n\nAgain on all the bright faces of the squadron the serious expression\nappeared that they had worn when under fire. Rost\xc3\xb3v watched his enemy,\nthe colonel, closely\xe2\x80\x94to find in his face confirmation of his own\nconjecture, but the colonel did not once glance at Rost\xc3\xb3v, and looked\nas he always did when at the front, solemn and stern. Then came the word\nof command.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook sharp! Look sharp!\xe2\x80\x9d several voices repeated around him.\n\nTheir sabers catching in the bridles and their spurs jingling, the\nhussars hastily dismounted, not knowing what they were to do. The men\nwere crossing themselves. Rost\xc3\xb3v no longer looked at the colonel, he\nhad no time. He was afraid of falling behind the hussars, so much afraid\nthat his heart stood still. His hand trembled as he gave his horse into\nan orderly\xe2\x80\x99s charge, and he felt the blood rush to his heart with\na thud. Den\xc3\xadsov rode past him, leaning back and shouting something.\nRost\xc3\xb3v saw nothing but the hussars running all around him, their spurs\ncatching and their sabers clattering.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cStretchers!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted someone behind him.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v did not think what this call for stretchers meant; he ran on,\ntrying only to be ahead of the others; but just at the bridge, not\nlooking at the ground, he came on some sticky, trodden mud, stumbled,\nand fell on his hands. The others outstripped him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt boss zides, Captain,\xe2\x80\x9d he heard the voice of the colonel, who,\nhaving ridden ahead, had pulled up his horse near the bridge, with a\ntriumphant, cheerful face.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v wiping his muddy hands on his breeches looked at his enemy and\nwas about to run on, thinking that the farther he went to the front\nthe better. But Bogd\xc3\xa1nich, without looking at or recognizing Rost\xc3\xb3v,\nshouted to him:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x99s that running on the middle of the bridge? To the right! Come\nback, Cadet!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried angrily; and turning to Den\xc3\xadsov, who, showing\noff his courage, had ridden on to the planks of the bridge:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy run risks, Captain? You should dismount,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, every bullet has its billet,\xe2\x80\x9d answered V\xc3\xa1ska Den\xc3\xadsov, turning\nin his saddle.\n\n\nMeanwhile Nesv\xc3\xadtski, Zherk\xc3\xb3v, and the officer of the suite were\nstanding together out of range of the shots, watching, now the small\ngroup of men with yellow shakos, dark-green jackets braided with cord,\nand blue riding breeches, who were swarming near the bridge, and then at\nwhat was approaching in the distance from the opposite side\xe2\x80\x94the blue\nuniforms and groups with horses, easily recognizable as artillery.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill they burn the bridge or not? Who\xe2\x80\x99ll get there first? Will they\nget there and fire the bridge or will the French get within grapeshot\nrange and wipe them out?\xe2\x80\x9d These were the questions each man of the\ntroops on the high ground above the bridge involuntarily asked himself\nwith a sinking heart\xe2\x80\x94watching the bridge and the hussars in the bright\nevening light and the blue tunics advancing from the other side with\ntheir bayonets and guns.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUgh. The hussars will get it hot!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nesv\xc3\xadtski; \xe2\x80\x9cthey are\nwithin grapeshot range now.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have taken so many men,\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer of the\nsuite.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue enough,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Nesv\xc3\xadtski; \xe2\x80\x9ctwo smart fellows could have\ndone the job just as well.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d put in Zherk\xc3\xb3v, his eyes fixed on the\nhussars, but still with that na\xc3\xafve air that made it impossible to know\nwhether he was speaking in jest or in earnest. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, your excellency!\nHow you look at things! Send two men? And who then would give us the\nVlad\xc3\xadmir medal and ribbon? But now, even if they do get peppered, the\nsquadron may be recommended for honors and he may get a ribbon. Our\nBogd\xc3\xa1nich knows how things are done.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere now!\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer of the suite, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s\ngrapeshot.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe pointed to the French guns, the limbers of which were being detached\nand hurriedly removed.\n\nOn the French side, amid the groups with cannon, a cloud of smoke\nappeared, then a second and a third almost simultaneously, and at the\nmoment when the first report was heard a fourth was seen. Then two\nreports one after another, and a third.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! Oh!\xe2\x80\x9d groaned Nesv\xc3\xadtski as if in fierce pain, seizing the\nofficer of the suite by the arm. \xe2\x80\x9cLook! A man has fallen! Fallen,\nfallen!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo, I think.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I were Tsar I would never go to war,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nesv\xc3\xadtski, turning\naway.\n\nThe French guns were hastily reloaded. The infantry in their blue\nuniforms advanced toward the bridge at a run. Smoke appeared again\nbut at irregular intervals, and grapeshot cracked and rattled onto the\nbridge. But this time Nesv\xc3\xadtski could not see what was happening there,\nas a dense cloud of smoke arose from it. The hussars had succeeded in\nsetting it on fire and the French batteries were now firing at them, no\nlonger to hinder them but because the guns were trained and there was\nsomeone to fire at.\n\nThe French had time to fire three rounds of grapeshot before the hussars\ngot back to their horses. Two were misdirected and the shot went too\nhigh, but the last round fell in the midst of a group of hussars and\nknocked three of them over.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v, absorbed by his relations with Bogd\xc3\xa1nich, had paused on the\nbridge not knowing what to do. There was no one to hew down (as he\nhad always imagined battles to himself), nor could he help to fire the\nbridge because he had not brought any burning straw with him like the\nother soldiers. He stood looking about him, when suddenly he heard a\nrattle on the bridge as if nuts were being spilt, and the hussar nearest\nto him fell against the rails with a groan. Rost\xc3\xb3v ran up to him with\nthe others. Again someone shouted, \xe2\x80\x9cStretchers!\xe2\x80\x9d Four men seized the\nhussar and began lifting him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOooh! For Christ\xe2\x80\x99s sake let me alone!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the wounded man, but\nstill he was lifted and laid on the stretcher.\n\nNicholas Rost\xc3\xb3v turned away and, as if searching for something, gazed\ninto the distance, at the waters of the Danube, at the sky, and at the\nsun. How beautiful the sky looked; how blue, how calm, and how deep!\nHow bright and glorious was the setting sun! With what soft glitter the\nwaters of the distant Danube shone. And fairer still were the faraway\nblue mountains beyond the river, the nunnery, the mysterious gorges, and\nthe pine forests veiled in the mist of their summits... There was peace\nand happiness... \xe2\x80\x9cI should wish for nothing else, nothing, if only I\nwere there,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Rost\xc3\xb3v. \xe2\x80\x9cIn myself alone and in that sunshine\nthere is so much happiness; but here... groans, suffering, fear, and\nthis uncertainty and hurry... There\xe2\x80\x94they are shouting again, and\nagain are all running back somewhere, and I shall run with them, and it,\ndeath, is here above me and around... Another instant and I shall never\nagain see the sun, this water, that gorge!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAt that instant the sun began to hide behind the clouds, and other\nstretchers came into view before Rost\xc3\xb3v. And the fear of death and of\nthe stretchers, and love of the sun and of life, all merged into one\nfeeling of sickening agitation.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Lord God! Thou who art in that heaven, save, forgive, and protect\nme!\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v whispered.\n\nThe hussars ran back to the men who held their horses; their voices\nsounded louder and calmer, the stretchers disappeared from sight.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, fwiend? So you\xe2\x80\x99ve smelt powdah!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted V\xc3\xa1ska Den\xc3\xadsov\njust above his ear.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all over; but I am a coward\xe2\x80\x94yes, a coward!\xe2\x80\x9d thought\nRost\xc3\xb3v, and sighing deeply he took Rook, his horse, which stood resting\none foot, from the orderly and began to mount.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas that grapeshot?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes and no mistake!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Den\xc3\xadsov. \xe2\x80\x9cYou worked like wegular\nbwicks and it\xe2\x80\x99s nasty work! An attack\xe2\x80\x99s pleasant work! Hacking\naway at the dogs! But this sort of thing is the very devil, with them\nshooting at you like a target.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Den\xc3\xadsov rode up to a group that had stopped near Rost\xc3\xb3v, composed\nof the colonel, Nesv\xc3\xadtski, Zherk\xc3\xb3v, and the officer from the suite.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it seems that no one has noticed,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Rost\xc3\xb3v. And this\nwas true. No one had taken any notice, for everyone knew the sensation\nwhich the cadet under fire for the first time had experienced.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s something for you to report,\xe2\x80\x9d said Zherk\xc3\xb3v. \xe2\x80\x9cSee if I\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t get promoted to a sublieutenancy.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cInform the prince that I the bridge fired!\xe2\x80\x9d said the colonel\ntriumphantly and gaily.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if he asks about the losses?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA trifle,\xe2\x80\x9d said the colonel in his bass voice: \xe2\x80\x9ctwo hussars\nwounded, and one knocked out,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, unable to restrain a happy\nsmile, and pronouncing the phrase \xe2\x80\x9cknocked out\xe2\x80\x9d with ringing\ndistinctness.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IX\n\nPursued by the French army of a hundred thousand men under the command\nof Bonaparte, encountering a population that was unfriendly to it,\nlosing confidence in its allies, suffering from shortness of supplies,\nand compelled to act under conditions of war unlike anything that had\nbeen foreseen, the Russian army of thirty-five thousand men commanded\nby Kut\xc3\xbazov was hurriedly retreating along the Danube, stopping where\novertaken by the enemy and fighting rearguard actions only as far as\nnecessary to enable it to retreat without losing its heavy equipment.\nThere had been actions at Lambach, Amstetten, and Melk; but despite the\ncourage and endurance\xe2\x80\x94acknowledged even by the enemy\xe2\x80\x94with which the\nRussians fought, the only consequence of these actions was a yet more\nrapid retreat. Austrian troops that had escaped capture at Ulm and had\njoined Kut\xc3\xbazov at Braunau now separated from the Russian army, and\nKut\xc3\xbazov was left with only his own weak and exhausted forces. The\ndefense of Vienna was no longer to be thought of. Instead of an\noffensive, the plan of which, carefully prepared in accord with the\nmodern science of strategics, had been handed to Kut\xc3\xbazov when he was in\nVienna by the Austrian Hofkriegsrath, the sole and almost unattainable\naim remaining for him was to effect a junction with the forces that were\nadvancing from Russia, without losing his army as Mack had done at Ulm.\n\nOn the twenty-eighth of October Kut\xc3\xbazov with his army crossed to the\nleft bank of the Danube and took up a position for the first time\nwith the river between himself and the main body of the French. On the\nthirtieth he attacked Mortier\xe2\x80\x99s division, which was on the left bank,\nand broke it up. In this action for the first time trophies were taken:\nbanners, cannon, and two enemy generals. For the first time, after a\nfortnight\xe2\x80\x99s retreat, the Russian troops had halted and after a fight\nhad not only held the field but had repulsed the French. Though the\ntroops were ill-clad, exhausted, and had lost a third of their number\nin killed, wounded, sick, and stragglers; though a number of sick and\nwounded had been abandoned on the other side of the Danube with a letter\nin which Kut\xc3\xbazov entrusted them to the humanity of the enemy; and\nthough the big hospitals and the houses in Krems converted into military\nhospitals could no longer accommodate all the sick and wounded, yet the\nstand made at Krems and the victory over Mortier raised the spirits of\nthe army considerably. Throughout the whole army and at headquarters\nmost joyful though erroneous rumors were rife of the imaginary approach\nof columns from Russia, of some victory gained by the Austrians, and of\nthe retreat of the frightened Bonaparte.\n\nPrince Andrew during the battle had been in attendance on the Austrian\nGeneral Schmidt, who was killed in the action. His horse had been\nwounded under him and his own arm slightly grazed by a bullet. As a mark\nof the commander in chief\xe2\x80\x99s special favor he was sent with the news of\nthis victory to the Austrian court, now no longer at Vienna (which was\nthreatened by the French) but at Br\xc3\xbcnn. Despite his apparently delicate\nbuild Prince Andrew could endure physical fatigue far better than many\nvery muscular men, and on the night of the battle, having arrived\nat Krems excited but not weary, with dispatches from Dokht\xc3\xbarov to\nKut\xc3\xbazov, he was sent immediately with a special dispatch to Br\xc3\xbcnn.\nTo be so sent meant not only a reward but an important step toward\npromotion.\n\nThe night was dark but starry, the road showed black in the snow that\nhad fallen the previous day\xe2\x80\x94the day of the battle. Reviewing his\nimpressions of the recent battle, picturing pleasantly to himself the\nimpression his news of a victory would create, or recalling the send-off\ngiven him by the commander in chief and his fellow officers, Prince\nAndrew was galloping along in a post chaise enjoying the feelings of a\nman who has at length begun to attain a long-desired happiness. As soon\nas he closed his eyes his ears seemed filled with the rattle of the\nwheels and the sensation of victory. Then he began to imagine that\nthe Russians were running away and that he himself was killed, but he\nquickly roused himself with a feeling of joy, as if learning afresh that\nthis was not so but that on the contrary the French had run away. He\nagain recalled all the details of the victory and his own calm courage\nduring the battle, and feeling reassured he dozed off.... The dark\nstarry night was followed by a bright cheerful morning. The snow was\nthawing in the sunshine, the horses galloped quickly, and on both sides\nof the road were forests of different kinds, fields, and villages.\n\nAt one of the post stations he overtook a convoy of Russian wounded.\nThe Russian officer in charge of the transport lolled back in the front\ncart, shouting and scolding a soldier with coarse abuse. In each of\nthe long German carts six or more pale, dirty, bandaged men were being\njolted over the stony road. Some of them were talking (he heard Russian\nwords), others were eating bread; the more severely wounded looked\nsilently, with the languid interest of sick children, at the envoy\nhurrying past them.\n\nPrince Andrew told his driver to stop, and asked a soldier in what\naction they had been wounded. \xe2\x80\x9cDay before yesterday, on the Danube,\xe2\x80\x9d\nanswered the soldier. Prince Andrew took out his purse and gave the\nsoldier three gold pieces.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s for them all,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the officer who came up.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet well soon, lads!\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, turning to the soldiers.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s plenty to do still.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat news, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the officer, evidently anxious to start a\nconversation.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood news!... Go on!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted to the driver, and they galloped\non.\n\nIt was already quite dark when Prince Andrew rattled over the paved\nstreets of Br\xc3\xbcnn and found himself surrounded by high buildings, the\nlights of shops, houses, and street lamps, fine carriages, and all that\natmosphere of a large and active town which is always so attractive to a\nsoldier after camp life. Despite his rapid journey and sleepless night,\nPrince Andrew when he drove up to the palace felt even more vigorous and\nalert than he had done the day before. Only his eyes gleamed feverishly\nand his thoughts followed one another with extraordinary clearness and\nrapidity. He again vividly recalled the details of the battle, no longer\ndim, but definite and in the concise form in which he imagined himself\nstating them to the Emperor Francis. He vividly imagined the casual\nquestions that might be put to him and the answers he would give. He\nexpected to be at once presented to the Emperor. At the chief entrance\nto the palace, however, an official came running out to meet him, and\nlearning that he was a special messenger led him to another entrance.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the right from the corridor, Euer Hochgeboren! There you will find\nthe adjutant on duty,\xe2\x80\x9d said the official. \xe2\x80\x9cHe will conduct you to\nthe Minister of War.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe adjutant on duty, meeting Prince Andrew, asked him to wait, and went\nin to the Minister of War. Five minutes later he returned and bowing\nwith particular courtesy ushered Prince Andrew before him along a\ncorridor to the cabinet where the Minister of War was at work. The\nadjutant by his elaborate courtesy appeared to wish to ward off any\nattempt at familiarity on the part of the Russian messenger.\n\nPrince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s joyous feeling was considerably weakened as he\napproached the door of the minister\xe2\x80\x99s room. He felt offended, and\nwithout his noticing it the feeling of offense immediately turned into\none of disdain which was quite uncalled for. His fertile mind instantly\nsuggested to him a point of view which gave him a right to despise\nthe adjutant and the minister. \xe2\x80\x9cAway from the smell of powder, they\nprobably think it easy to gain victories!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. His eyes\nnarrowed disdainfully, he entered the room of the Minister of War with\npeculiarly deliberate steps. This feeling of disdain was heightened\nwhen he saw the minister seated at a large table reading some papers\nand making pencil notes on them, and for the first two or three minutes\ntaking no notice of his arrival. A wax candle stood at each side of the\nminister\xe2\x80\x99s bent bald head with its gray temples. He went on reading\nto the end, without raising his eyes at the opening of the door and the\nsound of footsteps.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake this and deliver it,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to his adjutant, handing him the\npapers and still taking no notice of the special messenger.\n\nPrince Andrew felt that either the actions of Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s army\ninterested the Minister of War less than any of the other matters he was\nconcerned with, or he wanted to give the Russian special messenger that\nimpression. \xe2\x80\x9cBut that is a matter of perfect indifference to me,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nthought. The minister drew the remaining papers together, arranged them\nevenly, and then raised his head. He had an intellectual and distinctive\nhead, but the instant he turned to Prince Andrew the firm, intelligent\nexpression on his face changed in a way evidently deliberate and\nhabitual to him. His face took on the stupid artificial smile (which\ndoes not even attempt to hide its artificiality) of a man who is\ncontinually receiving many petitioners one after another.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom General Field Marshal Kut\xc3\xbazov?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cI hope it is\ngood news? There has been an encounter with Mortier? A victory? It was\nhigh time!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe took the dispatch which was addressed to him and began to read it\nwith a mournful expression.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God! My God! Schmidt!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed in German. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a\ncalamity! What a calamity!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHaving glanced through the dispatch he laid it on the table and looked\nat Prince Andrew, evidently considering something.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh what a calamity! You say the affair was decisive? But Mortier is\nnot captured.\xe2\x80\x9d Again he pondered. \xe2\x80\x9cI am very glad you have brought\ngood news, though Schmidt\xe2\x80\x99s death is a heavy price to pay for the\nvictory. His Majesty will no doubt wish to see you, but not today. I\nthank you! You must have a rest. Be at the levee tomorrow after the\nparade. However, I will let you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe stupid smile, which had left his face while he was speaking,\nreappeared.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAu revoir! Thank you very much. His Majesty will probably desire to\nsee you,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, bowing his head.\n\nWhen Prince Andrew left the palace he felt that all the interest\nand happiness the victory had afforded him had been now left in the\nindifferent hands of the Minister of War and the polite adjutant. The\nwhole tenor of his thoughts instantaneously changed; the battle seemed\nthe memory of a remote event long past.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER X\n\nPrince Andrew stayed at Br\xc3\xbcnn with Bil\xc3\xadbin, a Russian acquaintance of\nhis in the diplomatic service.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear prince! I could not have a more welcome visitor,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid Bil\xc3\xadbin as he came out to meet Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cFranz, put the\nprince\xe2\x80\x99s things in my bedroom,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to the servant who was\nushering Bolk\xc3\xb3nski in. \xe2\x80\x9cSo you\xe2\x80\x99re a messenger of victory, eh?\nSplendid! And I am sitting here ill, as you see.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAfter washing and dressing, Prince Andrew came into the diplomat\xe2\x80\x99s\nluxurious study and sat down to the dinner prepared for him. Bil\xc3\xadbin\nsettled down comfortably beside the fire.\n\nAfter his journey and the campaign during which he had been deprived of\nall the comforts of cleanliness and all the refinements of life, Prince\nAndrew felt a pleasant sense of repose among luxurious surroundings such\nas he had been accustomed to from childhood. Besides it was pleasant,\nafter his reception by the Austrians, to speak if not in Russian\n(for they were speaking French) at least with a Russian who would, he\nsupposed, share the general Russian antipathy to the Austrians which was\nthen particularly strong.\n\nBil\xc3\xadbin was a man of thirty-five, a bachelor, and of the same circle as\nPrince Andrew. They had known each other previously in Petersburg, but\nhad become more intimate when Prince Andrew was in Vienna with Kut\xc3\xbazov.\nJust as Prince Andrew was a young man who gave promise of rising high\nin the military profession, so to an even greater extent Bil\xc3\xadbin gave\npromise of rising in his diplomatic career. He was still a young man but\nno longer a young diplomat, as he had entered the service at the age\nof sixteen, had been in Paris and Copenhagen, and now held a rather\nimportant post in Vienna. Both the foreign minister and our ambassador\nin Vienna knew him and valued him. He was not one of those many\ndiplomats who are esteemed because they have certain negative qualities,\navoid doing certain things, and speak French. He was one of those,\nwho, liking work, knew how to do it, and despite his indolence would\nsometimes spend a whole night at his writing table. He worked well\nwhatever the import of his work. It was not the question \xe2\x80\x9cWhat for?\xe2\x80\x9d\nbut the question \xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d that interested him. What the diplomatic\nmatter might be he did not care, but it gave him great pleasure to\nprepare a circular, memorandum, or report, skillfully, pointedly, and\nelegantly. Bil\xc3\xadbin\xe2\x80\x99s services were valued not only for what he wrote,\nbut also for his skill in dealing and conversing with those in the\nhighest spheres.\n\nBil\xc3\xadbin liked conversation as he liked work, only when it could be\nmade elegantly witty. In society he always awaited an opportunity to say\nsomething striking and took part in a conversation only when that was\npossible. His conversation was always sprinkled with wittily original,\nfinished phrases of general interest. These sayings were prepared in the\ninner laboratory of his mind in a portable form as if intentionally, so\nthat insignificant society people might carry them from drawing room to\ndrawing room. And, in fact, Bil\xc3\xadbin\xe2\x80\x99s witticisms were hawked about\nin the Viennese drawing rooms and often had an influence on matters\nconsidered important.\n\nHis thin, worn, sallow face was covered with deep wrinkles, which always\nlooked as clean and well washed as the tips of one\xe2\x80\x99s fingers after a\nRussian bath. The movement of these wrinkles formed the principal play\nof expression on his face. Now his forehead would pucker into deep folds\nand his eyebrows were lifted, then his eyebrows would descend and\ndeep wrinkles would crease his cheeks. His small, deep-set eyes always\ntwinkled and looked out straight.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now tell me about your exploits,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski, very modestly without once mentioning himself, described the\nengagement and his reception by the Minister of War.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey received me and my news as one receives a dog in a game of\nskittles,\xe2\x80\x9d said he in conclusion.\n\nBil\xc3\xadbin smiled and the wrinkles on his face disappeared.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCependant, mon cher,\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked, examining his nails from a\ndistance and puckering the skin above his left eye, \xe2\x80\x9cmalgr\xc3\xa9 la haute\nestime que je professe pour the Orthodox Russian army, j\xe2\x80\x99avoue que\nvotre victoire n\xe2\x80\x99est pas des plus victorieuses.\xe2\x80\x9d *\n\n     * \xe2\x80\x9cBut my dear fellow, with all my respect for the Orthodox\n     Russian army, I must say that your victory was not\n     particularly victorious.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nHe went on talking in this way in French, uttering only those words in\nRussian on which he wished to put a contemptuous emphasis.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome now! You with all your forces fall on the unfortunate Mortier\nand his one division, and even then Mortier slips through your fingers!\nWhere\xe2\x80\x99s the victory?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut seriously,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew, \xe2\x80\x9cwe can at any rate say\nwithout boasting that it was a little better than at Ulm...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t you capture one, just one, marshal for us?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause not everything happens as one expects or with the smoothness\nof a parade. We had expected, as I told you, to get at their rear by\nseven in the morning but had not reached it by five in the afternoon.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why didn\xe2\x80\x99t you do it at seven in the morning? You ought to have\nbeen there at seven in the morning,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Bil\xc3\xadbin with a smile.\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ought to have been there at seven in the morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you not succeed in impressing on Bonaparte by diplomatic\nmethods that he had better leave Genoa alone?\xe2\x80\x9d retorted Prince Andrew\nin the same tone.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Bil\xc3\xadbin, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re thinking it\xe2\x80\x99s very\neasy to take marshals, sitting on a sofa by the fire! That is true, but\nstill why didn\xe2\x80\x99t you capture him? So don\xe2\x80\x99t be surprised if not only\nthe Minister of War but also his Most August Majesty the Emperor and\nKing Francis is not much delighted by your victory. Even I, a poor\nsecretary of the Russian Embassy, do not feel any need in token of my\njoy to give my Franz a thaler, or let him go with his Liebchen to the\nPrater... True, we have no Prater here...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe looked straight at Prince Andrew and suddenly unwrinkled his\nforehead.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is now my turn to ask you \xe2\x80\x98why?\xe2\x80\x99 mon cher,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bolk\xc3\xb3nski.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI confess I do not understand: perhaps there are diplomatic\nsubtleties here beyond my feeble intelligence, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t make it\nout. Mack loses a whole army, the Archduke Ferdinand and the Archduke\nKarl give no signs of life and make blunder after blunder. Kut\xc3\xbazov\nalone at last gains a real victory, destroying the spell of the\ninvincibility of the French, and the Minister of War does not even care\nto hear the details.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s just it, my dear fellow. You see it\xe2\x80\x99s hurrah for the Tsar,\nfor Russia, for the Orthodox Greek faith! All that is beautiful, but\nwhat do we, I mean the Austrian court, care for your victories? Bring\nus nice news of a victory by the Archduke Karl or Ferdinand (one\narchduke\xe2\x80\x99s as good as another, as you know) and even if it is only\nover a fire brigade of Bonaparte\xe2\x80\x99s, that will be another story and\nwe\xe2\x80\x99ll fire off some cannon! But this sort of thing seems done\non purpose to vex us. The Archduke Karl does nothing, the Archduke\nFerdinand disgraces himself. You abandon Vienna, give up its\ndefense\xe2\x80\x94as much as to say: \xe2\x80\x98Heaven is with us, but heaven help you\nand your capital!\xe2\x80\x99 The one general whom we all loved, Schmidt, you\nexpose to a bullet, and then you congratulate us on the victory! Admit\nthat more irritating news than yours could not have been conceived.\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s as if it had been done on purpose, on purpose. Besides, suppose\nyou did gain a brilliant victory, if even the Archduke Karl gained a\nvictory, what effect would that have on the general course of events?\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s too late now when Vienna is occupied by the French army!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? Occupied? Vienna occupied?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot only occupied, but Bonaparte is at Sch\xc3\xb6nbrunn, and the count,\nour dear Count Vrbna, goes to him for orders.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAfter the fatigues and impressions of the journey, his reception, and\nespecially after having dined, Bolk\xc3\xb3nski felt that he could not take in\nthe full significance of the words he heard.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount Lichtenfels was here this morning,\xe2\x80\x9d Bil\xc3\xadbin continued,\n\xe2\x80\x9cand showed me a letter in which the parade of the French in Vienna\nwas fully described: Prince Murat et tout le tremblement... You see that\nyour victory is not a matter for great rejoicing and that you can\xe2\x80\x99t be\nreceived as a savior.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally I don\xe2\x80\x99t care about that, I don\xe2\x80\x99t care at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nPrince Andrew, beginning to understand that his news of the battle\nbefore Krems was really of small importance in view of such events as\nthe fall of Austria\xe2\x80\x99s capital. \xe2\x80\x9cHow is it Vienna was taken? What of\nthe bridge and its celebrated bridgehead and Prince Auersperg? We heard\nreports that Prince Auersperg was defending Vienna?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrince Auersperg is on this, on our side of the river, and is\ndefending us\xe2\x80\x94doing it very badly, I think, but still he is defending\nus. But Vienna is on the other side. No, the bridge has not yet been\ntaken and I hope it will not be, for it is mined and orders have been\ngiven to blow it up. Otherwise we should long ago have been in the\nmountains of Bohemia, and you and your army would have spent a bad\nquarter of an hour between two fires.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut still this does not mean that the campaign is over,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nPrince Andrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I think it is. The bigwigs here think so too, but they\ndaren\xe2\x80\x99t say so. It will be as I said at the beginning of the campaign,\nit won\xe2\x80\x99t be your skirmishing at D\xc3\xbcrrenstein, or gunpowder at all,\nthat will decide the matter, but those who devised it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bil\xc3\xadbin\nquoting one of his own mots, releasing the wrinkles on his forehead, and\npausing. \xe2\x80\x9cThe only question is what will come of the meeting between\nthe Emperor Alexander and the King of Prussia in Berlin? If Prussia\njoins the Allies, Austria\xe2\x80\x99s hand will be forced and there will be war.\nIf not it is merely a question of settling where the preliminaries of\nthe new Campo Formio are to be drawn up.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat an extraordinary genius!\xe2\x80\x9d Prince Andrew suddenly exclaimed,\nclenching his small hand and striking the table with it, \xe2\x80\x9cand what\nluck the man has!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBuonaparte?\xe2\x80\x9d said Bil\xc3\xadbin inquiringly, puckering up his forehead\nto indicate that he was about to say something witty. \xe2\x80\x9cBuonaparte?\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe repeated, accentuating the u: \xe2\x80\x9cI think, however, now that he lays\ndown laws for Austria at Sch\xc3\xb6nbrunn, il faut lui faire gr\xc3\xa2ce de\nl\xe2\x80\x99u! * I shall certainly adopt an innovation and call him simply\nBonaparte!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cWe must let him off the u!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut joking apart,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you really think the\ncampaign is over?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is what I think. Austria has been made a fool of, and she is\nnot used to it. She will retaliate. And she has been fooled in the\nfirst place because her provinces have been pillaged\xe2\x80\x94they say the Holy\nRussian army loots terribly\xe2\x80\x94her army is destroyed, her capital\ntaken, and all this for the beaux yeux * of His Sardinian Majesty. And\ntherefore\xe2\x80\x94this is between ourselves\xe2\x80\x94I instinctively feel that we\nare being deceived, my instinct tells me of negotiations with France and\nprojects for peace, a secret peace concluded separately.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n    * Fine eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cThat would be too base.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we live we shall see,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bil\xc3\xadbin, his face again becoming\nsmooth as a sign that the conversation was at an end.\n\nWhen Prince Andrew reached the room prepared for him and lay down in a\nclean shirt on the feather bed with its warmed and fragrant pillows, he\nfelt that the battle of which he had brought tidings was far, far\naway from him. The alliance with Prussia, Austria\xe2\x80\x99s treachery,\nBonaparte\xe2\x80\x99s new triumph, tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s levee and parade, and the\naudience with the Emperor Francis occupied his thoughts.\n\nHe closed his eyes, and immediately a sound of cannonading, of musketry\nand the rattling of carriage wheels seemed to fill his ears, and now\nagain drawn out in a thin line the musketeers were descending the hill,\nthe French were firing, and he felt his heart palpitating as he rode\nforward beside Schmidt with the bullets merrily whistling all around,\nand he experienced tenfold the joy of living, as he had not done since\nchildhood.\n\nHe woke up...\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that all happened!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, and, smiling happily to himself\nlike a child, he fell into a deep, youthful slumber.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XI\n\nNext day he woke late. Recalling his recent impressions, the first\nthought that came into his mind was that today he had to be presented\nto the Emperor Francis; he remembered the Minister of War, the polite\nAustrian adjutant, Bil\xc3\xadbin, and last night\xe2\x80\x99s conversation. Having\ndressed for his attendance at court in full parade uniform, which he\nhad not worn for a long time, he went into Bil\xc3\xadbin\xe2\x80\x99s study fresh,\nanimated, and handsome, with his hand bandaged. In the study were four\ngentlemen of the diplomatic corps. With Prince Hippolyte Kur\xc3\xa1gin,\nwho was a secretary to the embassy, Bolk\xc3\xb3nski was already acquainted.\nBil\xc3\xadbin introduced him to the others.\n\nThe gentlemen assembled at Bil\xc3\xadbin\xe2\x80\x99s were young, wealthy, gay society\nmen, who here, as in Vienna, formed a special set which Bil\xc3\xadbin, their\nleader, called les n\xc3\xb4tres. * This set, consisting almost exclusively of\ndiplomats, evidently had its own interests which had nothing to do with\nwar or politics but related to high society, to certain women, and to\nthe official side of the service. These gentlemen received Prince\nAndrew as one of themselves, an honor they did not extend to many. From\npoliteness and to start conversation, they asked him a few questions\nabout the army and the battle, and then the talk went off into merry\njests and gossip.\n\n    * Ours.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the best of it was,\xe2\x80\x9d said one, telling of the misfortune of\na fellow diplomat, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the Chancellor told him flatly that his\nappointment to London was a promotion and that he was so to regard it.\nCan you fancy the figure he cut?...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the worst of it, gentlemen\xe2\x80\x94I am giving Kur\xc3\xa1gin away to\nyou\xe2\x80\x94is that that man suffers, and this Don Juan, wicked fellow, is\ntaking advantage of it!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Hippolyte was lolling in a lounge chair with his legs over its\narm. He began to laugh.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me about that!\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you Don Juan! You serpent!\xe2\x80\x9d cried several voices.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, Bolk\xc3\xb3nski, don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bil\xc3\xadbin turning to Prince\nAndrew, \xe2\x80\x9cthat all the atrocities of the French army (I nearly said of\nthe Russian army) are nothing compared to what this man has been doing\namong the women!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLa femme est la compagne de l\xe2\x80\x99homme,\xe2\x80\x9d * announced Prince\nHippolyte, and began looking through a lorgnette at his elevated legs.\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cWoman is man\xe2\x80\x99s companion.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nBil\xc3\xadbin and the rest of \xe2\x80\x9cours\xe2\x80\x9d burst out laughing in Hippolyte\xe2\x80\x99s\nface, and Prince Andrew saw that Hippolyte, of whom\xe2\x80\x94he had to\nadmit\xe2\x80\x94he had almost been jealous on his wife\xe2\x80\x99s account, was the butt\nof this set.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I must give you a treat,\xe2\x80\x9d Bil\xc3\xadbin whispered to Bolk\xc3\xb3nski.\n\xe2\x80\x9cKur\xc3\xa1gin is exquisite when he discusses politics\xe2\x80\x94you should see his\ngravity!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe sat down beside Hippolyte and wrinkling his forehead began talking\nto him about politics. Prince Andrew and the others gathered round these\ntwo.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Berlin cabinet cannot express a feeling of alliance,\xe2\x80\x9d began\nHippolyte gazing round with importance at the others, \xe2\x80\x9cwithout\nexpressing... as in its last note... you understand... Besides, unless\nHis Majesty the Emperor derogates from the principle of our alliance...\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait, I have not finished...\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Prince Andrew, seizing\nhim by the arm, \xe2\x80\x9cI believe that intervention will be stronger than\nnonintervention. And...\xe2\x80\x9d he paused. \xe2\x80\x9cFinally one cannot impute the\nnonreceipt of our dispatch of November 18. That is how it will end.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAnd he released Bolk\xc3\xb3nski\xe2\x80\x99s arm to indicate that he had now quite\nfinished.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDemosthenes, I know thee by the pebble thou secretest in thy golden\nmouth!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bil\xc3\xadbin, and the mop of hair on his head moved with\nsatisfaction.\n\nEverybody laughed, and Hippolyte louder than anyone. He was evidently\ndistressed, and breathed painfully, but could not restrain the wild\nlaughter that convulsed his usually impassive features.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell now, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bil\xc3\xadbin, \xe2\x80\x9cBolk\xc3\xb3nski is my guest in\nthis house and in Br\xc3\xbcnn itself. I want to entertain him as far as I\ncan, with all the pleasures of life here. If we were in Vienna it would\nbe easy, but here, in this wretched Moravian hole, it is more difficult,\nand I beg you all to help me. Br\xc3\xbcnn\xe2\x80\x99s attractions must be shown him.\nYou can undertake the theater, I society, and you, Hippolyte, of course\nthe women.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must let him see Amelie, she\xe2\x80\x99s exquisite!\xe2\x80\x9d said one of\n\xe2\x80\x9cours,\xe2\x80\x9d kissing his finger tips.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn general we must turn this bloodthirsty soldier to more humane\ninterests,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bil\xc3\xadbin.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall scarcely be able to avail myself of your hospitality,\ngentlemen, it is already time for me to go,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Prince Andrew\nlooking at his watch.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere to?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the Emperor.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! Oh! Oh!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, au revoir, Bolk\xc3\xb3nski! Au revoir, Prince! Come back early to\ndinner,\xe2\x80\x9d cried several voices. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll take you in hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen speaking to the Emperor, try as far as you can to praise the way\nthat provisions are supplied and the routes indicated,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bil\xc3\xadbin,\naccompanying him to the hall.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like to speak well of them, but as far as I know the facts,\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bolk\xc3\xb3nski, smiling.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, talk as much as you can, anyway. He has a passion for giving\naudiences, but he does not like talking himself and can\xe2\x80\x99t do it, as\nyou will see.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XII\n\nAt the levee Prince Andrew stood among the Austrian officers as he had\nbeen told to, and the Emperor Francis merely looked fixedly into his\nface and just nodded to him with his long head. But after it was\nover, the adjutant he had seen the previous day ceremoniously informed\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski that the Emperor desired to give him an audience. The Emperor\nFrancis received him standing in the middle of the room. Before the\nconversation began Prince Andrew was struck by the fact that the Emperor\nseemed confused and blushed as if not knowing what to say.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me, when did the battle begin?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked hurriedly.\n\nPrince Andrew replied. Then followed other questions just as simple:\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas Kut\xc3\xbazov well? When had he left Krems?\xe2\x80\x9d and so on. The Emperor\nspoke as if his sole aim were to put a given number of questions\xe2\x80\x94the\nanswers to these questions, as was only too evident, did not interest\nhim.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt what o\xe2\x80\x99clock did the battle begin?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Emperor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot inform Your Majesty at what o\xe2\x80\x99clock the battle began at\nthe front, but at D\xc3\xbcrrenstein, where I was, our attack began after\nfive in the afternoon,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bolk\xc3\xb3nski growing more animated and\nexpecting that he would have a chance to give a reliable account, which\nhe had ready in his mind, of all he knew and had seen. But the Emperor\nsmiled and interrupted him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow many miles?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom where to where, Your Majesty?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom D\xc3\xbcrrenstein to Krems.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree and a half miles, Your Majesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe French have abandoned the left bank?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAccording to the scouts the last of them crossed on rafts during the\nnight.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there sufficient forage in Krems?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cForage has not been supplied to the extent...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe Emperor interrupted him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt what o\xe2\x80\x99clock was General Schmidt killed?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, I believe.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock? It\xe2\x80\x99s very sad, very sad!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe Emperor thanked Prince Andrew and bowed. Prince Andrew withdrew and\nwas immediately surrounded by courtiers on all sides. Everywhere he\nsaw friendly looks and heard friendly words. Yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s adjutant\nreproached him for not having stayed at the palace, and offered him\nhis own house. The Minister of War came up and congratulated him on the\nMaria Theresa Order of the third grade, which the Emperor was conferring\non him. The Empress\xe2\x80\x99 chamberlain invited him to see Her Majesty. The\narchduchess also wished to see him. He did not know whom to answer, and\nfor a few seconds collected his thoughts. Then the Russian ambassador\ntook him by the shoulder, led him to the window, and began to talk to\nhim.\n\nContrary to Bil\xc3\xadbin\xe2\x80\x99s forecast the news he had brought was joyfully\nreceived. A thanksgiving service was arranged, Kut\xc3\xbazov was awarded\nthe Grand Cross of Maria Theresa, and the whole army received rewards.\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski was invited everywhere, and had to spend the whole morning\ncalling on the principal Austrian dignitaries. Between four and five\nin the afternoon, having made all his calls, he was returning to\nBil\xc3\xadbin\xe2\x80\x99s house thinking out a letter to his father about the battle\nand his visit to Br\xc3\xbcnn. At the door he found a vehicle half full of\nluggage. Franz, Bil\xc3\xadbin\xe2\x80\x99s man, was dragging a portmanteau with some\ndifficulty out of the front door.\n\nBefore returning to Bil\xc3\xadbin\xe2\x80\x99s Prince Andrew had gone to a bookshop\nto provide himself with some books for the campaign, and had spent some\ntime in the shop.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, your excellency!\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz, with difficulty rolling the\nportmanteau into the vehicle, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are to move on still farther. The\nscoundrel is again at our heels!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh? What?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Prince Andrew.\n\nBil\xc3\xadbin came out to meet him. His usually calm face showed excitement.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere now! Confess that this is delightful,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cThis\naffair of the Thabor Bridge, at Vienna.... They have crossed without\nstriking a blow!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew could not understand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where do you come from not to know what every coachman in the\ntown knows?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI come from the archduchess\xe2\x80\x99. I heard nothing there.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you didn\xe2\x80\x99t see that everybody is packing up?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not... What is it all about?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Prince Andrew\nimpatiently.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s it all about? Why, the French have crossed the bridge that\nAuersperg was defending, and the bridge was not blown up: so Murat\nis now rushing along the road to Br\xc3\xbcnn and will be here in a day or\ntwo.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? Here? But why did they not blow up the bridge, if it was\nmined?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is what I ask you. No one, not even Bonaparte, knows why.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski shrugged his shoulders.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if the bridge is crossed it means that the army too is lost? It\nwill be cut off,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s just it,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Bil\xc3\xadbin. \xe2\x80\x9cListen! The French entered\nVienna as I told you. Very well. Next day, which was yesterday, those\ngentlemen, messieurs les mar\xc3\xa9chaux, * Murat, Lannes, and Belliard,\nmount and ride to the bridge. (Observe that all three are Gascons.)\n\xe2\x80\x98Gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99 says one of them, \xe2\x80\x98you know the Thabor Bridge is\nmined and doubly mined and that there are menacing fortifications at its\nhead and an army of fifteen thousand men has been ordered to blow up\nthe bridge and not let us cross? But it will please our sovereign the\nEmperor Napoleon if we take this bridge, so let us three go and take\nit!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Yes, let\xe2\x80\x99s!\xe2\x80\x99 say the others. And off they go and take the\nbridge, cross it, and now with their whole army are on this side of the\nDanube, marching on us, you, and your lines of communication.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n    * The marshalls.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop jesting,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew sadly and seriously. This news\ngrieved him and yet he was pleased.\n\nAs soon as he learned that the Russian army was in such a hopeless\nsituation it occurred to him that it was he who was destined to lead it\nout of this position; that here was the Toulon that would lift him from\nthe ranks of obscure officers and offer him the first step to fame!\nListening to Bil\xc3\xadbin he was already imagining how on reaching the army\nhe would give an opinion at the war council which would be the only one\nthat could save the army, and how he alone would be entrusted with the\nexecuting of the plan.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop this jesting,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not jesting,\xe2\x80\x9d Bil\xc3\xadbin went on. \xe2\x80\x9cNothing is truer or sadder.\nThese gentlemen ride onto the bridge alone and wave white handkerchiefs;\nthey assure the officer on duty that they, the marshals, are on\ntheir way to negotiate with Prince Auersperg. He lets them enter the\nt\xc3\xaate-de-pont. * They spin him a thousand gasconades, saying that\nthe war is over, that the Emperor Francis is arranging a meeting with\nBonaparte, that they desire to see Prince Auersperg, and so on. The\nofficer sends for Auersperg; these gentlemen embrace the officers, crack\njokes, sit on the cannon, and meanwhile a French battalion gets to\nthe bridge unobserved, flings the bags of incendiary material into\nthe water, and approaches the t\xc3\xaate-de-pont. At length appears the\nlieutenant general, our dear Prince Auersperg von Mautern himself.\n\xe2\x80\x98Dearest foe! Flower of the Austrian army, hero of the Turkish wars!\nHostilities are ended, we can shake one another\xe2\x80\x99s hand.... The\nEmperor Napoleon burns with impatience to make Prince Auersperg\xe2\x80\x99s\nacquaintance.\xe2\x80\x99 In a word, those gentlemen, Gascons indeed, so\nbewildered him with fine words, and he is so flattered by his rapidly\nestablished intimacy with the French marshals, and so dazzled by the\nsight of Murat\xe2\x80\x99s mantle and ostrich plumes, qu\xe2\x80\x99il n\xe2\x80\x99y voit que du\nfeu, et oublie celui qu\xe2\x80\x99il devait faire faire sur l\xe2\x80\x99ennemi!\xe2\x80\x9d *(2)\nIn spite of the animation of his speech, Bil\xc3\xadbin did not forget to\npause after this mot to give time for its due appreciation. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\nFrench battalion rushes to the bridgehead, spikes the guns, and the\nbridge is taken! But what is best of all,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, his excitement\nsubsiding under the delightful interest of his own story, \xe2\x80\x9cis that the\nsergeant in charge of the cannon which was to give the signal to fire\nthe mines and blow up the bridge, this sergeant, seeing that the French\ntroops were running onto the bridge, was about to fire, but Lannes\nstayed his hand. The sergeant, who was evidently wiser than his general,\ngoes up to Auersperg and says: \xe2\x80\x98Prince, you are being deceived, here\nare the French!\xe2\x80\x99 Murat, seeing that all is lost if the sergeant is\nallowed to speak, turns to Auersperg with feigned astonishment (he is a\ntrue Gascon) and says: \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t recognize the world-famous Austrian\ndiscipline, if you allow a subordinate to address you like that!\xe2\x80\x99 It\nwas a stroke of genius. Prince Auersperg feels his dignity at stake and\norders the sergeant to be arrested. Come, you must own that this affair\nof the Thabor Bridge is delightful! It is not exactly stupidity, nor\nrascality....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n     * Bridgehead.\n\n     * (2) That their fire gets into his eyes and he forgets that\n     he ought to be firing at the enemy.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt may be treachery,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew, vividly imagining the\ngray overcoats, wounds, the smoke of gunpowder, the sounds of firing,\nand the glory that awaited him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot that either. That puts the court in too bad a light,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\nBil\xc3\xadbin. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not treachery nor rascality nor stupidity: it is\njust as at Ulm... it is...\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he seemed to be trying to find the right\nexpression. \xe2\x80\x9cC\xe2\x80\x99est... c\xe2\x80\x99est du Mack. Nous sommes mack\xc3\xa9s (It is...\nit is a bit of Mack. We are Macked),\xe2\x80\x9d he concluded, feeling that he\nhad produced a good epigram, a fresh one that would be repeated. His\nhitherto puckered brow became smooth as a sign of pleasure, and with a\nslight smile he began to examine his nails.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you off to?\xe2\x80\x9d he said suddenly to Prince Andrew who had\nrisen and was going toward his room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going away.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere to?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the army.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you meant to stay another two days?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut now I am off at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Prince Andrew after giving directions about his departure went to\nhis room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, mon cher,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bil\xc3\xadbin following him, \xe2\x80\x9cI have been\nthinking about you. Why are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd in proof of the conclusiveness of his opinion all the wrinkles\nvanished from his face.\n\nPrince Andrew looked inquiringly at him and gave no reply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you going? I know you think it your duty to gallop back to\nthe army now that it is in danger. I understand that. Mon cher, it is\nheroism!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut as you are a philosopher, be a consistent one, look at the other\nside of the question and you will see that your duty, on the contrary,\nis to take care of yourself. Leave it to those who are no longer fit for\nanything else.... You have not been ordered to return and have not been\ndismissed from here; therefore, you can stay and go with us wherever our\nill luck takes us. They say we are going to Olm\xc3\xbctz, and Olm\xc3\xbctz is a\nvery decent town. You and I will travel comfortably in my cal\xc3\xa8che.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo stop joking, Bil\xc3\xadbin,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bolk\xc3\xb3nski.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am speaking sincerely as a friend! Consider! Where and why are\nyou going, when you might remain here? You are faced by one of two\nthings,\xe2\x80\x9d and the skin over his left temple puckered, \xe2\x80\x9ceither you\nwill not reach your regiment before peace is concluded, or you will\nshare defeat and disgrace with Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s whole army.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Bil\xc3\xadbin unwrinkled his temple, feeling that the dilemma was\ninsoluble.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot argue about it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Prince Andrew coldly, but he\nthought: \xe2\x80\x9cI am going to save the army.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear fellow, you are a hero!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bil\xc3\xadbin.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIII\n\nThat same night, having taken leave of the Minister of War, Bolk\xc3\xb3nski\nset off to rejoin the army, not knowing where he would find it and\nfearing to be captured by the French on the way to Krems.\n\nIn Br\xc3\xbcnn everybody attached to the court was packing up, and the heavy\nbaggage was already being dispatched to Olm\xc3\xbctz. Near Hetzelsdorf Prince\nAndrew struck the high road along which the Russian army was moving with\ngreat haste and in the greatest disorder. The road was so obstructed\nwith carts that it was impossible to get by in a carriage.
