The\nregimental commander and Major Ekon\xc3\xb3mov had stopped beside a bridge,\nletting the retreating companies pass by them, when a soldier came up\nand took hold of the commander\xe2\x80\x99s stirrup, almost leaning against him.\nThe man was wearing a bluish coat of broadcloth, he had no knapsack\nor cap, his head was bandaged, and over his shoulder a French munition\npouch was slung. He had an officer\xe2\x80\x99s sword in his hand. The soldier\nwas pale, his blue eyes looked impudently into the commander\xe2\x80\x99s face,\nand his lips were smiling. Though the commander was occupied in giving\ninstructions to Major Ekon\xc3\xb3mov, he could not help taking notice of the\nsoldier.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency, here are two trophies,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov, pointing\nto the French sword and pouch. \xe2\x80\x9cI have taken an officer prisoner. I\nstopped the company.\xe2\x80\x9d D\xc3\xb3lokhov breathed heavily from weariness and\nspoke in abrupt sentences. \xe2\x80\x9cThe whole company can bear witness. I beg\nyou will remember this, your excellency!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, all right,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the commander, and turned to Major\nEkon\xc3\xb3mov.\n\nBut D\xc3\xb3lokhov did not go away; he untied the handkerchief around his\nhead, pulled it off, and showed the blood congealed on his hair.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA bayonet wound. I remained at the front. Remember, your\nexcellency!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nT\xc3\xbashin\xe2\x80\x99s battery had been forgotten and only at the very end of the\naction did Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n, still hearing the cannonade in the center,\nsend his orderly staff officer, and later Prince Andrew also, to order\nthe battery to retire as quickly as possible. When the supports attached\nto T\xc3\xbashin\xe2\x80\x99s battery had been moved away in the middle of the action\nby someone\xe2\x80\x99s order, the battery had continued firing and was only not\ncaptured by the French because the enemy could not surmise that anyone\ncould have the effrontery to continue firing from four quite undefended\nguns. On the contrary, the energetic action of that battery led the\nFrench to suppose that here\xe2\x80\x94in the center\xe2\x80\x94the main Russian forces\nwere concentrated. Twice they had attempted to attack this point, but on\neach occasion had been driven back by grapeshot from the four isolated\nguns on the hillock.\n\nSoon after Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n had left him, T\xc3\xbashin had succeeded in\nsetting fire to Sch\xc3\xb6n Grabern.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook at them scurrying! It\xe2\x80\x99s burning! Just see the smoke! Fine!\nGrand! Look at the smoke, the smoke!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the artillerymen,\nbrightening up.\n\nAll the guns, without waiting for orders, were being fired in the\ndirection of the conflagration. As if urging each other on, the soldiers\ncried at each shot: \xe2\x80\x9cFine! That\xe2\x80\x99s good! Look at it... Grand!\xe2\x80\x9d The\nfire, fanned by the breeze, was rapidly spreading. The French columns\nthat had advanced beyond the village went back; but as though in revenge\nfor this failure, the enemy placed ten guns to the right of the village\nand began firing them at T\xc3\xbashin\xe2\x80\x99s battery.\n\nIn their childlike glee, aroused by the fire and their luck in\nsuccessfully cannonading the French, our artillerymen only noticed this\nbattery when two balls, and then four more, fell among our guns, one\nknocking over two horses and another tearing off a munition-wagon\ndriver\xe2\x80\x99s leg. Their spirits once roused were, however, not diminished,\nbut only changed character. The horses were replaced by others from a\nreserve gun carriage, the wounded were carried away, and the four guns\nwere turned against the ten-gun battery. T\xc3\xbashin\xe2\x80\x99s companion officer\nhad been killed at the beginning of the engagement and within an hour\nseventeen of the forty men of the guns\xe2\x80\x99 crews had been disabled, but\nthe artillerymen were still as merry and lively as ever. Twice they\nnoticed the French appearing below them, and then they fired grapeshot\nat them.\n\nLittle T\xc3\xbashin, moving feebly and awkwardly, kept telling his orderly to\n\xe2\x80\x9crefill my pipe for that one!\xe2\x80\x9d and then, scattering sparks from it,\nran forward shading his eyes with his small hand to look at the French.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSmack at \xe2\x80\x98em, lads!\xe2\x80\x9d he kept saying, seizing the guns by the\nwheels and working the screws himself.\n\nAmid the smoke, deafened by the incessant reports which always made him\njump, T\xc3\xbashin not taking his pipe from his mouth ran from gun to gun,\nnow aiming, now counting the charges, now giving orders about replacing\ndead or wounded horses and harnessing fresh ones, and shouting in his\nfeeble voice, so high pitched and irresolute. His face grew more and\nmore animated. Only when a man was killed or wounded did he frown and\nturn away from the sight, shouting angrily at the men who, as is always\nthe case, hesitated about lifting the injured or dead. The soldiers,\nfor the most part handsome fellows and, as is always the case in an\nartillery company, a head and shoulders taller and twice as broad\nas their officer\xe2\x80\x94all looked at their commander like children in an\nembarrassing situation, and the expression on his face was invariably\nreflected on theirs.\n\nOwing to the terrible uproar and the necessity for concentration and\nactivity, T\xc3\xbashin did not experience the slightest unpleasant sense of\nfear, and the thought that he might be killed or badly wounded never\noccurred to him. On the contrary, he became more and more elated. It\nseemed to him that it was a very long time ago, almost a day, since he\nhad first seen the enemy and fired the first shot, and that the corner\nof the field he stood on was well-known and familiar ground. Though he\nthought of everything, considered everything, and did everything the\nbest of officers could do in his position, he was in a state akin to\nfeverish delirium or drunkenness.\n\nFrom the deafening sounds of his own guns around him, the whistle and\nthud of the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s cannon balls, from the flushed and perspiring\nfaces of the crew bustling round the guns, from the sight of the blood\nof men and horses, from the little puffs of smoke on the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s side\n(always followed by a ball flying past and striking the earth, a man, a\ngun, a horse), from the sight of all these things a fantastic world of\nhis own had taken possession of his brain and at that moment afforded\nhim pleasure. The enemy\xe2\x80\x99s guns were in his fancy not guns but pipes\nfrom which occasional puffs were blown by an invisible smoker.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere... he\xe2\x80\x99s puffing again,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered T\xc3\xbashin to himself, as a\nsmall cloud rose from the hill and was borne in a streak to the left by\nthe wind.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow look out for the ball... we\xe2\x80\x99ll throw it back.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want, your honor?\xe2\x80\x9d asked an artilleryman, standing\nclose by, who heard him muttering.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing... only a shell...\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome along, our Matv\xc3\xa9vna!\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cMatv\xc3\xa9vna\xe2\x80\x9d *\nwas the name his fancy gave to the farthest gun of the battery, which\nwas large and of an old pattern. The French swarming round their guns\nseemed to him like ants. In that world, the handsome drunkard Number One\nof the second gun\xe2\x80\x99s crew was \xe2\x80\x9cuncle\xe2\x80\x9d; T\xc3\xbashin looked at him more\noften than at anyone else and took delight in his every movement.\nThe sound of musketry at the foot of the hill, now diminishing, now\nincreasing, seemed like someone\xe2\x80\x99s breathing. He listened intently to\nthe ebb and flow of these sounds.\n\n    * Daughter of Matthew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! Breathing again, breathing!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered to himself.\n\nHe imagined himself as an enormously tall, powerful man who was throwing\ncannon balls at the French with both hands.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow then, Matv\xc3\xa9vna, dear old lady, don\xe2\x80\x99t let me down!\xe2\x80\x9d he was\nsaying as he moved from the gun, when a strange, unfamiliar voice called\nabove his head: \xe2\x80\x9cCaptain T\xc3\xbashin! Captain!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nT\xc3\xbashin turned round in dismay. It was the staff officer who had turned\nhim out of the booth at Grunth. He was shouting in a gasping voice:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you mad? You have twice been ordered to retreat, and you...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are they down on me?\xe2\x80\x9d thought T\xc3\xbashin, looking in alarm at his\nsuperior.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI... don\xe2\x80\x99t...\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered, holding up two fingers to his cap.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBut the staff officer did not finish what he wanted to say. A cannon\nball, flying close to him, caused him to duck and bend over his horse.\nHe paused, and just as he was about to say something more, another ball\nstopped him. He turned his horse and galloped off.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cRetire! All to retire!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted from a distance.\n\nThe soldiers laughed. A moment later, an adjutant arrived with the same\norder.\n\nIt was Prince Andrew. The first thing he saw on riding up to the space\nwhere T\xc3\xbashin\xe2\x80\x99s guns were stationed was an unharnessed horse with a\nbroken leg, that lay screaming piteously beside the harnessed horses.\nBlood was gushing from its leg as from a spring. Among the limbers lay\nseveral dead men. One ball after another passed over as he approached\nand he felt a nervous shudder run down his spine. But the mere thought\nof being afraid roused him again. \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot be afraid,\xe2\x80\x9d thought he,\nand dismounted slowly among the guns. He delivered the order and did\nnot leave the battery. He decided to have the guns removed from their\npositions and withdrawn in his presence. Together with T\xc3\xbashin, stepping\nacross the bodies and under a terrible fire from the French, he attended\nto the removal of the guns.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA staff officer was here a minute ago, but skipped off,\xe2\x80\x9d said an\nartilleryman to Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cNot like your honor!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew said nothing to T\xc3\xbashin. They were both so busy as to seem\nnot to notice one another. When having limbered up the only two cannon\nthat remained uninjured out of the four, they began moving down the hill\n(one shattered gun and one unicorn were left behind), Prince Andrew rode\nup to T\xc3\xbashin.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, till we meet again...\xe2\x80\x9d he said, holding out his hand to\nT\xc3\xbashin.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-by, my dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said T\xc3\xbashin. \xe2\x80\x9cDear soul! Good-by, my\ndear fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d and for some unknown reason tears suddenly filled his\neyes.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XXI\n\nThe wind had fallen and black clouds, merging with the powder smoke,\nhung low over the field of battle on the horizon. It was growing\ndark and the glow of two conflagrations was the more conspicuous. The\ncannonade was dying down, but the rattle of musketry behind and on the\nright sounded oftener and nearer. As soon as T\xc3\xbashin with his guns,\ncontinually driving round or coming upon wounded men, was out of range\nof fire and had descended into the dip, he was met by some of the staff,\namong them the staff officer and Zherk\xc3\xb3v, who had been twice sent to\nT\xc3\xbashin\xe2\x80\x99s battery but had never reached it. Interrupting one\nanother, they all gave, and transmitted, orders as to how to proceed,\nreprimanding and reproaching him. T\xc3\xbashin gave no orders, and,\nsilently\xe2\x80\x94fearing to speak because at every word he felt ready to\nweep without knowing why\xe2\x80\x94rode behind on his artillery nag. Though\nthe orders were to abandon the wounded, many of them dragged themselves\nafter troops and begged for seats on the gun carriages. The jaunty\ninfantry officer who just before the battle had rushed out of\nT\xc3\xbashin\xe2\x80\x99s wattle shed was laid, with a bullet in his stomach, on\n\xe2\x80\x9cMatv\xc3\xa9vna\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d carriage. At the foot of the hill, a pale hussar\ncadet, supporting one hand with the other, came up to T\xc3\xbashin and asked\nfor a seat.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain, for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake! I\xe2\x80\x99ve hurt my arm,\xe2\x80\x9d he said timidly.\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor God\xe2\x80\x99s sake... I can\xe2\x80\x99t walk. For God\xe2\x80\x99s sake!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIt was plain that this cadet had already repeatedly asked for a lift and\nbeen refused. He asked in a hesitating, piteous voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell them to give me a seat, for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive him a seat,\xe2\x80\x9d said T\xc3\xbashin. \xe2\x80\x9cLay a cloak for him to sit on,\nlad,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, addressing his favorite soldier. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd where is the\nwounded officer?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has been set down. He died,\xe2\x80\x9d replied someone.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp him up. Sit down, dear fellow, sit down! Spread out the cloak,\nAnt\xc3\xb3nov.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe cadet was Rost\xc3\xb3v. With one hand he supported the other; he was\npale and his jaw trembled, shivering feverishly. He was placed on\n\xe2\x80\x9cMatv\xc3\xa9vna,\xe2\x80\x9d the gun from which they had removed the dead officer.\nThe cloak they spread under him was wet with blood which stained his\nbreeches and arm.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, are you wounded, my lad?\xe2\x80\x9d said T\xc3\xbashin, approaching the gun\non which Rost\xc3\xb3v sat.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it\xe2\x80\x99s a sprain.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen what is this blood on the gun carriage?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired T\xc3\xbashin.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was the officer, your honor, stained it,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the\nartilleryman, wiping away the blood with his coat sleeve, as if\napologizing for the state of his gun.\n\nIt was all that they could do to get the guns up the rise aided by the\ninfantry, and having reached the village of Gruntersdorf they halted. It\nhad grown so dark that one could not distinguish the uniforms ten paces\noff, and the firing had begun to subside. Suddenly, near by on the\nright, shouting and firing were again heard. Flashes of shot gleamed in\nthe darkness. This was the last French attack and was met by soldiers\nwho had sheltered in the village houses. They all rushed out of\nthe village again, but T\xc3\xbashin\xe2\x80\x99s guns could not move, and the\nartillerymen, T\xc3\xbashin, and the cadet exchanged silent glances as they\nawaited their fate. The firing died down and soldiers, talking eagerly,\nstreamed out of a side street.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot hurt, Petr\xc3\xb3v?\xe2\x80\x9d asked one.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve given it \xe2\x80\x98em hot, mate! They won\xe2\x80\x99t make another push\nnow,\xe2\x80\x9d said another.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou couldn\xe2\x80\x99t see a thing. How they shot at their own fellows!\nNothing could be seen. Pitch-dark, brother! Isn\xe2\x80\x99t there something to\ndrink?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe French had been repulsed for the last time. And again and again in\nthe complete darkness T\xc3\xbashin\xe2\x80\x99s guns moved forward, surrounded by the\nhumming infantry as by a frame.\n\nIn the darkness, it seemed as though a gloomy unseen river was flowing\nalways in one direction, humming with whispers and talk and the sound of\nhoofs and wheels. Amid the general rumble, the groans and voices of the\nwounded were more distinctly heard than any other sound in the darkness\nof the night. The gloom that enveloped the army was filled with their\ngroans, which seemed to melt into one with the darkness of the night.\nAfter a while the moving mass became agitated, someone rode past on\na white horse followed by his suite, and said something in passing:\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did he say? Where to, now? Halt, is it? Did he thank us?\xe2\x80\x9d came\neager questions from all sides. The whole moving mass began pressing\ncloser together and a report spread that they were ordered to halt:\nevidently those in front had halted. All remained where they were in the\nmiddle of the muddy road.\n\nFires were lighted and the talk became more audible. Captain T\xc3\xbashin,\nhaving given orders to his company, sent a soldier to find a dressing\nstation or a doctor for the cadet, and sat down by a bonfire the\nsoldiers had kindled on the road. Rost\xc3\xb3v, too, dragged himself to the\nfire. From pain, cold, and damp, a feverish shivering shook his whole\nbody. Drowsiness was irresistibly mastering him, but he kept awake by\nan excruciating pain in his arm, for which he could find no satisfactory\nposition. He kept closing his eyes and then again looking at the fire,\nwhich seemed to him dazzlingly red, and at the feeble, round-shouldered\nfigure of T\xc3\xbashin who was sitting cross-legged like a Turk beside him.\nT\xc3\xbashin\xe2\x80\x99s large, kind, intelligent eyes were fixed with sympathy and\ncommiseration on Rost\xc3\xb3v, who saw that T\xc3\xbashin with his whole heart\nwished to help him but could not.\n\nFrom all sides were heard the footsteps and talk of the infantry, who\nwere walking, driving past, and settling down all around. The sound\nof voices, the tramping feet, the horses\xe2\x80\x99 hoofs moving in mud, the\ncrackling of wood fires near and afar, merged into one tremulous rumble.\n\nIt was no longer, as before, a dark, unseen river flowing through the\ngloom, but a dark sea swelling and gradually subsiding after a storm.\nRost\xc3\xb3v looked at and listened listlessly to what passed before and\naround him. An infantryman came to the fire, squatted on his heels, held\nhis hands to the blaze, and turned away his face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t mind your honor?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked T\xc3\xbashin. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve lost my\ncompany, your honor. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know where... such bad luck!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nWith the soldier, an infantry officer with a bandaged cheek came up to\nthe bonfire, and addressing T\xc3\xbashin asked him to have the guns moved a\ntrifle to let a wagon go past. After he had gone, two soldiers rushed to\nthe campfire. They were quarreling and fighting desperately, each trying\nto snatch from the other a boot they were both holding on to.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou picked it up?... I dare say! You\xe2\x80\x99re very smart!\xe2\x80\x9d one of them\nshouted hoarsely.\n\nThen a thin, pale soldier, his neck bandaged with a bloodstained leg\nband, came up and in angry tones asked the artillerymen for water.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMust one die like a dog?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\nT\xc3\xbashin told them to give the man some water. Then a cheerful soldier\nran up, begging a little fire for the infantry.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA nice little hot torch for the infantry! Good luck to you, fellow\ncountrymen. Thanks for the fire\xe2\x80\x94we\xe2\x80\x99ll return it with interest,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid he, carrying away into the darkness a glowing stick.\n\nNext came four soldiers, carrying something heavy on a cloak, and passed\nby the fire. One of them stumbled.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho the devil has put the logs on the road?\xe2\x80\x9d snarled he.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s dead\xe2\x80\x94why carry him?\xe2\x80\x9d said another.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShut up!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd they disappeared into the darkness with their load.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill aching?\xe2\x80\x9d T\xc3\xbashin asked Rost\xc3\xb3v in a whisper.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour honor, you\xe2\x80\x99re wanted by the general. He is in the hut here,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid a gunner, coming up to T\xc3\xbashin.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cComing, friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nT\xc3\xbashin rose and, buttoning his greatcoat and pulling it straight,\nwalked away from the fire.\n\nNot far from the artillery campfire, in a hut that had been prepared\nfor him, Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n sat at dinner, talking with some commanding\nofficers who had gathered at his quarters. The little old man with\nthe half-closed eyes was there greedily gnawing a mutton bone, and the\ngeneral who had served blamelessly for twenty-two years, flushed by a\nglass of vodka and the dinner; and the staff officer with the signet\nring, and Zherk\xc3\xb3v, uneasily glancing at them all, and Prince Andrew,\npale, with compressed lips and feverishly glittering eyes.\n\nIn a corner of the hut stood a standard captured from the French, and\nthe accountant with the na\xc3\xafve face was feeling its texture, shaking his\nhead in perplexity\xe2\x80\x94perhaps because the banner really interested him,\nperhaps because it was hard for him, hungry as he was, to look on at\na dinner where there was no place for him. In the next hut there was a\nFrench colonel who had been taken prisoner by our dragoons. Our officers\nwere flocking in to look at him. Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n was thanking the\nindividual commanders and inquiring into details of the action and our\nlosses. The general whose regiment had been inspected at Braunau was\ninforming the prince that as soon as the action began he had withdrawn\nfrom the wood, mustered the men who were woodcutting, and, allowing the\nFrench to pass him, had made a bayonet charge with two battalions and\nhad broken up the French troops.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I saw, your excellency, that their first battalion was\ndisorganized, I stopped in the road and thought: \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll let them\ncome on and will meet them with the fire of the whole battalion\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94and\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s what I did.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe general had so wished to do this and was so sorry he had not managed\nto do it that it seemed to him as if it had really happened. Perhaps\nit might really have been so? Could one possibly make out amid all that\nconfusion what did or did not happen?\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the way, your excellency, I should inform you,\xe2\x80\x9d he\ncontinued\xe2\x80\x94remembering D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s conversation with Kut\xc3\xbazov and his\nlast interview with the gentleman-ranker\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthat Private D\xc3\xb3lokhov,\nwho was reduced to the ranks, took a French officer prisoner in my\npresence and particularly distinguished himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw the P\xc3\xa1vlograd hussars attack there, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d chimed\nin Zherk\xc3\xb3v, looking uneasily around. He had not seen the hussars all\nthat day, but had heard about them from an infantry officer. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\nbroke up two squares, your excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nSeveral of those present smiled at Zherk\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s words, expecting one of\nhis usual jokes, but noticing that what he was saying redounded to\nthe glory of our arms and of the day\xe2\x80\x99s work, they assumed a serious\nexpression, though many of them knew that what he was saying was a lie\ndevoid of any foundation. Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n turned to the old colonel:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, I thank you all; all arms have behaved heroically:\ninfantry, cavalry, and artillery. How was it that two guns were\nabandoned in the center?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired, searching with his eyes for\nsomeone. (Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n did not ask about the guns on the left\nflank; he knew that all the guns there had been abandoned at the very\nbeginning of the action.) \xe2\x80\x9cI think I sent you?\xe2\x80\x9d he added, turning to\nthe staff officer on duty.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne was damaged,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the staff officer, \xe2\x80\x9cand the other I\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t understand. I was there all the time giving orders and had only\njust left.... It is true that it was hot there,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, modestly.\n\nSomeone mentioned that Captain T\xc3\xbashin was bivouacking close to the\nvillage and had already been sent for.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, but you were there?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n, addressing Prince\nAndrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course, we only just missed one another,\xe2\x80\x9d said the staff\nofficer, with a smile to Bolk\xc3\xb3nski.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had not the pleasure of seeing you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew, coldly\nand abruptly.\n\nAll were silent. T\xc3\xbashin appeared at the threshold and made his way\ntimidly from behind the backs of the generals. As he stepped past the\ngenerals in the crowded hut, feeling embarrassed as he always was by the\nsight of his superiors, he did not notice the staff of the banner and\nstumbled over it. Several of those present laughed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow was it a gun was abandoned?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Bagrati\xc3\xb3n, frowning, not so\nmuch at the captain as at those who were laughing, among whom Zherk\xc3\xb3v\nlaughed loudest.\n\nOnly now, when he was confronted by the stern authorities, did his guilt\nand the disgrace of having lost two guns and yet remaining alive present\nthemselves to T\xc3\xbashin in all their horror. He had been so excited that\nhe had not thought about it until that moment. The officers\xe2\x80\x99 laughter\nconfused him still more. He stood before Bagrati\xc3\xb3n with his lower\njaw trembling and was hardly able to mutter: \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know... your\nexcellency... I had no men... your excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou might have taken some from the covering troops.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nT\xc3\xbashin did not say that there were no covering troops, though that\nwas perfectly true. He was afraid of getting some other officer into\ntrouble, and silently fixed his eyes on Bagrati\xc3\xb3n as a schoolboy who\nhas blundered looks at an examiner.\n\nThe silence lasted some time. Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n, apparently not wishing\nto be severe, found nothing to say; the others did not venture to\nintervene. Prince Andrew looked at T\xc3\xbashin from under his brows and his\nfingers twitched nervously.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency!\xe2\x80\x9d Prince Andrew broke the silence with his abrupt\nvoice, \xe2\x80\x9cyou were pleased to send me to Captain T\xc3\xbashin\xe2\x80\x99s battery. I\nwent there and found two thirds of the men and horses knocked out, two\nguns smashed, and no supports at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n and T\xc3\xbashin looked with equal intentness at\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski, who spoke with suppressed agitation.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, if your excellency will allow me to express my opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d he\ncontinued, \xe2\x80\x9cwe owe today\xe2\x80\x99s success chiefly to the action of that\nbattery and the heroic endurance of Captain T\xc3\xbashin and his company,\xe2\x80\x9d\nand without awaiting a reply, Prince Andrew rose and left the table.\n\nPrince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n looked at T\xc3\xbashin, evidently reluctant to show\ndistrust in Bolk\xc3\xb3nski\xe2\x80\x99s emphatic opinion yet not feeling able fully\nto credit it, bent his head, and told T\xc3\xbashin that he could go. Prince\nAndrew went out with him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you; you saved me, my dear fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d said T\xc3\xbashin.\n\nPrince Andrew gave him a look, but said nothing and went away. He felt\nsad and depressed. It was all so strange, so unlike what he had hoped.\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are they? Why are they here? What do they want? And when will\nall this end?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Rost\xc3\xb3v, looking at the changing shadows before\nhim. The pain in his arm became more and more intense. Irresistible\ndrowsiness overpowered him, red rings danced before his eyes, and the\nimpression of those voices and faces and a sense of loneliness merged\nwith the physical pain. It was they, these soldiers\xe2\x80\x94wounded and\nunwounded\xe2\x80\x94it was they who were crushing, weighing down, and twisting\nthe sinews and scorching the flesh of his sprained arm and shoulder. To\nrid himself of them he closed his eyes.\n\nFor a moment he dozed, but in that short interval innumerable things\nappeared to him in a dream: his mother and her large white hand,\nS\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s thin little shoulders, Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s eyes and laughter,\nDen\xc3\xadsov with his voice and mustache, and Tely\xc3\xa1nin and all that affair\nwith Tely\xc3\xa1nin and Bogd\xc3\xa1nich. That affair was the same thing as this\nsoldier with the harsh voice, and it was that affair and this soldier\nthat were so agonizingly, incessantly pulling and pressing his arm and\nalways dragging it in one direction. He tried to get away from them, but\nthey would not for an instant let his shoulder move a hair\xe2\x80\x99s breadth.\nIt would not ache\xe2\x80\x94it would be well\xe2\x80\x94if only they did not pull it, but\nit was impossible to get rid of them.\n\nHe opened his eyes and looked up. The black canopy of night hung less\nthan a yard above the glow of the charcoal. Flakes of falling snow were\nfluttering in that light. T\xc3\xbashin had not returned, the doctor had not\ncome. He was alone now, except for a soldier who was sitting naked at\nthe other side of the fire, warming his thin yellow body.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNobody wants me!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Rost\xc3\xb3v. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is no one to help me or\npity me. Yet I was once at home, strong, happy, and loved.\xe2\x80\x9d He sighed\nand, doing so, groaned involuntarily.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, is anything hurting you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the soldier, shaking his shirt\nout over the fire, and not waiting for an answer he gave a grunt and\nadded: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a lot of men have been crippled today\xe2\x80\x94frightful!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v did not listen to the soldier. He looked at the snowflakes\nfluttering above the fire and remembered a Russian winter at his warm,\nbright home, his fluffy fur coat, his quickly gliding sleigh, his\nhealthy body, and all the affection and care of his family. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd why\ndid I come here?\xe2\x80\x9d he wondered.\n\nNext day the French army did not renew their attack, and the remnant of\nBagrati\xc3\xb3n\xe2\x80\x99s detachment was reunited to Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s army.\n\n\n\n\n\nBOOK THREE: 1805\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER I\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli was not a man who deliberately thought out his plans.\nStill less did he think of injuring anyone for his own advantage. He\nwas merely a man of the world who had got on and to whom getting on had\nbecome a habit. Schemes and devices for which he never rightly accounted\nto himself, but which formed the whole interest of his life,\nwere constantly shaping themselves in his mind, arising from the\ncircumstances and persons he met. Of these plans he had not merely one\nor two in his head but dozens, some only beginning to form themselves,\nsome approaching achievement, and some in course of disintegration. He\ndid not, for instance, say to himself: \xe2\x80\x9cThis man now has influence, I\nmust gain his confidence and friendship and through him obtain a special\ngrant.\xe2\x80\x9d Nor did he say to himself: \xe2\x80\x9cPierre is a rich man, I must\nentice him to marry my daughter and lend me the forty thousand rubles\nI need.\xe2\x80\x9d But when he came across a man of position his instinct\nimmediately told him that this man could be useful, and without any\npremeditation Prince Vas\xc3\xadli took the first opportunity to gain his\nconfidence, flatter him, become intimate with him, and finally make his\nrequest.\n\nHe had Pierre at hand in Moscow and procured for him an appointment as\nGentleman of the Bedchamber, which at that time conferred the status of\nCouncilor of State, and insisted on the young man accompanying him to\nPetersburg and staying at his house. With apparent absent-mindedness,\nyet with unhesitating assurance that he was doing the right thing,\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli did everything to get Pierre to marry his daughter. Had\nhe thought out his plans beforehand he could not have been so natural\nand shown such unaffected familiarity in intercourse with everybody both\nabove and below him in social standing. Something always drew him toward\nthose richer and more powerful than himself and he had rare skill in\nseizing the most opportune moment for making use of people.\n\nPierre, on unexpectedly becoming Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov and a rich man, felt\nhimself after his recent loneliness and freedom from cares so beset and\npreoccupied that only in bed was he able to be by himself. He had to\nsign papers, to present himself at government offices, the purpose of\nwhich was not clear to him, to question his chief steward, to visit his\nestate near Moscow, and to receive many people who formerly did not\neven wish to know of his existence but would now have been offended\nand grieved had he chosen not to see them. These different\npeople\xe2\x80\x94businessmen, relations, and acquaintances alike\xe2\x80\x94were all\ndisposed to treat the young heir in the most friendly and flattering\nmanner: they were all evidently firmly convinced of Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s noble\nqualities. He was always hearing such words as: \xe2\x80\x9cWith your remarkable\nkindness,\xe2\x80\x9d or, \xe2\x80\x9cWith your excellent heart,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cYou are yourself so\nhonorable, Count,\xe2\x80\x9d or, \xe2\x80\x9cWere he as clever as you,\xe2\x80\x9d and so on,\ntill he began sincerely to believe in his own exceptional kindness and\nextraordinary intelligence, the more so as in the depth of his heart it\nhad always seemed to him that he really was very kind and intelligent.\nEven people who had formerly been spiteful toward him and evidently\nunfriendly now became gentle and affectionate. The angry eldest\nprincess, with the long waist and hair plastered down like a doll\xe2\x80\x99s,\nhad come into Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s room after the funeral. With drooping eyes\nand frequent blushes she told him she was very sorry about their past\nmisunderstandings and did not now feel she had a right to ask him for\nanything, except only for permission, after the blow she had received,\nto remain for a few weeks longer in the house she so loved and where\nshe had sacrificed so much. She could not refrain from weeping at these\nwords. Touched that this statuesque princess could so change, Pierre\ntook her hand and begged her forgiveness, without knowing what for.\nFrom that day the eldest princess quite changed toward Pierre and began\nknitting a striped scarf for him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo this for my sake, mon cher; after all, she had to put up with a\ngreat deal from the deceased,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Vas\xc3\xadli to him, handing him\na deed to sign for the princess\xe2\x80\x99 benefit.\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli had come to the conclusion that it was necessary to throw\nthis bone\xe2\x80\x94a bill for thirty thousand rubles\xe2\x80\x94to the poor princess\nthat it might not occur to her to speak of his share in the affair of\nthe inlaid portfolio. Pierre signed the deed and after that the princess\ngrew still kinder. The younger sisters also became affectionate to him,\nespecially the youngest, the pretty one with the mole, who often made\nhim feel confused by her smiles and her own confusion when meeting him.\n\nIt seemed so natural to Pierre that everyone should like him, and it\nwould have seemed so unnatural had anyone disliked him, that he could\nnot but believe in the sincerity of those around him. Besides, he had\nno time to ask himself whether these people were sincere or not. He\nwas always busy and always felt in a state of mild and cheerful\nintoxication. He felt as though he were the center of some important and\ngeneral movement; that something was constantly expected of him, that if\nhe did not do it he would grieve and disappoint many people, but if he\ndid this and that, all would be well; and he did what was demanded of\nhim, but still that happy result always remained in the future.\n\nMore than anyone else, Prince Vas\xc3\xadli took possession of Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s\naffairs and of Pierre himself in those early days. From the death of\nCount Bez\xc3\xbakhov he did not let go his hold of the lad. He had the air of\na man oppressed by business, weary and suffering, who yet would not, for\npity\xe2\x80\x99s sake, leave this helpless youth who, after all, was the son of\nhis old friend and the possessor of such enormous wealth, to the caprice\nof fate and the designs of rogues. During the few days he spent in\nMoscow after the death of Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov, he would call Pierre, or\ngo to him himself, and tell him what ought to be done in a tone of\nweariness and assurance, as if he were adding every time: \xe2\x80\x9cYou know\nI am overwhelmed with business and it is purely out of charity that\nI trouble myself about you, and you also know quite well that what I\npropose is the only thing possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear fellow, tomorrow we are off at last,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli one day, closing his eyes and fingering Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s elbow,\nspeaking as if he were saying something which had long since been agreed\nupon and could not now be altered. \xe2\x80\x9cWe start tomorrow and I\xe2\x80\x99m giving\nyou a place in my carriage. I am very glad. All our important business\nhere is now settled, and I ought to have been off long ago. Here is\nsomething I have received from the chancellor. I asked him for you, and\nyou have been entered in the diplomatic corps and made a Gentleman of\nthe Bedchamber. The diplomatic career now lies open before you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNotwithstanding the tone of wearied assurance with which these words\nwere pronounced, Pierre, who had so long been considering his career,\nwished to make some suggestion. But Prince Vas\xc3\xadli interrupted him in\nthe special deep cooing tone, precluding the possibility of interrupting\nhis speech, which he used in extreme cases when special persuasion was\nneeded.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMais, mon cher, I did this for my own sake, to satisfy my conscience,\nand there is nothing to thank me for. No one has ever complained yet of\nbeing too much loved; and besides, you are free, you could throw it\nup tomorrow. But you will see everything for yourself when you get to\nPetersburg. It is high time for you to get away from these terrible\nrecollections.\xe2\x80\x9d Prince Vas\xc3\xadli sighed. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, my boy. And my\nvalet can go in your carriage. Ah! I was nearly forgetting,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know, mon cher, your father and I had some accounts to settle, so\nI have received what was due from the Ryaz\xc3\xa1n estate and will keep it;\nyou won\xe2\x80\x99t require it. We\xe2\x80\x99ll go into the accounts later.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBy \xe2\x80\x9cwhat was due from the Ryaz\xc3\xa1n estate\xe2\x80\x9d Prince Vas\xc3\xadli meant\nseveral thousand rubles quitrent received from Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s peasants,\nwhich the prince had retained for himself.\n\nIn Petersburg, as in Moscow, Pierre found the same atmosphere of\ngentleness and affection. He could not refuse the post, or rather the\nrank (for he did nothing), that Prince Vas\xc3\xadli had procured for him,\nand acquaintances, invitations, and social occupations were so numerous\nthat, even more than in Moscow, he felt a sense of bewilderment, bustle,\nand continual expectation of some good, always in front of him but never\nattained.\n\nOf his former bachelor acquaintances many were no longer in Petersburg.\nThe Guards had gone to the front; D\xc3\xb3lokhov had been reduced to the\nranks; Anatole was in the army somewhere in the provinces; Prince Andrew\nwas abroad; so Pierre had not the opportunity to spend his nights as he\nused to like to spend them, or to open his mind by intimate talks with\na friend older than himself and whom he respected. His whole time\nwas taken up with dinners and balls and was spent chiefly at Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s house in the company of the stout princess, his wife, and\nhis beautiful daughter H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne.\n\nLike the others, Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna Sch\xc3\xa9rer showed Pierre the change of\nattitude toward him that had taken place in society.\n\nFormerly in Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s presence, Pierre had always felt that\nwhat he was saying was out of place, tactless and unsuitable, that\nremarks which seemed to him clever while they formed in his mind became\nfoolish as soon as he uttered them, while on the contrary Hippolyte\xe2\x80\x99s\nstupidest remarks came out clever and apt. Now everything Pierre said\nwas charmant. Even if Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna did not say so, he could see that\nshe wished to and only refrained out of regard for his modesty.\n\nIn the beginning of the winter of 1805-6 Pierre received one of Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s usual pink notes with an invitation to which was added:\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will find the beautiful H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne here, whom it is always\ndelightful to see.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nWhen he read that sentence, Pierre felt for the first time that some\nlink which other people recognized had grown up between himself and\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, and that thought both alarmed him, as if some obligation were\nbeing imposed on him which he could not fulfill, and pleased him as an\nentertaining supposition.\n\nAnna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cAt Home\xe2\x80\x9d was like the former one, only the\nnovelty she offered her guests this time was not Mortemart, but a\ndiplomatist fresh from Berlin with the very latest details of the\nEmperor Alexander\xe2\x80\x99s visit to Potsdam, and of how the two august\nfriends had pledged themselves in an indissoluble alliance to uphold\nthe cause of justice against the enemy of the human race. Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\nreceived Pierre with a shade of melancholy, evidently relating to the\nyoung man\xe2\x80\x99s recent loss by the death of Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov (everyone\nconstantly considered it a duty to assure Pierre that he was greatly\nafflicted by the death of the father he had hardly known), and her\nmelancholy was just like the august melancholy she showed at the mention\nof her most august Majesty the Empress M\xc3\xa1rya F\xc3\xabdorovna. Pierre felt\nflattered by this. Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna arranged the different groups in her\ndrawing room with her habitual skill. The large group, in which were\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli and the generals, had the benefit of the diplomat.\nAnother group was at the tea table. Pierre wished to join the former,\nbut Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x94who was in the excited condition of a commander on\na battlefield to whom thousands of new and brilliant ideas occur which\nthere is hardly time to put in action\xe2\x80\x94seeing Pierre, touched his\nsleeve with her finger, saying:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a bit, I have something in view for you this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\n(She glanced at H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne and smiled at her.) \xe2\x80\x9cMy dear H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, be\ncharitable to my poor aunt who adores you. Go and keep her company for\nten minutes. And that it will not be too dull, here is the dear count\nwho will not refuse to accompany you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe beauty went to the aunt, but Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna detained Pierre, looking\nas if she had to give some final necessary instructions.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t she exquisite?\xe2\x80\x9d she said to Pierre, pointing to the stately\nbeauty as she glided away. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd how she carries herself! For so young\na girl, such tact, such masterly perfection of manner! It comes from\nher heart. Happy the man who wins her! With her the least worldly of men\nwould occupy a most brilliant position in society. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you think so?\nI only wanted to know your opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d and Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna let Pierre go.\n\nPierre, in reply, sincerely agreed with her as to H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s\nperfection of manner. If he ever thought of H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, it was just of\nher beauty and her remarkable skill in appearing silently dignified in\nsociety.\n\nThe old aunt received the two young people in her corner, but seemed\ndesirous of hiding her adoration for H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne and inclined rather\nto show her fear of Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna. She looked at her niece, as if\ninquiring what she was to do with these people. On leaving them, Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna again touched Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s sleeve, saying: \xe2\x80\x9cI hope you won\xe2\x80\x99t\nsay that it is dull in my house again,\xe2\x80\x9d and she glanced at H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne.\n\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne smiled, with a look implying that she did not admit the\npossibility of anyone seeing her without being enchanted. The aunt\ncoughed, swallowed, and said in French that she was very pleased to see\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, then she turned to Pierre with the same words of welcome\nand the same look. In the middle of a dull and halting conversation,\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne turned to Pierre with the beautiful bright smile that she gave\nto everyone. Pierre was so used to that smile, and it had so little\nmeaning for him, that he paid no attention to it. The aunt was just\nspeaking of a collection of snuffboxes that had belonged to Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s\nfather, Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov, and showed them her own box. Princess H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\nasked to see the portrait of the aunt\xe2\x80\x99s husband on the box lid.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is probably the work of Vinesse,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, mentioning\na celebrated miniaturist, and he leaned over the table to take the\nsnuffbox while trying to hear what was being said at the other table.\n\nHe half rose, meaning to go round, but the aunt handed him the snuffbox,\npassing it across H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s back. H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne stooped forward to make\nroom, and looked round with a smile. She was, as always at evening\nparties, wearing a dress such as was then fashionable, cut very low at\nfront and back. Her bust, which had always seemed like marble to Pierre,\nwas so close to him that his shortsighted eyes could not but perceive\nthe living charm of her neck and shoulders, so near to his lips that\nhe need only have bent his head a little to have touched them. He was\nconscious of the warmth of her body, the scent of perfume, and the\ncreaking of her corset as she moved. He did not see her marble beauty\nforming a complete whole with her dress, but all the charm of her body\nonly covered by her garments. And having once seen this he could not\nhelp being aware of it, just as we cannot renew an illusion we have once\nseen through.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you have never noticed before how beautiful I am?\xe2\x80\x9d H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\nseemed to say. \xe2\x80\x9cYou had not noticed that I am a woman? Yes, I am a\nwoman who may belong to anyone\xe2\x80\x94to you too,\xe2\x80\x9d said her glance. And at\nthat moment Pierre felt that H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne not only could, but must, be his\nwife, and that it could not be otherwise.\n\nHe knew this at that moment as surely as if he had been standing at the\naltar with her. How and when this would be he did not know, he did not\neven know if it would be a good thing (he even felt, he knew not why,\nthat it would be a bad thing), but he knew it would happen.\n\nPierre dropped his eyes, lifted them again, and wished once more to see\nher as a distant beauty far removed from him, as he had seen her every\nday until then, but he could no longer do it. He could not, any more\nthan a man who has been looking at a tuft of steppe grass through the\nmist and taking it for a tree can again take it for a tree after he has\nonce recognized it to be a tuft of grass. She was terribly close to him.\nShe already had power over him, and between them there was no longer any\nbarrier except the barrier of his own will.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I will leave you in your little corner,\xe2\x80\x9d came Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s voice, \xe2\x80\x9cI see you are all right there.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Pierre, anxiously trying to remember whether he had done anything\nreprehensible, looked round with a blush. It seemed to him that everyone\nknew what had happened to him as he knew it himself.\n\nA little later when he went up to the large circle, Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna said\nto him: \xe2\x80\x9cI hear you are refitting your Petersburg house?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThis was true. The architect had told him that it was necessary, and\nPierre, without knowing why, was having his enormous Petersburg house\ndone up.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a good thing, but don\xe2\x80\x99t move from Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s. It\nis good to have a friend like the prince,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, smiling at Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli. \xe2\x80\x9cI know something about that. Don\xe2\x80\x99t I? And you are still so\nyoung. You need advice. Don\xe2\x80\x99t be angry with me for exercising an old\nwoman\xe2\x80\x99s privilege.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe paused, as women always do, expecting something after they have\nmentioned their age. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you marry it will be a different thing,\xe2\x80\x9d\nshe continued, uniting them both in one glance. Pierre did not look at\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne nor she at him. But she was just as terribly close to him. He\nmuttered something and colored.\n\nWhen he got home he could not sleep for a long time for thinking of what\nhad happened. What had happened? Nothing. He had merely understood that\nthe woman he had known as a child, of whom when her beauty was mentioned\nhe had said absent-mindedly: \xe2\x80\x9cYes, she\xe2\x80\x99s good looking,\xe2\x80\x9d he had\nunderstood that this woman might belong to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut she\xe2\x80\x99s stupid. I have myself said she is stupid,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is something nasty, something wrong, in the feeling she excites\nin me. I have been told that her brother Anatole was in love with her\nand she with him, that there was quite a scandal and that that\xe2\x80\x99s why\nhe was sent away. Hippolyte is her brother... Prince Vas\xc3\xadli is her\nfather... It\xe2\x80\x99s bad....\xe2\x80\x9d he reflected, but while he was thinking this\n(the reflection was still incomplete), he caught himself smiling and was\nconscious that another line of thought had sprung up, and while thinking\nof her worthlessness he was also dreaming of how she would be his\nwife, how she would love him become quite different, and how all he had\nthought and heard of her might be false. And he again saw her not as the\ndaughter of Prince Vas\xc3\xadli, but visualized her whole body only veiled\nby its gray dress. \xe2\x80\x9cBut no! Why did this thought never occur to me\nbefore?\xe2\x80\x9d and again he told himself that it was impossible, that there\nwould be something unnatural, and as it seemed to him dishonorable, in\nthis marriage. He recalled her former words and looks and the words\nand looks of those who had seen them together. He recalled Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s words and looks when she spoke to him about his house,\nrecalled thousands of such hints from Prince Vas\xc3\xadli and others, and was\nseized by terror lest he had already, in some way, bound himself to do\nsomething that was evidently wrong and that he ought not to do. But at\nthe very time he was expressing this conviction to himself, in another\npart of his mind her image rose in all its womanly beauty.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER II\n\nIn November, 1805, Prince Vas\xc3\xadli had to go on a tour of inspection\nin four different provinces. He had arranged this for himself so as to\nvisit his neglected estates at the same time and pick up his son Anatole\nwhere his regiment was stationed, and take him to visit Prince Nicholas\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski in order to arrange a match for him with the daughter of that\nrich old man. But before leaving home and undertaking these new affairs,\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli had to settle matters with Pierre, who, it is true, had\nlatterly spent whole days at home, that is, in Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s house\nwhere he was staying, and had been absurd, excited, and foolish in\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s presence (as a lover should be), but had not yet proposed\nto her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is all very fine, but things must be settled,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli to himself, with a sorrowful sigh, one morning, feeling that\nPierre who was under such obligations to him (\xe2\x80\x9cBut never mind that\xe2\x80\x9d)\nwas not behaving very well in this matter. \xe2\x80\x9cYouth, frivolity... well,\nGod be with him,\xe2\x80\x9d thought he, relishing his own goodness of heart,\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut it must be brought to a head. The day after tomorrow will be\nL\xc3\xablya\xe2\x80\x99s name day. I will invite two or three people, and if he does\nnot understand what he ought to do then it will be my affair\xe2\x80\x94yes, my\naffair. I am her father.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nSix weeks after Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cAt Home\xe2\x80\x9d and after the sleepless\nnight when he had decided that to marry H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne would be a calamity and\nthat he ought to avoid her and go away, Pierre, despite that decision,\nhad not left Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s and felt with terror that in people\xe2\x80\x99s\neyes he was every day more and more connected with her, that it was\nimpossible for him to return to his former conception of her, that he\ncould not break away from her, and that though it would be a terrible\nthing he would have to unite his fate with hers. He might perhaps have\nbeen able to free himself but that Prince Vas\xc3\xadli (who had rarely before\ngiven receptions) now hardly let a day go by without having an evening\nparty at which Pierre had to be present unless he wished to spoil\nthe general pleasure and disappoint everyone\xe2\x80\x99s expectation. Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli, in the rare moments when he was at home, would take Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s\nhand in passing and draw it downwards, or absent-mindedly hold out his\nwrinkled, clean-shaven cheek for Pierre to kiss and would say: \xe2\x80\x9cTill\ntomorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d or, \xe2\x80\x9cBe in to dinner or I shall not see you,\xe2\x80\x9d or, \xe2\x80\x9cI\nam staying in for your sake,\xe2\x80\x9d and so on. And though Prince Vas\xc3\xadli,\nwhen he stayed in (as he said) for Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s sake, hardly exchanged a\ncouple of words with him, Pierre felt unable to disappoint him.\nEvery day he said to himself one and the same thing: \xe2\x80\x9cIt is time I\nunderstood her and made up my mind what she really is. Was I mistaken\nbefore, or am I mistaken now? No, she is not stupid, she is an excellent\ngirl,\xe2\x80\x9d he sometimes said to himself \xe2\x80\x9cshe never makes a mistake,\nnever says anything stupid. She says little, but what she does say is\nalways clear and simple, so she is not stupid. She never was abashed and\nis not abashed now, so she cannot be a bad woman!\xe2\x80\x9d He had often begun\nto make reflections or think aloud in her company, and she had always\nanswered him either by a brief but appropriate remark\xe2\x80\x94showing that it\ndid not interest her\xe2\x80\x94or by a silent look and smile which more palpably\nthan anything else showed Pierre her superiority. She was right in\nregarding all arguments as nonsense in comparison with that smile.\n\nShe always addressed him with a radiantly confiding smile meant for him\nalone, in which there was something more significant than in the general\nsmile that usually brightened her face. Pierre knew that everyone was\nwaiting for him to say a word and cross a certain line, and he knew that\nsooner or later he would step across it, but an incomprehensible terror\nseized him at the thought of that dreadful step. A thousand times during\nthat month and a half while he felt himself drawn nearer and nearer to\nthat dreadful abyss, Pierre said to himself: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat am I doing? I need\nresolution. Can it be that I have none?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe wished to take a decision, but felt with dismay that in this matter\nhe lacked that strength of will which he had known in himself and really\npossessed. Pierre was one of those who are only strong when they feel\nthemselves quite innocent, and since that day when he was overpowered\nby a feeling of desire while stooping over the snuffbox at Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s, an unacknowledged sense of the guilt of that desire\nparalyzed his will.\n\nOn H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s name day, a small party of just their own people\xe2\x80\x94as\nhis wife said\xe2\x80\x94met for supper at Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s. All these friends\nand relations had been given to understand that the fate of the young\ngirl would be decided that evening. The visitors were seated at supper.\nPrincess Kur\xc3\xa1gina, a portly imposing woman who had once been handsome,\nwas sitting at the head of the table. On either side of her sat the\nmore important guests\xe2\x80\x94an old general and his wife, and Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\nSch\xc3\xa9rer. At the other end sat the younger and less important guests,\nand there too sat the members of the family, and Pierre and H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne,\nside by side. Prince Vas\xc3\xadli was not having any supper: he went round\nthe table in a merry mood, sitting down now by one, now by another, of\nthe guests. To each of them he made some careless and agreeable remark\nexcept to Pierre and H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, whose presence he seemed not to notice.\nHe enlivened the whole party. The wax candles burned brightly, the\nsilver and crystal gleamed, so did the ladies\xe2\x80\x99 toilets and the gold\nand silver of the men\xe2\x80\x99s epaulets; servants in scarlet liveries moved\nround the table, the clatter of plates, knives, and glasses mingled with\nthe animated hum of several conversations. At one end of the table, the\nold chamberlain was heard assuring an old baroness that he loved her\npassionately, at which she laughed; at the other could be heard the\nstory of the misfortunes of some Mary V\xc3\xadktorovna or other. At the\ncenter of the table, Prince Vas\xc3\xadli attracted everybody\xe2\x80\x99s attention.\nWith a facetious smile on his face, he was telling the ladies about last\nWednesday\xe2\x80\x99s meeting of the Imperial Council, at which Serg\xc3\xa9y Kuzm\xc3\xadch\nVyazm\xc3\xadtinov, the new military governor general of Petersburg, had\nreceived and read the then famous rescript of the Emperor Alexander\nfrom the army to Serg\xc3\xa9y Kuzm\xc3\xadch, in which the Emperor said that he was\nreceiving from all sides declarations of the people\xe2\x80\x99s loyalty, that\nthe declaration from Petersburg gave him particular pleasure, and that\nhe was proud to be at the head of such a nation and would endeavor to be\nworthy of it. This rescript began with the words: \xe2\x80\x9cSerg\xc3\xa9y Kuzm\xc3\xadch,\nFrom all sides reports reach me,\xe2\x80\x9d etc.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and so he never got farther than: \xe2\x80\x98Serg\xc3\xa9y Kuzm\xc3\xadch\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d\nasked one of the ladies.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly, not a hair\xe2\x80\x99s breadth farther,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Prince Vas\xc3\xadli,\nlaughing, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Serg\xc3\xa9y Kuzm\xc3\xadch... From all sides... From all sides...\nSerg\xc3\xa9y Kuzm\xc3\xadch...\xe2\x80\x99 Poor Vyazm\xc3\xadtinov could not get any farther!\nHe began the rescript again and again, but as soon as he uttered\n\xe2\x80\x98Serg\xc3\xa9y\xe2\x80\x99 he sobbed, \xe2\x80\x98Kuz-m\xc3\xad-ch,\xe2\x80\x99 tears, and \xe2\x80\x98From all\nsides\xe2\x80\x99 was smothered in sobs and he could get no farther. And again\nhis handkerchief, and again: \xe2\x80\x98Serg\xc3\xa9y Kuzm\xc3\xadch, From all sides,\xe2\x80\x99...\nand tears, till at last somebody else was asked to read it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cKuzm\xc3\xadch... From all sides... and then tears,\xe2\x80\x9d someone repeated\nlaughing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be unkind,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna from her end of the table\nholding up a threatening finger. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is such a worthy and excellent\nman, our dear Vyazm\xc3\xadtinov....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nEverybody laughed a great deal. At the head of the table, where the\nhonored guests sat, everyone seemed to be in high spirits and under the\ninfluence of a variety of exciting sensations. Only Pierre and\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne sat silently side by side almost at the bottom of the table, a\nsuppressed smile brightening both their faces, a smile that had nothing\nto do with Serg\xc3\xa9y Kuzm\xc3\xadch\xe2\x80\x94a smile of bashfulness at their own\nfeelings. But much as all the rest laughed, talked, and joked, much\nas they enjoyed their Rhine wine, saut\xc3\xa9, and ices, and however they\navoided looking at the young couple, and heedless and unobservant as\nthey seemed of them, one could feel by the occasional glances they gave\nthat the story about Serg\xc3\xa9y Kuzm\xc3\xadch, the laughter, and the food\nwere all a pretense, and that the whole attention of that company was\ndirected to\xe2\x80\x94Pierre and H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne. Prince Vas\xc3\xadli mimicked the sobbing\nof Serg\xc3\xa9y Kuzm\xc3\xadch and at the same time his eyes glanced toward his\ndaughter, and while he laughed the expression on his face clearly said:\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes... it\xe2\x80\x99s getting on, it will all be settled today.\xe2\x80\x9d Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna threatened him on behalf of \xe2\x80\x9cour dear Vyazm\xc3\xadtinov,\xe2\x80\x9d and\nin her eyes, which, for an instant, glanced at Pierre, Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\nread a congratulation on his future son-in-law and on his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s\nhappiness. The old princess sighed sadly as she offered some wine to the\nold lady next to her and glanced angrily at her daughter, and her sigh\nseemed to say: \xe2\x80\x9cYes, there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing left for you and me but to sip\nsweet wine, my dear, now that the time has come for these young ones to\nbe thus boldly, provocatively happy.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cAnd what nonsense all this is\nthat I am saying!\xe2\x80\x9d thought a diplomatist, glancing at the happy faces\nof the lovers. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s happiness!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nInto the insignificant, trifling, and artificial interests uniting that\nsociety had entered the simple feeling of the attraction of a healthy\nand handsome young man and woman for one another. And this human feeling\ndominated everything else and soared above all their affected chatter.\nJests fell flat, news was not interesting, and the animation was\nevidently forced. Not only the guests but even the footmen waiting at\ntable seemed to feel this, and they forgot their duties as they looked\nat the beautiful H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne with her radiant face and at the red, broad,\nand happy though uneasy face of Pierre. It seemed as if the very light\nof the candles was focused on those two happy faces alone.\n\nPierre felt that he was the center of it all, and this both pleased and\nembarrassed him. He was like a man entirely absorbed in some occupation.\nHe did not see, hear, or understand anything clearly. Only now and\nthen detached ideas and impressions from the world of reality shot\nunexpectedly through his mind.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo it is all finished!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd how has it all happened?\nHow quickly! Now I know that not because of her alone, nor of myself\nalone, but because of everyone, it must inevitably come about. They are\nall expecting it, they are so sure that it will happen that I cannot, I\ncannot, disappoint them. But how will it be? I do not know, but it\nwill certainly happen!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Pierre, glancing at those dazzling\nshoulders close to his eyes.\n\nOr he would suddenly feel ashamed of he knew not what. He felt it\nawkward to attract everyone\xe2\x80\x99s attention and to be considered a\nlucky man and, with his plain face, to be looked on as a sort of Paris\npossessed of a Helen. \xe2\x80\x9cBut no doubt it always is and must be so!\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe consoled himself. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd besides, what have I done to bring it about?\nHow did it begin? I traveled from Moscow with Prince Vas\xc3\xadli. Then there\nwas nothing. So why should I not stay at his house? Then I played cards\nwith her and picked up her reticule and drove out with her. How did it\nbegin, when did it all come about?\xe2\x80\x9d And here he was sitting by her\nside as her betrothed, seeing, hearing, feeling her nearness, her\nbreathing, her movements, her beauty. Then it would suddenly seem to him\nthat it was not she but he was so unusually beautiful, and that that was\nwhy they all looked so at him, and flattered by this general admiration\nhe would expand his chest, raise his head, and rejoice at his good\nfortune. Suddenly he heard a familiar voice repeating something to him a\nsecond time. But Pierre was so absorbed that he did not understand what\nwas said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am asking you when you last heard from Bolk\xc3\xb3nski,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli a third time. \xe2\x80\x9cHow absent-minded you are, my dear\nfellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli smiled, and Pierre noticed that everyone was smiling at\nhim and H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what of it, if you all know it?\xe2\x80\x9d thought\nPierre. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat of it? It\xe2\x80\x99s the truth!\xe2\x80\x9d and he himself smiled his\ngentle childlike smile, and H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne smiled too.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen did you get the letter? Was it from Olm\xc3\xbctz?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli, who pretended to want to know this in order to settle a\ndispute.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can one talk or think of such trifles?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, from Olm\xc3\xbctz,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, with a sigh.\n\nAfter supper Pierre with his partner followed the others into the\ndrawing room. The guests began to disperse, some without taking leave\nof H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne. Some, as if unwilling to distract her from an important\noccupation, came up to her for a moment and made haste to go away,\nrefusing to let her see them off. The diplomatist preserved a mournful\nsilence as he left the drawing room. He pictured the vanity of his\ndiplomatic career in comparison with Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s happiness. The old\ngeneral grumbled at his wife when she asked how his leg was. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, the\nold fool,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cThat Princess H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne will be beautiful\nstill when she\xe2\x80\x99s fifty.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I may congratulate you,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna to the\nold princess, kissing her soundly. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t this headache I\xe2\x80\x99d\nhave stayed longer.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe old princess did not reply, she was tormented by jealousy of her\ndaughter\xe2\x80\x99s happiness.\n\nWhile the guests were taking their leave Pierre remained for a long time\nalone with H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne in the little drawing room where they were sitting.\nHe had often before, during the last six weeks, remained alone with her,\nbut had never spoken to her of love. Now he felt that it was inevitable,\nbut he could not make up his mind to take the final step. He felt\nashamed; he felt that he was occupying someone else\xe2\x80\x99s place here\nbeside H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne. \xe2\x80\x9cThis happiness is not for you,\xe2\x80\x9d some inner voice\nwhispered to him. \xe2\x80\x9cThis happiness is for those who have not in them\nwhat there is in you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBut, as he had to say something, he began by asking her whether she was\nsatisfied with the party. She replied in her usual simple manner that\nthis name day of hers had been one of the pleasantest she had ever had.\n\nSome of the nearest relatives had not yet left. They were sitting in\nthe large drawing room. Prince Vas\xc3\xadli came up to Pierre with languid\nfootsteps. Pierre rose and said it was getting late. Prince Vas\xc3\xadli gave\nhim a look of stern inquiry, as though what Pierre had just said was\nso strange that one could not take it in. But then the expression of\nseverity changed, and he drew Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s hand downwards, made him sit\ndown, and smiled affectionately.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, L\xc3\xablya?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, turning instantly to his daughter and\naddressing her with the careless tone of habitual tenderness natural to\nparents who have petted their children from babyhood, but which Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli had only acquired by imitating other parents.\n\nAnd he again turned to Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSerg\xc3\xa9y Kuzm\xc3\xadch\xe2\x80\x94From all sides\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d he said, unbuttoning the top\nbutton of his waistcoat.\n\nPierre smiled, but his smile showed that he knew it was not the story\nabout Serg\xc3\xa9y Kuzm\xc3\xadch that interested Prince Vas\xc3\xadli just then, and\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli saw that Pierre knew this. He suddenly muttered\nsomething and went away. It seemed to Pierre that even the prince was\ndisconcerted. The sight of the discomposure of that old man of the world\ntouched Pierre: he looked at H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne and she too seemed disconcerted,\nand her look seemed to say: \xe2\x80\x9cWell, it is your own fault.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe step must be taken but I cannot, I cannot!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Pierre,\nand he again began speaking about indifferent matters, about Serg\xc3\xa9y\nKuzm\xc3\xadch, asking what the point of the story was as he had not heard it\nproperly. H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne answered with a smile that she too had missed it.\n\nWhen Prince Vas\xc3\xadli returned to the drawing room, the princess, his\nwife, was talking in low tones to the elderly lady about Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course, it is a very brilliant match, but happiness, my dear...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarriages are made in heaven,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the elderly lady.\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli passed by, seeming not to hear the ladies, and sat down\non a sofa in a far corner of the room. He closed his eyes and seemed to\nbe dozing. His head sank forward and then he roused himself.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAline,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to his wife, \xe2\x80\x9cgo and see what they are about.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe princess went up to the door, passed by it with a dignified and\nindifferent air, and glanced into the little drawing room. Pierre and\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne still sat talking just as before.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill the same,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to her husband.\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli frowned, twisting his mouth, his cheeks quivered and his\nface assumed the coarse, unpleasant expression peculiar to him. Shaking\nhimself, he rose, threw back his head, and with resolute steps went\npast the ladies into the little drawing room. With quick steps he went\njoyfully up to Pierre. His face was so unusually triumphant that Pierre\nrose in alarm on seeing it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank God!\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Vas\xc3\xadli. \xe2\x80\x9cMy wife has told me\neverything!\xe2\x80\x9d (He put one arm around Pierre and the other around his\ndaughter.)\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear boy... L\xc3\xablya... I am very pleased.\xe2\x80\x9d (His\nvoice trembled.) \xe2\x80\x9cI loved your father... and she will make you a good\nwife... God bless you!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe embraced his daughter, and then again Pierre, and kissed him with his\nmalodorous mouth. Tears actually moistened his cheeks.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrincess, come here!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted.\n\nThe old princess came in and also wept. The elderly lady was using\nher handkerchief too. Pierre was kissed, and he kissed the beautiful\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s hand several times. After a while they were left alone\nagain.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll this had to be and could not be otherwise,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Pierre,\n\xe2\x80\x9cso it is useless to ask whether it is good or bad. It is good because\nit\xe2\x80\x99s definite and one is rid of the old tormenting doubt.\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre\nheld the hand of his betrothed in silence, looking at her beautiful\nbosom as it rose and fell.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne!\xe2\x80\x9d he said aloud and paused.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomething special is always said in such cases,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, but\ncould not remember what it was that people say. He looked at her face.\nShe drew nearer to him. Her face flushed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, take those off... those...\xe2\x80\x9d she said, pointing to his\nspectacles.\n\nPierre took them off, and his eyes, besides the strange look eyes have\nfrom which spectacles have just been removed, had also a frightened and\ninquiring look. He was about to stoop over her hand and kiss it, but\nwith a rapid, almost brutal movement of her head, she intercepted his\nlips and met them with her own. Her face struck Pierre, by its altered,\nunpleasantly excited expression.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is too late now, it\xe2\x80\x99s done; besides I love her,\xe2\x80\x9d thought\nPierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cJe vous aime!\xe2\x80\x9d * he said, remembering what has to be said at such\nmoments: but his words sounded so weak that he felt ashamed of himself.\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cI love you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nSix weeks later he was married, and settled in Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s\nlarge, newly furnished Petersburg house, the happy possessor, as people\nsaid, of a wife who was a celebrated beauty and of millions of money.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER III\n\nOld Prince Nicholas Bolk\xc3\xb3nski received a letter from Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\nin November, 1805, announcing that he and his son would be paying him\na visit. \xe2\x80\x9cI am starting on a journey of inspection, and of course I\nshall think nothing of an extra seventy miles to come and see you at\nthe same time, my honored benefactor,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote Prince Vas\xc3\xadli. \xe2\x80\x9cMy son\nAnatole is accompanying me on his way to the army, so I hope you will\nallow him personally to express the deep respect that, emulating his\nfather, he feels for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems that there will be no need to bring Mary out, suitors are\ncoming to us of their own accord,\xe2\x80\x9d incautiously remarked the little\nprincess on hearing the news.\n\nPrince Nicholas frowned, but said nothing.\n\nA fortnight after the letter Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s servants came one\nevening in advance of him, and he and his son arrived next day.\n\nOld Bolk\xc3\xb3nski had always had a poor opinion of Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s\ncharacter, but more so recently, since in the new reigns of Paul and\nAlexander Prince Vas\xc3\xadli had risen to high position and honors. And now,\nfrom the hints contained in his letter and given by the little princess,\nhe saw which way the wind was blowing, and his low opinion changed into\na feeling of contemptuous ill will. He snorted whenever he mentioned\nhim. On the day of Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s arrival, Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski was\nparticularly discontented and out of temper. Whether he was in a bad\ntemper because Prince Vas\xc3\xadli was coming, or whether his being in a bad\ntemper made him specially annoyed at Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s visit, he was\nin a bad temper, and in the morning T\xc3\xadkhon had already advised the\narchitect not to go to the prince with his report.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you hear how he\xe2\x80\x99s walking?\xe2\x80\x9d said T\xc3\xadkhon, drawing the\narchitect\xe2\x80\x99s attention to the sound of the prince\xe2\x80\x99s footsteps.\n\xe2\x80\x9cStepping flat on his heels\xe2\x80\x94we know what that means....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHowever, at nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock the prince, in his velvet coat with a sable\ncollar and cap, went out for his usual walk. It had snowed the day\nbefore and the path to the hothouse, along which the prince was in the\nhabit of walking, had been swept: the marks of the broom were still\nvisible in the snow and a shovel had been left sticking in one of the\nsoft snowbanks that bordered both sides of the path. The prince went\nthrough the conservatories, the serfs\xe2\x80\x99 quarters, and the outbuildings,\nfrowning and silent.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan a sleigh pass?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked his overseer, a venerable man,\nresembling his master in manners and looks, who was accompanying him\nback to the house.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe snow is deep. I am having the avenue swept, your honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe prince bowed his head and went up to the porch. \xe2\x80\x9cGod be\nthanked,\xe2\x80\x9d thought the overseer, \xe2\x80\x9cthe storm has blown over!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would have been hard to drive up, your honor,\xe2\x80\x9d he added. \xe2\x80\x9cI\nheard, your honor, that a minister is coming to visit your honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe prince turned round to the overseer and fixed his eyes on him,\nfrowning.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? A minister? What minister? Who gave orders?\xe2\x80\x9d he said in\nhis shrill, harsh voice. \xe2\x80\x9cThe road is not swept for the princess my\ndaughter, but for a minister! For me, there are no ministers!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour honor, I thought...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou thought!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the prince, his words coming more and more\nrapidly and indistinctly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou thought!... Rascals! Blackguards!...\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll teach you to think!\xe2\x80\x9d and lifting his stick he swung it and\nwould have hit Alp\xc3\xa1tych, the overseer, had not the latter instinctively\navoided the blow. \xe2\x80\x9cThought... Blackguards...\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the prince\nrapidly.\n\nBut although Alp\xc3\xa1tych, frightened at his own temerity in avoiding the\nstroke, came up to the prince, bowing his bald head resignedly before\nhim, or perhaps for that very reason, the prince, though he continued\nto shout: \xe2\x80\x9cBlackguards!... Throw the snow back on the road!\xe2\x80\x9d did not\nlift his stick again but hurried into the house.\n\nBefore dinner, Princess Mary and Mademoiselle Bourienne, who knew\nthat the prince was in a bad humor, stood awaiting him; Mademoiselle\nBourienne with a radiant face that said: \xe2\x80\x9cI know nothing, I am the\nsame as usual,\xe2\x80\x9d and Princess Mary pale, frightened, and with downcast\neyes. What she found hardest to bear was to know that on such occasions\nshe ought to behave like Mademoiselle Bourienne, but could not.\nShe thought: \xe2\x80\x9cIf I seem not to notice he will think that I do not\nsympathize with him; if I seem sad and out of spirits myself, he will\nsay (as he has done before) that I\xe2\x80\x99m in the dumps.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe prince looked at his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s frightened face and snorted.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFool... or dummy!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the other one is not here. They\xe2\x80\x99ve been telling tales,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nthought\xe2\x80\x94referring to the little princess who was not in the dining\nroom.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is the princess?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cHiding?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is not very well,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Mademoiselle Bourienne with\na bright smile, \xe2\x80\x9cso she won\xe2\x80\x99t come down. It is natural in her\nstate.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHm! Hm!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the prince, sitting down.\n\nHis plate seemed to him not quite clean, and pointing to a spot he\nflung it away. T\xc3\xadkhon caught it and handed it to a footman. The little\nprincess was not unwell, but had such an overpowering fear of the prince\nthat, hearing he was in a bad humor, she had decided not to appear.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid for the baby,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to Mademoiselle Bourienne:\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeaven knows what a fright might do.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIn general at Bald Hills the little princess lived in constant fear, and\nwith a sense of antipathy to the old prince which she did not\nrealize because the fear was so much the stronger feeling. The prince\nreciprocated this antipathy, but it was overpowered by his contempt\nfor her.
