When the little princess had grown accustomed to life at Bald\nHills, she took a special fancy to Mademoiselle Bourienne, spent whole\ndays with her, asked her to sleep in her room, and often talked with her\nabout the old prince and criticized him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo we are to have visitors, mon prince?\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Mademoiselle\nBourienne, unfolding her white napkin with her rosy fingers. \xe2\x80\x9cHis\nExcellency Prince Vas\xc3\xadli Kur\xc3\xa1gin and his son, I understand?\xe2\x80\x9d she\nsaid inquiringly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHm!\xe2\x80\x94his excellency is a puppy.... I got him his appointment in the\nservice,\xe2\x80\x9d said the prince disdainfully. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy his son is coming I\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t understand. Perhaps Princess Elizabeth and Princess Mary know.\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t want him.\xe2\x80\x9d (He looked at his blushing daughter.) \xe2\x80\x9cAre you\nunwell today? Eh? Afraid of the \xe2\x80\x98minister\xe2\x80\x99 as that idiot Alp\xc3\xa1tych\ncalled him this morning?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, mon p\xc3\xa8re.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThough Mademoiselle Bourienne had been so unsuccessful in her choice\nof a subject, she did not stop talking, but chattered about the\nconservatories and the beauty of a flower that had just opened, and\nafter the soup the prince became more genial.\n\nAfter dinner, he went to see his daughter-in-law. The little princess\nwas sitting at a small table, chattering with M\xc3\xa1sha, her maid. She grew\npale on seeing her father-in-law.\n\nShe was much altered. She was now plain rather than pretty. Her cheeks\nhad sunk, her lip was drawn up, and her eyes drawn down.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I feel a kind of oppression,\xe2\x80\x9d she said in reply to the\nprince\xe2\x80\x99s question as to how she felt.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you want anything?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, merci, mon p\xc3\xa8re.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, all right, all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe left the room and went to the waiting room where Alp\xc3\xa1tych stood with\nbowed head.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas the snow been shoveled back?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, your excellency. Forgive me for heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake... It was only\nmy stupidity.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, all right,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the prince, and laughing his\nunnatural way, he stretched out his hand for Alp\xc3\xa1tych to kiss, and then\nproceeded to his study.\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli arrived that evening. He was met in the avenue by\ncoachmen and footmen, who, with loud shouts, dragged his sleighs up to\none of the lodges over the road purposely laden with snow.\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli and Anatole had separate rooms assigned to them.\n\nAnatole, having taken off his overcoat, sat with arms akimbo before a\ntable on a corner of which he smilingly and absent-mindedly fixed his\nlarge and handsome eyes. He regarded his whole life as a continual round\nof amusement which someone for some reason had to provide for him.\nAnd he looked on this visit to a churlish old man and a rich and ugly\nheiress in the same way. All this might, he thought, turn out very well\nand amusingly. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd why not marry her if she really has so much money?\nThat never does any harm,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Anatole.\n\nHe shaved and scented himself with the care and elegance which had\nbecome habitual to him and, his handsome head held high, entered his\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s room with the good-humored and victorious air natural to\nhim. Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s two valets were busy dressing him, and he looked\nround with much animation and cheerfully nodded to his son as the latter\nentered, as if to say: \xe2\x80\x9cYes, that\xe2\x80\x99s how I want you to look.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, Father, joking apart, is she very hideous?\xe2\x80\x9d Anatole asked,\nas if continuing a conversation the subject of which had often been\nmentioned during the journey.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough! What nonsense! Above all, try to be respectful and cautious\nwith the old prince.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he starts a row I\xe2\x80\x99ll go away,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Anatole. \xe2\x80\x9cI\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t bear those old men! Eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemember, for you everything depends on this.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIn the meantime, not only was it known in the maidservants\xe2\x80\x99 rooms that\nthe minister and his son had arrived, but the appearance of both had\nbeen minutely described. Princess Mary was sitting alone in her room,\nvainly trying to master her agitation.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did they write, why did Lise tell me about it? It can never\nhappen!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, looking at herself in the glass. \xe2\x80\x9cHow shall I\nenter the drawing room? Even if I like him I can\xe2\x80\x99t now be myself with\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d The mere thought of her father\xe2\x80\x99s look filled her with terror.\nThe little princess and Mademoiselle Bourienne had already received\nfrom M\xc3\xa1sha, the lady\xe2\x80\x99s maid, the necessary report of how handsome the\nminister\xe2\x80\x99s son was, with his rosy cheeks and dark eyebrows, and with\nwhat difficulty the father had dragged his legs upstairs while the son\nhad followed him like an eagle, three steps at a time. Having received\nthis information, the little princess and Mademoiselle Bourienne, whose\nchattering voices had reached her from the corridor, went into Princess\nMary\xe2\x80\x99s room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know they\xe2\x80\x99ve come, Marie?\xe2\x80\x9d said the little princess, waddling\nin, and sinking heavily into an armchair.\n\nShe was no longer in the loose gown she generally wore in the morning,\nbut had on one of her best dresses. Her hair was carefully done and her\nface was animated, which, however, did not conceal its sunken and faded\noutlines. Dressed as she used to be in Petersburg society, it was still\nmore noticeable how much plainer she had become. Some unobtrusive touch\nhad been added to Mademoiselle Bourienne\xe2\x80\x99s toilet which rendered her\nfresh and pretty face yet more attractive.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! Are you going to remain as you are, dear princess?\xe2\x80\x9d she\nbegan. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ll be announcing that the gentlemen are in the drawing\nroom and we shall have to go down, and you have not smartened yourself\nup at all!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe little princess got up, rang for the maid, and hurriedly and merrily\nbegan to devise and carry out a plan of how Princess Mary should be\ndressed. Princess Mary\xe2\x80\x99s self-esteem was wounded by the fact that\nthe arrival of a suitor agitated her, and still more so by both\nher companions\xe2\x80\x99 not having the least conception that it could be\notherwise. To tell them that she felt ashamed for herself and for them\nwould be to betray her agitation, while to decline their offers to\ndress her would prolong their banter and insistence. She flushed, her\nbeautiful eyes grew dim, red blotches came on her face, and it took\non the unattractive martyrlike expression it so often wore, as she\nsubmitted herself to Mademoiselle Bourienne and Lise. Both these women\nquite sincerely tried to make her look pretty. She was so plain that\nneither of them could think of her as a rival, so they began dressing\nher with perfect sincerity, and with the na\xc3\xafve and firm conviction\nwomen have that dress can make a face pretty.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo really, my dear, this dress is not pretty,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lise, looking\nsideways at Princess Mary from a little distance. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have a maroon\ndress, have it fetched. Really! You know the fate of your whole life may\nbe at stake. But this one is too light, it\xe2\x80\x99s not becoming!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIt was not the dress, but the face and whole figure of Princess Mary\nthat was not pretty, but neither Mademoiselle Bourienne nor the little\nprincess felt this; they still thought that if a blue ribbon were placed\nin the hair, the hair combed up, and the blue scarf arranged lower on\nthe best maroon dress, and so on, all would be well. They forgot that\nthe frightened face and the figure could not be altered, and that\nhowever they might change the setting and adornment of that face, it\nwould still remain piteous and plain. After two or three changes to\nwhich Princess Mary meekly submitted, just as her hair had been arranged\non the top of her head (a style that quite altered and spoiled her\nlooks) and she had put on a maroon dress with a pale-blue scarf, the\nlittle princess walked twice round her, now adjusting a fold of the\ndress with her little hand, now arranging the scarf and looking at her\nwith her head bent first on one side and then on the other.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it will not do,\xe2\x80\x9d she said decidedly, clasping her hands. \xe2\x80\x9cNo,\nMary, really this dress does not suit you. I prefer you in your little\ngray everyday dress. Now please, do it for my sake. Katie,\xe2\x80\x9d she said\nto the maid, \xe2\x80\x9cbring the princess her gray dress, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll see,\nMademoiselle Bourienne, how I shall arrange it,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, smiling\nwith a foretaste of artistic pleasure.\n\nBut when Katie brought the required dress, Princess Mary remained\nsitting motionless before the glass, looking at her face, and saw in the\nmirror her eyes full of tears and her mouth quivering, ready to burst\ninto sobs.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, dear princess,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mademoiselle Bourienne, \xe2\x80\x9cjust one more\nlittle effort.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe little princess, taking the dress from the maid, came up to Princess\nMary.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now we\xe2\x80\x99ll arrange something quite simple and becoming,\xe2\x80\x9d she\nsaid.\n\nThe three voices, hers, Mademoiselle Bourienne\xe2\x80\x99s, and Katie\xe2\x80\x99s, who\nwas laughing at something, mingled in a merry sound, like the chirping\nof birds.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, leave me alone,\xe2\x80\x9d said Princess Mary.\n\nHer voice sounded so serious and so sad that the chirping of the birds\nwas silenced at once. They looked at the beautiful, large, thoughtful\neyes full of tears and of thoughts, gazing shiningly and imploringly at\nthem, and understood that it was useless and even cruel to insist.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt least, change your coiffure,\xe2\x80\x9d said the little princess.\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t I tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on, turning reproachfully to\nMademoiselle Bourienne, \xe2\x80\x9cMary\xe2\x80\x99s is a face which such a coiffure does\nnot suit in the least. Not in the least! Please change it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeave me alone, please leave me alone! It is all quite the same to\nme,\xe2\x80\x9d answered a voice struggling with tears.\n\nMademoiselle Bourienne and the little princess had to own to themselves\nthat Princess Mary in this guise looked very plain, worse than usual,\nbut it was too late. She was looking at them with an expression they\nboth knew, an expression thoughtful and sad. This expression in Princess\nMary did not frighten them (she never inspired fear in anyone), but they\nknew that when it appeared on her face, she became mute and was not to\nbe shaken in her determination.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will change it, won\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Lise. And as Princess Mary\ngave no answer, she left the room.\n\nPrincess Mary was left alone. She did not comply with Lise\xe2\x80\x99s request,\nshe not only left her hair as it was, but did not even look in her\nglass. Letting her arms fall helplessly, she sat with downcast eyes and\npondered. A husband, a man, a strong dominant and strangely attractive\nbeing rose in her imagination, and carried her into a totally different\nhappy world of his own. She fancied a child, her own\xe2\x80\x94such as she had\nseen the day before in the arms of her nurse\xe2\x80\x99s daughter\xe2\x80\x94at her\nown breast, the husband standing by and gazing tenderly at her and the\nchild. \xe2\x80\x9cBut no, it is impossible, I am too ugly,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease come to tea. The prince will be out in a moment,\xe2\x80\x9d came the\nmaid\xe2\x80\x99s voice at the door.\n\nShe roused herself, and felt appalled at what she had been thinking, and\nbefore going down she went into the room where the icons hung and, her\neyes fixed on the dark face of a large icon of the Saviour lit by a\nlamp, she stood before it with folded hands for a few moments. A painful\ndoubt filled her soul. Could the joy of love, of earthly love for a\nman, be for her? In her thoughts of marriage Princess Mary dreamed of\nhappiness and of children, but her strongest, most deeply hidden longing\nwas for earthly love. The more she tried to hide this feeling from\nothers and even from herself, the stronger it grew. \xe2\x80\x9cO God,\xe2\x80\x9d she\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9chow am I to stifle in my heart these temptations of the devil?\nHow am I to renounce forever these vile fancies, so as peacefully to\nfulfill Thy will?\xe2\x80\x9d And scarcely had she put that question than God\ngave her the answer in her own heart. \xe2\x80\x9cDesire nothing for thyself,\nseek nothing, be not anxious or envious. Man\xe2\x80\x99s future and thy own fate\nmust remain hidden from thee, but live so that thou mayest be ready for\nanything. If it be God\xe2\x80\x99s will to prove thee in the duties of marriage,\nbe ready to fulfill His will.\xe2\x80\x9d With this consoling thought (but\nyet with a hope for the fulfillment of her forbidden earthly longing)\nPrincess Mary sighed, and having crossed herself went down, thinking\nneither of her gown and coiffure nor of how she would go in nor of what\nshe would say. What could all that matter in comparison with the will of\nGod, without Whose care not a hair of man\xe2\x80\x99s head can fall?\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IV\n\nWhen Princess Mary came down, Prince Vas\xc3\xadli and his son were already\nin the drawing room, talking to the little princess and Mademoiselle\nBourienne. When she entered with her heavy step, treading on her heels,\nthe gentlemen and Mademoiselle Bourienne rose and the little princess,\nindicating her to the gentlemen, said: \xe2\x80\x9cVoil\xc3\xa0 Marie!\xe2\x80\x9d Princess Mary\nsaw them all and saw them in detail. She saw Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s face,\nserious for an instant at the sight of her, but immediately smiling\nagain, and the little princess curiously noting the impression\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarie\xe2\x80\x9d produced on the visitors. And she saw Mademoiselle\nBourienne, with her ribbon and pretty face, and her unusually animated\nlook which was fixed on him, but him she could not see, she only saw\nsomething large, brilliant, and handsome moving toward her as she\nentered the room. Prince Vas\xc3\xadli approached first, and she kissed the\nbold forehead that bent over her hand and answered his question by\nsaying that, on the contrary, she remembered him quite well. Then\nAnatole came up to her. She still could not see him. She only felt a\nsoft hand taking hers firmly, and she touched with her lips a white\nforehead, over which was beautiful light-brown hair smelling of pomade.\nWhen she looked up at him she was struck by his beauty. Anatole stood\nwith his right thumb under a button of his uniform, his chest expanded\nand his back drawn in, slightly swinging one foot, and, with his head a\nlittle bent, looked with beaming face at the princess without\nspeaking and evidently not thinking about her at all. Anatole was not\nquick-witted, nor ready or eloquent in conversation, but he had the\nfaculty, so invaluable in society, of composure and imperturbable\nself-possession. If a man lacking in self-confidence remains dumb on\na first introduction and betrays a consciousness of the impropriety of\nsuch silence and an anxiety to find something to say, the effect is\nbad. But Anatole was dumb, swung his foot, and smilingly examined the\nprincess\xe2\x80\x99 hair. It was evident that he could be silent in this way for\na very long time. \xe2\x80\x9cIf anyone finds this silence inconvenient, let him\ntalk, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to,\xe2\x80\x9d he seemed to say. Besides this, in his\nbehavior to women Anatole had a manner which particularly inspires in\nthem curiosity, awe, and even love\xe2\x80\x94a supercilious consciousness of\nhis own superiority. It was as if he said to them: \xe2\x80\x9cI know you, I know\nyou, but why should I bother about you? You\xe2\x80\x99d be only too glad, of\ncourse.\xe2\x80\x9d Perhaps he did not really think this when he met women\xe2\x80\x94even\nprobably he did not, for in general he thought very little\xe2\x80\x94but his\nlooks and manner gave that impression. The princess felt this, and as if\nwishing to show him that she did not even dare expect to interest him,\nshe turned to his father. The conversation was general and animated,\nthanks to Princess Lise\xe2\x80\x99s voice and little downy lip that lifted over\nher white teeth. She met Prince Vas\xc3\xadli with that playful manner often\nemployed by lively chatty people, and consisting in the assumption\nthat between the person they so address and themselves there are some\nsemi-private, long-established jokes and amusing reminiscences, though\nno such reminiscences really exist\xe2\x80\x94just as none existed in this case.\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli readily adopted her tone and the little princess also\ndrew Anatole, whom she hardly knew, into these amusing recollections of\nthings that had never occurred. Mademoiselle Bourienne also shared them\nand even Princess Mary felt herself pleasantly made to share in these\nmerry reminiscences.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere at least we shall have the benefit of your company all to\nourselves, dear prince,\xe2\x80\x9d said the little princess (of course, in\nFrench) to Prince Vas\xc3\xadli. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not as at Annette\xe2\x80\x99s * receptions\nwhere you always ran away; you remember cette ch\xc3\xa8re Annette!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n    * Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, but you won\xe2\x80\x99t talk politics to me like Annette!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd our little tea table?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy is it you were never at Annette\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d the little princess asked\nAnatole. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, I know, I know,\xe2\x80\x9d she said with a sly glance, \xe2\x80\x9cyour\nbrother Hippolyte told me about your goings on. Oh!\xe2\x80\x9d and she shook her\nfinger at him, \xe2\x80\x9cI have even heard of your doings in Paris!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd didn\xe2\x80\x99t Hippolyte tell you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Prince Vas\xc3\xadli, turning to\nhis son and seizing the little princess\xe2\x80\x99 arm as if she would have run\naway and he had just managed to catch her, \xe2\x80\x9cdidn\xe2\x80\x99t he tell you how\nhe himself was pining for the dear princess, and how she showed him the\ndoor? Oh, she is a pearl among women, Princess,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, turning to\nPrincess Mary.\n\nWhen Paris was mentioned, Mademoiselle Bourienne for her part seized the\nopportunity of joining in the general current of recollections.\n\nShe took the liberty of inquiring whether it was long since Anatole\nhad left Paris and how he had liked that city. Anatole answered the\nFrenchwoman very readily and, looking at her with a smile, talked to her\nabout her native land. When he saw the pretty little Bourienne, Anatole\ncame to the conclusion that he would not find Bald Hills dull either.\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all bad!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, examining her, \xe2\x80\x9cnot at all bad, that\nlittle companion! I hope she will bring her along with her when we\xe2\x80\x99re\nmarried, la petite est gentille.\xe2\x80\x9d *\n\n    * The little one is charming.\n\nThe old prince dressed leisurely in his study, frowning and considering\nwhat he was to do. The coming of these visitors annoyed him. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli and that son of his to me? Prince Vas\xc3\xadli is a shallow\nbraggart and his son, no doubt, is a fine specimen,\xe2\x80\x9d he grumbled to\nhimself. What angered him was that the coming of these visitors revived\nin his mind an unsettled question he always tried to stifle, one about\nwhich he always deceived himself. The question was whether he could ever\nbring himself to part from his daughter and give her to a husband. The\nprince never directly asked himself that question, knowing beforehand\nthat he would have to answer it justly, and justice clashed not only\nwith his feelings but with the very possibility of life. Life without\nPrincess Mary, little as he seemed to value her, was unthinkable to\nhim. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd why should she marry?\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cTo be unhappy for\ncertain. There\xe2\x80\x99s Lise, married to Andrew\xe2\x80\x94a better husband one would\nthink could hardly be found nowadays\xe2\x80\x94but is she contented with her\nlot? And who would marry Marie for love? Plain and awkward! They\xe2\x80\x99ll\ntake her for her connections and wealth. Are there no women living\nunmarried, and even the happier for it?\xe2\x80\x9d So thought Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski\nwhile dressing, and yet the question he was always putting off demanded\nan immediate answer. Prince Vas\xc3\xadli had brought his son with the evident\nintention of proposing, and today or tomorrow he would probably ask\nfor an answer. His birth and position in society were not bad. \xe2\x80\x9cWell,\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve nothing against it,\xe2\x80\x9d the prince said to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cbut he must\nbe worthy of her. And that is what we shall see.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is what we shall see! That is what we shall see!\xe2\x80\x9d he added\naloud.\n\nHe entered the drawing room with his usual alert step, glancing rapidly\nround the company. He noticed the change in the little princess\xe2\x80\x99\ndress, Mademoiselle Bourienne\xe2\x80\x99s ribbon, Princess Mary\xe2\x80\x99s unbecoming\ncoiffure, Mademoiselle Bourienne\xe2\x80\x99s and Anatole\xe2\x80\x99s smiles, and the\nloneliness of his daughter amid the general conversation. \xe2\x80\x9cGot herself\nup like a fool!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, looking irritably at her. \xe2\x80\x9cShe is\nshameless, and he ignores her!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe went straight up to Prince Vas\xc3\xadli.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! How d\xe2\x80\x99ye do? How d\xe2\x80\x99ye do? Glad to see you!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriendship laughs at distance,\xe2\x80\x9d began Prince Vas\xc3\xadli in his usual\nrapid, self-confident, familiar tone. \xe2\x80\x9cHere is my second son; please\nlove and befriend him.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski surveyed Anatole.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFine young fellow! Fine young fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, come and\nkiss me,\xe2\x80\x9d and he offered his cheek.\n\nAnatole kissed the old man, and looked at him with curiosity and perfect\ncomposure, waiting for a display of the eccentricities his father had\ntold him to expect.\n\nPrince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski sat down in his usual place in the corner of the sofa\nand, drawing up an armchair for Prince Vas\xc3\xadli, pointed to it and began\nquestioning him about political affairs and news. He seemed to listen\nattentively to what Prince Vas\xc3\xadli said, but kept glancing at Princess\nMary.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so they are writing from Potsdam already?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, repeating\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s last words. Then rising, he suddenly went up to his\ndaughter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it for visitors you\xe2\x80\x99ve got yourself up like that, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said\nhe. \xe2\x80\x9cFine, very fine! You have done up your hair in this new way for\nthe visitors, and before the visitors I tell you that in future you are\nnever to dare to change your way of dress without my consent.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was my fault, mon p\xc3\xa8re,\xe2\x80\x9d interceded the little princess, with a\nblush.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must do as you please,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski, bowing to his\ndaughter-in-law, \xe2\x80\x9cbut she need not make a fool of herself, she\xe2\x80\x99s\nplain enough as it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd he sat down again, paying no more attention to his daughter, who was\nreduced to tears.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, that coiffure suits the princess very well,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow you, young prince, what\xe2\x80\x99s your name?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski,\nturning to Anatole, \xe2\x80\x9ccome here, let us talk and get acquainted.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow the fun begins,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Anatole, sitting down with a smile\nbeside the old prince.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear boy, I hear you\xe2\x80\x99ve been educated abroad, not taught\nto read and write by the deacon, like your father and me. Now tell me,\nmy dear boy, are you serving in the Horse Guards?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the old man,\nscrutinizing Anatole closely and intently.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I have been transferred to the line,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole, hardly able\nto restrain his laughter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! That\xe2\x80\x99s a good thing. So, my dear boy, you wish to serve the\nTsar and the country? It is wartime. Such a fine fellow must serve.\nWell, are you off to the front?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Prince, our regiment has gone to the front, but I am attached...\nwhat is it I am attached to, Papa?\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole, turning to his\nfather with a laugh.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA splendid soldier, splendid! \xe2\x80\x98What am I attached to!\xe2\x80\x99 Ha, ha,\nha!\xe2\x80\x9d laughed Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski, and Anatole laughed still louder.\nSuddenly Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski frowned.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may go,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Anatole.\n\nAnatole returned smiling to the ladies.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so you\xe2\x80\x99ve had him educated abroad, Prince Vas\xc3\xadli, haven\xe2\x80\x99t\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d said the old prince to Prince Vas\xc3\xadli.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have done my best for him, and I can assure you the education there\nis much better than ours.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, everything is different nowadays, everything is changed. The\nlad\xe2\x80\x99s a fine fellow, a fine fellow! Well, come with me now.\xe2\x80\x9d He took\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s arm and led him to his study. As soon as they were\nalone together, Prince Vas\xc3\xadli announced his hopes and wishes to the old\nprince.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, do you think I shall prevent her, that I can\xe2\x80\x99t part from\nher?\xe2\x80\x9d said the old prince angrily. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat an idea! I\xe2\x80\x99m ready for it\ntomorrow! Only let me tell you, I want to know my son-in-law better. You\nknow my principles\xe2\x80\x94everything aboveboard! I will ask her tomorrow in\nyour presence; if she is willing, then he can stay on. He can stay and\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll see.\xe2\x80\x9d The old prince snorted. \xe2\x80\x9cLet her marry, it\xe2\x80\x99s all the\nsame to me!\xe2\x80\x9d he screamed in the same piercing tone as when parting\nfrom his son.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you frankly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Vas\xc3\xadli in the tone of\na crafty man convinced of the futility of being cunning with so\nkeen-sighted a companion. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know, you see right through people.\nAnatole is no genius, but he is an honest, goodhearted lad; an excellent\nson or kinsman.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, all right, we\xe2\x80\x99ll see!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAs always happens when women lead lonely lives for any length of time\nwithout male society, on Anatole\xe2\x80\x99s appearance all the three women of\nPrince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski\xe2\x80\x99s household felt that their life had not been real\ntill then. Their powers of reasoning, feeling, and observing immediately\nincreased tenfold, and their life, which seemed to have been passed in\ndarkness, was suddenly lit up by a new brightness, full of significance.\n\nPrincess Mary grew quite unconscious of her face and coiffure. The\nhandsome open face of the man who might perhaps be her husband absorbed\nall her attention. He seemed to her kind, brave, determined, manly, and\nmagnanimous. She felt convinced of that. Thousands of dreams of a future\nfamily life continually rose in her imagination. She drove them away and\ntried to conceal them.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut am I not too cold with him?\xe2\x80\x9d thought the princess. \xe2\x80\x9cI try\nto be reserved because in the depth of my soul I feel too near to him\nalready, but then he cannot know what I think of him and may imagine\nthat I do not like him.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Princess Mary tried, but could not manage, to be cordial to her new\nguest. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor girl, she\xe2\x80\x99s devilish ugly!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Anatole.\n\nMademoiselle Bourienne, also roused to great excitement by Anatole\xe2\x80\x99s\narrival, thought in another way. Of course, she, a handsome young woman\nwithout any definite position, without relations or even a country, did\nnot intend to devote her life to serving Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski, to reading\naloud to him and being friends with Princess Mary. Mademoiselle\nBourienne had long been waiting for a Russian prince who, able to\nappreciate at a glance her superiority to the plain, badly dressed,\nungainly Russian princesses, would fall in love with her and carry her\noff; and here at last was a Russian prince. Mademoiselle Bourienne knew\na story, heard from her aunt but finished in her own way, which she\nliked to repeat to herself. It was the story of a girl who had been\nseduced, and to whom her poor mother (sa pauvre m\xc3\xa8re) appeared, and\nreproached her for yielding to a man without being married. Mademoiselle\nBourienne was often touched to tears as in imagination she told this\nstory to him, her seducer. And now he, a real Russian prince, had\nappeared. He would carry her away and then sa pauvre m\xc3\xa8re would appear\nand he would marry her. So her future shaped itself in Mademoiselle\nBourienne\xe2\x80\x99s head at the very time she was talking to Anatole about\nParis. It was not calculation that guided her (she did not even for a\nmoment consider what she should do), but all this had long been familiar\nto her, and now that Anatole had appeared it just grouped itself around\nhim and she wished and tried to please him as much as possible.\n\nThe little princess, like an old war horse that hears the trumpet,\nunconsciously and quite forgetting her condition, prepared for the\nfamiliar gallop of coquetry, without any ulterior motive or any\nstruggle, but with na\xc3\xafve and lighthearted gaiety.\n\nAlthough in female society Anatole usually assumed the role of a man\ntired of being run after by women, his vanity was flattered by the\nspectacle of his power over these three women. Besides that, he was\nbeginning to feel for the pretty and provocative Mademoiselle Bourienne\nthat passionate animal feeling which was apt to master him with great\nsuddenness and prompt him to the coarsest and most reckless actions.\n\nAfter tea, the company went into the sitting room and Princess Mary was\nasked to play on the clavichord. Anatole, laughing and in high spirits,\ncame and leaned on his elbows, facing her and beside Mademoiselle\nBourienne. Princess Mary felt his look with a painfully joyous emotion.\nHer favorite sonata bore her into a most intimately poetic world and\nthe look she felt upon her made that world still more poetic. But\nAnatole\xe2\x80\x99s expression, though his eyes were fixed on her, referred not\nto her but to the movements of Mademoiselle Bourienne\xe2\x80\x99s little\nfoot, which he was then touching with his own under the clavichord.\nMademoiselle Bourienne was also looking at Princess Mary, and in her\nlovely eyes there was a look of fearful joy and hope that was also new\nto the princess.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow she loves me!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Princess Mary. \xe2\x80\x9cHow happy I am now,\nand how happy I may be with such a friend and such a husband! Husband?\nCan it be possible?\xe2\x80\x9d she thought, not daring to look at his face, but\nstill feeling his eyes gazing at her.\n\nIn the evening, after supper, when all were about to retire, Anatole\nkissed Princess Mary\xe2\x80\x99s hand. She did not know how she found the\ncourage, but she looked straight into his handsome face as it came near\nto her shortsighted eyes. Turning from Princess Mary he went up and\nkissed Mademoiselle Bourienne\xe2\x80\x99s hand. (This was not etiquette, but\nthen he did everything so simply and with such assurance!) Mademoiselle\nBourienne flushed, and gave the princess a frightened look.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat delicacy!\xe2\x80\x9d thought the princess. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible that\nAm\xc3\xa9lie\xe2\x80\x9d (Mademoiselle Bourienne) \xe2\x80\x9cthinks I could be jealous of her,\nand not value her pure affection and devotion to me?\xe2\x80\x9d She went up\nto her and kissed her warmly. Anatole went up to kiss the little\nprincess\xe2\x80\x99 hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! No! No! When your father writes to tell me that you are behaving\nwell I will give you my hand to kiss. Not till then!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. And\nsmilingly raising a finger at him, she left the room.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER V\n\nThey all separated, but, except Anatole who fell asleep as soon as he\ngot into bed, all kept awake a long time that night.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he really to be my husband, this stranger who is so kind\xe2\x80\x94yes,\nkind, that is the chief thing,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Princess Mary; and fear, which\nshe had seldom experienced, came upon her. She feared to look round, it\nseemed to her that someone was there standing behind the screen in the\ndark corner. And this someone was he\xe2\x80\x94the devil\xe2\x80\x94and he was also this\nman with the white forehead, black eyebrows, and red lips.\n\nShe rang for her maid and asked her to sleep in her room.\n\nMademoiselle Bourienne walked up and down the conservatory for a long\ntime that evening, vainly expecting someone, now smiling at someone, now\nworking herself up to tears with the imaginary words of her pauvre m\xc3\xa8re\nrebuking her for her fall.\n\nThe little princess grumbled to her maid that her bed was badly made.\nShe could not lie either on her face or on her side. Every position was\nawkward and uncomfortable, and her burden oppressed her now more than\never because Anatole\xe2\x80\x99s presence had vividly recalled to her the time\nwhen she was not like that and when everything was light and gay. She\nsat in an armchair in her dressing jacket and nightcap and Katie, sleepy\nand disheveled, beat and turned the heavy feather bed for the third\ntime, muttering to herself.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told you it was all lumps and holes!\xe2\x80\x9d the little princess\nrepeated. \xe2\x80\x9cI should be glad enough to fall asleep, so it\xe2\x80\x99s not my\nfault!\xe2\x80\x9d and her voice quivered like that of a child about to cry.\n\nThe old prince did not sleep either. T\xc3\xadkhon, half asleep, heard him\npacing angrily about and snorting. The old prince felt as though he\nhad been insulted through his daughter. The insult was the more pointed\nbecause it concerned not himself but another, his daughter, whom he\nloved more than himself. He kept telling himself that he would consider\nthe whole matter and decide what was right and how he should act, but\ninstead of that he only excited himself more and more.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe first man that turns up\xe2\x80\x94she forgets her father and everything\nelse, runs upstairs and does up her hair and wags her tail and is unlike\nherself! Glad to throw her father over! And she knew I should notice\nit. Fr... fr... fr! And don\xe2\x80\x99t I see that that idiot had eyes only for\nBourienne\xe2\x80\x94I shall have to get rid of her. And how is it she has not\npride enough to see it? If she has no pride for herself she might at\nleast have some for my sake! She must be shown that the blockhead thinks\nnothing of her and looks only at Bourienne. No, she has no pride... but\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll let her see....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe old prince knew that if he told his daughter she was making a\nmistake and that Anatole meant to flirt with Mademoiselle Bourienne,\nPrincess Mary\xe2\x80\x99s self-esteem would be wounded and his point (not to\nbe parted from her) would be gained, so pacifying himself with this\nthought, he called T\xc3\xadkhon and began to undress.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat devil brought them here?\xe2\x80\x9d thought he, while T\xc3\xadkhon was\nputting the nightshirt over his dried-up old body and gray-haired chest.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never invited them. They came to disturb my life\xe2\x80\x94and there is not\nmuch of it left.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDevil take \xe2\x80\x98em!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered, while his head was still covered by\nthe shirt.\n\nT\xc3\xadkhon knew his master\xe2\x80\x99s habit of sometimes thinking aloud, and\ntherefore met with unaltered looks the angrily inquisitive expression of\nthe face that emerged from the shirt.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGone to bed?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the prince.\n\nT\xc3\xadkhon, like all good valets, instinctively knew the direction of his\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts. He guessed that the question referred to Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli and his son.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey have gone to bed and put out their lights, your excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo good... no good...\xe2\x80\x9d said the prince rapidly, and thrusting his\nfeet into his slippers and his arms into the sleeves of his dressing\ngown, he went to the couch on which he slept.\n\nThough no words had passed between Anatole and Mademoiselle Bourienne,\nthey quite understood one another as to the first part of their romance,\nup to the appearance of the pauvre m\xc3\xa8re; they understood that they had\nmuch to say to one another in private and so they had been seeking an\nopportunity since morning to meet one another alone. When Princess Mary\nwent to her father\xe2\x80\x99s room at the usual hour, Mademoiselle Bourienne\nand Anatole met in the conservatory.\n\nPrincess Mary went to the door of the study with special trepidation.\nIt seemed to her that not only did everybody know that her fate would be\ndecided that day, but that they also knew what she thought about it. She\nread this in T\xc3\xadkhon\xe2\x80\x99s face and in that of Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s valet,\nwho made her a low bow when she met him in the corridor carrying hot\nwater.\n\nThe old prince was very affectionate and careful in his treatment of\nhis daughter that morning. Princess Mary well knew this painstaking\nexpression of her father\xe2\x80\x99s. His face wore that expression when his\ndry hands clenched with vexation at her not understanding a sum in\narithmetic, when rising from his chair he would walk away from her,\nrepeating in a low voice the same words several times over.\n\nHe came to the point at once, treating her ceremoniously.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have had a proposition made me concerning you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said with an\nunnatural smile. \xe2\x80\x9cI expect you have guessed that Prince Vas\xc3\xadli has\nnot come and brought his pupil with him\xe2\x80\x9d (for some reason Prince\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski referred to Anatole as a \xe2\x80\x9cpupil\xe2\x80\x9d) \xe2\x80\x9cfor the sake of my\nbeautiful eyes. Last night a proposition was made me on your account\nand, as you know my principles, I refer it to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow am I to understand you, mon p\xc3\xa8re?\xe2\x80\x9d said the princess, growing\npale and then blushing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow understand me!\xe2\x80\x9d cried her father angrily. \xe2\x80\x9cPrince Vas\xc3\xadli\nfinds you to his taste as a daughter-in-law and makes a proposal to you\non his pupil\xe2\x80\x99s behalf. That\xe2\x80\x99s how it\xe2\x80\x99s to be understood! \xe2\x80\x98How\nunderstand it\xe2\x80\x99!... And I ask you!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know what you think, Father,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered the princess.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? I? What of me? Leave me out of the question. I\xe2\x80\x99m not going to\nget married. What about you? That\xe2\x80\x99s what I want to know.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe princess saw that her father regarded the matter with disapproval,\nbut at that moment the thought occurred to her that her fate would be\ndecided now or never. She lowered her eyes so as not to see the gaze\nunder which she felt that she could not think, but would only be able to\nsubmit from habit, and she said: \xe2\x80\x9cI wish only to do your will, but if\nI had to express my own desire...\xe2\x80\x9d She had no time to finish. The old\nprince interrupted her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s admirable!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted. \xe2\x80\x9cHe will take you with your\ndowry and take Mademoiselle Bourienne into the bargain. She\xe2\x80\x99ll be the\nwife, while you...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe prince stopped. He saw the effect these words had produced on his\ndaughter. She lowered her head and was ready to burst into tears.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow then, now then, I\xe2\x80\x99m only joking!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cRemember this,\nPrincess, I hold to the principle that a maiden has a full right to\nchoose. I give you freedom. Only remember that your life\xe2\x80\x99s happiness\ndepends on your decision. Never mind me!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I do not know, Father!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no need to talk! He receives his orders and will marry you\nor anybody; but you are free to choose.... Go to your room, think it\nover, and come back in an hour and tell me in his presence: yes or no.\nI know you will pray over it. Well, pray if you like, but you had better\nthink it over. Go! Yes or no, yes or no, yes or no!\xe2\x80\x9d he still shouted\nwhen the princess, as if lost in a fog, had already staggered out of the\nstudy.\n\nHer fate was decided and happily decided. But what her father had said\nabout Mademoiselle Bourienne was dreadful. It was untrue to be sure, but\nstill it was terrible, and she could not help thinking of it. She was\ngoing straight on through the conservatory, neither seeing nor hearing\nanything, when suddenly the well-known whispering of Mademoiselle\nBourienne aroused her. She raised her eyes, and two steps away saw\nAnatole embracing the Frenchwoman and whispering something to her. With\na horrified expression on his handsome face, Anatole looked at Princess\nMary, but did not at once take his arm from the waist of Mademoiselle\nBourienne who had not yet seen her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x99s that? Why? Wait a moment!\xe2\x80\x9d Anatole\xe2\x80\x99s face seemed to say.\nPrincess Mary looked at them in silence. She could not understand it. At\nlast Mademoiselle Bourienne gave a scream and ran away. Anatole bowed to\nPrincess Mary with a gay smile, as if inviting her to join in a laugh at\nthis strange incident, and then shrugging his shoulders went to the door\nthat led to his own apartments.\n\nAn hour later, T\xc3\xadkhon came to call Princess Mary to the old prince;\nhe added that Prince Vas\xc3\xadli was also there. When T\xc3\xadkhon came to her\nPrincess Mary was sitting on the sofa in her room, holding the weeping\nMademoiselle Bourienne in her arms and gently stroking her hair. The\nprincess\xe2\x80\x99 beautiful eyes with all their former calm radiance were\nlooking with tender affection and pity at Mademoiselle Bourienne\xe2\x80\x99s\npretty face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Princess, I have lost your affection forever!\xe2\x80\x9d said\nMademoiselle Bourienne.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy? I love you more than ever,\xe2\x80\x9d said Princess Mary, \xe2\x80\x9cand I will\ntry to do all I can for your happiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you despise me. You who are so pure can never understand being so\ncarried away by passion. Oh, only my poor mother...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI quite understand,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Princess Mary, with a sad smile.\n\xe2\x80\x9cCalm yourself, my dear. I will go to my father,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, and went\nout.\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli, with one leg thrown high over the other and a snuffbox\nin his hand, was sitting there with a smile of deep emotion on his face,\nas if stirred to his heart\xe2\x80\x99s core and himself regretting and laughing\nat his own sensibility, when Princess Mary entered. He hurriedly took a\npinch of snuff.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear, my dear!\xe2\x80\x9d he began, rising and taking her by both\nhands. Then, sighing, he added: \xe2\x80\x9cMy son\xe2\x80\x99s fate is in your hands.\nDecide, my dear, good, gentle Marie, whom I have always loved as a\ndaughter!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe drew back and a real tear appeared in his eye.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFr... fr...\xe2\x80\x9d snorted Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski. \xe2\x80\x9cThe prince is making a\nproposition to you in his pupil\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94I mean, his son\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94name. Do you\nwish or not to be Prince Anatole Kur\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x99s wife? Reply: yes or no,\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe shouted, \xe2\x80\x9cand then I shall reserve the right to state my opinion\nalso. Yes, my opinion, and only my opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d added Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski,\nturning to Prince Vas\xc3\xadli and answering his imploring look. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, or\nno?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy desire is never to leave you, Father, never to separate my\nlife from yours. I don\xe2\x80\x99t wish to marry,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered positively,\nglancing at Prince Vas\xc3\xadli and at her father with her beautiful eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHumbug! Nonsense! Humbug, humbug, humbug!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski,\nfrowning and taking his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s hand; he did not kiss her, but only\nbending his forehead to hers just touched it, and pressed her hand so\nthat she winced and uttered a cry.\n\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli rose.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear, I must tell you that this is a moment I shall never, never\nforget. But, my dear, will you not give us a little hope of touching\nthis heart, so kind and generous? Say \xe2\x80\x98perhaps\xe2\x80\x99... The future is so\nlong. Say \xe2\x80\x98perhaps.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrince, what I have said is all there is in my heart. I thank you for\nthe honor, but I shall never be your son\xe2\x80\x99s wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, so that\xe2\x80\x99s finished, my dear fellow! I am very glad to have\nseen you. Very glad! Go back to your rooms, Princess. Go!\xe2\x80\x9d said\nthe old prince. \xe2\x80\x9cVery, very glad to have seen you,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated he,\nembracing Prince Vas\xc3\xadli.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy vocation is a different one,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Princess Mary. \xe2\x80\x9cMy\nvocation is to be happy with another kind of happiness, the happiness\nof love and self-sacrifice. And cost what it may, I will arrange\npoor Am\xc3\xa9lie\xe2\x80\x99s happiness, she loves him so passionately, and so\npassionately repents. I will do all I can to arrange the match between\nthem. If he is not rich I will give her the means; I will ask my\nfather and Andrew. I shall be so happy when she is his wife. She is so\nunfortunate, a stranger, alone, helpless! And, oh God, how passionately\nshe must love him if she could so far forget herself! Perhaps I might\nhave done the same!...\xe2\x80\x9d thought Princess Mary.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VI\n\nIt was long since the Rost\xc3\xb3vs had news of Nicholas. Not till midwinter\nwas the count at last handed a letter addressed in his son\xe2\x80\x99s\nhandwriting. On receiving it, he ran on tiptoe to his study in alarm and\nhaste, trying to escape notice, closed the door, and began to read the\nletter.\n\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, who always knew everything that passed in the house,\non hearing of the arrival of the letter went softly into the room and\nfound the count with it in his hand, sobbing and laughing at the same\ntime.\n\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, though her circumstances had improved, was still\nliving with the Rost\xc3\xb3vs.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear friend?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, in a tone of pathetic inquiry, prepared\nto sympathize in any way.\n\nThe count sobbed yet more.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNik\xc3\xb3lenka... a letter... wa... a... s... wounded... my darling\nboy... the countess... promoted to be an officer... thank God... How\ntell the little countess!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna sat down beside him, with her own handkerchief wiped\nthe tears from his eyes and from the letter, then having dried her\nown eyes she comforted the count, and decided that at dinner and till\nteatime she would prepare the countess, and after tea, with God\xe2\x80\x99s\nhelp, would inform her.\n\nAt dinner Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna talked the whole time about the war news\nand about Nik\xc3\xb3lenka, twice asked when the last letter had been received\nfrom him, though she knew that already, and remarked that they might\nvery likely be getting a letter from him that day. Each time that these\nhints began to make the countess anxious and she glanced uneasily at\nthe count and at Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, the latter very adroitly turned\nthe conversation to insignificant matters. Nat\xc3\xa1sha, who, of the whole\nfamily, was the most gifted with a capacity to feel any shades of\nintonation, look, and expression, pricked up her ears from the beginning\nof the meal and was certain that there was some secret between her\nfather and Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, that it had something to do with her\nbrother, and that Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna was preparing them for it. Bold as\nshe was, Nat\xc3\xa1sha, who knew how sensitive her mother was to anything\nrelating to Nik\xc3\xb3lenka, did not venture to ask any questions at dinner,\nbut she was too excited to eat anything and kept wriggling about on her\nchair regardless of her governess\xe2\x80\x99 remarks. After dinner, she rushed\nheadlong after Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna and, dashing at her, flung herself on\nher neck as soon as she overtook her in the sitting room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAuntie, darling, do tell me what it is!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing, my dear.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, dearest, sweet one, honey, I won\xe2\x80\x99t give up\xe2\x80\x94I know you know\nsomething.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna shook her head.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a little slyboots,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA letter from Nik\xc3\xb3lenka! I\xe2\x80\x99m sure of it!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Nat\xc3\xa1sha,\nreading confirmation in Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna\xe2\x80\x99s face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, be careful, you know how it may affect your\nmamma.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will, I will, only tell me! You won\xe2\x80\x99t? Then I will go and tell at\nonce.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, in a few words, told her the contents of the letter,\non condition that she should tell no one.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, on my true word of honor,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha, crossing herself,\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t tell anyone!\xe2\x80\x9d and she ran off at once to S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNik\xc3\xb3lenka... wounded... a letter,\xe2\x80\x9d she announced in gleeful\ntriumph.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNicholas!\xe2\x80\x9d was all S\xc3\xb3nya said, instantly turning white.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, seeing the impression the news of her brother\xe2\x80\x99s wound\nproduced on S\xc3\xb3nya, felt for the first time the sorrowful side of the\nnews.\n\nShe rushed to S\xc3\xb3nya, hugged her, and began to cry.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA little wound, but he has been made an officer; he is well now, he\nwrote himself,\xe2\x80\x9d said she through her tears.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere now! It\xe2\x80\x99s true that all you women are crybabies,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked\nP\xc3\xa9tya, pacing the room with large, resolute strides. \xe2\x80\x9cNow I\xe2\x80\x99m very\nglad, very glad indeed, that my brother has distinguished himself so.\nYou are all blubberers and understand nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha smiled through her tears.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou haven\xe2\x80\x99t read the letter?\xe2\x80\x9d asked S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but she said that it was all over and that he\xe2\x80\x99s now an\nofficer.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank God!\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya, crossing herself. \xe2\x80\x9cBut perhaps she\ndeceived you. Let us go to Mamma.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya paced the room in silence for a time.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I\xe2\x80\x99d been in Nik\xc3\xb3lenka\xe2\x80\x99s place I would have killed even more\nof those Frenchmen,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat nasty brutes they are! I\xe2\x80\x99d\nhave killed so many that there\xe2\x80\x99d have been a heap of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue, P\xc3\xa9tya, what a goose you are!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not a goose, but they are who cry about trifles,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nP\xc3\xa9tya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you remember him?\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha suddenly asked, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s\nsilence.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya smiled.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo I remember Nicholas?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, S\xc3\xb3nya, but do you remember so that you remember him perfectly,\nremember everything?\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha, with an expressive gesture,\nevidently wishing to give her words a very definite meaning. \xe2\x80\x9cI\nremember Nik\xc3\xb3lenka too, I remember him well,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t remember Bor\xc3\xads. I don\xe2\x80\x99t remember him a bit.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! You don\xe2\x80\x99t remember Bor\xc3\xads?\xe2\x80\x9d asked S\xc3\xb3nya in surprise.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not that I don\xe2\x80\x99t remember\xe2\x80\x94I know what he is like, but not\nas I remember Nik\xc3\xb3lenka. Him\xe2\x80\x94I just shut my eyes and remember,\nbut Bor\xc3\xads... No!\xe2\x80\x9d (She shut her eyes.) \xe2\x80\x9cNo! there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing at\nall.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Nat\xc3\xa1sha!\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya, looking ecstatically and earnestly at\nher friend as if she did not consider her worthy to hear what she meant\nto say and as if she were saying it to someone else, with whom joking\nwas out of the question, \xe2\x80\x9cI am in love with your brother once for all\nand, whatever may happen to him or to me, shall never cease to love him\nas long as I live.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha looked at S\xc3\xb3nya with wondering and inquisitive eyes, and said\nnothing. She felt that S\xc3\xb3nya was speaking the truth, that there was\nsuch love as S\xc3\xb3nya was speaking of. But Nat\xc3\xa1sha had not yet felt\nanything like it. She believed it could be, but did not understand it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall you write to him?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya became thoughtful. The question of how to write to Nicholas, and\nwhether she ought to write, tormented her. Now that he was already an\nofficer and a wounded hero, would it be right to remind him of herself\nand, as it might seem, of the obligations to her he had taken on\nhimself?\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know. I think if he writes, I will write too,\xe2\x80\x9d she said,\nblushing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you won\xe2\x80\x99t feel ashamed to write to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya smiled.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I should be ashamed to write to Bor\xc3\xads. I\xe2\x80\x99m not going to.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should you be ashamed?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. It\xe2\x80\x99s awkward and would make me ashamed.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I know why she\xe2\x80\x99d be ashamed,\xe2\x80\x9d said P\xc3\xa9tya, offended by\nNat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s previous remark. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s because she was in love with\nthat fat one in spectacles\xe2\x80\x9d (that was how P\xc3\xa9tya described his\nnamesake, the new Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov) \xe2\x80\x9cand now she\xe2\x80\x99s in love with that\nsinger\xe2\x80\x9d (he meant Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s Italian singing master), \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s\nwhy she\xe2\x80\x99s ashamed!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cP\xc3\xa9tya, you\xe2\x80\x99re stupid!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot more stupid than you, madam,\xe2\x80\x9d said the nine-year-old P\xc3\xa9tya,\nwith the air of an old brigadier.\n\nThe countess had been prepared by Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna\xe2\x80\x99s hints at dinner.\nOn retiring to her own room, she sat in an armchair, her eyes fixed on a\nminiature portrait of her son on the lid of a snuffbox, while the tears\nkept coming into her eyes. Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, with the letter, came on\ntiptoe to the countess\xe2\x80\x99 door and paused.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t come in,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to the old count who was following her.\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome later.\xe2\x80\x9d And she went in, closing the door behind her.\n\nThe count put his ear to the keyhole and listened.\n\nAt first he heard the sound of indifferent voices, then Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna\xe2\x80\x99s voice alone in a long speech, then a cry, then silence,\nthen both voices together with glad intonations, and then footsteps.\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna opened the door. Her face wore the proud expression\nof a surgeon who has just performed a difficult operation and admits the\npublic to appreciate his skill.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is done!\xe2\x80\x9d she said to the count, pointing triumphantly to the\ncountess, who sat holding in one hand the snuffbox with its portrait and\nin the other the letter, and pressing them alternately to her lips.\n\nWhen she saw the count, she stretched out her arms to him, embraced his\nbald head, over which she again looked at the letter and the portrait,\nand in order to press them again to her lips, she slightly pushed away\nthe bald head. V\xc3\xa9ra, Nat\xc3\xa1sha, S\xc3\xb3nya, and P\xc3\xa9tya now entered the room,\nand the reading of the letter began. After a brief description of\nthe campaign and the two battles in which he had taken part, and his\npromotion, Nicholas said that he kissed his father\xe2\x80\x99s and mother\xe2\x80\x99s\nhands asking for their blessing, and that he kissed V\xc3\xa9ra, Nat\xc3\xa1sha, and\nP\xc3\xa9tya. Besides that, he sent greetings to Monsieur Schelling, Madame\nSchoss, and his old nurse, and asked them to kiss for him \xe2\x80\x9cdear\nS\xc3\xb3nya, whom he loved and thought of just the same as ever.\xe2\x80\x9d When she\nheard this S\xc3\xb3nya blushed so that tears came into her eyes and, unable\nto bear the looks turned upon her, ran away into the dancing hall,\nwhirled round it at full speed with her dress puffed out like a balloon,\nand, flushed and smiling, plumped down on the floor. The countess was\ncrying.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you crying, Mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d asked V\xc3\xa9ra. \xe2\x80\x9cFrom all he says one\nshould be glad and not cry.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThis was quite true, but the count, the countess, and Nat\xc3\xa1sha looked\nat her reproachfully. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd who is it she takes after?\xe2\x80\x9d thought the\ncountess.\n\nNicholas\xe2\x80\x99 letter was read over hundreds of times, and those who were\nconsidered worthy to hear it had to come to the countess, for she\ndid not let it out of her hands. The tutors came, and the nurses, and\nDm\xc3\xadtri, and several acquaintances, and the countess reread the letter\neach time with fresh pleasure and each time discovered in it fresh\nproofs of Nik\xc3\xb3lenka\xe2\x80\x99s virtues. How strange, how extraordinary, how\njoyful it seemed, that her son, the scarcely perceptible motion of whose\ntiny limbs she had felt twenty years ago within her, that son about whom\nshe used to have quarrels with the too indulgent count, that son who\nhad first learned to say \xe2\x80\x9cpear\xe2\x80\x9d and then \xe2\x80\x9cgranny,\xe2\x80\x9d that this son\nshould now be away in a foreign land amid strange surroundings, a manly\nwarrior doing some kind of man\xe2\x80\x99s work of his own, without help or\nguidance. The universal experience of ages, showing that children do\ngrow imperceptibly from the cradle to manhood, did not exist for the\ncountess. Her son\xe2\x80\x99s growth toward manhood, at each of its stages,\nhad seemed as extraordinary to her as if there had never existed the\nmillions of human beings who grew up in the same way. As twenty\nyears before, it seemed impossible that the little creature who lived\nsomewhere under her heart would ever cry, suck her breast, and begin to\nspeak, so now she could not believe that that little creature could be\nthis strong, brave man, this model son and officer that, judging by this\nletter, he now was.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a style! How charmingly he describes!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, reading the\ndescriptive part of the letter. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd what a soul! Not a word about\nhimself.... Not a word! About some Den\xc3\xadsov or other, though he himself,\nI dare say, is braver than any of them. He says nothing about his\nsufferings. What a heart! How like him it is! And how he has remembered\neverybody! Not forgetting anyone. I always said when he was only so\nhigh\xe2\x80\x94I always said....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nFor more than a week preparations were being made, rough drafts of\nletters to Nicholas from all the household were written and copied out,\nwhile under the supervision of the countess and the solicitude of the\ncount, money and all things necessary for the uniform and equipment\nof the newly commissioned officer were collected. Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna,\npractical woman that she was, had even managed by favor with army\nauthorities to secure advantageous means of communication for herself\nand her son. She had opportunities of sending her letters to the Grand\nDuke Constantine P\xc3\xa1vlovich, who commanded the Guards. The Rost\xc3\xb3vs\nsupposed that The Russian Guards, Abroad, was quite a definite address,\nand that if a letter reached the Grand Duke in command of the Guards\nthere was no reason why it should not reach the P\xc3\xa1vlograd regiment,\nwhich was presumably somewhere in the same neighborhood. And so it was\ndecided to send the letters and money by the Grand Duke\xe2\x80\x99s courier to\nBor\xc3\xads and Bor\xc3\xads was to forward them to Nicholas. The letters were from\nthe old count, the countess, P\xc3\xa9tya, V\xc3\xa9ra, Nat\xc3\xa1sha, and S\xc3\xb3nya, and\nfinally there were six thousand rubles for his outfit and various other\nthings the old count sent to his son.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VII\n\nOn the twelfth of November, Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s active army, in camp before\nOlm\xc3\xbctz, was preparing to be reviewed next day by the two Emperors\xe2\x80\x94the\nRussian and the Austrian. The Guards, just arrived from Russia, spent\nthe night ten miles from Olm\xc3\xbctz and next morning were to come straight\nto the review, reaching the field at Olm\xc3\xbctz by ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\n\nThat day Nicholas Rost\xc3\xb3v received a letter from Bor\xc3\xads, telling him\nthat the Ism\xc3\xa1ylov regiment was quartered for the night ten miles from\nOlm\xc3\xbctz and that he wanted to see him as he had a letter and money for\nhim. Rost\xc3\xb3v was particularly in need of money now that the troops,\nafter their active service, were stationed near Olm\xc3\xbctz and the camp\nswarmed with well-provisioned sutlers and Austrian Jews offering\nall sorts of tempting wares. The P\xc3\xa1vlograds held feast after feast,\ncelebrating awards they had received for the campaign, and made\nexpeditions to Olm\xc3\xbctz to visit a certain Caroline the Hungarian,\nwho had recently opened a restaurant there with girls as waitresses.\nRost\xc3\xb3v, who had just celebrated his promotion to a cornetcy and bought\nDen\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s horse, Bedouin, was in debt all round, to his comrades and\nthe sutlers. On receiving Bor\xc3\xads\xe2\x80\x99 letter he rode with a fellow officer\nto Olm\xc3\xbctz, dined there, drank a bottle of wine, and then set off alone\nto the Guards\xe2\x80\x99 camp to find his old playmate. Rost\xc3\xb3v had not yet had\ntime to get his uniform. He had on a shabby cadet jacket, decorated with\na soldier\xe2\x80\x99s cross, equally shabby cadet\xe2\x80\x99s riding breeches lined with\nworn leather, and an officer\xe2\x80\x99s saber with a sword knot. The Don horse\nhe was riding was one he had bought from a Cossack during the campaign,\nand he wore a crumpled hussar cap stuck jauntily back on one side of his\nhead. As he rode up to the camp he thought how he would impress Bor\xc3\xads\nand all his comrades of the Guards by his appearance\xe2\x80\x94that of a\nfighting hussar who had been under fire.\n\nThe Guards had made their whole march as if on a pleasure trip, parading\ntheir cleanliness and discipline. They had come by easy stages, their\nknapsacks conveyed on carts, and the Austrian authorities had provided\nexcellent dinners for the officers at every halting place. The regiments\nhad entered and left the town with their bands playing, and by the Grand\nDuke\xe2\x80\x99s orders the men had marched all the way in step (a practice on\nwhich the Guards prided themselves), the officers on foot and at their\nproper posts. Bor\xc3\xads had been quartered, and had marched all the\nway, with Berg who was already in command of a company. Berg, who had\nobtained his captaincy during the campaign, had gained the confidence of\nhis superiors by his promptitude and accuracy and had arranged his money\nmatters very satisfactorily. Bor\xc3\xads, during the campaign, had made the\nacquaintance of many persons who might prove useful to him, and by\na letter of recommendation he had brought from Pierre had become\nacquainted with Prince Andrew Bolk\xc3\xb3nski, through whom he hoped to\nobtain a post on the commander in chief\xe2\x80\x99s staff. Berg and Bor\xc3\xads,\nhaving rested after yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s march, were sitting, clean and neatly\ndressed, at a round table in the clean quarters allotted to them,\nplaying chess. Berg held a smoking pipe between his knees. Bor\xc3\xads, in\nthe accurate way characteristic of him, was building a little pyramid of\nchessmen with his delicate white fingers while awaiting Berg\xe2\x80\x99s move,\nand watched his opponent\xe2\x80\x99s face, evidently thinking about the game as\nhe always thought only of whatever he was engaged on.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, how are you going to get out of that?\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll try to,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Berg, touching a pawn and then removing\nhis hand.\n\nAt that moment the door opened.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere he is at last!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Rost\xc3\xb3v. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd Berg too! Oh, you\npetisenfans, allay cushay dormir!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, imitating his Russian\nnurse\xe2\x80\x99s French, at which he and Bor\xc3\xads used to laugh long ago.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me, how you have changed!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBor\xc3\xads rose to meet Rost\xc3\xb3v, but in doing so did not omit to steady and\nreplace some chessmen that were falling. He was about to embrace his\nfriend, but Nicholas avoided him. With that peculiar feeling of youth,\nthat dread of beaten tracks, and wish to express itself in a manner\ndifferent from that of its elders which is often insincere, Nicholas\nwished to do something special on meeting his friend. He wanted to pinch\nhim, push him, do anything but kiss him\xe2\x80\x94a thing everybody did. But\nnotwithstanding this, Bor\xc3\xads embraced him in a quiet, friendly way and\nkissed him three times.\n\nThey had not met for nearly half a year and, being at the age when young\nmen take their first steps on life\xe2\x80\x99s road, each saw immense changes in\nthe other, quite a new reflection of the society in which they had taken\nthose first steps. Both had changed greatly since they last met and both\nwere in a hurry to show the changes that had taken place in them.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you damned dandies! Clean and fresh as if you\xe2\x80\x99d been to a fete,\nnot like us sinners of the line,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Rost\xc3\xb3v, with martial swagger\nand with baritone notes in his voice, new to Bor\xc3\xads, pointing to his own\nmud-bespattered breeches. The German landlady, hearing Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s loud\nvoice, popped her head in at the door.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, is she pretty?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked with a wink.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you shout so? You\xe2\x80\x99ll frighten them!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bor\xc3\xads. \xe2\x80\x9cI did\nnot expect you today,\xe2\x80\x9d he added. \xe2\x80\x9cI only sent you the note yesterday\nby Bolk\xc3\xb3nski\xe2\x80\x94an adjutant of Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s, who\xe2\x80\x99s a friend of mine.\nI did not think he would get it to you so quickly.... Well, how are you?\nBeen under fire already?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Bor\xc3\xads.\n\nWithout answering, Rost\xc3\xb3v shook the soldier\xe2\x80\x99s Cross of St. George\nfastened to the cording of his uniform and, indicating a bandaged arm,\nglanced at Berg with a smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs you see,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed? Yes, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bor\xc3\xads, with a smile. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd we too have\nhad a splendid march. You know, of course, that His Imperial Highness\nrode with our regiment all the time, so that we had every comfort and\nevery advantage. What receptions we had in Poland! What dinners and\nballs! I can\xe2\x80\x99t tell you. And the Tsar\xc3\xa9vich was very gracious to all\nour officers.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd the two friends told each other of their doings, the one of his\nhussar revels and life in the fighting line, the other of the pleasures\nand advantages of service under members of the Imperial family.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you Guards!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v. \xe2\x80\x9cI say, send for some wine.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBor\xc3\xads made a grimace.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you really want it,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\nHe went to his bed, drew a purse from under the clean pillow, and sent\nfor wine.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and I have some money and a letter to give you,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v took the letter and, throwing the money on the sofa, put both\narms on the table and began to read. After reading a few lines, he\nglanced angrily at Berg, then, meeting his eyes, hid his face behind the\nletter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, they\xe2\x80\x99ve sent you a tidy sum,\xe2\x80\x9d said Berg, eying the heavy\npurse that sank into the sofa. \xe2\x80\x9cAs for us, Count, we get along on our\npay. I can tell you for myself...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, Berg, my dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen you get a\nletter from home and meet one of your own people whom you want to talk\neverything over with, and I happen to be there, I\xe2\x80\x99ll go at once, to\nbe out of your way! Do go somewhere, anywhere... to the devil!\xe2\x80\x9d he\nexclaimed, and immediately seizing him by the shoulder and looking\namiably into his face, evidently wishing to soften the rudeness of his\nwords, he added, \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be hurt, my dear fellow; you know I speak\nfrom my heart as to an old acquaintance.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, don\xe2\x80\x99t mention it, Count! I quite understand,\xe2\x80\x9d said Berg,\ngetting up and speaking in a muffled and guttural voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo across to our hosts: they invited you,\xe2\x80\x9d added Bor\xc3\xads.\n\nBerg put on the cleanest of coats, without a spot or speck of dust,\nstood before a looking glass and brushed the hair on his temples\nupwards, in the way affected by the Emperor Alexander, and, having\nassured himself from the way Rost\xc3\xb3v looked at it that his coat had been\nnoticed, left the room with a pleasant smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh dear, what a beast I am!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Rost\xc3\xb3v, as he read the\nletter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, what a pig I am, not to have written and to have given them\nsuch a fright! Oh, what a pig I am!\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, flushing suddenly.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, have you sent Gabriel for some wine? All right let\xe2\x80\x99s have\nsome!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIn the letter from his parents was enclosed a letter of recommendation\nto Bagrati\xc3\xb3n which the old countess at Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna\xe2\x80\x99s advice had\nobtained through an acquaintance and sent to her son, asking him to take\nit to its destination and make use of it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat nonsense! Much I need it!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v, throwing the letter\nunder the table.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy have you thrown that away?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Bor\xc3\xads.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is some letter of recommendation... what the devil do I want it\nfor!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy \xe2\x80\x98What the devil\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d said Bor\xc3\xads, picking it up and reading\nthe address. \xe2\x80\x9cThis letter would be of great use to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want nothing, and I won\xe2\x80\x99t be anyone\xe2\x80\x99s adjutant.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Bor\xc3\xads.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a lackey\xe2\x80\x99s job!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are still the same dreamer, I see,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Bor\xc3\xads, shaking\nhis head.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you\xe2\x80\x99re still the same diplomatist! But that\xe2\x80\x99s not the\npoint... Come, how are you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, as you see. So far everything\xe2\x80\x99s all right, but I confess I\nshould much like to be an adjutant and not remain at the front.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause when once a man starts on military service, he should try to\nmake as successful a career of it as possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that\xe2\x80\x99s it!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v, evidently thinking of something\nelse.\n\nHe looked intently and inquiringly into his friend\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, evidently\ntrying in vain to find the answer to some question.\n\nOld Gabriel brought in the wine.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShouldn\xe2\x80\x99t we now send for Berg?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Bor\xc3\xads. \xe2\x80\x9cHe would drink\nwith you. I can\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, send for him... and how do you get on with that German?\xe2\x80\x9d\nasked Rost\xc3\xb3v, with a contemptuous smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a very, very nice, honest, and pleasant fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d answered\nBor\xc3\xads.\n\nAgain Rost\xc3\xb3v looked intently into Bor\xc3\xads\xe2\x80\x99 eyes and sighed. Berg\nreturned, and over the bottle of wine conversation between the three\nofficers became animated. The Guardsmen told Rost\xc3\xb3v of their march and\nhow they had been made much of in Russia, Poland, and abroad. They spoke\nof the sayings and doings of their commander, the Grand Duke, and told\nstories of his kindness and irascibility. Berg, as usual, kept silent\nwhen the subject did not relate to himself, but in connection with the\nstories of the Grand Duke\xe2\x80\x99s quick temper he related with gusto how in\nGalicia he had managed to deal with the Grand Duke when the latter\nmade a tour of the regiments and was annoyed at the irregularity of\na movement. With a pleasant smile Berg related how the Grand Duke\nhad ridden up to him in a violent passion, shouting: \xe2\x80\x9cArnauts!\xe2\x80\x9d\n(\xe2\x80\x9cArnauts\xe2\x80\x9d was the Tsar\xc3\xa9vich\xe2\x80\x99s favorite expression when he was in\na rage) and called for the company commander.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you believe it, Count, I was not at all alarmed, because I knew\nI was right. Without boasting, you know, I may say that I know the Army\nOrders by heart and know the Regulations as well as I do the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s\nPrayer. So, Count, there never is any negligence in my company, and\nso my conscience was at ease. I came forward....\xe2\x80\x9d (Berg stood up and\nshowed how he presented himself, with his hand to his cap, and really\nit would have been difficult for a face to express greater respect and\nself-complacency than his did.) \xe2\x80\x9cWell, he stormed at me, as the saying\nis, stormed and stormed and stormed! It was not a matter of life but\nrather of death, as the saying is. \xe2\x80\x98Albanians!\xe2\x80\x99 and \xe2\x80\x98devils!\xe2\x80\x99\nand \xe2\x80\x98To Siberia!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said Berg with a sagacious smile. \xe2\x80\x9cI knew I\nwas in the right so I kept silent; was not that best, Count?... \xe2\x80\x98Hey,\nare you dumb?\xe2\x80\x99 he shouted. Still I remained silent. And what do you\nthink, Count? The next day it was not even mentioned in the Orders of\nthe Day. That\xe2\x80\x99s what keeping one\xe2\x80\x99s head means. That\xe2\x80\x99s the way,\nCount,\xe2\x80\x9d said Berg, lighting his pipe and emitting rings of smoke.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that was fine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v, smiling.\n\nBut Bor\xc3\xads noticed that he was preparing to make fun of Berg, and\nskillfully changed the subject. He asked him to tell them how and where\nhe got his wound. This pleased Rost\xc3\xb3v and he began talking about it,\nand as he went on became more and more animated. He told them of his\nSch\xc3\xb6n Grabern affair, just as those who have taken part in a battle\ngenerally do describe it, that is, as they would like it to have been,\nas they have heard it described by others, and as sounds well, but not\nat all as it really was. Rost\xc3\xb3v was a truthful young man and would on\nno account have told a deliberate lie. He began his story meaning to\ntell everything just as it happened, but imperceptibly, involuntarily,\nand inevitably he lapsed into falsehood. If he had told the truth to his\nhearers\xe2\x80\x94who like himself had often heard stories of attacks and had\nformed a definite idea of what an attack was and were expecting to hear\njust such a story\xe2\x80\x94they would either not have believed him or, still\nworse, would have thought that Rost\xc3\xb3v was himself to blame since what\ngenerally happens to the narrators of cavalry attacks had not happened\nto him. He could not tell them simply that everyone went at a trot and\nthat he fell off his horse and sprained his arm and then ran as hard as\nhe could from a Frenchman into the wood. Besides, to tell everything as\nit really happened, it would have been necessary to make an effort of\nwill to tell only what happened. It is very difficult to tell the truth,\nand young people are rarely capable of it. His hearers expected a story\nof how beside himself and all aflame with excitement, he had flown like\na storm at the square, cut his way in, slashed right and left, how his\nsaber had tasted flesh and he had fallen exhausted, and so on. And so he\ntold them all that.\n\nIn the middle of his story, just as he was saying: \xe2\x80\x9cYou cannot imagine\nwhat a strange frenzy one experiences during an attack,\xe2\x80\x9d Prince\nAndrew, whom Bor\xc3\xads was expecting, entered the room. Prince Andrew, who\nliked to help young men, was flattered by being asked for his assistance\nand being well disposed toward Bor\xc3\xads, who had managed to please him the\nday before, he wished to do what the young man wanted. Having been sent\nwith papers from Kut\xc3\xbazov to the Tsar\xc3\xa9vich, he looked in on Bor\xc3\xads,\nhoping to find him alone. When he came in and saw an hussar of the line\nrecounting his military exploits (Prince Andrew could not endure\nthat sort of man), he gave Bor\xc3\xads a pleasant smile, frowned as with\nhalf-closed eyes he looked at Rost\xc3\xb3v, bowed slightly and wearily, and\nsat down languidly on the sofa: he felt it unpleasant to have dropped\nin on bad company. Rost\xc3\xb3v flushed up on noticing this, but he did not\ncare, this was a mere stranger.
