Glancing, however, at Bor\xc3\xads, he saw\nthat he too seemed ashamed of the hussar of the line.\n\nIn spite of Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s disagreeable, ironical tone, in spite of\nthe contempt with which Rost\xc3\xb3v, from his fighting army point of view,\nregarded all these little adjutants on the staff of whom the newcomer\nwas evidently one, Rost\xc3\xb3v felt confused, blushed, and became silent.\nBor\xc3\xads inquired what news there might be on the staff, and what, without\nindiscretion, one might ask about our plans.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall probably advance,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bolk\xc3\xb3nski, evidently reluctant\nto say more in the presence of a stranger.\n\nBerg took the opportunity to ask, with great politeness, whether, as was\nrumored, the allowance of forage money to captains of companies would be\ndoubled. To this Prince Andrew answered with a smile that he could\ngive no opinion on such an important government order, and Berg laughed\ngaily.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs to your business,\xe2\x80\x9d Prince Andrew continued, addressing Bor\xc3\xads,\n\xe2\x80\x9cwe will talk of it later\xe2\x80\x9d (and he looked round at Rost\xc3\xb3v). \xe2\x80\x9cCome\nto me after the review and we will do what is possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd, having glanced round the room, Prince Andrew turned to Rost\xc3\xb3v,\nwhose state of unconquerable childish embarrassment now changing to\nanger he did not condescend to notice, and said: \xe2\x80\x9cI think you were\ntalking of the Sch\xc3\xb6n Grabern affair? Were you there?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was there,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v angrily, as if intending to insult the\naide-de-camp.\n\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski noticed the hussar\xe2\x80\x99s state of mind, and it amused him. With\na slightly contemptuous smile, he said: \xe2\x80\x9cYes, there are many stories\nnow told about that affair!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, stories!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Rost\xc3\xb3v loudly, looking with eyes suddenly\ngrown furious, now at Bor\xc3\xads, now at Bolk\xc3\xb3nski. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, many stories!\nBut our stories are the stories of men who have been under the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s\nfire! Our stories have some weight, not like the stories of those\nfellows on the staff who get rewards without doing anything!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf whom you imagine me to be one?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew, with a quiet\nand particularly amiable smile.\n\nA strange feeling of exasperation and yet of respect for this man\xe2\x80\x99s\nself-possession mingled at that moment in Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s soul.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not talking about you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know you and,\nfrankly, I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to. I am speaking of the staff in general.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I will tell you this,\xe2\x80\x9d Prince Andrew interrupted in a tone of\nquiet authority, \xe2\x80\x9cyou wish to insult me, and I am ready to agree with\nyou that it would be very easy to do so if you haven\xe2\x80\x99t sufficient\nself-respect, but admit that the time and place are very badly chosen.\nIn a day or two we shall all have to take part in a greater and more\nserious duel, and besides, Drubetsk\xc3\xb3y, who says he is an old friend\nof yours, is not at all to blame that my face has the misfortune to\ndisplease you. However,\xe2\x80\x9d he added rising, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know my name and\nwhere to find me, but don\xe2\x80\x99t forget that I do not regard either myself\nor you as having been at all insulted, and as a man older than you, my\nadvice is to let the matter drop. Well then, on Friday after the review\nI shall expect you, Drubetsk\xc3\xb3y. Au revoir!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Prince Andrew,\nand with a bow to them both he went out.\n\nOnly when Prince Andrew was gone did Rost\xc3\xb3v think of what he ought to\nhave said. And he was still more angry at having omitted to say it. He\nordered his horse at once and, coldly taking leave of Bor\xc3\xads, rode\nhome. Should he go to headquarters next day and challenge that affected\nadjutant, or really let the matter drop, was the question that worried\nhim all the way. He thought angrily of the pleasure he would have at\nseeing the fright of that small and frail but proud man when covered by\nhis pistol, and then he felt with surprise that of all the men he knew\nthere was none he would so much like to have for a friend as that very\nadjutant whom he so hated.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VIII\n\nThe day after Rost\xc3\xb3v had been to see Bor\xc3\xads, a review was held of the\nAustrian and Russian troops, both those freshly arrived from Russia and\nthose who had been campaigning under Kut\xc3\xbazov. The two Emperors,\nthe Russian with his heir the Tsar\xc3\xa9vich, and the Austrian with the\nArchduke, inspected the allied army of eighty thousand men.\n\nFrom early morning the smart clean troops were on the move, forming up\non the field before the fortress. Now thousands of feet and bayonets\nmoved and halted at the officers\xe2\x80\x99 command, turned with banners flying,\nformed up at intervals, and wheeled round other similar masses of\ninfantry in different uniforms; now was heard the rhythmic beat of\nhoofs and the jingling of showy cavalry in blue, red, and green braided\nuniforms, with smartly dressed bandsmen in front mounted on black, roan,\nor gray horses; then again, spreading out with the brazen clatter of the\npolished shining cannon that quivered on the gun carriages and with\nthe smell of linstocks, came the artillery which crawled between the\ninfantry and cavalry and took up its appointed position. Not only the\ngenerals in full parade uniforms, with their thin or thick waists drawn\nin to the utmost, their red necks squeezed into their stiff collars, and\nwearing scarves and all their decorations, not only the elegant, pomaded\nofficers, but every soldier with his freshly washed and shaven face and\nhis weapons clean and polished to the utmost, and every horse groomed\ntill its coat shone like satin and every hair of its wetted mane lay\nsmooth\xe2\x80\x94felt that no small matter was happening, but an important and\nsolemn affair. Every general and every soldier was conscious of his own\ninsignificance, aware of being but a drop in that ocean of men, and\nyet at the same time was conscious of his strength as a part of that\nenormous whole.\n\nFrom early morning strenuous activities and efforts had begun and by ten\no\xe2\x80\x99clock all had been brought into due order. The ranks were drawn\nup on the vast field. The whole army was extended in three lines: the\ncavalry in front, behind it the artillery, and behind that again the\ninfantry.\n\nA space like a street was left between each two lines of troops. The\nthree parts of that army were sharply distinguished: Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s\nfighting army (with the P\xc3\xa1vlograds on the right flank of the front);\nthose recently arrived from Russia, both Guards and regiments of the\nline; and the Austrian troops. But they all stood in the same lines,\nunder one command, and in a like order.\n\nLike wind over leaves ran an excited whisper: \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re coming!\nThey\xe2\x80\x99re coming!\xe2\x80\x9d Alarmed voices were heard, and a stir of final\npreparation swept over all the troops.\n\nFrom the direction of Olm\xc3\xbctz in front of them, a group was seen\napproaching. And at that moment, though the day was still, a light gust\nof wind blowing over the army slightly stirred the streamers on the\nlances and the unfolded standards fluttered against their staffs. It\nlooked as if by that slight motion the army itself was expressing its\njoy at the approach of the Emperors. One voice was heard shouting:\n\xe2\x80\x9cEyes front!\xe2\x80\x9d Then, like the crowing of cocks at sunrise, this was\nrepeated by others from various sides and all became silent.\n\nIn the deathlike stillness only the tramp of horses was heard. This\nwas the Emperors\xe2\x80\x99 suites. The Emperors rode up to the flank, and the\ntrumpets of the first cavalry regiment played the general march. It\nseemed as though not the trumpeters were playing, but as if the army\nitself, rejoicing at the Emperors\xe2\x80\x99 approach, had naturally burst into\nmusic. Amid these sounds, only the youthful kindly voice of the Emperor\nAlexander was clearly heard. He gave the words of greeting, and the\nfirst regiment roared \xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d so deafeningly, continuously, and\njoyfully that the men themselves were awed by their multitude and the\nimmensity of the power they constituted.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v, standing in the front lines of Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s army which the Tsar\napproached first, experienced the same feeling as every other man in\nthat army: a feeling of self-forgetfulness, a proud consciousness of\nmight, and a passionate attraction to him who was the cause of this\ntriumph.\n\nHe felt that at a single word from that man all this vast mass (and he\nhimself an insignificant atom in it) would go through fire and water,\ncommit crime, die, or perform deeds of highest heroism, and so he could\nnot but tremble and his heart stand still at the imminence of that word.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah! Hurrah! Hurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d thundered from all sides, one regiment\nafter another greeting the Tsar with the strains of the march, and then\n\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d... Then the general march, and again \xe2\x80\x9cHurrah! Hurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d\ngrowing ever stronger and fuller and merging into a deafening roar.\n\nTill the Tsar reached it, each regiment in its silence and immobility\nseemed like a lifeless body, but as soon as he came up it became alive,\nits thunder joining the roar of the whole line along which he had\nalready passed. Through the terrible and deafening roar of those voices,\namid the square masses of troops standing motionless as if turned to\nstone, hundreds of riders composing the suites moved carelessly but\nsymmetrically and above all freely, and in front of them two men\xe2\x80\x94the\nEmperors. Upon them the undivided, tensely passionate attention of that\nwhole mass of men was concentrated.\n\nThe handsome young Emperor Alexander, in the uniform of the Horse\nGuards, wearing a cocked hat with its peaks front and back, with his\npleasant face and resonant though not loud voice, attracted everyone\xe2\x80\x99s\nattention.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v was not far from the trumpeters, and with his keen sight had\nrecognized the Tsar and watched his approach. When he was within twenty\npaces, and Nicholas could clearly distinguish every detail of his\nhandsome, happy young face, he experienced a feeling of tenderness\nand ecstasy such as he had never before known. Every trait and every\nmovement of the Tsar\xe2\x80\x99s seemed to him enchanting.\n\nStopping in front of the P\xc3\xa1vlograds, the Tsar said something in French\nto the Austrian Emperor and smiled.\n\nSeeing that smile, Rost\xc3\xb3v involuntarily smiled himself and felt a still\nstronger flow of love for his sovereign. He longed to show that love in\nsome way and knowing that this was impossible was ready to cry. The Tsar\ncalled the colonel of the regiment and said a few words to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh God, what would happen to me if the Emperor spoke to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\nthought Rost\xc3\xb3v. \xe2\x80\x9cI should die of happiness!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe Tsar addressed the officers also: \xe2\x80\x9cI thank you all, gentlemen, I\nthank you with my whole heart.\xe2\x80\x9d To Rost\xc3\xb3v every word sounded like a\nvoice from heaven. How gladly would he have died at once for his Tsar!\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have earned the St. George\xe2\x80\x99s standards and will be worthy of\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, to die, to die for him,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\nThe Tsar said something more which Rost\xc3\xb3v did not hear, and the\nsoldiers, straining their lungs, shouted \xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v too, bending over his saddle, shouted \xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d with all his\nmight, feeling that he would like to injure himself by that shout, if\nonly to express his rapture fully.\n\nThe Tsar stopped a few minutes in front of the hussars as if undecided.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can the Emperor be undecided?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Rost\xc3\xb3v, but then even\nthis indecision appeared to him majestic and enchanting, like everything\nelse the Tsar did.\n\nThat hesitation lasted only an instant. The Tsar\xe2\x80\x99s foot, in the narrow\npointed boot then fashionable, touched the groin of the bobtailed bay\nmare he rode, his hand in a white glove gathered up the reins, and he\nmoved off accompanied by an irregularly swaying sea of aides-de-camp.\nFarther and farther he rode away, stopping at other regiments, till at\nlast only his white plumes were visible to Rost\xc3\xb3v from amid the suites\nthat surrounded the Emperors.\n\nAmong the gentlemen of the suite, Rost\xc3\xb3v noticed Bolk\xc3\xb3nski, sitting\nhis horse indolently and carelessly. Rost\xc3\xb3v recalled their quarrel of\nyesterday and the question presented itself whether he ought or ought\nnot to challenge Bolk\xc3\xb3nski. \xe2\x80\x9cOf course not!\xe2\x80\x9d he now thought. \xe2\x80\x9cIs\nit worth thinking or speaking of it at such a moment? At a time of such\nlove, such rapture, and such self-sacrifice, what do any of our quarrels\nand affronts matter? I love and forgive everybody now.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nWhen the Emperor had passed nearly all the regiments, the troops began\na ceremonial march past him, and Rost\xc3\xb3v on Bedouin, recently purchased\nfrom Den\xc3\xadsov, rode past too, at the rear of his squadron\xe2\x80\x94that is,\nalone and in full view of the Emperor.\n\nBefore he reached him, Rost\xc3\xb3v, who was a splendid horseman, spurred\nBedouin twice and successfully put him to the showy trot in which the\nanimal went when excited. Bending his foaming muzzle to his chest, his\ntail extended, Bedouin, as if also conscious of the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s eye\nupon him, passed splendidly, lifting his feet with a high and graceful\naction, as if flying through the air without touching the ground.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v himself, his legs well back and his stomach drawn in and feeling\nhimself one with his horse, rode past the Emperor with a frowning but\nblissful face \xe2\x80\x9clike a vewy devil,\xe2\x80\x9d as Den\xc3\xadsov expressed it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFine fellows, the P\xc3\xa1vlograds!\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the Emperor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy God, how happy I should be if he ordered me to leap into the fire\nthis instant!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\nWhen the review was over, the newly arrived officers, and also\nKut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s, collected in groups and began to talk about the awards,\nabout the Austrians and their uniforms, about their lines, about\nBonaparte, and how badly the latter would fare now, especially if the\nEssen corps arrived and Prussia took our side.\n\nBut the talk in every group was chiefly about the Emperor Alexander. His\nevery word and movement was described with ecstasy.\n\nThey all had but one wish: to advance as soon as possible against the\nenemy under the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s command. Commanded by the Emperor himself\nthey could not fail to vanquish anyone, be it whom it might: so thought\nRost\xc3\xb3v and most of the officers after the review.\n\nAll were then more confident of victory than the winning of two battles\nwould have made them.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IX\n\nThe day after the review, Bor\xc3\xads, in his best uniform and with his\ncomrade Berg\xe2\x80\x99s best wishes for success, rode to Olm\xc3\xbctz to see\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski, wishing to profit by his friendliness and obtain for himself\nthe best post he could\xe2\x80\x94preferably that of adjutant to some important\npersonage, a position in the army which seemed to him most attractive.\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is all very well for Rost\xc3\xb3v, whose father sends him ten thousand\nrubles at a time, to talk about not wishing to cringe to anybody and not\nbe anyone\xe2\x80\x99s lackey, but I who have nothing but my brains have to\nmake a career and must not miss opportunities, but must avail myself of\nthem!\xe2\x80\x9d he reflected.\n\nHe did not find Prince Andrew in Olm\xc3\xbctz that day, but the appearance of\nthe town where the headquarters and the diplomatic corps were stationed\nand the two Emperors were living with their suites, households, and\ncourts only strengthened his desire to belong to that higher world.\n\nHe knew no one, and despite his smart Guardsman\xe2\x80\x99s uniform, all these\nexalted personages passing in the streets in their elegant carriages\nwith their plumes, ribbons, and medals, both courtiers and military\nmen, seemed so immeasurably above him, an insignificant officer of the\nGuards, that they not only did not wish to, but simply could not, be\naware of his existence. At the quarters of the commander in chief,\nKut\xc3\xbazov, where he inquired for Bolk\xc3\xb3nski, all the adjutants and even\nthe orderlies looked at him as if they wished to impress on him that a\ngreat many officers like him were always coming there and that everybody\nwas heartily sick of them. In spite of this, or rather because of\nit, next day, November 15, after dinner he again went to Olm\xc3\xbctz and,\nentering the house occupied by Kut\xc3\xbazov, asked for Bolk\xc3\xb3nski. Prince\nAndrew was in and Bor\xc3\xads was shown into a large hall probably formerly\nused for dancing, but in which five beds now stood, and furniture of\nvarious kinds: a table, chairs, and a clavichord. One adjutant, nearest\nthe door, was sitting at the table in a Persian dressing gown, writing.\nAnother, the red, stout Nesv\xc3\xadtski, lay on a bed with his arms under his\nhead, laughing with an officer who had sat down beside him. A third was\nplaying a Viennese waltz on the clavichord, while a fourth, lying on\nthe clavichord, sang the tune. Bolk\xc3\xb3nski was not there. None of these\ngentlemen changed his position on seeing Bor\xc3\xads. The one who was writing\nand whom Bor\xc3\xads addressed turned round crossly and told him Bolk\xc3\xb3nski\nwas on duty and that he should go through the door on the left into the\nreception room if he wished to see him. Bor\xc3\xads thanked him and went to\nthe reception room, where he found some ten officers and generals.\n\nWhen he entered, Prince Andrew, his eyes drooping contemptuously (with\nthat peculiar expression of polite weariness which plainly says, \xe2\x80\x9cIf\nit were not my duty I would not talk to you for a moment\xe2\x80\x9d), was\nlistening to an old Russian general with decorations, who stood very\nerect, almost on tiptoe, with a soldier\xe2\x80\x99s obsequious expression on his\npurple face, reporting something.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, then, be so good as to wait,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew to the\ngeneral, in Russian, speaking with the French intonation he affected\nwhen he wished to speak contemptuously, and noticing Bor\xc3\xads, Prince\nAndrew, paying no more heed to the general who ran after him imploring\nhim to hear something more, nodded and turned to him with a cheerful\nsmile.\n\nAt that moment Bor\xc3\xads clearly realized what he had before surmised, that\nin the army, besides the subordination and discipline prescribed in the\nmilitary code, which he and the others knew in the regiment, there was\nanother, more important, subordination, which made this tight-laced,\npurple-faced general wait respectfully while Captain Prince Andrew, for\nhis own pleasure, chose to chat with Lieutenant Drubetsk\xc3\xb3y. More than\never was Bor\xc3\xads resolved to serve in future not according to the written\ncode, but under this unwritten law. He felt now that merely by having\nbeen recommended to Prince Andrew he had already risen above the general\nwho at the front had the power to annihilate him, a lieutenant of the\nGuards. Prince Andrew came up to him and took his hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very sorry you did not find me in yesterday. I was fussing about\nwith Germans all day. We went with Weyrother to survey the dispositions.\nWhen Germans start being accurate, there\xe2\x80\x99s no end to it!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBor\xc3\xads smiled, as if he understood what Prince Andrew was alluding to\nas something generally known. But it was the first time he had heard\nWeyrother\xe2\x80\x99s name, or even the term \xe2\x80\x9cdispositions.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear fellow, so you still want to be an adjutant? I have\nbeen thinking about you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I was thinking\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94for some reason Bor\xc3\xads could not help\nblushing\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cof asking the commander in chief. He has had a letter from\nPrince Kur\xc3\xa1gin about me. I only wanted to ask because I fear the Guards\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t be in action,\xe2\x80\x9d he added as if in apology.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, all right. We\xe2\x80\x99ll talk it over,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Prince Andrew.\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly let me report this gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s business, and I shall be at\nyour disposal.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nWhile Prince Andrew went to report about the purple-faced general, that\ngentleman\xe2\x80\x94evidently not sharing Bor\xc3\xads\xe2\x80\x99 conception of the advantages\nof the unwritten code of subordination\xe2\x80\x94looked so fixedly at the\npresumptuous lieutenant who had prevented his finishing what he had to\nsay to the adjutant that Bor\xc3\xads felt uncomfortable. He turned away and\nwaited impatiently for Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s return from the commander in\nchief\xe2\x80\x99s room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, my dear fellow, I have been thinking about you,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid Prince Andrew when they had gone into the large room where the\nclavichord was. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s no use your going to the commander in chief.\nHe would say a lot of pleasant things, ask you to dinner\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cThat\nwould not be bad as regards the unwritten code,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Bor\xc3\xads),\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut nothing more would come of it. There will soon be a battalion of\nus aides-de-camp and adjutants! But this is what we\xe2\x80\x99ll do: I have\na good friend, an adjutant general and an excellent fellow, Prince\nDolgor\xc3\xbakov; and though you may not know it, the fact is that now\nKut\xc3\xbazov with his staff and all of us count for nothing. Everything is\nnow centered round the Emperor. So we will go to Dolgor\xc3\xbakov; I have to\ngo there anyhow and I have already spoken to him about you. We shall\nsee whether he cannot attach you to himself or find a place for you\nsomewhere nearer the sun.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew always became specially keen when he had to guide a young\nman and help him to worldly success. Under cover of obtaining help\nof this kind for another, which from pride he would never accept for\nhimself, he kept in touch with the circle which confers success and\nwhich attracted him. He very readily took up Bor\xc3\xads\xe2\x80\x99 cause and went\nwith him to Dolgor\xc3\xbakov.\n\nIt was late in the evening when they entered the palace at Olm\xc3\xbctz\noccupied by the Emperors and their retinues.\n\nThat same day a council of war had been held in which all the members of\nthe Hofkriegsrath and both Emperors took part. At that council, contrary\nto the views of the old generals Kut\xc3\xbazov and Prince Schwartzenberg, it\nhad been decided to advance immediately and give battle to Bonaparte.\nThe council of war was just over when Prince Andrew accompanied\nby Bor\xc3\xads arrived at the palace to find Dolgor\xc3\xbakov. Everyone at\nheadquarters was still under the spell of the day\xe2\x80\x99s council, at which\nthe party of the young had triumphed. The voices of those who counseled\ndelay and advised waiting for something else before advancing had been\nso completely silenced and their arguments confuted by such conclusive\nevidence of the advantages of attacking that what had been discussed\nat the council\xe2\x80\x94the coming battle and the victory that would certainly\nresult from it\xe2\x80\x94no longer seemed to be in the future but in the past.\nAll the advantages were on our side. Our enormous forces, undoubtedly\nsuperior to Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s, were concentrated in one place, the troops\ninspired by the Emperors\xe2\x80\x99 presence were eager for action. The\nstrategic position where the operations would take place was familiar in\nall its details to the Austrian General Weyrother: a lucky accident had\nordained that the Austrian army should maneuver the previous year on the\nvery fields where the French had now to be fought; the adjacent\nlocality was known and shown in every detail on the maps, and Bonaparte,\nevidently weakened, was undertaking nothing.\n\nDolgor\xc3\xbakov, one of the warmest advocates of an attack, had just\nreturned from the council, tired and exhausted but eager and proud\nof the victory that had been gained. Prince Andrew introduced his\nprot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9, but Prince Dolgor\xc3\xbakov politely and firmly pressing his hand\nsaid nothing to Bor\xc3\xads and, evidently unable to suppress the thoughts\nwhich were uppermost in his mind at that moment, addressed Prince Andrew\nin French.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear fellow, what a battle we have gained! God grant that\nthe one that will result from it will be as victorious! However, dear\nfellow,\xe2\x80\x9d he said abruptly and eagerly, \xe2\x80\x9cI must confess to having\nbeen unjust to the Austrians and especially to Weyrother. What\nexactitude, what minuteness, what knowledge of the locality, what\nforesight for every eventuality, every possibility even to the smallest\ndetail! No, my dear fellow, no conditions better than our present ones\ncould have been devised. This combination of Austrian precision with\nRussian valor\xe2\x80\x94what more could be wished for?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo the attack is definitely resolved on?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Bolk\xc3\xb3nski.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you know, my dear fellow, it seems to me that Bonaparte has\ndecidedly lost bearings, you know that a letter was received from him\ntoday for the Emperor.\xe2\x80\x9d Dolgor\xc3\xbakov smiled significantly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that so? And what did he say?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Bolk\xc3\xb3nski.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can he say? Tra-di-ri-di-ra and so on... merely to gain time.\nI tell you he is in our hands, that\xe2\x80\x99s certain! But what was most\namusing,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, with a sudden, good-natured laugh, \xe2\x80\x9cwas that\nwe could not think how to address the reply! If not as \xe2\x80\x98Consul\xe2\x80\x99\nand of course not as \xe2\x80\x98Emperor,\xe2\x80\x99 it seemed to me it should be to\n\xe2\x80\x98General Bonaparte.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut between not recognizing him as Emperor and calling him General\nBonaparte, there is a difference,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Bolk\xc3\xb3nski.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s just it,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Dolgor\xc3\xbakov quickly, laughing.\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know Bil\xc3\xadbin\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s a very clever fellow. He suggested\naddressing him as \xe2\x80\x98Usurper and Enemy of Mankind.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDolgor\xc3\xbakov laughed merrily.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly that?\xe2\x80\x9d said Bolk\xc3\xb3nski.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll the same, it was Bil\xc3\xadbin who found a suitable form for the\naddress. He is a wise and clever fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was it?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the Head of the French Government... Au chef du gouvernement\nfran\xc3\xa7ais,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dolgor\xc3\xbakov, with grave satisfaction. \xe2\x80\x9cGood,\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but he will dislike it extremely,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bolk\xc3\xb3nski.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, very much! My brother knows him, he\xe2\x80\x99s dined with him\xe2\x80\x94the\npresent Emperor\xe2\x80\x94more than once in Paris, and tells me he never met a\nmore cunning or subtle diplomatist\xe2\x80\x94you know, a combination of French\nadroitness and Italian play-acting! Do you know the tale about him and\nCount Mark\xc3\xb3v? Count Mark\xc3\xb3v was the only man who knew how to handle\nhim. You know the story of the handkerchief? It is delightful!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd the talkative Dolgor\xc3\xbakov, turning now to Bor\xc3\xads, now to Prince\nAndrew, told how Bonaparte wishing to test Mark\xc3\xb3v, our ambassador,\npurposely dropped a handkerchief in front of him and stood looking\nat Mark\xc3\xb3v, probably expecting Mark\xc3\xb3v to pick it up for him, and how\nMark\xc3\xb3v immediately dropped his own beside it and picked it up without\ntouching Bonaparte\xe2\x80\x99s.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDelightful!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bolk\xc3\xb3nski. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I have come to you, Prince,\nas a petitioner on behalf of this young man. You see...\xe2\x80\x9d but\nbefore Prince Andrew could finish, an aide-de-camp came in to summon\nDolgor\xc3\xbakov to the Emperor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, what a nuisance,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dolgor\xc3\xbakov, getting up hurriedly and\npressing the hands of Prince Andrew and Bor\xc3\xads. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know I should\nbe very glad to do all in my power both for you and for this dear young\nman.\xe2\x80\x9d Again he pressed the hand of the latter with an expression of\ngood-natured, sincere, and animated levity. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you see... another\ntime!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBor\xc3\xads was excited by the thought of being so close to the higher powers\nas he felt himself to be at that moment. He was conscious that here\nhe was in contact with the springs that set in motion the enormous\nmovements of the mass of which in his regiment he felt himself a tiny,\nobedient, and insignificant atom. They followed Prince Dolgor\xc3\xbakov out\ninto the corridor and met\xe2\x80\x94coming out of the door of the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s\nroom by which Dolgor\xc3\xbakov had entered\xe2\x80\x94a short man in civilian clothes\nwith a clever face and sharply projecting jaw which, without spoiling\nhis face, gave him a peculiar vivacity and shiftiness of expression.\nThis short man nodded to Dolgor\xc3\xbakov as to an intimate friend and stared\nat Prince Andrew with cool intensity, walking straight toward him and\nevidently expecting him to bow or to step out of his way. Prince Andrew\ndid neither: a look of animosity appeared on his face and the other\nturned away and went down the side of the corridor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho was that?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Bor\xc3\xads.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is one of the most remarkable, but to me most unpleasant of\nmen\xe2\x80\x94the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Prince Adam Czartor\xc3\xbdski.... It\nis such men as he who decide the fate of nations,\xe2\x80\x9d added Bolk\xc3\xb3nski\nwith a sigh he could not suppress, as they passed out of the palace.\n\nNext day, the army began its campaign, and up to the very battle of\nAusterlitz, Bor\xc3\xads was unable to see either Prince Andrew or Dolgor\xc3\xbakov\nagain and remained for a while with the Ism\xc3\xa1ylov regiment.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER X\n\nAt dawn on the sixteenth of November, Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s squadron, in\nwhich Nicholas Rost\xc3\xb3v served and which was in Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n\xe2\x80\x99s\ndetachment, moved from the place where it had spent the night, advancing\ninto action as arranged, and after going behind other columns for\nabout two thirds of a mile was stopped on the highroad. Rost\xc3\xb3v saw the\nCossacks and then the first and second squadrons of hussars and infantry\nbattalions and artillery pass by and go forward and then Generals\nBagrati\xc3\xb3n and Dolgor\xc3\xbakov ride past with their adjutants. All the fear\nbefore action which he had experienced as previously, all the inner\nstruggle to conquer that fear, all his dreams of distinguishing himself\nas a true hussar in this battle, had been wasted. Their squadron\nremained in reserve and Nicholas Rost\xc3\xb3v spent that day in a dull and\nwretched mood. At nine in the morning, he heard firing in front and\nshouts of hurrah, and saw wounded being brought back (there were not\nmany of them), and at last he saw how a whole detachment of French\ncavalry was brought in, convoyed by a s\xc3\xb3tnya of Cossacks. Evidently the\naffair was over and, though not big, had been a successful engagement.\nThe men and officers returning spoke of a brilliant victory, of the\noccupation of the town of Wischau and the capture of a whole French\nsquadron. The day was bright and sunny after a sharp night frost, and\nthe cheerful glitter of that autumn day was in keeping with the news of\nvictory which was conveyed, not only by the tales of those who had taken\npart in it, but also by the joyful expression on the faces of soldiers,\nofficers, generals, and adjutants, as they passed Rost\xc3\xb3v going or\ncoming. And Nicholas, who had vainly suffered all the dread that\nprecedes a battle and had spent that happy day in inactivity, was all\nthe more depressed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome here, Wost\xc3\xb3v. Let\xe2\x80\x99s dwink to dwown our gwief!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted\nDen\xc3\xadsov, who had settled down by the roadside with a flask and some\nfood.\n\nThe officers gathered round Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s canteen, eating and talking.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere! They are bringing another!\xe2\x80\x9d cried one of the officers,\nindicating a captive French dragoon who was being brought in on foot by\ntwo Cossacks.\n\nOne of them was leading by the bridle a fine large French horse he had\ntaken from the prisoner.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSell us that horse!\xe2\x80\x9d Den\xc3\xadsov called out to the Cossacks.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you like, your honor!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe officers got up and stood round the Cossacks and their prisoner.\nThe French dragoon was a young Alsatian who spoke French with a German\naccent. He was breathless with agitation, his face was red, and when\nhe heard some French spoken he at once began speaking to the officers,\naddressing first one, then another. He said he would not have been\ntaken, it was not his fault but the corporal\xe2\x80\x99s who had sent him to\nseize some horsecloths, though he had told him the Russians were there.\nAnd at every word he added: \xe2\x80\x9cBut don\xe2\x80\x99t hurt my little horse!\xe2\x80\x9d and\nstroked the animal. It was plain that he did not quite grasp where he\nwas. Now he excused himself for having been taken prisoner and now,\nimagining himself before his own officers, insisted on his soldierly\ndiscipline and zeal in the service. He brought with him into our\nrearguard all the freshness of atmosphere of the French army, which was\nso alien to us.\n\nThe Cossacks sold the horse for two gold pieces, and Rost\xc3\xb3v, being the\nrichest of the officers now that he had received his money, bought it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut don\xe2\x80\x99t hurt my little horse!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Alsatian good-naturedly\nto Rost\xc3\xb3v when the animal was handed over to the hussar.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v smilingly reassured the dragoon and gave him money.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlley! Alley!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Cossack, touching the prisoner\xe2\x80\x99s arm to\nmake him go on.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Emperor! The Emperor!\xe2\x80\x9d was suddenly heard among the hussars.\n\nAll began to run and bustle, and Rost\xc3\xb3v saw coming up the road behind\nhim several riders with white plumes in their hats. In a moment everyone\nwas in his place, waiting.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v did not know or remember how he ran to his place and mounted.\nInstantly his regret at not having been in action and his dejected mood\namid people of whom he was weary had gone, instantly every thought of\nhimself had vanished. He was filled with happiness at his nearness to\nthe Emperor. He felt that this nearness by itself made up to him for the\nday he had lost. He was happy as a lover when the longed-for moment of\nmeeting arrives. Not daring to look round and without looking round, he\nwas ecstatically conscious of his approach. He felt it not only from the\nsound of the hoofs of the approaching cavalcade, but because as he drew\nnear everything grew brighter, more joyful, more significant, and more\nfestive around him. Nearer and nearer to Rost\xc3\xb3v came that sun shedding\nbeams of mild and majestic light around, and already he felt himself\nenveloped in those beams, he heard his voice, that kindly, calm,\nand majestic voice that was yet so simple! And as if in accord with\nRost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s feeling, there was a deathly stillness amid which was heard\nthe Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe P\xc3\xa1vlograd hussars?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe reserves, sire!\xe2\x80\x9d replied a voice, a very human one compared to\nthat which had said: \xe2\x80\x9cThe P\xc3\xa1vlograd hussars?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe Emperor drew level with Rost\xc3\xb3v and halted. Alexander\xe2\x80\x99s face was\neven more beautiful than it had been three days before at the review. It\nshone with such gaiety and youth, such innocent youth, that it suggested\nthe liveliness of a fourteen-year-old boy, and yet it was the face\nof the majestic Emperor. Casually, while surveying the squadron, the\nEmperor\xe2\x80\x99s eyes met Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s and rested on them for not more than\ntwo seconds. Whether or no the Emperor understood what was going on in\nRost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s soul (it seemed to Rost\xc3\xb3v that he understood everything),\nat any rate his light-blue eyes gazed for about two seconds into\nRost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s face. A gentle, mild light poured from them. Then all at\nonce he raised his eyebrows, abruptly touched his horse with his left\nfoot, and galloped on.\n\nThe younger Emperor could not restrain his wish to be present at the\nbattle and, in spite of the remonstrances of his courtiers, at twelve\no\xe2\x80\x99clock left the third column with which he had been and galloped\ntoward the vanguard. Before he came up with the hussars, several\nadjutants met him with news of the successful result of the action.\n\nThis battle, which consisted in the capture of a French squadron, was\nrepresented as a brilliant victory over the French, and so the\nEmperor and the whole army, especially while the smoke hung over\nthe battlefield, believed that the French had been defeated and were\nretreating against their will. A few minutes after the Emperor had\npassed, the P\xc3\xa1vlograd division was ordered to advance. In Wischau\nitself, a petty German town, Rost\xc3\xb3v saw the Emperor again. In the\nmarket place, where there had been some rather heavy firing before the\nEmperor\xe2\x80\x99s arrival, lay several killed and wounded soldiers whom there\nhad not been time to move. The Emperor, surrounded by his suite\nof officers and courtiers, was riding a bobtailed chestnut mare, a\ndifferent one from that which he had ridden at the review, and bending\nto one side he gracefully held a gold lorgnette to his eyes and looked\nat a soldier who lay prone, with blood on his uncovered head. The\nwounded soldier was so dirty, coarse, and revolting that his proximity\nto the Emperor shocked Rost\xc3\xb3v. Rost\xc3\xb3v saw how the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s rather\nround shoulders shuddered as if a cold shiver had run down them, how his\nleft foot began convulsively tapping the horse\xe2\x80\x99s side with the spur,\nand how the well-trained horse looked round unconcerned and did not\nstir. An adjutant, dismounting, lifted the soldier under the arms to\nplace him on a stretcher that had been brought. The soldier groaned.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGently, gently! Can\xe2\x80\x99t you do it more gently?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Emperor\napparently suffering more than the dying soldier, and he rode away.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v saw tears filling the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s eyes and heard him, as he was\nriding away, say to Czartor\xc3\xbdski: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a terrible thing war is: what\na terrible thing! Quelle terrible chose que la guerre!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe troops of the vanguard were stationed before Wischau, within sight\nof the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s lines, which all day long had yielded ground to us\nat the least firing. The Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s gratitude was announced to the\nvanguard, rewards were promised, and the men received a double ration of\nvodka. The campfires crackled and the soldiers\xe2\x80\x99 songs resounded\neven more merrily than on the previous night. Den\xc3\xadsov celebrated his\npromotion to the rank of major, and Rost\xc3\xb3v, who had already drunk\nenough, at the end of the feast proposed the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s health. \xe2\x80\x9cNot\n\xe2\x80\x98our Sovereign, the Emperor,\xe2\x80\x99 as they say at official dinners,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid he, \xe2\x80\x9cbut the health of our Sovereign, that good, enchanting, and\ngreat man! Let us drink to his health and to the certain defeat of the\nFrench!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we fought before,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cnot letting the French pass, as\nat Sch\xc3\xb6n Grabern, what shall we not do now when he is at the front? We\nwill all die for him gladly! Is it not so, gentlemen? Perhaps I am not\nsaying it right, I have drunk a good deal\xe2\x80\x94but that is how I feel, and\nso do you too! To the health of Alexander the First! Hurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d rang the enthusiastic voices of the officers.\n\nAnd the old cavalry captain, K\xc3\xadrsten, shouted enthusiastically and no\nless sincerely than the twenty-year-old Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\nWhen the officers had emptied and smashed their glasses, K\xc3\xadrsten filled\nothers and, in shirt sleeves and breeches, went glass in hand to the\nsoldiers\xe2\x80\x99 bonfires and with his long gray mustache, his white chest\nshowing under his open shirt, he stood in a majestic pose in the light\nof the campfire, waving his uplifted arm.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLads! here\xe2\x80\x99s to our Sovereign, the Emperor, and victory over\nour enemies! Hurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed in his dashing, old, hussar\xe2\x80\x99s\nbaritone.\n\nThe hussars crowded round and responded heartily with loud shouts.\n\nLate that night, when all had separated, Den\xc3\xadsov with his short hand\npatted his favorite, Rost\xc3\xb3v, on the shoulder.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs there\xe2\x80\x99s no one to fall in love with on campaign, he\xe2\x80\x99s fallen\nin love with the Tsar,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDen\xc3\xadsov, don\xe2\x80\x99t make fun of it!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Rost\xc3\xb3v. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is such a\nlofty, beautiful feeling, such a...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe it, I believe it, fwiend, and I share and appwove...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you don\xe2\x80\x99t understand!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Rost\xc3\xb3v got up and went wandering among the campfires, dreaming of\nwhat happiness it would be to die\xe2\x80\x94not in saving the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s life\n(he did not even dare to dream of that), but simply to die before his\neyes. He really was in love with the Tsar and the glory of the Russian\narms and the hope of future triumph. And he was not the only man to\nexperience that feeling during those memorable days preceding the battle\nof Austerlitz: nine tenths of the men in the Russian army were then in\nlove, though less ecstatically, with their Tsar and the glory of the\nRussian arms.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XI\n\nThe next day the Emperor stopped at Wischau, and Villier, his physician,\nwas repeatedly summoned to see him. At headquarters and among the troops\nnear by the news spread that the Emperor was unwell. He ate nothing and\nhad slept badly that night, those around him reported. The cause of this\nindisposition was the strong impression made on his sensitive mind by\nthe sight of the killed and wounded.\n\nAt daybreak on the seventeenth, a French officer who had come with\na flag of truce, demanding an audience with the Russian Emperor, was\nbrought into Wischau from our outposts. This officer was Savary. The\nEmperor had only just fallen asleep and so Savary had to wait. At midday\nhe was admitted to the Emperor, and an hour later he rode off with\nPrince Dolgor\xc3\xbakov to the advanced post of the French army.\n\nIt was rumored that Savary had been sent to propose to Alexander\na meeting with Napoleon. To the joy and pride of the whole army, a\npersonal interview was refused, and instead of the Sovereign, Prince\nDolgor\xc3\xbakov, the victor at Wischau, was sent with Savary to negotiate\nwith Napoleon if, contrary to expectations, these negotiations were\nactuated by a real desire for peace.\n\nToward evening Dolgor\xc3\xbakov came back, went straight to the Tsar, and\nremained alone with him for a long time.\n\nOn the eighteenth and nineteenth of November, the army advanced two\ndays\xe2\x80\x99 march and the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s outposts after a brief interchange\nof shots retreated. In the highest army circles from midday on the\nnineteenth, a great, excitedly bustling activity began which lasted till\nthe morning of the twentieth, when the memorable battle of Austerlitz\nwas fought.\n\nTill midday on the nineteenth, the activity\xe2\x80\x94the eager talk, running to\nand fro, and dispatching of adjutants\xe2\x80\x94was confined to the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s\nheadquarters. But on the afternoon of that day, this activity reached\nKut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s headquarters and the staffs of the commanders of columns.\nBy evening, the adjutants had spread it to all ends and parts of the\narmy, and in the night from the nineteenth to the twentieth, the whole\neighty thousand allied troops rose from their bivouacs to the hum of\nvoices, and the army swayed and started in one enormous mass six miles\nlong.\n\nThe concentrated activity which had begun at the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s\nheadquarters in the morning and had started the whole movement that\nfollowed was like the first movement of the main wheel of a large tower\nclock. One wheel slowly moved, another was set in motion, and a third,\nand wheels began to revolve faster and faster, levers and cogwheels to\nwork, chimes to play, figures to pop out, and the hands to advance with\nregular motion as a result of all that activity.\n\nJust as in the mechanism of a clock, so in the mechanism of the military\nmachine, an impulse once given leads to the final result; and just as\nindifferently quiescent till the moment when motion is transmitted\nto them are the parts of the mechanism which the impulse has not yet\nreached. Wheels creak on their axles as the cogs engage one another and\nthe revolving pulleys whirr with the rapidity of their movement, but a\nneighboring wheel is as quiet and motionless as though it were prepared\nto remain so for a hundred years; but the moment comes when the lever\ncatches it and obeying the impulse that wheel begins to creak and joins\nin the common motion the result and aim of which are beyond its ken.\n\nJust as in a clock, the result of the complicated motion of innumerable\nwheels and pulleys is merely a slow and regular movement of the\nhands which show the time, so the result of all the complicated human\nactivities of 160,000 Russians and French\xe2\x80\x94all their passions, desires,\nremorse, humiliations, sufferings, outbursts of pride, fear, and\nenthusiasm\xe2\x80\x94was only the loss of the battle of Austerlitz, the\nso-called battle of the three Emperors\xe2\x80\x94that is to say, a slow movement\nof the hand on the dial of human history.\n\nPrince Andrew was on duty that day and in constant attendance on the\ncommander in chief.\n\nAt six in the evening, Kut\xc3\xbazov went to the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s headquarters\nand after staying but a short time with the Tsar went to see the grand\nmarshal of the court, Count Tolst\xc3\xb3y.\n\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski took the opportunity to go in to get some details of the\ncoming action from Dolgor\xc3\xbakov. He felt that Kut\xc3\xbazov was upset\nand dissatisfied about something and that at headquarters they were\ndissatisfied with him, and also that at the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s headquarters\neveryone adopted toward him the tone of men who know something others do\nnot know: he therefore wished to speak to Dolgor\xc3\xbakov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, how d\xe2\x80\x99you do, my dear fellow?\xe2\x80\x9d said Dolgor\xc3\xbakov, who was\nsitting at tea with Bil\xc3\xadbin. \xe2\x80\x9cThe fete is for tomorrow. How is your\nold fellow? Out of sorts?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t say he is out of sorts, but I fancy he would like to be\nheard.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut they heard him at the council of war and will hear him when he\ntalks sense, but to temporize and wait for something now when Bonaparte\nfears nothing so much as a general battle is impossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you have seen him?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what is\nBonaparte like? How did he impress you?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I saw him, and am convinced that he fears nothing so much as\na general engagement,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Dolgor\xc3\xbakov, evidently prizing this\ngeneral conclusion which he had arrived at from his interview with\nNapoleon. \xe2\x80\x9cIf he weren\xe2\x80\x99t afraid of a battle why did he ask for that\ninterview? Why negotiate, and above all why retreat, when to retreat is\nso contrary to his method of conducting war? Believe me, he is afraid,\nafraid of a general battle. His hour has come! Mark my words!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut tell me, what is he like, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew again.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a man in a gray overcoat, very anxious that I should call\nhim \xe2\x80\x98Your Majesty,\xe2\x80\x99 but who, to his chagrin, got no title from\nme! That\xe2\x80\x99s the sort of man he is, and nothing more,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\nDolgor\xc3\xbakov, looking round at Bil\xc3\xadbin with a smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDespite my great respect for old Kut\xc3\xbazov,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, \xe2\x80\x9cwe\nshould be a nice set of fellows if we were to wait about and so give him\na chance to escape, or to trick us, now that we certainly have him in\nour hands! No, we mustn\xe2\x80\x99t forget Suv\xc3\xb3rov and his rule\xe2\x80\x94not to put\nyourself in a position to be attacked, but yourself to attack. Believe\nme in war the energy of young men often shows the way better than all\nthe experience of old Cunctators.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut in what position are we going to attack him? I have been at the\noutposts today and it is impossible to say where his chief forces are\nsituated,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew.\n\nHe wished to explain to Dolgor\xc3\xbakov a plan of attack he had himself\nformed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that is all the same,\xe2\x80\x9d Dolgor\xc3\xbakov said quickly, and getting up\nhe spread a map on the table. \xe2\x80\x9cAll eventualities have been foreseen.\nIf he is standing before Br\xc3\xbcnn...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Prince Dolgor\xc3\xbakov rapidly but indistinctly explained Weyrother\xe2\x80\x99s\nplan of a flanking movement.\n\nPrince Andrew began to reply and to state his own plan, which might\nhave been as good as Weyrother\xe2\x80\x99s, but for the disadvantage that\nWeyrother\xe2\x80\x99s had already been approved. As soon as Prince Andrew began\nto demonstrate the defects of the latter and the merits of his own plan,\nPrince Dolgor\xc3\xbakov ceased to listen to him and gazed absent-mindedly not\nat the map, but at Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere will be a council of war at Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s tonight, though; you\ncan say all this there,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Dolgor\xc3\xbakov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will do so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew, moving away from the map.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhatever are you bothering about, gentlemen?\xe2\x80\x9d said Bil\xc3\xadbin, who,\ntill then, had listened with an amused smile to their conversation and\nnow was evidently ready with a joke. \xe2\x80\x9cWhether tomorrow brings\nvictory or defeat, the glory of our Russian arms is secure. Except your\nKut\xc3\xbazov, there is not a single Russian in command of a column! The\ncommanders are: Herr General Wimpfen, le Comte de Langeron, le Prince de\nLichtenstein, le Prince de Hohenlohe, and finally Prishprish, and so on\nlike all those Polish names.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe quiet, backbiter!\xe2\x80\x9d said Dolgor\xc3\xbakov. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is not true; there\nare now two Russians, Milor\xc3\xa1dovich, and Dokht\xc3\xbarov, and there would be\na third, Count Arakch\xc3\xa9ev, if his nerves were not too weak.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHowever, I think General Kut\xc3\xbazov has come out,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince\nAndrew. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish you good luck and success, gentlemen!\xe2\x80\x9d he added and\nwent out after shaking hands with Dolgor\xc3\xbakov and Bil\xc3\xadbin.\n\nOn the way home, Prince Andrew could not refrain from asking Kut\xc3\xbazov,\nwho was sitting silently beside him, what he thought of tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s\nbattle.\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov looked sternly at his adjutant and, after a pause, replied:\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think the battle will be lost, and so I told Count Tolst\xc3\xb3y and\nasked him to tell the Emperor. What do you think he replied? \xe2\x80\x98But, my\ndear general, I am engaged with rice and cutlets, look after military\nmatters yourself!\xe2\x80\x99 Yes... That was the answer I got!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XII\n\nShortly after nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock that evening, Weyrother drove with his\nplans to Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s quarters where the council of war was to be\nheld. All the commanders of columns were summoned to the commander in\nchief\xe2\x80\x99s and with the exception of Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n, who declined to\ncome, were all there at the appointed time.\n\nWeyrother, who was in full control of the proposed battle, by his\neagerness and briskness presented a marked contrast to the dissatisfied\nand drowsy Kut\xc3\xbazov, who reluctantly played the part of chairman and\npresident of the council of war. Weyrother evidently felt himself to be\nat the head of a movement that had already become unrestrainable. He was\nlike a horse running downhill harnessed to a heavy cart. Whether he was\npulling it or being pushed by it he did not know, but rushed along at\nheadlong speed with no time to consider what this movement might lead\nto. Weyrother had been twice that evening to the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s picket\nline to reconnoiter personally, and twice to the Emperors, Russian and\nAustrian, to report and explain, and to his headquarters where he had\ndictated the dispositions in German, and now, much exhausted, he arrived\nat Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s.\n\nHe was evidently so busy that he even forgot to be polite to the\ncommander in chief. He interrupted him, talked rapidly and indistinctly,\nwithout looking at the man he was addressing, and did not reply to\nquestions put to him. He was bespattered with mud and had a pitiful,\nweary, and distracted air, though at the same time he was haughty and\nself-confident.\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov was occupying a nobleman\xe2\x80\x99s castle of modest dimensions near\nOstralitz. In the large drawing room which had become the commander\nin chief\xe2\x80\x99s office were gathered Kut\xc3\xbazov himself, Weyrother, and the\nmembers of the council of war. They were drinking tea, and only awaited\nPrince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n to begin the council. At last Bagrati\xc3\xb3n\xe2\x80\x99s orderly\ncame with the news that the prince could not attend. Prince Andrew came\nin to inform the commander in chief of this and, availing himself\nof permission previously given him by Kut\xc3\xbazov to be present at the\ncouncil, he remained in the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSince Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n is not coming, we may begin,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nWeyrother, hurriedly rising from his seat and going up to the table on\nwhich an enormous map of the environs of Br\xc3\xbcnn was spread out.\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov, with his uniform unbuttoned so that his fat neck bulged over\nhis collar as if escaping, was sitting almost asleep in a low chair,\nwith his podgy old hands resting symmetrically on its arms. At the sound\nof Weyrother\xe2\x80\x99s voice, he opened his one eye with an effort.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, if you please! It is already late,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, and nodding\nhis head he let it droop and again closed his eye.\n\nIf at first the members of the council thought that Kut\xc3\xbazov was\npretending to sleep, the sounds his nose emitted during the reading that\nfollowed proved that the commander in chief at that moment was absorbed\nby a far more serious matter than a desire to show his contempt for\nthe dispositions or anything else\xe2\x80\x94he was engaged in satisfying the\nirresistible human need for sleep. He really was asleep. Weyrother, with\nthe gesture of a man too busy to lose a moment, glanced at Kut\xc3\xbazov and,\nhaving convinced himself that he was asleep, took up a paper and in\na loud, monotonous voice began to read out the dispositions for the\nimpending battle, under a heading which he also read out:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDispositions for an attack on the enemy position behind Kobelnitz and\nSokolnitz, November 30, 1805.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe dispositions were very complicated and difficult. They began as\nfollows:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s left wing rests on wooded hills and his right\nextends along Kobelnitz and Sokolnitz behind the ponds that are there,\nwhile we, on the other hand, with our left wing by far outflank his\nright, it is advantageous to attack the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s latter wing especially\nif we occupy the villages of Sokolnitz and Kobelnitz, whereby we\ncan both fall on his flank and pursue him over the plain between\nSchlappanitz and the Thuerassa forest, avoiding the defiles of\nSchlappanitz and Bellowitz which cover the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s front. For this\nobject it is necessary that... The first column marches... The second\ncolumn marches... The third column marches...\xe2\x80\x9d and so on, read\nWeyrother.\n\nThe generals seemed to listen reluctantly to the difficult dispositions.\nThe tall, fair-haired General Buxh\xc3\xb6wden stood, leaning his back against\nthe wall, his eyes fixed on a burning candle, and seemed not to listen\nor even to wish to be thought to listen. Exactly opposite Weyrother,\nwith his glistening wide-open eyes fixed upon him and his mustache\ntwisted upwards, sat the ruddy Milor\xc3\xa1dovich in a military pose, his\nelbows turned outwards, his hands on his knees, and his shoulders\nraised. He remained stubbornly silent, gazing at Weyrother\xe2\x80\x99s face,\nand only turned away his eyes when the Austrian chief of staff finished\nreading. Then Milor\xc3\xa1dovich looked round significantly at the other\ngenerals. But one could not tell from that significant look whether he\nagreed or disagreed and was satisfied or not with the arrangements. Next\nto Weyrother sat Count Langeron who, with a subtle smile that never left\nhis typically southern French face during the whole time of the reading,\ngazed at his delicate fingers which rapidly twirled by its corners\na gold snuffbox on which was a portrait. In the middle of one of the\nlongest sentences, he stopped the rotary motion of the snuffbox, raised\nhis head, and with inimical politeness lurking in the corners of his\nthin lips interrupted Weyrother, wishing to say something. But the\nAustrian general, continuing to read, frowned angrily and jerked his\nelbows, as if to say: \xe2\x80\x9cYou can tell me your views later, but now be so\ngood as to look at the map and listen.\xe2\x80\x9d Langeron lifted his eyes with\nan expression of perplexity, turned round to Milor\xc3\xa1dovich as if seeking\nan explanation, but meeting the latter\xe2\x80\x99s impressive but meaningless\ngaze drooped his eyes sadly and again took to twirling his snuffbox.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA geography lesson!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered as if to himself, but loud enough\nto be heard.\n\nPrzebysz\xc3\xa9wski, with respectful but dignified politeness, held his\nhand to his ear toward Weyrother, with the air of a man absorbed in\nattention. Dohkt\xc3\xbarov, a little man, sat opposite Weyrother, with\nan assiduous and modest mien, and stooping over the outspread map\nconscientiously studied the dispositions and the unfamiliar locality. He\nasked Weyrother several times to repeat words he had not clearly heard\nand the difficult names of villages. Weyrother complied and Dohkt\xc3\xbarov\nnoted them down.\n\nWhen the reading which lasted more than an hour was over, Langeron again\nbrought his snuffbox to rest and, without looking at Weyrother or at\nanyone in particular, began to say how difficult it was to carry out\nsuch a plan in which the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s position was assumed to be known,\nwhereas it was perhaps not known, since the enemy was in movement.\nLangeron\xe2\x80\x99s objections were valid but it was obvious that their chief\naim was to show General Weyrother\xe2\x80\x94who had read his dispositions with\nas much self-confidence as if he were addressing school children\xe2\x80\x94that\nhe had to do, not with fools, but with men who could teach him something\nin military matters.\n\nWhen the monotonous sound of Weyrother\xe2\x80\x99s voice ceased, Kut\xc3\xbazov opened\nhis eye as a miller wakes up when the soporific drone of the mill wheel\nis interrupted. He listened to what Langeron said, as if remarking,\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you are still at that silly business!\xe2\x80\x9d quickly closed his eye\nagain, and let his head sink still lower.\n\nLangeron, trying as virulently as possible to sting Weyrother\xe2\x80\x99s vanity\nas author of the military plan, argued that Bonaparte might easily\nattack instead of being attacked, and so render the whole of this\nplan perfectly worthless. Weyrother met all objections with a firm and\ncontemptuous smile, evidently prepared beforehand to meet all objections\nbe they what they might.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he could attack us, he would have done so today,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you think he is powerless?\xe2\x80\x9d said Langeron.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has forty thousand men at most,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Weyrother, with the\nsmile of a doctor to whom an old wife wishes to explain the treatment of\na case.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case he is inviting his doom by awaiting our attack,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nLangeron, with a subtly ironical smile, again glancing round for support\nto Milor\xc3\xa1dovich who was near him.\n\nBut Milor\xc3\xa1dovich was at that moment evidently thinking of anything\nrather than of what the generals were disputing about.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMa foi!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9ctomorrow we shall see all that on the\nbattlefield.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nWeyrother again gave that smile which seemed to say that to him it was\nstrange and ridiculous to meet objections from Russian generals and to\nhave to prove to them what he had not merely convinced himself of, but\nhad also convinced the sovereign Emperors of.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe enemy has quenched his fires and a continual noise is heard from\nhis camp,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat does that mean? Either he is retreating,\nwhich is the only thing we need fear, or he is changing his position.\xe2\x80\x9d\n(He smiled ironically.) \xe2\x80\x9cBut even if he also took up a position in\nthe Thuerassa, he merely saves us a great deal of trouble and all our\narrangements to the minutest detail remain the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is that?...\xe2\x80\x9d began Prince Andrew, who had for long been waiting\nan opportunity to express his doubts.\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov here woke up, coughed heavily, and looked round at the\ngenerals.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, the dispositions for tomorrow\xe2\x80\x94or rather for today, for\nit is past midnight\xe2\x80\x94cannot now be altered,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have\nheard them, and we shall all do our duty. But before a battle, there is\nnothing more important...\xe2\x80\x9d he paused, \xe2\x80\x9cthan to have a good sleep.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe moved as if to rise. The generals bowed and retired. It was past\nmidnight. Prince Andrew went out.\n\nThe council of war, at which Prince Andrew had not been able to\nexpress his opinion as he had hoped to, left on him a vague and uneasy\nimpression. Whether Dolgor\xc3\xbakov and Weyrother, or Kut\xc3\xbazov, Langeron,\nand the others who did not approve of the plan of attack, were\nright\xe2\x80\x94he did not know. \xe2\x80\x9cBut was it really not possible for Kut\xc3\xbazov\nto state his views plainly to the Emperor? Is it possible that on\naccount of court and personal considerations tens of thousands of lives,\nand my life, my life,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, \xe2\x80\x9cmust be risked?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it is very likely that I shall be killed tomorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nthought. And suddenly, at this thought of death, a whole series of most\ndistant, most intimate, memories rose in his imagination: he remembered\nhis last parting from his father and his wife; he remembered the days\nwhen he first loved her. He thought of her pregnancy and felt sorry for\nher and for himself, and in a nervously emotional and softened mood he\nwent out of the hut in which he was billeted with Nesv\xc3\xadtski and began\nto walk up and down before it.\n\nThe night was foggy and through the fog the moonlight gleamed\nmysteriously. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, tomorrow, tomorrow!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow\neverything may be over for me! All these memories will be no more, none\nof them will have any meaning for me. Tomorrow perhaps, even certainly,\nI have a presentiment that for the first time I shall have to show all\nI can do.\xe2\x80\x9d And his fancy pictured the battle, its loss, the\nconcentration of fighting at one point, and the hesitation of all the\ncommanders. And then that happy moment, that Toulon for which he had\nso long waited, presents itself to him at last. He firmly and clearly\nexpresses his opinion to Kut\xc3\xbazov, to Weyrother, and to the Emperors.\nAll are struck by the justness of his views, but no one undertakes to\ncarry them out, so he takes a regiment, a division\xe2\x80\x94stipulates that no\none is to interfere with his arrangements\xe2\x80\x94leads his division to\nthe decisive point, and gains the victory alone. \xe2\x80\x9cBut death and\nsuffering?\xe2\x80\x9d suggested another voice. Prince Andrew, however, did not\nanswer that voice and went on dreaming of his triumphs. The dispositions\nfor the next battle are planned by him alone. Nominally he is only an\nadjutant on Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s staff, but he does everything alone. The next\nbattle is won by him alone. Kut\xc3\xbazov is removed and he is appointed...\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell and then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the other voice. \xe2\x80\x9cIf before that you are\nnot ten times wounded, killed, or betrayed, well... what then?...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then,\xe2\x80\x9d Prince Andrew answered himself, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know\nwhat will happen and don\xe2\x80\x99t want to know, and can\xe2\x80\x99t, but if I want\nthis\xe2\x80\x94want glory, want to be known to men, want to be loved by them, it\nis not my fault that I want it and want nothing but that and live only\nfor that. Yes, for that alone! I shall never tell anyone, but, oh God!\nwhat am I to do if I love nothing but fame and men\xe2\x80\x99s esteem? Death,\nwounds, the loss of family\xe2\x80\x94I fear nothing. And precious and dear\nas many persons are to me\xe2\x80\x94father, sister, wife\xe2\x80\x94those dearest to\nme\xe2\x80\x94yet dreadful and unnatural as it seems, I would give them all at\nonce for a moment of glory, of triumph over men, of love from men I\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know and never shall know, for the love of these men here,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nthought, as he listened to voices in Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s courtyard. The voices\nwere those of the orderlies who were packing up; one voice, probably a\ncoachman\xe2\x80\x99s, was teasing Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s old cook whom Prince Andrew knew,\nand who was called Tit. He was saying, \xe2\x80\x9cTit, I say, Tit!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d returned the old man.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, Tit, thresh a bit!\xe2\x80\x9d said the wag.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, go to the devil!\xe2\x80\x9d called out a voice, drowned by the laughter\nof the orderlies and servants.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll the same, I love and value nothing but triumph over them all, I\nvalue this mystic power and glory that is floating here above me in this\nmist!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIII\n\nThat same night, Rost\xc3\xb3v was with a platoon on skirmishing duty in front\nof Bagrati\xc3\xb3n\xe2\x80\x99s detachment. His hussars were placed along the line\nin couples and he himself rode along the line trying to master the\nsleepiness that kept coming over him. An enormous space, with our\narmy\xe2\x80\x99s campfires dimly glowing in the fog, could be seen behind him;\nin front of him was misty darkness. Rost\xc3\xb3v could see nothing, peer as\nhe would into that foggy distance: now something gleamed gray, now there\nwas something black, now little lights seemed to glimmer where the enemy\nought to be, now he fancied it was only something in his own eyes. His\neyes kept closing, and in his fancy appeared\xe2\x80\x94now the Emperor, now\nDen\xc3\xadsov, and now Moscow memories\xe2\x80\x94and he again hurriedly opened his\neyes and saw close before him the head and ears of the horse he was\nriding, and sometimes, when he came within six paces of them, the\nblack figures of hussars, but in the distance was still the same misty\ndarkness. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?... It might easily happen,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Rost\xc3\xb3v,\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat the Emperor will meet me and give me an order as he would to any\nother officer; he\xe2\x80\x99ll say: \xe2\x80\x98Go and find out what\xe2\x80\x99s there.\xe2\x80\x99 There\nare many stories of his getting to know an officer in just such a chance\nway and attaching him to himself! What if he gave me a place near him?\nOh, how I would guard him, how I would tell him the truth, how I would\nunmask his deceivers!\xe2\x80\x9d And in order to realize vividly his love\ndevotion to the sovereign, Rost\xc3\xb3v pictured to himself an enemy or a\ndeceitful German, whom he would not only kill with pleasure but whom\nhe would slap in the face before the Emperor. Suddenly a distant shout\naroused him. He started and opened his eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere am I? Oh yes, in the skirmishing line... pass and\nwatchword\xe2\x80\x94shaft, Olm\xc3\xbctz. What a nuisance that our squadron will be in\nreserve tomorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll ask leave to go to the front,\nthis may be my only chance of seeing the Emperor. It won\xe2\x80\x99t be long\nnow before I am off duty. I\xe2\x80\x99ll take another turn and when I get back\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll go to the general and ask him.\xe2\x80\x9d He readjusted himself in the\nsaddle and touched up his horse to ride once more round his hussars. It\nseemed to him that it was getting lighter. To the left he saw a sloping\ndescent lit up, and facing it a black knoll that seemed as steep as a\nwall. On this knoll there was a white patch that Rost\xc3\xb3v could not at\nall make out: was it a glade in the wood lit up by the moon, or some\nunmelted snow, or some white houses? He even thought something moved on\nthat white spot. \xe2\x80\x9cI expect it\xe2\x80\x99s snow... that spot... a spot\xe2\x80\x94une\ntache,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cThere now... it\xe2\x80\x99s not a tache... Nat\xc3\xa1sha...\nsister, black eyes... Na... tasha... (Won\xe2\x80\x99t she be surprised when\nI tell her how I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen the Emperor?) Nat\xc3\xa1sha... take my\nsabretache...\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cKeep to the right, your honor, there are bushes\nhere,\xe2\x80\x9d came the voice of an hussar, past whom Rost\xc3\xb3v was riding in\nthe act of falling asleep. Rost\xc3\xb3v lifted his head that had sunk almost\nto his horse\xe2\x80\x99s mane and pulled up beside the hussar. He was succumbing\nto irresistible, youthful, childish drowsiness. \xe2\x80\x9cBut what was I\nthinking? I mustn\xe2\x80\x99t forget. How shall I speak to the Emperor? No,\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s not it\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s tomorrow. Oh yes! Nat\xc3\xa1sha... sabretache...\nsaber them... Whom? The hussars... Ah, the hussars with mustaches. Along\nthe Tversk\xc3\xa1ya Street rode the hussar with mustaches... I thought about\nhim too, just opposite G\xc3\xbaryev\xe2\x80\x99s house... Old G\xc3\xbaryev.... Oh, but\nDen\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s a fine fellow. But that\xe2\x80\x99s all nonsense. The chief thing\nis that the Emperor is here. How he looked at me and wished to say\nsomething, but dared not.... No, it was I who dared not. But that\xe2\x80\x99s\nnonsense, the chief thing is not to forget the important thing I\nwas thinking of. Yes, Na-t\xc3\xa1sha, sabretache, oh, yes, yes! That\xe2\x80\x99s\nright!\xe2\x80\x9d And his head once more sank to his horse\xe2\x80\x99s neck. All at once\nit seemed to him that he was being fired at. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat? What? What?... Cut\nthem down! What?...\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v, waking up. At the moment he opened\nhis eyes he heard in front of him, where the enemy was, the long-drawn\nshouts of thousands of voices. His horse and the horse of the hussar\nnear him pricked their ears at these shouts. Over there, where the\nshouting came from, a fire flared up and went out again, then another,\nand all along the French line on the hill fires flared up and the\nshouting grew louder and louder. Rost\xc3\xb3v could hear the sound of French\nwords but could not distinguish them. The din of many voices was too\ngreat; all he could hear was: \xe2\x80\x9cahahah!\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9crrrr!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that? What do you make of it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v to the hussar\nbeside him. \xe2\x80\x9cThat must be the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s camp!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe hussar did not reply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, don\xe2\x80\x99t you hear it?\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v asked again, after waiting for a\nreply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho can tell, your honor?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the hussar reluctantly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom the direction, it must be the enemy,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt may be he or it may be nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the hussar. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s\ndark... Steady!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried to his fidgeting horse.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s horse was also getting restive: it pawed the frozen ground,\npricking its ears at the noise and looking at the lights. The shouting\ngrew still louder and merged into a general roar that only an army\nof several thousand men could produce. The lights spread farther and\nfarther, probably along the line of the French camp. Rost\xc3\xb3v no longer\nwanted to sleep. The gay triumphant shouting of the enemy army had a\nstimulating effect on him. \xe2\x80\x9cVive l\xe2\x80\x99Empereur! l\xe2\x80\x99Empereur!\xe2\x80\x9d he now\nheard distinctly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey can\xe2\x80\x99t be far off, probably just beyond the stream,\xe2\x80\x9d he said\nto the hussar beside him.\n\nThe hussar only sighed without replying and coughed angrily. The sound\nof horse\xe2\x80\x99s hoofs approaching at a trot along the line of hussars was\nheard, and out of the foggy darkness the figure of a sergeant of hussars\nsuddenly appeared, looming huge as an elephant.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour honor, the generals!\xe2\x80\x9d said the sergeant, riding up to Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v, still looking round toward the fires and the shouts, rode with\nthe sergeant to meet some mounted men who were riding along the line.\nOne was on a white horse. Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n and Prince Dolgor\xc3\xbakov with\ntheir adjutants had come to witness the curious phenomenon of the\nlights and shouts in the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s camp. Rost\xc3\xb3v rode up to Bagrati\xc3\xb3n,\nreported to him, and then joined the adjutants listening to what the\ngenerals were saying.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBelieve me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Dolgor\xc3\xbakov, addressing Bagrati\xc3\xb3n, \xe2\x80\x9cit\nis nothing but a trick! He has retreated and ordered the rearguard to\nkindle fires and make a noise to deceive us.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHardly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bagrati\xc3\xb3n. \xe2\x80\x9cI saw them this evening on that\nknoll; if they had retreated they would have withdrawn from that too....\nOfficer!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bagrati\xc3\xb3n to Rost\xc3\xb3v, \xe2\x80\x9care the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s skirmishers\nstill there?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey were there this evening, but now I don\xe2\x80\x99t know, your\nexcellency. Shall I go with some of my hussars to see?\xe2\x80\x9d replied\nRost\xc3\xb3v.\n\nBagrati\xc3\xb3n stopped and, before replying, tried to see Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s face\nin the mist.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, go and see,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, after a pause.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v spurred his horse, called to Sergeant F\xc3\xa9dchenko and two other\nhussars, told them to follow him, and trotted downhill in the direction\nfrom which the shouting came. He felt both frightened and pleased to be\nriding alone with three hussars into that mysterious and dangerous misty\ndistance where no one had been before him. Bagrati\xc3\xb3n called to him from\nthe hill not to go beyond the stream, but Rost\xc3\xb3v pretended not to hear\nhim and did not stop but rode on and on, continually mistaking bushes\nfor trees and gullies for men and continually discovering his mistakes.\nHaving descended the hill at a trot, he no longer saw either our own or\nthe enemy\xe2\x80\x99s fires, but heard the shouting of the French more loudly\nand distinctly. In the valley he saw before him something like a river,\nbut when he reached it he found it was a road. Having come out onto\nthe road he reined in his horse, hesitating whether to ride along it or\ncross it and ride over the black field up the hillside. To keep to the\nroad which gleamed white in the mist would have been safer because it\nwould be easier to see people coming along it. \xe2\x80\x9cFollow me!\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\ncrossed the road, and began riding up the hill at a gallop toward the\npoint where the French pickets had been standing that evening.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour honor, there he is!\xe2\x80\x9d cried one of the hussars behind him. And\nbefore Rost\xc3\xb3v had time to make out what the black thing was that had\nsuddenly appeared in the fog, there was a flash, followed by a report,\nand a bullet whizzing high up in the mist with a plaintive sound passed\nout of hearing. Another musket missed fire but flashed in the pan.\nRost\xc3\xb3v turned his horse and galloped back. Four more reports followed\nat intervals, and the bullets passed somewhere in the fog singing in\ndifferent tones. Rost\xc3\xb3v reined in his horse, whose spirits had risen,\nlike his own, at the firing, and went back at a footpace. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, some\nmore! Some more!\xe2\x80\x9d a merry voice was saying in his soul.
