Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see?\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s our house,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v. \xe2\x80\x9cOf course, it\xe2\x80\x99s our house!\nDen\xc3\xadsov, Den\xc3\xadsov! We\xe2\x80\x99re almost there!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov raised his head, coughed, and made no answer.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDm\xc3\xadtri,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v to his valet on the box, \xe2\x80\x9cthose lights are\nin our house, aren\xe2\x80\x99t they?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir, and there\xe2\x80\x99s a light in your father\xe2\x80\x99s study.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen they\xe2\x80\x99ve not gone to bed yet? What do you think? Mind now,\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t forget to put out my new coat,\xe2\x80\x9d added Rost\xc3\xb3v, fingering his\nnew mustache. \xe2\x80\x9cNow then, get on,\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted to the driver. \xe2\x80\x9cDo\nwake up, V\xc3\xa1ska!\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, turning to Den\xc3\xadsov, whose head\nwas again nodding. \xe2\x80\x9cCome, get on! You shall have three rubles for\nvodka\xe2\x80\x94get on!\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v shouted, when the sleigh was only three\nhouses from his door. It seemed to him the horses were not moving at\nall. At last the sleigh bore to the right, drew up at an entrance, and\nRost\xc3\xb3v saw overhead the old familiar cornice with a bit of plaster\nbroken off, the porch, and the post by the side of the pavement. He\nsprang out before the sleigh stopped, and ran into the hall. The house\nstood cold and silent, as if quite regardless of who had come to it.\nThere was no one in the hall. \xe2\x80\x9cOh God! Is everyone all right?\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe thought, stopping for a moment with a sinking heart, and then\nimmediately starting to run along the hall and up the warped steps of\nthe familiar staircase. The well-known old door handle, which always\nangered the countess when it was not properly cleaned, turned as loosely\nas ever. A solitary tallow candle burned in the anteroom.\n\nOld Michael was asleep on the chest. Prok\xc3\xb3fy, the footman, who was\nso strong that he could lift the back of the carriage from behind, sat\nplaiting slippers out of cloth selvedges. He looked up at the opening\ndoor and his expression of sleepy indifference suddenly changed to one\nof delighted amazement.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGracious heavens! The young count!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, recognizing his\nyoung master. \xe2\x80\x9cCan it be? My treasure!\xe2\x80\x9d and Prok\xc3\xb3fy, trembling with\nexcitement, rushed toward the drawing room door, probably in order to\nannounce him, but, changing his mind, came back and stooped to kiss the\nyoung man\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll well?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Rost\xc3\xb3v, drawing away his arm.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, God be thanked! Yes! They\xe2\x80\x99ve just finished supper. Let me have\na look at you, your excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs everything quite all right?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord be thanked, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v, who had completely forgotten Den\xc3\xadsov, not wishing anyone to\nforestall him, threw off his fur coat and ran on tiptoe through the\nlarge dark ballroom. All was the same: there were the same old card\ntables and the same chandelier with a cover over it; but someone had\nalready seen the young master, and, before he had reached the drawing\nroom, something flew out from a side door like a tornado and began\nhugging and kissing him. Another and yet another creature of the same\nkind sprang from a second door and a third; more hugging, more kissing,\nmore outcries, and tears of joy. He could not distinguish which was\nPapa, which Nat\xc3\xa1sha, and which P\xc3\xa9tya. Everyone shouted, talked, and\nkissed him at the same time. Only his mother was not there, he noticed\nthat.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I did not know... Nicholas... My darling!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere he is... our own... K\xc3\xb3lya, * dear fellow... How he has\nchanged!... Where are the candles?... Tea!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n    * Nicholas.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd me, kiss me!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDearest... and me!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya, Nat\xc3\xa1sha, P\xc3\xa9tya, Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, V\xc3\xa9ra, and the old count\nwere all hugging him, and the serfs, men and maids, flocked into the\nroom, exclaiming and oh-ing and ah-ing.\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya, clinging to his legs, kept shouting, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd me too!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, after she had pulled him down toward her and covered his face\nwith kisses, holding him tight by the skirt of his coat, sprang away and\npranced up and down in one place like a goat and shrieked piercingly.\n\nAll around were loving eyes glistening with tears of joy, and all around\nwere lips seeking a kiss.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya too, all rosy red, clung to his arm and, radiant with bliss,\nlooked eagerly toward his eyes, waiting for the look for which she\nlonged. S\xc3\xb3nya now was sixteen and she was very pretty, especially at\nthis moment of happy, rapturous excitement. She gazed at him, not taking\nher eyes off him, and smiling and holding her breath. He gave her a\ngrateful look, but was still expectant and looking for someone. The old\ncountess had not yet come. But now steps were heard at the door, steps\nso rapid that they could hardly be his mother\xe2\x80\x99s.\n\nYet it was she, dressed in a new gown which he did not know, made since\nhe had left. All the others let him go, and he ran to her. When they\nmet, she fell on his breast, sobbing. She could not lift her face, but\nonly pressed it to the cold braiding of his hussar\xe2\x80\x99s jacket. Den\xc3\xadsov,\nwho had come into the room unnoticed by anyone, stood there and wiped\nhis eyes at the sight.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVas\xc3\xadli Den\xc3\xadsov, your son\xe2\x80\x99s friend,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, introducing\nhimself to the count, who was looking inquiringly at him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are most welcome! I know, I know,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, kissing and\nembracing Den\xc3\xadsov. \xe2\x80\x9cNicholas wrote us... Nat\xc3\xa1sha, V\xc3\xa9ra, look! Here\nis Den\xc3\xadsov!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe same happy, rapturous faces turned to the shaggy figure of Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDarling Den\xc3\xadsov!\xe2\x80\x9d screamed Nat\xc3\xa1sha, beside herself with rapture,\nspringing to him, putting her arms round him, and kissing him. This\nescapade made everybody feel confused. Den\xc3\xadsov blushed too, but smiled\nand, taking Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s hand, kissed it.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov was shown to the room prepared for him, and the Rost\xc3\xb3vs all\ngathered round Nicholas in the sitting room.\n\nThe old countess, not letting go of his hand and kissing it every\nmoment, sat beside him: the rest, crowding round him, watched every\nmovement, word, or look of his, never taking their blissfully adoring\neyes off him. His brother and sisters struggled for the places nearest\nto him and disputed with one another who should bring him his tea,\nhandkerchief, and pipe.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v was very happy in the love they showed him; but the first\nmoment of meeting had been so beatific that his present joy seemed\ninsufficient, and he kept expecting something more, more and yet more.\n\nNext morning, after the fatigues of their journey, the travelers slept\ntill ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\n\nIn the room next to their bedroom there was a confusion of sabers,\nsatchels, sabretaches, open portmanteaus, and dirty boots. Two freshly\ncleaned pairs with spurs had just been placed by the wall. The servants\nwere bringing in jugs and basins, hot water for shaving, and their\nwell-brushed clothes. There was a masculine odor and a smell of tobacco.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHallo, Gw\xc3\xadska\xe2\x80\x94my pipe!\xe2\x80\x9d came Vas\xc3\xadli Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s husky voice.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWost\xc3\xb3v, get up!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v, rubbing his eyes that seemed glued together, raised his\ndisheveled head from the hot pillow.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, is it late?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLate! It\xe2\x80\x99s nearly ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s voice.\nA rustle of starched petticoats and the whispering and laughter of\ngirls\xe2\x80\x99 voices came from the adjoining room. The door was opened a\ncrack and there was a glimpse of something blue, of ribbons, black hair,\nand merry faces. It was Nat\xc3\xa1sha, S\xc3\xb3nya, and P\xc3\xa9tya, who had come to\nsee whether they were getting up.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNicholas! Get up!\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s voice was again heard at the door.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDirectly!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nMeanwhile, P\xc3\xa9tya, having found and seized the sabers in the outer room,\nwith the delight boys feel at the sight of a military elder brother, and\nforgetting that it was unbecoming for the girls to see men undressed,\nopened the bedroom door.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs this your saber?\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted.\n\nThe girls sprang aside. Den\xc3\xadsov hid his hairy legs under the blanket,\nlooking with a scared face at his comrade for help. The door, having let\nP\xc3\xa9tya in, closed again. A sound of laughter came from behind it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNicholas! Come out in your dressing gown!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs this your saber?\xe2\x80\x9d asked P\xc3\xa9tya. \xe2\x80\x9cOr is it yours?\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\naddressing the black-mustached Den\xc3\xadsov with servile deference.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v hurriedly put something on his feet, drew on his dressing gown,\nand went out. Nat\xc3\xa1sha had put on one spurred boot and was just getting\nher foot into the other. S\xc3\xb3nya, when he came in, was twirling round and\nwas about to expand her dresses into a balloon and sit down. They were\ndressed alike, in new pale-blue frocks, and were both fresh, rosy, and\nbright. S\xc3\xb3nya ran away, but Nat\xc3\xa1sha, taking her brother\xe2\x80\x99s arm, led\nhim into the sitting room, where they began talking. They hardly gave\none another time to ask questions and give replies concerning a thousand\nlittle matters which could not interest anyone but themselves. Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nlaughed at every word he said or that she said herself, not because what\nthey were saying was amusing, but because she felt happy and was unable\nto control her joy which expressed itself by laughter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, how nice, how splendid!\xe2\x80\x9d she said to everything.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v felt that, under the influence of the warm rays of love, that\nchildlike smile which had not once appeared on his face since he left\nhome now for the first time after eighteen months again brightened his\nsoul and his face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but listen,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cnow you are quite a man, aren\xe2\x80\x99t\nyou? I\xe2\x80\x99m awfully glad you\xe2\x80\x99re my brother.\xe2\x80\x9d She touched his\nmustache. \xe2\x80\x9cI want to know what you men are like. Are you the same as\nwe? No?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did S\xc3\xb3nya run away?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes! That\xe2\x80\x99s a whole long story! How are you going to speak to\nher\xe2\x80\x94thou or you?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs may happen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, call her you, please! I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you all about it some other\ntime. No, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you now. You know S\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s my dearest friend.\nSuch a friend that I burned my arm for her sake. Look here!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe pulled up her muslin sleeve and showed him a red scar on her long,\nslender, delicate arm, high above the elbow on that part that is covered\neven by a ball dress.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI burned this to prove my love for her. I just heated a ruler in the\nfire and pressed it there!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nSitting on the sofa with the little cushions on its arms, in what used\nto be his old schoolroom, and looking into Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s wildly bright\neyes, Rost\xc3\xb3v re-entered that world of home and childhood which had no\nmeaning for anyone else, but gave him some of the best joys of his life;\nand the burning of an arm with a ruler as a proof of love did not seem\nto him senseless, he understood and was not surprised at it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and is that all?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are such friends, such friends! All that ruler business was just\nnonsense, but we are friends forever. She, if she loves anyone, does it\nfor life, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand that, I forget quickly.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what then?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, she loves me and you like that.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha suddenly flushed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you remember before you went away?... Well, she says you are to\nforget all that.... She says: \xe2\x80\x98I shall love him always, but let him be\nfree.\xe2\x80\x99 Isn\xe2\x80\x99t that lovely and noble! Yes, very noble? Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\nasked Nat\xc3\xa1sha, so seriously and excitedly that it was evident that what\nshe was now saying she had talked of before, with tears.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v became thoughtful.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never go back on my word,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cBesides, S\xc3\xb3nya is so\ncharming that only a fool would renounce such happiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nat\xc3\xa1sha, \xe2\x80\x9cshe and I have already talked it over.\nWe knew you\xe2\x80\x99d say so. But it won\xe2\x80\x99t do, because you see, if you say\nthat\xe2\x80\x94if you consider yourself bound by your promise\xe2\x80\x94it will seem as\nif she had not meant it seriously. It makes it as if you were marrying\nher because you must, and that wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v saw that it had been well considered by them. S\xc3\xb3nya had already\nstruck him by her beauty on the preceding day. Today, when he had caught\na glimpse of her, she seemed still more lovely. She was a charming girl\nof sixteen, evidently passionately in love with him (he did not doubt\nthat for an instant). Why should he not love her now, and even marry\nher, Rost\xc3\xb3v thought, but just now there were so many other pleasures\nand interests before him! \xe2\x80\x9cYes, they have taken a wise decision,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nthought, \xe2\x80\x9cI must remain free.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then, that\xe2\x80\x99s excellent,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll talk it over\nlater on. Oh, how glad I am to have you!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and are you still true to Bor\xc3\xads?\xe2\x80\x9d he continued.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, what nonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nat\xc3\xa1sha, laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think\nabout him or anyone else, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t want anything of the kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me! Then what are you up to now?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Nat\xc3\xa1sha, and a happy smile lit up her face. \xe2\x80\x9cHave\nyou seen Duport?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot seen Duport\xe2\x80\x94the famous dancer? Well then, you won\xe2\x80\x99t\nunderstand. That\xe2\x80\x99s what I\xe2\x80\x99m up to.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nCurving her arms, Nat\xc3\xa1sha held out her skirts as dancers do, ran back\na few steps, turned, cut a caper, brought her little feet sharply\ntogether, and made some steps on the very tips of her toes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee, I\xe2\x80\x99m standing! See!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, but could not maintain herself\non her toes any longer. \xe2\x80\x9cSo that\xe2\x80\x99s what I\xe2\x80\x99m up to! I\xe2\x80\x99ll never\nmarry anyone, but will be a dancer. Only don\xe2\x80\x99t tell anyone.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v laughed so loud and merrily that Den\xc3\xadsov, in his bedroom, felt\nenvious and Nat\xc3\xa1sha could not help joining in.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but don\xe2\x80\x99t you think it\xe2\x80\x99s nice?\xe2\x80\x9d she kept repeating.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNice! And so you no longer wish to marry Bor\xc3\xads?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha flared up. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to marry anyone. And I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell\nhim so when I see him!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that\xe2\x80\x99s all rubbish,\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha chattered on. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd is\nDen\xc3\xadsov nice?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, well then, good-by: go and dress. Is he very terrible,\nDen\xc3\xadsov?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy terrible?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Nicholas. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, V\xc3\xa1ska is a splendid\nfellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou call him V\xc3\xa1ska? That\xe2\x80\x99s funny! And is he very nice?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then, be quick. We\xe2\x80\x99ll all have breakfast together.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Nat\xc3\xa1sha rose and went out of the room on tiptoe, like a ballet\ndancer, but smiling as only happy girls of fifteen can smile. When\nRost\xc3\xb3v met S\xc3\xb3nya in the drawing room, he reddened. He did not know\nhow to behave with her. The evening before, in the first happy moment of\nmeeting, they had kissed each other, but today they felt it could not\nbe done; he felt that everybody, including his mother and sisters, was\nlooking inquiringly at him and watching to see how he would behave\nwith her. He kissed her hand and addressed her not as thou but as\nyou\xe2\x80\x94S\xc3\xb3nya. But their eyes met and said thou, and exchanged tender\nkisses. Her looks asked him to forgive her for having dared, by\nNat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s intermediacy, to remind him of his promise, and then\nthanked him for his love. His looks thanked her for offering him his\nfreedom and told her that one way or another he would never cease to\nlove her, for that would be impossible.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow strange it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said V\xc3\xa9ra, selecting a moment when all were\nsilent, \xe2\x80\x9cthat S\xc3\xb3nya and Nicholas now say you to one another and meet\nlike strangers.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nV\xc3\xa9ra\xe2\x80\x99s remark was correct, as her remarks always were, but, like\nmost of her observations, it made everyone feel uncomfortable, not\nonly S\xc3\xb3nya, Nicholas, and Nat\xc3\xa1sha, but even the old countess,\nwho\xe2\x80\x94dreading this love affair which might hinder Nicholas from making\na brilliant match\xe2\x80\x94blushed like a girl.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov, to Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s surprise, appeared in the drawing room with\npomaded hair, perfumed, and in a new uniform, looking just as smart as\nhe made himself when going into battle, and he was more amiable to the\nladies and gentlemen than Rost\xc3\xb3v had ever expected to see him.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER II\n\nOn his return to Moscow from the army, Nicholas Rost\xc3\xb3v was welcomed\nby his home circle as the best of sons, a hero, and their darling\nNik\xc3\xb3lenka; by his relations as a charming, attractive, and polite young\nman; by his acquaintances as a handsome lieutenant of hussars, a good\ndancer, and one of the best matches in the city.\n\nThe Rost\xc3\xb3vs knew everybody in Moscow. The old count had money enough\nthat year, as all his estates had been remortgaged, and so Nicholas,\nacquiring a trotter of his own, very stylish riding breeches of the\nlatest cut, such as no one else yet had in Moscow, and boots of the\nlatest fashion, with extremely pointed toes and small silver spurs,\npassed his time very gaily. After a short period of adapting himself\nto the old conditions of life, Nicholas found it very pleasant to be\nat home again. He felt that he had grown up and matured very much. His\ndespair at failing in a Scripture examination, his borrowing money from\nGavr\xc3\xadl to pay a sleigh driver, his kissing S\xc3\xb3nya on the sly\xe2\x80\x94he now\nrecalled all this as childishness he had left immeasurably behind.\nNow he was a lieutenant of hussars, in a jacket laced with silver, and\nwearing the Cross of St. George, awarded to soldiers for bravery in\naction, and in the company of well-known, elderly, and respected racing\nmen was training a trotter of his own for a race. He knew a lady on one\nof the boulevards whom he visited of an evening. He led the mazurka\nat the Arkh\xc3\xa1rovs\xe2\x80\x99 ball, talked about the war with Field Marshal\nK\xc3\xa1menski, visited the English Club, and was on intimate terms with a\ncolonel of forty to whom Den\xc3\xadsov had introduced him.\n\nHis passion for the Emperor had cooled somewhat in Moscow. But still, as\nhe did not see him and had no opportunity of seeing him, he often spoke\nabout him and about his love for him, letting it be understood that he\nhad not told all and that there was something in his feelings for the\nEmperor not everyone could understand, and with his whole soul he shared\nthe adoration then common in Moscow for the Emperor, who was spoken of\nas the \xe2\x80\x9cangel incarnate.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDuring Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s short stay in Moscow, before rejoining the army, he\ndid not draw closer to S\xc3\xb3nya, but rather drifted away from her. She was\nvery pretty and sweet, and evidently deeply in love with him, but he was\nat the period of youth when there seems so much to do that there is no\ntime for that sort of thing and a young man fears to bind himself and\nprizes his freedom which he needs for so many other things. When he\nthought of S\xc3\xb3nya, during this stay in Moscow, he said to himself,\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, there will be, and there are, many more such girls somewhere whom\nI do not yet know. There will be time enough to think about love when I\nwant to, but now I have no time.\xe2\x80\x9d Besides, it seemed to him that the\nsociety of women was rather derogatory to his manhood. He went to balls\nand into ladies\xe2\x80\x99 society with an affectation of doing so against his\nwill. The races, the English Club, sprees with Den\xc3\xadsov, and visits to\na certain house\xe2\x80\x94that was another matter and quite the thing for a\ndashing young hussar!\n\nAt the beginning of March, old Count Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v was very busy\narranging a dinner in honor of Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n at the English Club.\n\nThe count walked up and down the hall in his dressing gown, giving\norders to the club steward and to the famous Feokt\xc3\xadst, the club\xe2\x80\x99s\nhead cook, about asparagus, fresh cucumbers, strawberries, veal, and\nfish for this dinner. The count had been a member and on the committee\nof the club from the day it was founded. To him the club entrusted the\narrangement of the festival in honor of Bagrati\xc3\xb3n, for few men knew\nso well how to arrange a feast on an open-handed, hospitable scale,\nand still fewer men would be so well able and willing to make up out of\ntheir own resources what might be needed for the success of the fete.\nThe club cook and the steward listened to the count\xe2\x80\x99s orders with\npleased faces, for they knew that under no other management could they\nso easily extract a good profit for themselves from a dinner costing\nseveral thousand rubles.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then, mind and have cocks\xe2\x80\x99 comb in the turtle soup, you\nknow!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we have three cold dishes then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the cook.\n\nThe count considered.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe can\xe2\x80\x99t have less\xe2\x80\x94yes, three... the mayonnaise, that\xe2\x80\x99s one,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid he, bending down a finger.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen am I to order those large sterlets?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the steward.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it can\xe2\x80\x99t be helped if they won\xe2\x80\x99t take less. Ah, dear me! I\nwas forgetting. We must have another entr\xc3\xa9e. Ah, goodness gracious!\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe clutched at his head. \xe2\x80\x9cWho is going to get me the flowers? Dm\xc3\xadtri!\nEh, Dm\xc3\xadtri! Gallop off to our Moscow estate,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the factotum\nwho appeared at his call. \xe2\x80\x9cHurry off and tell Maks\xc3\xadm, the gardener,\nto set the serfs to work. Say that everything out of the hothouses must\nbe brought here well wrapped up in felt. I must have two hundred pots\nhere on Friday.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHaving given several more orders, he was about to go to his \xe2\x80\x9clittle\ncountess\xe2\x80\x9d to have a rest, but remembering something else of\nimportance, he returned again, called back the cook and the club\nsteward, and again began giving orders. A light footstep and the\nclinking of spurs were heard at the door, and the young count, handsome,\nrosy, with a dark little mustache, evidently rested and made sleeker by\nhis easy life in Moscow, entered the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my boy, my head\xe2\x80\x99s in a whirl!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man with a smile,\nas if he felt a little confused before his son. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, if you would\nonly help a bit! I must have singers too. I shall have my own orchestra,\nbut shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t we get the gypsy singers as well? You military men like\nthat sort of thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, Papa, I believe Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n worried himself less before\nthe battle of Sch\xc3\xb6n Grabern than you do now,\xe2\x80\x9d said his son with a\nsmile.\n\nThe old count pretended to be angry.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you talk, but try it yourself!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd the count turned to the cook, who, with a shrewd and respectful\nexpression, looked observantly and sympathetically at the father and\nson.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have the young people come to nowadays, eh, Feokt\xc3\xadst?\xe2\x80\x9d said\nhe. \xe2\x80\x9cLaughing at us old fellows!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s so, your excellency, all they have to do is to eat a good\ndinner, but providing it and serving it all up, that\xe2\x80\x99s not their\nbusiness!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it, that\xe2\x80\x99s it!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the count, and gaily seizing\nhis son by both hands, he cried, \xe2\x80\x9cNow I\xe2\x80\x99ve got you, so take the\nsleigh and pair at once, and go to Bez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s, and tell him \xe2\x80\x98Count\nIly\xc3\xa1 has sent you to ask for strawberries and fresh pineapples.\xe2\x80\x99 We\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t get them from anyone else. He\xe2\x80\x99s not there himself, so you\xe2\x80\x99ll\nhave to go in and ask the princesses; and from there go on to the\nRasguly\xc3\xa1y\xe2\x80\x94the coachman Ip\xc3\xa1tka knows\xe2\x80\x94and look up the gypsy\nIly\xc3\xbashka, the one who danced at Count Orl\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s, you remember, in a\nwhite Cossack coat, and bring him along to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd am I to bring the gypsy girls along with him?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Nicholas,\nlaughing. \xe2\x80\x9cDear, dear!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAt that moment, with noiseless footsteps and with the businesslike,\npreoccupied, yet meekly Christian look which never left her face, Anna\nMikh\xc3\xa1ylovna entered the hall. Though she came upon the count in his\ndressing gown every day, he invariably became confused and begged her to\nexcuse his costume.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo matter at all, my dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, meekly closing her\neyes. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I\xe2\x80\x99ll go to Bez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s myself. Pierre has arrived, and\nnow we shall get anything we want from his hothouses. I have to see him\nin any case. He has forwarded me a letter from Bor\xc3\xads. Thank God, Bor\xc3\xads\nis now on the staff.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe count was delighted at Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna\xe2\x80\x99s taking upon herself one\nof his commissions and ordered the small closed carriage for her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell Bez\xc3\xbakhov to come. I\xe2\x80\x99ll put his name down. Is his wife with\nhim?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\n\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna turned up her eyes, and profound sadness was depicted\non her face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear friend, he is very unfortunate,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf what\nwe hear is true, it is dreadful. How little we dreamed of such a thing\nwhen we were rejoicing at his happiness! And such a lofty angelic soul\nas young Bez\xc3\xbakhov! Yes, I pity him from my heart, and shall try to give\nhim what consolation I can.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWh-what is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d asked both the young and old Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\nAnna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna sighed deeply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xc3\xb3lokhov, Mary Iv\xc3\xa1novna\xe2\x80\x99s son,\xe2\x80\x9d she said in a mysterious\nwhisper, \xe2\x80\x9chas compromised her completely, they say. Pierre took him\nup, invited him to his house in Petersburg, and now... she has come here\nand that daredevil after her!\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna, wishing to show\nher sympathy for Pierre, but by involuntary intonations and a half smile\nbetraying her sympathy for the \xe2\x80\x9cdaredevil,\xe2\x80\x9d as she called D\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey say Pierre is quite broken by his misfortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear, dear! But still tell him to come to the club\xe2\x80\x94it will all blow\nover. It will be a tremendous banquet.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNext day, the third of March, soon after one o\xe2\x80\x99clock, two hundred and\nfifty members of the English Club and fifty guests were awaiting the\nguest of honor and hero of the Austrian campaign, Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n, to\ndinner.\n\nOn the first arrival of the news of the battle of Austerlitz, Moscow had\nbeen bewildered. At that time, the Russians were so used to victories\nthat on receiving news of the defeat some would simply not believe it,\nwhile others sought some extraordinary explanation of so strange an\nevent. In the English Club, where all who were distinguished, important,\nand well informed foregathered when the news began to arrive in\nDecember, nothing was said about the war and the last battle, as\nthough all were in a conspiracy of silence. The men who set the tone\nin conversation\xe2\x80\x94Count Rostopch\xc3\xadn, Prince Y\xc3\xbari Dolgor\xc3\xbakov, Val\xc3\xbaev,\nCount Mark\xc3\xb3v, and Prince Vy\xc3\xa1zemski\xe2\x80\x94did not show themselves at the\nclub, but met in private houses in intimate circles, and the\nMoscovites who took their opinions from others\xe2\x80\x94Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v among\nthem\xe2\x80\x94remained for a while without any definite opinion on the subject\nof the war and without leaders. The Moscovites felt that something was\nwrong and that to discuss the bad news was difficult, and so it was best\nto be silent. But after a while, just as a jury comes out of its room,\nthe bigwigs who guided the club\xe2\x80\x99s opinion reappeared, and everybody\nbegan speaking clearly and definitely. Reasons were found for the\nincredible, unheard-of, and impossible event of a Russian defeat,\neverything became clear, and in all corners of Moscow the same things\nbegan to be said. These reasons were the treachery of the Austrians, a\ndefective commissariat, the treachery of the Pole Przebysz\xc3\xa9wski and of\nthe Frenchman Langeron, Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s incapacity, and (it was whispered)\nthe youth and inexperience of the sovereign, who had trusted worthless\nand insignificant people. But the army, the Russian army, everyone\ndeclared, was extraordinary and had achieved miracles of valor. The\nsoldiers, officers, and generals were heroes. But the hero of heroes was\nPrince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n, distinguished by his Sch\xc3\xb6n Grabern affair and by\nthe retreat from Austerlitz, where he alone had withdrawn his column\nunbroken and had all day beaten back an enemy force twice as numerous\nas his own. What also conduced to Bagrati\xc3\xb3n\xe2\x80\x99s being selected as\nMoscow\xe2\x80\x99s hero was the fact that he had no connections in the city\nand was a stranger there. In his person, honor was shown to a simple\nfighting Russian soldier without connections and intrigues, and to one\nwho was associated by memories of the Italian campaign with the name of\nSuv\xc3\xb3rov. Moreover, paying such honor to Bagrati\xc3\xb3n was the best way of\nexpressing disapproval and dislike of Kut\xc3\xbazov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad there been no Bagrati\xc3\xb3n, it would have been necessary to\ninvent him,\xe2\x80\x9d said the wit Shinsh\xc3\xadn, parodying the words of Voltaire.\nKut\xc3\xbazov no one spoke of, except some who abused him in whispers,\ncalling him a court weathercock and an old satyr.\n\nAll Moscow repeated Prince Dolgor\xc3\xbakov\xe2\x80\x99s saying: \xe2\x80\x9cIf you go on\nmodeling and modeling you must get smeared with clay,\xe2\x80\x9d suggesting\nconsolation for our defeat by the memory of former victories; and the\nwords of Rostopch\xc3\xadn, that French soldiers have to be incited to battle\nby highfalutin words, and Germans by logical arguments to show them\nthat it is more dangerous to run away than to advance, but that Russian\nsoldiers only need to be restrained and held back! On all sides, new and\nfresh anecdotes were heard of individual examples of heroism shown by\nour officers and men at Austerlitz. One had saved a standard, another\nhad killed five Frenchmen, a third had loaded five cannon singlehanded.\nBerg was mentioned, by those who did not know him, as having, when\nwounded in the right hand, taken his sword in the left, and gone\nforward. Of Bolk\xc3\xb3nski, nothing was said, and only those who knew him\nintimately regretted that he had died so young, leaving a pregnant wife\nwith his eccentric father.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER III\n\nOn that third of March, all the rooms in the English Club were filled\nwith a hum of conversation, like the hum of bees swarming in springtime.\nThe members and guests of the club wandered hither and thither, sat,\nstood, met, and separated, some in uniform and some in evening dress,\nand a few here and there with powdered hair and in Russian kaft\xc3\xa1ns.\nPowdered footmen, in livery with buckled shoes and smart stockings,\nstood at every door anxiously noting visitors\xe2\x80\x99 every movement in order\nto offer their services. Most of those present were elderly, respected\nmen with broad, self-confident faces, fat fingers, and resolute gestures\nand voices. This class of guests and members sat in certain habitual\nplaces and met in certain habitual groups. A minority of those present\nwere casual guests\xe2\x80\x94chiefly young men, among whom were Den\xc3\xadsov,\nRost\xc3\xb3v, and D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x94who was now again an officer in the Sem\xc3\xabnov\nregiment. The faces of these young people, especially those who were\nmilitary men, bore that expression of condescending respect for their\nelders which seems to say to the older generation, \xe2\x80\x9cWe are prepared to\nrespect and honor you, but all the same remember that the future belongs\nto us.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNesv\xc3\xadtski was there as an old member of the club. Pierre, who at his\nwife\xe2\x80\x99s command had let his hair grow and abandoned his spectacles,\nwent about the rooms fashionably dressed but looking sad and dull. Here,\nas elsewhere, he was surrounded by an atmosphere of subservience to\nhis wealth, and being in the habit of lording it over these people, he\ntreated them with absent-minded contempt.\n\nBy his age he should have belonged to the younger men, but by his wealth\nand connections he belonged to the groups of old and honored guests, and\nso he went from one group to another. Some of the most important old men\nwere the center of groups which even strangers approached respectfully\nto hear the voices of well-known men. The largest circles formed round\nCount Rostopch\xc3\xadn, Val\xc3\xbaev, and Nar\xc3\xbdshkin. Rostopch\xc3\xadn was describing\nhow the Russians had been overwhelmed by flying Austrians and had had to\nforce their way through them with bayonets.\n\nVal\xc3\xbaev was confidentially telling that Uv\xc3\xa1rov had been sent from\nPetersburg to ascertain what Moscow was thinking about Austerlitz.\n\nIn the third circle, Nar\xc3\xbdshkin was speaking of the meeting of the\nAustrian Council of War at which Suv\xc3\xb3rov crowed like a cock in reply to\nthe nonsense talked by the Austrian generals. Shinsh\xc3\xadn, standing close\nby, tried to make a joke, saying that Kut\xc3\xbazov had evidently failed to\nlearn from Suv\xc3\xb3rov even so simple a thing as the art of crowing like a\ncock, but the elder members glanced severely at the wit, making him\nfeel that in that place and on that day, it was improper to speak so of\nKut\xc3\xbazov.\n\nCount Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v, hurried and preoccupied, went about in his soft\nboots between the dining and drawing rooms, hastily greeting the\nimportant and unimportant, all of whom he knew, as if they were all\nequals, while his eyes occasionally sought out his fine well-set-up\nyoung son, resting on him and winking joyfully at him. Young Rost\xc3\xb3v\nstood at a window with D\xc3\xb3lokhov, whose acquaintance he had lately\nmade and highly valued. The old count came up to them and pressed\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease come and visit us... you know my brave boy... been together\nout there... both playing the hero... Ah, Vas\xc3\xadli Ign\xc3\xa1tovich...\nHow d\xe2\x80\x99ye do, old fellow?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, turning to an old man who was\npassing, but before he had finished his greeting there was a general\nstir, and a footman who had run in announced, with a frightened face:\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s arrived!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBells rang, the stewards rushed forward, and\xe2\x80\x94like rye shaken together\nin a shovel\xe2\x80\x94the guests who had been scattered about in different rooms\ncame together and crowded in the large drawing room by the door of the\nballroom.\n\nBagrati\xc3\xb3n appeared in the doorway of the anteroom without hat or sword,\nwhich, in accord with the club custom, he had given up to the hall\nporter. He had no lambskin cap on his head, nor had he a loaded whip\nover his shoulder, as when Rost\xc3\xb3v had seen him on the eve of the battle\nof Austerlitz, but wore a tight new uniform with Russian and foreign\nOrders, and the Star of St. George on his left breast. Evidently just\nbefore coming to the dinner he had had his hair and whiskers trimmed,\nwhich changed his appearance for the worse. There was something na\xc3\xafvely\nfestive in his air, which, in conjunction with his firm and virile\nfeatures, gave him a rather comical expression. Beklesh\xc3\xabv and Theodore\nUv\xc3\xa1rov, who had arrived with him, paused at the doorway to allow him,\nas the guest of honor, to enter first. Bagrati\xc3\xb3n was embarrassed, not\nwishing to avail himself of their courtesy, and this caused some delay\nat the doors, but after all he did at last enter first. He walked shyly\nand awkwardly over the parquet floor of the reception room, not knowing\nwhat to do with his hands; he was more accustomed to walk over a plowed\nfield under fire, as he had done at the head of the Kursk regiment at\nSch\xc3\xb6n Grabern\xe2\x80\x94and he would have found that easier. The committeemen\nmet him at the first door and, expressing their delight at seeing such a\nhighly honored guest, took possession of him as it were, without waiting\nfor his reply, surrounded him, and led him to the drawing room. It was\nat first impossible to enter the drawing room door for the crowd of\nmembers and guests jostling one another and trying to get a good look\nat Bagrati\xc3\xb3n over each other\xe2\x80\x99s shoulders, as if he were some rare\nanimal. Count Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v, laughing and repeating the words, \xe2\x80\x9cMake\nway, dear boy! Make way, make way!\xe2\x80\x9d pushed through the crowd more\nenergetically than anyone, led the guests into the drawing room, and\nseated them on the center sofa. The bigwigs, the most respected members\nof the club, beset the new arrivals. Count Ily\xc3\xa1, again thrusting his\nway through the crowd, went out of the drawing room and reappeared a\nminute later with another committeeman, carrying a large silver salver\nwhich he presented to Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n. On the salver lay some verses\ncomposed and printed in the hero\xe2\x80\x99s honor. Bagrati\xc3\xb3n, on seeing the\nsalver, glanced around in dismay, as though seeking help. But all eyes\ndemanded that he should submit. Feeling himself in their power, he\nresolutely took the salver with both hands and looked sternly and\nreproachfully at the count who had presented it to him. Someone\nobligingly took the dish from Bagrati\xc3\xb3n (or he would, it seemed, have\nheld it till evening and have gone in to dinner with it) and drew his\nattention to the verses.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I will read them, then!\xe2\x80\x9d Bagrati\xc3\xb3n seemed to say, and,\nfixing his weary eyes on the paper, began to read them with a fixed and\nserious expression. But the author himself took the verses and began\nreading them aloud. Bagrati\xc3\xb3n bowed his head and listened:\n\n   Bring glory then to Alexander\xe2\x80\x99s reign\n   And on the throne our Titus shield.\n   A dreaded foe be thou, kindhearted as a man,\n   A Rhipheus at home, a Caesar in the field!\n   E\xe2\x80\x99en fortunate Napoleon\n   Knows by experience, now, Bagrati\xc3\xb3n,\n   And dare not Herculean Russians trouble...\n\nBut before he had finished reading, a stentorian major-domo announced\nthat dinner was ready! The door opened, and from the dining room came\nthe resounding strains of the polonaise:\n\n   Conquest\xe2\x80\x99s joyful thunder waken,\n   Triumph, valiant Russians, now!...\n\nand Count Rost\xc3\xb3v, glancing angrily at the author who went on reading\nhis verses, bowed to Bagrati\xc3\xb3n. Everyone rose, feeling that dinner\nwas more important than verses, and Bagrati\xc3\xb3n, again preceding all the\nrest, went in to dinner. He was seated in the place of honor between\ntwo Alexanders\xe2\x80\x94Beklesh\xc3\xabv and Nar\xc3\xbdshkin\xe2\x80\x94which was a significant\nallusion to the name of the sovereign. Three hundred persons took their\nseats in the dining room, according to their rank and importance: the\nmore important nearer to the honored guest, as naturally as water flows\ndeepest where the land lies lowest.\n\nJust before dinner, Count Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v presented his son to Bagrati\xc3\xb3n,\nwho recognized him and said a few words to him, disjointed and awkward,\nas were all the words he spoke that day, and Count Ily\xc3\xa1 looked joyfully\nand proudly around while Bagrati\xc3\xb3n spoke to his son.\n\nNicholas Rost\xc3\xb3v, with Den\xc3\xadsov and his new acquaintance, D\xc3\xb3lokhov, sat\nalmost at the middle of the table. Facing them sat Pierre, beside Prince\nNesv\xc3\xadtski. Count Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v with the other members of the committee\nsat facing Bagrati\xc3\xb3n and, as the very personification of Moscow\nhospitality, did the honors to the prince.\n\nHis efforts had not been in vain. The dinner, both the Lenten and the\nother fare, was splendid, yet he could not feel quite at ease till the\nend of the meal. He winked at the butler, whispered directions to the\nfootmen, and awaited each expected dish with some anxiety. Everything\nwas excellent. With the second course, a gigantic sterlet (at sight of\nwhich Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v blushed with self-conscious pleasure), the footmen\nbegan popping corks and filling the champagne glasses. After the fish,\nwhich made a certain sensation, the count exchanged glances with\nthe other committeemen. \xe2\x80\x9cThere will be many toasts, it\xe2\x80\x99s time to\nbegin,\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered, and taking up his glass, he rose. All were\nsilent, waiting for what he would say.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the health of our Sovereign, the Emperor!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, and at the\nsame moment his kindly eyes grew moist with tears of joy and enthusiasm.\nThe band immediately struck up \xe2\x80\x9cConquest\xe2\x80\x99s joyful thunder\nwaken...\xe2\x80\x9d All rose and cried \xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d Bagrati\xc3\xb3n also rose and\nshouted \xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d in exactly the same voice in which he had shouted\nit on the field at Sch\xc3\xb6n Grabern. Young Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s ecstatic voice\ncould be heard above the three hundred others. He nearly wept. \xe2\x80\x9cTo the\nhealth of our Sovereign, the Emperor!\xe2\x80\x9d he roared, \xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d and\nemptying his glass at one gulp he dashed it to the floor. Many followed\nhis example, and the loud shouting continued for a long time. When the\nvoices subsided, the footmen cleared away the broken glass and everybody\nsat down again, smiling at the noise they had made and exchanging\nremarks. The old count rose once more, glanced at a note lying beside\nhis plate, and proposed a toast, \xe2\x80\x9cTo the health of the hero of our\nlast campaign, Prince Peter Iv\xc3\xa1novich Bagrati\xc3\xb3n!\xe2\x80\x9d and again his blue\neyes grew moist. \xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the three hundred voices again,\nbut instead of the band a choir began singing a cantata composed by Paul\nIv\xc3\xa1novich Kut\xc3\xbazov:\n\n   Russians! O\xe2\x80\x99er all barriers on!\n   Courage conquest guarantees;\n   Have we not Bagrati\xc3\xb3n?\n   He brings foemen to their knees,... etc.\n\nAs soon as the singing was over, another and another toast was proposed\nand Count Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v became more and more moved, more glass was\nsmashed, and the shouting grew louder. They drank to Beklesh\xc3\xabv,\nNar\xc3\xbdshkin, Uv\xc3\xa1rov, Dolgor\xc3\xbakov, Apr\xc3\xa1ksin, Val\xc3\xbaev, to the committee,\nto all the club members and to all the club guests, and finally to\nCount Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v separately, as the organizer of the banquet. At that\ntoast, the count took out his handkerchief and, covering his face, wept\noutright.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IV\n\nPierre sat opposite D\xc3\xb3lokhov and Nicholas Rost\xc3\xb3v. As usual, he ate and\ndrank much, and eagerly. But those who knew him intimately noticed that\nsome great change had come over him that day. He was silent all through\ndinner and looked about, blinking and scowling, or, with fixed eyes and\na look of complete absent-mindedness, kept rubbing the bridge of his\nnose. His face was depressed and gloomy. He seemed to see and hear\nnothing of what was going on around him and to be absorbed by some\ndepressing and unsolved problem.\n\nThe unsolved problem that tormented him was caused by hints given by the\nprincess, his cousin, at Moscow, concerning D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s intimacy with\nhis wife, and by an anonymous letter he had received that morning, which\nin the mean jocular way common to anonymous letters said that he saw\nbadly through his spectacles, but that his wife\xe2\x80\x99s connection with\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov was a secret to no one but himself. Pierre absolutely\ndisbelieved both the princess\xe2\x80\x99 hints and the letter, but he feared\nnow to look at D\xc3\xb3lokhov, who was sitting opposite him. Every time\nhe chanced to meet D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s handsome insolent eyes, Pierre felt\nsomething terrible and monstrous rising in his soul and turned quickly\naway. Involuntarily recalling his wife\xe2\x80\x99s past and her relations with\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov, Pierre saw clearly that what was said in the letter might be\ntrue, or might at least seem to be true had it not referred to his wife.\nHe involuntarily remembered how D\xc3\xb3lokhov, who had fully recovered his\nformer position after the campaign, had returned to Petersburg and come\nto him. Availing himself of his friendly relations with Pierre as a boon\ncompanion, D\xc3\xb3lokhov had come straight to his house, and Pierre had put\nhim up and lent him money. Pierre recalled how H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne had smilingly\nexpressed disapproval of D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s living at their house, and how\ncynically D\xc3\xb3lokhov had praised his wife\xe2\x80\x99s beauty to him and from that\ntime till they came to Moscow had not left them for a day.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he is very handsome,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Pierre, \xe2\x80\x9cand I know him. It\nwould be particularly pleasant to him to dishonor my name and ridicule\nme, just because I have exerted myself on his behalf, befriended him,\nand helped him. I know and understand what a spice that would add to the\npleasure of deceiving me, if it really were true. Yes, if it were true,\nbut I do not believe it. I have no right to, and can\xe2\x80\x99t, believe it.\xe2\x80\x9d\nHe remembered the expression D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s face assumed in his moments\nof cruelty, as when tying the policeman to the bear and dropping them\ninto the water, or when he challenged a man to a duel without any\nreason, or shot a post-boy\xe2\x80\x99s horse with a pistol. That expression\nwas often on D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s face when looking at him. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, he is a\nbully,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Pierre, \xe2\x80\x9cto kill a man means nothing to him. It must\nseem to him that everyone is afraid of him, and that must please him.\nHe must think that I, too, am afraid of him\xe2\x80\x94and in fact I am afraid of\nhim,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, and again he felt something terrible and monstrous\nrising in his soul. D\xc3\xb3lokhov, Den\xc3\xadsov, and Rost\xc3\xb3v were now sitting\nopposite Pierre and seemed very gay. Rost\xc3\xb3v was talking merrily to his\ntwo friends, one of whom was a dashing hussar and the other a notorious\nduelist and rake, and every now and then he glanced ironically at\nPierre, whose preoccupied, absent-minded, and massive figure was a very\nnoticeable one at the dinner. Rost\xc3\xb3v looked inimically at Pierre,\nfirst because Pierre appeared to his hussar eyes as a rich civilian, the\nhusband of a beauty, and in a word\xe2\x80\x94an old woman; and secondly because\nPierre in his preoccupation and absent-mindedness had not recognized\nRost\xc3\xb3v and had not responded to his greeting. When the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s\nhealth was drunk, Pierre, lost in thought, did not rise or lift his\nglass.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you about?\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Rost\xc3\xb3v, looking at him in an ecstasy\nof exasperation. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you hear it\xe2\x80\x99s His Majesty the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s\nhealth?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre sighed, rose submissively, emptied his glass, and, waiting till\nall were seated again, turned with his kindly smile to Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t recognize you!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. But Rost\xc3\xb3v was otherwise\nengaged; he was shouting \xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you renew the acquaintance?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov to Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cConfound him, he\xe2\x80\x99s a fool!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne should make up to the husbands of pretty women,\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\nPierre did not catch what they were saying, but knew they were talking\nabout him. He reddened and turned away.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now to the health of handsome women!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov, and\nwith a serious expression, but with a smile lurking at the corners of\nhis mouth, he turned with his glass to Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s to the health of lovely women, Peterkin\xe2\x80\x94and their\nlovers!\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\n\nPierre, with downcast eyes, drank out of his glass without looking at\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov or answering him. The footman, who was distributing leaflets\nwith Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s cantata, laid one before Pierre as one of the\nprincipal guests. He was just going to take it when D\xc3\xb3lokhov, leaning\nacross, snatched it from his hand and began reading it. Pierre looked\nat D\xc3\xb3lokhov and his eyes dropped, the something terrible and monstrous\nthat had tormented him all dinnertime rose and took possession of him.\nHe leaned his whole massive body across the table.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow dare you take it?\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted.\n\nHearing that cry and seeing to whom it was addressed, Nesv\xc3\xadtski and the\nneighbor on his right quickly turned in alarm to Bez\xc3\xbakhov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t! Don\xe2\x80\x99t! What are you about?\xe2\x80\x9d whispered their frightened\nvoices.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov looked at Pierre with clear, mirthful, cruel eyes, and that\nsmile of his which seemed to say, \xe2\x80\x9cAh! This is what I like!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shan\xe2\x80\x99t have it!\xe2\x80\x9d he said distinctly.\n\nPale, with quivering lips, Pierre snatched the copy.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou...! you... scoundrel! I challenge you!\xe2\x80\x9d he ejaculated, and,\npushing back his chair, he rose from the table.\n\nAt the very instant he did this and uttered those words, Pierre felt\nthat the question of his wife\xe2\x80\x99s guilt which had been tormenting him\nthe whole day was finally and indubitably answered in the affirmative.\nHe hated her and was forever sundered from her. Despite Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s\nrequest that he would take no part in the matter, Rost\xc3\xb3v agreed to be\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s second, and after dinner he discussed the arrangements for\nthe duel with Nesv\xc3\xadtski, Bez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s second. Pierre went home, but\nRost\xc3\xb3v with D\xc3\xb3lokhov and Den\xc3\xadsov stayed on at the club till late,\nlistening to the gypsies and other singers.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then, till tomorrow at Sok\xc3\xb3lniki,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov, as he took\nleave of Rost\xc3\xb3v in the club porch.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you feel quite calm?\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v asked.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov paused.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you see, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you the whole secret of dueling in two\nwords. If you are going to fight a duel, and you make a will and write\naffectionate letters to your parents, and if you think you may be\nkilled, you are a fool and are lost for certain. But go with the firm\nintention of killing your man as quickly and surely as possible, and\nthen all will be right, as our bear huntsman at Kostrom\xc3\xa1 used to tell\nme. \xe2\x80\x98Everyone fears a bear,\xe2\x80\x99 he says, \xe2\x80\x98but when you see one your\nfear\xe2\x80\x99s all gone, and your only thought is not to let him get away!\xe2\x80\x99\nAnd that\xe2\x80\x99s how it is with me. \xc3\x80 demain, mon cher.\xe2\x80\x9d *\n\n    * Till tomorrow, my dear fellow.\n\nNext day, at eight in the morning, Pierre and Nesv\xc3\xadtski drove to the\nSok\xc3\xb3lniki forest and found D\xc3\xb3lokhov, Den\xc3\xadsov, and Rost\xc3\xb3v already\nthere. Pierre had the air of a man preoccupied with considerations which\nhad no connection with the matter in hand. His haggard face was yellow.\nHe had evidently not slept that night. He looked about distractedly and\nscrewed up his eyes as if dazzled by the sun. He was entirely absorbed\nby two considerations: his wife\xe2\x80\x99s guilt, of which after his sleepless\nnight he had not the slightest doubt, and the guiltlessness of\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov, who had no reason to preserve the honor of a man who was\nnothing to him.... \xe2\x80\x9cI should perhaps have done the same thing in his\nplace,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Pierre. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s even certain that I should have done\nthe same, then why this duel, this murder? Either I shall kill him, or\nhe will hit me in the head, or elbow, or knee. Can\xe2\x80\x99t I go away from\nhere, run away, bury myself somewhere?\xe2\x80\x9d passed through his mind. But\njust at moments when such thoughts occurred to him, he would ask in a\nparticularly calm and absent-minded way, which inspired the respect of\nthe onlookers, \xe2\x80\x9cWill it be long? Are things ready?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nWhen all was ready, the sabers stuck in the snow to mark the barriers,\nand the pistols loaded, Nesv\xc3\xadtski went up to Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should not be doing my duty, Count,\xe2\x80\x9d he said in timid tones,\n\xe2\x80\x9cand should not justify your confidence and the honor you have done\nme in choosing me for your second, if at this grave, this very\ngrave, moment I did not tell you the whole truth. I think there is no\nsufficient ground for this affair, or for blood to be shed over it....\nYou were not right, not quite in the right, you were impetuous...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, it is horribly stupid,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen allow me to express your regrets, and I am sure your opponent\nwill accept them,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nesv\xc3\xadtski (who like the others concerned in\nthe affair, and like everyone in similar cases, did not yet believe that\nthe affair had come to an actual duel). \xe2\x80\x9cYou know, Count, it is much\nmore honorable to admit one\xe2\x80\x99s mistake than to let matters become\nirreparable. There was no insult on either side. Allow me to\nconvey....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! What is there to talk about?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all the\nsame.... Is everything ready?\xe2\x80\x9d he added. \xe2\x80\x9cOnly tell me where to go\nand where to shoot,\xe2\x80\x9d he said with an unnaturally gentle smile.\n\nHe took the pistol in his hand and began asking about the working of the\ntrigger, as he had not before held a pistol in his hand\xe2\x80\x94a fact that he\ndid not wish to confess.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, like that, I know, I only forgot,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo apologies, none whatever,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov to Den\xc3\xadsov (who on\nhis side had been attempting a reconciliation), and he also went up to\nthe appointed place.\n\nThe spot chosen for the duel was some eighty paces from the road,\nwhere the sleighs had been left, in a small clearing in the pine forest\ncovered with melting snow, the frost having begun to break up during the\nlast few days. The antagonists stood forty paces apart at the farther\nedge of the clearing. The seconds, measuring the paces, left tracks in\nthe deep wet snow between the place where they had been standing and\nNesv\xc3\xadtski\xe2\x80\x99s and D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s sabers, which were stuck into the\nground ten paces apart to mark the barrier. It was thawing and misty; at\nforty paces\xe2\x80\x99 distance nothing could be seen. For three minutes all had\nbeen ready, but they still delayed and all were silent.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER V\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, begin!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, still smiling in the same way. A feeling\nof dread was in the air. It was evident that the affair so lightly begun\ncould no longer be averted but was taking its course independently of\nmen\xe2\x80\x99s will.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov first went to the barrier and announced: \xe2\x80\x9cAs the\nadve\xe2\x80\x99sawies have wefused a weconciliation, please pwoceed. Take your\npistols, and at the word thwee begin to advance.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cO-ne! T-wo! Thwee!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted angrily and stepped aside.\n\nThe combatants advanced along the trodden tracks, nearer and nearer to\none another, beginning to see one another through the mist. They had the\nright to fire when they liked as they approached the barrier. D\xc3\xb3lokhov\nwalked slowly without raising his pistol, looking intently with his\nbright, sparkling blue eyes into his antagonist\xe2\x80\x99s face. His mouth wore\nits usual semblance of a smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo I can fire when I like!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, and at the word\n\xe2\x80\x9cthree,\xe2\x80\x9d he went quickly forward, missing the trodden path and\nstepping into the deep snow. He held the pistol in his right hand at\narm\xe2\x80\x99s length, apparently afraid of shooting himself with it. His left\nhand he held carefully back, because he wished to support his right\nhand with it and knew he must not do so. Having advanced six paces and\nstrayed off the track into the snow, Pierre looked down at his feet,\nthen quickly glanced at D\xc3\xb3lokhov and, bending his finger as he had been\nshown, fired. Not at all expecting so loud a report, Pierre shuddered\nat the sound and then, smiling at his own sensations, stood still. The\nsmoke, rendered denser by the mist, prevented him from seeing anything\nfor an instant, but there was no second report as he had expected. He\nonly heard D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s hurried steps, and his figure came in view\nthrough the smoke. He was pressing one hand to his left side, while\nthe other clutched his drooping pistol. His face was pale. Rost\xc3\xb3v ran\ntoward him and said something.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo-o-o!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered D\xc3\xb3lokhov through his teeth, \xe2\x80\x9cno, it\xe2\x80\x99s not\nover.\xe2\x80\x9d And after stumbling a few staggering steps right up to the\nsaber, he sank on the snow beside it. His left hand was bloody; he wiped\nit on his coat and supported himself with it. His frowning face was\npallid and quivered.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlea...\xe2\x80\x9d began D\xc3\xb3lokhov, but could not at first pronounce the\nword.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease,\xe2\x80\x9d he uttered with an effort.\n\nPierre, hardly restraining his sobs, began running toward D\xc3\xb3lokhov and\nwas about to cross the space between the barriers, when D\xc3\xb3lokhov cried:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo your barrier!\xe2\x80\x9d and Pierre, grasping what was meant, stopped by\nhis saber. Only ten paces divided them. D\xc3\xb3lokhov lowered his head to\nthe snow, greedily bit at it, again raised his head, adjusted himself,\ndrew in his legs and sat up, seeking a firm center of gravity. He sucked\nand swallowed the cold snow, his lips quivered but his eyes, still\nsmiling, glittered with effort and exasperation as he mustered his\nremaining strength. He raised his pistol and aimed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSideways! Cover yourself with your pistol!\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated Nesv\xc3\xadtski.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCover yourself!\xe2\x80\x9d even Den\xc3\xadsov cried to his adversary.\n\nPierre, with a gentle smile of pity and remorse, his arms and legs\nhelplessly spread out, stood with his broad chest directly facing\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov and looked sorrowfully at him. Den\xc3\xadsov, Rost\xc3\xb3v, and\nNesv\xc3\xadtski closed their eyes. At the same instant they heard a report\nand D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s angry cry.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMissed!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted D\xc3\xb3lokhov, and he lay helplessly, face downwards\non the snow.\n\nPierre clutched his temples, and turning round went into the forest,\ntrampling through the deep snow, and muttering incoherent words:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFolly... folly! Death... lies...\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, puckering his face.\n\nNesv\xc3\xadtski stopped him and took him home.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v and Den\xc3\xadsov drove away with the wounded D\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\nThe latter lay silent in the sleigh with closed eyes and did not answer\na word to the questions addressed to him. But on entering Moscow he\nsuddenly came to and, lifting his head with an effort, took Rost\xc3\xb3v, who\nwas sitting beside him, by the hand. Rost\xc3\xb3v was struck by the\ntotally altered and unexpectedly rapturous and tender expression on\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell? How do you feel?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBad! But it\xe2\x80\x99s not that, my friend\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov with a\ngasping voice. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere are we? In Moscow, I know. I don\xe2\x80\x99t matter,\nbut I have killed her, killed... She won\xe2\x80\x99t get over it! She won\xe2\x80\x99t\nsurvive....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy mother! My mother, my angel, my adored angel mother,\xe2\x80\x9d and\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov pressed Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s hand and burst into tears.\n\nWhen he had become a little quieter, he explained to Rost\xc3\xb3v that he was\nliving with his mother, who, if she saw him dying, would not survive it.\nHe implored Rost\xc3\xb3v to go on and prepare her.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v went on ahead to do what was asked, and to his great surprise\nlearned that D\xc3\xb3lokhov the brawler, D\xc3\xb3lokhov the bully, lived in Moscow\nwith an old mother and a hunchback sister, and was the most affectionate\nof sons and brothers.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VI\n\nPierre had of late rarely seen his wife alone. Both in Petersburg and in\nMoscow their house was always full of visitors. The night after the\nduel he did not go to his bedroom but, as he often did, remained in his\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s room, that huge room in which Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov had died.\n\nHe lay down on the sofa meaning to fall asleep and forget all that\nhad happened to him, but could not do so. Such a storm of feelings,\nthoughts, and memories suddenly arose within him that he could not fall\nasleep, nor even remain in one place, but had to jump up and pace the\nroom with rapid steps. Now he seemed to see her in the early days of\ntheir marriage, with bare shoulders and a languid, passionate look on\nher face, and then immediately he saw beside her D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s handsome,\ninsolent, hard, and mocking face as he had seen it at the banquet, and\nthen that same face pale, quivering, and suffering, as it had been when\nhe reeled and sank on the snow.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has happened?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked himself. \xe2\x80\x9cI have killed her lover,\nyes, killed my wife\xe2\x80\x99s lover. Yes, that was it! And why? How did I come\nto do it?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you married her,\xe2\x80\x9d answered an inner voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut in what was I to blame?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cIn marrying her without\nloving her; in deceiving yourself and her.\xe2\x80\x9d And he vividly recalled\nthat moment after supper at Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s, when he spoke those\nwords he had found so difficult to utter: \xe2\x80\x9cI love you.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cIt all\ncomes from that! Even then I felt it,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cI felt then that\nit was not so, that I had no right to do it. And so it turns out.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe remembered his honeymoon and blushed at the recollection.\nParticularly vivid, humiliating, and shameful was the recollection of\nhow one day soon after his marriage he came out of the bedroom into his\nstudy a little before noon in his silk dressing gown and found his head\nsteward there, who, bowing respectfully, looked into his face and at\nhis dressing gown and smiled slightly, as if expressing respectful\nunderstanding of his employer\xe2\x80\x99s happiness.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how often I have felt proud of her, proud of her majestic beauty\nand social tact,\xe2\x80\x9d thought he; \xe2\x80\x9cbeen proud of my house, in which she\nreceived all Petersburg, proud of her unapproachability and beauty. So\nthis is what I was proud of! I then thought that I did not understand\nher. How often when considering her character I have told myself that\nI was to blame for not understanding her, for not understanding that\nconstant composure and complacency and lack of all interests or desires,\nand the whole secret lies in the terrible truth that she is a depraved\nwoman. Now I have spoken that terrible word to myself all has become\nclear.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnatole used to come to borrow money from her and used to kiss her\nnaked shoulders. She did not give him the money, but let herself be\nkissed. Her father in jest tried to rouse her jealousy, and she replied\nwith a calm smile that she was not so stupid as to be jealous: \xe2\x80\x98Let\nhim do what he pleases,\xe2\x80\x99 she used to say of me. One day I asked her if\nshe felt any symptoms of pregnancy. She laughed contemptuously and said\nshe was not a fool to want to have children, and that she was not going\nto have any children by me.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThen he recalled the coarseness and bluntness of her thoughts and the\nvulgarity of the expressions that were natural to her, though she had\nbeen brought up in the most aristocratic circles.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not such a fool.... Just you try it on.... Allez-vous\npromener,\xe2\x80\x9d * she used to say. Often seeing the success she had with\nyoung and old men and women Pierre could not understand why he did not\nlove her.\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cYou clear out of this.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I never loved her,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to himself; \xe2\x80\x9cI knew she was a\ndepraved woman,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, \xe2\x80\x9cbut dared not admit it to myself.\nAnd now there\xe2\x80\x99s D\xc3\xb3lokhov sitting in the snow with a forced smile and\nperhaps dying, while meeting my remorse with some forced bravado!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre was one of those people who, in spite of an appearance of what\nis called weak character, do not seek a confidant in their troubles. He\ndigested his sufferings alone.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is all, all her fault,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself; \xe2\x80\x9cbut what of that?\nWhy did I bind myself to her? Why did I say \xe2\x80\x98Je vous aime\xe2\x80\x99 * to her,\nwhich was a lie, and worse than a lie? I am guilty and must endure...\nwhat? A slur on my name? A misfortune for life? Oh, that\xe2\x80\x99s\nnonsense,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cThe slur on my name and honor\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all\napart from myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n    * I love you.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLouis XVI was executed because they said he was dishonorable and a\ncriminal,\xe2\x80\x9d came into Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s head, \xe2\x80\x9cand from their point of\nview they were right, as were those too who canonized him and died a\nmartyr\xe2\x80\x99s death for his sake. Then Robespierre was beheaded for being\na despot. Who is right and who is wrong? No one! But if you are\nalive\xe2\x80\x94live: tomorrow you\xe2\x80\x99ll die as I might have died an hour ago.\nAnd is it worth tormenting oneself, when one has only a moment of life\nin comparison with eternity?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBut at the moment when he imagined himself calmed by such reflections,\nshe suddenly came into his mind as she was at the moments when he had\nmost strongly expressed his insincere love for her, and he felt the\nblood rush to his heart and had again to get up and move about and break\nand tear whatever came to his hand. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy did I tell her that \xe2\x80\x98Je\nvous aime\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d he kept repeating to himself. And when he had said it\nfor the tenth time, Moli\xc3\xa8re\xe2\x80\x99s words: \xe2\x80\x9cMais que diable allait-il\nfaire dans cette gal\xc3\xa8re?\xe2\x80\x9d * occurred to him, and he began to laugh at\nhimself.\n\n      * \xe2\x80\x9cBut what the devil was he doing in that galley?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nIn the night he called his valet and told him to pack up to go to\nPetersburg. He could not imagine how he could speak to her now. He\nresolved to go away next day and leave a letter informing her of his\nintention to part from her forever.\n\nNext morning when the valet came into the room with his coffee, Pierre\nwas lying asleep on the ottoman with an open book in his hand.\n\nHe woke up and looked round for a while with a startled expression,\nunable to realize where he was.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe countess told me to inquire whether your excellency was at\nhome,\xe2\x80\x9d said the valet.\n\nBut before Pierre could decide what answer he would send, the countess\nherself in a white satin dressing gown embroidered with silver and with\nsimply dressed hair (two immense plaits twice round her lovely head like\na coronet) entered the room, calm and majestic, except that there was\na wrathful wrinkle on her rather prominent marble brow. With her\nimperturbable calm she did not begin to speak in front of the valet.\nShe knew of the duel and had come to speak about it. She waited till the\nvalet had set down the coffee things and left the room. Pierre looked\nat her timidly over his spectacles, and like a hare surrounded by hounds\nwho lays back her ears and continues to crouch motionless before her\nenemies, he tried to continue reading. But feeling this to be senseless\nand impossible, he again glanced timidly at her. She did not sit down\nbut looked at him with a contemptuous smile, waiting for the valet to\ngo.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what\xe2\x80\x99s this now? What have you been up to now, I should like\nto know?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked sternly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? What have I...?\xe2\x80\x9d stammered Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo it seems you\xe2\x80\x99re a hero, eh? Come now, what was this duel about?\nWhat is it meant to prove? What? I ask you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre turned over heavily on the ottoman and opened his mouth, but\ncould not reply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you won\xe2\x80\x99t answer, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you...\xe2\x80\x9d H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne went on. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\nbelieve everything you\xe2\x80\x99re told. You were told...\xe2\x80\x9d H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne laughed,\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat D\xc3\xb3lokhov was my lover,\xe2\x80\x9d she said in French with her coarse\nplainness of speech, uttering the word amant as casually as any other\nword, \xe2\x80\x9cand you believed it! Well, what have you proved? What does this\nduel prove? That you\xe2\x80\x99re a fool, que vous \xc3\xaates un sot, but everybody\nknew that. What will be the result? That I shall be the laughingstock of\nall Moscow, that everyone will say that you, drunk and not knowing what\nyou were about, challenged a man you are jealous of without cause.\xe2\x80\x9d\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne raised her voice and became more and more excited, \xe2\x80\x9cA man\nwho\xe2\x80\x99s a better man than you in every way...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHm... Hm...!\xe2\x80\x9d growled Pierre, frowning without looking at her, and\nnot moving a muscle.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how could you believe he was my lover? Why? Because I like\nhis company? If you were cleverer and more agreeable, I should prefer\nyours.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t speak to me... I beg you,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Pierre hoarsely.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t I speak? I can speak as I like, and I tell you\nplainly that there are not many wives with husbands such as you who\nwould not have taken lovers (des amants), but I have not done so,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid she.\n\nPierre wished to say something, looked at her with eyes whose strange\nexpression she did not understand, and lay down again. He was suffering\nphysically at that moment, there was a weight on his chest and he could\nnot breathe. He knew that he must do something to put an end to this\nsuffering, but what he wanted to do was too terrible.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe had better separate,\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered in a broken voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeparate? Very well, but only if you give me a fortune,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne. \xe2\x80\x9cSeparate! That\xe2\x80\x99s a thing to frighten me with!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre leaped up from the sofa and rushed staggering toward her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll kill you!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted, and seizing the marble top of a table\nwith a strength he had never before felt, he made a step toward her\nbrandishing the slab.\n\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s face became terrible, she shrieked and sprang aside. His\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s nature showed itself in Pierre. He felt the fascination and\ndelight of frenzy. He flung down the slab, broke it, and swooping\ndown on her with outstretched hands shouted, \xe2\x80\x9cGet out!\xe2\x80\x9d in such a\nterrible voice that the whole house heard it with horror. God knows what\nhe would have done at that moment had H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne not fled from the room.\n\n\nA week later Pierre gave his wife full power to control all his estates\nin Great Russia, which formed the larger part of his property, and left\nfor Petersburg alone.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VII\n\nTwo months had elapsed since the news of the battle of Austerlitz and\nthe loss of Prince Andrew had reached Bald Hills, and in spite of the\nletters sent through the embassy and all the searches made, his body had\nnot been found nor was he on the list of prisoners. What was worst of\nall for his relations was the fact that there was still a possibility of\nhis having been picked up on the battlefield by the people of the\nplace and that he might now be lying, recovering or dying, alone among\nstrangers and unable to send news of himself. The gazettes from which\nthe old prince first heard of the defeat at Austerlitz stated, as usual\nvery briefly and vaguely, that after brilliant engagements the Russians\nhad had to retreat and had made their withdrawal in perfect order. The\nold prince understood from this official report that our army had been\ndefeated. A week after the gazette report of the battle of Austerlitz\ncame a letter from Kut\xc3\xbazov informing the prince of the fate that had\nbefallen his son.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour son,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote Kut\xc3\xbazov, \xe2\x80\x9cfell before my eyes, a standard in\nhis hand and at the head of a regiment\xe2\x80\x94he fell as a hero, worthy of\nhis father and his fatherland. To the great regret of myself and of the\nwhole army it is still uncertain whether he is alive or not. I comfort\nmyself and you with the hope that your son is alive, for otherwise\nhe would have been mentioned among the officers found on the field of\nbattle, a list of whom has been sent me under flag of truce.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAfter receiving this news late in the evening, when he was alone in his\nstudy, the old prince went for his walk as usual next morning, but he\nwas silent with his steward, the gardener, and the architect, and though\nhe looked very grim he said nothing to anyone.\n\nWhen Princess Mary went to him at the usual hour he was working at his\nlathe and, as usual, did not look round at her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Princess Mary!\xe2\x80\x9d he said suddenly in an unnatural voice,\nthrowing down his chisel. (The wheel continued to revolve by its own\nimpetus, and Princess Mary long remembered the dying creak of that\nwheel, which merged in her memory with what followed.)\n\nShe approached him, saw his face, and something gave way within her. Her\neyes grew dim. By the expression of her father\xe2\x80\x99s face, not sad, not\ncrushed, but angry and working unnaturally, she saw that hanging over\nher and about to crush her was some terrible misfortune, the worst\nin life, one she had not yet experienced, irreparable and\nincomprehensible\xe2\x80\x94the death of one she loved.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather! Andrew!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94said the ungraceful, awkward princess with such\nan indescribable charm of sorrow and self-forgetfulness that her father\ncould not bear her look but turned away with a sob.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBad news! He\xe2\x80\x99s not among the prisoners nor among the killed!\nKut\xc3\xbazov writes...\xe2\x80\x9d and he screamed as piercingly as if he wished to\ndrive the princess away by that scream... \xe2\x80\x9cKilled!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe princess did not fall down or faint. She was already pale, but on\nhearing these words her face changed and something brightened in her\nbeautiful, radiant eyes. It was as if joy\xe2\x80\x94a supreme joy apart from the\njoys and sorrows of this world\xe2\x80\x94overflowed the great grief within her.\nShe forgot all fear of her father, went up to him, took his hand, and\ndrawing him down put her arm round his thin, scraggy neck.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not turn away from me, let us weep\ntogether.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cScoundrels! Blackguards!\xe2\x80\x9d shrieked the old man, turning his face\naway from her. \xe2\x80\x9cDestroying the army, destroying the men! And why? Go,\ngo and tell Lise.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe princess sank helplessly into an armchair beside her father and\nwept. She saw her brother now as he had been at the moment when he took\nleave of her and of Lise, his look tender yet proud.
