She saw him tender\nand amused as he was when he put on the little icon. \xe2\x80\x9cDid he believe?\nHad he repented of his unbelief? Was he now there? There in the realms\nof eternal peace and blessedness?\xe2\x80\x9d she thought.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather, tell me how it happened,\xe2\x80\x9d she asked through her tears.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo! Go! Killed in battle, where the best of Russian men and\nRussia\xe2\x80\x99s glory were led to destruction. Go, Princess Mary. Go and tell\nLise. I will follow.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nWhen Princess Mary returned from her father, the little princess sat\nworking and looked up with that curious expression of inner, happy calm\npeculiar to pregnant women. It was evident that her eyes did not see\nPrincess Mary but were looking within... into herself... at something\njoyful and mysterious taking place within her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMary,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, moving away from the embroidery frame and lying\nback, \xe2\x80\x9cgive me your hand.\xe2\x80\x9d She took her sister-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s hand and\nheld it below her waist.\n\nHer eyes were smiling expectantly, her downy lip rose and remained\nlifted in childlike happiness.\n\nPrincess Mary knelt down before her and hid her face in the folds of her\nsister-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s dress.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, there! Do you feel it? I feel so strange. And do you know,\nMary, I am going to love him very much,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lise, looking with\nbright and happy eyes at her sister-in-law.\n\nPrincess Mary could not lift her head, she was weeping.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter, Mary?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing... only I feel sad... sad about Andrew,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, wiping\naway her tears on her sister-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s knee.\n\nSeveral times in the course of the morning Princess Mary began trying to\nprepare her sister-in-law, and every time began to cry. Unobservant as\nwas the little princess, these tears, the cause of which she did not\nunderstand, agitated her. She said nothing but looked about uneasily as\nif in search of something. Before dinner the old prince, of whom she was\nalways afraid, came into her room with a peculiarly restless and malign\nexpression and went out again without saying a word. She looked at\nPrincess Mary, then sat thinking for a while with that expression of\nattention to something within her that is only seen in pregnant women,\nand suddenly began to cry.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas anything come from Andrew?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you know it\xe2\x80\x99s too soon for news. But my father is anxious and I\nfeel afraid.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Princess Mary, looking firmly with her radiant\neyes at her sister-in-law.\n\nShe had determined not to tell her and persuaded her father to hide the\nterrible news from her till after her confinement, which was expected\nwithin a few days. Princess Mary and the old prince each bore and hid\ntheir grief in their own way. The old prince would not cherish any hope:\nhe made up his mind that Prince Andrew had been killed, and though he\nsent an official to Austria to seek for traces of his son, he ordered a\nmonument from Moscow which he intended to erect in his own garden to his\nmemory, and he told everybody that his son had been killed. He tried not\nto change his former way of life, but his strength failed him. He walked\nless, ate less, slept less, and became weaker every day. Princess Mary\nhoped. She prayed for her brother as living and was always awaiting news\nof his return.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VIII\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDearest,\xe2\x80\x9d said the little princess after breakfast on the morning\nof the nineteenth March, and her downy little lip rose from old habit,\nbut as sorrow was manifest in every smile, the sound of every word, and\neven every footstep in that house since the terrible news had come, so\nnow the smile of the little princess\xe2\x80\x94influenced by the general mood\nthough without knowing its cause\xe2\x80\x94was such as to remind one still more\nof the general sorrow.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDearest, I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid this morning\xe2\x80\x99s fruschtique *\xe2\x80\x94as F\xc3\xb3ka the\ncook calls it\xe2\x80\x94has disagreed with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n    * Fr\xc3\xbchst\xc3\xbcck: breakfast.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter with you, my darling? You look pale. Oh, you\nare very pale!\xe2\x80\x9d said Princess Mary in alarm, running with her soft,\nponderous steps up to her sister-in-law.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency, should not Mary Bogd\xc3\xa1novna be sent for?\xe2\x80\x9d said one\nof the maids who was present. (Mary Bogd\xc3\xa1novna was a midwife from the\nneighboring town, who had been at Bald Hills for the last fortnight.)\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes,\xe2\x80\x9d assented Princess Mary, \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps that\xe2\x80\x99s it. I\xe2\x80\x99ll go.\nCourage, my angel.\xe2\x80\x9d She kissed Lise and was about to leave the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, no!\xe2\x80\x9d And besides the pallor and the physical suffering\non the little princess\xe2\x80\x99 face, an expression of childish fear of\ninevitable pain showed itself.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it\xe2\x80\x99s only indigestion?... Say it\xe2\x80\x99s only indigestion, say so,\nMary! Say...\xe2\x80\x9d And the little princess began to cry capriciously like\na suffering child and to wring her little hands even with some\naffectation. Princess Mary ran out of the room to fetch Mary\nBogd\xc3\xa1novna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMon Dieu! Mon Dieu! Oh!\xe2\x80\x9d she heard as she left the room.\n\nThe midwife was already on her way to meet her, rubbing her small, plump\nwhite hands with an air of calm importance.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMary Bogd\xc3\xa1novna, I think it\xe2\x80\x99s beginning!\xe2\x80\x9d said Princess Mary\nlooking at the midwife with wide-open eyes of alarm.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, the Lord be thanked, Princess,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary Bogd\xc3\xa1novna, not\nhastening her steps. \xe2\x80\x9cYou young ladies should not know anything about\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how is it the doctor from Moscow is not here yet?\xe2\x80\x9d said the\nprincess. (In accordance with Lise\xe2\x80\x99s and Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s wishes they\nhad sent in good time to Moscow for a doctor and were expecting him at\nany moment.)\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo matter, Princess, don\xe2\x80\x99t be alarmed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary Bogd\xc3\xa1novna.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll manage very well without a doctor.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nFive minutes later Princess Mary from her room heard something heavy\nbeing carried by. She looked out. The men servants were carrying the\nlarge leather sofa from Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s study into the bedroom. On\ntheir faces was a quiet and solemn look.\n\nPrincess Mary sat alone in her room listening to the sounds in the\nhouse, now and then opening her door when someone passed and watching\nwhat was going on in the passage. Some women passing with quiet steps in\nand out of the bedroom glanced at the princess and turned away. She did\nnot venture to ask any questions, and shut the door again, now sitting\ndown in her easy chair, now taking her prayer book, now kneeling before\nthe icon stand. To her surprise and distress she found that her prayers\ndid not calm her excitement. Suddenly her door opened softly and her old\nnurse, Prask\xc3\xb3vya S\xc3\xa1vishna, who hardly ever came to that room as the\nold prince had forbidden it, appeared on the threshold with a shawl\nround her head.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve come to sit with you a bit, M\xc3\xa1sha,\xe2\x80\x9d said the nurse, \xe2\x80\x9cand\nhere I\xe2\x80\x99ve brought the prince\xe2\x80\x99s wedding candles to light before his\nsaint, my angel,\xe2\x80\x9d she said with a sigh.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nurse, I\xe2\x80\x99m so glad!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod is merciful, birdie.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe nurse lit the gilt candles before the icons and sat down by the door\nwith her knitting. Princess Mary took a book and began reading. Only\nwhen footsteps or voices were heard did they look at one another, the\nprincess anxious and inquiring, the nurse encouraging. Everyone in the\nhouse was dominated by the same feeling that Princess Mary experienced\nas she sat in her room. But owing to the superstition that the fewer\nthe people who know of it the less a woman in travail suffers, everyone\ntried to pretend not to know; no one spoke of it, but apart from the\nordinary staid and respectful good manners habitual in the prince\xe2\x80\x99s\nhousehold, a common anxiety, a softening of the heart, and a\nconsciousness that something great and mysterious was being accomplished\nat that moment made itself felt.\n\nThere was no laughter in the maids\xe2\x80\x99 large hall. In the men servants\xe2\x80\x99\nhall all sat waiting, silently and alert. In the outlying serfs\xe2\x80\x99\nquarters torches and candles were burning and no one slept. The old\nprince, stepping on his heels, paced up and down his study and sent\nT\xc3\xadkhon to ask Mary Bogd\xc3\xa1novna what news.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSay only that \xe2\x80\x98the\nprince told me to ask,\xe2\x80\x99 and come and tell me her answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cInform the prince that labor has begun,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary Bogd\xc3\xa1novna,\ngiving the messenger a significant look.\n\nT\xc3\xadkhon went and told the prince.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good!\xe2\x80\x9d said the prince closing the door behind him, and\nT\xc3\xadkhon did not hear the slightest sound from the study after that.\n\nAfter a while he re-entered it as if to snuff the candles, and, seeing\nthe prince was lying on the sofa, looked at him, noticed his perturbed\nface, shook his head, and going up to him silently kissed him on the\nshoulder and left the room without snuffing the candles or saying why he\nhad entered. The most solemn mystery in the world continued its course.\nEvening passed, night came, and the feeling of suspense and softening of\nheart in the presence of the unfathomable did not lessen but increased.\nNo one slept.\n\nIt was one of those March nights when winter seems to wish to resume its\nsway and scatters its last snows and storms with desperate fury. A relay\nof horses had been sent up the highroad to meet the German doctor from\nMoscow who was expected every moment, and men on horseback with lanterns\nwere sent to the crossroads to guide him over the country road with its\nhollows and snow-covered pools of water.\n\nPrincess Mary had long since put aside her book: she sat silent, her\nluminous eyes fixed on her nurse\xe2\x80\x99s wrinkled face (every line of which\nshe knew so well), on the lock of gray hair that escaped from under the\nkerchief, and the loose skin that hung under her chin.\n\nNurse S\xc3\xa1vishna, knitting in hand, was telling in low tones, scarcely\nhearing or understanding her own words, what she had told hundreds of\ntimes before: how the late princess had given birth to Princess Mary\nin Kishen\xc3\xabv with only a Moldavian peasant woman to help instead of a\nmidwife.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod is merciful, doctors are never needed,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\n\nSuddenly a gust of wind beat violently against the casement of the\nwindow, from which the double frame had been removed (by order of the\nprince, one window frame was removed in each room as soon as the larks\nreturned), and, forcing open a loosely closed latch, set the damask\ncurtain flapping and blew out the candle with its chill, snowy draft.\nPrincess Mary shuddered; her nurse, putting down the stocking she was\nknitting, went to the window and leaning out tried to catch the open\ncasement. The cold wind flapped the ends of her kerchief and her loose\nlocks of gray hair.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrincess, my dear, there\xe2\x80\x99s someone driving up the avenue!\xe2\x80\x9d she\nsaid, holding the casement and not closing it. \xe2\x80\x9cWith lanterns. Most\nlikely the doctor.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God! thank God!\xe2\x80\x9d said Princess Mary. \xe2\x80\x9cI must go and meet\nhim, he does not know Russian.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrincess Mary threw a shawl over her head and ran to meet the newcomer.\nAs she was crossing the anteroom she saw through the window a carriage\nwith lanterns, standing at the entrance. She went out on the stairs. On\na banister post stood a tallow candle which guttered in the draft. On\nthe landing below, Philip, the footman, stood looking scared and holding\nanother candle. Still lower, beyond the turn of the staircase, one\ncould hear the footstep of someone in thick felt boots, and a voice that\nseemed familiar to Princess Mary was saying something.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank God!\xe2\x80\x9d said the voice. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd Father?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGone to bed,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the voice of Demy\xc3\xa1n the house steward, who\nwas downstairs.\n\nThen the voice said something more, Demy\xc3\xa1n replied, and the steps in\nthe felt boots approached the unseen bend of the staircase more rapidly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s Andrew!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Princess Mary. \xe2\x80\x9cNo it can\xe2\x80\x99t be, that\nwould be too extraordinary,\xe2\x80\x9d and at the very moment she thought this,\nthe face and figure of Prince Andrew, in a fur cloak the deep collar of\nwhich covered with snow, appeared on the landing where the footman\nstood with the candle. Yes, it was he, pale, thin, with a changed and\nstrangely softened but agitated expression on his face. He came up the\nstairs and embraced his sister.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou did not get my letter?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, and not waiting for a\nreply\xe2\x80\x94which he would not have received, for the princess was unable to\nspeak\xe2\x80\x94he turned back, rapidly mounted the stairs again with the\ndoctor who had entered the hall after him (they had met at the last post\nstation), and again embraced his sister.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a strange fate, M\xc3\xa1sha darling!\xe2\x80\x9d And having taken off his\ncloak and felt boots, he went to the little princess\xe2\x80\x99 apartment.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IX\n\nThe little princess lay supported by pillows, with a white cap on her\nhead (the pains had just left her). Strands of her black hair lay round\nher inflamed and perspiring cheeks, her charming rosy mouth with its\ndowny lip was open and she was smiling joyfully. Prince Andrew entered\nand paused facing her at the foot of the sofa on which she was lying.\nHer glittering eyes, filled with childlike fear and excitement, rested\non him without changing their expression. \xe2\x80\x9cI love you all and have\ndone no harm to anyone; why must I suffer so? Help me!\xe2\x80\x9d her look\nseemed to say. She saw her husband, but did not realize the significance\nof his appearance before her now. Prince Andrew went round the sofa and\nkissed her forehead.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy darling!\xe2\x80\x9d he said\xe2\x80\x94a word he had never used to her before.\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod is merciful....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe looked at him inquiringly and with childlike reproach.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI expected help from you and I get none, none from you either!\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid her eyes. She was not surprised at his having come; she did\nnot realize that he had come. His coming had nothing to do with\nher sufferings or with their relief. The pangs began again and Mary\nBogd\xc3\xa1novna advised Prince Andrew to leave the room.\n\nThe doctor entered. Prince Andrew went out and, meeting Princess Mary,\nagain joined her. They began talking in whispers, but their talk broke\noff at every moment. They waited and listened.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Princess Mary.\n\nPrince Andrew went again to his wife and sat waiting in the room next\nto hers. A woman came from the bedroom with a frightened face and became\nconfused when she saw Prince Andrew. He covered his face with his hands\nand remained so for some minutes. Piteous, helpless, animal moans came\nthrough the door. Prince Andrew got up, went to the door, and tried to\nopen it. Someone was holding it shut.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t come in! You can\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said a terrified voice from\nwithin.\n\nHe began pacing the room. The screaming ceased, and a few more seconds\nwent by. Then suddenly a terrible shriek\xe2\x80\x94it could not be hers, she\ncould not scream like that\xe2\x80\x94came from the bedroom. Prince Andrew ran to\nthe door; the scream ceased and he heard the wail of an infant.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have they taken a baby in there for?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Prince Andrew in\nthe first second. \xe2\x80\x9cA baby? What baby...? Why is there a baby there? Or\nis the baby born?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThen suddenly he realized the joyful significance of that wail; tears\nchoked him, and leaning his elbows on the window sill he began to cry,\nsobbing like a child. The door opened. The doctor with his shirt sleeves\ntucked up, without a coat, pale and with a trembling jaw, came out\nof the room. Prince Andrew turned to him, but the doctor gave him a\nbewildered look and passed by without a word. A woman rushed out and\nseeing Prince Andrew stopped, hesitating on the threshold. He went into\nhis wife\xe2\x80\x99s room. She was lying dead, in the same position he had seen\nher in five minutes before and, despite the fixed eyes and the pallor of\nthe cheeks, the same expression was on her charming childlike face with\nits upper lip covered with tiny black hair.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI love you all, and have done no harm to anyone; and what have you\ndone to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94said her charming, pathetic, dead face.\n\nIn a corner of the room something red and tiny gave a grunt and squealed\nin Mary Bogd\xc3\xa1novna\xe2\x80\x99s trembling white hands.\n\n\nTwo hours later Prince Andrew, stepping softly, went into his father\xe2\x80\x99s\nroom. The old man already knew everything. He was standing close to\nthe door and as soon as it opened his rough old arms closed like a vise\nround his son\xe2\x80\x99s neck, and without a word he began to sob like a child.\n\n\nThree days later the little princess was buried, and Prince Andrew went\nup the steps to where the coffin stood, to give her the farewell kiss.\nAnd there in the coffin was the same face, though with closed eyes.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, what have you done to me?\xe2\x80\x9d it still seemed to say, and Prince\nAndrew felt that something gave way in his soul and that he was guilty\nof a sin he could neither remedy nor forget. He could not weep. The\nold man too came up and kissed the waxen little hands that lay quietly\ncrossed one on the other on her breast, and to him, too, her face seemed\nto say: \xe2\x80\x9cAh, what have you done to me, and why?\xe2\x80\x9d And at the sight\nthe old man turned angrily away.\n\n\nAnother five days passed, and then the young Prince Nicholas Andr\xc3\xa9evich\nwas baptized. The wet nurse supported the coverlet with her chin, while\nthe priest with a goose feather anointed the boy\xe2\x80\x99s little red and\nwrinkled soles and palms.\n\nHis grandfather, who was his godfather, trembling and afraid of dropping\nhim, carried the infant round the battered tin font and handed him over\nto the godmother, Princess Mary. Prince Andrew sat in another room,\nfaint with fear lest the baby should be drowned in the font, and awaited\nthe termination of the ceremony. He looked up joyfully at the baby when\nthe nurse brought it to him and nodded approval when she told him that\nthe wax with the baby\xe2\x80\x99s hair had not sunk in the font but had floated.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER X\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s share in D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s duel with Bez\xc3\xbakhov was hushed up by\nthe efforts of the old count, and instead of being degraded to the ranks\nas he expected he was appointed an adjutant to the governor general of\nMoscow. As a result he could not go to the country with the rest of the\nfamily, but was kept all summer in Moscow by his new duties. D\xc3\xb3lokhov\nrecovered, and Rost\xc3\xb3v became very friendly with him during his\nconvalescence. D\xc3\xb3lokhov lay ill at his mother\xe2\x80\x99s who loved him\npassionately and tenderly, and old Mary Iv\xc3\xa1novna, who had grown fond of\nRost\xc3\xb3v for his friendship to her F\xc3\xa9dya, often talked to him about her\nson.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Count,\xe2\x80\x9d she would say, \xe2\x80\x9che is too noble and pure-souled for\nour present, depraved world. No one now loves virtue; it seems like\na reproach to everyone. Now tell me, Count, was it right, was it\nhonorable, of Bez\xc3\xbakhov? And F\xc3\xa9dya, with his noble spirit, loved him\nand even now never says a word against him. Those pranks in Petersburg\nwhen they played some tricks on a policeman, didn\xe2\x80\x99t they do it\ntogether? And there! Bez\xc3\xbakhov got off scotfree, while F\xc3\xa9dya had to\nbear the whole burden on his shoulders. Fancy what he had to go through!\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s true he has been reinstated, but how could they fail to do that?\nI think there were not many such gallant sons of the fatherland out\nthere as he. And now\xe2\x80\x94this duel! Have these people no feeling, or\nhonor? Knowing him to be an only son, to challenge him and shoot so\nstraight! It\xe2\x80\x99s well God had mercy on us. And what was it for? Who\ndoesn\xe2\x80\x99t have intrigues nowadays? Why, if he was so jealous, as I see\nthings he should have shown it sooner, but he lets it go on for months.\nAnd then to call him out, reckoning on F\xc3\xa9dya not fighting because he\nowed him money! What baseness! What meanness! I know you understand\nF\xc3\xa9dya, my dear count; that, believe me, is why I am so fond of you. Few\npeople do understand him. He is such a lofty, heavenly soul!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov himself during his convalescence spoke to Rost\xc3\xb3v in a way no\none would have expected of him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know people consider me a bad man!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cLet them! I\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t care a straw about anyone but those I love; but those I love,\nI love so that I would give my life for them, and the others I\xe2\x80\x99d\nthrottle if they stood in my way. I have an adored, a priceless mother,\nand two or three friends\xe2\x80\x94you among them\xe2\x80\x94and as for the rest I only\ncare about them in so far as they are harmful or useful. And most of\nthem are harmful, especially the women. Yes, dear boy,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued,\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have met loving, noble, high-minded men, but I have not yet met\nany women\xe2\x80\x94countesses or cooks\xe2\x80\x94who were not venal. I have not yet met\nthat divine purity and devotion I look for in women. If I found such a\none I\xe2\x80\x99d give my life for her! But those!...\xe2\x80\x9d and he made a gesture\nof contempt. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd believe me, if I still value my life it is\nonly because I still hope to meet such a divine creature, who will\nregenerate, purify, and elevate me. But you don\xe2\x80\x99t understand it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, I quite understand,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rost\xc3\xb3v, who was under his\nnew friend\xe2\x80\x99s influence.\n\nIn the autumn the Rost\xc3\xb3vs returned to Moscow. Early in the winter\nDen\xc3\xadsov also came back and stayed with them. The first half of the\nwinter of 1806, which Nicholas Rost\xc3\xb3v spent in Moscow, was one of the\nhappiest, merriest times for him and the whole family. Nicholas brought\nmany young men to his parents\xe2\x80\x99 house. V\xc3\xa9ra was a handsome girl\nof twenty; S\xc3\xb3nya a girl of sixteen with all the charm of an opening\nflower; Nat\xc3\xa1sha, half grown up and half child, was now childishly\namusing, now girlishly enchanting.\n\nAt that time in the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 house there prevailed an amorous\natmosphere characteristic of homes where there are very young and very\ncharming girls. Every young man who came to the house\xe2\x80\x94seeing those\nimpressionable, smiling young faces (smiling probably at their own\nhappiness), feeling the eager bustle around him, and hearing the fitful\nbursts of song and music and the inconsequent but friendly prattle of\nyoung girls ready for anything and full of hope\xe2\x80\x94experienced the same\nfeeling; sharing with the young folk of the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 household a\nreadiness to fall in love and an expectation of happiness.\n\nAmong the young men introduced by Rost\xc3\xb3v one of the first was\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov, whom everyone in the house liked except Nat\xc3\xa1sha. She almost\nquarreled with her brother about him. She insisted that he was a bad\nman, and that in the duel with Bez\xc3\xbakhov, Pierre was right and D\xc3\xb3lokhov\nwrong, and further that he was disagreeable and unnatural.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s nothing for me to understand,\xe2\x80\x9d she cried out with\nresolute self-will, \xe2\x80\x9che is wicked and heartless. There now, I like\nyour Den\xc3\xadsov though he is a rake and all that, still I like him; so\nyou see I do understand. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how to put it... with this one\neverything is calculated, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t like that. But Den\xc3\xadsov...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Den\xc3\xadsov is quite different,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Nicholas, implying that\neven Den\xc3\xadsov was nothing compared to D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyou must understand\nwhat a soul there is in D\xc3\xb3lokhov, you should see him with his mother.\nWhat a heart!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know about that, but I am uncomfortable with him. And\ndo you know he has fallen in love with S\xc3\xb3nya?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat nonsense...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m certain of it; you\xe2\x80\x99ll see.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s prediction proved true. D\xc3\xb3lokhov, who did not usually care\nfor the society of ladies, began to come often to the house, and the\nquestion for whose sake he came (though no one spoke of it) was soon\nsettled. He came because of S\xc3\xb3nya. And S\xc3\xb3nya, though she would never\nhave dared to say so, knew it and blushed scarlet every time D\xc3\xb3lokhov\nappeared.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov often dined at the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99, never missed a performance at\nwhich they were present, and went to Iogel\xe2\x80\x99s balls for young people\nwhich the Rost\xc3\xb3vs always attended. He was pointedly attentive to S\xc3\xb3nya\nand looked at her in such a way that not only could she not bear his\nglances without coloring, but even the old countess and Nat\xc3\xa1sha blushed\nwhen they saw his looks.\n\nIt was evident that this strange, strong man was under the irresistible\ninfluence of the dark, graceful girl who loved another.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v noticed something new in D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s relations with S\xc3\xb3nya,\nbut he did not explain to himself what these new relations were.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re always in love with someone,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought of S\xc3\xb3nya and\nNat\xc3\xa1sha. But he was not as much at ease with S\xc3\xb3nya and D\xc3\xb3lokhov as\nbefore and was less frequently at home.\n\nIn the autumn of 1806 everybody had again begun talking of the war with\nNapoleon with even greater warmth than the year before. Orders were\ngiven to raise recruits, ten men in every thousand for the regular army,\nand besides this, nine men in every thousand for the militia. Everywhere\nBonaparte was anathematized and in Moscow nothing but the coming war\nwas talked of. For the Rost\xc3\xb3v family the whole interest of these\npreparations for war lay in the fact that Nicholas would not hear of\nremaining in Moscow, and only awaited the termination of Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s\nfurlough after Christmas to return with him to their regiment. His\napproaching departure did not prevent his amusing himself, but rather\ngave zest to his pleasures. He spent the greater part of his time away\nfrom home, at dinners, parties, and balls.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XI\n\nOn the third day after Christmas Nicholas dined at home, a thing he had\nrarely done of late. It was a grand farewell dinner, as he and Den\xc3\xadsov\nwere leaving to join their regiment after Epiphany. About twenty people\nwere present, including D\xc3\xb3lokhov and Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\nNever had love been so much in the air, and never had the amorous\natmosphere made itself so strongly felt in the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 house as at\nthis holiday time. \xe2\x80\x9cSeize the moments of happiness, love and be loved!\nThat is the only reality in the world, all else is folly. It is the one\nthing we are interested in here,\xe2\x80\x9d said the spirit of the place.\n\nNicholas, having as usual exhausted two pairs of horses, without\nvisiting all the places he meant to go to and where he had been invited,\nreturned home just before dinner. As soon as he entered he noticed and\nfelt the tension of the amorous air in the house, and also noticed a\ncurious embarrassment among some of those present. S\xc3\xb3nya, D\xc3\xb3lokhov,\nand the old countess were especially disturbed, and to a lesser degree\nNat\xc3\xa1sha. Nicholas understood that something must have happened between\nS\xc3\xb3nya and D\xc3\xb3lokhov before dinner, and with the kindly sensitiveness\nnatural to him was very gentle and wary with them both at dinner. On\nthat same evening there was to be one of the balls that Iogel (the\ndancing master) gave for his pupils during the holidays.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNicholas, will you come to Iogel\xe2\x80\x99s? Please do!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe asked you, and Vas\xc3\xadli Dm\xc3\xadtrich * is also going.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n    * Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere would I not go at the countess\xe2\x80\x99 command!\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov,\nwho at the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 had jocularly assumed the role of Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s\nknight. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m even weady to dance the pas de ch\xc3\xa2le.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I have time,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Nicholas. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I promised the\nArkh\xc3\xa1rovs; they have a party.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked D\xc3\xb3lokhov, but as soon as he had asked the\nquestion he noticed that it should not have been put.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d coldly and angrily replied D\xc3\xb3lokhov, glancing at S\xc3\xb3nya,\nand, scowling, he gave Nicholas just such a look as he had given Pierre\nat the club dinner.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is something up,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nicholas, and he was further\nconfirmed in this conclusion by the fact that D\xc3\xb3lokhov left immediately\nafter dinner. He called Nat\xc3\xa1sha and asked her what was the matter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I was looking for you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha running out to him. \xe2\x80\x9cI\ntold you, but you would not believe it,\xe2\x80\x9d she said triumphantly. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\nhas proposed to S\xc3\xb3nya!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nLittle as Nicholas had occupied himself with S\xc3\xb3nya of late, something\nseemed to give way within him at this news. D\xc3\xb3lokhov was a suitable and\nin some respects a brilliant match for the dowerless, orphan girl. From\nthe point of view of the old countess and of society it was out of the\nquestion for her to refuse him. And therefore Nicholas\xe2\x80\x99 first feeling\non hearing the news was one of anger with S\xc3\xb3nya.... He tried to say,\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s capital; of course she\xe2\x80\x99ll forget her childish promises\nand accept the offer,\xe2\x80\x9d but before he had time to say it Nat\xc3\xa1sha began\nagain.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd fancy! she refused him quite definitely!\xe2\x80\x9d adding, after a\npause, \xe2\x80\x9cshe told him she loved another.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my S\xc3\xb3nya could not have done otherwise!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nicholas.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMuch as Mamma pressed her, she refused, and I know she won\xe2\x80\x99t change\nonce she has said...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Mamma pressed her!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas reproachfully.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, Nicholas\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t be\nangry\xe2\x80\x94but I know you will not marry her. I know, heaven knows how, but\nI know for certain that you won\xe2\x80\x99t marry her.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow you don\xe2\x80\x99t know that at all!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I must\ntalk to her. What a darling S\xc3\xb3nya is!\xe2\x80\x9d he added with a smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, she is indeed a darling! I\xe2\x80\x99ll send her to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Nat\xc3\xa1sha kissed her brother and ran away.\n\nA minute later S\xc3\xb3nya came in with a frightened, guilty, and scared\nlook. Nicholas went up to her and kissed her hand. This was the first\ntime since his return that they had talked alone and about their love.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSophie,\xe2\x80\x9d he began, timidly at first and then more and more\nboldly, \xe2\x80\x9cif you wish to refuse one who is not only a brilliant and\nadvantageous match but a splendid, noble fellow... he is my friend...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya interrupted him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have already refused,\xe2\x80\x9d she said hurriedly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you are refusing for my sake, I am afraid that I...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya again interrupted. She gave him an imploring, frightened look.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNicholas, don\xe2\x80\x99t tell me that!\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but I must. It may be arrogant of me, but still it is best to say\nit. If you refuse him on my account, I must tell you the whole truth. I\nlove you, and I think I love you more than anyone else....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is enough for me,\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya, blushing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but I have been in love a thousand times and shall fall in\nlove again, though for no one have I such a feeling of friendship,\nconfidence, and love as I have for you. Then I am young. Mamma does\nnot wish it. In a word, I make no promise. And I beg you to consider\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s offer,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, articulating his friend\xe2\x80\x99s name with\ndifficulty.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t say that to me! I want nothing. I love you as a brother and\nalways shall, and I want nothing more.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are an angel: I am not worthy of you, but I am afraid of\nmisleading you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Nicholas again kissed her hand.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XII\n\nIogel\xe2\x80\x99s were the most enjoyable balls in Moscow. So said the mothers\nas they watched their young people executing their newly learned steps,\nand so said the youths and maidens themselves as they danced till they\nwere ready to drop, and so said the grown-up young men and women who\ncame to these balls with an air of condescension and found them most\nenjoyable. That year two marriages had come of these balls. The two\npretty young Princesses Gorchak\xc3\xb3v met suitors there and were married\nand so further increased the fame of these dances. What distinguished\nthem from others was the absence of host or hostess and the presence of\nthe good-natured Iogel, flying about like a feather and bowing according\nto the rules of his art, as he collected the tickets from all his\nvisitors. There was the fact that only those came who wished to dance\nand amuse themselves as girls of thirteen and fourteen do who are\nwearing long dresses for the first time. With scarcely any exceptions\nthey all were, or seemed to be, pretty\xe2\x80\x94so rapturous were their smiles\nand so sparkling their eyes. Sometimes the best of the pupils, of whom\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, who was exceptionally graceful, was first, even danced the pas\nde ch\xc3\xa2le, but at this last ball only the \xc3\xa9cossaise, the anglaise, and\nthe mazurka, which was just coming into fashion, were danced. Iogel had\ntaken a ballroom in Bez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s house, and the ball, as everyone said,\nwas a great success. There were many pretty girls and the Rost\xc3\xb3v girls\nwere among the prettiest. They were both particularly happy and gay.\nThat evening, proud of D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s proposal, her refusal, and her\nexplanation with Nicholas, S\xc3\xb3nya twirled about before she left home\nso that the maid could hardly get her hair plaited, and she was\ntransparently radiant with impulsive joy.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha no less proud of her first long dress and of being at a real\nball was even happier. They were both dressed in white muslin with pink\nribbons.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha fell in love the very moment she entered the ballroom. She\nwas not in love with anyone in particular, but with everyone. Whatever\nperson she happened to look at she was in love with for that moment.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, how delightful it is!\xe2\x80\x9d she kept saying, running up to S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\nNicholas and Den\xc3\xadsov were walking up and down, looking with kindly\npatronage at the dancers.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow sweet she is\xe2\x80\x94she will be a weal beauty!\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCountess Nat\xc3\xa1sha,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how she dances! What gwace!\xe2\x80\x9d he said again after a pause.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are you talking about?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout your sister,\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated Den\xc3\xadsov testily.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v smiled.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear count, you were one of my best pupils\xe2\x80\x94you must dance,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid little Iogel coming up to Nicholas. \xe2\x80\x9cLook how many charming young\nladies\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d He turned with the same request to Den\xc3\xadsov who was also a\nformer pupil of his.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my dear fellow, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be a wallflower,\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you wecollect what bad use I made of your lessons?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no!\xe2\x80\x9d said Iogel, hastening to reassure him. \xe2\x80\x9cYou were only\ninattentive, but you had talent\xe2\x80\x94oh yes, you had talent!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe band struck up the newly introduced mazurka. Nicholas could not\nrefuse Iogel and asked S\xc3\xb3nya to dance. Den\xc3\xadsov sat down by the old\nladies and, leaning on his saber and beating time with his foot, told\nthem something funny and kept them amused, while he watched the young\npeople dancing, Iogel with Nat\xc3\xa1sha, his pride and his best pupil, were\nthe first couple. Noiselessly, skillfully stepping with his little\nfeet in low shoes, Iogel flew first across the hall with Nat\xc3\xa1sha, who,\nthough shy, went on carefully executing her steps. Den\xc3\xadsov did not\ntake his eyes off her and beat time with his saber in a way that clearly\nindicated that if he was not dancing it was because he would not and not\nbecause he could not. In the middle of a figure he beckoned to Rost\xc3\xb3v\nwho was passing:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is not at all the thing,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat sort of Polish\nmazuwka is this? But she does dance splendidly.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nKnowing that Den\xc3\xadsov had a reputation even in Poland for the masterly\nway in which he danced the mazurka, Nicholas ran up to Nat\xc3\xa1sha:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo and choose Den\xc3\xadsov. He is a real dancer, a wonder!\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\nWhen it came to Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s turn to choose a partner, she rose and,\ntripping rapidly across in her little shoes trimmed with bows, ran\ntimidly to the corner where Den\xc3\xadsov sat. She saw that everybody was\nlooking at her and waiting. Nicholas saw that Den\xc3\xadsov was refusing\nthough he smiled delightedly. He ran up to them.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease, Vas\xc3\xadli Dm\xc3\xadtrich,\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha was saying, \xe2\x80\x9cdo come!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no, let me off, Countess,\xe2\x80\x9d Den\xc3\xadsov replied.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow then, V\xc3\xa1ska,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey coax me as if I were V\xc3\xa1ska the cat!\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov jokingly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll sing for you a whole evening,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, the faiwy! She can do anything with me!\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov, and\nhe unhooked his saber. He came out from behind the chairs, clasped his\npartner\xe2\x80\x99s hand firmly, threw back his head, and advanced his foot,\nwaiting for the beat. Only on horse back and in the mazurka was\nDen\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s short stature not noticeable and he looked the fine fellow\nhe felt himself to be. At the right beat of the music he looked sideways\nat his partner with a merry and triumphant air, suddenly stamped with\none foot, bounded from the floor like a ball, and flew round the room\ntaking his partner with him. He glided silently on one foot half across\nthe room, and seeming not to notice the chairs was dashing straight at\nthem, when suddenly, clinking his spurs and spreading out his legs,\nhe stopped short on his heels, stood so a second, stamped on the spot\nclanking his spurs, whirled rapidly round, and, striking his left heel\nagainst his right, flew round again in a circle. Nat\xc3\xa1sha guessed what\nhe meant to do, and abandoning herself to him followed his lead hardly\nknowing how. First he spun her round, holding her now with his left, now\nwith his right hand, then falling on one knee he twirled her round him,\nand again jumping up, dashed so impetuously forward that it seemed as if\nhe would rush through the whole suite of rooms without drawing breath,\nand then he suddenly stopped and performed some new and unexpected\nsteps. When at last, smartly whirling his partner round in front of her\nchair, he drew up with a click of his spurs and bowed to her, Nat\xc3\xa1sha\ndid not even make him a curtsy. She fixed her eyes on him in amazement,\nsmiling as if she did not recognize him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does this mean?\xe2\x80\x9d she brought out.\n\nAlthough Iogel did not acknowledge this to be the real mazurka, everyone\nwas delighted with Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s skill, he was asked again and again as\na partner, and the old men began smilingly to talk about Poland and the\ngood old days. Den\xc3\xadsov, flushed after the mazurka and mopping himself\nwith his handkerchief, sat down by Nat\xc3\xa1sha and did not leave her for\nthe rest of the evening.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIII\n\nFor two days after that Rost\xc3\xb3v did not see D\xc3\xb3lokhov at his own or at\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s home: on the third day he received a note from him:\n\nAs I do not intend to be at your house again for reasons you know\nof, and am going to rejoin my regiment, I am giving a farewell supper\ntonight to my friends\xe2\x80\x94come to the English Hotel.\n\nAbout ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock Rost\xc3\xb3v went to the English Hotel straight from the\ntheater, where he had been with his family and Den\xc3\xadsov. He was at once\nshown to the best room, which D\xc3\xb3lokhov had taken for that evening. Some\ntwenty men were gathered round a table at which D\xc3\xb3lokhov sat between\ntwo candles. On the table was a pile of gold and paper money, and he\nwas keeping the bank. Rost\xc3\xb3v had not seen him since his proposal and\nS\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s refusal and felt uncomfortable at the thought of how they\nwould meet.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s clear, cold glance met Rost\xc3\xb3v as soon as he entered the\ndoor, as though he had long expected him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a long time since we met,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThanks for coming.\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll just finish dealing, and then Ily\xc3\xbashka will come with his\nchorus.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI called once or twice at your house,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v, reddening.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov made no reply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may punt,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v recalled at that moment a strange conversation he had once had\nwith D\xc3\xb3lokhov. \xe2\x80\x9cNone but fools trust to luck in play,\xe2\x80\x9d D\xc3\xb3lokhov\nhad then said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr are you afraid to play with me?\xe2\x80\x9d D\xc3\xb3lokhov now asked as if\nguessing Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s thought.\n\nBeneath his smile Rost\xc3\xb3v saw in him the mood he had shown at the club\ndinner and at other times, when as if tired of everyday life he had felt\na need to escape from it by some strange, and usually cruel, action.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v felt ill at ease. He tried, but failed, to find some joke with\nwhich to reply to D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s words. But before he had thought of\nanything, D\xc3\xb3lokhov, looking straight in his face, said slowly and\ndeliberately so that everyone could hear:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you remember we had a talk about cards... \xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s a fool who\ntrusts to luck, one should make certain,\xe2\x80\x99 and I want to try.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo try his luck or the certainty?\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v asked himself.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99d better not play,\xe2\x80\x9d D\xc3\xb3lokhov added, and springing a\nnew pack of cards said: \xe2\x80\x9cBank, gentlemen!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nMoving the money forward he prepared to deal. Rost\xc3\xb3v sat down by his\nside and at first did not play. D\xc3\xb3lokhov kept glancing at him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you play?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\n\nAnd strange to say Nicholas felt that he could not help taking up a\ncard, putting a small stake on it, and beginning to play.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no money with me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll trust you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v staked five rubles on a card and lost, staked again, and again\nlost. D\xc3\xb3lokhov \xe2\x80\x9ckilled,\xe2\x80\x9d that is, beat, ten cards of Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s\nrunning.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov after he had dealt for some time.\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease place your money on the cards or I may get muddled in the\nreckoning.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nOne of the players said he hoped he might be trusted.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you might, but I am afraid of getting the accounts mixed. So I\nask you to put the money on your cards,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xc3\xb3lokhov. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t\nstint yourself, we\xe2\x80\x99ll settle afterwards,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, turning to\nRost\xc3\xb3v.\n\nThe game continued; a waiter kept handing round champagne.\n\nAll Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s cards were beaten and he had eight hundred rubles scored\nup against him. He wrote \xe2\x80\x9c800 rubles\xe2\x80\x9d on a card, but while the\nwaiter filled his glass he changed his mind and altered it to his usual\nstake of twenty rubles.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeave it,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov, though he did not seem to be even\nlooking at Rost\xc3\xb3v, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ll win it back all the sooner. I lose to\nthe others but win from you. Or are you afraid of me?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked again.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v submitted. He let the eight hundred remain and laid down a seven\nof hearts with a torn corner, which he had picked up from the floor. He\nwell remembered that seven afterwards. He laid down the seven of hearts,\non which with a broken bit of chalk he had written \xe2\x80\x9c800 rubles\xe2\x80\x9d in\nclear upright figures; he emptied the glass of warm champagne that was\nhanded him, smiled at D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s words, and with a sinking heart,\nwaiting for a seven to turn up, gazed at D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s hands which held\nthe pack. Much depended on Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s winning or losing on that seven\nof hearts. On the previous Sunday the old count had given his son\ntwo thousand rubles, and though he always disliked speaking of money\ndifficulties had told Nicholas that this was all he could let him have\ntill May, and asked him to be more economical this time. Nicholas had\nreplied that it would be more than enough for him and that he gave his\nword of honor not to take anything more till the spring. Now only twelve\nhundred rubles was left of that money, so that this seven of hearts\nmeant for him not only the loss of sixteen hundred rubles, but the\nnecessity of going back on his word. With a sinking heart he watched\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s hands and thought, \xe2\x80\x9cNow then, make haste and let me have\nthis card and I\xe2\x80\x99ll take my cap and drive home to supper with Den\xc3\xadsov,\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, and S\xc3\xb3nya, and will certainly never touch a card again.\xe2\x80\x9d At\nthat moment his home life, jokes with P\xc3\xa9tya, talks with S\xc3\xb3nya, duets\nwith Nat\xc3\xa1sha, piquet with his father, and even his comfortable bed\nin the house on the Povarsk\xc3\xa1ya rose before him with such vividness,\nclearness, and charm that it seemed as if it were all a lost and\nunappreciated bliss, long past. He could not conceive that a stupid\nchance, letting the seven be dealt to the right rather than to the left,\nmight deprive him of all this happiness, newly appreciated and newly\nillumined, and plunge him into the depths of unknown and undefined\nmisery. That could not be, yet he awaited with a sinking heart the\nmovement of D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s hands. Those broad, reddish hands, with hairy\nwrists visible from under the shirt cuffs, laid down the pack and took\nup a glass and a pipe that were handed him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you are not afraid to play with me?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated D\xc3\xb3lokhov, and as\nif about to tell a good story he put down the cards, leaned back in his\nchair, and began deliberately with a smile:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, gentlemen, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been told there\xe2\x80\x99s a rumor going about Moscow\nthat I\xe2\x80\x99m a sharper, so I advise you to be careful.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome now, deal!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, those Moscow gossips!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov, and he took up the cards\nwith a smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAah!\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v almost screamed lifting both hands to his head. The\nseven he needed was lying uppermost, the first card in the pack. He had\nlost more than he could pay.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill, don\xe2\x80\x99t ruin yourself!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov with a side glance at\nRost\xc3\xb3v as he continued to deal.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIV\n\nAn hour and a half later most of the players were but little interested\nin their own play.\n\nThe whole interest was concentrated on Rost\xc3\xb3v. Instead of sixteen\nhundred rubles he had a long column of figures scored against him,\nwhich he had reckoned up to ten thousand, but that now, as he vaguely\nsupposed, must have risen to fifteen thousand. In reality it already\nexceeded twenty thousand rubles. D\xc3\xb3lokhov was no longer listening to\nstories or telling them, but followed every movement of Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s\nhands and occasionally ran his eyes over the score against him. He had\ndecided to play until that score reached forty-three thousand. He\nhad fixed on that number because forty-three was the sum of his and\nS\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s joint ages. Rost\xc3\xb3v, leaning his head on both hands, sat at\nthe table which was scrawled over with figures, wet with spilled wine,\nand littered with cards. One tormenting impression did not leave him:\nthat those broad-boned reddish hands with hairy wrists visible from\nunder the shirt sleeves, those hands which he loved and hated, held him\nin their power.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSix hundred rubles, ace, a corner, a nine... winning it back\xe2\x80\x99s\nimpossible... Oh, how pleasant it was at home!... The knave, double or\nquits... it can\xe2\x80\x99t be!... And why is he doing this to me?\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v\npondered. Sometimes he staked a large sum, but D\xc3\xb3lokhov refused to\naccept it and fixed the stake himself. Nicholas submitted to him, and at\none moment prayed to God as he had done on the battlefield at the bridge\nover the Enns, and then guessed that the card that came first to hand\nfrom the crumpled heap under the table would save him, now counted the\ncords on his coat and took a card with that number and tried staking the\ntotal of his losses on it, then he looked round for aid from the other\nplayers, or peered at the now cold face of D\xc3\xb3lokhov and tried to read\nwhat was passing in his mind.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe knows of course what this loss means to me. He can\xe2\x80\x99t want my\nruin. Wasn\xe2\x80\x99t he my friend? Wasn\xe2\x80\x99t I fond of him? But it\xe2\x80\x99s not his\nfault. What\xe2\x80\x99s he to do if he has such luck?... And it\xe2\x80\x99s not my fault\neither,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cI have done nothing wrong. Have I\nkilled anyone, or insulted or wished harm to anyone? Why such a terrible\nmisfortune? And when did it begin? Such a little while ago I came to\nthis table with the thought of winning a hundred rubles to buy that\ncasket for Mamma\xe2\x80\x99s name day and then going home. I was so happy, so\nfree, so lighthearted! And I did not realize how happy I was! When did\nthat end and when did this new, terrible state of things begin? What\nmarked the change? I sat all the time in this same place at this table,\nchose and placed cards, and watched those broad-boned agile hands in the\nsame way. When did it happen and what has happened? I am well and strong\nand still the same and in the same place. No, it can\xe2\x80\x99t be! Surely it\nwill all end in nothing!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe was flushed and bathed in perspiration, though the room was not hot.\nHis face was terrible and piteous to see, especially from its helpless\nefforts to seem calm.\n\nThe score against him reached the fateful sum of forty-three thousand.\nRost\xc3\xb3v had just prepared a card, by bending the corner of which he\nmeant to double the three thousand just put down to his score, when\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov, slamming down the pack of cards, put it aside and began\nrapidly adding up the total of Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s debt, breaking the chalk as\nhe marked the figures in his clear, bold hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSupper, it\xe2\x80\x99s time for supper! And here are the gypsies!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nSome swarthy men and women were really entering from the cold outside\nand saying something in their gypsy accents. Nicholas understood that it\nwas all over; but he said in an indifferent tone:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, won\xe2\x80\x99t you go on? I had a splendid card all ready,\xe2\x80\x9d as if it\nwere the fun of the game which interested him most.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all up! I\xe2\x80\x99m lost!\xe2\x80\x9d thought he. \xe2\x80\x9cNow a bullet through my\nbrain\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all that\xe2\x80\x99s left me!\xe2\x80\x9d And at the same time he said\nin a cheerful voice:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome now, just this one more little card!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov, having finished the addition. \xe2\x80\x9cAll\nright! Twenty-one rubles,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, pointing to the figure twenty-one\nby which the total exceeded the round sum of forty-three thousand; and\ntaking up a pack he prepared to deal. Rost\xc3\xb3v submissively unbent the\ncorner of his card and, instead of the six thousand he had intended,\ncarefully wrote twenty-one.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all the same to me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI only want to see whether\nyou will let me win this ten, or beat it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov began to deal seriously. Oh, how Rost\xc3\xb3v detested at that\nmoment those hands with their short reddish fingers and hairy wrists,\nwhich held him in their power.... The ten fell to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou owe forty-three thousand, Count,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov, and\nstretching himself he rose from the table. \xe2\x80\x9cOne does get tired sitting\nso long,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I\xe2\x80\x99m tired too,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov cut him short, as if to remind him that it was not for him to\njest.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen am I to receive the money, Count?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v, flushing, drew D\xc3\xb3lokhov into the next room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot pay it all immediately. Will you take an I.O.U.?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, Rost\xc3\xb3v,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov clearly, smiling and looking\nNicholas straight in the eyes, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know the saying, \xe2\x80\x98Lucky in love,\nunlucky at cards.\xe2\x80\x99 Your cousin is in love with you, I know.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it\xe2\x80\x99s terrible to feel oneself so in this man\xe2\x80\x99s power,\xe2\x80\x9d\nthought Rost\xc3\xb3v. He knew what a shock he would inflict on his father and\nmother by the news of this loss, he knew what a relief it would be to\nescape it all, and felt that D\xc3\xb3lokhov knew that he could save him from\nall this shame and sorrow, but wanted now to play with him as a cat does\nwith a mouse.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour cousin...\xe2\x80\x9d D\xc3\xb3lokhov started to say, but Nicholas interrupted\nhim.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy cousin has nothing to do with this and it\xe2\x80\x99s not necessary to\nmention her!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed fiercely.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen when am I to have it?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rost\xc3\xb3v and left the room.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XV\n\nTo say \xe2\x80\x9ctomorrow\xe2\x80\x9d and keep up a dignified tone was not difficult,\nbut to go home alone, see his sisters, brother, mother, and father,\nconfess and ask for money he had no right to after giving his word of\nhonor, was terrible.\n\nAt home, they had not yet gone to bed. The young people, after returning\nfrom the theater, had had supper and were grouped round the clavichord.\nAs soon as Nicholas entered, he was enfolded in that poetic atmosphere\nof love which pervaded the Rost\xc3\xb3v household that winter and, now after\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s proposal and Iogel\xe2\x80\x99s ball, seemed to have grown thicker\nround S\xc3\xb3nya and Nat\xc3\xa1sha as the air does before a thunderstorm. S\xc3\xb3nya\nand Nat\xc3\xa1sha, in the light-blue dresses they had worn at the theater,\nlooking pretty and conscious of it, were standing by the clavichord,\nhappy and smiling. V\xc3\xa9ra was playing chess with Shinsh\xc3\xadn in the drawing\nroom. The old countess, waiting for the return of her husband and son,\nsat playing patience with the old gentlewoman who lived in their house.\nDen\xc3\xadsov, with sparkling eyes and ruffled hair, sat at the clavichord\nstriking chords with his short fingers, his legs thrown back and his\neyes rolling as he sang, with his small, husky, but true voice, some\nverses called \xe2\x80\x9cEnchantress,\xe2\x80\x9d which he had composed, and to which he\nwas trying to fit music:\n\n   Enchantress, say, to my forsaken lyre\n   What magic power is this recalls me still?\n   What spark has set my inmost soul on fire,\n   What is this bliss that makes my fingers thrill?\n\nHe was singing in passionate tones, gazing with his sparkling\nblack-agate eyes at the frightened and happy Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSplendid! Excellent!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cAnother verse,\xe2\x80\x9d she\nsaid, without noticing Nicholas.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverything\xe2\x80\x99s still the same with them,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nicholas,\nglancing into the drawing room, where he saw V\xc3\xa9ra and his mother with\nthe old lady.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, and here\xe2\x80\x99s Nicholas!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nat\xc3\xa1sha, running up to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Papa at home?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am so glad you\xe2\x80\x99ve come!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha, without answering him.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are enjoying ourselves! Vas\xc3\xadli Dm\xc3\xadtrich is staying a day longer\nfor my sake! Did you know?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Papa is not back yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNicholas, have you come? Come here, dear!\xe2\x80\x9d called the old countess\nfrom the drawing room.\n\nNicholas went to her, kissed her hand, and sitting down silently at her\ntable began to watch her hands arranging the cards. From the dancing\nroom, they still heard the laughter and merry voices trying to persuade\nNat\xc3\xa1sha to sing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll wight! All wight!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Den\xc3\xadsov. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s no good making\nexcuses now! It\xe2\x80\x99s your turn to sing the ba\xe2\x80\x99cawolla\xe2\x80\x94I entweat\nyou!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe countess glanced at her silent son.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as if weary of being continually asked the\nsame question. \xe2\x80\x9cWill Papa be back soon?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI expect so.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverything\xe2\x80\x99s the same with them. They know nothing about it! Where\nam I to go?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nicholas, and went again into the dancing room\nwhere the clavichord stood.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya was sitting at the clavichord, playing the prelude to\nDen\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s favorite barcarolle. Nat\xc3\xa1sha was preparing to sing.\nDen\xc3\xadsov was looking at her with enraptured eyes.\n\nNicholas began pacing up and down the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do they want to make her sing? How can she sing? There\xe2\x80\x99s\nnothing to be happy about!\xe2\x80\x9d thought he.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya struck the first chord of the prelude.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy God, I\xe2\x80\x99m a ruined and dishonored man! A bullet through my brain\nis the only thing left me\xe2\x80\x94not singing!\xe2\x80\x9d his thoughts ran on. \xe2\x80\x9cGo\naway? But where to? It\xe2\x80\x99s one\xe2\x80\x94let them sing!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe continued to pace the room, looking gloomily at Den\xc3\xadsov and the\ngirls and avoiding their eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNik\xc3\xb3lenka, what is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d S\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s eyes fixed on him\nseemed to ask. She noticed at once that something had happened to him.\n\nNicholas turned away from her. Nat\xc3\xa1sha too, with her quick instinct,\nhad instantly noticed her brother\xe2\x80\x99s condition. But, though she noticed\nit, she was herself in such high spirits at that moment, so far from\nsorrow, sadness, or self-reproach, that she purposely deceived herself\nas young people often do. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, I am too happy now to spoil my\nenjoyment by sympathy with anyone\xe2\x80\x99s sorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d she felt, and she said\nto herself: \xe2\x80\x9cNo, I must be mistaken, he must be feeling happy, just as\nI am.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, S\xc3\xb3nya!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, going to the very middle of the room, where\nshe considered the resonance was best.\n\nHaving lifted her head and let her arms droop lifelessly, as ballet\ndancers do, Nat\xc3\xa1sha, rising energetically from her heels to her toes,\nstepped to the middle of the room and stood still.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that\xe2\x80\x99s me!\xe2\x80\x9d she seemed to say, answering the rapt gaze with\nwhich Den\xc3\xadsov followed her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is she so pleased about?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nicholas, looking at his\nsister. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy isn\xe2\x80\x99t she dull and ashamed?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha took the first note, her throat swelled, her chest rose,\nher eyes became serious. At that moment she was oblivious of her\nsurroundings, and from her smiling lips flowed sounds which anyone may\nproduce at the same intervals and hold for the same time, but which\nleave you cold a thousand times and the thousand and first time thrill\nyou and make you weep.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, that winter, had for the first time begun to sing seriously,\nmainly because Den\xc3\xadsov so delighted in her singing. She no longer sang\nas a child, there was no longer in her singing that comical, childish,\npainstaking effect that had been in it before; but she did not yet sing\nwell, as all the connoisseurs who heard her said: \xe2\x80\x9cIt is not trained,\nbut it is a beautiful voice that must be trained.\xe2\x80\x9d Only they generally\nsaid this some time after she had finished singing. While that untrained\nvoice, with its incorrect breathing and labored transitions, was\nsounding, even the connoisseurs said nothing, but only delighted in\nit and wished to hear it again. In her voice there was a virginal\nfreshness, an unconsciousness of her own powers, and an as yet untrained\nvelvety softness, which so mingled with her lack of art in singing that\nit seemed as if nothing in that voice could be altered without spoiling\nit.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is this?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nicholas, listening to her with widely\nopened eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat has happened to her? How she is singing today!\xe2\x80\x9d\nAnd suddenly the whole world centered for him on anticipation of the\nnext note, the next phrase, and everything in the world was divided into\nthree beats: \xe2\x80\x9cOh mio crudele affetto.\xe2\x80\x9d... One, two, three... one,\ntwo, three... One... \xe2\x80\x9cOh mio crudele affetto.\xe2\x80\x9d... One, two, three...\nOne. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, this senseless life of ours!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nicholas. \xe2\x80\x9cAll\nthis misery, and money, and D\xc3\xb3lokhov, and anger, and honor\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s all\nnonsense... but this is real.... Now then, Nat\xc3\xa1sha, now then, dearest!\nNow then, darling! How will she take that si? She\xe2\x80\x99s taken it! Thank\nGod!\xe2\x80\x9d And without noticing that he was singing, to strengthen the si\nhe sung a second, a third below the high note. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, God! How fine! Did\nI really take it? How fortunate!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought.\n\nOh, how that chord vibrated, and how moved was something that was finest\nin Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s soul! And this something was apart from everything else\nin the world and above everything in the world. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat were losses, and\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov, and words of honor?... All nonsense! One might kill and rob\nand yet be happy....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVI\n\nIt was long since Rost\xc3\xb3v had felt such enjoyment from music as he\ndid that day. But no sooner had Nat\xc3\xa1sha finished her barcarolle than\nreality again presented itself. He got up without saying a word and went\ndownstairs to his own room. A quarter of an hour later the old count\ncame in from his club, cheerful and contented. Nicholas, hearing him\ndrive up, went to meet him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell\xe2\x80\x94had a good time?\xe2\x80\x9d said the old count, smiling gaily and\nproudly at his son.\n\nNicholas tried to say \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d but could not: and he nearly burst into\nsobs. The count was lighting his pipe and did not notice his son\xe2\x80\x99s\ncondition.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, it can\xe2\x80\x99t be avoided!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nicholas, for the first and\nlast time. And suddenly, in the most casual tone, which made him feel\nashamed of himself, he said, as if merely asking his father to let him\nhave the carriage to drive to town:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa, I have come on a matter of business. I was nearly forgetting. I\nneed some money.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me!\xe2\x80\x9d said his father, who was in a specially good humor. \xe2\x80\x9cI\ntold you it would not be enough. How much?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery much,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas flushing, and with a stupid careless\nsmile, for which he was long unable to forgive himself, \xe2\x80\x9cI have lost a\nlittle, I mean a good deal, a great deal\xe2\x80\x94forty three thousand.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! To whom?... Nonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the count, suddenly reddening\nwith an apoplectic flush over neck and nape as old people do.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promised to pay tomorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!...\xe2\x80\x9d said the old count, spreading out his arms and sinking\nhelplessly on the sofa.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt can\xe2\x80\x99t be helped! It happens to everyone!\xe2\x80\x9d said the son, with\na bold, free, and easy tone, while in his soul he regarded himself as a\nworthless scoundrel whose whole life could not atone for his crime. He\nlonged to kiss his father\xe2\x80\x99s hands and kneel to beg his forgiveness,\nbut said, in a careless and even rude voice, that it happens to\neveryone!\n\nThe old count cast down his eyes on hearing his son\xe2\x80\x99s words and began\nbustlingly searching for something.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered, \xe2\x80\x9cit will be difficult, I fear, difficult\nto raise... happens to everybody! Yes, who has not done it?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd with a furtive glance at his son\xe2\x80\x99s face, the count went out of the\nroom.... Nicholas had been prepared for resistance, but had not at all\nexpected this.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa! Pa-pa!\xe2\x80\x9d he called after him, sobbing, \xe2\x80\x9cforgive me!\xe2\x80\x9d And\nseizing his father\xe2\x80\x99s hand, he pressed it to his lips and burst into\ntears.\n\nWhile father and son were having their explanation, the mother and\ndaughter were having one not less important. Nat\xc3\xa1sha came running to\nher mother, quite excited.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma!... Mamma!... He has made me...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMade what?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMade, made me an offer, Mamma! Mamma!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed.\n\nThe countess did not believe her ears. Den\xc3\xadsov had proposed. To whom?\nTo this chit of a girl, Nat\xc3\xa1sha, who not so long ago was playing with\ndolls and who was still having lessons.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t, Nat\xc3\xa1sha! What nonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, hoping it was a joke.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense, indeed! I am telling you the fact,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nindignantly. \xe2\x80\x9cI come to ask you what to do, and you call it\n\xe2\x80\x98nonsense!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe countess shrugged her shoulders.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it is true that Monsieur Den\xc3\xadsov has made you a proposal, tell\nhim he is a fool, that\xe2\x80\x99s all!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he\xe2\x80\x99s not a fool!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Nat\xc3\xa1sha indignantly and seriously.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then, what do you want? You\xe2\x80\x99re all in love nowadays. Well,\nif you are in love, marry him!\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, with a laugh of\nannoyance. \xe2\x80\x9cGood luck to you!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Mamma, I\xe2\x80\x99m not in love with him, I suppose I\xe2\x80\x99m not in love\nwith him.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then, tell him so.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, are you cross? Don\xe2\x80\x99t be cross, dear! Is it my fault?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but what is it, my dear? Do you want me to go and tell him?\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid the countess smiling.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I will do it myself, only tell me what to say. It\xe2\x80\x99s all very\nwell for you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha, with a responsive smile. \xe2\x80\x9cYou should\nhave seen how he said it! I know he did not mean to say it, but it came\nout accidently.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, all the same, you must refuse him.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I mustn\xe2\x80\x99t. I am so sorry for him! He\xe2\x80\x99s so nice.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then, accept his offer. It\xe2\x80\x99s high time for you to be\nmarried,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the countess sharply and sarcastically.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Mamma, but I\xe2\x80\x99m so sorry for him. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how I\xe2\x80\x99m to\nsay it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing for you to say. I shall speak to him myself,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid the countess, indignant that they should have dared to treat this\nlittle Nat\xc3\xa1sha as grown up.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not on any account! I will tell him myself, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll listen\nat the door,\xe2\x80\x9d and Nat\xc3\xa1sha ran across the drawing room to the dancing\nhall, where Den\xc3\xadsov was sitting on the same chair by the clavichord\nwith his face in his hands.\n\nHe jumped up at the sound of her light step.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNataly,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, moving with rapid steps toward her, \xe2\x80\x9cdecide my\nfate. It is in your hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVas\xc3\xadli Dm\xc3\xadtrich, I\xe2\x80\x99m so sorry for you!... No, but you are so\nnice... but it won\xe2\x80\x99t do...not that... but as a friend, I shall always\nlove you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov bent over her hand and she heard strange sounds she did not\nunderstand. She kissed his rough curly black head. At this instant, they\nheard the quick rustle of the countess\xe2\x80\x99 dress. She came up to them.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVas\xc3\xadli Dm\xc3\xadtrich, I thank you for the honor,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with an\nembarrassed voice, though it sounded severe to Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbut my\ndaughter is so young, and I thought that, as my son\xe2\x80\x99s friend, you\nwould have addressed yourself first to me. In that case you would not\nhave obliged me to give this refusal.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCountess...\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov, with downcast eyes and a guilty face.\nHe tried to say more, but faltered.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha could not remain calm, seeing him in such a plight. She began\nto sob aloud.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCountess, I have done w\xe2\x80\x99ong,\xe2\x80\x9d Den\xc3\xadsov went on in an unsteady\nvoice, \xe2\x80\x9cbut believe me, I so adore your daughter and all your family\nthat I would give my life twice over...\xe2\x80\x9d He looked at the countess,\nand seeing her severe face said: \xe2\x80\x9cWell, good-by, Countess,\xe2\x80\x9d and\nkissing her hand, he left the room with quick resolute strides, without\nlooking at Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\nNext day Rost\xc3\xb3v saw Den\xc3\xadsov off. He did not wish to stay another\nday in Moscow. All Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s Moscow friends gave him a farewell\nentertainment at the gypsies\xe2\x80\x99, with the result that he had no\nrecollection of how he was put in the sleigh or of the first three\nstages of his journey.\n\nAfter Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s departure, Rost\xc3\xb3v spent another fortnight in Moscow,\nwithout going out of the house, waiting for the money his father could\nnot at once raise, and he spent most of his time in the girls\xe2\x80\x99 room.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya was more tender and devoted to him than ever. It was as if she\nwanted to show him that his losses were an achievement that made her\nlove him all the more, but Nicholas now considered himself unworthy of\nher.\n\nHe filled the girls\xe2\x80\x99 albums with verses and music, and having at last\nsent D\xc3\xb3lokhov the whole forty-three thousand rubles and received his\nreceipt, he left at the end of November, without taking leave of any of\nhis acquaintances, to overtake his regiment which was already in Poland.\n\n\n\n\n\nBOOK FIVE: 1806 - 07\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER I\n\nAfter his interview with his wife Pierre left for Petersburg. At the\nTorzh\xc3\xb3k post station, either there were no horses or the postmaster\nwould not supply them. Pierre was obliged to wait. Without undressing,\nhe lay down on the leather sofa in front of a round table, put his big\nfeet in their overboots on the table, and began to reflect.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you have the portmanteaus brought in? And a bed got ready, and\ntea?\xe2\x80\x9d asked his valet.\n\nPierre gave no answer, for he neither heard nor saw anything. He had\nbegun to think of the last station and was still pondering on the same\nquestion\xe2\x80\x94one so important that he took no notice of what went\non around him. Not only was he indifferent as to whether he got to\nPetersburg earlier or later, or whether he secured accommodation at this\nstation, but compared to the thoughts that now occupied him it was a\nmatter of indifference whether he remained there for a few hours or for\nthe rest of his life.\n\nThe postmaster, his wife, the valet, and a peasant woman selling\nTorzh\xc3\xb3k embroidery came into the room offering their services.\nWithout changing his careless attitude, Pierre looked at them over his\nspectacles unable to understand what they wanted or how they could go on\nliving without having solved the problems that so absorbed him. He had\nbeen engrossed by the same thoughts ever since the day he returned from\nSok\xc3\xb3lniki after the duel and had spent that first agonizing, sleepless\nnight. But now, in the solitude of the journey, they seized him with\nspecial force. No matter what he thought about, he always returned to\nthese same questions which he could not solve and yet could not cease to\nask himself. It was as if the thread of the chief screw which held his\nlife together were stripped, so that the screw could not get in or out,\nbut went on turning uselessly in the same place.\n\nThe postmaster came in and began obsequiously to beg his excellency to\nwait only two hours, when, come what might, he would let his excellency\nhave the courier horses. It was plain that he was lying and only wanted\nto get more money from the traveler.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs this good or bad?\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre asked himself. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is good for me,\nbad for another traveler, and for himself it\xe2\x80\x99s unavoidable, because\nhe needs money for food; the man said an officer had once given him a\nthrashing for letting a private traveler have the courier horses.\nBut the officer thrashed him because he had to get on as quickly as\npossible. And I,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Pierre, \xe2\x80\x9cshot D\xc3\xb3lokhov because I\nconsidered myself injured, and Louis XVI was executed because they\nconsidered him a criminal, and a year later they executed those who\nexecuted him\xe2\x80\x94also for some reason. What is bad? What is good? What\nshould one love and what hate? What does one live for? And what am I?\nWhat is life, and what is death? What power governs all?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThere was no answer to any of these questions, except one, and that\nnot a logical answer and not at all a reply to them. The answer was:\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll die and all will end. You\xe2\x80\x99ll die and know all, or cease\nasking.\xe2\x80\x9d But dying was also dreadful.\n\nThe Torzh\xc3\xb3k peddler woman, in a whining voice, went on offering her\nwares, especially a pair of goatskin slippers. \xe2\x80\x9cI have hundreds of\nrubles I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what to do with, and she stands in her tattered\ncloak looking timidly at me,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd what does she\nwant the money for? As if that money could add a hair\xe2\x80\x99s breadth to\nhappiness or peace of mind. Can anything in the world make her or me\nless a prey to evil and death?\xe2\x80\x94death which ends all and must come\ntoday or tomorrow\xe2\x80\x94at any rate, in an instant as compared with\neternity.\xe2\x80\x9d And again he twisted the screw with the stripped thread,\nand again it turned uselessly in the same place.\n\nHis servant handed him a half-cut novel, in the form of letters, by\nMadame de Souza. He began reading about the sufferings and virtuous\nstruggles of a certain Emilie de Mansfeld. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd why did she resist\nher seducer when she loved him?\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cGod could not have put\ninto her heart an impulse that was against His will. My wife\xe2\x80\x94as she\nonce was\xe2\x80\x94did not struggle, and perhaps she was right. Nothing has been\nfound out, nothing discovered,\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre again said to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cAll\nwe can know is that we know nothing. And that\xe2\x80\x99s the height of human\nwisdom.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nEverything within and around him seemed confused, senseless, and\nrepellent.
