Announce me.\xe2\x80\x99 Vewy well, so out comes their head\nchief\xe2\x80\x94also took it into his head to lecture me: \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s\nwobbewy!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Wobbewy,\xe2\x80\x99 I say, \xe2\x80\x98is not done by man who seizes\npwovisions to feed his soldiers, but by him who takes them to fill his\nown pockets!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Will you please be silent?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Vewy good!\xe2\x80\x99 Then\nhe says: \xe2\x80\x98Go and give a weceipt to the commissioner, but your affair\nwill be passed on to headquarters.\xe2\x80\x99 I go to the commissioner. I enter,\nand at the table... who do you think? No, but wait a bit!... Who is it\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s starving us?\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Den\xc3\xadsov, hitting the table with the\nfist of his newly bled arm so violently that the table nearly broke down\nand the tumblers on it jumped about. \xe2\x80\x9cTely\xc3\xa1nin! \xe2\x80\x98What? So it\xe2\x80\x99s\nyou who\xe2\x80\x99s starving us to death! Is it? Take this and this!\xe2\x80\x99 and I\nhit him so pat, stwaight on his snout... \xe2\x80\x98Ah, what a... what a...!\xe2\x80\x99\nand I sta\xe2\x80\x99ted fwashing him... Well, I\xe2\x80\x99ve had a bit of fun I can tell\nyou!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Den\xc3\xadsov, gleeful and yet angry, his white teeth showing\nunder his black mustache. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d have killed him if they hadn\xe2\x80\x99t\ntaken him away!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what are you shouting for? Calm yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve set your arm bleeding afresh. Wait, we must tie it up\nagain.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov was bandaged up again and put to bed. Next day he woke calm and\ncheerful.\n\nBut at noon the adjutant of the regiment came into Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s and\nDen\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s dugout with a grave and serious face and regretfully showed\nthem a paper addressed to Major Den\xc3\xadsov from the regimental commander\nin which inquiries were made about yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s occurrence. The\nadjutant told them that the affair was likely to take a very bad\nturn: that a court-martial had been appointed, and that in view of the\nseverity with which marauding and insubordination were now regarded,\ndegradation to the ranks would be the best that could be hoped for.\n\nThe case, as represented by the offended parties, was that, after\nseizing the transports, Major Den\xc3\xadsov, being drunk, went to the chief\nquartermaster and without any provocation called him a thief, threatened\nto strike him, and on being led out had rushed into the office and given\ntwo officials a thrashing, and dislocated the arm of one of them.\n\nIn answer to Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s renewed questions, Den\xc3\xadsov said, laughing,\nthat he thought he remembered that some other fellow had got mixed up\nin it, but that it was all nonsense and rubbish, and he did not in the\nleast fear any kind of trial, and that if those scoundrels dared attack\nhim he would give them an answer that they would not easily forget.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov spoke contemptuously of the whole matter, but Rost\xc3\xb3v knew him\ntoo well not to detect that (while hiding it from others) at heart\nhe feared a court-martial and was worried over the affair, which was\nevidently taking a bad turn. Every day, letters of inquiry and notices\nfrom the court arrived, and on the first of May, Den\xc3\xadsov was ordered\nto hand the squadron over to the next in seniority and appear before\nthe staff of his division to explain his violence at the commissariat\noffice. On the previous day Pl\xc3\xa1tov reconnoitered with two Cossack\nregiments and two squadrons of hussars. Den\xc3\xadsov, as was his wont, rode\nout in front of the outposts, parading his courage. A bullet fired by\na French sharpshooter hit him in the fleshy part of his leg. Perhaps at\nanother time Den\xc3\xadsov would not have left the regiment for so slight a\nwound, but now he took advantage of it to excuse himself from appearing\nat the staff and went into hospital.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVII\n\nIn June the battle of Friedland was fought, in which the P\xc3\xa1vlograds did\nnot take part, and after that an armistice was proclaimed. Rost\xc3\xb3v, who\nfelt his friend\xe2\x80\x99s absence very much, having no news of him since he\nleft and feeling very anxious about his wound and the progress of his\naffairs, took advantage of the armistice to get leave to visit Den\xc3\xadsov\nin hospital.\n\nThe hospital was in a small Prussian town that had been twice devastated\nby Russian and French troops. Because it was summer, when it is so\nbeautiful out in the fields, the little town presented a particularly\ndismal appearance with its broken roofs and fences, its foul streets,\ntattered inhabitants, and the sick and drunken soldiers wandering about.\n\nThe hospital was in a brick building with some of the window frames and\npanes broken and a courtyard surrounded by the remains of a wooden fence\nthat had been pulled to pieces. Several bandaged soldiers, with pale\nswollen faces, were sitting or walking about in the sunshine in the\nyard.\n\nDirectly Rost\xc3\xb3v entered the door he was enveloped by a smell of\nputrefaction and hospital air. On the stairs he met a Russian army\ndoctor smoking a cigar. The doctor was followed by a Russian assistant.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t tear myself to pieces,\xe2\x80\x9d the doctor was saying. \xe2\x80\x9cCome to\nMak\xc3\xa1r Alex\xc3\xa9evich in the evening. I shall be there.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe assistant asked some further questions.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, do the best you can! Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it all the same?\xe2\x80\x9d The doctor\nnoticed Rost\xc3\xb3v coming upstairs.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d said the doctor. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want?\nThe bullets having spared you, do you want to try typhus? This is a\npesthouse, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTyphus, sir. It\xe2\x80\x99s death to go in. Only we two, Mak\xc3\xa9ev and I\xe2\x80\x9d (he\npointed to the assistant), \xe2\x80\x9ckeep on here. Some five of us doctors have\ndied in this place.... When a new one comes he is done for in a week,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid the doctor with evident satisfaction. \xe2\x80\x9cPrussian doctors have been\ninvited here, but our allies don\xe2\x80\x99t like it at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v explained that he wanted to see Major Den\xc3\xadsov of the hussars,\nwho was wounded.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know. I can\xe2\x80\x99t tell you, sir. Only think! I am alone in\ncharge of three hospitals with more than four hundred patients! It\xe2\x80\x99s\nwell that the charitable Prussian ladies send us two pounds of coffee\nand some lint each month or we should be lost!\xe2\x80\x9d he laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cFour\nhundred, sir, and they\xe2\x80\x99re always sending me fresh ones. There are four\nhundred? Eh?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, turning to the assistant.\n\nThe assistant looked fagged out. He was evidently vexed and impatient\nfor the talkative doctor to go.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMajor Den\xc3\xadsov,\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v said again. \xe2\x80\x9cHe was wounded at\nMolliten.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDead, I fancy. Eh, Mak\xc3\xa9ev?\xe2\x80\x9d queried the doctor, in a tone of\nindifference.\n\nThe assistant, however, did not confirm the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s words.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he tall and with reddish hair?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the doctor.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v described Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s appearance.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere was one like that,\xe2\x80\x9d said the doctor, as if pleased. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\none is dead, I fancy. However, I\xe2\x80\x99ll look up our list. We had a list.\nHave you got it, Mak\xc3\xa9ev?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMak\xc3\xa1r Alex\xc3\xa9evich has the list,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the assistant. \xe2\x80\x9cBut if\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll step into the officers\xe2\x80\x99 wards you\xe2\x80\x99ll see for yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe added, turning to Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you\xe2\x80\x99d better not go, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the doctor, \xe2\x80\x9cor you may\nhave to stay here yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBut Rost\xc3\xb3v bowed himself away from the doctor and asked the assistant\nto show him the way.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly don\xe2\x80\x99t blame me!\xe2\x80\x9d the doctor shouted up after him.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v and the assistant went into the dark corridor. The smell was so\nstrong there that Rost\xc3\xb3v held his nose and had to pause and collect\nhis strength before he could go on. A door opened to the right, and an\nemaciated sallow man on crutches, barefoot and in underclothing, limped\nout and, leaning against the doorpost, looked with glittering envious\neyes at those who were passing. Glancing in at the door, Rost\xc3\xb3v\nsaw that the sick and wounded were lying on the floor on straw and\novercoats.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I go in and look?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is there to see?\xe2\x80\x9d said the assistant.\n\nBut, just because the assistant evidently did not want him to go in,\nRost\xc3\xb3v entered the soldiers\xe2\x80\x99 ward. The foul air, to which he had\nalready begun to get used in the corridor, was still stronger here. It\nwas a little different, more pungent, and one felt that this was where\nit originated.\n\nIn the long room, brightly lit up by the sun through the large windows,\nthe sick and wounded lay in two rows with their heads to the walls, and\nleaving a passage in the middle. Most of them were unconscious and\npaid no attention to the newcomers. Those who were conscious raised\nthemselves or lifted their thin yellow faces, and all looked intently at\nRost\xc3\xb3v with the same expression of hope, of relief, reproach, and\nenvy of another\xe2\x80\x99s health. Rost\xc3\xb3v went to the middle of the room and\nlooking through the open doors into the two adjoining rooms saw the same\nthing there. He stood still, looking silently around. He had not at all\nexpected such a sight. Just before him, almost across the middle of the\npassage on the bare floor, lay a sick man, probably a Cossack to judge\nby the cut of his hair. The man lay on his back, his huge arms and legs\noutstretched. His face was purple, his eyes were rolled back so that\nonly the whites were seen, and on his bare legs and arms which were\nstill red, the veins stood out like cords. He was knocking the back of\nhis head against the floor, hoarsely uttering some word which he kept\nrepeating. Rost\xc3\xb3v listened and made out the word. It was \xe2\x80\x9cdrink,\ndrink, a drink!\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v glanced round, looking for someone who would\nput this man back in his place and bring him water.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho looks after the sick here?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked the assistant.\n\nJust then a commissariat soldier, a hospital orderly, came in from the\nnext room, marching stiffly, and drew up in front of Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood day, your honor!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted, rolling his eyes at Rost\xc3\xb3v and\nevidently mistaking him for one of the hospital authorities.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet him to his place and give him some water,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v,\npointing to the Cossack.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, your honor,\xe2\x80\x9d the soldier replied complacently, and rolling\nhis eyes more than ever he drew himself up still straighter, but did not\nmove.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible to do anything here,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Rost\xc3\xb3v,\nlowering his eyes, and he was going out, but became aware of an intense\nlook fixed on him on his right, and he turned. Close to the corner, on\nan overcoat, sat an old, unshaven, gray-bearded soldier as thin as a\nskeleton, with a stern sallow face and eyes intently fixed on Rost\xc3\xb3v.\nThe man\xe2\x80\x99s neighbor on one side whispered something to him, pointing\nat Rost\xc3\xb3v, who noticed that the old man wanted to speak to him. He drew\nnearer and saw that the old man had only one leg bent under him, the\nother had been amputated above the knee. His neighbor on the other side,\nwho lay motionless some distance from him with his head thrown back, was\na young soldier with a snub nose. His pale waxen face was still freckled\nand his eyes were rolled back. Rost\xc3\xb3v looked at the young soldier and a\ncold chill ran down his back.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, this one seems...\xe2\x80\x9d he began, turning to the assistant.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how we\xe2\x80\x99ve been begging, your honor,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old soldier,\nhis jaw quivering. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s been dead since morning. After all we\xe2\x80\x99re\nmen, not dogs.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll send someone at once. He shall be taken away\xe2\x80\x94taken away at\nonce,\xe2\x80\x9d said the assistant hurriedly. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us go, your honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, let us go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v hastily, and lowering his\neyes and shrinking, he tried to pass unnoticed between the rows of\nreproachful envious eyes that were fixed upon him, and went out of the\nroom.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVIII\n\nGoing along the corridor, the assistant led Rost\xc3\xb3v to the officers\xe2\x80\x99\nwards, consisting of three rooms, the doors of which stood open. There\nwere beds in these rooms and the sick and wounded officers were lying or\nsitting on them. Some were walking about the rooms in hospital dressing\ngowns. The first person Rost\xc3\xb3v met in the officers\xe2\x80\x99 ward was a thin\nlittle man with one arm, who was walking about the first room in a\nnightcap and hospital dressing gown, with a pipe between his teeth.\nRost\xc3\xb3v looked at him, trying to remember where he had seen him before.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee where we\xe2\x80\x99ve met again!\xe2\x80\x9d said the little man. \xe2\x80\x9cT\xc3\xbashin,\nT\xc3\xbashin, don\xe2\x80\x99t you remember, who gave you a lift at Sch\xc3\xb6n Grabern?\nAnd I\xe2\x80\x99ve had a bit cut off, you see...\xe2\x80\x9d he went on with a smile,\npointing to the empty sleeve of his dressing gown. \xe2\x80\x9cLooking for\nVas\xc3\xadli Dm\xc3\xadtrich Den\xc3\xadsov? My neighbor,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, when he heard\nwho Rost\xc3\xb3v wanted. \xe2\x80\x9cHere, here,\xe2\x80\x9d and T\xc3\xbashin led him into the next\nroom, from whence came sounds of several laughing voices.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can they laugh, or even live at all here?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Rost\xc3\xb3v,\nstill aware of that smell of decomposing flesh that had been so strong\nin the soldiers\xe2\x80\x99 ward, and still seeming to see fixed on him those\nenvious looks which had followed him out from both sides, and the face\nof that young soldier with eyes rolled back.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov lay asleep on his bed with his head under the blanket, though\nit was nearly noon.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Wost\xc3\xb3v? How are you, how are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he called out, still in the\nsame voice as in the regiment, but Rost\xc3\xb3v noticed sadly that under this\nhabitual ease and animation some new, sinister, hidden feeling showed\nitself in the expression of Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s face and the intonations of his\nvoice.\n\nHis wound, though a slight one, had not yet healed even now, six weeks\nafter he had been hit. His face had the same swollen pallor as the faces\nof the other hospital patients, but it was not this that struck Rost\xc3\xb3v.\nWhat struck him was that Den\xc3\xadsov did not seem glad to see him, and\nsmiled at him unnaturally. He did not ask about the regiment, nor about\nthe general state of affairs, and when Rost\xc3\xb3v spoke of these matters\ndid not listen.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v even noticed that Den\xc3\xadsov did not like to be reminded of the\nregiment, or in general of that other free life which was going on\noutside the hospital. He seemed to try to forget that old life and\nwas only interested in the affair with the commissariat officers. On\nRost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s inquiry as to how the matter stood, he at once produced from\nunder his pillow a paper he had received from the commission and the\nrough draft of his answer to it. He became animated when he began\nreading his paper and specially drew Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s attention to the\nstinging rejoinders he made to his enemies. His hospital companions,\nwho had gathered round Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x94a fresh arrival from the world\noutside\xe2\x80\x94gradually began to disperse as soon as Den\xc3\xadsov began reading\nhis answer. Rost\xc3\xb3v noticed by their faces that all those gentlemen had\nalready heard that story more than once and were tired of it. Only the\nman who had the next bed, a stout Uhlan, continued to sit on his bed,\ngloomily frowning and smoking a pipe, and little one-armed T\xc3\xbashin still\nlistened, shaking his head disapprovingly. In the middle of the reading,\nthe Uhlan interrupted Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what I say is,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, turning to Rost\xc3\xb3v, \xe2\x80\x9cit would be\nbest simply to petition the Emperor for pardon. They say great rewards\nwill now be distributed, and surely a pardon would be granted....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe petition the Empewo\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Den\xc3\xadsov, in a voice to which\nhe tried hard to give the old energy and fire, but which sounded like\nan expression of irritable impotence. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat for? If I were a wobber I\nwould ask mercy, but I\xe2\x80\x99m being court-martialed for bwinging wobbers\nto book. Let them twy me, I\xe2\x80\x99m not afwaid of anyone. I\xe2\x80\x99ve served\nthe Tsar and my countwy honowably and have not stolen! And am I to be\ndegwaded?... Listen, I\xe2\x80\x99m w\xe2\x80\x99iting to them stwaight. This is what I\nsay: \xe2\x80\x98If I had wobbed the Tweasuwy...\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s certainly well written,\xe2\x80\x9d said T\xc3\xbashin, \xe2\x80\x9cbut that\xe2\x80\x99s not\nthe point, Vas\xc3\xadli Dm\xc3\xadtrich,\xe2\x80\x9d and he also turned to Rost\xc3\xb3v. \xe2\x80\x9cOne\nhas to submit, and Vas\xc3\xadli Dm\xc3\xadtrich doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want to. You know the\nauditor told you it was a bad business.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, let it be bad,\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe auditor wrote out a petition for you,\xe2\x80\x9d continued T\xc3\xbashin,\n\xe2\x80\x9cand you ought to sign it and ask this gentleman to take it. No doubt\nhe\xe2\x80\x9d (indicating Rost\xc3\xb3v) \xe2\x80\x9chas connections on the staff. You won\xe2\x80\x99t\nfind a better opportunity.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHaven\xe2\x80\x99t I said I\xe2\x80\x99m not going to gwovel?\xe2\x80\x9d Den\xc3\xadsov interrupted\nhim, went on reading his paper.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v had not the courage to persuade Den\xc3\xadsov, though he\ninstinctively felt that the way advised by T\xc3\xbashin and the other\nofficers was the safest, and though he would have been glad to be of\nservice to Den\xc3\xadsov. He knew his stubborn will and straightforward hasty\ntemper.\n\nWhen the reading of Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s virulent reply, which took more than an\nhour, was over, Rost\xc3\xb3v said nothing, and he spent the rest of the day\nin a most dejected state of mind amid Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s hospital comrades,\nwho had gathered round him, telling them what he knew and listening to\ntheir stories. Den\xc3\xadsov was moodily silent all the evening.\n\nLate in the evening, when Rost\xc3\xb3v was about to leave, he asked Den\xc3\xadsov\nwhether he had no commission for him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, wait a bit,\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov, glancing round at the officers,\nand taking his papers from under his pillow he went to the window, where\nhe had an inkpot, and sat down to write.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems it\xe2\x80\x99s no use knocking one\xe2\x80\x99s head against a wall!\xe2\x80\x9d he\nsaid, coming from the window and giving Rost\xc3\xb3v a large envelope. In\nit was the petition to the Emperor drawn up by the auditor, in\nwhich Den\xc3\xadsov, without alluding to the offenses of the commissariat\nofficials, simply asked for pardon.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHand it in. It seems...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe did not finish, but gave a painfully unnatural smile.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIX\n\nHaving returned to the regiment and told the commander the state of\nDen\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s affairs, Rost\xc3\xb3v rode to Tilsit with the letter to the\nEmperor.\n\nOn the thirteenth of June the French and Russian Emperors arrived in\nTilsit. Bor\xc3\xads Drubetsk\xc3\xb3y had asked the important personage on whom he\nwas in attendance, to include him in the suite appointed for the stay at\nTilsit.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like to see the great man,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, alluding to Napoleon,\nwhom hitherto he, like everyone else, had always called Buonaparte.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are speaking of Buonaparte?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the general, smiling.\n\nBor\xc3\xads looked at his general inquiringly and immediately saw that he was\nbeing tested.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am speaking, Prince, of the Emperor Napoleon,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied. The\ngeneral patted him on the shoulder, with a smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will go far,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, and took him to Tilsit with him.\n\nBor\xc3\xads was among the few present at the Niemen on the day the two\nEmperors met. He saw the raft, decorated with monograms, saw Napoleon\npass before the French Guards on the farther bank of the river, saw the\npensive face of the Emperor Alexander as he sat in silence in a tavern\non the bank of the Niemen awaiting Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s arrival, saw both\nEmperors get into boats, and saw how Napoleon\xe2\x80\x94reaching the raft\nfirst\xe2\x80\x94stepped quickly forward to meet Alexander and held out his hand\nto him, and how they both retired into the pavilion. Since he had begun\nto move in the highest circles Bor\xc3\xads had made it his habit to watch\nattentively all that went on around him and to note it down. At the time\nof the meeting at Tilsit he asked the names of those who had come with\nNapoleon and about the uniforms they wore, and listened attentively to\nwords spoken by important personages. At the moment the Emperors went\ninto the pavilion he looked at his watch, and did not forget to look at\nit again when Alexander came out. The interview had lasted an hour and\nfifty-three minutes. He noted this down that same evening, among other\nfacts he felt to be of historic importance. As the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s suite\nwas a very small one, it was a matter of great importance, for a man who\nvalued his success in the service, to be at Tilsit on the occasion of\nthis interview between the two Emperors, and having succeeded in this,\nBor\xc3\xads felt that henceforth his position was fully assured. He had not\nonly become known, but people had grown accustomed to him and accepted\nhim. Twice he had executed commissions to the Emperor himself, so\nthat the latter knew his face, and all those at court, far from\ncold-shouldering him as at first when they considered him a newcomer,\nwould now have been surprised had he been absent.\n\nBor\xc3\xads lodged with another adjutant, the Polish Count Zhil\xc3\xadnski.\nZhil\xc3\xadnski, a Pole brought up in Paris, was rich, and passionately\nfond of the French, and almost every day of the stay at Tilsit, French\nofficers of the Guard and from French headquarters were dining and\nlunching with him and Bor\xc3\xads.\n\nOn the evening of the twenty-fourth of June, Count Zhil\xc3\xadnski arranged a\nsupper for his French friends. The guest of honor was an aide-de-camp of\nNapoleon\xe2\x80\x99s, there were also several French officers of the Guard,\nand a page of Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s, a young lad of an old aristocratic French\nfamily. That same day, Rost\xc3\xb3v, profiting by the darkness to avoid being\nrecognized in civilian dress, came to Tilsit and went to the lodging\noccupied by Bor\xc3\xads and Zhil\xc3\xadnski.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v, in common with the whole army from which he came, was far\nfrom having experienced the change of feeling toward Napoleon and the\nFrench\xe2\x80\x94who from being foes had suddenly become friends\xe2\x80\x94that had\ntaken place at headquarters and in Bor\xc3\xads. In the army, Bonaparte and\nthe French were still regarded with mingled feelings of anger, contempt,\nand fear. Only recently, talking with one of Pl\xc3\xa1tov\xe2\x80\x99s Cossack\nofficers, Rost\xc3\xb3v had argued that if Napoleon were taken prisoner he\nwould be treated not as a sovereign, but as a criminal. Quite lately,\nhappening to meet a wounded French colonel on the road, Rost\xc3\xb3v had\nmaintained with heat that peace was impossible between a legitimate\nsovereign and the criminal Bonaparte. Rost\xc3\xb3v was therefore unpleasantly\nstruck by the presence of French officers in Bor\xc3\xads\xe2\x80\x99 lodging, dressed\nin uniforms he had been accustomed to see from quite a different point\nof view from the outposts of the flank. As soon as he noticed a French\nofficer, who thrust his head out of the door, that warlike feeling of\nhostility which he always experienced at the sight of the enemy suddenly\nseized him. He stopped at the threshold and asked in Russian whether\nDrubetsk\xc3\xb3y lived there. Bor\xc3\xads, hearing a strange voice in the\nanteroom, came out to meet him. An expression of annoyance showed itself\nfor a moment on his face on first recognizing Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, it\xe2\x80\x99s you? Very glad, very glad to see you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, however,\ncoming toward him with a smile. But Rost\xc3\xb3v had noticed his first\nimpulse.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve come at a bad time I think. I should not have come, but I have\nbusiness,\xe2\x80\x9d he said coldly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I only wonder how you managed to get away from your regiment.\nDans un moment je suis \xc3\xa0 vous,\xe2\x80\x9d * he said, answering someone who\ncalled him.\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cIn a minute I shall be at your disposal.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see I\xe2\x80\x99m intruding,\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v repeated.\n\nThe look of annoyance had already disappeared from Bor\xc3\xads\xe2\x80\x99 face:\nhaving evidently reflected and decided how to act, he very quietly took\nboth Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s hands and led him into the next room. His eyes, looking\nserenely and steadily at Rost\xc3\xb3v, seemed to be veiled by something,\nas if screened by blue spectacles of conventionality. So it seemed to\nRost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, come now! As if you could come at a wrong time!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bor\xc3\xads,\nand he led him into the room where the supper table was laid and\nintroduced him to his guests, explaining that he was not a civilian, but\nan hussar officer, and an old friend of his.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount Zhil\xc3\xadnski\xe2\x80\x94le Comte N. N.\xe2\x80\x94le Capitaine S. S.,\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\nnaming his guests. Rost\xc3\xb3v looked frowningly at the Frenchmen, bowed\nreluctantly, and remained silent.\n\nZhil\xc3\xadnski evidently did not receive this new Russian person very\nwillingly into his circle and did not speak to Rost\xc3\xb3v. Bor\xc3\xads did not\nappear to notice the constraint the newcomer produced and, with the same\npleasant composure and the same veiled look in his eyes with which\nhe had met Rost\xc3\xb3v, tried to enliven the conversation. One of the\nFrenchmen, with the politeness characteristic of his countrymen,\naddressed the obstinately taciturn Rost\xc3\xb3v, saying that the latter had\nprobably come to Tilsit to see the Emperor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I came on business,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rost\xc3\xb3v, briefly.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v had been out of humor from the moment he noticed the look of\ndissatisfaction on Bor\xc3\xads\xe2\x80\x99 face, and as always happens to those in a\nbad humor, it seemed to him that everyone regarded him with aversion\nand that he was in everybody\xe2\x80\x99s way. He really was in their way, for he\nalone took no part in the conversation which again became general. The\nlooks the visitors cast on him seemed to say: \xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is he sitting\nhere for?\xe2\x80\x9d He rose and went up to Bor\xc3\xads.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnyhow, I\xe2\x80\x99m in your way,\xe2\x80\x9d he said in a low tone. \xe2\x80\x9cCome and talk\nover my business and I\xe2\x80\x99ll go away.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, not at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bor\xc3\xads. \xe2\x80\x9cBut if you are tired, come and\nlie down in my room and have a rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, really...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThey went into the little room where Bor\xc3\xads slept. Rost\xc3\xb3v, without\nsitting down, began at once, irritably (as if Bor\xc3\xads were to blame in\nsome way) telling him about Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s affair, asking him whether,\nthrough his general, he could and would intercede with the Emperor on\nDen\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s behalf and get Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s petition handed in. When he\nand Bor\xc3\xads were alone, Rost\xc3\xb3v felt for the first time that he could not\nlook Bor\xc3\xads in the face without a sense of awkwardness. Bor\xc3\xads, with one\nleg crossed over the other and stroking his left hand with the slender\nfingers of his right, listened to Rost\xc3\xb3v as a general listens to the\nreport of a subordinate, now looking aside and now gazing straight into\nRost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s eyes with the same veiled look. Each time this happened\nRost\xc3\xb3v felt uncomfortable and cast down his eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have heard of such cases and know that His Majesty is very severe\nin such affairs. I think it would be best not to bring it before the\nEmperor, but to apply to the commander of the corps.... But in general,\nI think...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you don\xe2\x80\x99t want to do anything? Well then, say so!\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v\nalmost shouted, not looking Bor\xc3\xads in the face.\n\nBor\xc3\xads smiled.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, I will do what I can. Only I thought...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAt that moment Zhil\xc3\xadnski\xe2\x80\x99s voice was heard calling Bor\xc3\xads.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then, go, go, go...\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v, and refusing supper and\nremaining alone in the little room, he walked up and down for a long\ntime, hearing the lighthearted French conversation from the next room.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XX\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v had come to Tilsit the day least suitable for a petition\non Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s behalf. He could not himself go to the general in\nattendance as he was in mufti and had come to Tilsit without permission\nto do so, and Bor\xc3\xads, even had he wished to, could not have done so on\nthe following day. On that day, June 27, the preliminaries of peace were\nsigned. The Emperors exchanged decorations: Alexander received the Cross\nof the Legion of Honor and Napoleon the Order of St. Andrew of the\nFirst Degree, and a dinner had been arranged for the evening, given by\na battalion of the French Guards to the Preobrazh\xc3\xa9nsk battalion. The\nEmperors were to be present at that banquet.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v felt so ill at ease and uncomfortable with Bor\xc3\xads that, when the\nlatter looked in after supper, he pretended to be asleep, and early next\nmorning went away, avoiding Bor\xc3\xads. In his civilian clothes and a\nround hat, he wandered about the town, staring at the French and their\nuniforms and at the streets and houses where the Russian and French\nEmperors were staying. In a square he saw tables being set up and\npreparations made for the dinner; he saw the Russian and French colors\ndraped from side to side of the streets, with huge monograms A and N. In\nthe windows of the houses also flags and bunting were displayed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBor\xc3\xads doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want to help me and I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to ask him.\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s settled,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nicholas. \xe2\x80\x9cAll is over between us, but\nI won\xe2\x80\x99t leave here without having done all I can for Den\xc3\xadsov and\ncertainly not without getting his letter to the Emperor. The Emperor!...\nHe is here!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Rost\xc3\xb3v, who had unconsciously returned to the\nhouse where Alexander lodged.\n\nSaddled horses were standing before the house and the suite were\nassembling, evidently preparing for the Emperor to come out.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI may see him at any moment,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Rost\xc3\xb3v. \xe2\x80\x9cIf only I were\nto hand the letter direct to him and tell him all... could they really\narrest me for my civilian clothes? Surely not! He would understand on\nwhose side justice lies. He understands everything, knows everything.\nWho can be more just, more magnanimous than he? And even if they did\narrest me for being here, what would it matter?\xe2\x80\x9d thought he, looking\nat an officer who was entering the house the Emperor occupied. \xe2\x80\x9cAfter\nall, people do go in.... It\xe2\x80\x99s all nonsense! I\xe2\x80\x99ll go in and hand\nthe letter to the Emperor myself so much the worse for Drubetsk\xc3\xb3y who\ndrives me to it!\xe2\x80\x9d And suddenly with a determination he himself did not\nexpect, Rost\xc3\xb3v felt for the letter in his pocket and went straight to\nthe house.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I won\xe2\x80\x99t miss my opportunity now, as I did after Austerlitz,\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe thought, expecting every moment to meet the monarch, and conscious of\nthe blood that rushed to his heart at the thought. \xe2\x80\x9cI will fall at\nhis feet and beseech him. He will lift me up, will listen, and will even\nthank me. \xe2\x80\x98I am happy when I can do good, but to remedy injustice is\nthe greatest happiness,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v fancied the sovereign saying. And\npassing people who looked after him with curiosity, he entered the porch\nof the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s house.\n\nA broad staircase led straight up from the entry, and to the right he\nsaw a closed door. Below, under the staircase, was a door leading to the\nlower floor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d someone inquired.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo hand in a letter, a petition, to His Majesty,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas,\nwith a tremor in his voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA petition? This way, to the officer on duty\xe2\x80\x9d (he was shown the\ndoor leading downstairs), \xe2\x80\x9conly it won\xe2\x80\x99t be accepted.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nOn hearing this indifferent voice, Rost\xc3\xb3v grew frightened at what\nhe was doing; the thought of meeting the Emperor at any moment was so\nfascinating and consequently so alarming that he was ready to run away,\nbut the official who had questioned him opened the door, and Rost\xc3\xb3v\nentered.\n\nA short stout man of about thirty, in white breeches and high boots and\na batiste shirt that he had evidently only just put on, standing in that\nroom, and his valet was buttoning on to the back of his breeches a\nnew pair of handsome silk-embroidered braces that, for some reason,\nattracted Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s attention. This man was speaking to someone in the\nadjoining room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA good figure and in her first bloom,\xe2\x80\x9d he was saying, but on seeing\nRost\xc3\xb3v, he stopped short and frowned.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it? A petition?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the person in the other room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnother petitioner,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the man with the braces.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell him to come later. He\xe2\x80\x99ll be coming out directly, we must\ngo.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLater... later! Tomorrow. It\xe2\x80\x99s too late...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v turned and was about to go, but the man in the braces stopped\nhim.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom have you come from? Who are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI come from Major Den\xc3\xadsov,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you an officer?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLieutenant Count Rost\xc3\xb3v.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat audacity! Hand it in through your commander. And go along with\nyou... go,\xe2\x80\x9d and he continued to put on the uniform the valet handed\nhim.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v went back into the hall and noticed that in the porch there were\nmany officers and generals in full parade uniform, whom he had to pass.\n\nCursing his temerity, his heart sinking at the thought of finding\nhimself at any moment face to face with the Emperor and being put to\nshame and arrested in his presence, fully alive now to the impropriety\nof his conduct and repenting of it, Rost\xc3\xb3v, with downcast eyes, was\nmaking his way out of the house through the brilliant suite when a\nfamiliar voice called him and a hand detained him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing here, sir, in civilian dress?\xe2\x80\x9d asked a deep\nvoice.\n\nIt was a cavalry general who had obtained the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s special favor\nduring this campaign, and who had formerly commanded the division in\nwhich Rost\xc3\xb3v was serving.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v, in dismay, began justifying himself, but seeing the kindly,\njocular face of the general, he took him aside and in an excited voice\ntold him the whole affair, asking him to intercede for Den\xc3\xadsov, whom\nthe general knew. Having heard Rost\xc3\xb3v to the end, the general shook his\nhead gravely.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sorry, sorry for that fine fellow. Give me the letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHardly had Rost\xc3\xb3v handed him the letter and finished explaining\nDen\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s case, when hasty steps and the jingling of spurs were heard\non the stairs, and the general, leaving him, went to the porch. The\ngentlemen of the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s suite ran down the stairs and went to their\nhorses. Hayne, the same groom who had been at Austerlitz, led up the\nEmperor\xe2\x80\x99s horse, and the faint creak of a footstep Rost\xc3\xb3v knew at\nonce was heard on the stairs. Forgetting the danger of being recognized,\nRost\xc3\xb3v went close to the porch, together with some inquisitive\ncivilians, and again, after two years, saw those features he adored:\nthat same face and same look and step, and the same union of majesty and\nmildness.... And the feeling of enthusiasm and love for his sovereign\nrose again in Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s soul in all its old force. In the uniform of\nthe Preobrazh\xc3\xa9nsk regiment\xe2\x80\x94white chamois-leather breeches and high\nboots\xe2\x80\x94and wearing a star Rost\xc3\xb3v did not know (it was that of the\nL\xc3\xa9gion d\xe2\x80\x99honneur), the monarch came out into the porch, putting on\nhis gloves and carrying his hat under his arm. He stopped and looked\nabout him, brightening everything around by his glance. He spoke a few\nwords to some of the generals, and, recognizing the former commander of\nRost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s division, smiled and beckoned to him.\n\nAll the suite drew back and Rost\xc3\xb3v saw the general talking for some\ntime to the Emperor.\n\nThe Emperor said a few words to him and took a step toward his horse.\nAgain the crowd of members of the suite and street gazers (among whom\nwas Rost\xc3\xb3v) moved nearer to the Emperor. Stopping beside his horse,\nwith his hand on the saddle, the Emperor turned to the cavalry general\nand said in a loud voice, evidently wishing to be heard by all:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot do it, General. I cannot, because the law is stronger than\nI,\xe2\x80\x9d and he raised his foot to the stirrup.\n\nThe general bowed his head respectfully, and the monarch mounted and\nrode down the street at a gallop. Beside himself with enthusiasm,\nRost\xc3\xb3v ran after him with the crowd.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XXI\n\nThe Emperor rode to the square where, facing one another, a battalion\nof the Preobrazh\xc3\xa9nsk regiment stood on the right and a battalion of the\nFrench Guards in their bearskin caps on the left.\n\nAs the Tsar rode up to one flank of the battalions, which presented\narms, another group of horsemen galloped up to the opposite flank, and\nat the head of them Rost\xc3\xb3v recognized Napoleon. It could be no one\nelse. He came at a gallop, wearing a small hat, a blue uniform open over\na white vest, and the St. Andrew ribbon over his shoulder. He was riding\na very fine thoroughbred gray Arab horse with a crimson gold-embroidered\nsaddlecloth. On approaching Alexander he raised his hat, and as he did\nso, Rost\xc3\xb3v, with his cavalryman\xe2\x80\x99s eye, could not help noticing\nthat Napoleon did not sit well or firmly in the saddle. The battalions\nshouted \xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cVive l\xe2\x80\x99Empereur!\xe2\x80\x9d Napoleon said\nsomething to Alexander, and both Emperors dismounted and took each\nother\xe2\x80\x99s hands. Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s face wore an unpleasant and artificial\nsmile. Alexander was saying something affable to him.\n\nIn spite of the trampling of the French gendarmes\xe2\x80\x99 horses, which\nwere pushing back the crowd, Rost\xc3\xb3v kept his eyes on every movement\nof Alexander and Bonaparte. It struck him as a surprise that Alexander\ntreated Bonaparte as an equal and that the latter was quite at ease with\nthe Tsar, as if such relations with an Emperor were an everyday matter\nto him.\n\nAlexander and Napoleon, with the long train of their suites, approached\nthe right flank of the Preobrazh\xc3\xa9nsk battalion and came straight up to\nthe crowd standing there. The crowd unexpectedly found itself so close\nto the Emperors that Rost\xc3\xb3v, standing in the front row, was afraid he\nmight be recognized.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, I ask your permission to present the Legion of Honor to the\nbravest of your soldiers,\xe2\x80\x9d said a sharp, precise voice, articulating\nevery letter.\n\nThis was said by the undersized Napoleon, looking up straight into\nAlexander\xe2\x80\x99s eyes. Alexander listened attentively to what was said to\nhim and, bending his head, smiled pleasantly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo him who has borne himself most bravely in this last war,\xe2\x80\x9d added\nNapoleon, accentuating each syllable, as with a composure and assurance\nexasperating to Rost\xc3\xb3v, he ran his eyes over the Russian ranks drawn\nup before him, who all presented arms with their eyes fixed on their\nEmperor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill Your Majesty allow me to consult the colonel?\xe2\x80\x9d said Alexander\nand took a few hasty steps toward Prince Kozl\xc3\xb3vski, the commander of\nthe battalion.\n\nBonaparte meanwhile began taking the glove off his small white hand,\ntore it in doing so, and threw it away. An aide-de-camp behind him\nrushed forward and picked it up.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo whom shall it be given?\xe2\x80\x9d the Emperor Alexander asked Kozl\xc3\xb3vski,\nin Russian in a low voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo whomever Your Majesty commands.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe Emperor knit his brows with dissatisfaction and, glancing back,\nremarked:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut we must give him an answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nKozl\xc3\xb3vski scanned the ranks resolutely and included Rost\xc3\xb3v in his\nscrutiny.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan it be me?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cL\xc3\xa1zarev!\xe2\x80\x9d the colonel called, with a frown, and L\xc3\xa1zarev, the\nfirst soldier in the rank, stepped briskly forward.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you off to? Stop here!\xe2\x80\x9d voices whispered to L\xc3\xa1zarev who\ndid not know where to go. L\xc3\xa1zarev stopped, casting a sidelong look at\nhis colonel in alarm. His face twitched, as often happens to soldiers\ncalled before the ranks.\n\nNapoleon slightly turned his head, and put his plump little hand out\nbehind him as if to take something. The members of his suite, guessing\nat once what he wanted, moved about and whispered as they passed\nsomething from one to another, and a page\xe2\x80\x94the same one Rost\xc3\xb3v\nhad seen the previous evening at Bor\xc3\xads\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94ran forward and, bowing\nrespectfully over the outstretched hand and not keeping it waiting a\nmoment, laid in it an Order on a red ribbon. Napoleon, without looking,\npressed two fingers together and the badge was between them. Then he\napproached L\xc3\xa1zarev (who rolled his eyes and persistently gazed at his\nown monarch), looked round at the Emperor Alexander to imply that what\nhe was now doing was done for the sake of his ally, and the small white\nhand holding the Order touched one of L\xc3\xa1zarev\xe2\x80\x99s buttons. It was as if\nNapoleon knew that it was only necessary for his hand to deign to touch\nthat soldier\xe2\x80\x99s breast for the soldier to be forever happy, rewarded,\nand distinguished from everyone else in the world. Napoleon merely laid\nthe cross on L\xc3\xa1zarev\xe2\x80\x99s breast and, dropping his hand, turned toward\nAlexander as though sure that the cross would adhere there. And it\nreally did.\n\nOfficious hands, Russian and French, immediately seized the cross and\nfastened it to the uniform. L\xc3\xa1zarev glanced morosely at the little\nman with white hands who was doing something to him and, still standing\nmotionless presenting arms, looked again straight into Alexander\xe2\x80\x99s\neyes, as if asking whether he should stand there, or go away, or do\nsomething else. But receiving no orders, he remained for some time in\nthat rigid position.\n\nThe Emperors remounted and rode away. The Preobrazh\xc3\xa9nsk battalion,\nbreaking rank, mingled with the French Guards and sat down at the tables\nprepared for them.\n\nL\xc3\xa1zarev sat in the place of honor. Russian and French officers embraced\nhim, congratulated him, and pressed his hands. Crowds of officers and\ncivilians drew near merely to see him. A rumble of Russian and French\nvoices and laughter filled the air round the tables in the square.\nTwo officers with flushed faces, looking cheerful and happy, passed by\nRost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat d\xe2\x80\x99you think of the treat? All on silver plate,\xe2\x80\x9d one of them\nwas saying. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you seen L\xc3\xa1zarev?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow, I hear, the Preobrazh\xc3\xa9nskis will give them a dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but what luck for L\xc3\xa1zarev! Twelve hundred francs\xe2\x80\x99 pension for\nlife.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s a cap, lads!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted a Preobrazh\xc3\xa9nsk soldier, donning a\nshaggy French cap.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a fine thing! First-rate!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you heard the password?\xe2\x80\x9d asked one Guards\xe2\x80\x99 officer of\nanother. \xe2\x80\x9cThe day before yesterday it was \xe2\x80\x98Napol\xc3\xa9on, France,\nbravoure\xe2\x80\x99; yesterday, \xe2\x80\x98Alexandre, Russie, grandeur.\xe2\x80\x99 One day our\nEmperor gives it and next day Napoleon. Tomorrow our Emperor will send\na St. George\xe2\x80\x99s Cross to the bravest of the French Guards. It has to be\ndone. He must respond in kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBor\xc3\xads, too, with his friend Zhil\xc3\xadnski, came to see the Preobrazh\xc3\xa9nsk\nbanquet. On his way back, he noticed Rost\xc3\xb3v standing by the corner of a\nhouse.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cRost\xc3\xb3v! How d\xe2\x80\x99you do? We missed one another,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, and could\nnot refrain from asking what was the matter, so strangely dismal and\ntroubled was Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing, nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll call round?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I will.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v stood at that corner for a long time, watching the feast from a\ndistance. In his mind, a painful process was going on which he could\nnot bring to a conclusion. Terrible doubts rose in his soul. Now he\nremembered Den\xc3\xadsov with his changed expression, his submission, and the\nwhole hospital, with arms and legs torn off and its dirt and disease. So\nvividly did he recall that hospital stench of dead flesh that he\nlooked round to see where the smell came from. Next he thought of that\nself-satisfied Bonaparte, with his small white hand, who was now an\nEmperor, liked and respected by Alexander. Then why those severed\narms and legs and those dead men?... Then again he thought of L\xc3\xa1zarev\nrewarded and Den\xc3\xadsov punished and unpardoned. He caught himself\nharboring such strange thoughts that he was frightened.\n\nThe smell of the food the Preobrazh\xc3\xa9nskis were eating and a sense of\nhunger recalled him from these reflections; he had to get something to\neat before going away. He went to a hotel he had noticed that morning.\nThere he found so many people, among them officers who, like himself,\nhad come in civilian clothes, that he had difficulty in getting a\ndinner. Two officers of his own division joined him. The conversation\nnaturally turned on the peace. The officers, his comrades, like most of\nthe army, were dissatisfied with the peace concluded after the battle of\nFriedland. They said that had we held out a little longer Napoleon would\nhave been done for, as his troops had neither provisions nor ammunition.\nNicholas ate and drank (chiefly the latter) in silence. He finished a\ncouple of bottles of wine by himself. The process in his mind went on\ntormenting him without reaching a conclusion. He feared to give way to\nhis thoughts, yet could not get rid of them. Suddenly, on one of the\nofficers\xe2\x80\x99 saying that it was humiliating to look at the French,\nRost\xc3\xb3v began shouting with uncalled-for wrath, and therefore much to\nthe surprise of the officers:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can you judge what\xe2\x80\x99s best?\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, the blood suddenly\nrushing to his face. \xe2\x80\x9cHow can you judge the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s actions? What\nright have we to argue? We cannot comprehend either the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s aims\nor his actions!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I never said a word about the Emperor!\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer,\njustifying himself, and unable to understand Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s outburst,\nexcept on the supposition that he was drunk.\n\nBut Rost\xc3\xb3v did not listen to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are not diplomatic officials, we are soldiers and nothing more,\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe went on. \xe2\x80\x9cIf we are ordered to die, we must die. If we\xe2\x80\x99re\npunished, it means that we have deserved it, it\xe2\x80\x99s not for us to judge.\nIf the Emperor pleases to recognize Bonaparte as Emperor and to conclude\nan alliance with him, it means that that is the right thing to do. If\nonce we begin judging and arguing about everything, nothing sacred\nwill be left! That way we shall be saying there is no God\xe2\x80\x94nothing!\xe2\x80\x9d\nshouted Nicholas, banging the table\xe2\x80\x94very little to the point as it\nseemed to his listeners, but quite relevantly to the course of his own\nthoughts.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur business is to do our duty, to fight and not to think! That\xe2\x80\x99s\nall....\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd to drink,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the officers, not wishing to quarrel.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and to drink,\xe2\x80\x9d assented Nicholas. \xe2\x80\x9cHullo there! Another\nbottle!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted.\n\nIn 1808 the Emperor Alexander went to Erfurt for a fresh interview with\nthe Emperor Napoleon, and in the upper circles of Petersburg there was\nmuch talk of the grandeur of this important meeting.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XXII\n\nIn 1809 the intimacy between \xe2\x80\x9cthe world\xe2\x80\x99s two arbiters,\xe2\x80\x9d as\nNapoleon and Alexander were called, was such that when Napoleon declared\nwar on Austria a Russian corps crossed the frontier to co-operate with\nour old enemy Bonaparte against our old ally the Emperor of Austria, and\nin court circles the possibility of marriage between Napoleon and one\nof Alexander\xe2\x80\x99s sisters was spoken of. But besides considerations of\nforeign policy, the attention of Russian society was at that time keenly\ndirected on the internal changes that were being undertaken in all the\ndepartments of government.\n\nLife meanwhile\xe2\x80\x94real life, with its essential interests of health and\nsickness, toil and rest, and its intellectual interests in thought,\nscience, poetry, music, love, friendship, hatred, and passions\xe2\x80\x94went on\nas usual, independently of and apart from political friendship or enmity\nwith Napoleon Bonaparte and from all the schemes of reconstruction.\n\n\n\n\n\nBOOK SIX: 1808 - 10\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER I\n\nPrince Andrew had spent two years continuously in the country.\n\nAll the plans Pierre had attempted on his estates\xe2\x80\x94and constantly\nchanging from one thing to another had never accomplished\xe2\x80\x94were carried\nout by Prince Andrew without display and without perceptible difficulty.\n\nHe had in the highest degree a practical tenacity which Pierre lacked,\nand without fuss or strain on his part this set things going.\n\nOn one of his estates the three hundred serfs were liberated and became\nfree agricultural laborers\xe2\x80\x94this being one of the first examples of\nthe kind in Russia. On other estates the serfs\xe2\x80\x99 compulsory labor was\ncommuted for a quitrent. A trained midwife was engaged for Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo\nat his expense, and a priest was paid to teach reading and writing to\nthe children of the peasants and household serfs.\n\nPrince Andrew spent half his time at Bald Hills with his father and his\nson, who was still in the care of nurses. The other half he spent in\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoguch\xc3\xa1rovo Cloister,\xe2\x80\x9d as his father called Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s\nestate. Despite the indifference to the affairs of the world he had\nexpressed to Pierre, he diligently followed all that went on, received\nmany books, and to his surprise noticed that when he or his father had\nvisitors from Petersburg, the very vortex of life, these people lagged\nbehind himself\xe2\x80\x94who never left the country\xe2\x80\x94in knowledge of what was\nhappening in home and foreign affairs.\n\nBesides being occupied with his estates and reading a great variety of\nbooks, Prince Andrew was at this time busy with a critical survey of\nour last two unfortunate campaigns, and with drawing up a proposal for a\nreform of the army rules and regulations.\n\nIn the spring of 1809 he went to visit the Ryaz\xc3\xa1n estates which had\nbeen inherited by his son, whose guardian he was.\n\nWarmed by the spring sunshine he sat in the cal\xc3\xa8che looking at the new\ngrass, the first leaves on the birches, and the first puffs of white\nspring clouds floating across the clear blue sky. He was not thinking of\nanything, but looked absent-mindedly and cheerfully from side to side.\n\nThey crossed the ferry where he had talked with Pierre the year before.\nThey went through the muddy village, past threshing floors and green\nfields of winter rye, downhill where snow still lodged near the bridge,\nuphill where the clay had been liquefied by the rain, past strips of\nstubble land and bushes touched with green here and there, and into a\nbirch forest growing on both sides of the road. In the forest it was\nalmost hot, no wind could be felt. The birches with their sticky green\nleaves were motionless, and lilac-colored flowers and the first blades\nof green grass were pushing up and lifting last year\xe2\x80\x99s leaves. The\ncoarse evergreen color of the small fir trees scattered here and there\namong the birches was an unpleasant reminder of winter. On entering the\nforest the horses began to snort and sweated visibly.\n\nPeter the footman made some remark to the coachman; the latter assented.\nBut apparently the coachman\xe2\x80\x99s sympathy was not enough for Peter, and\nhe turned on the box toward his master.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow pleasant it is, your excellency!\xe2\x80\x9d he said with a respectful\nsmile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s pleasant, your excellency!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is he talking about?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, the\nspring, I suppose,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought as he turned round. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, really\neverything is green already.... How early! The birches and cherry and\nalders too are coming out.... But the oaks show no sign yet. Ah, here is\none oak!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAt the edge of the road stood an oak. Probably ten times the age of the\nbirches that formed the forest, it was ten times as thick and twice as\ntall as they. It was an enormous tree, its girth twice as great as a\nman could embrace, and evidently long ago some of its branches had been\nbroken off and its bark scarred. With its huge ungainly limbs sprawling\nunsymmetrically, and its gnarled hands and fingers, it stood an aged,\nstern, and scornful monster among the smiling birch trees. Only the\ndead-looking evergreen firs dotted about in the forest, and this oak,\nrefused to yield to the charm of spring or notice either the spring or\nthe sunshine.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpring, love, happiness!\xe2\x80\x9d this oak seemed to say. \xe2\x80\x9cAre you not\nweary of that stupid, meaningless, constantly repeated fraud? Always the\nsame and always a fraud? There is no spring, no sun, no happiness! Look\nat those cramped dead firs, ever the same, and at me too, sticking out\nmy broken and barked fingers just where they have grown, whether from my\nback or my sides: as they have grown so I stand, and I do not believe in\nyour hopes and your lies.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAs he passed through the forest Prince Andrew turned several times to\nlook at that oak, as if expecting something from it. Under the oak,\ntoo, were flowers and grass, but it stood among them scowling, rigid,\nmisshapen, and grim as ever.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the oak is right, a thousand times right,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Prince\nAndrew. \xe2\x80\x9cLet others\xe2\x80\x94the young\xe2\x80\x94yield afresh to that fraud, but we\nknow life, our life is finished!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nA whole sequence of new thoughts, hopeless but mournfully pleasant, rose\nin his soul in connection with that tree. During this journey he, as\nit were, considered his life afresh and arrived at his old conclusion,\nrestful in its hopelessness: that it was not for him to begin anything\nanew\xe2\x80\x94but that he must live out his life, content to do no harm, and\nnot disturbing himself or desiring anything.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER II\n\nPrince Andrew had to see the Marshal of the Nobility for the district\nin connection with the affairs of the Ryaz\xc3\xa1n estate of which he was\ntrustee. This Marshal was Count Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v, and in the middle of May\nPrince Andrew went to visit him.\n\nIt was now hot spring weather. The whole forest was already clothed in\ngreen. It was dusty and so hot that on passing near water one longed to\nbathe.\n\nPrince Andrew, depressed and preoccupied with the business about which\nhe had to speak to the Marshal, was driving up the avenue in the grounds\nof the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 house at Otr\xc3\xa1dnoe. He heard merry girlish cries\nbehind some trees on the right and saw a group of girls running to cross\nthe path of his cal\xc3\xa8che. Ahead of the rest and nearer to him ran a\ndark-haired, remarkably slim, pretty girl in a yellow chintz dress, with\na white handkerchief on her head from under which loose locks of hair\nescaped. The girl was shouting something but, seeing that he was a\nstranger, ran back laughing without looking at him.\n\nSuddenly, he did not know why, he felt a pang. The day was so beautiful,\nthe sun so bright, everything around so gay, but that slim pretty girl\ndid not know, or wish to know, of his existence and was contented and\ncheerful in her own separate\xe2\x80\x94probably foolish\xe2\x80\x94but bright and happy\nlife. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is she so glad about? What is she thinking of? Not of\nthe military regulations or of the arrangement of the Ryaz\xc3\xa1n serfs\xe2\x80\x99\nquitrents. Of what is she thinking? Why is she so happy?\xe2\x80\x9d Prince\nAndrew asked himself with instinctive curiosity.\n\nIn 1809 Count Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v was living at Otr\xc3\xa1dnoe just as he had done\nin former years, that is, entertaining almost the whole province with\nhunts, theatricals, dinners, and music. He was glad to see Prince\nAndrew, as he was to see any new visitor, and insisted on his staying\nthe night.\n\nDuring the dull day, in the course of which he was entertained by\nhis elderly hosts and by the more important of the visitors (the old\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s house was crowded on account of an approaching name day),\nPrince Andrew repeatedly glanced at Nat\xc3\xa1sha, gay and laughing among the\nyounger members of the company, and asked himself each time, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is\nshe thinking about? Why is she so glad?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThat night, alone in new surroundings, he was long unable to sleep. He\nread awhile and then put out his candle, but relit it. It was hot in the\nroom, the inside shutters of which were closed. He was cross with the\nstupid old man (as he called Rost\xc3\xb3v), who had made him stay by assuring\nhim that some necessary documents had not yet arrived from town, and he\nwas vexed with himself for having stayed.\n\nHe got up and went to the window to open it. As soon as he opened the\nshutters the moonlight, as if it had long been watching for this, burst\ninto the room. He opened the casement. The night was fresh, bright, and\nvery still. Just before the window was a row of pollard trees, looking\nblack on one side and with a silvery light on the other. Beneath the\ntrees grew some kind of lush, wet, bushy vegetation with silver-lit\nleaves and stems here and there. Farther back beyond the dark trees a\nroof glittered with dew, to the right was a leafy tree with brilliantly\nwhite trunk and branches, and above it shone the moon, nearly at its\nfull, in a pale, almost starless, spring sky. Prince Andrew leaned his\nelbows on the window ledge and his eyes rested on that sky.\n\nHis room was on the first floor. Those in the rooms above were also\nawake. He heard female voices overhead.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust once more,\xe2\x80\x9d said a girlish voice above him which Prince Andrew\nrecognized at once.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut when are you coming to bed?\xe2\x80\x9d replied another voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t, I can\xe2\x80\x99t sleep, what\xe2\x80\x99s the use? Come now for the last\ntime.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nTwo girlish voices sang a musical passage\xe2\x80\x94the end of some song.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, how lovely! Now go to sleep, and there\xe2\x80\x99s an end of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou go to sleep, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said the first voice, coming\nnearer to the window. She was evidently leaning right out, for the\nrustle of her dress and even her breathing could be heard. Everything\nwas stone-still, like the moon and its light and the shadows. Prince\nAndrew, too, dared not stir, for fear of betraying his unintentional\npresence.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xb3nya! S\xc3\xb3nya!\xe2\x80\x9d he again heard the first speaker. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, how can\nyou sleep? Only look how glorious it is! Ah, how glorious! Do wake up,\nS\xc3\xb3nya!\xe2\x80\x9d she said almost with tears in her voice. \xe2\x80\x9cThere never,\nnever was such a lovely night before!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya made some reluctant reply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo just come and see what a moon!... Oh, how lovely! Come here....\nDarling, sweetheart, come here! There, you see? I feel like sitting down\non my heels, putting my arms round my knees like this, straining tight,\nas tight as possible, and flying away! Like this....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake care, you\xe2\x80\x99ll fall out.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe heard the sound of a scuffle and S\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s disapproving voice:\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s past one o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you only spoil things for me. All right, go, go!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAgain all was silent, but Prince Andrew knew she was still sitting\nthere. From time to time he heard a soft rustle and at times a sigh.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cO God, O God! What does it mean?\xe2\x80\x9d she suddenly exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cTo bed\nthen, if it must be!\xe2\x80\x9d and she slammed the casement.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor her I might as well not exist!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Prince Andrew while he\nlistened to her voice, for some reason expecting yet fearing that she\nmight say something about him. \xe2\x80\x9cThere she is again! As if it were on\npurpose,\xe2\x80\x9d thought he.\n\nIn his soul there suddenly arose such an unexpected turmoil of youthful\nthoughts and hopes, contrary to the whole tenor of his life, that unable\nto explain his condition to himself he lay down and fell asleep at once.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER III\n\nNext morning, having taken leave of no one but the count, and not\nwaiting for the ladies to appear, Prince Andrew set off for home.\n\nIt was already the beginning of June when on his return journey he drove\ninto the birch forest where the gnarled old oak had made so strange and\nmemorable an impression on him. In the forest the harness bells sounded\nyet more muffled than they had done six weeks before, for now all was\nthick, shady, and dense, and the young firs dotted about in the forest\ndid not jar on the general beauty but, lending themselves to the mood\naround, were delicately green with fluffy young shoots.\n\nThe whole day had been hot. Somewhere a storm was gathering, but only\na small cloud had scattered some raindrops lightly, sprinkling the road\nand the sappy leaves. The left side of the forest was dark in the shade,\nthe right side glittered in the sunlight, wet and shiny and scarcely\nswayed by the breeze. Everything was in blossom, the nightingales\ntrilled, and their voices reverberated now near, now far away.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, here in this forest was that oak with which I agreed,\xe2\x80\x9d thought\nPrince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cBut where is it?\xe2\x80\x9d he again wondered, gazing at\nthe left side of the road, and without recognizing it he looked with\nadmiration at the very oak he sought. The old oak, quite transfigured,\nspreading out a canopy of sappy dark-green foliage, stood rapt and\nslightly trembling in the rays of the evening sun. Neither gnarled\nfingers nor old scars nor old doubts and sorrows were any of them in\nevidence now. Through the hard century-old bark, even where there were\nno twigs, leaves had sprouted such as one could hardly believe the old\nveteran could have produced.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it is the same oak,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Prince Andrew, and all at once he\nwas seized by an unreasoning springtime feeling of joy and renewal. All\nthe best moments of his life suddenly rose to his memory. Austerlitz\nwith the lofty heavens, his wife\xe2\x80\x99s dead reproachful face, Pierre at\nthe ferry, that girl thrilled by the beauty of the night, and that night\nitself and the moon, and... all this rushed suddenly to his mind.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, life is not over at thirty-one!\xe2\x80\x9d Prince Andrew suddenly decided\nfinally and decisively. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is not enough for me to know what I have\nin me\xe2\x80\x94everyone must know it: Pierre, and that young girl who wanted to\nfly away into the sky, everyone must know me, so that my life may not be\nlived for myself alone while others live so apart from it, but so that\nit may be reflected in them all, and they and I may live in harmony!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nOn reaching home Prince Andrew decided to go to Petersburg that autumn\nand found all sorts of reasons for this decision. A whole series of\nsensible and logical considerations showing it to be essential for him\nto go to Petersburg, and even to re-enter the service, kept springing\nup in his mind. He could not now understand how he could ever even have\ndoubted the necessity of taking an active share in life, just as a month\nbefore he had not understood how the idea of leaving the quiet country\ncould ever enter his head. It now seemed clear to him that all his\nexperience of life must be senselessly wasted unless he applied it to\nsome kind of work and again played an active part in life. He did not\neven remember how formerly, on the strength of similar wretched logical\narguments, it had seemed obvious that he would be degrading himself if\nhe now, after the lessons he had had in life, allowed himself to believe\nin the possibility of being useful and in the possibility of happiness\nor love. Now reason suggested quite the opposite. After that journey\nto Ryaz\xc3\xa1n he found the country dull; his former pursuits no longer\ninterested him, and often when sitting alone in his study he got up,\nwent to the mirror, and gazed a long time at his own face. Then he would\nturn away to the portrait of his dead Lise, who with hair curled \xc3\xa0 la\ngrecque looked tenderly and gaily at him out of the gilt frame. She\ndid not now say those former terrible words to him, but looked simply,\nmerrily, and inquisitively at him. And Prince Andrew, crossing his\narms behind him, long paced the room, now frowning, now smiling, as\nhe reflected on those irrational, inexpressible thoughts, secret as a\ncrime, which altered his whole life and were connected with Pierre, with\nfame, with the girl at the window, the oak, and woman\xe2\x80\x99s beauty\nand love. And if anyone came into his room at such moments he was\nparticularly cold, stern, and above all unpleasantly logical.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear,\xe2\x80\x9d Princess Mary entering at such a moment would say,\n\xe2\x80\x9clittle Nicholas can\xe2\x80\x99t go out today, it\xe2\x80\x99s very cold.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it were hot,\xe2\x80\x9d Prince Andrew would reply at such times very dryly\nto his sister, \xe2\x80\x9che could go out in his smock, but as it is cold he\nmust wear warm clothes, which were designed for that purpose. That is\nwhat follows from the fact that it is cold; and not that a child who\nneeds fresh air should remain at home,\xe2\x80\x9d he would add with extreme\nlogic, as if punishing someone for those secret illogical emotions that\nstirred within him.\n\nAt such moments Princess Mary would think how intellectual work dries\nmen up.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IV\n\nPrince Andrew arrived in Petersburg in August, 1809. It was the time\nwhen the youthful Sper\xc3\xa1nski was at the zenith of his fame and his\nreforms were being pushed forward with the greatest energy. That same\nAugust the Emperor was thrown from his cal\xc3\xa8che, injured his leg, and\nremained three weeks at Peterhof, receiving Sper\xc3\xa1nski every day and no\none else. At that time the two famous decrees were being prepared\nthat so agitated society\xe2\x80\x94abolishing court ranks and introducing\nexaminations to qualify for the grades of Collegiate Assessor and\nState Councilor\xe2\x80\x94and not merely these but a whole state constitution,\nintended to change the existing order of government in Russia: legal,\nadministrative, and financial, from the Council of State down to the\ndistrict tribunals. Now those vague liberal dreams with which the\nEmperor Alexander had ascended the throne, and which he had tried to put\ninto effect with the aid of his associates, Czartor\xc3\xbdski, Novos\xc3\xadltsev,\nKochub\xc3\xa9y, and Str\xc3\xb3gonov\xe2\x80\x94whom he himself in jest had called his\nComit\xc3\xa9 de salut public\xe2\x80\x94were taking shape and being realized.\n\nNow all these men were replaced by Sper\xc3\xa1nski on the civil side, and\nArakch\xc3\xa9ev on the military. Soon after his arrival Prince Andrew, as a\ngentleman of the chamber, presented himself at court and at a levee. The\nEmperor, though he met him twice, did not favor him with a single word.\nIt had always seemed to Prince Andrew before that he was antipathetic\nto the Emperor and that the latter disliked his face and personality\ngenerally, and in the cold, repellent glance the Emperor gave him, he\nnow found further confirmation of this surmise. The courtiers explained\nthe Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s neglect of him by His Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s displeasure at\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski\xe2\x80\x99s not having served since 1805.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know myself that one cannot help one\xe2\x80\x99s sympathies and\nantipathies,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Prince Andrew, \xe2\x80\x9cso it will not do to present\nmy proposal for the reform of the army regulations to the Emperor\npersonally, but the project will speak for itself.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe mentioned what he had written to an old field marshal, a friend\nof his father\xe2\x80\x99s. The field marshal made an appointment to see him,\nreceived him graciously, and promised to inform the Emperor. A few\ndays later Prince Andrew received notice that he was to go to see the\nMinister of War, Count Arakch\xc3\xa9ev.\n\n\nOn the appointed day Prince Andrew entered Count Arakch\xc3\xa9ev\xe2\x80\x99s waiting\nroom at nine in the morning.\n\nHe did not know Arakch\xc3\xa9ev personally, had never seen him, and all he\nhad heard of him inspired him with but little respect for the man.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is Minister of War, a man trusted by the Emperor, and I need not\nconcern myself about his personal qualities: he has been commissioned to\nconsider my project, so he alone can get it adopted,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Prince\nAndrew as he waited among a number of important and unimportant people\nin Count Arakch\xc3\xa9ev\xe2\x80\x99s waiting room.\n\nDuring his service, chiefly as an adjutant, Prince Andrew had seen the\nanterooms of many important men, and the different types of such rooms\nwere well known to him. Count Arakch\xc3\xa9ev\xe2\x80\x99s anteroom had quite a\nspecial character. The faces of the unimportant people awaiting their\nturn for an audience showed embarrassment and servility; the faces of\nthose of higher rank expressed a common feeling of awkwardness, covered\nby a mask of unconcern and ridicule of themselves, their situation, and\nthe person for whom they were waiting. Some walked thoughtfully up and\ndown, others whispered and laughed. Prince Andrew heard the nickname\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xadla Andr\xc3\xa9evich\xe2\x80\x9d and the words, \xe2\x80\x9cUncle will give it to us\nhot,\xe2\x80\x9d in reference to Count Arakch\xc3\xa9ev. One general (an important\npersonage), evidently feeling offended at having to wait so long, sat\ncrossing and uncrossing his legs and smiling contemptuously to himself.\n\nBut the moment the door opened one feeling alone appeared on all\nfaces\xe2\x80\x94that of fear. Prince Andrew for the second time asked the\nadjutant on duty to take in his name, but received an ironical look and\nwas told that his turn would come in due course. After some others had\nbeen shown in and out of the minister\xe2\x80\x99s room by the adjutant on duty,\nan officer who struck Prince Andrew by his humiliated and frightened air\nwas admitted at that terrible door. This officer\xe2\x80\x99s audience lasted a\nlong time. Then suddenly the grating sound of a harsh voice was heard\nfrom the other side of the door, and the officer\xe2\x80\x94with pale face and\ntrembling lips\xe2\x80\x94came out and passed through the waiting room, clutching\nhis head.\n\nAfter this Prince Andrew was conducted to the door and the officer on\nduty said in a whisper, \xe2\x80\x9cTo the right, at the window.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew entered a plain tidy room and saw at the table a man of\nforty with a long waist, a long closely cropped head, deep wrinkles,\nscowling brows above dull greenish-hazel eyes and an overhanging red\nnose. Arakch\xc3\xa9ev turned his head toward him without looking at him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your petition?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Arakch\xc3\xa9ev.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not petitioning, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Prince Andrew\nquietly.\n\nArakch\xc3\xa9ev\xe2\x80\x99s eyes turned toward him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit down,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cPrince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not petitioning about anything. His Majesty the Emperor has\ndeigned to send your excellency a project submitted by me...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, my dear sir, I have read your project,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted\nArakch\xc3\xa9ev, uttering only the first words amiably and then\xe2\x80\x94again\nwithout looking at Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x94relapsing gradually into a tone of\ngrumbling contempt. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are proposing new military laws? There are\nmany laws but no one to carry out the old ones. Nowadays everybody\ndesigns laws, it is easier writing than doing.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI came at His Majesty the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s wish to learn from your\nexcellency how you propose to deal with the memorandum I have\npresented,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew politely.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have endorsed a resolution on your memorandum and sent it to the\ncommittee. I do not approve of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Arakch\xc3\xa9ev, rising and taking\na paper from his writing table. \xe2\x80\x9cHere!\xe2\x80\x9d and he handed it to Prince\nAndrew.\n\nAcross the paper was scrawled in pencil, without capital letters,\nmisspelled, and without punctuation: \xe2\x80\x9cUnsoundly constructed because\nresembles an imitation of the French military code and from the Articles\nof War needlessly deviating.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo what committee has the memorandum been referred?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired\nPrince Andrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the Committee on Army Regulations, and I have recommended that\nyour honor should be appointed a member, but without a salary.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew smiled.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want one.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA member without salary,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Arakch\xc3\xa9ev. \xe2\x80\x9cI have the\nhonor... Eh! Call the next one! Who else is there?\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted, bowing\nto Prince Andrew.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER V\n\nWhile waiting for the announcement of his appointment to the committee\nPrince Andrew looked up his former acquaintances, particularly those he\nknew to be in power and whose aid he might need. In Petersburg he now\nexperienced the same feeling he had had on the eve of a battle, when\ntroubled by anxious curiosity and irresistibly attracted to the ruling\ncircles where the future, on which the fate of millions depended, was\nbeing shaped. From the irritation of the older men, the curiosity of the\nuninitiated, the reserve of the initiated, the hurry and preoccupation\nof everyone, and the innumerable committees and commissions of whose\nexistence he learned every day, he felt that now, in 1809, here in\nPetersburg a vast civil conflict was in preparation, the commander in\nchief of which was a mysterious person he did not know, but who was\nsupposed to be a man of genius\xe2\x80\x94Sper\xc3\xa1nski. And this movement of\nreconstruction of which Prince Andrew had a vague idea, and Sper\xc3\xa1nski\nits chief promoter, began to interest him so keenly that the question\nof the army regulations quickly receded to a secondary place in his\nconsciousness.\n\nPrince Andrew was most favorably placed to secure good reception in the\nhighest and most diverse Petersburg circles of the day. The reforming\nparty cordially welcomed and courted him, in the first place because\nhe was reputed to be clever and very well read, and secondly because by\nliberating his serfs he had obtained the reputation of being a liberal.\nThe party of the old and dissatisfied, who censured the innovations,\nturned to him expecting his sympathy in their disapproval of the\nreforms, simply because he was the son of his father. The feminine\nsociety world welcomed him gladly, because he was rich, distinguished, a\ngood match, and almost a newcomer, with a halo of romance on account\nof his supposed death and the tragic loss of his wife.
