S\xc3\xb3nya and her mother put themselves entirely in her hands.\nThe countess was to wear a claret-colored velvet dress, and the two\ngirls white gauze over pink silk slips, with roses on their bodices and\ntheir hair dressed \xc3\xa0 la grecque.\n\nEverything essential had already been done; feet, hands, necks, and\nears washed, perfumed, and powdered, as befits a ball; the openwork\nsilk stockings and white satin shoes with ribbons were already on; the\nhairdressing was almost done. S\xc3\xb3nya was finishing dressing and so was\nthe countess, but Nat\xc3\xa1sha, who had bustled about helping them all, was\nbehindhand. She was still sitting before a looking-glass with a dressing\njacket thrown over her slender shoulders. S\xc3\xb3nya stood ready dressed in\nthe middle of the room and, pressing the head of a pin till it hurt her\ndainty finger, was fixing on a last ribbon that squeaked as the pin went\nthrough it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s not the way, that\xe2\x80\x99s not the way, S\xc3\xb3nya!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nturning her head and clutching with both hands at her hair which the\nmaid who was dressing it had not time to release. \xe2\x80\x9cThat bow is not\nright. Come here!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya sat down and Nat\xc3\xa1sha pinned the ribbon on differently.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllow me, Miss! I can\xe2\x80\x99t do it like that,\xe2\x80\x9d said the maid who was\nholding Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s hair.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, dear! Well then, wait. That\xe2\x80\x99s right, S\xc3\xb3nya.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAren\xe2\x80\x99t you ready? It is nearly ten,\xe2\x80\x9d came the countess\xe2\x80\x99 voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDirectly! Directly! And you, Mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have only my cap to pin on.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t do it without me!\xe2\x80\x9d called Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cYou won\xe2\x80\x99t do it\nright.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it\xe2\x80\x99s already ten.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThey had decided to be at the ball by half-past ten, and Nat\xc3\xa1sha had\nstill to get dressed and they had to call at the Taurida Gardens.\n\nWhen her hair was done, Nat\xc3\xa1sha, in her short petticoat from under\nwhich her dancing shoes showed, and in her mother\xe2\x80\x99s dressing jacket,\nran up to S\xc3\xb3nya, scrutinized her, and then ran to her mother. Turning\nher mother\xe2\x80\x99s head this way and that, she fastened on the cap and,\nhurriedly kissing her gray hair, ran back to the maids who were turning\nup the hem of her skirt.\n\nThe cause of the delay was Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s skirt, which was too long.\nTwo maids were turning up the hem and hurriedly biting off the ends of\nthread. A third with pins in her mouth was running about between the\ncountess and S\xc3\xb3nya, and a fourth held the whole of the gossamer garment\nup high on one uplifted hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cM\xc3\xa1vra, quicker, darling!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me my thimble, Miss, from there...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhenever will you be ready?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the count coming to the door.\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is some scent. Per\xc3\xb3nskaya must be tired of waiting.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s ready, Miss,\xe2\x80\x9d said the maid, holding up the shortened gauze\ndress with two fingers, and blowing and shaking something off it, as if\nby this to express a consciousness of the airiness and purity of what\nshe held.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha began putting on the dress.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn a minute! In a minute! Don\xe2\x80\x99t come in, Papa!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried to her\nfather as he opened the door\xe2\x80\x94speaking from under the filmy skirt which\nstill covered her whole face.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya slammed the door to. A minute later they let the count in. He was\nwearing a blue swallow-tail coat, shoes and stockings, and was perfumed\nand his hair pomaded.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Papa! how nice you look! Charming!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nat\xc3\xa1sha, as she\nstood in the middle of the room smoothing out the folds of the gauze.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you please, Miss! allow me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the maid, who on her knees was\npulling the skirt straight and shifting the pins from one side of her\nmouth to the other with her tongue.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay what you like,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed S\xc3\xb3nya, in a despairing voice as she\nlooked at Nat\xc3\xa1sha, \xe2\x80\x9csay what you like, it\xe2\x80\x99s still too long.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha stepped back to look at herself in the pier glass. The dress\nwas too long.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, madam, it is not at all too long,\xe2\x80\x9d said M\xc3\xa1vra, crawling on\nher knees after her young lady.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if it\xe2\x80\x99s too long we\xe2\x80\x99ll tack it up... we\xe2\x80\x99ll tack it up\nin one minute,\xe2\x80\x9d said the resolute Duny\xc3\xa1sha taking a needle that was\nstuck on the front of her little shawl and, still kneeling on the floor,\nset to work once more.\n\nAt that moment, with soft steps, the countess came in shyly, in her cap\nand velvet gown.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOo-oo, my beauty!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the count, \xe2\x80\x9cshe looks better than\nany of you!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe would have embraced her but, blushing, she stepped aside fearing to\nbe rumpled.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, your cap, more to this side,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll\narrange it,\xe2\x80\x9d and she rushed forward so that the maids who were tacking\nup her skirt could not move fast enough and a piece of gauze was torn\noff.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh goodness! What has happened? Really it was not my fault!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind, I\xe2\x80\x99ll run it up, it won\xe2\x80\x99t show,\xe2\x80\x9d said Duny\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a beauty\xe2\x80\x94a very queen!\xe2\x80\x9d said the nurse as she came to the\ndoor. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd S\xc3\xb3nya! They are lovely!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAt a quarter past ten they at last got into their carriages and started.\nBut they had still to call at the Taurida Gardens.\n\nPer\xc3\xb3nskaya was quite ready. In spite of her age and plainness she\nhad gone through the same process as the Rost\xc3\xb3vs, but with less\nflurry\xe2\x80\x94for to her it was a matter of routine. Her ugly old body was\nwashed, perfumed, and powdered in just the same way. She had washed\nbehind her ears just as carefully, and when she entered her drawing\nroom in her yellow dress, wearing her badge as maid of honor, her old\nlady\xe2\x80\x99s maid was as full of rapturous admiration as the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99\nservants had been.\n\nShe praised the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 toilets. They praised her taste and toilet,\nand at eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, careful of their coiffures and dresses, they\nsettled themselves in their carriages and drove off.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XV\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha had not had a moment free since early morning and had not once\nhad time to think of what lay before her.\n\nIn the damp chill air and crowded closeness of the swaying carriage, she\nfor the first time vividly imagined what was in store for her there at\nthe ball, in those brightly lighted rooms\xe2\x80\x94with music, flowers, dances,\nthe Emperor, and all the brilliant young people of Petersburg. The\nprospect was so splendid that she hardly believed it would come true,\nso out of keeping was it with the chill darkness and closeness of the\ncarriage. She understood all that awaited her only when, after stepping\nover the red baize at the entrance, she entered the hall, took off her\nfur cloak, and, beside S\xc3\xb3nya and in front of her mother, mounted the\nbrightly illuminated stairs between the flowers. Only then did she\nremember how she must behave at a ball, and tried to assume the majestic\nair she considered indispensable for a girl on such an occasion. But,\nfortunately for her, she felt her eyes growing misty, she saw nothing\nclearly, her pulse beat a hundred to the minute, and the blood throbbed\nat her heart. She could not assume that pose, which would have made her\nridiculous, and she moved on almost fainting from excitement and trying\nwith all her might to conceal it. And this was the very attitude that\nbecame her best. Before and behind them other visitors were entering,\nalso talking in low tones and wearing ball dresses. The mirrors on the\nlanding reflected ladies in white, pale-blue, and pink dresses, with\ndiamonds and pearls on their bare necks and arms.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha looked in the mirrors and could not distinguish her reflection\nfrom the others. All was blended into one brilliant procession.\nOn entering the ballroom the regular hum of voices, footsteps, and\ngreetings deafened Nat\xc3\xa1sha, and the light and glitter dazzled her still\nmore. The host and hostess, who had already been standing at the door\nfor half an hour repeating the same words to the various arrivals,\n\xe2\x80\x9cCharm\xc3\xa9 de vous voir,\xe2\x80\x9d * greeted the Rost\xc3\xb3vs and Per\xc3\xb3nskaya in\nthe same manner.\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cDelighted to see you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nThe two girls in their white dresses, each with a rose in her\nblack hair, both curtsied in the same way, but the hostess\xe2\x80\x99 eye\ninvoluntarily rested longer on the slim Nat\xc3\xa1sha. She looked at her\nand gave her alone a special smile in addition to her usual smile as\nhostess. Looking at her she may have recalled the golden, irrecoverable\ndays of her own girlhood and her own first ball. The host also followed\nNat\xc3\xa1sha with his eyes and asked the count which was his daughter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCharming!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, kissing the tips of his fingers.\n\nIn the ballroom guests stood crowding at the entrance doors awaiting\nthe Emperor. The countess took up a position in one of the front rows\nof that crowd. Nat\xc3\xa1sha heard and felt that several people were asking\nabout her and looking at her. She realized that those noticing her liked\nher, and this observation helped to calm her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are some like ourselves and some worse,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought.\n\nPer\xc3\xb3nskaya was pointing out to the countess the most important people\nat the ball.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the Dutch ambassador, do you see? That gray-haired man,\xe2\x80\x9d\nshe said, indicating an old man with a profusion of silver-gray curly\nhair, who was surrounded by ladies laughing at something he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, here she is, the Queen of Petersburg, Countess Bez\xc3\xbakhova,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid Per\xc3\xb3nskaya, indicating H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne who had just entered. \xe2\x80\x9cHow\nlovely! She is quite equal to M\xc3\xa1rya Ant\xc3\xb3novna. See how the men, young\nand old, pay court to her. Beautiful and clever... they say Prince\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 is quite mad about her. But see, those two, though not\ngood-looking, are even more run after.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe pointed to a lady who was crossing the room followed by a very plain\ndaughter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is a splendid match, a millionairess,\xe2\x80\x9d said Per\xc3\xb3nskaya. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\nlook, here come her suitors.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is Bez\xc3\xbakhova\xe2\x80\x99s brother, Anatole Kur\xc3\xa1gin,\xe2\x80\x9d she said,\nindicating a handsome officer of the Horse Guards who passed by them\nwith head erect, looking at something over the heads of the ladies.\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s handsome, isn\xe2\x80\x99t he? I hear they will marry him to that rich\ngirl. But your cousin, Drubetsk\xc3\xb3y, is also very attentive to her. They\nsay she has millions. Oh yes, that\xe2\x80\x99s the French ambassador himself!\xe2\x80\x9d\nshe replied to the countess\xe2\x80\x99 inquiry about Caulaincourt. \xe2\x80\x9cLooks as\nif he were a king! All the same, the French are charming, very charming.\nNo one more charming in society. Ah, here she is! Yes, she is still the\nmost beautiful of them all, our M\xc3\xa1rya Ant\xc3\xb3novna! And how simply she\nis dressed! Lovely! And that stout one in spectacles is the universal\nFreemason,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on, indicating Pierre. \xe2\x80\x9cPut him beside his wife\nand he looks a regular buffoon!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre, swaying his stout body, advanced, making way through the crowd\nand nodding to right and left as casually and good-naturedly as if he\nwere passing through a crowd at a fair. He pushed through, evidently\nlooking for someone.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha looked joyfully at the familiar face of Pierre, \xe2\x80\x9cthe\nbuffoon,\xe2\x80\x9d as Per\xc3\xb3nskaya had called him, and knew he was looking for\nthem, and for her in particular. He had promised to be at the ball and\nintroduce partners to her.\n\nBut before he reached them Pierre stopped beside a very handsome, dark\nman of middle height, and in a white uniform, who stood by a window\ntalking to a tall man wearing stars and a ribbon. Nat\xc3\xa1sha at once\nrecognized the shorter and younger man in the white uniform: it was\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski, who seemed to her to have grown much younger, happier, and\nbetter-looking.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s someone else we know\xe2\x80\x94Bolk\xc3\xb3nski, do you see, Mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid Nat\xc3\xa1sha, pointing out Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cYou remember, he stayed a\nnight with us at Otr\xc3\xa1dnoe.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you know him?\xe2\x80\x9d said Per\xc3\xb3nskaya. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t bear him. Il fait\n\xc3\xa0 pr\xc3\xa9sent la pluie et le beau temps. * He\xe2\x80\x99s too proud for anything.\nTakes after his father. And he\xe2\x80\x99s hand in glove with Sper\xc3\xa1nski,\nwriting some project or other. Just look how he treats the ladies!\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s one talking to him and he has turned away,\xe2\x80\x9d she said,\npointing at him. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d give it to him if he treated me as he does\nthose ladies.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cHe is all the rage just now.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVI\n\nSuddenly everybody stirred, began talking, and pressed forward and then\nback, and between the two rows, which separated, the Emperor entered to\nthe sounds of music that had immediately struck up. Behind him walked\nhis host and hostess. He walked in rapidly, bowing to right and left\nas if anxious to get the first moments of the reception over. The band\nplayed the polonaise in vogue at that time on account of the words that\nhad been set to it, beginning: \xe2\x80\x9cAlexander, Elisaveta, all our hearts\nyou ravish quite...\xe2\x80\x9d The Emperor passed on to the drawing room, the\ncrowd made a rush for the doors, and several persons with excited faces\nhurried there and back again. Then the crowd hastily retired from\nthe drawing room door, at which the Emperor reappeared talking to the\nhostess. A young man, looking distraught, pounced down on the ladies,\nasking them to move aside. Some ladies, with faces betraying complete\nforgetfulness of all the rules of decorum, pushed forward to the\ndetriment of their toilets. The men began to choose partners and take\ntheir places for the polonaise.\n\nEveryone moved back, and the Emperor came smiling out of the drawing\nroom leading his hostess by the hand but not keeping time to the\nmusic. The host followed with M\xc3\xa1rya Ant\xc3\xb3novna Nar\xc3\xbdshkina; then\ncame ambassadors, ministers, and various generals, whom Per\xc3\xb3nskaya\ndiligently named. More than half the ladies already had partners\nand were taking up, or preparing to take up, their positions for the\npolonaise. Nat\xc3\xa1sha felt that she would be left with her mother and\nS\xc3\xb3nya among a minority of women who crowded near the wall, not having\nbeen invited to dance. She stood with her slender arms hanging down,\nher scarcely defined bosom rising and falling regularly, and with\nbated breath and glittering, frightened eyes gazed straight before\nher, evidently prepared for the height of joy or misery. She was\nnot concerned about the Emperor or any of those great people whom\nPer\xc3\xb3nskaya was pointing out\xe2\x80\x94she had but one thought: \xe2\x80\x9cIs it\npossible no one will ask me, that I shall not be among the first to\ndance? Is it possible that not one of all these men will notice me?\nThey do not even seem to see me, or if they do they look as if they\nwere saying, \xe2\x80\x98Ah, she\xe2\x80\x99s not the one I\xe2\x80\x99m after, so it\xe2\x80\x99s not worth\nlooking at her!\xe2\x80\x99 No, it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought. \xe2\x80\x9cThey must\nknow how I long to dance, how splendidly I dance, and how they would\nenjoy dancing with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe strains of the polonaise, which had continued for a considerable\ntime, had begun to sound like a sad reminiscence to Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s ears.\nShe wanted to cry. Per\xc3\xb3nskaya had left them. The count was at the\nother end of the room. She and the countess and S\xc3\xb3nya were standing by\nthemselves as in the depths of a forest amid that crowd of strangers,\nwith no one interested in them and not wanted by anyone. Prince Andrew\nwith a lady passed by, evidently not recognizing them. The handsome\nAnatole was smilingly talking to a partner on his arm and looked at\nNat\xc3\xa1sha as one looks at a wall. Bor\xc3\xads passed them twice and each time\nturned away. Berg and his wife, who were not dancing, came up to them.\n\nThis family gathering seemed humiliating to Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x94as if there were\nnowhere else for the family to talk but here at the ball. She did not\nlisten to or look at V\xc3\xa9ra, who was telling her something about her own\ngreen dress.\n\nAt last the Emperor stopped beside his last partner (he had danced\nwith three) and the music ceased. A worried aide-de-camp ran up to the\nRost\xc3\xb3vs requesting them to stand farther back, though as it was they\nwere already close to the wall, and from the gallery resounded the\ndistinct, precise, enticingly rhythmical strains of a waltz. The Emperor\nlooked smilingly down the room. A minute passed but no one had yet begun\ndancing. An aide-de-camp, the Master of Ceremonies, went up to Countess\nBez\xc3\xbakhova and asked her to dance. She smilingly raised her hand and\nlaid it on his shoulder without looking at him. The aide-de-camp, an\nadept in his art, grasping his partner firmly round her waist, with\nconfident deliberation started smoothly, gliding first round the edge of\nthe circle, then at the corner of the room he caught H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s\nleft hand and turned her, the only sound audible, apart from the\never-quickening music, being the rhythmic click of the spurs on his\nrapid, agile feet, while at every third beat his partner\xe2\x80\x99s velvet\ndress spread out and seemed to flash as she whirled round. Nat\xc3\xa1sha\ngazed at them and was ready to cry because it was not she who was\ndancing that first turn of the waltz.\n\nPrince Andrew, in the white uniform of a cavalry colonel, wearing\nstockings and dancing shoes, stood looking animated and bright in the\nfront row of the circle not far from the Rost\xc3\xb3vs. Baron Firhoff was\ntalking to him about the first sitting of the Council of State to be\nheld next day. Prince Andrew, as one closely connected with Sper\xc3\xa1nski\nand participating in the work of the legislative commission, could give\nreliable information about that sitting, concerning which various rumors\nwere current. But not listening to what Firhoff was saying, he was\ngazing now at the sovereign and now at the men intending to dance who\nhad not yet gathered courage to enter the circle.\n\nPrince Andrew was watching these men abashed by the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s\npresence, and the women who were breathlessly longing to be asked to\ndance.\n\nPierre came up to him and caught him by the arm.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou always dance. I have a prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9e, the young Rost\xc3\xb3va, here. Ask\nher,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is she?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Bolk\xc3\xb3nski. \xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me!\xe2\x80\x9d he added, turning\nto the baron, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will finish this conversation elsewhere\xe2\x80\x94at a ball\none must dance.\xe2\x80\x9d He stepped forward in the direction Pierre indicated.\nThe despairing, dejected expression of Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s face caught his eye.\nHe recognized her, guessed her feelings, saw that it was her d\xc3\xa9but,\nremembered her conversation at the window, and with an expression of\npleasure on his face approached Countess Rost\xc3\xb3va.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllow me to introduce you to my daughter,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, with\nheightened color.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have the pleasure of being already acquainted, if the countess\nremembers me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew with a low and courteous bow quite\nbelying Per\xc3\xb3nskaya\xe2\x80\x99s remarks about his rudeness, and approaching\nNat\xc3\xa1sha he held out his arm to grasp her waist before he had completed\nhis invitation. He asked her to waltz. That tremulous expression on\nNat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s face, prepared either for despair or rapture, suddenly\nbrightened into a happy, grateful, childlike smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have long been waiting for you,\xe2\x80\x9d that frightened happy little\ngirl seemed to say by the smile that replaced the threatened tears, as\nshe raised her hand to Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder. They were the second\ncouple to enter the circle. Prince Andrew was one of the best dancers of\nhis day and Nat\xc3\xa1sha danced exquisitely. Her little feet in their white\nsatin dancing shoes did their work swiftly, lightly, and independently\nof herself, while her face beamed with ecstatic happiness. Her slender\nbare arms and neck were not beautiful\xe2\x80\x94compared to H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s her\nshoulders looked thin and her bosom undeveloped. But H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne seemed, as\nit were, hardened by a varnish left by the thousands of looks that had\nscanned her person, while Nat\xc3\xa1sha was like a girl exposed for the first\ntime, who would have felt very much ashamed had she not been assured\nthat this was absolutely necessary.\n\nPrince Andrew liked dancing, and wishing to escape as quickly as\npossible from the political and clever talk which everyone addressed\nto him, wishing also to break up the circle of restraint he disliked,\ncaused by the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s presence, he danced, and had chosen Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nbecause Pierre pointed her out to him and because she was the first\npretty girl who caught his eye; but scarcely had he embraced that\nslender supple figure and felt her stirring so close to him and smiling\nso near him than the wine of her charm rose to his head, and he\nfelt himself revived and rejuvenated when after leaving her he stood\nbreathing deeply and watching the other dancers.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVII\n\nAfter Prince Andrew, Bor\xc3\xads came up to ask Nat\xc3\xa1sha for a dance, and\nthen the aide-de-camp who had opened the ball, and several other young\nmen, so that, flushed and happy, and passing on her superfluous partners\nto S\xc3\xb3nya, she did not cease dancing all the evening. She noticed and\nsaw nothing of what occupied everyone else. Not only did she fail to\nnotice that the Emperor talked a long time with the French ambassador,\nand how particularly gracious he was to a certain lady, or that Prince\nSo-and-so and So-and-so did and said this and that, and that H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\nhad great success and was honored by the special attention of So-and-so,\nbut she did not even see the Emperor, and only noticed that he had gone\nbecause the ball became livelier after his departure. For one of the\nmerry cotillions before supper Prince Andrew was again her partner. He\nreminded her of their first encounter in the Otr\xc3\xa1dnoe avenue, and how\nshe had been unable to sleep that moonlight night, and told her how he\nhad involuntarily overheard her. Nat\xc3\xa1sha blushed at that recollection\nand tried to excuse herself, as if there had been something to be\nashamed of in what Prince Andrew had overheard.\n\nLike all men who have grown up in society, Prince Andrew liked meeting\nsomeone there not of the conventional society stamp. And such was\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, with her surprise, her delight, her shyness, and even her\nmistakes in speaking French. With her he behaved with special care and\ntenderness, sitting beside her and talking of the simplest and most\nunimportant matters; he admired her shy grace. In the middle of the\ncotillion, having completed one of the figures, Nat\xc3\xa1sha, still out of\nbreath, was returning to her seat when another dancer chose her. She was\ntired and panting and evidently thought of declining, but immediately\nput her hand gaily on the man\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder, smiling at Prince Andrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d be glad to sit beside you and rest: I\xe2\x80\x99m tired; but you see\nhow they keep asking me, and I\xe2\x80\x99m glad of it, I\xe2\x80\x99m happy and I love\neverybody, and you and I understand it all,\xe2\x80\x9d and much, much more was\nsaid in her smile. When her partner left her Nat\xc3\xa1sha ran across the\nroom to choose two ladies for the figure.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf she goes to her cousin first and then to another lady, she will be\nmy wife,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew to himself quite to his own surprise, as\nhe watched her. She did go first to her cousin.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat rubbish sometimes enters one\xe2\x80\x99s head!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Prince Andrew,\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut what is certain is that that girl is so charming, so original,\nthat she won\xe2\x80\x99t be dancing here a month before she will be married....\nSuch as she are rare here,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, as Nat\xc3\xa1sha, readjusting a\nrose that was slipping on her bodice, settled herself beside him.\n\nWhen the cotillion was over the old count in his blue coat came up to\nthe dancers. He invited Prince Andrew to come and see them, and asked\nhis daughter whether she was enjoying herself. Nat\xc3\xa1sha did not answer\nat once but only looked up with a smile that said reproachfully: \xe2\x80\x9cHow\ncan you ask such a question?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have never enjoyed myself so much before!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, and Prince\nAndrew noticed how her thin arms rose quickly as if to embrace her\nfather and instantly dropped again. Nat\xc3\xa1sha was happier than she had\never been in her life. She was at that height of bliss when one becomes\ncompletely kind and good and does not believe in the possibility of\nevil, unhappiness, or sorrow.\n\nAt that ball Pierre for the first time felt humiliated by the position\nhis wife occupied in court circles. He was gloomy and absent-minded. A\ndeep furrow ran across his forehead, and standing by a window he stared\nover his spectacles seeing no one.\n\nOn her way to supper Nat\xc3\xa1sha passed him.\n\nPierre\xe2\x80\x99s gloomy, unhappy look struck her. She stopped in front of him.\nShe wished to help him, to bestow on him the superabundance of her own\nhappiness.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow delightful it is, Count!\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre smiled absent-mindedly, evidently not grasping what she said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I am very glad,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can people be dissatisfied with anything?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEspecially such a capital fellow as Bez\xc3\xbakhov!\xe2\x80\x9d In Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s\neyes all the people at the ball alike were good, kind, and splendid\npeople, loving one another; none of them capable of injuring\nanother\xe2\x80\x94and so they ought all to be happy.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVIII\n\nNext day Prince Andrew thought of the ball, but his mind did not dwell\non it long. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, it was a very brilliant ball,\xe2\x80\x9d and then... \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\nthat little Rost\xc3\xb3va is very charming. There\xe2\x80\x99s something fresh,\noriginal, un-Petersburg-like about her that distinguishes her.\xe2\x80\x9d That\nwas all he thought about yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s ball, and after his morning tea\nhe set to work.\n\nBut either from fatigue or want of sleep he was ill-disposed for work\nand could get nothing done. He kept criticizing his own work, as he\noften did, and was glad when he heard someone coming.\n\nThe visitor was B\xc3\xadtski, who served on various committees, frequented\nall the societies in Petersburg, and was a passionate devotee of the new\nideas and of Sper\xc3\xa1nski, and a diligent Petersburg newsmonger\xe2\x80\x94one of\nthose men who choose their opinions like their clothes according to\nthe fashion, but who for that very reason appear to be the warmest\npartisans. Hardly had he got rid of his hat before he ran into Prince\nAndrew\xe2\x80\x99s room with a preoccupied air and at once began talking. He\nhad just heard particulars of that morning\xe2\x80\x99s sitting of the Council\nof State opened by the Emperor, and he spoke of it enthusiastically. The\nEmperor\xe2\x80\x99s speech had been extraordinary. It had been a speech such as\nonly constitutional monarchs deliver. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Sovereign plainly said\nthat the Council and Senate are estates of the realm, he said that the\ngovernment must rest not on authority but on secure bases. The Emperor\nsaid that the fiscal system must be reorganized and the accounts\npublished,\xe2\x80\x9d recounted B\xc3\xadtski, emphasizing certain words and opening\nhis eyes significantly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes! Today\xe2\x80\x99s events mark an epoch, the greatest epoch in our\nhistory,\xe2\x80\x9d he concluded.\n\nPrince Andrew listened to the account of the opening of the Council of\nState, which he had so impatiently awaited and to which he had attached\nsuch importance, and was surprised that this event, now that it had\ntaken place, did not affect him, and even seemed quite insignificant. He\nlistened with quiet irony to B\xc3\xadtski\xe2\x80\x99s enthusiastic account of it. A\nvery simple thought occurred to him: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat does it matter to me or to\nB\xc3\xadtski what the Emperor was pleased to say at the Council? Can all that\nmake me any happier or better?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd this simple reflection suddenly destroyed all the interest Prince\nAndrew had felt in the impending reforms. He was going to dine that\nevening at Sper\xc3\xa1nski\xe2\x80\x99s, \xe2\x80\x9cwith only a few friends,\xe2\x80\x9d as the host\nhad said when inviting him. The prospect of that dinner in the intimate\nhome circle of the man he so admired had greatly interested Prince\nAndrew, especially as he had not yet seen Sper\xc3\xa1nski in his domestic\nsurroundings, but now he felt disinclined to go to it.\n\nAt the appointed hour, however, he entered the modest house Sper\xc3\xa1nski\nowned in the Taurida Gardens. In the parqueted dining room of this small\nhouse, remarkable for its extreme cleanliness (suggesting that of a\nmonastery), Prince Andrew, who was rather late, found the friendly\ngathering of Sper\xc3\xa1nski\xe2\x80\x99s intimate acquaintances already assembled\nat five o\xe2\x80\x99clock. There were no ladies present except Sper\xc3\xa1nski\xe2\x80\x99s\nlittle daughter (long-faced like her father) and her governess. The\nother guests were Gervais, Magn\xc3\xadtski, and Stol\xc3\xbdpin. While still in\nthe anteroom Prince Andrew heard loud voices and a ringing staccato\nlaugh\xe2\x80\x94a laugh such as one hears on the stage. Someone\xe2\x80\x94it sounded\nlike Sper\xc3\xa1nski\xe2\x80\x94was distinctly ejaculating ha-ha-ha. Prince Andrew\nhad never before heard Sper\xc3\xa1nski\xe2\x80\x99s famous laugh, and this ringing,\nhigh-pitched laughter from a statesman made a strange impression on him.\n\nHe entered the dining room. The whole company were standing between two\nwindows at a small table laid with hors-d\xe2\x80\x99oeuvres. Sper\xc3\xa1nski, wearing\na gray swallow-tail coat with a star on the breast, and evidently still\nthe same waistcoat and high white stock he had worn at the meeting of\nthe Council of State, stood at the table with a beaming countenance. His\nguests surrounded him. Magn\xc3\xadtski, addressing himself to Sper\xc3\xa1nski,\nwas relating an anecdote, and Sper\xc3\xa1nski was laughing in advance at\nwhat Magn\xc3\xadtski was going to say. When Prince Andrew entered the room\nMagn\xc3\xadtski\xe2\x80\x99s words were again crowned by laughter. Stol\xc3\xbdpin gave\na deep bass guffaw as he munched a piece of bread and cheese. Gervais\nlaughed softly with a hissing chuckle, and Sper\xc3\xa1nski in a high-pitched\nstaccato manner.\n\nStill laughing, Sper\xc3\xa1nski held out his soft white hand to Prince\nAndrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery pleased to see you, Prince,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cOne moment...\xe2\x80\x9d he\nwent on, turning to Magn\xc3\xadtski and interrupting his story. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have\nagreed that this is a dinner for recreation, with not a word about\nbusiness!\xe2\x80\x9d and turning again to the narrator he began to laugh afresh.\n\nPrince Andrew looked at the laughing Sper\xc3\xa1nski with astonishment,\nregret, and disillusionment. It seemed to him that this was not\nSper\xc3\xa1nski but someone else. Everything that had formerly appeared\nmysterious and fascinating in Sper\xc3\xa1nski suddenly became plain and\nunattractive.\n\nAt dinner the conversation did not cease for a moment and seemed to\nconsist of the contents of a book of funny anecdotes. Before Magn\xc3\xadtski\nhad finished his story someone else was anxious to relate something\nstill funnier. Most of the anecdotes, if not relating to the state\nservice, related to people in the service. It seemed that in this\ncompany the insignificance of those people was so definitely accepted\nthat the only possible attitude toward them was one of good humored\nridicule. Sper\xc3\xa1nski related how at the Council that morning a deaf\ndignitary, when asked his opinion, replied that he thought so too.\nGervais gave a long account of an official revision, remarkable for the\nstupidity of everybody concerned. Stol\xc3\xbdpin, stuttering, broke into\nthe conversation and began excitedly talking of the abuses that existed\nunder the former order of things\xe2\x80\x94threatening to give a serious turn\nto the conversation. Magn\xc3\xadtski starting quizzing Stol\xc3\xbdpin about his\nvehemence. Gervais intervened with a joke, and the talk reverted to its\nformer lively tone.\n\nEvidently Sper\xc3\xa1nski liked to rest after his labors and find amusement\nin a circle of friends, and his guests, understanding his wish, tried\nto enliven him and amuse themselves. But their gaiety seemed to Prince\nAndrew mirthless and tiresome. Sper\xc3\xa1nski\xe2\x80\x99s high-pitched voice struck\nhim unpleasantly, and the incessant laughter grated on him like a false\nnote. Prince Andrew did not laugh and feared that he would be a damper\non the spirits of the company, but no one took any notice of his being\nout of harmony with the general mood. They all seemed very gay.\n\nHe tried several times to join in the conversation, but his remarks were\ntossed aside each time like a cork thrown out of the water, and he could\nnot jest with them.\n\nThere was nothing wrong or unseemly in what they said, it was witty and\nmight have been funny, but it lacked just that something which is the\nsalt of mirth, and they were not even aware that such a thing existed.\n\nAfter dinner Sper\xc3\xa1nski\xe2\x80\x99s daughter and her governess rose. He patted\nthe little girl with his white hand and kissed her. And that gesture,\ntoo, seemed unnatural to Prince Andrew.\n\nThe men remained at table over their port\xe2\x80\x94English fashion. In the\nmidst of a conversation that was started about Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s Spanish\naffairs, which they all agreed in approving, Prince Andrew began to\nexpress a contrary opinion. Sper\xc3\xa1nski smiled and, with an evident wish\nto prevent the conversation from taking an unpleasant course, told a\nstory that had no connection with the previous conversation. For a few\nmoments all were silent.\n\nHaving sat some time at table, Sper\xc3\xa1nski corked a bottle of wine and,\nremarking, \xe2\x80\x9cNowadays good wine rides in a carriage and pair,\xe2\x80\x9d passed\nit to the servant and got up. All rose and continuing to talk loudly\nwent into the drawing room. Two letters brought by a courier were handed\nto Sper\xc3\xa1nski and he took them to his study. As soon as he had left\nthe room the general merriment stopped and the guests began to converse\nsensibly and quietly with one another.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow for the recitation!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sper\xc3\xa1nski on returning from\nhis study. \xe2\x80\x9cA wonderful talent!\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Prince Andrew, and\nMagn\xc3\xadtski immediately assumed a pose and began reciting some humorous\nverses in French which he had composed about various well-known\nPetersburg people. He was interrupted several times by applause. When\nthe verses were finished Prince Andrew went up to Sper\xc3\xa1nski and took\nhis leave.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you off to so early?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Sper\xc3\xa1nski.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promised to go to a reception.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThey said no more. Prince Andrew looked closely into those mirrorlike,\nimpenetrable eyes, and felt that it had been ridiculous of him to have\nexpected anything from Sper\xc3\xa1nski and from any of his own activities\nconnected with him, or ever to have attributed importance to what\nSper\xc3\xa1nski was doing. That precise, mirthless laughter rang in Prince\nAndrew\xe2\x80\x99s ears long after he had left the house.\n\nWhen he reached home Prince Andrew began thinking of his life in\nPetersburg during those last four months as if it were something new. He\nrecalled his exertions and solicitations, and the history of his project\nof army reform, which had been accepted for consideration and which they\nwere trying to pass over in silence simply because another, a very poor\none, had already been prepared and submitted to the Emperor. He thought\nof the meetings of a committee of which Berg was a member. He remembered\nhow carefully and at what length everything relating to form and\nprocedure was discussed at those meetings, and how sedulously and\npromptly all that related to the gist of the business was evaded. He\nrecalled his labors on the Legal Code, and how painstakingly he had\ntranslated the articles of the Roman and French codes into Russian,\nand he felt ashamed of himself. Then he vividly pictured to himself\nBoguch\xc3\xa1rovo, his occupations in the country, his journey to Ryaz\xc3\xa1n;\nhe remembered the peasants and Dron the village elder, and mentally\napplying to them the Personal Rights he had divided into paragraphs, he\nfelt astonished that he could have spent so much time on such useless\nwork.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIX\n\nNext day Prince Andrew called at a few houses he had not visited before,\nand among them at the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 with whom he had renewed acquaintance\nat the ball. Apart from considerations of politeness which demanded the\ncall, he wanted to see that original, eager girl who had left such a\npleasant impression on his mind, in her own home.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha was one of the first to meet him. She was wearing a dark-blue\nhouse dress in which Prince Andrew thought her even prettier than in\nher ball dress. She and all the Rost\xc3\xb3v family welcomed him as an old\nfriend, simply and cordially. The whole family, whom he had formerly\njudged severely, now seemed to him to consist of excellent, simple,\nand kindly people. The old count\xe2\x80\x99s hospitality and good nature, which\nstruck one especially in Petersburg as a pleasant surprise, were such\nthat Prince Andrew could not refuse to stay to dinner. \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe thought, \xe2\x80\x9cthey are capital people, who of course have not the\nslightest idea what a treasure they possess in Nat\xc3\xa1sha; but they are\nkindly folk and form the best possible setting for this strikingly\npoetic, charming girl, overflowing with life!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIn Nat\xc3\xa1sha Prince Andrew was conscious of a strange world completely\nalien to him and brimful of joys unknown to him, a different world,\nthat in the Otr\xc3\xa1dnoe avenue and at the window that moonlight night\nhad already begun to disconcert him. Now this world disconcerted him no\nlonger and was no longer alien to him, but he himself having entered it\nfound in it a new enjoyment.\n\nAfter dinner Nat\xc3\xa1sha, at Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s request, went to the\nclavichord and began singing. Prince Andrew stood by a window talking\nto the ladies and listened to her. In the midst of a phrase he ceased\nspeaking and suddenly felt tears choking him, a thing he had thought\nimpossible for him. He looked at Nat\xc3\xa1sha as she sang, and something new\nand joyful stirred in his soul. He felt happy and at the same time sad.\nHe had absolutely nothing to weep about yet he was ready to weep. What\nabout? His former love? The little princess? His disillusionments?...\nHis hopes for the future?... Yes and no. The chief reason was a sudden,\nvivid sense of the terrible contrast between something infinitely great\nand illimitable within him and that limited and material something that\nhe, and even she, was. This contrast weighed on and yet cheered him\nwhile she sang.\n\nAs soon as Nat\xc3\xa1sha had finished she went up to him and asked how he\nliked her voice. She asked this and then became confused, feeling that\nshe ought not to have asked it. He smiled, looking at her, and said he\nliked her singing as he liked everything she did.\n\nPrince Andrew left the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 late in the evening. He went to bed\nfrom habit, but soon realized that he could not sleep. Having lit his\ncandle he sat up in bed, then got up, then lay down again not at all\ntroubled by his sleeplessness: his soul was as fresh and joyful as if he\nhad stepped out of a stuffy room into God\xe2\x80\x99s own fresh air. It did not\nenter his head that he was in love with Nat\xc3\xa1sha; he was not thinking\nabout her, but only picturing her to himself, and in consequence all\nlife appeared in a new light. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy do I strive, why do I toil in this\nnarrow, confined frame, when life, all life with all its joys, is open\nto me?\xe2\x80\x9d said he to himself. And for the first time for a very long\nwhile he began making happy plans for the future. He decided that he\nmust attend to his son\xe2\x80\x99s education by finding a tutor and putting\nthe boy in his charge, then he ought to retire from the service and go\nabroad, and see England, Switzerland and Italy. \xe2\x80\x9cI must use my freedom\nwhile I feel so much strength and youth in me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself.\n\xe2\x80\x9cPierre was right when he said one must believe in the possibility of\nhappiness in order to be happy, and now I do believe in it. Let the dead\nbury their dead, but while one has life one must live and be happy!\xe2\x80\x9d\nthought he.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XX\n\nOne morning Colonel Berg, whom Pierre knew as he knew everybody in\nMoscow and Petersburg, came to see him. Berg arrived in an immaculate\nbrand-new uniform, with his hair pomaded and brushed forward over his\ntemples as the Emperor Alexander wore his hair.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have just been to see the countess, your wife. Unfortunately she\ncould not grant my request, but I hope, Count, I shall be more fortunate\nwith you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said with a smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it you wish, Colonel? I am at your service.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have now quite settled in my new rooms, Count\xe2\x80\x9d (Berg said\nthis with perfect conviction that this information could not but be\nagreeable), \xe2\x80\x9cand so I wish to arrange just a small party for my own\nand my wife\xe2\x80\x99s friends.\xe2\x80\x9d (He smiled still more pleasantly.) \xe2\x80\x9cI\nwished to ask the countess and you to do me the honor of coming to tea\nand to supper.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nOnly Countess H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, considering the society of such people as the\nBergs beneath her, could be cruel enough to refuse such an invitation.\nBerg explained so clearly why he wanted to collect at his house a small\nbut select company, and why this would give him pleasure, and why though\nhe grudged spending money on cards or anything harmful, he was prepared\nto run into some expense for the sake of good society\xe2\x80\x94that Pierre\ncould not refuse, and promised to come.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut don\xe2\x80\x99t be late, Count, if I may venture to ask; about ten\nminutes to eight, please. We shall make up a rubber. Our general is\ncoming. He is very good to me. We shall have supper, Count. So you will\ndo me the favor.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nContrary to his habit of being late, Pierre on that day arrived at the\nBergs\xe2\x80\x99 house, not at ten but at fifteen minutes to eight.\n\nHaving prepared everything necessary for the party, the Bergs were ready\nfor their guests\xe2\x80\x99 arrival.\n\nIn their new, clean, and light study with its small busts and pictures\nand new furniture sat Berg and his wife. Berg, closely buttoned up in\nhis new uniform, sat beside his wife explaining to her that one always\ncould and should be acquainted with people above one, because only then\ndoes one get satisfaction from acquaintances.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can get to know something, you can ask for something. See how I\nmanaged from my first promotion.\xe2\x80\x9d (Berg measured his life not by years\nbut by promotions.) \xe2\x80\x9cMy comrades are still nobodies, while I am only\nwaiting for a vacancy to command a regiment, and have the happiness to\nbe your husband.\xe2\x80\x9d (He rose and kissed V\xc3\xa9ra\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and on the way\nto her straightened out a turned-up corner of the carpet.) \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\nhow have I obtained all this? Chiefly by knowing how to choose my\naquaintances. It goes without saying that one must be conscientious and\nmethodical.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBerg smiled with a sense of his superiority over a weak woman, and\npaused, reflecting that this dear wife of his was after all but a weak\nwoman who could not understand all that constitutes a man\xe2\x80\x99s dignity,\nwhat it was ein Mann zu sein. * V\xc3\xa9ra at the same time smiling with a\nsense of superiority over her good, conscientious husband, who all the\nsame understood life wrongly, as according to V\xc3\xa9ra all men did. Berg,\njudging by his wife, thought all women weak and foolish. V\xc3\xa9ra, judging\nonly by her husband and generalizing from that observation, supposed\nthat all men, though they understand nothing and are conceited and\nselfish, ascribe common sense to themselves alone.\n\n    * To be a man.\n\nBerg rose and embraced his wife carefully, so as not to crush her lace\nfichu for which he had paid a good price, kissing her straight on the\nlips.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe only thing is, we mustn\xe2\x80\x99t have children too soon,\xe2\x80\x9d he\ncontinued, following an unconscious sequence of ideas.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d answered V\xc3\xa9ra, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t at all want that. We must live\nfor society.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrincess Yus\xc3\xbapova wore one exactly like this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Berg, pointing\nto the fichu with a happy and kindly smile.\n\nJust then Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov was announced. Husband and wife glanced at one\nanother, both smiling with self-satisfaction, and each mentally claiming\nthe honor of this visit.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is what comes of knowing how to make acquaintances,\xe2\x80\x9d thought\nBerg. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is what comes of knowing how to conduct oneself.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut please don\xe2\x80\x99t interrupt me when I am entertaining the guests,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid V\xc3\xa9ra, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause I know what interests each of them and what to\nsay to different people.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBerg smiled again.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt can\xe2\x80\x99t be helped: men must sometimes have masculine\nconversation,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\nThey received Pierre in their small, new drawing room, where it was\nimpossible to sit down anywhere without disturbing its symmetry,\nneatness, and order; so it was quite comprehensible and not strange that\nBerg, having generously offered to disturb the symmetry of an armchair\nor of the sofa for his dear guest, but being apparently painfully\nundecided on the matter himself, eventually left the visitor to settle\nthe question of selection. Pierre disturbed the symmetry by moving a\nchair for himself, and Berg and V\xc3\xa9ra immediately began their evening\nparty, interrupting each other in their efforts to entertain their\nguest.\n\nV\xc3\xa9ra, having decided in her own mind that Pierre ought to be\nentertained with conversation about the French embassy, at once began\naccordingly. Berg, having decided that masculine conversation was\nrequired, interrupted his wife\xe2\x80\x99s remarks and touched on the question\nof the war with Austria, and unconsciously jumped from the general\nsubject to personal considerations as to the proposals made him to take\npart in the Austrian campaign and the reasons why he had declined them.\nThough the conversation was very incoherent and V\xc3\xa9ra was angry at the\nintrusion of the masculine element, both husband and wife felt with\nsatisfaction that, even if only one guest was present, their evening had\nbegun very well and was as like as two peas to every other evening party\nwith its talk, tea, and lighted candles.\n\nBefore long Bor\xc3\xads, Berg\xe2\x80\x99s old comrade, arrived. There was a shade of\ncondescension and patronage in his treatment of Berg and V\xc3\xa9ra. After\nBor\xc3\xads came a lady with the colonel, then the general himself, then the\nRost\xc3\xb3vs, and the party became unquestionably exactly like all other\nevening parties. Berg and V\xc3\xa9ra could not repress their smiles of\nsatisfaction at the sight of all this movement in their drawing room,\nat the sound of the disconnected talk, the rustling of dresses, and the\nbowing and scraping. Everything was just as everybody always has it,\nespecially so the general, who admired the apartment, patted Berg on the\nshoulder, and with parental authority superintended the setting out of\nthe table for boston. The general sat down by Count Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v, who\nwas next to himself the most important guest. The old people sat with\nthe old, the young with the young, and the hostess at the tea table, on\nwhich stood exactly the same kind of cakes in a silver cake basket as\nthe Panins had at their party. Everything was just as it was everywhere\nelse.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XXI\n\nPierre, as one of the principal guests, had to sit down to boston\nwith Count Rost\xc3\xb3v, the general, and the colonel. At the card table he\nhappened to be directly facing Nat\xc3\xa1sha, and was struck by a curious\nchange that had come over her since the ball. She was silent, and not\nonly less pretty than at the ball, but only redeemed from plainness by\nher look of gentle indifference to everything around.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with her?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Pierre, glancing at her.\nShe was sitting by her sister at the tea table, and reluctantly, without\nlooking at him, made some reply to Bor\xc3\xads who sat down beside her. After\nplaying out a whole suit and to his partner\xe2\x80\x99s delight taking five\ntricks, Pierre, hearing greetings and the steps of someone who had\nentered the room while he was picking up his tricks, glanced again at\nNat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has happened to her?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked himself with still greater\nsurprise.\n\nPrince Andrew was standing before her, saying something to her with a\nlook of tender solicitude. She, having raised her head, was looking up\nat him, flushed and evidently trying to master her rapid breathing. And\nthe bright glow of some inner fire that had been suppressed was again\nalight in her. She was completely transformed and from a plain girl had\nagain become what she had been at the ball.\n\nPrince Andrew went up to Pierre, and the latter noticed a new and\nyouthful expression in his friend\xe2\x80\x99s face.\n\nPierre changed places several times during the game, sitting now with\nhis back to Nat\xc3\xa1sha and now facing her, but during the whole of the six\nrubbers he watched her and his friend.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomething very important is happening between them,\xe2\x80\x9d thought\nPierre, and a feeling that was both joyful and painful agitated him and\nmade him neglect the game.\n\nAfter six rubbers the general got up, saying that it was no use playing\nlike that, and Pierre was released. Nat\xc3\xa1sha on one side was talking\nwith S\xc3\xb3nya and Bor\xc3\xads, and V\xc3\xa9ra with a subtle smile was saying\nsomething to Prince Andrew. Pierre went up to his friend and, asking\nwhether they were talking secrets, sat down beside them. V\xc3\xa9ra, having\nnoticed Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s attentions to Nat\xc3\xa1sha, decided that at a\nparty, a real evening party, subtle allusions to the tender passion were\nabsolutely necessary and, seizing a moment when Prince Andrew was alone,\nbegan a conversation with him about feelings in general and about her\nsister. With so intellectual a guest as she considered Prince Andrew to\nbe, she felt that she had to employ her diplomatic tact.\n\nWhen Pierre went up to them he noticed that V\xc3\xa9ra was being carried away\nby her self-satisfied talk, but that Prince Andrew seemed embarrassed, a\nthing that rarely happened with him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d V\xc3\xa9ra was saying with an arch smile. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are\nso discerning, Prince, and understand people\xe2\x80\x99s characters so well at\na glance. What do you think of Natalie? Could she be constant in her\nattachments? Could she, like other women\xe2\x80\x9d (V\xc3\xa9ra meant herself),\n\xe2\x80\x9clove a man once for all and remain true to him forever? That is what\nI consider true love. What do you think, Prince?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know your sister too little,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Prince Andrew, with a\nsarcastic smile under which he wished to hide his embarrassment, \xe2\x80\x9cto\nbe able to solve so delicate a question, and then I have noticed that\nthe less attractive a woman is the more constant she is likely to be,\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe added, and looked up at Pierre who was just approaching them.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that is true, Prince. In our days,\xe2\x80\x9d continued\nV\xc3\xa9ra\xe2\x80\x94mentioning \xe2\x80\x9cour days\xe2\x80\x9d as people of limited intelligence are\nfond of doing, imagining that they have discovered and appraised the\npeculiarities of \xe2\x80\x9cour days\xe2\x80\x9d and that human characteristics change\nwith the times\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cin our days a girl has so much freedom that the\npleasure of being courted often stifles real feeling in her. And it must\nbe confessed that Natalie is very susceptible.\xe2\x80\x9d This return to\nthe subject of Natalie caused Prince Andrew to knit his brows with\ndiscomfort: he was about to rise, but V\xc3\xa9ra continued with a still more\nsubtle smile:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think no one has been more courted than she,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on, \xe2\x80\x9cbut\ntill quite lately she never cared seriously for anyone. Now you know,\nCount,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to Pierre, \xe2\x80\x9ceven our dear cousin Bor\xc3\xads, who,\nbetween ourselves, was very far gone in the land of tenderness...\xe2\x80\x9d\n(alluding to a map of love much in vogue at that time).\n\nPrince Andrew frowned and remained silent.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are friendly with Bor\xc3\xads, aren\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked V\xc3\xa9ra.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I know him....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI expect he has told you of his childish love for Nat\xc3\xa1sha?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, there was childish love?\xe2\x80\x9d suddenly asked Prince Andrew,\nblushing unexpectedly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you know between cousins intimacy often leads to love. Le\ncousinage est un dangereux voisinage. * Don\xe2\x80\x99t you think so?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cCousinhood is a dangerous neighborhood.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, undoubtedly!\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew, and with sudden and unnatural\nliveliness he began chaffing Pierre about the need to be very careful\nwith his fifty-year-old Moscow cousins, and in the midst of these\njesting remarks he rose, taking Pierre by the arm, and drew him aside.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pierre, seeing his friend\xe2\x80\x99s strange animation with\nsurprise, and noticing the glance he turned on Nat\xc3\xa1sha as he rose.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must... I must have a talk with you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\nknow that pair of women\xe2\x80\x99s gloves?\xe2\x80\x9d (He referred to the Masonic\ngloves given to a newly initiated Brother to present to the woman he\nloved.) \xe2\x80\x9cI... but no, I will talk to you later on,\xe2\x80\x9d and with a\nstrange light in his eyes and restlessness in his movements, Prince\nAndrew approached Nat\xc3\xa1sha and sat down beside her. Pierre saw how\nPrince Andrew asked her something and how she flushed as she replied.\n\nBut at that moment Berg came to Pierre and began insisting that he\nshould take part in an argument between the general and the colonel on\nthe affairs in Spain.\n\nBerg was satisfied and happy. The smile of pleasure never left his face.\nThe party was very successful and quite like other parties he had\nseen. Everything was similar: the ladies\xe2\x80\x99 subtle talk, the cards, the\ngeneral raising his voice at the card table, and the samovar and the tea\ncakes; only one thing was lacking that he had always seen at the evening\nparties he wished to imitate. They had not yet had a loud conversation\namong the men and a dispute about something important and clever. Now\nthe general had begun such a discussion and so Berg drew Pierre to it.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XXII\n\nNext day, having been invited by the count, Prince Andrew dined with the\nRost\xc3\xb3vs and spent the rest of the day there.\n\nEveryone in the house realized for whose sake Prince Andrew came, and\nwithout concealing it he tried to be with Nat\xc3\xa1sha all day. Not only in\nthe soul of the frightened yet happy and enraptured Nat\xc3\xa1sha, but in the\nwhole house, there was a feeling of awe at something important that was\nbound to happen. The countess looked with sad and sternly serious eyes\nat Prince Andrew when he talked to Nat\xc3\xa1sha and timidly started some\nartificial conversation about trifles as soon as he looked her way.\nS\xc3\xb3nya was afraid to leave Nat\xc3\xa1sha and afraid of being in the way when\nshe was with them. Nat\xc3\xa1sha grew pale, in a panic of expectation, when\nshe remained alone with him for a moment. Prince Andrew surprised her by\nhis timidity. She felt that he wanted to say something to her but could\nnot bring himself to do so.\n\nIn the evening, when Prince Andrew had left, the countess went up to\nNat\xc3\xa1sha and whispered: \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma! For heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake don\xe2\x80\x99t ask me anything now! One can\xe2\x80\x99t\ntalk about that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\nBut all the same that night Nat\xc3\xa1sha, now agitated and now frightened,\nlay a long time in her mother\xe2\x80\x99s bed gazing straight before her. She\ntold her how he had complimented her, how he told her he was going\nabroad, asked her where they were going to spend the summer, and then\nhow he had asked her about Bor\xc3\xads.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut such a... such a... never happened to me before!\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly I feel afraid in his presence. I am always afraid when I\xe2\x80\x99m\nwith him. What does that mean? Does it mean that it\xe2\x80\x99s the real thing?\nYes? Mamma, are you asleep?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my love; I am frightened myself,\xe2\x80\x9d answered her mother. \xe2\x80\x9cNow\ngo!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll the same I shan\xe2\x80\x99t sleep. What silliness, to sleep! Mummy!\nMummy! such a thing never happened to me before,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, surprised\nand alarmed at the feeling she was aware of in herself. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd could we\never have thought!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIt seemed to Nat\xc3\xa1sha that even at the time she first saw Prince Andrew\nat Otr\xc3\xa1dnoe she had fallen in love with him. It was as if she feared\nthis strange, unexpected happiness of meeting again the very man she had\nthen chosen (she was firmly convinced she had done so) and of finding\nhim, as it seemed, not indifferent to her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it had to happen that he should come specially to Petersburg\nwhile we are here. And it had to happen that we should meet at that\nball. It is fate. Clearly it is fate that everything led up to this!\nAlready then, directly I saw him I felt something peculiar.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat else did he say to you? What are those verses? Read them...\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid her mother, thoughtfully, referring to some verses Prince Andrew\nhad written in Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s album.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, one need not be ashamed of his being a widower?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t, Nat\xc3\xa1sha! Pray to God. \xe2\x80\x98Marriages are made in\nheaven,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said her mother.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDarling Mummy, how I love you! How happy I am!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nat\xc3\xa1sha,\nshedding tears of joy and excitement and embracing her mother.\n\nAt that very time Prince Andrew was sitting with Pierre and telling him\nof his love for Nat\xc3\xa1sha and his firm resolve to make her his wife.\n\nThat day Countess H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne had a reception at her house. The French\nambassador was there, and a foreign prince of the blood who had of\nlate become a frequent visitor of hers, and many brilliant ladies and\ngentlemen. Pierre, who had come downstairs, walked through the rooms and\nstruck everyone by his preoccupied, absent-minded, and morose air.\n\nSince the ball he had felt the approach of a fit of nervous depression\nand had made desperate efforts to combat it. Since the intimacy of\nhis wife with the royal prince, Pierre had unexpectedly been made a\ngentleman of the bedchamber, and from that time he had begun to feel\noppressed and ashamed in court society, and dark thoughts of the vanity\nof all things human came to him oftener than before. At the same time\nthe feeling he had noticed between his prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9e Nat\xc3\xa1sha and Prince\nAndrew accentuated his gloom by the contrast between his own position\nand his friend\xe2\x80\x99s. He tried equally to avoid thinking about his wife,\nand about Nat\xc3\xa1sha and Prince Andrew; and again everything seemed to him\ninsignificant in comparison with eternity; again the question: for what?\npresented itself; and he forced himself to work day and night at Masonic\nlabors, hoping to drive away the evil spirit that threatened him. Toward\nmidnight, after he had left the countess\xe2\x80\x99 apartments, he was sitting\nupstairs in a shabby dressing gown, copying out the original transaction\nof the Scottish lodge of Freemasons at a table in his low room cloudy\nwith tobacco smoke, when someone came in. It was Prince Andrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, it\xe2\x80\x99s you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre with a preoccupied, dissatisfied air.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I, you see, am hard at it.\xe2\x80\x9d He pointed to his manuscript book\nwith that air of escaping from the ills of life with which unhappy\npeople look at their work.\n\nPrince Andrew, with a beaming, ecstatic expression of renewed life on\nhis face, paused in front of Pierre and, not noticing his sad look,\nsmiled at him with the egotism of joy.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, dear heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI wanted to tell you about it\nyesterday and I have come to do so today. I never experienced anything\nlike it before. I am in love, my friend!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nSuddenly Pierre heaved a deep sigh and dumped his heavy person down on\nthe sofa beside Prince Andrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith Nat\xc3\xa1sha Rost\xc3\xb3va, yes?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes! Who else should it be? I should never have believed it,\nbut the feeling is stronger than I. Yesterday I tormented myself and\nsuffered, but I would not exchange even that torment for anything in\nthe world, I have not lived till now. At last I live, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t\nlive without her! But can she love me?... I am too old for her.... Why\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t you speak?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? I? What did I tell you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre suddenly, rising and\nbeginning to pace up and down the room. \xe2\x80\x9cI always thought it.... That\ngirl is such a treasure... she is a rare girl.... My dear friend,\nI entreat you, don\xe2\x80\x99t philosophize, don\xe2\x80\x99t doubt, marry, marry,\nmarry.... And I am sure there will not be a happier man than you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what of her?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe loves you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t talk rubbish...\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew, smiling and looking\ninto Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe does, I know,\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre cried fiercely.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut do listen,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Prince Andrew, holding him by the\narm. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you know the condition I am in? I must talk about it to\nsomeone.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, go on, go on. I am very glad,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, and his face\nreally changed, his brow became smooth, and he listened gladly to Prince\nAndrew. Prince Andrew seemed, and really was, quite a different, quite\na new man. Where was his spleen, his contempt for life, his\ndisillusionment? Pierre was the only person to whom he made up his mind\nto speak openly; and to him he told all that was in his soul. Now he\nboldly and lightly made plans for an extended future, said he could not\nsacrifice his own happiness to his father\xe2\x80\x99s caprice, and spoke of how\nhe would either make his father consent to this marriage and love her,\nor would do without his consent; then he marveled at the feeling that\nhad mastered him as at something strange, apart from and independent of\nhimself.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should not have believed anyone who told me that I was capable of\nsuch love,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is not at all the same feeling\nthat I knew in the past. The whole world is now for me divided into two\nhalves: one half is she, and there all is joy, hope, light: the\nother half is everything where she is not, and there is all gloom and\ndarkness....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDarkness and gloom,\xe2\x80\x9d reiterated Pierre: \xe2\x80\x9cyes, yes, I understand\nthat.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot help loving the light, it is not my fault. And I am very\nhappy! You understand me? I know you are glad for my sake.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre assented, looking at his friend with a touched\nand sad expression in his eyes. The brighter Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s lot\nappeared to him, the gloomier seemed his own.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XXIII\n\nPrince Andrew needed his father\xe2\x80\x99s consent to his marriage, and to\nobtain this he started for the country next day.\n\nHis father received his son\xe2\x80\x99s communication with external composure,\nbut inward wrath. He could not comprehend how anyone could wish to\nalter his life or introduce anything new into it, when his own life\nwas already ending. \xe2\x80\x9cIf only they would let me end my days as I want\nto,\xe2\x80\x9d thought the old man, \xe2\x80\x9cthen they might do as they please.\xe2\x80\x9d\nWith his son, however, he employed the diplomacy he reserved for\nimportant occasions and, adopting a quiet tone, discussed the whole\nmatter.\n\nIn the first place the marriage was not a brilliant one as regards\nbirth, wealth, or rank. Secondly, Prince Andrew was no longer as young\nas he had been and his health was poor (the old man laid special stress\non this), while she was very young. Thirdly, he had a son whom it would\nbe a pity to entrust to a chit of a girl. \xe2\x80\x9cFourthly and finally,\xe2\x80\x9d\nthe father said, looking ironically at his son, \xe2\x80\x9cI beg you to put it\noff for a year: go abroad, take a cure, look out as you wanted to for\na German tutor for Prince Nicholas. Then if your love or passion or\nobstinacy\xe2\x80\x94as you please\xe2\x80\x94is still as great, marry! And that\xe2\x80\x99s my\nlast word on it. Mind, the last...\xe2\x80\x9d concluded the prince, in a tone\nwhich showed that nothing would make him alter his decision.\n\nPrince Andrew saw clearly that the old man hoped that his feelings, or\nhis fianc\xc3\xa9e\xe2\x80\x99s, would not stand a year\xe2\x80\x99s test, or that he (the old\nprince himself) would die before then, and he decided to conform to his\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s wish\xe2\x80\x94to propose, and postpone the wedding for a year.\n\nThree weeks after the last evening he had spent with the Rost\xc3\xb3vs,\nPrince Andrew returned to Petersburg.\n\n\nNext day after her talk with her mother Nat\xc3\xa1sha expected Bolk\xc3\xb3nski all\nday, but he did not come. On the second and third day it was the same.\nPierre did not come either and Nat\xc3\xa1sha, not knowing that Prince Andrew\nhad gone to see his father, could not explain his absence to herself.\n\nThree weeks passed in this way. Nat\xc3\xa1sha had no desire to go out\nanywhere and wandered from room to room like a shadow, idle and\nlistless; she wept secretly at night and did not go to her mother in the\nevenings. She blushed continually and was irritable. It seemed to her\nthat everybody knew about her disappointment and was laughing at her and\npitying her. Strong as was her inward grief, this wound to her vanity\nintensified her misery.\n\nOnce she came to her mother, tried to say something, and suddenly began\nto cry. Her tears were those of an offended child who does not know why\nit is being punished.\n\nThe countess began to soothe Nat\xc3\xa1sha, who after first listening to her\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s words, suddenly interrupted her:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeave off, Mamma! I don\xe2\x80\x99t think, and don\xe2\x80\x99t want to think about\nit! He just came and then left off, left off....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHer voice trembled, and she again nearly cried, but recovered and went\non quietly:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I don\xe2\x80\x99t at all want to get married. And I am afraid of him; I\nhave now become quite calm, quite calm.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe day after this conversation Nat\xc3\xa1sha put on the old dress which\nshe knew had the peculiar property of conducing to cheerfulness in the\nmornings, and that day she returned to the old way of life which she had\nabandoned since the ball. Having finished her morning tea she went to\nthe ballroom, which she particularly liked for its loud resonance, and\nbegan singing her solfeggio. When she had finished her first exercise\nshe stood still in the middle of the room and sang a musical phrase that\nparticularly pleased her. She listened joyfully (as though she had not\nexpected it) to the charm of the notes reverberating, filling the\nwhole empty ballroom, and slowly dying away; and all at once she felt\ncheerful. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the good of making so much of it? Things are nice\nas it is,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to herself, and she began walking up and down the\nroom, not stepping simply on the resounding parquet but treading with\neach step from the heel to the toe (she had on a new and favorite pair\nof shoes) and listening to the regular tap of the heel and creak of\nthe toe as gladly as she had to the sounds of her own voice. Passing a\nmirror she glanced into it. \xe2\x80\x9cThere, that\xe2\x80\x99s me!\xe2\x80\x9d the expression of\nher face seemed to say as she caught sight of herself. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, and very\nnice too! I need nobody.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nA footman wanted to come in to clear away something in the room but she\nwould not let him, and having closed the door behind him continued her\nwalk. That morning she had returned to her favorite mood\xe2\x80\x94love of,\nand delight in, herself. \xe2\x80\x9cHow charming that Nat\xc3\xa1sha is!\xe2\x80\x9d she said\nagain, speaking as some third, collective, male person. \xe2\x80\x9cPretty,\na good voice, young, and in nobody\xe2\x80\x99s way if only they leave her in\npeace.\xe2\x80\x9d But however much they left her in peace she could not now be\nat peace, and immediately felt this.\n\nIn the hall the porch door opened, and someone asked, \xe2\x80\x9cAt home?\xe2\x80\x9d and\nthen footsteps were heard. Nat\xc3\xa1sha was looking at the mirror, but did\nnot see herself. She listened to the sounds in the hall. When she saw\nherself, her face was pale. It was he. She knew this for certain, though\nshe hardly heard his voice through the closed doors.\n\nPale and agitated, Nat\xc3\xa1sha ran into the drawing room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma! Bolk\xc3\xb3nski has come!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cMamma, it is awful, it is\nunbearable! I don\xe2\x80\x99t want... to be tormented? What am I to do?...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBefore the countess could answer, Prince Andrew entered the room with\nan agitated and serious face. As soon as he saw Nat\xc3\xa1sha his face\nbrightened. He kissed the countess\xe2\x80\x99 hand and Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s, and sat\ndown beside the sofa.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is long since we had the pleasure...\xe2\x80\x9d began the countess,\nbut Prince Andrew interrupted her by answering her intended question,\nobviously in haste to say what he had to.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have not been to see you all this time because I have been at my\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s. I had to talk over a very important matter with him. I only\ngot back last night,\xe2\x80\x9d he said glancing at Nat\xc3\xa1sha; \xe2\x80\x9cI want to have\na talk with you, Countess,\xe2\x80\x9d he added after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s pause.\n\nThe countess lowered her eyes, sighing deeply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am at your disposal,\xe2\x80\x9d she murmured.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha knew that she ought to go away, but was unable to do so:\nsomething gripped her throat, and regardless of manners she stared\nstraight at Prince Andrew with wide-open eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt once? This instant!... No, it can\xe2\x80\x99t be!\xe2\x80\x9d she thought.\n\nAgain he glanced at her, and that glance convinced her that she was not\nmistaken. Yes, at once, that very instant, her fate would be decided.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, Nat\xc3\xa1sha! I will call you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess in a whisper.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha glanced with frightened imploring eyes at Prince Andrew and at\nher mother and went out.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have come, Countess, to ask for your daughter\xe2\x80\x99s hand,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nPrince Andrew.\n\nThe countess\xe2\x80\x99 face flushed hotly, but she said nothing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour offer...\xe2\x80\x9d she began at last sedately. He remained silent,\nlooking into her eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cYour offer...\xe2\x80\x9d (she grew confused) \xe2\x80\x9cis\nagreeable to us, and I accept your offer. I am glad. And my husband... I\nhope... but it will depend on her....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will speak to her when I have your consent.... Do you give it to\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the countess. She held out her hand to him, and with\na mixed feeling of estrangement and tenderness pressed her lips to his\nforehead as he stooped to kiss her hand. She wished to love him as a\nson, but felt that to her he was a stranger and a terrifying man. \xe2\x80\x9cI\nam sure my husband will consent,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, \xe2\x80\x9cbut your\nfather...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father, to whom I have told my plans, has made it an express\ncondition of his consent that the wedding is not to take place for a\nyear. And I wished to tell you of that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true that Nat\xc3\xa1sha is still young, but\xe2\x80\x94so long as that?...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is unavoidable,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew with a sigh.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will send her to you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, and left the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord have mercy upon us!\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated while seeking her daughter.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya said that Nat\xc3\xa1sha was in her bedroom. Nat\xc3\xa1sha was sitting on\nthe bed, pale and dry-eyed, and was gazing at the icons and whispering\nsomething as she rapidly crossed herself. Seeing her mother she jumped\nup and flew to her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Mamma?... Well?...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, go to him. He is asking for your hand,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess,\ncoldly it seemed to Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cGo... go,\xe2\x80\x9d said the mother, sadly and\nreproachfully, with a deep sigh, as her daughter ran away.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha never remembered how she entered the drawing room. When she\ncame in and saw him she paused. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible that this stranger\nhas now become everything to me?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked herself, and immediately\nanswered, \xe2\x80\x9cYes, everything! He alone is now dearer to me than\neverything in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d Prince Andrew came up to her with downcast\neyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have loved you from the very first moment I saw you. May I hope?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe looked at her and was struck by the serious impassioned expression of\nher face. Her face said: \xe2\x80\x9cWhy ask? Why doubt what you cannot but know?\nWhy speak, when words cannot express what one feels?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe drew near to him and stopped. He took her hand and kissed it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you love me?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha murmured as if in vexation. Then she sighed\nloudly and, catching her breath more and more quickly, began to sob.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it? What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I am so happy!\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, smiled through her tears, bent\nover closer to him, paused for an instant as if asking herself whether\nshe might, and then kissed him.\n\nPrince Andrew held her hands, looked into her eyes, and did not find\nin his heart his former love for her. Something in him had suddenly\nchanged; there was no longer the former poetic and mystic charm of\ndesire, but there was pity for her feminine and childish weakness, fear\nat her devotion and trustfulness, and an oppressive yet joyful sense of\nthe duty that now bound him to her forever. The present feeling, though\nnot so bright and poetic as the former, was stronger and more serious.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid your mother tell you that it cannot be for a year?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\nPrince Andrew, still looking into her eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible that I\xe2\x80\x94the \xe2\x80\x98chit of a girl,\xe2\x80\x99 as everybody called\nme,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cis it possible that I am now to be the\nwife and the equal of this strange, dear, clever man whom even my father\nlooks up to? Can it be true? Can it be true that there can be no\nmore playing with life, that now I am grown up, that on me now lies\na responsibility for my every word and deed? Yes, but what did he ask\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, but she had not understood his question.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cForgive me!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you are so young, and I have already\nbeen through so much in life.
