The masters rode together. \xe2\x80\x9cUncle,\xe2\x80\x9d Rost\xc3\xb3v, and\nIl\xc3\xa1gin kept stealthily glancing at one another\xe2\x80\x99s dogs, trying not\nto be observed by their companions and searching uneasily for rivals to\ntheir own borzois.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v was particularly struck by the beauty of a small, pure-bred,\nred-spotted bitch on Il\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x99s leash, slender but with muscles like\nsteel, a delicate muzzle, and prominent black eyes. He had heard of\nthe swiftness of Il\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x99s borzois, and in that beautiful bitch saw a\nrival to his own M\xc3\xadlka.\n\nIn the middle of a sober conversation begun by Il\xc3\xa1gin about the\nyear\xe2\x80\x99s harvest, Nicholas pointed to the red-spotted bitch.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA fine little bitch, that!\xe2\x80\x9d said he in a careless tone. \xe2\x80\x9cIs she\nswift?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat one? Yes, she\xe2\x80\x99s a good dog, gets what she\xe2\x80\x99s after,\xe2\x80\x9d\nanswered Il\xc3\xa1gin indifferently, of the red-spotted bitch Erz\xc3\xa1, for\nwhich, a year before, he had given a neighbor three families of house\nserfs. \xe2\x80\x9cSo in your parts, too, the harvest is nothing to boast of,\nCount?\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, continuing the conversation they had begun. And\nconsidering it polite to return the young count\xe2\x80\x99s compliment, Il\xc3\xa1gin\nlooked at his borzois and picked out M\xc3\xadlka who attracted his attention\nby her breadth. \xe2\x80\x9cThat black-spotted one of yours is fine\xe2\x80\x94well\nshaped!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, she\xe2\x80\x99s fast enough,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Nicholas, and thought: \xe2\x80\x9cIf\nonly a full-grown hare would cross the field now I\xe2\x80\x99d show you what\nsort of borzoi she is,\xe2\x80\x9d and turning to his groom, he said he would\ngive a ruble to anyone who found a hare.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t understand,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Il\xc3\xa1gin, \xe2\x80\x9chow some sportsmen can\nbe so jealous about game and dogs. For myself, I can tell you, Count,\nI enjoy riding in company such as this... what could be better?\xe2\x80\x9d (he\nagain raised his cap to Nat\xc3\xa1sha) \xe2\x80\x9cbut as for counting skins and what\none takes, I don\xe2\x80\x99t care about that.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course not!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr being upset because someone else\xe2\x80\x99s borzoi and not mine catches\nsomething. All I care about is to enjoy seeing the chase, is it not so,\nCount? For I consider that...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA-tu!\xe2\x80\x9d came the long-drawn cry of one of the borzoi whippers-in,\nwho had halted. He stood on a knoll in the stubble, holding his whip\naloft, and again repeated his long-drawn cry, \xe2\x80\x9cA-tu!\xe2\x80\x9d (This call and\nthe uplifted whip meant that he saw a sitting hare.)\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, he has found one, I think,\xe2\x80\x9d said Il\xc3\xa1gin carelessly. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, we\nmust ride up.... Shall we both course it?\xe2\x80\x9d answered Nicholas, seeing\nin Erz\xc3\xa1 and \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d red Rug\xc3\xa1y two rivals he had never yet had\na chance of pitting against his own borzois. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd suppose they outdo\nmy M\xc3\xadlka at once!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought as he rode with \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d and Il\xc3\xa1gin\ntoward the hare.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA full-grown one?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Il\xc3\xa1gin as he approached the whip who\nhad sighted the hare\xe2\x80\x94and not without agitation he looked round and\nwhistled to Erz\xc3\xa1.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, Michael Nikan\xc3\xb3rovich?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, addressing \xe2\x80\x9cUncle.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe latter was riding with a sullen expression on his face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can I join in? Why, you\xe2\x80\x99ve given a village for each of your\nborzois! That\xe2\x80\x99s it, come on! Yours are worth thousands. Try yours\nagainst one another, you two, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll look on!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cRug\xc3\xa1y, hey, hey!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted. \xe2\x80\x9cRug\xc3\xa1yushka!\xe2\x80\x9d he added,\ninvoluntarily by this diminutive expressing his affection and the hopes\nhe placed on this red borzoi. Nat\xc3\xa1sha saw and felt the agitation the\ntwo elderly men and her brother were trying to conceal, and was herself\nexcited by it.\n\nThe huntsman stood halfway up the knoll holding up his whip and the\ngentlefolk rode up to him at a footpace; the hounds that were far off\non the horizon turned away from the hare, and the whips, but not the\ngentlefolk, also moved away. All were moving slowly and sedately.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is it pointing?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Nicholas, riding a hundred paces toward\nthe whip who had sighted the hare.\n\nBut before the whip could reply, the hare, scenting the frost coming\nnext morning, was unable to rest and leaped up. The pack on leash rushed\ndownhill in full cry after the hare, and from all sides the borzois that\nwere not on leash darted after the hounds and the hare. All the hunt,\nwho had been moving slowly, shouted, \xe2\x80\x9cStop!\xe2\x80\x9d calling in the hounds,\nwhile the borzoi whips, with a cry of \xe2\x80\x9cA-tu!\xe2\x80\x9d galloped across the\nfield setting the borzois on the hare. The tranquil Il\xc3\xa1gin, Nicholas,\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, and \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d flew, reckless of where and how they went,\nseeing only the borzois and the hare and fearing only to lose sight even\nfor an instant of the chase. The hare they had started was a strong and\nswift one. When he jumped up he did not run at once, but pricked his\nears listening to the shouting and trampling that resounded from all\nsides at once. He took a dozen bounds, not very quickly, letting the\nborzois gain on him, and, finally having chosen his direction and\nrealized his danger, laid back his ears and rushed off headlong. He had\nbeen lying in the stubble, but in front of him was the autumn sowing\nwhere the ground was soft. The two borzois of the huntsman who had\nsighted him, having been the nearest, were the first to see and pursue\nhim, but they had not gone far before Il\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x99s red-spotted Erz\xc3\xa1\npassed them, got within a length, flew at the hare with terrible\nswiftness aiming at his scut, and, thinking she had seized him, rolled\nover like a ball. The hare arched his back and bounded off yet more\nswiftly. From behind Erz\xc3\xa1 rushed the broad-haunched, black-spotted\nM\xc3\xadlka and began rapidly gaining on the hare.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMil\xc3\xa1shka, dear!\xe2\x80\x9d rose Nicholas\xe2\x80\x99 triumphant cry. It looked as if\nM\xc3\xadlka would immediately pounce on the hare, but she overtook him and\nflew past. The hare had squatted. Again the beautiful Erz\xc3\xa1 reached him,\nbut when close to the hare\xe2\x80\x99s scut paused as if measuring the distance,\nso as not to make a mistake this time but seize his hind leg.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cErz\xc3\xa1, darling!\xe2\x80\x9d Il\xc3\xa1gin wailed in a voice unlike his own. Erz\xc3\xa1\ndid not hearken to his appeal. At the very moment when she would have\nseized her prey, the hare moved and darted along the balk between the\nwinter rye and the stubble. Again Erz\xc3\xa1 and M\xc3\xadlka were abreast, running\nlike a pair of carriage horses, and began to overtake the hare, but\nit was easier for the hare to run on the balk and the borzois did not\novertake him so quickly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cRug\xc3\xa1y, Rug\xc3\xa1yushka! That\xe2\x80\x99s it, come on!\xe2\x80\x9d came a third voice just\nthen, and \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d red borzoi, straining and curving its back,\ncaught up with the two foremost borzois, pushed ahead of them regardless\nof the terrible strain, put on speed close to the hare, knocked it off\nthe balk onto the ryefield, again put on speed still more viciously,\nsinking to his knees in the muddy field, and all one could see was\nhow, muddying his back, he rolled over with the hare. A ring of borzois\nsurrounded him. A moment later everyone had drawn up round the crowd\nof dogs. Only the delighted \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d dismounted, and cut off a pad,\nshaking the hare for the blood to drip off, and anxiously glancing round\nwith restless eyes while his arms and legs twitched. He spoke without\nhimself knowing whom to or what about. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it, come on! That\xe2\x80\x99s\na dog!... There, it has beaten them all, the thousand-ruble as well as\nthe one-ruble borzois. That\xe2\x80\x99s it, come on!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, panting and\nlooking wrathfully around as if he were abusing someone, as if they\nwere all his enemies and had insulted him, and only now had he at\nlast succeeded in justifying himself. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are your thousand-ruble\nones.... That\xe2\x80\x99s it, come on!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cRug\xc3\xa1y, here\xe2\x80\x99s a pad for you!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, throwing down the\nhare\xe2\x80\x99s muddy pad. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve deserved it, that\xe2\x80\x99s it, come on!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99d tired herself out, she\xe2\x80\x99d run it down three times by\nherself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas, also not listening to anyone and regardless\nof whether he were heard or not.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what is there in running across it like that?\xe2\x80\x9d said Il\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x99s\ngroom.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnce she had missed it and turned it away, any mongrel could take\nit,\xe2\x80\x9d Il\xc3\xa1gin was saying at the same time, breathless from his gallop\nand his excitement. At the same moment Nat\xc3\xa1sha, without drawing\nbreath, screamed joyously, ecstatically, and so piercingly that it set\neveryone\xe2\x80\x99s ear tingling. By that shriek she expressed what the others\nexpressed by all talking at once, and it was so strange that she must\nherself have been ashamed of so wild a cry and everyone else would have\nbeen amazed at it at any other time. \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d himself twisted up the\nhare, threw it neatly and smartly across his horse\xe2\x80\x99s back as if by\nthat gesture he meant to rebuke everybody, and, with an air of not\nwishing to speak to anyone, mounted his bay and rode off. The others all\nfollowed, dispirited and shamefaced, and only much later were they able\nto regain their former affectation of indifference. For a long time they\ncontinued to look at red Rug\xc3\xa1y who, his arched back spattered with\nmud and clanking the ring of his leash, walked along just behind\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d horse with the serene air of a conqueror.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I am like any other dog as long as it\xe2\x80\x99s not a question of\ncoursing. But when it is, then look out!\xe2\x80\x9d his appearance seemed to\nNicholas to be saying.\n\nWhen, much later, \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d rode up to Nicholas and began talking\nto him, he felt flattered that, after what had happened, \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d\ndeigned to speak to him.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VII\n\nToward evening Il\xc3\xa1gin took leave of Nicholas, who found that they were\nso far from home that he accepted \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d offer that the hunting\nparty should spend the night in his little village of Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if you put up at my house that will be better still. That\xe2\x80\x99s it,\ncome on!\xe2\x80\x9d said \xe2\x80\x9cUncle.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cYou see it\xe2\x80\x99s damp weather, and you\ncould rest, and the little countess could be driven home in a trap.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d offer was accepted. A huntsman was sent to Otr\xc3\xa1dnoe for\na trap, while Nicholas rode with Nat\xc3\xa1sha and P\xc3\xa9tya to \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d\nhouse.\n\nSome five male domestic serfs, big and little, rushed out to the front\nporch to meet their master. A score of women serfs, old and young, as\nwell as children, popped out from the back entrance to have a look at\nthe hunters who were arriving. The presence of Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x94a woman, a\nlady, and on horseback\xe2\x80\x94raised the curiosity of the serfs to such a\ndegree that many of them came up to her, stared her in the face, and\nunabashed by her presence made remarks about her as though she were some\nprodigy on show and not a human being able to hear or understand what\nwas said about her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAr\xc3\xadnka! Look, she sits sideways! There she sits and her skirt\ndangles.... See, she\xe2\x80\x99s got a little hunting horn!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGoodness gracious! See her knife?...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t she a Tartar!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is it you didn\xe2\x80\x99t go head over heels?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the boldest of\nall, addressing Nat\xc3\xa1sha directly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d dismounted at the porch of his little wooden house which\nstood in the midst of an overgrown garden and, after a glance at his\nretainers, shouted authoritatively that the superfluous ones should take\nthemselves off and that all necessary preparations should be made to\nreceive the guests and the visitors.\n\nThe serfs all dispersed. \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d lifted Nat\xc3\xa1sha off her horse and\ntaking her hand led her up the rickety wooden steps of the porch. The\nhouse, with its bare, unplastered log walls, was not overclean\xe2\x80\x94it\ndid not seem that those living in it aimed at keeping it spotless\xe2\x80\x94but\nneither was it noticeably neglected. In the entry there was a smell of\nfresh apples, and wolf and fox skins hung about.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d led the visitors through the anteroom into a small hall with\na folding table and red chairs, then into the drawing room with a round\nbirchwood table and a sofa, and finally into his private room where\nthere was a tattered sofa, a worn carpet, and portraits of Suv\xc3\xb3rov, of\nthe host\xe2\x80\x99s father and mother, and of himself in military uniform. The\nstudy smelt strongly of tobacco and dogs. \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d asked his visitors\nto sit down and make themselves at home, and then went out of the room.\nRug\xc3\xa1y, his back still muddy, came into the room and lay down on the\nsofa, cleaning himself with his tongue and teeth. Leading from the study\nwas a passage in which a partition with ragged curtains could be\nseen. From behind this came women\xe2\x80\x99s laughter and whispers. Nat\xc3\xa1sha,\nNicholas, and P\xc3\xa9tya took off their wraps and sat down on the sofa.\nP\xc3\xa9tya, leaning on his elbow, fell asleep at once. Nat\xc3\xa1sha and Nicholas\nwere silent. Their faces glowed, they were hungry and very cheerful.\nThey looked at one another (now that the hunt was over and they were in\nthe house, Nicholas no longer considered it necessary to show his manly\nsuperiority over his sister), Nat\xc3\xa1sha gave him a wink, and neither\nrefrained long from bursting into a peal of ringing laughter even before\nthey had a pretext ready to account for it.\n\nAfter a while \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d came in, in a Cossack coat, blue trousers, and\nsmall top boots. And Nat\xc3\xa1sha felt that this costume, the very one she\nhad regarded with surprise and amusement at Otr\xc3\xa1dnoe, was just the\nright thing and not at all worse than a swallow-tail or frock coat.\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d too was in high spirits and far from being offended by the\nbrother\xe2\x80\x99s and sister\xe2\x80\x99s laughter (it could never enter his head that\nthey might be laughing at his way of life) he himself joined in the\nmerriment.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right, young countess, that\xe2\x80\x99s it, come on! I never saw\nanyone like her!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, offering Nicholas a pipe with a long stem\nand, with a practiced motion of three fingers, taking down another that\nhad been cut short. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s ridden all day like a man, and is as\nfresh as ever!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nSoon after \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d reappearance the door was opened, evidently\nfrom the sound by a barefooted girl, and a stout, rosy, good-looking\nwoman of about forty, with a double chin and full red lips, entered\ncarrying a large loaded tray. With hospitable dignity and cordiality in\nher glance and in every motion, she looked at the visitors and, with\na pleasant smile, bowed respectfully. In spite of her exceptional\nstoutness, which caused her to protrude her chest and stomach and throw\nback her head, this woman (who was \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d housekeeper) trod\nvery lightly. She went to the table, set down the tray, and with her\nplump white hands deftly took from it the bottles and various hors\nd\xe2\x80\x99oeuvres and dishes and arranged them on the table. When she had\nfinished, she stepped aside and stopped at the door with a smile on her\nface. \xe2\x80\x9cHere I am. I am she! Now do you understand \xe2\x80\x98Uncle\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d her\nexpression said to Rost\xc3\xb3v. How could one help understanding? Not only\nNicholas, but even Nat\xc3\xa1sha understood the meaning of his puckered brow\nand the happy complacent smile that slightly puckered his lips when\nAn\xc3\xadsya F\xc3\xabdorovna entered. On the tray was a bottle of herb wine,\ndifferent kinds of vodka, pickled mushrooms, rye cakes made with\nbuttermilk, honey in the comb, still mead and sparkling mead, apples,\nnuts (raw and roasted), and nut-and-honey sweets. Afterwards she brought\na freshly roasted chicken, ham, preserves made with honey, and preserves\nmade with sugar.\n\nAll this was the fruit of An\xc3\xadsya F\xc3\xabdorovna\xe2\x80\x99s housekeeping, gathered\nand prepared by her. The smell and taste of it all had a smack\nof An\xc3\xadsya F\xc3\xabdorovna herself: a savor of juiciness, cleanliness,\nwhiteness, and pleasant smiles.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake this, little Lady-Countess!\xe2\x80\x9d she kept saying, as she offered\nNat\xc3\xa1sha first one thing and then another.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha ate of everything and thought she had never seen or eaten such\nbuttermilk cakes, such aromatic jam, such honey-and-nut sweets, or such\na chicken anywhere. An\xc3\xadsya F\xc3\xabdorovna left the room.\n\nAfter supper, over their cherry brandy, Rost\xc3\xb3v and \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d talked\nof past and future hunts, of Rug\xc3\xa1y and Il\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x99s dogs, while Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nsat upright on the sofa and listened with sparkling eyes. She tried\nseveral times to wake P\xc3\xa9tya that he might eat something, but he\nonly muttered incoherent words without waking up. Nat\xc3\xa1sha felt so\nlighthearted and happy in these novel surroundings that she only feared\nthe trap would come for her too soon. After a casual pause, such as\noften occurs when receiving friends for the first time in one\xe2\x80\x99s own\nhouse, \xe2\x80\x9cUncle,\xe2\x80\x9d answering a thought that was in his visitors\xe2\x80\x99\nminds, said:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis, you see, is how I am finishing my days... Death will come.\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s it, come on! Nothing will remain. Then why harm anyone?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d face was very significant and even handsome as he said\nthis. Involuntarily Rost\xc3\xb3v recalled all the good he had heard about\nhim from his father and the neighbors. Throughout the whole province\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d had the reputation of being the most honorable and\ndisinterested of cranks. They called him in to decide family disputes,\nchose him as executor, confided secrets to him, elected him to be a\njustice and to other posts; but he always persistently refused public\nappointments, passing the autumn and spring in the fields on his bay\ngelding, sitting at home in winter, and lying in his overgrown garden in\nsummer.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you enter the service, Uncle?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did once, but gave it up. I am not fit for it. That\xe2\x80\x99s it, come\non! I can\xe2\x80\x99t make head or tail of it. That\xe2\x80\x99s for you\xe2\x80\x94I haven\xe2\x80\x99t\nbrains enough. Now, hunting is another matter\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s it, come on!\nOpen the door, there!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy have you shut it?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe door at the end of the passage led to the huntsmen\xe2\x80\x99s room, as they\ncalled the room for the hunt servants.\n\nThere was a rapid patter of bare feet, and an unseen hand opened the\ndoor into the huntsmen\xe2\x80\x99s room, from which came the clear sounds of a\nbalal\xc3\xa1yka on which someone, who was evidently a master of the art, was\nplaying. Nat\xc3\xa1sha had been listening to those strains for some time and\nnow went out into the passage to hear better.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s M\xc3\xadtka, my coachman.... I have got him a good balal\xc3\xa1yka.\nI\xe2\x80\x99m fond of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said \xe2\x80\x9cUncle.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIt was the custom for M\xc3\xadtka to play the balal\xc3\xa1yka in the huntsmen\xe2\x80\x99s\nroom when \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d returned from the chase. \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d was fond of\nsuch music.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow good! Really very good!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas with some unintentional\nsuperciliousness, as if ashamed to confess that the sounds pleased him\nvery much.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good?\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha reproachfully, noticing her brother\xe2\x80\x99s\ntone. \xe2\x80\x9cNot \xe2\x80\x98very good\xe2\x80\x99--it\xe2\x80\x99s simply delicious!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nJust as \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d pickled mushrooms, honey, and cherry brandy had\nseemed to her the best in the world, so also that song, at that moment,\nseemed to her the acme of musical delight.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMore, please, more!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nat\xc3\xa1sha at the door as soon as the\nbalal\xc3\xa1yka ceased. M\xc3\xadtka tuned up afresh, and recommenced thrumming\nthe balal\xc3\xa1yka to the air of My Lady, with trills and variations.\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d sat listening, slightly smiling, with his head on one side.\nThe air was repeated a hundred times. The balal\xc3\xa1yka was retuned several\ntimes and the same notes were thrummed again, but the listeners did\nnot grow weary of it and wished to hear it again and again. An\xc3\xadsya\nF\xc3\xabdorovna came in and leaned her portly person against the doorpost.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou like listening?\xe2\x80\x9d she said to Nat\xc3\xa1sha, with a smile extremely\nlike \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a good player of ours,\xe2\x80\x9d she added.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t play that part right!\xe2\x80\x9d said \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d suddenly, with\nan energetic gesture. \xe2\x80\x9cHere he ought to burst out\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s it, come\non!\xe2\x80\x94ought to burst out.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you play then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d did not answer, but smiled.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn\xc3\xadsya, go and see if the strings of my guitar are all right. I\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t touched it for a long time. That\xe2\x80\x99s it\xe2\x80\x94come on! I\xe2\x80\x99ve\ngiven it up.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAn\xc3\xadsya F\xc3\xabdorovna, with her light step, willingly went to fulfill her\nerrand and brought back the guitar.\n\nWithout looking at anyone, \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d blew the dust off it and, tapping\nthe case with his bony fingers, tuned the guitar and settled himself in\nhis armchair. He took the guitar a little above the fingerboard, arching\nhis left elbow with a somewhat theatrical gesture, and, with a wink at\nAn\xc3\xadsya F\xc3\xabdorovna, struck a single chord, pure and sonorous, and then\nquietly, smoothly, and confidently began playing in very slow time, not\nMy Lady, but the well-known song: Came a maiden down the street. The\ntune, played with precision and in exact time, began to thrill in the\nhearts of Nicholas and Nat\xc3\xa1sha, arousing in them the same kind of\nsober mirth as radiated from An\xc3\xadsya F\xc3\xabdorovna\xe2\x80\x99s whole being. An\xc3\xadsya\nF\xc3\xabdorovna flushed, and drawing her kerchief over her face went laughing\nout of the room. \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d continued to play correctly, carefully,\nwith energetic firmness, looking with a changed and inspired expression\nat the spot where An\xc3\xadsya F\xc3\xabdorovna had just stood. Something seemed to\nbe laughing a little on one side of his face under his gray mustaches,\nespecially as the song grew brisker and the time quicker and when, here\nand there, as he ran his fingers over the strings, something seemed to\nsnap.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLovely, lovely! Go on, Uncle, go on!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Nat\xc3\xa1sha as soon as\nhe had finished. She jumped up and hugged and kissed him. \xe2\x80\x9cNicholas,\nNicholas!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, turning to her brother, as if asking him: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\nis it moves me so?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNicholas too was greatly pleased by \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d playing, and\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d played the piece over again. An\xc3\xadsya F\xc3\xabdorovna\xe2\x80\x99s smiling\nface reappeared in the doorway and behind hers other faces...\n\n    Fetching water clear and sweet,\n    Stop, dear maiden, I entreat\xe2\x80\x94\n\nplayed \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d once more, running his fingers skillfully over the\nstrings, and then he stopped short and jerked his shoulders.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, Uncle dear,\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha wailed in an imploring tone as if her\nlife depended on it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d rose, and it was as if there were two men in him: one of\nthem smiled seriously at the merry fellow, while the merry fellow struck\na na\xc3\xafve and precise attitude preparatory to a folk dance.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow then, niece!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, waving to Nat\xc3\xa1sha the hand that\nhad just struck a chord.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha threw off the shawl from her shoulders, ran forward to face\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle,\xe2\x80\x9d and setting her arms akimbo also made a motion with her\nshoulders and struck an attitude.\n\nWhere, how, and when had this young countess, educated by an \xc3\xa9migr\xc3\xa9e\nFrench governess, imbibed from the Russian air she breathed that spirit\nand obtained that manner which the pas de ch\xc3\xa2le * would, one would have\nsupposed, long ago have effaced? But the spirit and the movements were\nthose inimitable and unteachable Russian ones that \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d had\nexpected of her. As soon as she had struck her pose, and smiled\ntriumphantly, proudly, and with sly merriment, the fear that had at\nfirst seized Nicholas and the others that she might not do the right\nthing was at an end, and they were already admiring her.\n\n    * The French shawl dance.\n\nShe did the right thing with such precision, such complete precision,\nthat An\xc3\xadsya F\xc3\xabdorovna, who had at once handed her the handkerchief she\nneeded for the dance, had tears in her eyes, though she laughed as she\nwatched this slim, graceful countess, reared in silks and velvets and so\ndifferent from herself, who yet was able to understand all that was\nin An\xc3\xadsya and in An\xc3\xadsya\xe2\x80\x99s father and mother and aunt, and in every\nRussian man and woman.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, little countess; that\xe2\x80\x99s it\xe2\x80\x94come on!\xe2\x80\x9d cried \xe2\x80\x9cUncle,\xe2\x80\x9d\nwith a joyous laugh, having finished the dance. \xe2\x80\x9cWell done, niece! Now\na fine young fellow must be found as husband for you. That\xe2\x80\x99s it\xe2\x80\x94come\non!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s chosen already,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas smiling.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh?\xe2\x80\x9d said \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d in surprise, looking inquiringly at Nat\xc3\xa1sha,\nwho nodded her head with a happy smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd such a one!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. But as soon as she had said it a new\ntrain of thoughts and feelings arose in her. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat did Nicholas\xe2\x80\x99\nsmile mean when he said \xe2\x80\x98chosen already\xe2\x80\x99? Is he glad of it or not?\nIt is as if he thought my Bolk\xc3\xb3nski would not approve of or understand\nour gaiety. But he would understand it all. Where is he now?\xe2\x80\x9d she\nthought, and her face suddenly became serious. But this lasted only a\nsecond. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t dare to think about it,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to herself,\nand sat down again smilingly beside \xe2\x80\x9cUncle,\xe2\x80\x9d begging him to play\nsomething more.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d played another song and a valse; then after a pause he\ncleared his throat and sang his favorite hunting song:\n\n    As \xe2\x80\x98twas growing dark last night\n    Fell the snow so soft and light...\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d sang as peasants sing, with full and na\xc3\xafve conviction that\nthe whole meaning of a song lies in the words and that the tune comes\nof itself, and that apart from the words there is no tune, which exists\nonly to give measure to the words. As a result of this the unconsidered\ntune, like the song of a bird, was extraordinarily good. Nat\xc3\xa1sha was in\necstasies over \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d singing. She resolved to give up learning\nthe harp and to play only the guitar. She asked \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d for his\nguitar and at once found the chords of the song.\n\nAfter nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock two traps and three mounted men, who had been sent\nto look for them, arrived to fetch Nat\xc3\xa1sha and P\xc3\xa9tya. The count and\ncountess did not know where they were and were very anxious, said one of\nthe men.\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya was carried out like a log and laid in the larger of the two\ntraps. Nat\xc3\xa1sha and Nicholas got into the other. \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x9d wrapped\nNat\xc3\xa1sha up warmly and took leave of her with quite a new tenderness. He\naccompanied them on foot as far as the bridge that could not be crossed,\nso that they had to go round by the ford, and he sent huntsmen to ride\nin front with lanterns.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-by, dear niece,\xe2\x80\x9d his voice called out of the darkness\xe2\x80\x94not\nthe voice Nat\xc3\xa1sha had known previously, but the one that had sung As\n\xe2\x80\x98twas growing dark last night.\n\nIn the village through which they passed there were red lights and a\ncheerful smell of smoke.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a darling Uncle is!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha, when they had come out\nonto the highroad.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Nicholas. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re not cold?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. I\xe2\x80\x99m quite, quite all right. I feel so comfortable!\xe2\x80\x9d answered\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, almost perplexed by her feelings. They remained silent a long\nwhile. The night was dark and damp. They could not see the horses, but\nonly heard them splashing through the unseen mud.\n\nWhat was passing in that receptive childlike soul that so eagerly caught\nand assimilated all the diverse impressions of life? How did they all\nfind place in her? But she was very happy. As they were nearing home she\nsuddenly struck up the air of As \xe2\x80\x98twas growing dark last night\xe2\x80\x94the\ntune of which she had all the way been trying to get and had at last\ncaught.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGot it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat were you thinking about just now, Nicholas?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired\nNat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\nThey were fond of asking one another that question.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas, trying to remember. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, you see, first I\nthought that Rug\xc3\xa1y, the red hound, was like Uncle, and that if he were\na man he would always keep Uncle near him, if not for his riding, then\nfor his manner. What a good fellow Uncle is! Don\xe2\x80\x99t you think so?...\nWell, and you?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? Wait a bit, wait.... Yes, first I thought that we are driving\nalong and imagining that we are going home, but that heaven knows\nwhere we are really going in the darkness, and that we shall arrive and\nsuddenly find that we are not in Otr\xc3\xa1dnoe, but in Fairyland. And then I\nthought... No, nothing else.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know, I expect you thought of him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas, smiling as\nNat\xc3\xa1sha knew by the sound of his voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha, though she had in reality been thinking about\nPrince Andrew at the same time as of the rest, and of how he would\nhave liked \xe2\x80\x9cUncle.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cAnd then I was saying to myself all the way,\n\xe2\x80\x98How well An\xc3\xadsya carried herself, how well!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d And Nicholas heard\nher spontaneous, happy, ringing laughter. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you know,\xe2\x80\x9d she\nsuddenly said, \xe2\x80\x9cI know that I shall never again be as happy and\ntranquil as I am now.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cRubbish, nonsense, humbug!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Nicholas, and he thought:\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow charming this Nat\xc3\xa1sha of mine is! I have no other friend like\nher and never shall have. Why should she marry? We might always drive\nabout together!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a darling this Nicholas of mine is!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, there are still lights in the drawing room!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, pointing\nto the windows of the house that gleamed invitingly in the moist velvety\ndarkness of the night.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VIII\n\nCount Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v had resigned the position of Marshal of the Nobility\nbecause it involved him in too much expense, but still his affairs\ndid not improve. Nat\xc3\xa1sha and Nicholas often noticed their parents\nconferring together anxiously and privately and heard suggestions of\nselling the fine ancestral Rost\xc3\xb3v house and estate near Moscow. It was\nnot necessary to entertain so freely as when the count had been Marshal,\nand life at Otr\xc3\xa1dnoe was quieter than in former years, but still the\nenormous house and its lodges were full of people and more than twenty\nsat down to table every day. These were all their own people who had\nsettled down in the house almost as members of the family, or persons\nwho were, it seemed, obliged to live in the count\xe2\x80\x99s house. Such were\nDimmler the musician and his wife, Vogel the dancing master and his\nfamily, Bel\xc3\xb3va, an old maiden lady, an inmate of the house, and many\nothers such as P\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x99s tutors, the girls\xe2\x80\x99 former governess, and\nother people who simply found it preferable and more advantageous to\nlive in the count\xe2\x80\x99s house than at home. They had not as many visitors\nas before, but the old habits of life without which the count and\ncountess could not conceive of existence remained unchanged. There was\nstill the hunting establishment which Nicholas had even enlarged, the\nsame fifty horses and fifteen grooms in the stables, the same expensive\npresents and dinner parties to the whole district on name days; there\nwere still the count\xe2\x80\x99s games of whist and boston, at which\xe2\x80\x94spreading\nout his cards so that everybody could see them\xe2\x80\x94he let himself be\nplundered of hundreds of rubles every day by his neighbors, who looked\nupon an opportunity to play a rubber with Count Rost\xc3\xb3v as a most\nprofitable source of income.\n\nThe count moved in his affairs as in a huge net, trying not to believe\nthat he was entangled but becoming more and more so at every step, and\nfeeling too feeble to break the meshes or to set to work carefully and\npatiently to disentangle them. The countess, with her loving heart, felt\nthat her children were being ruined, that it was not the count\xe2\x80\x99s fault\nfor he could not help being what he was\xe2\x80\x94that (though he tried to\nhide it) he himself suffered from the consciousness of his own and\nhis children\xe2\x80\x99s ruin, and she tried to find means of remedying the\nposition. From her feminine point of view she could see only one\nsolution, namely, for Nicholas to marry a rich heiress. She felt this to\nbe their last hope and that if Nicholas refused the match she had found\nfor him, she would have to abandon the hope of ever getting matters\nright. This match was with Julie Kar\xc3\xa1gina, the daughter of excellent\nand virtuous parents, a girl the Rost\xc3\xb3vs had known from childhood, and\nwho had now become a wealthy heiress through the death of the last of\nher brothers.\n\nThe countess had written direct to Julie\xe2\x80\x99s mother in Moscow suggesting\na marriage between their children and had received a favorable answer\nfrom her. Kar\xc3\xa1gina had replied that for her part she was agreeable, and\neverything depend on her daughter\xe2\x80\x99s inclination. She invited Nicholas\nto come to Moscow.\n\nSeveral times the countess, with tears in her eyes, told her son that\nnow both her daughters were settled, her only wish was to see him\nmarried. She said she could lie down in her grave peacefully if that\nwere accomplished. Then she told him that she knew of a splendid girl\nand tried to discover what he thought about marriage.\n\nAt other times she praised Julie to him and advised him to go to\nMoscow during the holidays to amuse himself. Nicholas guessed what his\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s remarks were leading to and during one of these conversations\ninduced her to speak quite frankly. She told him that her only hope\nof getting their affairs disentangled now lay in his marrying Julie\nKar\xc3\xa1gina.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Mamma, suppose I loved a girl who has no fortune, would\nyou expect me to sacrifice my feelings and my honor for the sake of\nmoney?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked his mother, not realizing the cruelty of his question\nand only wishing to show his noble-mindedness.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you have not understood me,\xe2\x80\x9d said his mother, not knowing how\nto justify herself. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have not understood me, Nik\xc3\xb3lenka. It is\nyour happiness I wish for,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, feeling that she was telling an\nuntruth and was becoming entangled. She began to cry.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, don\xe2\x80\x99t cry! Only tell me that you wish it, and you know I\nwill give my life, anything, to put you at ease,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas. \xe2\x80\x9cI\nwould sacrifice anything for you\xe2\x80\x94even my feelings.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBut the countess did not want the question put like that: she did not\nwant a sacrifice from her son, she herself wished to make a sacrifice\nfor him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you have not understood me, don\xe2\x80\x99t let us talk about it,\xe2\x80\x9d she\nreplied, wiping away her tears.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaybe I do love a poor girl,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cAm I to\nsacrifice my feelings and my honor for money? I wonder how Mamma could\nspeak so to me. Because S\xc3\xb3nya is poor I must not love her,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nthought, \xe2\x80\x9cmust not respond to her faithful, devoted love? Yet I should\ncertainly be happier with her than with some doll-like Julie. I can\nalways sacrifice my feelings for my family\xe2\x80\x99s welfare,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to\nhimself, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I can\xe2\x80\x99t coerce my feelings. If I love S\xc3\xb3nya, that\nfeeling is for me stronger and higher than all else.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNicholas did not go to Moscow, and the countess did not renew the\nconversation with him about marriage. She saw with sorrow, and sometimes\nwith exasperation, symptoms of a growing attachment between her son and\nthe portionless S\xc3\xb3nya. Though she blamed herself for it, she could\nnot refrain from grumbling at and worrying S\xc3\xb3nya, often pulling her up\nwithout reason, addressing her stiffly as \xe2\x80\x9cmy dear,\xe2\x80\x9d and using the\nformal \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x9d instead of the intimate \xe2\x80\x9cthou\xe2\x80\x9d in speaking to her.\nThe kindhearted countess was the more vexed with S\xc3\xb3nya because that\npoor, dark-eyed niece of hers was so meek, so kind, so devotedly\ngrateful to her benefactors, and so faithfully, unchangingly, and\nunselfishly in love with Nicholas, that there were no grounds for\nfinding fault with her.\n\nNicholas was spending the last of his leave at home. A fourth letter had\ncome from Prince Andrew, from Rome, in which he wrote that he would have\nbeen on his way back to Russia long ago had not his wound unexpectedly\nreopened in the warm climate, which obliged him to defer his return till\nthe beginning of the new year. Nat\xc3\xa1sha was still as much in love with\nher betrothed, found the same comfort in that love, and was still as\nready to throw herself into all the pleasures of life as before; but at\nthe end of the fourth month of their separation she began to have fits\nof depression which she could not master. She felt sorry for herself:\nsorry that she was being wasted all this time and of no use to\nanyone\xe2\x80\x94while she felt herself so capable of loving and being loved.\n\nThings were not cheerful in the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 home.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IX\n\nChristmas came and except for the ceremonial Mass, the solemn and\nwearisome Christmas congratulations from neighbors and servants, and the\nnew dresses everyone put on, there were no special festivities, though\nthe calm frost of twenty degrees R\xc3\xa9aumur, the dazzling sunshine by day,\nand the starlight of the winter nights seemed to call for some special\ncelebration of the season.\n\nOn the third day of Christmas week, after the midday dinner, all the\ninmates of the house dispersed to various rooms. It was the dullest time\nof the day. Nicholas, who had been visiting some neighbors that morning,\nwas asleep on the sitting-room sofa. The old count was resting in his\nstudy. S\xc3\xb3nya sat in the drawing room at the round table, copying a\ndesign for embroidery. The countess was playing patience. Nast\xc3\xa1sya\nIv\xc3\xa1novna the buffoon sat with a sad face at the window with two old\nladies. Nat\xc3\xa1sha came into the room, went up to S\xc3\xb3nya, glanced at\nwhat she was doing, and then went up to her mother and stood without\nspeaking.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you wandering about like an outcast?\xe2\x80\x9d asked her mother.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHim... I want him... now, this minute! I want him!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha,\nwith glittering eyes and no sign of a smile.\n\nThe countess lifted her head and looked attentively at her daughter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t look at me, Mamma! Don\xe2\x80\x99t look; I shall cry directly.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit down with me a little,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, I want him. Why should I be wasted like this, Mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHer voice broke, tears gushed from her eyes, and she turned quickly to\nhide them and left the room.\n\nShe passed into the sitting room, stood there thinking awhile, and then\nwent into the maids\xe2\x80\x99 room. There an old maidservant was grumbling at\na young girl who stood panting, having just run in through the cold from\nthe serfs\xe2\x80\x99 quarters.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop playing\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s a time for everything,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old\nwoman.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet her alone, Kondr\xc3\xa1tevna,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cGo, Mavr\xc3\xbashka,\ngo.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHaving released Mavr\xc3\xbashka, Nat\xc3\xa1sha crossed the dancing hall and went\nto the vestibule. There an old footman and two young ones were playing\ncards. They broke off and rose as she entered.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can I do with them?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Nik\xc3\xadta, please go... where can I send him?... Yes, go to the\nyard and fetch a fowl, please, a cock, and you, Misha, bring me some\noats.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust a few oats?\xe2\x80\x9d said Misha, cheerfully and readily.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, go quickly,\xe2\x80\x9d the old man urged him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, Theodore, get me a piece of chalk.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nOn her way past the butler\xe2\x80\x99s pantry she told them to set a samovar,\nthough it was not at all the time for tea.\n\nF\xc3\xb3ka, the butler, was the most ill-tempered person in the house.\nNat\xc3\xa1sha liked to test her power over him. He distrusted the order and\nasked whether the samovar was really wanted.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh dear, what a young lady!\xe2\x80\x9d said F\xc3\xb3ka, pretending to frown at\nNat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\nNo one in the house sent people about or gave them as much trouble as\nNat\xc3\xa1sha did. She could not see people unconcernedly, but had to send\nthem on some errand. She seemed to be trying whether any of them would\nget angry or sulky with her; but the serfs fulfilled no one\xe2\x80\x99s orders\nso readily as they did hers. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat can I do, where can I go?\xe2\x80\x9d\nthought she, as she went slowly along the passage.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNast\xc3\xa1sya Iv\xc3\xa1novna, what sort of children shall I have?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked\nthe buffoon, who was coming toward her in a woman\xe2\x80\x99s jacket.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, fleas, crickets, grasshoppers,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the buffoon.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Lord, O Lord, it\xe2\x80\x99s always the same! Oh, where am I to go? What\nam I to do with myself?\xe2\x80\x9d And tapping with her heels, she ran quickly\nupstairs to see Vogel and his wife who lived on the upper story.\n\nTwo governesses were sitting with the Vogels at a table, on which were\nplates of raisins, walnuts, and almonds. The governesses were discussing\nwhether it was cheaper to live in Moscow or Odessa. Nat\xc3\xa1sha sat down,\nlistened to their talk with a serious and thoughtful air, and then got\nup again.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe island of Madagascar,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cMa-da-gas-car,\xe2\x80\x9d she\nrepeated, articulating each syllable distinctly, and, not replying to\nMadame Schoss who asked her what she was saying, she went out of the\nroom.\n\nHer brother P\xc3\xa9tya was upstairs too; with the man in attendance on him\nhe was preparing fireworks to let off that night.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cP\xc3\xa9tya! P\xc3\xa9tya!\xe2\x80\x9d she called to him. \xe2\x80\x9cCarry me downstairs.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya ran up and offered her his back. She jumped on it, putting her\narms round his neck, and he pranced along with her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, don\xe2\x80\x99t... the island of Madagascar!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, and jumping off\nhis back she went downstairs.\n\nHaving as it were reviewed her kingdom, tested her power, and made\nsure that everyone was submissive, but that all the same it was dull,\nNat\xc3\xa1sha betook herself to the ballroom, picked up her guitar, sat down\nin a dark corner behind a bookcase, and began to run her fingers over\nthe strings in the bass, picking out a passage she recalled from an\nopera she had heard in Petersburg with Prince Andrew. What she drew from\nthe guitar would have had no meaning for other listeners, but in her\nimagination a whole series of reminiscences arose from those sounds.\nShe sat behind the bookcase with her eyes fixed on a streak of light\nescaping from the pantry door and listened to herself and pondered. She\nwas in a mood for brooding on the past.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya passed to the pantry with a glass in her hand. Nat\xc3\xa1sha glanced\nat her and at the crack in the pantry door, and it seemed to her that\nshe remembered the light falling through that crack once before and\nS\xc3\xb3nya passing with a glass in her hand. \xe2\x80\x9cYes it was exactly the\nsame,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xb3nya, what is this?\xe2\x80\x9d she cried, twanging a thick string.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you are there!\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya with a start, and came near and\nlistened. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know. A storm?\xe2\x80\x9d she ventured timidly, afraid of\nbeing wrong.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere! That\xe2\x80\x99s just how she started and just how she came up smiling\ntimidly when all this happened before,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nat\xc3\xa1sha, \xe2\x80\x9cand in\njust the same way I thought there was something lacking in her.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it\xe2\x80\x99s the chorus from The Water-Carrier, listen!\xe2\x80\x9d and Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nsang the air of the chorus so that S\xc3\xb3nya should catch it. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere were\nyou going?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo change the water in this glass. I am just finishing the design.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou always find something to do, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where\xe2\x80\x99s Nicholas?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAsleep, I think.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xb3nya, go and wake him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cTell him I want him to\ncome and sing.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe sat awhile, wondering what the meaning of it all having happened\nbefore could be, and without solving this problem, or at all regretting\nnot having done so, she again passed in fancy to the time when she was\nwith him and he was looking at her with a lover\xe2\x80\x99s eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, if only he would come quicker! I am so afraid it will never be!\nAnd, worst of all, I am growing old\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s the thing! There won\xe2\x80\x99t\nthen be in me what there is now. But perhaps he\xe2\x80\x99ll come today, will\ncome immediately. Perhaps he has come and is sitting in the drawing\nroom. Perhaps he came yesterday and I have forgotten it.\xe2\x80\x9d She rose,\nput down the guitar, and went to the drawing room.\n\nAll the domestic circle, tutors, governesses, and guests, were already\nat the tea table. The servants stood round the table\xe2\x80\x94but Prince Andrew\nwas not there and life was going on as before.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, here she is!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old count, when he saw Nat\xc3\xa1sha enter.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sit down by me.\xe2\x80\x9d But Nat\xc3\xa1sha stayed by her mother and\nglanced round as if looking for something.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma!\xe2\x80\x9d she muttered, \xe2\x80\x9cgive him to me, give him, Mamma, quickly,\nquickly!\xe2\x80\x9d and she again had difficulty in repressing her sobs.\n\nShe sat down at the table and listened to the conversation between the\nelders and Nicholas, who had also come to the table. \xe2\x80\x9cMy God, my God!\nThe same faces, the same talk, Papa holding his cup and blowing in the\nsame way!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nat\xc3\xa1sha, feeling with horror a sense of repulsion\nrising up in her for the whole household, because they were always the\nsame.\n\nAfter tea, Nicholas, S\xc3\xb3nya, and Nat\xc3\xa1sha went to the sitting room, to\ntheir favorite corner where their most intimate talks always began.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER X\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes it ever happen to you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha to her brother, when\nthey settled down in the sitting room, \xe2\x80\x9cdoes it ever happen to you to\nfeel as if there were nothing more to come\xe2\x80\x94nothing; that everything\ngood is past? And to feel not exactly dull, but sad?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should think so!\xe2\x80\x9d he replied. \xe2\x80\x9cI have felt like that when\neverything was all right and everyone was cheerful. The thought has come\ninto my mind that I was already tired of it all, and that we must all\ndie. Once in the regiment I had not gone to some merrymaking where there\nwas music... and suddenly I felt so depressed...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, I know, I know, I know!\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha interrupted him. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen\nI was quite little that used to be so with me. Do you remember when\nI was punished once about some plums? You were all dancing, and I sat\nsobbing in the schoolroom? I shall never forget it: I felt sad and sorry\nfor everyone, for myself, and for everyone. And I was innocent\xe2\x80\x94that\nwas the chief thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you remember?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI remember,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Nicholas. \xe2\x80\x9cI remember that I came to you\nafterwards and wanted to comfort you, but do you know, I felt ashamed\nto. We were terribly absurd. I had a funny doll then and wanted to give\nit to you. Do you remember?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you remember,\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha asked with a pensive smile, \xe2\x80\x9chow\nonce, long, long ago, when we were quite little, Uncle called us into\nthe study\xe2\x80\x94that was in the old house\xe2\x80\x94and it was dark\xe2\x80\x94we went in and\nsuddenly there stood...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Negro,\xe2\x80\x9d chimed in Nicholas with a smile of delight. \xe2\x80\x9cOf course\nI remember. Even now I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether there really was a Negro, or\nif we only dreamed it or were told about him.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was gray, you remember, and had white teeth, and stood and looked\nat us....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xb3nya, do you remember?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Nicholas.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, I do remember something too,\xe2\x80\x9d S\xc3\xb3nya answered timidly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know I have asked Papa and Mamma about that Negro,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, \xe2\x80\x9cand they say there was no Negro at all. But you see, you\nremember!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course I do, I remember his teeth as if I had just seen them.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow strange it is! It\xe2\x80\x99s as if it were a dream! I like that.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you remember how we rolled hard-boiled eggs in the ballroom,\nand suddenly two old women began spinning round on the carpet? Was that\nreal or not? Do you remember what fun it was?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and you remember how Papa in his blue overcoat fired a gun in\nthe porch?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nSo they went through their memories, smiling with pleasure: not the sad\nmemories of old age, but poetic, youthful ones\xe2\x80\x94those impressions of\none\xe2\x80\x99s most distant past in which dreams and realities blend\xe2\x80\x94and they\nlaughed with quiet enjoyment.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya, as always, did not quite keep pace with them, though they shared\nthe same reminiscences.\n\nMuch that they remembered had slipped from her mind, and what she\nrecalled did not arouse the same poetic feeling as they experienced. She\nsimply enjoyed their pleasure and tried to fit in with it.\n\nShe only really took part when they recalled S\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s first arrival.\nShe told them how afraid she had been of Nicholas because he had on a\ncorded jacket and her nurse had told her that she, too, would be sewn up\nwith cords.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I remember their telling me that you had been born under a\ncabbage,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha, \xe2\x80\x9cand I remember that I dared not disbelieve\nit then, but knew that it was not true, and I felt so uncomfortable.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nWhile they were talking a maid thrust her head in at the other door of\nthe sitting room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey have brought the cock, Miss,\xe2\x80\x9d she said in a whisper.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt isn\xe2\x80\x99t wanted, P\xc3\xb3lya. Tell them to take it away,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\nNat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\nIn the middle of their talk in the sitting room, Dimmler came in and\nwent up to the harp that stood there in a corner. He took off its cloth\ncovering, and the harp gave out a jarring sound.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Dimmler, please play my favorite nocturne by Field,\xe2\x80\x9d came the\nold countess\xe2\x80\x99 voice from the drawing room.\n\nDimmler struck a chord and, turning to Nat\xc3\xa1sha, Nicholas, and S\xc3\xb3nya,\nremarked: \xe2\x80\x9cHow quiet you young people are!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, we\xe2\x80\x99re philosophizing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha, glancing round for a\nmoment and then continuing the conversation. They were now discussing\ndreams.\n\nDimmler began to play; Nat\xc3\xa1sha went on tiptoe noiselessly to the table,\ntook up a candle, carried it out, and returned, seating herself quietly\nin her former place. It was dark in the room especially where they were\nsitting on the sofa, but through the big windows the silvery light of\nthe full moon fell on the floor. Dimmler had finished the piece but\nstill sat softly running his fingers over the strings, evidently\nuncertain whether to stop or to play something else.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha in a whisper, moving closer to Nicholas\nand S\xc3\xb3nya, \xe2\x80\x9cthat when one goes on and on recalling memories, one at\nlast begins to remember what happened before one was in the world....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is metempsychosis,\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya, who had always learned well,\nand remembered everything. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Egyptians believed that our souls have\nlived in animals, and will go back into animals again.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe we ever were in animals,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha,\nstill in a whisper though the music had ceased. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I am certain that\nwe were angels somewhere there, and have been here, and that is why we\nremember....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I join you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Dimmler who had come up quietly, and he sat\ndown by them.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we have been angels, why have we fallen lower?\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas.\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, that can\xe2\x80\x99t be!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot lower, who said we were lower?... How do I know what I\nwas before?\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha rejoined with conviction. \xe2\x80\x9cThe soul is\nimmortal\xe2\x80\x94well then, if I shall always live I must have lived before,\nlived for a whole eternity.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but it is hard for us to imagine eternity,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Dimmler,\nwho had joined the young folk with a mildly condescending smile but now\nspoke as quietly and seriously as they.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy is it hard to imagine eternity?\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is now\ntoday, and it will be tomorrow, and always; and there was yesterday, and\nthe day before....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1sha! Now it\xe2\x80\x99s your turn. Sing me something,\xe2\x80\x9d they heard the\ncountess say. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you sitting there like conspirators?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, I don\xe2\x80\x99t at all want to,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Nat\xc3\xa1sha, but all the\nsame she rose.\n\nNone of them, not even the middle-aged Dimmler, wanted to break off\ntheir conversation and quit that corner in the sitting room, but\nNat\xc3\xa1sha got up and Nicholas sat down at the clavichord. Standing\nas usual in the middle of the hall and choosing the place where the\nresonance was best, Nat\xc3\xa1sha began to sing her mother\xe2\x80\x99s favorite song.\n\nShe had said she did not want to sing, but it was long since she had\nsung, and long before she again sang, as she did that evening. The\ncount, from his study where he was talking to M\xc3\xadtenka, heard her and,\nlike a schoolboy in a hurry to run out to play, blundered in his talk\nwhile giving orders to the steward, and at last stopped, while M\xc3\xadtenka\nstood in front of him also listening and smiling. Nicholas did not take\nhis eyes off his sister and drew breath in time with her. S\xc3\xb3nya, as she\nlistened, thought of the immense difference there was between herself\nand her friend, and how impossible it was for her to be anything like as\nbewitching as her cousin. The old countess sat with a blissful yet sad\nsmile and with tears in her eyes, occasionally shaking her head. She\nthought of Nat\xc3\xa1sha and of her own youth, and of how there was something\nunnatural and dreadful in this impending marriage of Nat\xc3\xa1sha and Prince\nAndrew.\n\nDimmler, who had seated himself beside the countess, listened with\nclosed eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Countess,\xe2\x80\x9d he said at last, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s a European talent, she\nhas nothing to learn\xe2\x80\x94what softness, tenderness, and strength....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, how afraid I am for her, how afraid I am!\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess,\nnot realizing to whom she was speaking. Her maternal instinct told her\nthat Nat\xc3\xa1sha had too much of something, and that because of this\nshe would not be happy. Before Nat\xc3\xa1sha had finished singing,\nfourteen-year-old P\xc3\xa9tya rushed in delightedly, to say that some mummers\nhad arrived.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha stopped abruptly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIdiot!\xe2\x80\x9d she screamed at her brother and, running to a chair, threw\nherself on it, sobbing so violently that she could not stop for a long\ntime.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s nothing, Mamma, really it\xe2\x80\x99s nothing; only P\xc3\xa9tya startled\nme,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, trying to smile, but her tears still flowed and sobs\nstill choked her.\n\nThe mummers (some of the house serfs) dressed up as bears, Turks,\ninnkeepers, and ladies\xe2\x80\x94frightening and funny\xe2\x80\x94bringing in with\nthem the cold from outside and a feeling of gaiety, crowded, at first\ntimidly, into the anteroom, then hiding behind one another they pushed\ninto the ballroom where, shyly at first and then more and more merrily\nand heartily, they started singing, dancing, and playing Christmas\ngames. The countess, when she had identified them and laughed at their\ncostumes, went into the drawing room. The count sat in the ballroom,\nsmiling radiantly and applauding the players. The young people had\ndisappeared.\n\nHalf an hour later there appeared among the other mummers in the\nballroom an old lady in a hooped skirt\xe2\x80\x94this was Nicholas. A Turkish\ngirl was P\xc3\xa9tya. A clown was Dimmler. An hussar was Nat\xc3\xa1sha, and a\nCircassian was S\xc3\xb3nya with burnt-cork mustache and eyebrows.\n\nAfter the condescending surprise, nonrecognition, and praise, from those\nwho were not themselves dressed up, the young people decided that their\ncostumes were so good that they ought to be shown elsewhere.\n\nNicholas, who, as the roads were in splendid condition, wanted to take\nthem all for a drive in his troyka, proposed to take with them about a\ndozen of the serf mummers and drive to \xe2\x80\x9cUncle\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, why disturb the old fellow?\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess. \xe2\x80\x9cBesides,\nyou wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have room to turn round there. If you must go, go to the\nMelyuk\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nMelyuk\xc3\xb3va was a widow, who, with her family and their tutors and\ngovernesses, lived three miles from the Rost\xc3\xb3vs.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d chimed in the old count, thoroughly\naroused. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll dress up at once and go with them. I\xe2\x80\x99ll make\nPashette open her eyes.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBut the countess would not agree to his going; he had had a bad leg all\nthese last days. It was decided that the count must not go, but that if\nLouisa Iv\xc3\xa1novna (Madame Schoss) would go with them, the young ladies\nmight go to the Melyuk\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99, S\xc3\xb3nya, generally so timid and shy, more\nurgently than anyone begging Louisa Iv\xc3\xa1novna not to refuse.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s costume was the best of all. Her mustache and eyebrows were\nextraordinarily becoming. Everyone told her she looked very handsome,\nand she was in a spirited and energetic mood unusual with her. Some\ninner voice told her that now or never her fate would be decided, and\nin her male attire she seemed quite a different person. Louisa Iv\xc3\xa1novna\nconsented to go, and in half an hour four troyka sleighs with large and\nsmall bells, their runners squeaking and whistling over the frozen snow,\ndrove up to the porch.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha was foremost in setting a merry holiday tone, which, passing\nfrom one to another, grew stronger and reached its climax when they all\ncame out into the frost and got into the sleighs, talking, calling to\none another, laughing, and shouting.\n\nTwo of the troykas were the usual household sleighs, the third was the\nold count\xe2\x80\x99s with a trotter from the Orl\xc3\xb3v stud as shaft horse,\nthe fourth was Nicholas\xe2\x80\x99 own with a short shaggy black shaft horse.\nNicholas, in his old lady\xe2\x80\x99s dress over which he had belted his hussar\novercoat, stood in the middle of the sleigh, reins in hand.\n\nIt was so light that he could see the moonlight reflected from the metal\nharness disks and from the eyes of the horses, who looked round in alarm\nat the noisy party under the shadow of the porch roof.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, S\xc3\xb3nya, Madame Schoss, and two maids got into Nicholas\xe2\x80\x99\nsleigh; Dimmler, his wife, and P\xc3\xa9tya, into the old count\xe2\x80\x99s, and the\nrest of the mummers seated themselves in the other two sleighs.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou go ahead, Zakh\xc3\xa1r!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Nicholas to his father\xe2\x80\x99s\ncoachman, wishing for a chance to race past him.\n\nThe old count\xe2\x80\x99s troyka, with Dimmler and his party, started forward,\nsqueaking on its runners as though freezing to the snow, its deep-toned\nbell clanging. The side horses, pressing against the shafts of the\nmiddle horse, sank in the snow, which was dry and glittered like sugar,\nand threw it up.\n\nNicholas set off, following the first sleigh; behind him the others\nmoved noisily, their runners squeaking. At first they drove at a steady\ntrot along the narrow road. While they drove past the garden the shadows\nof the bare trees often fell across the road and hid the brilliant\nmoonlight, but as soon as they were past the fence, the snowy plain\nbathed in moonlight and motionless spread out before them glittering\nlike diamonds and dappled with bluish shadows. Bang, bang! went the\nfirst sleigh over a cradle hole in the snow of the road, and each of\nthe other sleighs jolted in the same way, and rudely breaking the\nfrost-bound stillness, the troykas began to speed along the road, one\nafter the other.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA hare\xe2\x80\x99s track, a lot of tracks!\xe2\x80\x9d rang out Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s voice\nthrough the frost-bound air.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow light it is, Nicholas!\xe2\x80\x9d came S\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s voice.\n\nNicholas glanced round at S\xc3\xb3nya, and bent down to see her face closer.\nQuite a new, sweet face with black eyebrows and mustaches peeped up\nat him from her sable furs\xe2\x80\x94so close and yet so distant\xe2\x80\x94in the\nmoonlight.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat used to be S\xc3\xb3nya,\xe2\x80\x9d thought he, and looked at her closer and\nsmiled.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, Nicholas?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said he and turned again to the horses.\n\nWhen they came out onto the beaten highroad\xe2\x80\x94polished by sleigh runners\nand cut up by rough-shod hoofs, the marks of which were visible in the\nmoonlight\xe2\x80\x94the horses began to tug at the reins of their own accord and\nincreased their pace. The near side horse, arching his head and breaking\ninto a short canter, tugged at his traces. The shaft horse swayed from\nside to side, moving his ears as if asking: \xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t it time to begin\nnow?\xe2\x80\x9d In front, already far ahead the deep bell of the sleigh ringing\nfarther and farther off, the black horses driven by Zakh\xc3\xa1r could be\nclearly seen against the white snow. From that sleigh one could hear the\nshouts, laughter, and voices of the mummers.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGee up, my darlings!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Nicholas, pulling the reins to one\nside and flourishing the whip.\n\nIt was only by the keener wind that met them and the jerks given by the\nside horses who pulled harder\xe2\x80\x94ever increasing their gallop\xe2\x80\x94that\none noticed how fast the troyka was flying. Nicholas looked back. With\nscreams, squeals, and waving of whips that caused even the shaft horses\nto gallop\xe2\x80\x94the other sleighs followed. The shaft horse swung steadily\nbeneath the bow over its head, with no thought of slackening pace and\nready to put on speed when required.\n\nNicholas overtook the first sleigh. They were driving downhill and\ncoming out upon a broad trodden track across a meadow, near a river.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are we?\xe2\x80\x9d thought he. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the Kos\xc3\xb3y meadow, I suppose.\nBut no\xe2\x80\x94this is something new I\xe2\x80\x99ve never seen before. This isn\xe2\x80\x99t\nthe Kos\xc3\xb3y meadow nor the D\xc3\xabmkin hill, and heaven only knows what it\nis! It is something new and enchanted. Well, whatever it may be...\xe2\x80\x9d\nAnd shouting to his horses, he began to pass the first sleigh.\n\nZakh\xc3\xa1r held back his horses and turned his face, which was already\ncovered with hoarfrost to his eyebrows.\n\nNicholas gave the horses the rein, and Zakh\xc3\xa1r, stretching out his arms,\nclucked his tongue and let his horses go.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, look out, master!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried.\n\nFaster still the two troykas flew side by side, and faster moved\nthe feet of the galloping side horses. Nicholas began to draw ahead.\nZakh\xc3\xa1r, while still keeping his arms extended, raised one hand with the\nreins.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo you won\xe2\x80\x99t, master!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted.\n\nNicholas put all his horses to a gallop and passed Zakh\xc3\xa1r. The horses\nshowered the fine dry snow on the faces of those in the sleigh\xe2\x80\x94beside\nthem sounded quick ringing bells and they caught confused glimpses of\nswiftly moving legs and the shadows of the troyka they were passing.\nThe whistling sound of the runners on the snow and the voices of girls\nshrieking were heard from different sides.\n\nAgain checking his horses, Nicholas looked around him. They were still\nsurrounded by the magic plain bathed in moonlight and spangled with\nstars.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cZakh\xc3\xa1r is shouting that I should turn to the left, but why to the\nleft?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nicholas. \xe2\x80\x9cAre we getting to the Melyuk\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99? Is\nthis Melyuk\xc3\xb3vka? Heaven only knows where we are going, and heaven knows\nwhat is happening to us\xe2\x80\x94but it is very strange and pleasant whatever\nit is.\xe2\x80\x9d And he looked round in the sleigh.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook, his mustache and eyelashes are all white!\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the\nstrange, pretty, unfamiliar people\xe2\x80\x94the one with fine eyebrows and\nmustache.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think this used to be Nat\xc3\xa1sha,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nicholas, \xe2\x80\x9cand that\nwas Madame Schoss, but perhaps it\xe2\x80\x99s not, and this Circassian with the\nmustache I don\xe2\x80\x99t know, but I love her.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAren\xe2\x80\x99t you cold?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\n\nThey did not answer but began to laugh. Dimmler from the sleigh behind\nshouted something\xe2\x80\x94probably something funny\xe2\x80\x94but they could not make\nout what he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d some voices answered, laughing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut here was a fairy forest with black moving shadows, and a glitter\nof diamonds and a flight of marble steps and the silver roofs of fairy\nbuildings and the shrill yells of some animals. And if this is really\nMelyuk\xc3\xb3vka, it is still stranger that we drove heaven knows where and\nhave come to Melyuk\xc3\xb3vka,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nicholas.\n\nIt really was Melyuk\xc3\xb3vka, and maids and footmen with merry faces came\nrunning, out to the porch carrying candles.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked someone in the porch.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe mummers from the count\xe2\x80\x99s. I know by the horses,\xe2\x80\x9d replied some\nvoices.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XI\n\nPelag\xc3\xa9ya Dan\xc3\xadlovna Melyuk\xc3\xb3va, a broadly built, energetic woman\nwearing spectacles, sat in the drawing room in a loose dress, surrounded\nby her daughters whom she was trying to keep from feeling dull. They\nwere quietly dropping melted wax into snow and looking at the shadows\nthe wax figures would throw on the wall, when they heard the steps and\nvoices of new arrivals in the vestibule.\n\nHussars, ladies, witches, clowns, and bears, after clearing their\nthroats and wiping the hoarfrost from their faces in the vestibule,\ncame into the ballroom where candles were hurriedly lighted. The\nclown\xe2\x80\x94Dimmler\xe2\x80\x94and the lady\xe2\x80\x94Nicholas\xe2\x80\x94started a dance. Surrounded\nby the screaming children the mummers, covering their faces and\ndisguising their voices, bowed to their hostess and arranged themselves\nabout the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me! there\xe2\x80\x99s no recognizing them! And Nat\xc3\xa1sha! See whom\nshe looks like! She really reminds me of somebody. But Herr\nDimmler\xe2\x80\x94isn\xe2\x80\x99t he good! I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know him! And how he dances. Dear\nme, there\xe2\x80\x99s a Circassian. Really, how becoming it is to dear S\xc3\xb3nya.\nAnd who is that? Well, you have cheered us up! Nik\xc3\xadta and Vanya\xe2\x80\x94clear\naway the tables! And we were sitting so quietly. Ha, ha, ha!... The\nhussar, the hussar! Just like a boy! And the legs!... I can\xe2\x80\x99t look at\nhim...\xe2\x80\x9d different voices were saying.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, the young Melyuk\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 favorite, disappeared with them into\nthe back rooms where a cork and various dressing gowns and male garments\nwere called for and received from the footman by bare girlish arms from\nbehind the door. Ten minutes later, all the young Melyuk\xc3\xb3vs joined the\nmummers.\n\nPelag\xc3\xa9ya Dan\xc3\xadlovna, having given orders to clear the rooms for the\nvisitors and arranged about refreshments for the gentry and the serfs,\nwent about among the mummers without removing her spectacles, peering\ninto their faces with a suppressed smile and failing to recognize any\nof them. It was not merely Dimmler and the Rost\xc3\xb3vs she failed to\nrecognize, she did not even recognize her own daughters, or her late\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s, dressing gowns and uniforms, which they had put on.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who is this?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked her governess, peering into the face of\nher own daughter dressed up as a Kaz\xc3\xa1n-Tartar. \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose it is one\nof the Rost\xc3\xb3vs! Well, Mr. Hussar, and what regiment do you serve in?\xe2\x80\x9d\nshe asked Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cHere, hand some fruit jelly to the Turk!\xe2\x80\x9d\nshe ordered the butler who was handing things round. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s not\nforbidden by his law.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nSometimes, as she looked at the strange but amusing capers cut by the\ndancers, who\xe2\x80\x94having decided once for all that being disguised, no one\nwould recognize them\xe2\x80\x94were not at all shy, Pelag\xc3\xa9ya Dan\xc3\xadlovna hid\nher face in her handkerchief, and her whole stout body shook with\nirrepressible, kindly, elderly laughter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy little S\xc3\xa1sha! Look at S\xc3\xa1sha!\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\n\nAfter Russian country dances and chorus dances, Pelag\xc3\xa9ya Dan\xc3\xadlovna\nmade the serfs and gentry join in one large circle: a ring, a string,\nand a silver ruble were fetched and they all played games together.\n\nIn an hour, all the costumes were crumpled and disordered. The corked\neyebrows and mustaches were smeared over the perspiring, flushed,\nand merry faces. Pelag\xc3\xa9ya Dan\xc3\xadlovna began to recognize the mummers,\nadmired their cleverly contrived costumes, and particularly how they\nsuited the young ladies, and she thanked them all for having entertained\nher so well. The visitors were invited to supper in the drawing room,\nand the serfs had something served to them in the ballroom.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow to tell one\xe2\x80\x99s fortune in the empty bathhouse is frightening!\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid an old maid who lived with the Melyuk\xc3\xb3vs, during supper.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d said the eldest Melyuk\xc3\xb3v girl.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t go, it takes courage....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go,\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell what happened to the young lady!\xe2\x80\x9d said the second Melyuk\xc3\xb3v\ngirl.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d began the old maid, \xe2\x80\x9ca young lady once went out, took a\ncock, laid the table for two, all properly, and sat down. After sitting\na while, she suddenly hears someone coming... a sleigh drives up with\nharness bells; she hears him coming! He comes in, just in the shape of a\nman, like an officer\xe2\x80\x94comes in and sits down to table with her.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! ah!\xe2\x80\x9d screamed Nat\xc3\xa1sha, rolling her eyes with horror.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes? And how... did he speak?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, like a man. Everything quite all right, and he began persuading\nher; and she should have kept him talking till cockcrow, but she got\nfrightened, just got frightened and hid her face in her hands. Then he\ncaught her up. It was lucky the maids ran in just then....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, why frighten them?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pelag\xc3\xa9ya Dan\xc3\xadlovna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, you used to try your fate yourself...\xe2\x80\x9d said her daughter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how does one do it in a barn?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, say you went to the barn now, and listened. It depends on what\nyou hear; hammering and knocking\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s bad; but a sound of shifting\ngrain is good and one sometimes hears that, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, tell us what happened to you in the barn.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPelag\xc3\xa9ya Dan\xc3\xadlovna smiled.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I\xe2\x80\x99ve forgotten...\xe2\x80\x9d she replied. \xe2\x80\x9cBut none of you would\ngo?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I will; Pelag\xc3\xa9ya Dan\xc3\xadlovna, let me! I\xe2\x80\x99ll go,\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, why not, if you\xe2\x80\x99re not afraid?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLouisa Iv\xc3\xa1novna, may I?\xe2\x80\x9d asked S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\nWhether they were playing the ring and string game or the ruble game or\ntalking as now, Nicholas did not leave S\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s side, and gazed at her\nwith quite new eyes. It seemed to him that it was only today, thanks\nto that burnt-cork mustache, that he had fully learned to know her. And\nreally, that evening, S\xc3\xb3nya was brighter, more animated, and prettier\nthan Nicholas had ever seen her before.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that\xe2\x80\x99s what she is like; what a fool I have been!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought\ngazing at her sparkling eyes, and under the mustache a happy rapturous\nsmile dimpled her cheeks, a smile he had never seen before.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not afraid of anything,\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya. \xe2\x80\x9cMay I go at once?\xe2\x80\x9d\nShe got up.\n\nThey told her where the barn was and how she should stand and listen,\nand they handed her a fur cloak. She threw this over her head and\nshoulders and glanced at Nicholas.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a darling that girl is!\xe2\x80\x9d thought he. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd what have I been\nthinking of till now?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya went out into the passage to go to the barn. Nicholas went\nhastily to the front porch, saying he felt too hot. The crowd of people\nreally had made the house stuffy.\n\nOutside, there was the same cold stillness and the same moon, but even\nbrighter than before. The light was so strong and the snow sparkled with\nso many stars that one did not wish to look up at the sky and the real\nstars were unnoticed.
