She did not at all realize that before having seen her future\nsister-in-law she was prejudiced against her by involuntary envy of her\nbeauty, youth, and happiness, as well as by jealousy of her brother\xe2\x80\x99s\nlove for her. Apart from this insuperable antipathy to her, Princess\nMary was agitated just then because on the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 being announced,\nthe old prince had shouted that he did not wish to see them, that\nPrincess Mary might do so if she chose, but they were not to be admitted\nto him. She had decided to receive them, but feared lest the prince\nmight at any moment indulge in some freak, as he seemed much upset by\nthe Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 visit.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, my dear princess, I\xe2\x80\x99ve brought you my songstress,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nthe count, bowing and looking round uneasily as if afraid the old prince\nmight appear. \xe2\x80\x9cI am so glad you should get to know one another... very\nsorry the prince is still ailing,\xe2\x80\x9d and after a few more commonplace\nremarks he rose. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you\xe2\x80\x99ll allow me to leave my Nat\xc3\xa1sha in your\nhands for a quarter of an hour, Princess, I\xe2\x80\x99ll drive round to see Anna\nSem\xc3\xabnovna, it\xe2\x80\x99s quite near in the Dogs\xe2\x80\x99 Square, and then I\xe2\x80\x99ll\ncome back for her.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe count had devised this diplomatic ruse (as he afterwards told his\ndaughter) to give the future sisters-in-law an opportunity to talk\nto one another freely, but another motive was to avoid the danger of\nencountering the old prince, of whom he was afraid. He did not mention\nthis to his daughter, but Nat\xc3\xa1sha noticed her father\xe2\x80\x99s nervousness\nand anxiety and felt mortified by it. She blushed for him, grew still\nangrier at having blushed, and looked at the princess with a bold and\ndefiant expression which said that she was not afraid of anybody. The\nprincess told the count that she would be delighted, and only begged him\nto stay longer at Anna Sem\xc3\xabnovna\xe2\x80\x99s, and he departed.\n\nDespite the uneasy glances thrown at her by Princess Mary\xe2\x80\x94who wished\nto have a t\xc3\xaate-\xc3\xa0-t\xc3\xaate with Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x94Mademoiselle Bourienne\nremained in the room and persistently talked about Moscow amusements and\ntheaters. Nat\xc3\xa1sha felt offended by the hesitation she had noticed in\nthe anteroom, by her father\xe2\x80\x99s nervousness, and by the unnatural manner\nof the princess who\xe2\x80\x94she thought\xe2\x80\x94was making a favor of receiving her,\nand so everything displeased her. She did not like Princess Mary, whom\nshe thought very plain, affected, and dry. Nat\xc3\xa1sha suddenly shrank\ninto herself and involuntarily assumed an offhand air which alienated\nPrincess Mary still more. After five minutes of irksome, constrained\nconversation, they heard the sound of slippered feet rapidly\napproaching. Princess Mary looked frightened.\n\nThe door opened and the old prince, in a dressing gown and a white\nnightcap, came in.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, madam!\xe2\x80\x9d he began. \xe2\x80\x9cMadam, Countess... Countess Rost\xc3\xb3va, if\nI am not mistaken... I beg you to excuse me, to excuse me... I did not\nknow, madam. God is my witness, I did not know you had honored us with\na visit, and I came in such a costume only to see my daughter. I beg you\nto excuse me... God is my witness, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated,\nstressing the word \xe2\x80\x9cGod\xe2\x80\x9d so unnaturally and so unpleasantly that\nPrincess Mary stood with downcast eyes not daring to look either at her\nfather or at Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\nNor did the latter, having risen and curtsied, know what to do.\nMademoiselle Bourienne alone smiled agreeably.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg you to excuse me, excuse me! God is my witness, I did not\nknow,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the old man, and after looking Nat\xc3\xa1sha over from head\nto foot he went out.\n\nMademoiselle Bourienne was the first to recover herself after this\napparition and began speaking about the prince\xe2\x80\x99s indisposition.\nNat\xc3\xa1sha and Princess Mary looked at one another in silence, and the\nlonger they did so without saying what they wanted to say, the greater\ngrew their antipathy to one another.\n\nWhen the count returned, Nat\xc3\xa1sha was impolitely pleased and hastened\nto get away: at that moment she hated the stiff, elderly princess, who\ncould place her in such an embarrassing position and had spent half an\nhour with her without once mentioning Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\nbegin talking about him in the presence of that Frenchwoman,\xe2\x80\x9d thought\nNat\xc3\xa1sha. The same thought was meanwhile tormenting Princess Mary. She\nknew what she ought to have said to Nat\xc3\xa1sha, but she had been unable\nto say it because Mademoiselle Bourienne was in the way, and because,\nwithout knowing why, she felt it very difficult to speak of the\nmarriage. When the count was already leaving the room, Princess Mary\nwent up hurriedly to Nat\xc3\xa1sha, took her by the hand, and said with a\ndeep sigh:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait, I must...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha glanced at her ironically without knowing why.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Natalie,\xe2\x80\x9d said Princess Mary, \xe2\x80\x9cI want you to know that I am\nglad my brother has found happiness....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe paused, feeling that she was not telling the truth. Nat\xc3\xa1sha noticed\nthis and guessed its reason.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think, Princess, it is not convenient to speak of that now,\xe2\x80\x9d\nshe said with external dignity and coldness, though she felt the tears\nchoking her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have I said and what have I done?\xe2\x80\x9d thought she, as soon as she\nwas out of the room.\n\nThey waited a long time for Nat\xc3\xa1sha to come to dinner that day. She sat\nin her room crying like a child, blowing her nose and sobbing. S\xc3\xb3nya\nstood beside her, kissing her hair.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1sha, what is it about?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do they matter to\nyou? It will all pass, Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if you only knew how offensive it was... as if I...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t talk about it, Nat\xc3\xa1sha. It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t your fault so why should\nyou mind? Kiss me,\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha raised her head and, kissing her friend on the lips, pressed\nher wet face against her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t tell you, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. No one\xe2\x80\x99s to blame,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nNat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s my fault. But it all hurts terribly. Oh, why\ndoesn\xe2\x80\x99t he come?...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe came in to dinner with red eyes. M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna, who knew how\nthe prince had received the Rost\xc3\xb3vs, pretended not to notice how upset\nNat\xc3\xa1sha was and jested resolutely and loudly at table with the count\nand the other guests.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VIII\n\nThat evening the Rost\xc3\xb3vs went to the Opera, for which M\xc3\xa1rya\nDm\xc3\xadtrievna had taken a box.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha did not want to go, but could not refuse M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\xe2\x80\x99s\nkind offer which was intended expressly for her. When she came ready\ndressed into the ballroom to await her father, and looking in the large\nmirror there saw that she was pretty, very pretty, she felt even more\nsad, but it was a sweet, tender sadness.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cO God, if he were here now I would not behave as I did then, but\ndifferently. I would not be silly and afraid of things, I would simply\nembrace him, cling to him, and make him look at me with those searching\ninquiring eyes with which he has so often looked at me, and then I\nwould make him laugh as he used to laugh. And his eyes\xe2\x80\x94how I see those\neyes!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd what do his father and sister matter\nto me? I love him alone, him, him, with that face and those eyes, with\nhis smile, manly and yet childlike.... No, I had better not think of\nhim; not think of him but forget him, quite forget him for the present.\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t bear this waiting and I shall cry in a minute!\xe2\x80\x9d and she\nturned away from the glass, making an effort not to cry. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd how\ncan S\xc3\xb3nya love Nicholas so calmly and quietly and wait so long and so\npatiently?\xe2\x80\x9d thought she, looking at S\xc3\xb3nya, who also came in quite\nready, with a fan in her hand. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, she\xe2\x80\x99s altogether different. I\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha at that moment felt so softened and tender that it was not\nenough for her to love and know she was beloved, she wanted now, at\nonce, to embrace the man she loved, to speak and hear from him words of\nlove such as filled her heart. While she sat in the carriage beside her\nfather, pensively watching the lights of the street lamps flickering on\nthe frozen window, she felt still sadder and more in love, and forgot\nwhere she was going and with whom. Having fallen into the line of\ncarriages, the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 carriage drove up to the theater, its wheels\nsqueaking over the snow. Nat\xc3\xa1sha and S\xc3\xb3nya, holding up their dresses,\njumped out quickly. The count got out helped by the footmen, and,\npassing among men and women who were entering and the program sellers,\nthey all three went along the corridor to the first row of boxes.\nThrough the closed doors the music was already audible.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1sha, your hair!...\xe2\x80\x9d whispered S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\nAn attendant deferentially and quickly slipped before the ladies and\nopened the door of their box. The music sounded louder and through the\ndoor rows of brightly lit boxes in which ladies sat with bare arms and\nshoulders, and noisy stalls brilliant with uniforms, glittered before\ntheir eyes. A lady entering the next box shot a glance of feminine envy\nat Nat\xc3\xa1sha. The curtain had not yet risen and the overture was being\nplayed. Nat\xc3\xa1sha, smoothing her gown, went in with S\xc3\xb3nya and sat down,\nscanning the brilliant tiers of boxes opposite. A sensation she had not\nexperienced for a long time\xe2\x80\x94that of hundreds of eyes looking at\nher bare arms and neck\xe2\x80\x94suddenly affected her both agreeably and\ndisagreeably and called up a whole crowd of memories, desires and\nemotions associated with that feeling.\n\nThe two remarkably pretty girls, Nat\xc3\xa1sha and S\xc3\xb3nya, with Count Rost\xc3\xb3v\nwho had not been seen in Moscow for a long time, attracted general\nattention. Moreover, everybody knew vaguely of Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s engagement\nto Prince Andrew, and knew that the Rost\xc3\xb3vs had lived in the country\never since, and all looked with curiosity at a fianc\xc3\xa9e who was making\none of the best matches in Russia.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s looks, as everyone told her, had improved in the country,\nand that evening thanks to her agitation she was particularly pretty.\nShe struck those who saw her by her fullness of life and beauty,\ncombined with her indifference to everything about her. Her black eyes\nlooked at the crowd without seeking anyone, and her delicate arm, bare\nto above the elbow, lay on the velvet edge of the box, while, evidently\nunconsciously, she opened and closed her hand in time to the music,\ncrumpling her program. \xe2\x80\x9cLook, there\xe2\x80\x99s Al\xc3\xa9nina,\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya,\n\xe2\x80\x9cwith her mother, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me, Michael Kir\xc3\xadlovich has grown still stouter!\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the\ncount.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook at our Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna\xe2\x80\x94what a headdress she has on!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Kar\xc3\xa1gins, Julie\xe2\x80\x94and Bor\xc3\xads with them. One can see at once that\nthey\xe2\x80\x99re engaged....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrubetsk\xc3\xb3y has proposed?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, I heard it today,\xe2\x80\x9d said Shinsh\xc3\xadn, coming into the\nRost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 box.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha looked in the direction in which her father\xe2\x80\x99s eyes were\nturned and saw Julie sitting beside her mother with a happy look on her\nface and a string of pearls round her thick red neck\xe2\x80\x94which Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nknew was covered with powder. Behind them, wearing a smile and leaning\nover with an ear to Julie\xe2\x80\x99s mouth, was Bor\xc3\xads\xe2\x80\x99 handsome smoothly\nbrushed head. He looked at the Rost\xc3\xb3vs from under his brows and said\nsomething, smiling, to his betrothed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are talking about us, about me and him!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he no doubt is calming her jealousy of me. They needn\xe2\x80\x99t trouble\nthemselves! If only they knew how little I am concerned about any of\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBehind them sat Anna Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna wearing a green headdress and with a\nhappy look of resignation to the will of God on her face. Their box was\npervaded by that atmosphere of an affianced couple which Nat\xc3\xa1sha knew\nso well and liked so much. She turned away and suddenly remembered all\nthat had been so humiliating in her morning\xe2\x80\x99s visit.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat right has he not to wish to receive me into his family? Oh,\nbetter not think of it\xe2\x80\x94not till he comes back!\xe2\x80\x9d she told herself,\nand began looking at the faces, some strange and some familiar, in\nthe stalls. In the front, in the very center, leaning back against\nthe orchestra rail, stood D\xc3\xb3lokhov in a Persian dress, his curly hair\nbrushed up into a huge shock. He stood in full view of the audience,\nwell aware that he was attracting everyone\xe2\x80\x99s attention, yet as much at\nease as though he were in his own room. Around him thronged Moscow\xe2\x80\x99s\nmost brilliant young men, whom he evidently dominated.\n\nThe count, laughing, nudged the blushing S\xc3\xb3nya and pointed to her\nformer adorer.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you recognize him?\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd where has he sprung from?\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe asked, turning to Shinsh\xc3\xadn. \xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t he vanish somewhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe did,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Shinsh\xc3\xadn. \xe2\x80\x9cHe was in the Caucasus and ran\naway from there. They say he has been acting as minister to some ruling\nprince in Persia, where he killed the Shah\xe2\x80\x99s brother. Now all the\nMoscow ladies are mad about him! It\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x98D\xc3\xb3lokhov the Persian\xe2\x80\x99 that\ndoes it! We never hear a word but D\xc3\xb3lokhov is mentioned. They swear\nby him, they offer him to you as they would a dish of choice sterlet.\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov and Anatole Kur\xc3\xa1gin have turned all our ladies\xe2\x80\x99 heads.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nA tall, beautiful woman with a mass of plaited hair and much exposed\nplump white shoulders and neck, round which she wore a double string of\nlarge pearls, entered the adjoining box rustling her heavy silk dress\nand took a long time settling into her place.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha involuntarily gazed at that neck, those shoulders, and pearls\nand coiffure, and admired the beauty of the shoulders and the pearls.\nWhile Nat\xc3\xa1sha was fixing her gaze on her for the second time the lady\nlooked round and, meeting the count\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, nodded to him and smiled.\nShe was the Countess Bez\xc3\xbakhova, Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s wife, and the count, who\nknew everyone in society, leaned over and spoke to her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you been here long, Countess?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll call,\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll call to kiss your hand. I\xe2\x80\x99m here on business and have brought\nmy girls with me. They say Sem\xc3\xabnova acts marvelously. Count Pierre\nnever used to forget us. Is he here?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he meant to look in,\xe2\x80\x9d answered H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, and glanced\nattentively at Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\nCount Rost\xc3\xb3v resumed his seat.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHandsome, isn\xe2\x80\x99t she?\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered to Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWonderful!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s a woman one could easily\nfall in love with.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nJust then the last chords of the overture were heard and the conductor\ntapped with his stick. Some latecomers took their seats in the stalls,\nand the curtain rose.\n\nAs soon as it rose everyone in the boxes and stalls became silent, and\nall the men, old and young, in uniform and evening dress, and all the\nwomen with gems on their bare flesh, turned their whole attention with\neager curiosity to the stage. Nat\xc3\xa1sha too began to look at it.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IX\n\nThe floor of the stage consisted of smooth boards, at the sides was\nsome painted cardboard representing trees, and at the back was a cloth\nstretched over boards. In the center of the stage sat some girls in red\nbodices and white skirts. One very fat girl in a white silk dress sat\napart on a low bench, to the back of which a piece of green cardboard\nwas glued. They all sang something. When they had finished their song\nthe girl in white went up to the prompter\xe2\x80\x99s box and a man with tight\nsilk trousers over his stout legs, and holding a plume and a dagger,\nwent up to her and began singing, waving his arms about.\n\nFirst the man in the tight trousers sang alone, then she sang, then they\nboth paused while the orchestra played and the man fingered the hand\nof the girl in white, obviously awaiting the beat to start singing with\nher. They sang together and everyone in the theater began clapping\nand shouting, while the man and woman on the stage\xe2\x80\x94who represented\nlovers\xe2\x80\x94began smiling, spreading out their arms, and bowing.\n\nAfter her life in the country, and in her present serious mood, all this\nseemed grotesque and amazing to Nat\xc3\xa1sha. She could not follow the opera\nnor even listen to the music; she saw only the painted cardboard and the\nqueerly dressed men and women who moved, spoke, and sang so strangely in\nthat brilliant light. She knew what it was all meant to represent, but\nit was so pretentiously false and unnatural that she first felt ashamed\nfor the actors and then amused at them. She looked at the faces of the\naudience, seeking in them the same sense of ridicule and perplexity she\nherself experienced, but they all seemed attentive to what was happening\non the stage, and expressed delight which to Nat\xc3\xa1sha seemed feigned.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose it has to be like this!\xe2\x80\x9d she thought. She kept looking\nround in turn at the rows of pomaded heads in the stalls and then at\nthe seminude women in the boxes, especially at H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne in the next box,\nwho\xe2\x80\x94apparently quite unclothed\xe2\x80\x94sat with a quiet tranquil smile, not\ntaking her eyes off the stage. And feeling the bright light that flooded\nthe whole place and the warm air heated by the crowd, Nat\xc3\xa1sha little\nby little began to pass into a state of intoxication she had not\nexperienced for a long while. She did not realize who and where she\nwas, nor what was going on before her. As she looked and thought, the\nstrangest fancies unexpectedly and disconnectedly passed through her\nmind: the idea occurred to her of jumping onto the edge of the box and\nsinging the aria the actress was singing, then she wished to touch with\nher fan an old gentleman sitting not far from her, then to lean over to\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne and tickle her.\n\nAt a moment when all was quiet before the commencement of a song, a door\nleading to the stalls on the side nearest the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 box creaked,\nand the steps of a belated arrival were heard. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s Kur\xc3\xa1gin!\xe2\x80\x9d\nwhispered Shinsh\xc3\xadn. Countess Bez\xc3\xbakhova turned smiling to the newcomer,\nand Nat\xc3\xa1sha, following the direction of that look, saw an exceptionally\nhandsome adjutant approaching their box with a self-assured yet\ncourteous bearing. This was Anatole Kur\xc3\xa1gin whom she had seen\nand noticed long ago at the ball in Petersburg. He was now in an\nadjutant\xe2\x80\x99s uniform with one epaulet and a shoulder knot. He moved with\na restrained swagger which would have been ridiculous had he not been\nso good-looking and had his handsome face not worn such an expression\nof good-humored complacency and gaiety. Though the performance was\nproceeding, he walked deliberately down the carpeted gangway, his sword\nand spurs slightly jingling and his handsome perfumed head held high.\nHaving looked at Nat\xc3\xa1sha he approached his sister, laid his well gloved\nhand on the edge of her box, nodded to her, and leaning forward asked a\nquestion, with a motion toward Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMais charmante!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, evidently referring to Nat\xc3\xa1sha, who did\nnot exactly hear his words but understood them from the movement of his\nlips. Then he took his place in the first row of the stalls and sat down\nbeside D\xc3\xb3lokhov, nudging with his elbow in a friendly and offhand way\nthat D\xc3\xb3lokhov whom others treated so fawningly. He winked at him gaily,\nsmiled, and rested his foot against the orchestra screen.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow like the brother is to the sister,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the count. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\nhow handsome they both are!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShinsh\xc3\xadn, lowering his voice, began to tell the count of some intrigue\nof Kur\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x99s in Moscow, and Nat\xc3\xa1sha tried to overhear it just\nbecause he had said she was \xe2\x80\x9ccharmante.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe first act was over. In the stalls everyone began moving about, going\nout and coming in.\n\nBor\xc3\xads came to the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 box, received their congratulations very\nsimply, and raising his eyebrows with an absent-minded smile conveyed to\nNat\xc3\xa1sha and S\xc3\xb3nya his fianc\xc3\xa9e\xe2\x80\x99s invitation to her wedding, and\nwent away. Nat\xc3\xa1sha with a gay, coquettish smile talked to him, and\ncongratulated on his approaching wedding that same Bor\xc3\xads with whom\nshe had formerly been in love. In the state of intoxication she was in,\neverything seemed simple and natural.\n\nThe scantily clad H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne smiled at everyone in the same way, and\nNat\xc3\xa1sha gave Bor\xc3\xads a similar smile.\n\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s box was filled and surrounded from the stalls by the most\ndistinguished and intellectual men, who seemed to vie with one another\nin their wish to let everyone see that they knew her.\n\nDuring the whole of that entr\xe2\x80\x99acte Kur\xc3\xa1gin stood with D\xc3\xb3lokhov\nin front of the orchestra partition, looking at the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 box.\nNat\xc3\xa1sha knew he was talking about her and this afforded her pleasure.\nShe even turned so that he should see her profile in what she thought\nwas its most becoming aspect. Before the beginning of the second act\nPierre appeared in the stalls. The Rost\xc3\xb3vs had not seen him since\ntheir arrival. His face looked sad, and he had grown still stouter since\nNat\xc3\xa1sha last saw him. He passed up to the front rows, not noticing\nanyone. Anatole went up to him and began speaking to him, looking at and\nindicating the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 box. On seeing Nat\xc3\xa1sha Pierre grew animated\nand, hastily passing between the rows, came toward their box. When he\ngot there he leaned on his elbows and, smiling, talked to her for a long\ntime. While conversing with Pierre, Nat\xc3\xa1sha heard a man\xe2\x80\x99s voice in\nCountess Bez\xc3\xbakhova\xe2\x80\x99s box and something told her it was Kur\xc3\xa1gin. She\nturned and their eyes met. Almost smiling, he gazed straight into her\neyes with such an enraptured caressing look that it seemed strange to be\nso near him, to look at him like that, to be so sure he admired her, and\nnot to be acquainted with him.\n\nIn the second act there was scenery representing tombstones, there was a\nround hole in the canvas to represent the moon, shades were raised over\nthe footlights, and from horns and contrabass came deep notes while many\npeople appeared from right and left wearing black cloaks and holding\nthings like daggers in their hands. They began waving their arms. Then\nsome other people ran in and began dragging away the maiden who had been\nin white and was now in light blue. They did not drag her away at once,\nbut sang with her for a long time and then at last dragged her off, and\nbehind the scenes something metallic was struck three times and\neveryone knelt down and sang a prayer. All these things were repeatedly\ninterrupted by the enthusiastic shouts of the audience.\n\nDuring this act every time Nat\xc3\xa1sha looked toward the stalls she saw\nAnatole Kur\xc3\xa1gin with an arm thrown across the back of his chair,\nstaring at her. She was pleased to see that he was captivated by her and\nit did not occur to her that there was anything wrong in it.\n\nWhen the second act was over Countess Bez\xc3\xbakhova rose, turned to the\nRost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 box\xe2\x80\x94her whole bosom completely exposed\xe2\x80\x94beckoned the old\ncount with a gloved finger, and paying no attention to those who had\nentered her box began talking to him with an amiable smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo make me acquainted with your charming daughters,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe whole town is singing their praises and I don\xe2\x80\x99t even know\nthem!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha rose and curtsied to the splendid countess. She was so pleased\nby praise from this brilliant beauty that she blushed with pleasure.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to become a Moscovite too, now,\xe2\x80\x9d said H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne. \xe2\x80\x9cHow is it\nyou\xe2\x80\x99re not ashamed to bury such pearls in the country?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nCountess Bez\xc3\xbakhova quite deserved her reputation of being a fascinating\nwoman. She could say what she did not think\xe2\x80\x94especially what was\nflattering\xe2\x80\x94quite simply and naturally.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear count, you must let me look after your daughters! Though I am\nnot staying here long this time\xe2\x80\x94nor are you\xe2\x80\x94I will try to amuse\nthem. I have already heard much of you in Petersburg and wanted to get\nto know you,\xe2\x80\x9d said she to Nat\xc3\xa1sha with her stereotyped and lovely\nsmile. \xe2\x80\x9cI had heard about you from my page, Drubetsk\xc3\xb3y. Have you\nheard he is getting married? And also from my husband\xe2\x80\x99s friend\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski, Prince Andrew Bolk\xc3\xb3nski,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on with special\nemphasis, implying that she knew of his relation to Nat\xc3\xa1sha. To get\nbetter acquainted she asked that one of the young ladies should come\ninto her box for the rest of the performance, and Nat\xc3\xa1sha moved over to\nit.\n\nThe scene of the third act represented a palace in which many candles\nwere burning and pictures of knights with short beards hung on the\nwalls. In the middle stood what were probably a king and a queen. The\nking waved his right arm and, evidently nervous, sang something badly\nand sat down on a crimson throne. The maiden who had been first in white\nand then in light blue, now wore only a smock, and stood beside the\nthrone with her hair down. She sang something mournfully, addressing the\nqueen, but the king waved his arm severely, and men and women with bare\nlegs came in from both sides and began dancing all together. Then the\nviolins played very shrilly and merrily and one of the women with thick\nbare legs and thin arms, separating from the others, went behind the\nwings, adjusted her bodice, returned to the middle of the stage, and\nbegan jumping and striking one foot rapidly against the other. In the\nstalls everyone clapped and shouted \xe2\x80\x9cbravo!\xe2\x80\x9d Then one of the men\nwent into a corner of the stage. The cymbals and horns in the orchestra\nstruck up more loudly, and this man with bare legs jumped very high and\nwaved his feet about very rapidly. (He was Duport, who received sixty\nthousand rubles a year for this art.) Everybody in the stalls, boxes,\nand galleries began clapping and shouting with all their might, and the\nman stopped and began smiling and bowing to all sides. Then other men\nand women danced with bare legs. Then the king again shouted to the\nsound of music, and they all began singing. But suddenly a storm\ncame on, chromatic scales and diminished sevenths were heard in the\norchestra, everyone ran off, again dragging one of their number away,\nand the curtain dropped. Once more there was a terrible noise and\nclatter among the audience, and with rapturous faces everyone began\nshouting: \xe2\x80\x9cDuport! Duport! Duport!\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha no longer thought this\nstrange. She looked about with pleasure, smiling joyfully.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t Duport delightful?\xe2\x80\x9d H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne asked her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER X\n\nDuring the entr\xe2\x80\x99acte a whiff of cold air came into H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s box,\nthe door opened, and Anatole entered, stooping and trying not to brush\nagainst anyone.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me introduce my brother to you,\xe2\x80\x9d said H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, her eyes\nshifting uneasily from Nat\xc3\xa1sha to Anatole.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha turned her pretty little head toward the elegant young officer\nand smiled at him over her bare shoulder. Anatole, who was as handsome\nat close quarters as at a distance, sat down beside her and told her he\nhad long wished to have this happiness\xe2\x80\x94ever since the Nar\xc3\xbdshkins\xe2\x80\x99\nball in fact, at which he had had the well-remembered pleasure of seeing\nher. Kur\xc3\xa1gin was much more sensible and simple with women than among\nmen. He talked boldly and naturally, and Nat\xc3\xa1sha was strangely and\nagreeably struck by the fact that there was nothing formidable in this\nman about whom there was so much talk, but that on the contrary his\nsmile was most na\xc3\xafve, cheerful, and good-natured.\n\nKur\xc3\xa1gin asked her opinion of the performance and told her how at a\nprevious performance Sem\xc3\xabnova had fallen down on the stage.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you know, Countess,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, suddenly addressing her as an\nold, familiar acquaintance, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are getting up a costume tournament;\nyou ought to take part in it! It will be great fun. We shall all meet at\nthe Kar\xc3\xa1gins\xe2\x80\x99! Please come! No! Really, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\nWhile saying this he never removed his smiling eyes from her face,\nher neck, and her bare arms. Nat\xc3\xa1sha knew for certain that he was\nenraptured by her. This pleased her, yet his presence made her feel\nconstrained and oppressed. When she was not looking at him she felt that\nhe was looking at her shoulders, and she involuntarily caught his eye\nso that he should look into hers rather than this. But looking into his\neyes she was frightened, realizing that there was not that barrier of\nmodesty she had always felt between herself and other men. She did not\nknow how it was that within five minutes she had come to feel herself\nterribly near to this man. When she turned away she feared he might\nseize her from behind by her bare arm and kiss her on the neck. They\nspoke of most ordinary things, yet she felt that they were closer to\none another than she had ever been to any man. Nat\xc3\xa1sha kept turning to\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne and to her father, as if asking what it all meant, but H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\nwas engaged in conversation with a general and did not answer her\nlook, and her father\xe2\x80\x99s eyes said nothing but what they always said:\n\xe2\x80\x9cHaving a good time? Well, I\xe2\x80\x99m glad of it!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDuring one of these moments of awkward silence when Anatole\xe2\x80\x99s\nprominent eyes were gazing calmly and fixedly at her, Nat\xc3\xa1sha, to break\nthe silence, asked him how he liked Moscow. She asked the question and\nblushed. She felt all the time that by talking to him she was doing\nsomething improper. Anatole smiled as though to encourage her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt first I did not like it much, because what makes a town pleasant\nce sont les jolies femmes, * isn\xe2\x80\x99t that so? But now I like it very\nmuch indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking at her significantly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll come\nto the costume tournament, Countess? Do come!\xe2\x80\x9d and putting out his\nhand to her bouquet and dropping his voice, he added, \xe2\x80\x9cYou will be the\nprettiest there. Do come, dear countess, and give me this flower as a\npledge!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n    * Are the pretty women.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha did not understand what he was saying any more than he did\nhimself, but she felt that his incomprehensible words had an improper\nintention. She did not know what to say and turned away as if she had\nnot heard his remark. But as soon as she had turned away she felt that\nhe was there, behind, so close behind her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is he now? Confused? Angry? Ought I to put it right?\xe2\x80\x9d she\nasked herself, and she could not refrain from turning round. She looked\nstraight into his eyes, and his nearness, self-assurance, and the\ngood-natured tenderness of his smile vanquished her. She smiled just\nas he was doing, gazing straight into his eyes. And again she felt with\nhorror that no barrier lay between him and her.\n\nThe curtain rose again. Anatole left the box, serene and gay. Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nwent back to her father in the other box, now quite submissive to the\nworld she found herself in. All that was going on before her now seemed\nquite natural, but on the other hand all her previous thoughts of her\nbetrothed, of Princess Mary, or of life in the country did not once\nrecur to her mind and were as if belonging to a remote past.\n\nIn the fourth act there was some sort of devil who sang waving his arm\nabout, till the boards were withdrawn from under him and he disappeared\ndown below. That was the only part of the fourth act that Nat\xc3\xa1sha saw.\nShe felt agitated and tormented, and the cause of this was Kur\xc3\xa1gin whom\nshe could not help watching. As they were leaving the theater Anatole\ncame up to them, called their carriage, and helped them in. As he was\nputting Nat\xc3\xa1sha in he pressed her arm above the elbow. Agitated and\nflushed she turned round. He was looking at her with glittering eyes,\nsmiling tenderly.\n\n\nOnly after she had reached home was Nat\xc3\xa1sha able clearly to think over\nwhat had happened to her, and suddenly remembering Prince Andrew she\nwas horrified, and at tea to which all had sat down after the opera, she\ngave a loud exclamation, flushed, and ran out of the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cO God! I am lost!\xe2\x80\x9d she said to herself. \xe2\x80\x9cHow could I let him?\xe2\x80\x9d\nShe sat for a long time hiding her flushed face in her hands trying to\nrealize what had happened to her, but was unable either to understand\nwhat had happened or what she felt. Everything seemed dark, obscure,\nand terrible. There in that enormous, illuminated theater where the\nbare-legged Duport, in a tinsel-decorated jacket, jumped about to the\nmusic on wet boards, and young girls and old men, and the nearly\nnaked H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne with her proud, calm smile, rapturously cried\n\xe2\x80\x9cbravo!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94there in the presence of that H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne it had all seemed\nclear and simple; but now, alone by herself, it was incomprehensible.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it? What was that terror I felt of him? What is this gnawing\nof conscience I am feeling now?\xe2\x80\x9d she thought.\n\nOnly to the old countess at night in bed could Nat\xc3\xa1sha have told all\nshe was feeling. She knew that S\xc3\xb3nya with her severe and simple views\nwould either not understand it at all or would be horrified at such\na confession. So Nat\xc3\xa1sha tried to solve what was torturing her by\nherself.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I spoiled for Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s love or not?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked herself, and\nwith soothing irony replied: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a fool I am to ask that! What did\nhappen to me? Nothing! I have done nothing, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t lead him on\nat all. Nobody will know and I shall never see him again,\xe2\x80\x9d she told\nherself. \xe2\x80\x9cSo it is plain that nothing has happened and there is\nnothing to repent of, and Andrew can love me still. But why \xe2\x80\x98still?\xe2\x80\x99\nO God, why isn\xe2\x80\x99t he here?\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha quieted herself for a moment,\nbut again some instinct told her that though all this was true, and\nthough nothing had happened, yet the former purity of her love for\nPrince Andrew had perished. And again in imagination she went over her\nwhole conversation with Kur\xc3\xa1gin, and again saw the face, gestures, and\ntender smile of that bold handsome man when he pressed her arm.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XI\n\nAnatole Kur\xc3\xa1gin was staying in Moscow because his father had sent him\naway from Petersburg, where he had been spending twenty thousand rubles\na year in cash, besides running up debts for as much more, which his\ncreditors demanded from his father.\n\nHis father announced to him that he would now pay half his debts for the\nlast time, but only on condition that he went to Moscow as adjutant to\nthe commander in chief\xe2\x80\x94a post his father had procured for him\xe2\x80\x94and\nwould at last try to make a good match there. He indicated to him\nPrincess Mary and Julie Kar\xc3\xa1gina.\n\nAnatole consented and went to Moscow, where he put up at Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s\nhouse. Pierre received him unwillingly at first, but got used to him\nafter a while, sometimes even accompanied him on his carousals, and gave\nhim money under the guise of loans.\n\nAs Shinsh\xc3\xadn had remarked, from the time of his arrival Anatole had\nturned the heads of the Moscow ladies, especially by the fact that\nhe slighted them and plainly preferred the gypsy girls and French\nactresses\xe2\x80\x94with the chief of whom, Mademoiselle George, he was said to\nbe on intimate relations. He had never missed a carousal at Dan\xc3\xadlov\xe2\x80\x99s\nor other Moscow revelers\xe2\x80\x99, drank whole nights through, outvying\neveryone else, and was at all the balls and parties of the best society.\nThere was talk of his intrigues with some of the ladies, and he flirted\nwith a few of them at the balls. But he did not run after the unmarried\ngirls, especially the rich heiresses who were most of them plain.\nThere was a special reason for this, as he had got married two years\nbefore\xe2\x80\x94a fact known only to his most intimate friends. At that time\nwhile with his regiment in Poland, a Polish landowner of small means had\nforced him to marry his daughter. Anatole had very soon abandoned his\nwife and, for a payment which he agreed to send to his father-in-law,\nhad arranged to be free to pass himself off as a bachelor.\n\nAnatole was always content with his position, with himself, and with\nothers. He was instinctively and thoroughly convinced that it was\nimpossible for him to live otherwise than as he did and that he had\nnever in his life done anything base. He was incapable of considering\nhow his actions might affect others or what the consequences of this or\nthat action of his might be. He was convinced that, as a duck is so made\nthat it must live in water, so God had made him such that he must spend\nthirty thousand rubles a year and always occupy a prominent position in\nsociety. He believed this so firmly that others, looking at him, were\npersuaded of it too and did not refuse him either a leading place\nin society or money, which he borrowed from anyone and everyone and\nevidently would not repay.\n\nHe was not a gambler, at any rate he did not care about winning. He was\nnot vain. He did not mind what people thought of him. Still less could\nhe be accused of ambition. More than once he had vexed his father by\nspoiling his own career, and he laughed at distinctions of all kinds. He\nwas not mean, and did not refuse anyone who asked of him. All he cared\nabout was gaiety and women, and as according to his ideas there\nwas nothing dishonorable in these tastes, and he was incapable of\nconsidering what the gratification of his tastes entailed for others,\nhe honestly considered himself irreproachable, sincerely despised rogues\nand bad people, and with a tranquil conscience carried his head high.\n\nRakes, those male Magdalenes, have a secret feeling of innocence\nsimilar to that which female Magdalenes have, based on the same hope of\nforgiveness. \xe2\x80\x9cAll will be forgiven her, for she loved much; and all\nwill be forgiven him, for he enjoyed much.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov, who had reappeared that year in Moscow after his exile and\nhis Persian adventures, and was leading a life of luxury, gambling, and\ndissipation, associated with his old Petersburg comrade Kur\xc3\xa1gin and\nmade use of him for his own ends.\n\nAnatole was sincerely fond of D\xc3\xb3lokhov for his cleverness and\naudacity. D\xc3\xb3lokhov, who needed Anatole Kur\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x99s name, position, and\nconnections as a bait to draw rich young men into his gambling set, made\nuse of him and amused himself at his expense without letting the other\nfeel it. Apart from the advantage he derived from Anatole, the very\nprocess of dominating another\xe2\x80\x99s will was in itself a pleasure, a\nhabit, and a necessity to D\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha had made a strong impression on Kur\xc3\xa1gin. At supper after\nthe opera he described to D\xc3\xb3lokhov with the air of a connoisseur the\nattractions of her arms, shoulders, feet, and hair and expressed his\nintention of making love to her. Anatole had no notion and was incapable\nof considering what might come of such love-making, as he never had any\nnotion of the outcome of any of his actions.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s first-rate, my dear fellow, but not for us,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell my sister to ask her to dinner,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole.\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d better wait till she\xe2\x80\x99s married....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know, I adore little girls, they lose their heads at once,\xe2\x80\x9d\npursued Anatole.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have been caught once already by a \xe2\x80\x98little girl,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov who knew of Kur\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x99s marriage. \xe2\x80\x9cTake care!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that can\xe2\x80\x99t happen twice! Eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole, with a\ngood-humored laugh.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XII\n\nThe day after the opera the Rost\xc3\xb3vs went nowhere and nobody came to see\nthem. M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna talked to the count about something which they\nconcealed from Nat\xc3\xa1sha. Nat\xc3\xa1sha guessed they were talking about the\nold prince and planning something, and this disquieted and offended her.\nShe was expecting Prince Andrew any moment and twice that day sent a\nmanservant to the Vozdv\xc3\xadzhenka to ascertain whether he had come. He had\nnot arrived. She suffered more now than during her first days in Moscow.\nTo her impatience and pining for him were now added the unpleasant\nrecollection of her interview with Princess Mary and the old prince,\nand a fear and anxiety of which she did not understand the cause. She\ncontinually fancied that either he would never come or that something\nwould happen to her before he came. She could no longer think of him by\nherself calmly and continuously as she had done before. As soon as she\nbegan to think of him, the recollection of the old prince, of Princess\nMary, of the theater, and of Kur\xc3\xa1gin mingled with her thoughts. The\nquestion again presented itself whether she was not guilty, whether she\nhad not already broken faith with Prince Andrew, and again she found\nherself recalling to the minutest detail every word, every gesture, and\nevery shade in the play of expression on the face of the man who had\nbeen able to arouse in her such an incomprehensible and terrifying\nfeeling. To the family Nat\xc3\xa1sha seemed livelier than usual, but she was\nfar less tranquil and happy than before.\n\nOn Sunday morning M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna invited her visitors to Mass at her\nparish church\xe2\x80\x94the Church of the Assumption built over the graves of\nvictims of the plague.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t like those fashionable churches,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, evidently\npriding herself on her independence of thought. \xe2\x80\x9cGod is the same\neverywhere. We have an excellent priest, he conducts the service\ndecently and with dignity, and the deacon is the same. What holiness is\nthere in giving concerts in the choir? I don\xe2\x80\x99t like it, it\xe2\x80\x99s just\nself-indulgence!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nM\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna liked Sundays and knew how to keep them. Her whole\nhouse was scrubbed and cleaned on Saturdays; neither she nor the\nservants worked, and they all wore holiday dress and went to church. At\nher table there were extra dishes at dinner, and the servants had vodka\nand roast goose or suckling pig. But in nothing in the house was the\nholiday so noticeable as in M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\xe2\x80\x99s broad, stern face,\nwhich on that day wore an invariable look of solemn festivity.\n\nAfter Mass, when they had finished their coffee in the dining room\nwhere the loose covers had been removed from the furniture, a servant\nannounced that the carriage was ready, and M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna rose with\na stern air. She wore her holiday shawl, in which she paid calls, and\nannounced that she was going to see Prince Nicholas Bolk\xc3\xb3nski to have\nan explanation with him about Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\nAfter she had gone, a dressmaker from Madame Suppert-Roguet waited on\nthe Rost\xc3\xb3vs, and Nat\xc3\xa1sha, very glad of this diversion, having shut\nherself into a room adjoining the drawing room, occupied herself trying\non the new dresses. Just as she had put on a bodice without sleeves and\nonly tacked together, and was turning her head to see in the glass how\nthe back fitted, she heard in the drawing room the animated sounds\nof her father\xe2\x80\x99s voice and another\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94a woman\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94that made her\nflush. It was H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne. Nat\xc3\xa1sha had not time to take off the bodice\nbefore the door opened and Countess Bez\xc3\xbakhova, dressed in a purple\nvelvet gown with a high collar, came into the room beaming with\ngood-humored amiable smiles.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my enchantress!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried to the blushing Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\xe2\x80\x9cCharming! No, this is really beyond anything, my dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nshe to Count Rost\xc3\xb3v who had followed her in. \xe2\x80\x9cHow can you live in\nMoscow and go nowhere? No, I won\xe2\x80\x99t let you off! Mademoiselle George\nwill recite at my house tonight and there\xe2\x80\x99ll be some people, and if\nyou don\xe2\x80\x99t bring your lovely girls\xe2\x80\x94who are prettier than Mademoiselle\nGeorge\xe2\x80\x94I won\xe2\x80\x99t know you! My husband is away in Tver or I would send\nhim to fetch you. You must come. You positively must! Between eight and\nnine.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe nodded to the dressmaker, whom she knew and who had curtsied\nrespectfully to her, and seated herself in an armchair beside the\nlooking glass, draping the folds of her velvet dress picturesquely. She\ndid not cease chattering good-naturedly and gaily, continually praising\nNat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s beauty. She looked at Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s dresses and praised\nthem, as well as a new dress of her own made of \xe2\x80\x9cmetallic gauze,\xe2\x80\x9d\nwhich she had received from Paris, and advised Nat\xc3\xa1sha to have one like\nit.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut anything suits you, my charmer!\xe2\x80\x9d she remarked.\n\nA smile of pleasure never left Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s face. She felt happy and as\nif she were blossoming under the praise of this dear Countess Bez\xc3\xbakhova\nwho had formerly seemed to her so unapproachable and important and was\nnow so kind to her. Nat\xc3\xa1sha brightened up and felt almost in love with\nthis woman, who was so beautiful and so kind. H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne for her part was\nsincerely delighted with Nat\xc3\xa1sha and wished to give her a good time.\nAnatole had asked her to bring him and Nat\xc3\xa1sha together, and she was\ncalling on the Rost\xc3\xb3vs for that purpose. The idea of throwing her\nbrother and Nat\xc3\xa1sha together amused her.\n\nThough at one time, in Petersburg, she had been annoyed with Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nfor drawing Bor\xc3\xads away, she did not think of that now, and in her own\nway heartily wished Nat\xc3\xa1sha well. As she was leaving the Rost\xc3\xb3vs she\ncalled her prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9e aside.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy brother dined with me yesterday\xe2\x80\x94we nearly died of laughter\xe2\x80\x94he\nate nothing and kept sighing for you, my charmer! He is madly, quite\nmadly, in love with you, my dear.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha blushed scarlet when she heard this.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow she blushes, how she blushes, my pretty!\xe2\x80\x9d said H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\nmust certainly come. If you love somebody, my charmer, that is not a\nreason to shut yourself up. Even if you are engaged, I am sure your\nfianc\xc3\xa9 would wish you to go into society rather than be bored to\ndeath.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo she knows I am engaged, and she and her husband Pierre\xe2\x80\x94that good\nPierre\xe2\x80\x94have talked and laughed about this. So it\xe2\x80\x99s all right.\xe2\x80\x9d And\nagain, under H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s influence, what had seemed terrible now seemed\nsimple and natural. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd she is such a grande dame, so kind, and\nevidently likes me so much. And why not enjoy myself?\xe2\x80\x9d thought\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, gazing at H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne with wide-open, wondering eyes.\n\nM\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna came back to dinner taciturn and serious, having\nevidently suffered a defeat at the old prince\xe2\x80\x99s. She was still too\nagitated by the encounter to be able to talk of the affair calmly. In\nanswer to the count\xe2\x80\x99s inquiries she replied that things were all\nright and that she would tell about it next day. On hearing of Countess\nBez\xc3\xbakhova\xe2\x80\x99s visit and the invitation for that evening, M\xc3\xa1rya\nDm\xc3\xadtrievna remarked:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t care to have anything to do with Bez\xc3\xbakhova and don\xe2\x80\x99t\nadvise you to; however, if you\xe2\x80\x99ve promised\xe2\x80\x94go. It will divert your\nthoughts,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, addressing Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIII\n\nCount Rost\xc3\xb3v took the girls to Countess Bez\xc3\xbakhova\xe2\x80\x99s. There were\na good many people there, but nearly all strangers to Nat\xc3\xa1sha. Count\nRost\xc3\xb3v was displeased to see that the company consisted almost entirely\nof men and women known for the freedom of their conduct. Mademoiselle\nGeorge was standing in a corner of the drawing room surrounded by young\nmen. There were several Frenchmen present, among them M\xc3\xa9tivier who from\nthe time H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne reached Moscow had been an intimate in her house. The\ncount decided not to sit down to cards or let his girls out of his sight\nand to get away as soon as Mademoiselle George\xe2\x80\x99s performance was over.\n\nAnatole was at the door, evidently on the lookout for the Rost\xc3\xb3vs.\nImmediately after greeting the count he went up to Nat\xc3\xa1sha and followed\nher. As soon as she saw him she was seized by the same feeling she had\nhad at the opera\xe2\x80\x94gratified vanity at his admiration of her and fear at\nthe absence of a moral barrier between them.\n\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne welcomed Nat\xc3\xa1sha delightedly and was loud in admiration of her\nbeauty and her dress. Soon after their arrival Mademoiselle George went\nout of the room to change her costume. In the drawing room people began\narranging the chairs and taking their seats. Anatole moved a chair for\nNat\xc3\xa1sha and was about to sit down beside her, but the count, who never\nlost sight of her, took the seat himself. Anatole sat down behind her.\n\nMademoiselle George, with her bare, fat, dimpled arms, and a red shawl\ndraped over one shoulder, came into the space left vacant for her, and\nassumed an unnatural pose. Enthusiastic whispering was audible.\n\nMademoiselle George looked sternly and gloomily at the audience and\nbegan reciting some French verses describing her guilty love for her\nson. In some places she raised her voice, in others she whispered,\nlifting her head triumphantly; sometimes she paused and uttered hoarse\nsounds, rolling her eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdorable! divine! delicious!\xe2\x80\x9d was heard from every side.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha looked at the fat actress, but neither saw nor heard nor\nunderstood anything of what went on before her. She only felt herself\nagain completely borne away into this strange senseless world\xe2\x80\x94so\nremote from her old world\xe2\x80\x94a world in which it was impossible to know\nwhat was good or bad, reasonable or senseless. Behind her sat Anatole,\nand conscious of his proximity she experienced a frightened sense of\nexpectancy.\n\nAfter the first monologue the whole company rose and surrounded\nMademoiselle George, expressing their enthusiasm.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow beautiful she is!\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha remarked to her father who had also\nrisen and was moving through the crowd toward the actress.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think so when I look at you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole, following\nNat\xc3\xa1sha. He said this at a moment when she alone could hear him. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\nare enchanting... from the moment I saw you I have never ceased...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, Nat\xc3\xa1sha!\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, as he turned back for his\ndaughter. \xe2\x80\x9cHow beautiful she is!\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha without saying anything\nstepped up to her father and looked at him with surprised inquiring\neyes.\n\nAfter giving several recitations, Mademoiselle George left, and Countess\nBez\xc3\xbakhova asked her visitors into the ballroom.\n\nThe count wished to go home, but H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne entreated him not to spoil her\nimprovised ball, and the Rost\xc3\xb3vs stayed on. Anatole asked Nat\xc3\xa1sha for\na valse and as they danced he pressed her waist and hand and told her\nshe was bewitching and that he loved her. During the \xc3\xa9cossaise, which\nshe also danced with him, Anatole said nothing when they happened to be\nby themselves, but merely gazed at her. Nat\xc3\xa1sha lifted her frightened\neyes to him, but there was such confident tenderness in his affectionate\nlook and smile that she could not, whilst looking at him, say what she\nhad to say. She lowered her eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t say such things to me. I am betrothed and love another,\xe2\x80\x9d\nshe said rapidly.... She glanced at him.\n\nAnatole was not upset or pained by what she had said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t speak to me of that! What can I do?\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cI tell\nyou I am madly, madly, in love with you! Is it my fault that you are\nenchanting?... It\xe2\x80\x99s our turn to begin.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, animated and excited, looked about her with wide-open\nfrightened eyes and seemed merrier than usual. She understood hardly\nanything that went on that evening. They danced the \xc3\xa9cossaise and the\nGrossvater. Her father asked her to come home, but she begged to remain.\nWherever she went and whomever she was speaking to, she felt his eyes\nupon her. Later on she recalled how she had asked her father to let\nher go to the dressing room to rearrange her dress, that H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne had\nfollowed her and spoken laughingly of her brother\xe2\x80\x99s love, and that she\nagain met Anatole in the little sitting room. H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne had disappeared\nleaving them alone, and Anatole had taken her hand and said in a tender\nvoice:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot come to visit you but is it possible that I shall never see\nyou? I love you madly. Can I never...?\xe2\x80\x9d and, blocking her path, he\nbrought his face close to hers.\n\nHis large, glittering, masculine eyes were so close to hers that she saw\nnothing but them.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNatalie?\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered inquiringly while she felt her hands being\npainfully pressed. \xe2\x80\x9cNatalie?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t understand. I have nothing to say,\xe2\x80\x9d her eyes replied.\n\nBurning lips were pressed to hers, and at the same instant she felt\nherself released, and H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s footsteps and the rustle of her dress\nwere heard in the room. Nat\xc3\xa1sha looked round at her, and then, red\nand trembling, threw a frightened look of inquiry at Anatole and moved\ntoward the door.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne word, just one, for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Anatole.\n\nShe paused. She so wanted a word from him that would explain to her what\nhad happened and to which she could find no answer.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNatalie, just a word, only one!\xe2\x80\x9d he kept repeating, evidently not\nknowing what to say and he repeated it till H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne came up to them.\n\nH\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne returned with Nat\xc3\xa1sha to the drawing room. The Rost\xc3\xb3vs went\naway without staying for supper.\n\nAfter reaching home Nat\xc3\xa1sha did not sleep all night. She was tormented\nby the insoluble question whether she loved Anatole or Prince Andrew.\nShe loved Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x94she remembered distinctly how deeply she loved\nhim. But she also loved Anatole, of that there was no doubt. \xe2\x80\x9cElse how\ncould all this have happened?\xe2\x80\x9d thought she. \xe2\x80\x9cIf, after that, I could\nreturn his smile when saying good-by, if I was able to let it come to\nthat, it means that I loved him from the first. It means that he is\nkind, noble, and splendid, and I could not help loving him. What am I to\ndo if I love him and the other one too?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked herself, unable to\nfind an answer to these terrible questions.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIV\n\nMorning came with its cares and bustle. Everyone got up and began\nto move about and talk, dressmakers came again. M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\nappeared, and they were called to breakfast. Nat\xc3\xa1sha kept looking\nuneasily at everybody with wide-open eyes, as if wishing to intercept\nevery glance directed toward her, and tried to appear the same as usual.\n\nAfter breakfast, which was her best time, M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna sat down in\nher armchair and called Nat\xc3\xa1sha and the count to her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, friends, I have now thought the whole matter over and this is\nmy advice,\xe2\x80\x9d she began. \xe2\x80\x9cYesterday, as you know, I went to see Prince\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski. Well, I had a talk with him.... He took it into his head to\nbegin shouting, but I am not one to be shouted down. I said what I had\nto say!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and he?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the count.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe? He\xe2\x80\x99s crazy... he did not want to listen. But what\xe2\x80\x99s the use\nof talking? As it is we have worn the poor girl out,\xe2\x80\x9d said M\xc3\xa1rya\nDm\xc3\xadtrievna. \xe2\x80\x9cMy advice to you is finish your business and go back\nhome to Otr\xc3\xa1dnoe... and wait there.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, go back,\xe2\x80\x9d said M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna, \xe2\x80\x9cand wait there. If your\nbetrothed comes here now\xe2\x80\x94there will be no avoiding a quarrel; but\nalone with the old man he will talk things over and then come on to\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nCount Rost\xc3\xb3v approved of this suggestion, appreciating its\nreasonableness. If the old man came round it would be all the better to\nvisit him in Moscow or at Bald Hills later on; and if not, the wedding,\nagainst his wishes, could only be arranged at Otr\xc3\xa1dnoe.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is perfectly true. And I am sorry I went to see him and took\nher,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old count.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, why be sorry? Being here, you had to pay your respects. But if he\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s his affair,\xe2\x80\x9d said M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna, looking for\nsomething in her reticule. \xe2\x80\x9cBesides, the trousseau is ready, so there\nis nothing to wait for; and what is not ready I\xe2\x80\x99ll send after you.\nThough I don\xe2\x80\x99t like letting you go, it is the best way. So go, with\nGod\xe2\x80\x99s blessing!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHaving found what she was looking for in the reticule she handed it to\nNat\xc3\xa1sha. It was a letter from Princess Mary.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has written to you. How she torments herself, poor thing! She\xe2\x80\x99s\nafraid you might think that she does not like you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut she doesn\xe2\x80\x99t like me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t talk nonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d cried M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shan\xe2\x80\x99t believe anyone, I know she doesn\xe2\x80\x99t like me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\nNat\xc3\xa1sha boldly as she took the letter, and her face expressed a cold\nand angry resolution that caused M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna to look at her more\nintently and to frown.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t answer like that, my good girl!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat I say is\ntrue! Write an answer!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha did not reply and went to her own room to read Princess\nMary\xe2\x80\x99s letter.\n\nPrincess Mary wrote that she was in despair at the misunderstanding that\nhad occurred between them. Whatever her father\xe2\x80\x99s feelings might be,\nshe begged Nat\xc3\xa1sha to believe that she could not help loving her as\nthe one chosen by her brother, for whose happiness she was ready to\nsacrifice everything.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not think, however,\xe2\x80\x9d she wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cthat my father is\nill-disposed toward you. He is an invalid and an old man who must be\nforgiven; but he is good and magnanimous and will love her who makes his\nson happy.\xe2\x80\x9d Princess Mary went on to ask Nat\xc3\xa1sha to fix a time when\nshe could see her again.\n\nAfter reading the letter Nat\xc3\xa1sha sat down at the writing table\nto answer it. \xe2\x80\x9cDear Princess,\xe2\x80\x9d she wrote in French quickly and\nmechanically, and then paused. What more could she write after all that\nhad happened the evening before? \xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes! All that has happened, and\nnow all is changed,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought as she sat with the letter she had\nbegun before her. \xe2\x80\x9cMust I break off with him? Must I really? That\xe2\x80\x99s\nawful...\xe2\x80\x9d and to escape from these dreadful thoughts she went to\nS\xc3\xb3nya and began sorting patterns with her.\n\nAfter dinner Nat\xc3\xa1sha went to her room and again took up Princess\nMary\xe2\x80\x99s letter. \xe2\x80\x9cCan it be that it is all over?\xe2\x80\x9d she thought.\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan it be that all this has happened so quickly and has destroyed all\nthat went before?\xe2\x80\x9d She recalled her love for Prince Andrew in all its\nformer strength, and at the same time felt that she loved Kur\xc3\xa1gin. She\nvividly pictured herself as Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s wife, and the scenes of\nhappiness with him she had so often repeated in her imagination, and\nat the same time, aglow with excitement, recalled every detail of\nyesterday\xe2\x80\x99s interview with Anatole.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy could that not be as well?\xe2\x80\x9d she sometimes asked herself in\ncomplete bewilderment. \xe2\x80\x9cOnly so could I be completely happy; but now I\nhave to choose, and I can\xe2\x80\x99t be happy without either of them. Only,\xe2\x80\x9d\nshe thought, \xe2\x80\x9cto tell Prince Andrew what has happened or to hide\nit from him are both equally impossible. But with that one nothing is\nspoiled. But am I really to abandon forever the joy of Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s\nlove, in which I have lived so long?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease, Miss!\xe2\x80\x9d whispered a maid entering the room with a mysterious\nair. \xe2\x80\x9cA man told me to give you this\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d and she handed Nat\xc3\xa1sha a\nletter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly, for Christ\xe2\x80\x99s sake...\xe2\x80\x9d the girl went on, as Nat\xc3\xa1sha,\nwithout thinking, mechanically broke the seal and read a love letter\nfrom Anatole, of which, without taking in a word, she understood only\nthat it was a letter from him\xe2\x80\x94from the man she loved. Yes, she loved\nhim, or else how could that have happened which had happened? And how\ncould she have a love letter from him in her hand?\n\nWith trembling hands Nat\xc3\xa1sha held that passionate love letter which\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov had composed for Anatole, and as she read it she found in it\nan echo of all that she herself imagined she was feeling.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSince yesterday evening my fate has been sealed; to be loved by you\nor to die. There is no other way for me,\xe2\x80\x9d the letter began. Then he\nwent on to say that he knew her parents would not give her to him\xe2\x80\x94for\nthis there were secret reasons he could reveal only to her\xe2\x80\x94but that if\nshe loved him she need only say the word yes, and no human power could\nhinder their bliss. Love would conquer all. He would steal her away and\ncarry her off to the ends of the earth.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes! I love him!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Nat\xc3\xa1sha, reading the letter for the\ntwentieth time and finding some peculiarly deep meaning in each word of\nit.\n\nThat evening M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna was going to the Akh\xc3\xa1rovs\xe2\x80\x99 and\nproposed to take the girls with her. Nat\xc3\xa1sha, pleading a headache,\nremained at home.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XV\n\nOn returning late in the evening S\xc3\xb3nya went to Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s room, and\nto her surprise found her still dressed and asleep on the sofa. Open on\nthe table, beside her lay Anatole\xe2\x80\x99s letter. S\xc3\xb3nya picked it up and\nread it.\n\nAs she read she glanced at the sleeping Nat\xc3\xa1sha, trying to find in her\nface an explanation of what she was reading, but did not find it. Her\nface was calm, gentle, and happy. Clutching her breast to keep herself\nfrom choking, S\xc3\xb3nya, pale and trembling with fear and agitation, sat\ndown in an armchair and burst into tears.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow was it I noticed nothing? How could it go so far? Can she have\nleft off loving Prince Andrew? And how could she let Kur\xc3\xa1gin go to\nsuch lengths? He is a deceiver and a villain, that\xe2\x80\x99s plain! What will\nNicholas, dear noble Nicholas, do when he hears of it? So this is\nthe meaning of her excited, resolute, unnatural look the day before\nyesterday, yesterday, and today,\xe2\x80\x9d thought S\xc3\xb3nya. \xe2\x80\x9cBut it can\xe2\x80\x99t be\nthat she loves him! She probably opened the letter without knowing who\nit was from. Probably she is offended by it. She could not do such a\nthing!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya wiped away her tears and went up to Nat\xc3\xa1sha, again scanning her\nface.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1sha!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, just audibly.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha awoke and saw S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you\xe2\x80\x99re back?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd with the decision and tenderness that often come at the moment of\nawakening, she embraced her friend, but noticing S\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s look of\nembarrassment, her own face expressed confusion and suspicion.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xb3nya, you\xe2\x80\x99ve read that letter?\xe2\x80\x9d she demanded.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d answered S\xc3\xb3nya softly.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha smiled rapturously.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, S\xc3\xb3nya, I can\xe2\x80\x99t any longer!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t hide it\nfrom you any longer. You know, we love one another! S\xc3\xb3nya, darling, he\nwrites... S\xc3\xb3nya...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya stared open-eyed at Nat\xc3\xa1sha, unable to believe her ears.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Bolk\xc3\xb3nski?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, S\xc3\xb3nya, if you only knew how happy I am!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know what love is....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Nat\xc3\xa1sha, can that be all over?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha looked at S\xc3\xb3nya with wide-open eyes as if she could not grasp\nthe question.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, are you refusing Prince Andrew?\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you don\xe2\x80\x99t understand anything! Don\xe2\x80\x99t talk nonsense, just\nlisten!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha, with momentary vexation.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I can\xe2\x80\x99t believe it,\xe2\x80\x9d insisted S\xc3\xb3nya. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t\nunderstand. How is it you have loved a man for a whole year and\nsuddenly... Why, you have only seen him three times! Nat\xc3\xa1sha, I don\xe2\x80\x99t\nbelieve you, you\xe2\x80\x99re joking! In three days to forget everything and\nso...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree days?\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me I\xe2\x80\x99ve loved him a\nhundred years. It seems to me that I have never loved anyone before. You\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t understand it.... S\xc3\xb3nya, wait a bit, sit here,\xe2\x80\x9d and Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nembraced and kissed her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had heard that it happens like this, and you must have heard it\ntoo, but it\xe2\x80\x99s only now that I feel such love. It\xe2\x80\x99s not the same as\nbefore. As soon as I saw him I felt he was my master and I his slave,\nand that I could not help loving him. Yes, his slave! Whatever he orders\nI shall do. You don\xe2\x80\x99t understand that. What can I do? What can I do,\nS\xc3\xb3nya?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nat\xc3\xa1sha with a happy yet frightened expression.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut think what you are doing,\xe2\x80\x9d cried S\xc3\xb3nya. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t leave\nit like this. This secret correspondence... How could you let him go so\nfar?\xe2\x80\x9d she went on, with a horror and disgust she could hardly conceal.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told you that I have no will,\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha replied. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy can\xe2\x80\x99t\nyou understand? I love him!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I won\xe2\x80\x99t let it come to that... I shall tell!\xe2\x80\x9d cried S\xc3\xb3nya,\nbursting into tears.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean? For God\xe2\x80\x99s sake... If you tell, you are my\nenemy!\xe2\x80\x9d declared Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cYou want me to be miserable, you want us\nto be separated....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nWhen she saw Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s fright, S\xc3\xb3nya shed tears of shame and pity\nfor her friend.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what has happened between you?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat has he said\nto you? Why doesn\xe2\x80\x99t he come to the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha did not answer her questions.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, S\xc3\xb3nya, don\xe2\x80\x99t tell anyone, don\xe2\x80\x99t torture\nme,\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha entreated. \xe2\x80\x9cRemember no one ought to interfere in such\nmatters! I have confided in you....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why this secrecy? Why doesn\xe2\x80\x99t he come to the house?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\nS\xc3\xb3nya. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy doesn\xe2\x80\x99t he openly ask for your hand? You know Prince\nAndrew gave you complete freedom\xe2\x80\x94if it is really so; but I don\xe2\x80\x99t\nbelieve it! Nat\xc3\xa1sha, have you considered what these secret reasons can\nbe?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha looked at S\xc3\xb3nya with astonishment. Evidently this question\npresented itself to her mind for the first time and she did not know how\nto answer it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know what the reasons are. But there must be reasons!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya sighed and shook her head incredulously.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf there were reasons...\xe2\x80\x9d she began.\n\nBut Nat\xc3\xa1sha, guessing her doubts, interrupted her in alarm.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xb3nya, one can\xe2\x80\x99t doubt him! One can\xe2\x80\x99t, one can\xe2\x80\x99t! Don\xe2\x80\x99t you\nunderstand?\xe2\x80\x9d she cried.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes he love you?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes he love me?\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha repeated with a smile of pity at her\nfriend\xe2\x80\x99s lack of comprehension. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you have read his letter and\nyou have seen him.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if he is dishonorable?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe! dishonorable? If you only knew!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he is an honorable man he should either declare his intentions or\ncease seeing you; and if you won\xe2\x80\x99t do this, I will. I will write to\nhim, and I will tell Papa!\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya resolutely.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I can\xe2\x80\x99t live without him!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1sha, I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand you. And what are you saying! Think of\nyour father and of Nicholas.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want anyone, I don\xe2\x80\x99t love anyone but him. How dare you\nsay he is dishonorable? Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know that I love him?\xe2\x80\x9d screamed\nNat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cGo away, S\xc3\xb3nya! I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to quarrel with you, but\ngo, for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake go! You see how I am suffering!\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha cried\nangrily, in a voice of despair and repressed irritation. S\xc3\xb3nya burst\ninto sobs and ran from the room.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha went to the table and without a moment\xe2\x80\x99s reflection wrote\nthat answer to Princess Mary which she had been unable to write all\nthe morning. In this letter she said briefly that all their\nmisunderstandings were at an end; that availing herself of the\nmagnanimity of Prince Andrew who when he went abroad had given her her\nfreedom, she begged Princess Mary to forget everything and forgive her\nif she had been to blame toward her, but that she could not be his\nwife. At that moment this all seemed quite easy, simple, and clear to\nNat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\nOn Friday the Rost\xc3\xb3vs were to return to the country, but on Wednesday\nthe count went with the prospective purchaser to his estate near Moscow.\n\nOn the day the count left, S\xc3\xb3nya and Nat\xc3\xa1sha were invited to a big\ndinner party at the Kar\xc3\xa1gins\xe2\x80\x99, and M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna took them\nthere. At that party Nat\xc3\xa1sha again met Anatole, and S\xc3\xb3nya noticed\nthat she spoke to him, trying not to be overheard, and that all through\ndinner she was more agitated than ever. When they got home Nat\xc3\xa1sha was\nthe first to begin the explanation S\xc3\xb3nya expected.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, S\xc3\xb3nya, you were talking all sorts of nonsense about him,\xe2\x80\x9d\nNat\xc3\xa1sha began in a mild voice such as children use when they wish to be\npraised. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have had an explanation today.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what happened? What did he say? Nat\xc3\xa1sha, how glad I am\nyou\xe2\x80\x99re not angry with me! Tell me everything\xe2\x80\x94the whole truth. What\ndid he say?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha became thoughtful.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, S\xc3\xb3nya, if you knew him as I do! He said... He asked me what I\nhad promised Bolk\xc3\xb3nski. He was glad I was free to refuse him.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya sighed sorrowfully.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you haven\xe2\x80\x99t refused Bolk\xc3\xb3nski?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps I have. Perhaps all is over between me and Bolk\xc3\xb3nski. Why do\nyou think so badly of me?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think anything, only I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand this...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a bit, S\xc3\xb3nya, you\xe2\x80\x99ll understand everything. You\xe2\x80\x99ll see what\na man he is! Now don\xe2\x80\x99t think badly of me or of him. I don\xe2\x80\x99t think\nbadly of anyone: I love and pity everybody. But what am I to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya did not succumb to the tender tone Nat\xc3\xa1sha used toward her.\nThe more emotional and ingratiating the expression of Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s face\nbecame, the more serious and stern grew S\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1sha,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cyou asked me not to speak to you, and I\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t spoken, but now you yourself have begun. I don\xe2\x80\x99t trust him,\nNat\xc3\xa1sha. Why this secrecy?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAgain, again!\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1sha, I am afraid for you!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfraid of what?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid you\xe2\x80\x99re going to your ruin,\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya resolutely,\nand was herself horrified at what she had said.\n\nAnger again showed in Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I\xe2\x80\x99ll go to my ruin, I will, as soon as possible! It\xe2\x80\x99s not\nyour business! It won\xe2\x80\x99t be you, but I, who\xe2\x80\x99ll suffer. Leave me\nalone, leave me alone! I hate you!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1sha!\xe2\x80\x9d moaned S\xc3\xb3nya, aghast.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hate you, I hate you! You\xe2\x80\x99re my enemy forever!\xe2\x80\x9d And Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nran out of the room.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha did not speak to S\xc3\xb3nya again and avoided her. With the same\nexpression of agitated surprise and guilt she went about the house,\ntaking up now one occupation, now another, and at once abandoning them.\n\nHard as it was for S\xc3\xb3nya, she watched her friend and did not let her\nout of her sight.\n\nThe day before the count was to return, S\xc3\xb3nya noticed that Nat\xc3\xa1sha sat\nby the drawing room window all the morning as if expecting something and\nthat she made a sign to an officer who drove past, whom S\xc3\xb3nya took to\nbe Anatole.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya began watching her friend still more attentively and noticed that\nat dinner and all that evening Nat\xc3\xa1sha was in a strange and unnatural\nstate. She answered questions at random, began sentences she did not\nfinish, and laughed at everything.\n\nAfter tea S\xc3\xb3nya noticed a housemaid at Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s door timidly\nwaiting to let her pass. She let the girl go in, and then listening at\nthe door learned that another letter had been delivered.\n\nThen suddenly it became clear to S\xc3\xb3nya that Nat\xc3\xa1sha had some dreadful\nplan for that evening. S\xc3\xb3nya knocked at her door. Nat\xc3\xa1sha did not let\nher in.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe will run away with him!\xe2\x80\x9d thought S\xc3\xb3nya. \xe2\x80\x9cShe is capable of\nanything. There was something particularly pathetic and resolute in\nher face today.
