She cried as she said good-by to Uncle,\xe2\x80\x9d S\xc3\xb3nya\nremembered. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, that\xe2\x80\x99s it, she means to elope with him, but\nwhat am I to do?\xe2\x80\x9d thought she, recalling all the signs that clearly\nindicated that Nat\xc3\xa1sha had some terrible intention. \xe2\x80\x9cThe count is\naway. What am I to do? Write to Kur\xc3\xa1gin demanding an explanation? But\nwhat is there to oblige him to reply? Write to Pierre, as Prince Andrew\nasked me to in case of some misfortune?... But perhaps she really\nhas already refused Bolk\xc3\xb3nski\xe2\x80\x94she sent a letter to Princess Mary\nyesterday. And Uncle is away....\xe2\x80\x9d To tell M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna who had\nsuch faith in Nat\xc3\xa1sha seemed to S\xc3\xb3nya terrible. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, anyway,\xe2\x80\x9d\nthought S\xc3\xb3nya as she stood in the dark passage, \xe2\x80\x9cnow or never I must\nprove that I remember the family\xe2\x80\x99s goodness to me and that I love\nNicholas. Yes! If I don\xe2\x80\x99t sleep for three nights I\xe2\x80\x99ll not leave this\npassage and will hold her back by force and will and not let the family\nbe disgraced,\xe2\x80\x9d thought she.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVI\n\nAnatole had lately moved to D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s. The plan for Natalie\nRost\xc3\xb3va\xe2\x80\x99s abduction had been arranged and the preparations made by\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov a few days before, and on the day that S\xc3\xb3nya, after listening\nat Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s door, resolved to safeguard her, it was to have been\nput into execution. Nat\xc3\xa1sha had promised to come out to Kur\xc3\xa1gin at the\nback porch at ten that evening. Kur\xc3\xa1gin was to put her into a troyka\nhe would have ready and to drive her forty miles to the village of\nK\xc3\xa1menka, where an unfrocked priest was in readiness to perform a\nmarriage ceremony over them. At K\xc3\xa1menka a relay of horses was to wait\nwhich would take them to the Warsaw highroad, and from there they would\nhasten abroad with post horses.\n\nAnatole had a passport, an order for post horses, ten thousand rubles\nhe had taken from his sister and another ten thousand borrowed with\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s help.\n\nTwo witnesses for the mock marriage\xe2\x80\x94Khv\xc3\xb3stikov, a retired petty\nofficial whom D\xc3\xb3lokhov made use of in his gambling transactions, and\nMak\xc3\xa1rin, a retired hussar, a kindly, weak fellow who had an unbounded\naffection for Kur\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x94were sitting at tea in D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s front\nroom.\n\nIn his large study, the walls of which were hung to the ceiling with\nPersian rugs, bearskins, and weapons, sat D\xc3\xb3lokhov in a traveling cloak\nand high boots, at an open desk on which lay an abacus and some bundles\nof paper money. Anatole, with uniform unbuttoned, walked to and fro from\nthe room where the witnesses were sitting, through the study to the room\nbehind, where his French valet and others were packing the last of his\nthings. D\xc3\xb3lokhov was counting the money and noting something down.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cKhv\xc3\xb3stikov must have two thousand.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive it to him, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMak\xc3\xa1rka\xe2\x80\x9d (their name for Mak\xc3\xa1rin) \xe2\x80\x9cwill go through fire and\nwater for you for nothing. So here are our accounts all settled,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov, showing him the memorandum. \xe2\x80\x9cIs that right?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, of course,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Anatole, evidently not listening to\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov and looking straight before him with a smile that did not\nleave his face.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov banged down the lid of his desk and turned to Anatole with an\nironic smile:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know? You\xe2\x80\x99d really better drop it all. There\xe2\x80\x99s still\ntime!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFool,\xe2\x80\x9d retorted Anatole. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t talk nonsense! If you only\nknew... it\xe2\x80\x99s the devil knows what!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, really, give it up!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov. \xe2\x80\x9cI am speaking\nseriously. It\xe2\x80\x99s no joke, this plot you\xe2\x80\x99ve hatched.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, teasing again? Go to the devil! Eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole, making a\ngrimace. \xe2\x80\x9cReally it\xe2\x80\x99s no time for your stupid jokes,\xe2\x80\x9d and he left\nthe room.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov smiled contemptuously and condescendingly when Anatole had\ngone out.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wait a bit,\xe2\x80\x9d he called after him. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not joking, I\xe2\x80\x99m\ntalking sense. Come here, come here!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnatole returned and looked at D\xc3\xb3lokhov, trying to give him his\nattention and evidently submitting to him involuntarily.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow listen to me. I\xe2\x80\x99m telling you this for the last time. Why\nshould I joke about it? Did I hinder you? Who arranged everything for\nyou? Who found the priest and got the passport? Who raised the money? I\ndid it all.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, thank you for it. Do you think I am not grateful?\xe2\x80\x9d And\nAnatole sighed and embraced D\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI helped you, but all the same I must tell you the truth; it is a\ndangerous business, and if you think about it\xe2\x80\x94a stupid business. Well,\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll carry her off\xe2\x80\x94all right! Will they let it stop at that? It\nwill come out that you\xe2\x80\x99re already married. Why, they\xe2\x80\x99ll have you in\nthe criminal court....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nonsense, nonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d Anatole ejaculated and again made a\ngrimace. \xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t I explain to you? What?\xe2\x80\x9d And Anatole, with the\npartiality dull-witted people have for any conclusion they have reached\nby their own reasoning, repeated the argument he had already put to\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov a hundred times. \xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t I explain to you that I have come\nto this conclusion: if this marriage is invalid,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, crooking\none finger, \xe2\x80\x9cthen I have nothing to answer for; but if it is valid, no\nmatter! Abroad no one will know anything about it. Isn\xe2\x80\x99t that so? And\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t talk to me, don\xe2\x80\x99t, don\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeriously, you\xe2\x80\x99d better drop it! You\xe2\x80\x99ll only get yourself into a\nmess!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to the devil!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Anatole and, clutching his hair, left the\nroom, but returned at once and dropped into an armchair in front of\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov with his feet turned under him. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the very devil!\nWhat? Feel how it beats!\xe2\x80\x9d He took D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s hand and put it on his\nheart. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a foot, my dear fellow! What a glance! A goddess!\xe2\x80\x9d he\nadded in French. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov with a cold smile and a gleam in his handsome insolent eyes\nlooked at him\xe2\x80\x94evidently wishing to get some more amusement out of him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell and when the money\xe2\x80\x99s gone, what then?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat then? Eh?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Anatole, sincerely perplexed by a thought\nof the future. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat then?... Then, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know.... But why talk\nnonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d He glanced at his watch. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s time!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnatole went into the back room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow then! Nearly ready? You\xe2\x80\x99re dawdling!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted to the\nservants.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov put away the money, called a footman whom he ordered to bring\nsomething for them to eat and drink before the journey, and went into\nthe room where Khv\xc3\xb3stikov and Mak\xc3\xa1rin were sitting.\n\nAnatole lay on the sofa in the study leaning on his elbow and smiling\npensively, while his handsome lips muttered tenderly to himself.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome and eat something. Have a drink!\xe2\x80\x9d D\xc3\xb3lokhov shouted to him\nfrom the other room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Anatole continuing to smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome! Balag\xc3\xa1 is here.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnatole rose and went into the dining room. Balag\xc3\xa1 was a famous troyka\ndriver who had known D\xc3\xb3lokhov and Anatole some six years and had given\nthem good service with his troykas. More than once when Anatole\xe2\x80\x99s\nregiment was stationed at Tver he had taken him from Tver in the\nevening, brought him to Moscow by daybreak, and driven him back again\nthe next night. More than once he had enabled D\xc3\xb3lokhov to escape when\npursued. More than once he had driven them through the town with gypsies\nand \xe2\x80\x9cladykins\xe2\x80\x9d as he called the cocottes. More than once in their\nservice he had run over pedestrians and upset vehicles in the streets\nof Moscow and had always been protected from the consequences by \xe2\x80\x9cmy\ngentlemen\xe2\x80\x9d as he called them. He had ruined more than one horse in\ntheir service. More than once they had beaten him, and more than once\nthey had made him drunk on champagne and Madeira, which he loved; and\nhe knew more than one thing about each of them which would long ago have\nsent an ordinary man to Siberia. They often called Balag\xc3\xa1 into their\norgies and made him drink and dance at the gypsies\xe2\x80\x99, and more than one\nthousand rubles of their money had passed through his hands. In their\nservice he risked his skin and his life twenty times a year, and in\ntheir service had lost more horses than the money he had from them would\nbuy. But he liked them; liked that mad driving at twelve miles an hour,\nliked upsetting a driver or running down a pedestrian, and flying at\nfull gallop through the Moscow streets. He liked to hear those wild,\ntipsy shouts behind him: \xe2\x80\x9cGet on! Get on!\xe2\x80\x9d when it was impossible\nto go any faster. He liked giving a painful lash on the neck to some\npeasant who, more dead than alive, was already hurrying out of his way.\n\xe2\x80\x9cReal gentlemen!\xe2\x80\x9d he considered them.\n\nAnatole and D\xc3\xb3lokhov liked Balag\xc3\xa1 too for his masterly driving and\nbecause he liked the things they liked. With others Balag\xc3\xa1 bargained,\ncharging twenty-five rubles for a two hours\xe2\x80\x99 drive, and rarely\ndrove himself, generally letting his young men do so. But with \xe2\x80\x9chis\ngentlemen\xe2\x80\x9d he always drove himself and never demanded anything for\nhis work. Only a couple of times a year\xe2\x80\x94when he knew from their valets\nthat they had money in hand\xe2\x80\x94he would turn up of a morning quite sober\nand with a deep bow would ask them to help him. The gentlemen always\nmade him sit down.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo help me out, Theodore Iv\xc3\xa1nych, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cyour excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe would say. \xe2\x80\x9cI am quite out of horses. Let me have what you can to\ngo to the fair.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Anatole and D\xc3\xb3lokhov, when they had money, would give him a\nthousand or a couple of thousand rubles.\n\nBalag\xc3\xa1 was a fair-haired, short, and snub-nosed peasant of about\ntwenty-seven; red-faced, with a particularly red thick neck, glittering\nlittle eyes, and a small beard. He wore a fine, dark-blue, silk-lined\ncloth coat over a sheepskin.\n\nOn entering the room now he crossed himself, turning toward the front\ncorner of the room, and went up to D\xc3\xb3lokhov, holding out a small, black\nhand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTheodore Iv\xc3\xa1nych!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, bowing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow d\xe2\x80\x99you do, friend? Well, here he is!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood day, your excellency!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, again holding out his hand to\nAnatole who had just come in.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, Balag\xc3\xa1,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole, putting his hands on the man\xe2\x80\x99s\nshoulders, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you care for me or not? Eh? Now, do me a service....\nWhat horses have you come with? Eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs your messenger ordered, your special beasts,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Balag\xc3\xa1.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, listen, Balag\xc3\xa1! Drive all three to death but get me there in\nthree hours. Eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen they are dead, what shall I drive?\xe2\x80\x9d said Balag\xc3\xa1 with a wink.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMind, I\xe2\x80\x99ll smash your face in! Don\xe2\x80\x99t make jokes!\xe2\x80\x9d cried\nAnatole, suddenly rolling his eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy joke?\xe2\x80\x9d said the driver, laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cAs if I\xe2\x80\x99d grudge my\ngentlemen anything! As fast as ever the horses can gallop, so fast\nwe\xe2\x80\x99ll go!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, sit down.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sit down!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll stand, Theodore Iv\xc3\xa1nych.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit down; nonsense! Have a drink!\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole, and filled a large\nglass of Madeira for him.\n\nThe driver\xe2\x80\x99s eyes sparkled at the sight of the wine. After refusing\nit for manners\xe2\x80\x99 sake, he drank it and wiped his mouth with a red silk\nhandkerchief he took out of his cap.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when are we to start, your excellency?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell...\xe2\x80\x9d Anatole looked at his watch. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll start at once.\nMind, Balag\xc3\xa1! You\xe2\x80\x99ll get there in time? Eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat depends on our luck in starting, else why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t we be\nthere in time?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Balag\xc3\xa1. \xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t we get you to Tver in\nseven hours? I think you remember that, your excellency?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, one Christmas I drove from Tver,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole,\nsmilingly at the recollection and turning to Mak\xc3\xa1rin who gazed\nrapturously at him with wide-open eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cWill you believe it,\nMak\xc3\xa1rka, it took one\xe2\x80\x99s breath away, the rate we flew. We came across\na train of loaded sleighs and drove right over two of them. Eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose were horses!\xe2\x80\x9d Balag\xc3\xa1 continued the tale. \xe2\x80\x9cThat time I\xe2\x80\x99d\nharnessed two young side horses with the bay in the shafts,\xe2\x80\x9d he went\non, turning to D\xc3\xb3lokhov. \xe2\x80\x9cWill you believe it, Theodore Iv\xc3\xa1nych,\nthose animals flew forty miles? I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t hold them in, my hands grew\nnumb in the sharp frost so that I threw down the reins\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Catch hold\nyourself, your excellency!\xe2\x80\x99 says I, and I just tumbled on the bottom\nof the sleigh and sprawled there. It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a case of urging them on,\nthere was no holding them in till we reached the place. The devils took\nus there in three hours! Only the near one died of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVII\n\nAnatole went out of the room and returned a few minutes later wearing\na fur coat girt with a silver belt, and a sable cap jauntily set on one\nside and very becoming to his handsome face. Having looked in a mirror,\nand standing before D\xc3\xb3lokhov in the same pose he had assumed before it,\nhe lifted a glass of wine.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, good-by, Theodore. Thank you for everything and farewell!\xe2\x80\x9d said\nAnatole. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, comrades and friends...\xe2\x80\x9d he considered for a moment \xe2\x80\x9c...\nof my youth, farewell!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, turning to Mak\xc3\xa1rin and the others.\n\nThough they were all going with him, Anatole evidently wished to make\nsomething touching and solemn out of this address to his comrades. He\nspoke slowly in a loud voice and throwing out his chest slightly swayed\none leg.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll take glasses; you too, Balag\xc3\xa1. Well, comrades and friends of my\nyouth, we\xe2\x80\x99ve had our fling and lived and reveled. Eh? And now, when\nshall we meet again? I am going abroad. We have had a good time\xe2\x80\x94now\nfarewell, lads! To our health! Hurrah!...\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, and emptying his\nglass flung it on the floor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo your health!\xe2\x80\x9d said Balag\xc3\xa1 who also emptied his glass, and wiped his\nmouth with his handkerchief.\n\nMak\xc3\xa1rin embraced Anatole with tears in his eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Prince, how sorry I am to part from you!\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s go. Let\xe2\x80\x99s go!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Anatole.\n\nBalag\xc3\xa1 was about to leave the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, stop!\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole. \xe2\x80\x9cShut the door; we have first to sit down.\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s the way.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThey shut the door and all sat down.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, quick march, lads!\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole, rising.\n\nJoseph, his valet, handed him his sabretache and saber, and they all\nwent out into the vestibule.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where\xe2\x80\x99s the fur cloak?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xc3\xb3lokhov. \xe2\x80\x9cHey, Ign\xc3\xa1tka! Go to\nMatr\xc3\xabna Matr\xc3\xa9vna and ask her for the sable cloak. I have heard what\nelopements are like,\xe2\x80\x9d continued D\xc3\xb3lokhov with a wink. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, she\xe2\x80\x99ll rush\nout more dead than alive just in the things she is wearing; if you delay\nat all there\xe2\x80\x99ll be tears and \xe2\x80\x98Papa\xe2\x80\x99 and \xe2\x80\x98Mamma,\xe2\x80\x99 and she\xe2\x80\x99s frozen in a\nminute and must go back\xe2\x80\x94but you wrap the fur cloak round her first thing\nand carry her to the sleigh.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe valet brought a woman\xe2\x80\x99s fox-lined cloak.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFool, I told you the sable one! Hey, Matr\xc3\xabna, the sable!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted so\nthat his voice rang far through the rooms.\n\nA handsome, slim, and pale-faced gypsy girl with glittering black eyes\nand curly blue-black hair, wearing a red shawl, ran out with a sable\nmantle on her arm.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, I don\xe2\x80\x99t grudge it\xe2\x80\x94take it!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, evidently afraid of her\nmaster and yet regretful of her cloak.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov, without answering, took the cloak, threw it over Matr\xc3\xabna, and\nwrapped her up in it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the way,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov, \xe2\x80\x9cand then so!\xe2\x80\x9d and he turned the collar\nup round her head, leaving only a little of the face uncovered. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\nthen so, do you see?\xe2\x80\x9d and he pushed Anatole\xe2\x80\x99s head forward to meet the\ngap left by the collar, through which Matr\xc3\xabna\xe2\x80\x99s brilliant smile was\nseen.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, good-by, Matr\xc3\xabna,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole, kissing her. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, my revels here\nare over. Remember me to St\xc3\xabshka. There, good-by! Good-by, Matr\xc3\xabna, wish\nme luck!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Prince, may God give you great luck!\xe2\x80\x9d said Matr\xc3\xabna in her gypsy\naccent.\n\nTwo troykas were standing before the porch and two young drivers were\nholding the horses. Balag\xc3\xa1 took his seat in the front one and holding\nhis elbows high arranged the reins deliberately. Anatole and D\xc3\xb3lokhov\ngot in with him. Mak\xc3\xa1rin, Khv\xc3\xb3stikov, and a valet seated themselves in\nthe other sleigh.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, are you ready?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Balag\xc3\xa1.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, twisting the reins round his hands, and the troyka tore\ndown the Nik\xc3\xadtski Boulevard.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTproo! Get out of the way! Hi!... Tproo!...\xe2\x80\x9d The shouting of Balag\xc3\xa1\nand of the sturdy young fellow seated on the box was all that could\nbe heard. On the Arb\xc3\xa1t Square the troyka caught against a carriage;\nsomething cracked, shouts were heard, and the troyka flew along the\nArb\xc3\xa1t Street.\n\nAfter taking a turn along the Podnov\xc3\xadnski Boulevard, Balag\xc3\xa1 began to\nrein in, and turning back drew up at the crossing of the old Kony\xc3\xbasheny\nStreet.\n\nThe young fellow on the box jumped down to hold the horses and Anatole\nand D\xc3\xb3lokhov went along the pavement. When they reached the gate\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov whistled. The whistle was answered, and a maidservant ran out.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome into the courtyard or you\xe2\x80\x99ll be seen; she\xe2\x80\x99ll come out directly,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid she.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov stayed by the gate. Anatole followed the maid into the\ncourtyard, turned the corner, and ran up into the porch.\n\nHe was met by Gabriel, M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\xe2\x80\x99s gigantic footman.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome to the mistress, please,\xe2\x80\x9d said the footman in his deep bass,\nintercepting any retreat.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo what Mistress? Who are you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Anatole in a breathless whisper.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cKindly step in, my orders are to bring you in.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cKur\xc3\xa1gin! Come back!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted D\xc3\xb3lokhov. \xe2\x80\x9cBetrayed! Back!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov, after Anatole entered, had remained at the wicket gate and was\nstruggling with the yard porter who was trying to lock it. With a last\ndesperate effort D\xc3\xb3lokhov pushed the porter aside, and when Anatole ran\nback seized him by the arm, pulled him through the wicket, and ran back\nwith him to the troyka.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVIII\n\nM\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna, having found S\xc3\xb3nya weeping in the corridor, made her\nconfess everything, and intercepting the note to Nat\xc3\xa1sha she read it and\nwent into Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s room with it in her hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shameless good-for-nothing!\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t hear a word.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPushing back Nat\xc3\xa1sha who looked at her with astonished but tearless\neyes, she locked her in; and having given orders to the yard porter to\nadmit the persons who would be coming that evening, but not to let them\nout again, and having told the footman to bring them up to her, she\nseated herself in the drawing room to await the abductors.\n\nWhen Gabriel came to inform her that the men who had come had run\naway again, she rose frowning, and clasping her hands behind her paced\nthrough the rooms a long time considering what she should do. Toward\nmidnight she went to Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s room fingering the key in her pocket.\nS\xc3\xb3nya was sitting sobbing in the corridor. \xe2\x80\x9cM\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna, for God\xe2\x80\x99s\nsake let me in to her!\xe2\x80\x9d she pleaded, but M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna unlocked\nthe door and went in without giving her an answer.... \xe2\x80\x9cDisgusting,\nabominable... In my house... horrid girl, hussy! I\xe2\x80\x99m only sorry for her\nfather!\xe2\x80\x9d thought she, trying to restrain her wrath. \xe2\x80\x9cHard as it may\nbe, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell them all to hold their tongues and will hide it from the\ncount.\xe2\x80\x9d She entered the room with resolute steps. Nat\xc3\xa1sha lying on the\nsofa, her head hidden in her hands, and she did not stir. She was in\njust the same position in which M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna had left her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA nice girl! Very nice!\xe2\x80\x9d said M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna. \xe2\x80\x9cArranging meetings\nwith lovers in my house! It\xe2\x80\x99s no use pretending: you listen when I speak\nto you!\xe2\x80\x9d And M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna touched her arm. \xe2\x80\x9cListen when I speak!\nYou\xe2\x80\x99ve disgraced yourself like the lowest of hussies. I\xe2\x80\x99d treat you\ndifferently, but I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry for your father, so I will conceal it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha did not change her position, but her whole body heaved with\nnoiseless, convulsive sobs which choked her. M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna glanced\nround at S\xc3\xb3nya and seated herself on the sofa beside Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s lucky for him that he escaped me; but I\xe2\x80\x99ll find him!\xe2\x80\x9d she said in\nher rough voice. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you hear what I am saying or not?\xe2\x80\x9d she added.\n\nShe put her large hand under Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s face and turned it toward her.\nBoth M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna and S\xc3\xb3nya were amazed when they saw how Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nlooked. Her eyes were dry and glistening, her lips compressed, her\ncheeks sunken.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me be!... What is it to me?... I shall die!\xe2\x80\x9d she muttered,\nwrenching herself from M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\xe2\x80\x99s hands with a vicious effort\nand sinking down again into her former position.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNatalie!\xe2\x80\x9d said M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish for your good. Lie still,\nstay like that then, I won\xe2\x80\x99t touch you. But listen. I won\xe2\x80\x99t tell you how\nguilty you are. You know that yourself. But when your father comes back\ntomorrow what am I to tell him? Eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAgain Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s body shook with sobs.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose he finds out, and your brother, and your betrothed?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no betrothed: I have refused him!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all the same,\xe2\x80\x9d continued M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna. \xe2\x80\x9cIf they hear of\nthis, will they let it pass? He, your father, I know him... if he\nchallenges him to a duel will that be all right? Eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, let me be! Why have you interfered at all? Why? Why? Who asked\nyou to?\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Nat\xc3\xa1sha, raising herself on the sofa and looking\nmalignantly at M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what did you want?\xe2\x80\x9d cried M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna, growing angry again.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere you kept under lock and key? Who hindered his coming to the house?\nWhy carry you off as if you were some gypsy singing girl?... Well, if he\nhad carried you off... do you think they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have found him?\nYour father, or brother, or your betrothed? And he\xe2\x80\x99s a scoundrel, a\nwretch\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s a fact!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is better than any of you!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Nat\xc3\xa1sha getting up. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you\nhadn\xe2\x80\x99t interfered... Oh, my God! What is it all? What is it? S\xc3\xb3nya,\nwhy?... Go away!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd she burst into sobs with the despairing vehemence with which people\nbewail disasters they feel they have themselves occasioned. M\xc3\xa1rya\nDm\xc3\xadtrievna was to speak again but Nat\xc3\xa1sha cried out:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo away! Go away! You all hate and despise me!\xe2\x80\x9d and she threw herself\nback on the sofa.\n\nM\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna went on admonishing her for some time, enjoining on her\nthat it must all be kept from her father and assuring her that nobody\nwould know anything about it if only Nat\xc3\xa1sha herself would undertake\nto forget it all and not let anyone see that something had happened.\nNat\xc3\xa1sha did not reply, nor did she sob any longer, but she grew cold\nand had a shivering fit. M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna put a pillow under her head,\ncovered her with two quilts, and herself brought her some lime-flower\nwater, but Nat\xc3\xa1sha did not respond to her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, let her sleep,\xe2\x80\x9d said M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna as she went out of the room\nsupposing Nat\xc3\xa1sha to be asleep.\n\nBut Nat\xc3\xa1sha was not asleep; with pale face and fixed wide-open eyes she\nlooked straight before her. All that night she did not sleep or weep and\ndid not speak to S\xc3\xb3nya who got up and went to her several times.\n\nNext day Count Rost\xc3\xb3v returned from his estate near Moscow in time for\nlunch as he had promised. He was in very good spirits; the affair with\nthe purchaser was going on satisfactorily, and there was nothing to keep\nhim any longer in Moscow, away from the countess whom he missed. M\xc3\xa1rya\nDm\xc3\xadtrievna met him and told him that Nat\xc3\xa1sha had been very unwell the\nday before and that they had sent for the doctor, but that she was\nbetter now. Nat\xc3\xa1sha had not left her room that morning. With compressed\nand parched lips and dry fixed eyes, she sat at the window, uneasily\nwatching the people who drove past and hurriedly glancing round at\nanyone who entered the room. She was evidently expecting news of him and\nthat he would come or would write to her.\n\nWhen the count came to see her she turned anxiously round at the sound\nof a man\xe2\x80\x99s footstep, and then her face resumed its cold and malevolent\nexpression. She did not even get up to greet him. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter\nwith you, my angel? Are you ill?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the count.\n\nAfter a moment\xe2\x80\x99s silence Nat\xc3\xa1sha answered: \xe2\x80\x9cYes, ill.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIn reply to the count\xe2\x80\x99s anxious inquiries as to why she was so dejected\nand whether anything had happened to her betrothed, she assured him\nthat nothing had happened and asked him not to worry. M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\nconfirmed Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s assurances that nothing had happened. From\nthe pretense of illness, from his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s distress, and by the\nembarrassed faces of S\xc3\xb3nya and M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna, the count saw clearly\nthat something had gone wrong during his absence, but it was so terrible\nfor him to think that anything disgraceful had happened to his beloved\ndaughter, and he so prized his own cheerful tranquillity, that he\navoided inquiries and tried to assure himself that nothing particularly\nhad happened; and he was only dissatisfied that her indisposition\ndelayed their return to the country.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIX\n\nFrom the day his wife arrived in Moscow Pierre had been intending to go\naway somewhere, so as not to be near her. Soon after the Rost\xc3\xb3vs came\nto Moscow the effect Nat\xc3\xa1sha had on him made him hasten to carry out\nhis intention. He went to Tver to see Joseph Alex\xc3\xa9evich\xe2\x80\x99s widow, who\nhad long since promised to hand over to him some papers of her deceased\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s.\n\nWhen he returned to Moscow Pierre was handed a letter from M\xc3\xa1rya\nDm\xc3\xadtrievna asking him to come and see her on a matter of great\nimportance relating to Andrew Bolk\xc3\xb3nski and his betrothed. Pierre had\nbeen avoiding Nat\xc3\xa1sha because it seemed to him that his feeling for her\nwas stronger than a married man\xe2\x80\x99s should be for his friend\xe2\x80\x99s fianc\xc3\xa9e.\nYet some fate constantly threw them together.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can have happened? And what can they want with me?\xe2\x80\x9d thought he\nas he dressed to go to M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\xe2\x80\x99s. \xe2\x80\x9cIf only Prince Andrew would\nhurry up and come and marry her!\xe2\x80\x9d thought he on his way to the house.\n\nOn the Tversk\xc3\xb3y Boulevard a familiar voice called to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPierre! Been back long?\xe2\x80\x9d someone shouted. Pierre raised his head. In\na sleigh drawn by two gray trotting-horses that were bespattering the\ndashboard with snow, Anatole and his constant companion Mak\xc3\xa1rin dashed\npast. Anatole was sitting upright in the classic pose of military\ndandies, the lower part of his face hidden by his beaver collar and his\nhead slightly bent. His face was fresh and rosy, his white-plumed hat,\ntilted to one side, disclosed his curled and pomaded hair besprinkled\nwith powdery snow.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed, that\xe2\x80\x99s a true sage,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Pierre. \xe2\x80\x9cHe sees nothing\nbeyond the pleasure of the moment, nothing troubles him and so he is\nalways cheerful, satisfied, and serene. What wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t I give to be like\nhim!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought enviously.\n\nIn M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\xe2\x80\x99s anteroom the footman who helped him off with his\nfur coat said that the mistress asked him to come to her bedroom.\n\nWhen he opened the ballroom door Pierre saw Nat\xc3\xa1sha sitting at the\nwindow, with a thin, pale, and spiteful face. She glanced round at him,\nfrowned, and left the room with an expression of cold dignity.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has happened?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pierre, entering M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\xe2\x80\x99s room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFine doings!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Dm\xc3\xadtrievna. \xe2\x80\x9cFor fifty-eight years have I lived\nin this world and never known anything so disgraceful!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd having put him on his honor not to repeat anything she told him,\nM\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna informed him that Nat\xc3\xa1sha had refused Prince Andrew\nwithout her parents\xe2\x80\x99 knowledge and that the cause of this was Anatole\nKur\xc3\xa1gin into whose society Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s wife had thrown her and with whom\nNat\xc3\xa1sha had tried to elope during her father\xe2\x80\x99s absence, in order to be\nmarried secretly.\n\nPierre raised his shoulders and listened open-mouthed to what was told\nhim, scarcely able to believe his own ears. That Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s\ndeeply loved affianced wife\xe2\x80\x94the same Nat\xc3\xa1sha Rost\xc3\xb3va who used to be so\ncharming\xe2\x80\x94should give up Bolk\xc3\xb3nski for that fool Anatole who was already\nsecretly married (as Pierre knew), and should be so in love with him as\nto agree to run away with him, was something Pierre could not conceive\nand could not imagine.\n\nHe could not reconcile the charming impression he had of Nat\xc3\xa1sha, whom\nhe had known from a child, with this new conception of her baseness,\nfolly, and cruelty. He thought of his wife. \xe2\x80\x9cThey are all alike!\xe2\x80\x9d he\nsaid to himself, reflecting that he was not the only man unfortunate\nenough to be tied to a bad woman. But still he pitied Prince Andrew to\nthe point of tears and sympathized with his wounded pride, and the more\nhe pitied his friend the more did he think with contempt and even with\ndisgust of that Nat\xc3\xa1sha who had just passed him in the ballroom with\nsuch a look of cold dignity. He did not know that Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s soul was\noverflowing with despair, shame, and humiliation, and that it was not\nher fault that her face happened to assume an expression of calm dignity\nand severity.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how get married?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, in answer to M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\ncould not marry\xe2\x80\x94he is married!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThings get worse from hour to hour!\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna. \xe2\x80\x9cA\nnice youth! What a scoundrel! And she\xe2\x80\x99s expecting him\xe2\x80\x94expecting him\nsince yesterday. She must be told! Then at least she won\xe2\x80\x99t go on\nexpecting him.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAfter hearing the details of Anatole\xe2\x80\x99s marriage from Pierre, and giving\nvent to her anger against Anatole in words of abuse, M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\ntold Pierre why she had sent for him. She was afraid that the count or\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski, who might arrive at any moment, if they knew of this affair\n(which she hoped to hide from them) might challenge Anatole to a duel,\nand she therefore asked Pierre to tell his brother-in-law in her name to\nleave Moscow and not dare to let her set eyes on him again. Pierre\xe2\x80\x94only\nnow realizing the danger to the old count, Nicholas, and Prince\nAndrew\xe2\x80\x94promised to do as she wished. Having briefly and exactly\nexplained her wishes to him, she let him go to the drawing room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMind, the count knows nothing. Behave as if you know nothing either,\xe2\x80\x9d\nshe said. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd I will go and tell her it is no use expecting him! And\nstay to dinner if you care to!\xe2\x80\x9d she called after Pierre.\n\nPierre met the old count, who seemed nervous and upset. That morning\nNat\xc3\xa1sha had told him that she had rejected Bolk\xc3\xb3nski.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTroubles, troubles, my dear fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Pierre. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat troubles\none has with these girls without their mother! I do so regret having\ncome here.... I will be frank with you. Have you heard she has broken\noff her engagement without consulting anybody? It\xe2\x80\x99s true this engagement\nnever was much to my liking. Of course he is an excellent man, but\nstill, with his father\xe2\x80\x99s disapproval they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been happy, and\nNat\xc3\xa1sha won\xe2\x80\x99t lack suitors. Still, it has been going on so long, and\nto take such a step without father\xe2\x80\x99s or mother\xe2\x80\x99s consent! And now she\xe2\x80\x99s\nill, and God knows what! It\xe2\x80\x99s hard, Count, hard to manage daughters in\ntheir mother\xe2\x80\x99s absence....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre saw that the count was much upset and tried to change the\nsubject, but the count returned to his troubles.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya entered the room with an agitated face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1sha is not quite well; she\xe2\x80\x99s in her room and would like to see you.\nM\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna is with her and she too asks you to come.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you are a great friend of Bolk\xc3\xb3nski\xe2\x80\x99s, no doubt she wants to send\nhim a message,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count. \xe2\x80\x9cOh dear! Oh dear! How happy it all\nwas!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd clutching the spare gray locks on his temples the count left the\nroom.\n\nWhen M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna told Nat\xc3\xa1sha that Anatole was married, Nat\xc3\xa1sha\ndid not wish to believe it and insisted on having it confirmed by Pierre\nhimself. S\xc3\xb3nya told Pierre this as she led him along the corridor to\nNat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s room.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, pale and stern, was sitting beside M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna, and her\neyes, glittering feverishly, met Pierre with a questioning look the\nmoment he entered. She did not smile or nod, but only gazed fixedly at\nhim, and her look asked only one thing: was he a friend, or like the\nothers an enemy in regard to Anatole? As for Pierre, he evidently did\nnot exist for her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe knows all about it,\xe2\x80\x9d said M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna pointing to Pierre and\naddressing Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cLet him tell you whether I have told the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha looked from one to the other as a hunted and wounded animal\nlooks at the approaching dogs and sportsmen.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1lya Ilyn\xc3\xadchna,\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre began, dropping his eyes with a feeling of\npity for her and loathing for the thing he had to do, \xe2\x80\x9cwhether it is\ntrue or not should make no difference to you, because...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen it is not true that he\xe2\x80\x99s married!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it is true.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas he been married long?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked. \xe2\x80\x9cOn your honor?...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre gave his word of honor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he still here?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, quickly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I have just seen him.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe was evidently unable to speak and made a sign with her hands that\nthey should leave her alone.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XX\n\nPierre did not stay for dinner, but left the room and went away at once.\nHe drove through the town seeking Anatole Kur\xc3\xa1gin, at the thought of\nwhom now the blood rushed to his heart and he felt a difficulty in\nbreathing. He was not at the ice hills, nor at the gypsies\xe2\x80\x99, nor at\nKomoneno\xe2\x80\x99s. Pierre drove to the Club. In the Club all was going on as\nusual. The members who were assembling for dinner were sitting about\nin groups; they greeted Pierre and spoke of the town news. The footman\nhaving greeted him, knowing his habits and his acquaintances, told him\nthere was a place left for him in the small dining room and that Prince\nMichael Zakh\xc3\xa1rych was in the library, but Paul Timof\xc3\xa9evich had not yet\narrived. One of Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s acquaintances, while they were talking about\nthe weather, asked if he had heard of Kur\xc3\xa1gin\xe2\x80\x99s abduction of Rost\xc3\xb3va\nwhich was talked of in the town, and was it true? Pierre laughed and\nsaid it was nonsense for he had just come from the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99. He asked\neveryone about Anatole. One man told him he had not come yet, and\nanother that he was coming to dinner. Pierre felt it strange to see this\ncalm, indifferent crowd of people unaware of what was going on in his\nsoul. He paced through the ballroom, waited till everyone had come, and\nas Anatole had not turned up did not stay for dinner but drove home.\n\nAnatole, for whom Pierre was looking, dined that day with D\xc3\xb3lokhov,\nconsulting him as to how to remedy this unfortunate affair. It seemed to\nhim essential to see Nat\xc3\xa1sha. In the evening he drove to his sister\xe2\x80\x99s\nto discuss with her how to arrange a meeting. When Pierre returned home\nafter vainly hunting all over Moscow, his valet informed him that Prince\nAnatole was with the countess. The countess\xe2\x80\x99 drawing room was full of\nguests.\n\nPierre without greeting his wife whom he had not seen since his\nreturn\xe2\x80\x94at that moment she was more repulsive to him than ever\xe2\x80\x94entered\nthe drawing room and seeing Anatole went up to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Pierre,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess going up to her husband. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know\nwhat a plight our Anatole...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe stopped, seeing in the forward thrust of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s head, in his\nglowing eyes and his resolute gait, the terrible indications of that\nrage and strength which she knew and had herself experienced after his\nduel with D\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere you are, there is vice and evil!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre to his wife.\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnatole, come with me! I must speak to you,\xe2\x80\x9d he added in French.\n\nAnatole glanced round at his sister and rose submissively, ready to\nfollow Pierre. Pierre, taking him by the arm, pulled him toward himself\nand was leading him from the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you allow yourself in my drawing room...\xe2\x80\x9d whispered H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, but\nPierre did not reply and went out of the room.\n\nAnatole followed him with his usual jaunty step but his face betrayed\nanxiety.\n\nHaving entered his study Pierre closed the door and addressed Anatole\nwithout looking at him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou promised Countess Rost\xc3\xb3va to marry her and were about to elope with\nher, is that so?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMon cher,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Anatole (their whole conversation was in French),\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t consider myself bound to answer questions put to me in that\ntone.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre\xe2\x80\x99s face, already pale, became distorted by fury. He seized Anatole\nby the collar of his uniform with his big hand and shook him from side\nto side till Anatole\xe2\x80\x99s face showed a sufficient degree of terror.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I tell you that I must talk to you!...\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome now, this is stupid. What?\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole, fingering a button of\nhis collar that had been wrenched loose with a bit of the cloth.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re a scoundrel and a blackguard, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what deprives\nme from the pleasure of smashing your head with this!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre,\nexpressing himself so artificially because he was talking French.\n\nHe took a heavy paperweight and lifted it threateningly, but at once put\nit back in its place.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you promise to marry her?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI... I didn\xe2\x80\x99t think of it. I never promised, because...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre interrupted him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you any letters of hers? Any letters?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, moving toward\nAnatole.\n\nAnatole glanced at him and immediately thrust his hand into his pocket\nand drew out his pocketbook.\n\nPierre took the letter Anatole handed him and, pushing aside a table\nthat stood in his way, threw himself on the sofa.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shan\xe2\x80\x99t be violent, don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre in answer to a\nfrightened gesture of Anatole\xe2\x80\x99s. \xe2\x80\x9cFirst, the letters,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as if\nrepeating a lesson to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cSecondly,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued after a short\npause, again rising and again pacing the room, \xe2\x80\x9ctomorrow you must get\nout of Moscow.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how can I?...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThirdly,\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre continued without listening to him, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must never\nbreathe a word of what has passed between you and Countess Rost\xc3\xb3va.\nI know I can\xe2\x80\x99t prevent your doing so, but if you have a spark of\nconscience...\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre paced the room several times in silence.\n\nAnatole sat at a table frowning and biting his lips.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter all, you must understand that besides your pleasure there is such\na thing as other people\xe2\x80\x99s happiness and peace, and that you are ruining\na whole life for the sake of amusing yourself! Amuse yourself with women\nlike my wife\xe2\x80\x94with them you are within your rights, for they know what\nyou want of them. They are armed against you by the same experience\nof debauchery; but to promise a maid to marry her... to deceive, to\nkidnap.... Don\xe2\x80\x99t you understand that it is as mean as beating an old man\nor a child?...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre paused and looked at Anatole no longer with an angry but with a\nquestioning look.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know about that, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said Anatole, growing more confident as\nPierre mastered his wrath. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know that and don\xe2\x80\x99t want to,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nsaid, not looking at Pierre and with a slight tremor of his lower jaw,\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut you have used such words to me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98mean\xe2\x80\x99 and so on\xe2\x80\x94which as a man of\nhonor I can\xe2\x80\x99t allow anyone to use.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre glanced at him with amazement, unable to understand what he\nwanted.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThough it was t\xc3\xaate-\xc3\xa0-t\xc3\xaate,\xe2\x80\x9d Anatole continued, \xe2\x80\x9cstill I can\xe2\x80\x99t...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it satisfaction you want?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre ironically.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou could at least take back your words. What? If you want me to do as\nyou wish, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI take them back, I take them back!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, \xe2\x80\x9cand I ask you to\nforgive me.\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre involuntarily glanced at the loose button. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd if\nyou require money for your journey...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnatole smiled. The expression of that base and cringing smile, which\nPierre knew so well in his wife, revolted him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, vile and heartless brood!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, and left the room.\n\nNext day Anatole left for Petersburg.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XXI\n\nPierre drove to M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna\xe2\x80\x99s to tell her of the fulfillment of her\nwish that Kur\xc3\xa1gin should be banished from Moscow. The whole house was in\na state of alarm and commotion. Nat\xc3\xa1sha was very ill, having, as M\xc3\xa1rya\nDm\xc3\xadtrievna told him in secret, poisoned herself the night after she had\nbeen told that Anatole was married, with some arsenic she had stealthily\nprocured. After swallowing a little she had been so frightened that she\nwoke S\xc3\xb3nya and told her what she had done. The necessary antidotes had\nbeen administered in time and she was now out of danger, though still so\nweak that it was out of the question to move her to the country, and\nso the countess had been sent for. Pierre saw the distracted count, and\nS\xc3\xb3nya, who had a tear-stained face, but he could not see Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\nPierre dined at the club that day and heard on all sides gossip about\nthe attempted abduction of Rost\xc3\xb3va. He resolutely denied these\nrumors, assuring everyone that nothing had happened except that his\nbrother-in-law had proposed to her and been refused. It seemed to\nPierre that it was his duty to conceal the whole affair and re-establish\nNat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s reputation.\n\nHe was awaiting Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s return with dread and went every day to\nthe old prince\xe2\x80\x99s for news of him.\n\nOld Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski heard all the rumors current in the town from\nMademoiselle Bourienne and had read the note to Princess Mary in which\nNat\xc3\xa1sha had broken off her engagement. He seemed in better spirits than\nusual and awaited his son with great impatience.\n\nSome days after Anatole\xe2\x80\x99s departure Pierre received a note from Prince\nAndrew, informing him of his arrival and asking him to come to see him.\n\nAs soon as he reached Moscow, Prince Andrew had received from his\nfather Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s note to Princess Mary breaking off her engagement\n(Mademoiselle Bourienne had purloined it from Princess Mary and given\nit to the old prince), and he heard from him the story of Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s\nelopement, with additions.\n\nPrince Andrew had arrived in the evening and Pierre came to see him next\nmorning. Pierre expected to find Prince Andrew in almost the same state\nas Nat\xc3\xa1sha and was therefore surprised on entering the drawing room\nto hear him in the study talking in a loud animated voice about some\nintrigue going on in Petersburg. The old prince\xe2\x80\x99s voice and another now\nand then interrupted him. Princess Mary came out to meet Pierre. She\nsighed, looking toward the door of the room where Prince Andrew was,\nevidently intending to express her sympathy with his sorrow, but Pierre\nsaw by her face that she was glad both at what had happened and at the\nway her brother had taken the news of Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s faithlessness.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe says he expected it,\xe2\x80\x9d she remarked. \xe2\x80\x9cI know his pride will not let\nhim express his feelings, but still he has taken it better, far better,\nthan I expected. Evidently it had to be....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut is it possible that all is really ended?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pierre.\n\nPrincess Mary looked at him with astonishment. She did not understand\nhow he could ask such a question. Pierre went into the study. Prince\nAndrew, greatly changed and plainly in better health, but with a fresh\nhorizontal wrinkle between his brows, stood in civilian dress facing\nhis father and Prince Meshch\xc3\xa9rski, warmly disputing and vigorously\ngesticulating. The conversation was about Sper\xc3\xa1nski\xe2\x80\x94the news of whose\nsudden exile and alleged treachery had just reached Moscow.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow he is censured and accused by all who were enthusiastic about him\na month ago,\xe2\x80\x9d Prince Andrew was saying, \xe2\x80\x9cand by those who were unable to\nunderstand his aims. To judge a man who is in disfavor and to throw on\nhim all the blame of other men\xe2\x80\x99s mistakes is very easy, but I maintain\nthat if anything good has been accomplished in this reign it was done by\nhim, by him alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe paused at the sight of Pierre. His face quivered and immediately\nassumed a vindictive expression.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPosterity will do him justice,\xe2\x80\x9d he concluded, and at once turned to\nPierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, how are you? Still getting stouter?\xe2\x80\x9d he said with animation, but\nthe new wrinkle on his forehead deepened. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, I am well,\xe2\x80\x9d he said in\nanswer to Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s question, and smiled.\n\nTo Pierre that smile said plainly: \xe2\x80\x9cI am well, but my health is now of\nno use to anyone.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAfter a few words to Pierre about the awful roads from the Polish\nfrontier, about people he had met in Switzerland who knew Pierre, and\nabout M. Dessalles, whom he had brought from abroad to be his son\xe2\x80\x99s\ntutor, Prince Andrew again joined warmly in the conversation about\nSper\xc3\xa1nski which was still going on between the two old men.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf there were treason, or proofs of secret relations with Napoleon,\nthey would have been made public,\xe2\x80\x9d he said with warmth and haste. \xe2\x80\x9cI do\nnot, and never did, like Sper\xc3\xa1nski personally, but I like justice!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre now recognized in his friend a need with which he was only too\nfamiliar, to get excited and to have arguments about extraneous matters\nin order to stifle thoughts that were too oppressive and too intimate.\nWhen Prince Meshch\xc3\xa9rski had left, Prince Andrew took Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s arm and\nasked him into the room that had been assigned him. A bed had been made\nup there, and some open portmanteaus and trunks stood about. Prince\nAndrew went to one and took out a small casket, from which he drew a\npacket wrapped in paper. He did it all silently and very quickly. He\nstood up and coughed. His face was gloomy and his lips compressed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cForgive me for troubling you....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre saw that Prince Andrew was going to speak of Nat\xc3\xa1sha, and his\nbroad face expressed pity and sympathy. This expression irritated Prince\nAndrew, and in a determined, ringing, and unpleasant tone he continued:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have received a refusal from Countess Rost\xc3\xb3va and have heard reports\nof your brother-in-law having sought her hand, or something of that\nkind. Is that true?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoth true and untrue,\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre began; but Prince Andrew interrupted him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere are her letters and her portrait,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\nHe took the packet from the table and handed it to Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive this to the countess... if you see her.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is very ill,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen she is here still?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd Prince Kur\xc3\xa1gin?\xe2\x80\x9d he\nadded quickly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe left long ago. She has been at death\xe2\x80\x99s door.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI much regret her illness,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew; and he smiled like his\nfather, coldly, maliciously, and unpleasantly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo Monsieur Kur\xc3\xa1gin has not honored Countess Rost\xc3\xb3va with his hand?\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid Prince Andrew, and he snorted several times.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe could not marry, for he was married already,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre.\n\nPrince Andrew laughed disagreeably, again reminding one of his father.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where is your brother-in-law now, if I may ask?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has gone to Peters... But I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cTell Countess Rost\xc3\xb3va\nthat she was and is perfectly free and that I wish her all that is\ngood.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre took the packet. Prince Andrew, as if trying to remember whether\nhe had something more to say, or waiting to see if Pierre would say\nanything, looked fixedly at him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, do you remember our discussion in Petersburg?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pierre,\n\xe2\x80\x9cabout...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Prince Andrew hastily. \xe2\x80\x9cI said that a fallen woman\nshould be forgiven, but I didn\xe2\x80\x99t say I could forgive her. I can\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut can this be compared...?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre.\n\nPrince Andrew interrupted him and cried sharply: \xe2\x80\x9cYes, ask her hand\nagain, be magnanimous, and so on?... Yes, that would be very noble, but\nI am unable to follow in that gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s footsteps. If you wish to be\nmy friend never speak to me of that... of all that! Well, good-by. So\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll give her the packet?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre left the room and went to the old prince and Princess Mary.\n\nThe old man seemed livelier than usual. Princess Mary was the same as\nalways, but beneath her sympathy for her brother, Pierre noticed her\nsatisfaction that the engagement had been broken off. Looking at them\nPierre realized what contempt and animosity they all felt for the\nRost\xc3\xb3vs, and that it was impossible in their presence even to mention\nthe name of her who could give up Prince Andrew for anyone else.\n\nAt dinner the talk turned on the war, the approach of which was becoming\nevident. Prince Andrew talked incessantly, arguing now with his father,\nnow with the Swiss tutor Dessalles, and showing an unnatural animation,\nthe cause of which Pierre so well understood.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XXII\n\nThat same evening Pierre went to the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 to fulfill the commission\nentrusted to him. Nat\xc3\xa1sha was in bed, the count at the club, and Pierre,\nafter giving the letters to S\xc3\xb3nya, went to M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna who was\ninterested to know how Prince Andrew had taken the news. Ten minutes\nlater S\xc3\xb3nya came to M\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1sha insists on seeing Count Peter Kir\xc3\xadlovich,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how? Are we to take him up to her? The room there has not been\ntidied up.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, she has dressed and gone into the drawing room,\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\nM\xc3\xa1rya Dm\xc3\xadtrievna only shrugged her shoulders.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen will her mother come? She has worried me to death! Now mind, don\xe2\x80\x99t\ntell her everything!\xe2\x80\x9d said she to Pierre. \xe2\x80\x9cOne hasn\xe2\x80\x99t the heart to scold\nher, she is so much to be pitied, so much to be pitied.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha was standing in the middle of the drawing room, emaciated, with\na pale set face, but not at all shamefaced as Pierre expected to find\nher. When he appeared at the door she grew flurried, evidently undecided\nwhether to go to meet him or to wait till he came up.\n\nPierre hastened to her. He thought she would give him her hand as\nusual; but she, stepping up to him, stopped, breathing heavily, her arms\nhanging lifelessly just in the pose she used to stand in when she\nwent to the middle of the ballroom to sing, but with quite a different\nexpression of face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeter Kir\xc3\xadlovich,\xe2\x80\x9d she began rapidly, \xe2\x80\x9cPrince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski was your\nfriend\xe2\x80\x94is your friend,\xe2\x80\x9d she corrected herself. (It seemed to her that\neverything that had once been must now be different.) \xe2\x80\x9cHe told me once\nto apply to you...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre sniffed as he looked at her, but did not speak. Till then he had\nreproached her in his heart and tried to despise her, but he now felt so\nsorry for her that there was no room in his soul for reproach.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is here now: tell him... to for... forgive me!\xe2\x80\x9d She stopped and\nbreathed still more quickly, but did not shed tears.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes... I will tell him,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pierre; \xe2\x80\x9cbut...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe did not know what to say.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha was evidently dismayed at the thought of what he might think she\nhad meant.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I know all is over,\xe2\x80\x9d she said hurriedly. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, that can never be.\nI\xe2\x80\x99m only tormented by the wrong I have done him. Tell him only that I\nbeg him to forgive, forgive, forgive me for everything....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe trembled all over and sat down on a chair.\n\nA sense of pity he had never before known overflowed Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s heart.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell him, I will tell him everything once more,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre.\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut... I should like to know one thing....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cKnow what?\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s eyes asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like to know, did you love...\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre did not know how to\nrefer to Anatole and flushed at the thought of him\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cdid you love that\nbad man?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t call him bad!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I don\xe2\x80\x99t know, don\xe2\x80\x99t know at\nall....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe began to cry and a still greater sense of pity, tenderness, and love\nwelled up in Pierre. He felt the tears trickle under his spectacles and\nhoped they would not be noticed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe won\xe2\x80\x99t speak of it any more, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, and his gentle,\ncordial tone suddenly seemed very strange to Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe won\xe2\x80\x99t speak of it, my dear\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell him everything; but one thing\nI beg of you, consider me your friend and if you want help, advice,\nor simply to open your heart to someone\xe2\x80\x94not now, but when your mind is\nclearer--think of me!\xe2\x80\x9d He took her hand and kissed it. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall be happy\nif it\xe2\x80\x99s in my power...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre grew confused.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t speak to me like that. I am not worth it!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Nat\xc3\xa1sha and\nturned to leave the room, but Pierre held her hand.\n\nHe knew he had something more to say to her. But when he said it he was\namazed at his own words.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop, stop! You have your whole life before you,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBefore me? No! All is over for me,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied with shame and\nself-abasement.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll over?\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I were not myself, but the handsomest,\ncleverest, and best man in the world, and were free, I would this moment\nask on my knees for your hand and your love!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nFor the first time for many days Nat\xc3\xa1sha wept tears of gratitude and\ntenderness, and glancing at Pierre she went out of the room.\n\nPierre too when she had gone almost ran into the anteroom, restraining\ntears of tenderness and joy that choked him, and without finding the\nsleeves of his fur cloak threw it on and got into his sleigh.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere to now, your excellency?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the coachman.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere to?\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre asked himself. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere can I go now? Surely not to the\nClub or to pay calls?\xe2\x80\x9d All men seemed so pitiful, so poor, in comparison\nwith this feeling of tenderness and love he experienced: in comparison\nwith that softened, grateful, last look she had given him through her\ntears.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHome!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, and despite twenty-two degrees of frost Fahrenheit\nhe threw open the bearskin cloak from his broad chest and inhaled the\nair with joy.\n\nIt was clear and frosty. Above the dirty, ill-lit streets, above the\nblack roofs, stretched the dark starry sky. Only looking up at the sky\ndid Pierre cease to feel how sordid and humiliating were all mundane\nthings compared with the heights to which his soul had just been raised.\nAt the entrance to the Arb\xc3\xa1t Square an immense expanse of dark starry\nsky presented itself to his eyes. Almost in the center of it, above the\nPrech\xc3\xadstenka Boulevard, surrounded and sprinkled on all sides by stars\nbut distinguished from them all by its nearness to the earth, its white\nlight, and its long uplifted tail, shone the enormous and brilliant\ncomet of 1812\xe2\x80\x94the comet which was said to portend all kinds of woes\nand the end of the world. In Pierre, however, that comet with its long\nluminous tail aroused no feeling of fear. On the contrary he gazed\njoyfully, his eyes moist with tears, at this bright comet which, having\ntraveled in its orbit with inconceivable velocity through immeasurable\nspace, seemed suddenly\xe2\x80\x94like an arrow piercing the earth\xe2\x80\x94to remain\nfixed in a chosen spot, vigorously holding its tail erect, shining and\ndisplaying its white light amid countless other scintillating stars. It\nseemed to Pierre that this comet fully responded to what was passing in\nhis own softened and uplifted soul, now blossoming into a new life.\n\n\n\n\n\nBOOK NINE: 1812\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER I\n\nFrom the close of the year 1811 an intensified arming and concentrating of\nthe forces of Western Europe began, and in 1812 these forces\xe2\x80\x94millions\nof men, reckoning those transporting and feeding the army\xe2\x80\x94moved from the\nwest eastwards to the Russian frontier, toward which since 1811 Russian\nforces had been similarly drawn. On the twelfth of June, 1812, the\nforces of Western Europe crossed the Russian frontier and war began,\nthat is, an event took place opposed to human reason and to human\nnature. Millions of men perpetrated against one another such innumerable\ncrimes, frauds, treacheries, thefts, forgeries, issues of false money,\nburglaries, incendiarisms, and murders as in whole centuries are not\nrecorded in the annals of all the law courts of the world, but which\nthose who committed them did not at the time regard as being crimes.\n\nWhat produced this extraordinary occurrence? What were its causes? The\nhistorians tell us with na\xc3\xafve assurance that its causes were the wrongs\ninflicted on the Duke of Oldenburg, the nonobservance of the Continental\nSystem, the ambition of Napoleon, the firmness of Alexander, the\nmistakes of the diplomatists, and so on.\n\nConsequently, it would only have been necessary for Metternich,\nRumy\xc3\xa1ntsev, or Talleyrand, between a levee and an evening party, to have\ntaken proper pains and written a more adroit note, or for Napoleon to\nhave written to Alexander: \xe2\x80\x9cMy respected Brother, I consent to restore\nthe duchy to the Duke of Oldenburg\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and there would have been no war.\n\nWe can understand that the matter seemed like that to contemporaries.\nIt naturally seemed to Napoleon that the war was caused by England\xe2\x80\x99s\nintrigues (as in fact he said on the island of St. Helena). It naturally\nseemed to members of the English Parliament that the cause of the war\nwas Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s ambition; to the Duke of Oldenburg, that the cause of the\nwar was the violence done to him; to businessmen that the cause of the\nwar was the Continental System which was ruining Europe; to the generals\nand old soldiers that the chief reason for the war was the necessity of\ngiving them employment; to the legitimists of that day that it was the\nneed of re-establishing les bons principes, and to the diplomatists of\nthat time that it all resulted from the fact that the alliance between\nRussia and Austria in 1809 had not been sufficiently well concealed\nfrom Napoleon, and from the awkward wording of Memorandum No. 178. It\nis natural that these and a countless and infinite quantity of other\nreasons, the number depending on the endless diversity of points\nof view, presented themselves to the men of that day; but to us, to\nposterity who view the thing that happened in all its magnitude and\nperceive its plain and terrible meaning, these causes seem insufficient.\nTo us it is incomprehensible that millions of Christian men killed and\ntortured each other either because Napoleon was ambitious or Alexander\nwas firm, or because England\xe2\x80\x99s policy was astute or the Duke of\nOldenburg wronged. We cannot grasp what connection such circumstances\nhave with the actual fact of slaughter and violence: why because the\nDuke was wronged, thousands of men from the other side of Europe killed\nand ruined the people of Smol\xc3\xa9nsk and Moscow and were killed by them.\n\nTo us, their descendants, who are not historians and are not carried\naway by the process of research and can therefore regard the event\nwith unclouded common sense, an incalculable number of causes present\nthemselves. The deeper we delve in search of these causes the more of\nthem we find; and each separate cause or whole series of causes appears\nto us equally valid in itself and equally false by its insignificance\ncompared to the magnitude of the events, and by its impotence\xe2\x80\x94apart\nfrom the cooperation of all the other coincident causes\xe2\x80\x94to occasion the\nevent. To us, the wish or objection of this or that French corporal to\nserve a second term appears as much a cause as Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s refusal to\nwithdraw his troops beyond the Vistula and to restore the duchy of\nOldenburg; for had he not wished to serve, and had a second, a third,\nand a thousandth corporal and private also refused, there would have\nbeen so many less men in Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s army and the war could not have\noccurred.\n\nHad Napoleon not taken offense at the demand that he should withdraw\nbeyond the Vistula, and not ordered his troops to advance, there would\nhave been no war; but had all his sergeants objected to serving a second\nterm then also there could have been no war. Nor could there have been\na war had there been no English intrigues and no Duke of Oldenburg, and\nhad Alexander not felt insulted, and had there not been an autocratic\ngovernment in Russia, or a Revolution in France and a subsequent\ndictatorship and Empire, or all the things that produced the French\nRevolution, and so on. Without each of these causes nothing could have\nhappened. So all these causes\xe2\x80\x94myriads of causes\xe2\x80\x94coincided to bring it\nabout. And so there was no one cause for that occurrence, but it had\nto occur because it had to. Millions of men, renouncing their human\nfeelings and reason, had to go from west to east to slay their fellows,\njust as some centuries previously hordes of men had come from the east\nto the west, slaying their fellows.\n\nThe actions of Napoleon and Alexander, on whose words the event seemed\nto hang, were as little voluntary as the actions of any soldier who was\ndrawn into the campaign by lot or by conscription. This could not be\notherwise, for in order that the will of Napoleon and Alexander (on whom\nthe event seemed to depend) should be carried out, the concurrence of\ninnumerable circumstances was needed without any one of which the event\ncould not have taken place. It was necessary that millions of men in\nwhose hands lay the real power\xe2\x80\x94the soldiers who fired, or transported\nprovisions and guns\xe2\x80\x94should consent to carry out the will of these weak\nindividuals, and should have been induced to do so by an infinite number\nof diverse and complex causes.\n\nWe are forced to fall back on fatalism as an explanation of irrational\nevents (that is to say, events the reasonableness of which we do\nnot understand). The more we try to explain such events in history\nreasonably, the more unreasonable and incomprehensible do they become to\nus.\n\nEach man lives for himself, using his freedom to attain his personal\naims, and feels with his whole being that he can now do or abstain from\ndoing this or that action; but as soon as he has done it, that action\nperformed at a certain moment in time becomes irrevocable and belongs to\nhistory, in which it has not a free but a predestined significance.\n\nThere are two sides to the life of every man, his individual life, which\nis the more free the more abstract its interests, and his elemental hive\nlife in which he inevitably obeys laws laid down for him.\n\nMan lives consciously for himself, but is an unconscious instrument in\nthe attainment of the historic, universal, aims of humanity. A deed done\nis irrevocable, and its result coinciding in time with the actions of\nmillions of other men assumes an historic significance. The higher a man\nstands on the social ladder, the more people he is connected with\nand the more power he has over others, the more evident is the\npredestination and inevitability of his every action.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe king\xe2\x80\x99s heart is in the hands of the Lord.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nA king is history\xe2\x80\x99s slave.\n\nHistory, that is, the unconscious, general, hive life of mankind, uses\nevery moment of the life of kings as a tool for its own purposes.\n\nThough Napoleon at that time, in 1812, was more convinced than ever that\nit depended on him, verser (ou ne pas verser) le sang de ses peuples\n*\xe2\x80\x94as Alexander expressed it in the last letter he wrote him\xe2\x80\x94he had never\nbeen so much in the grip of inevitable laws, which compelled him, while\nthinking that he was acting on his own volition, to perform for the hive\nlife\xe2\x80\x94that is to say, for history\xe2\x80\x94whatever had to be performed.\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cTo shed (or not to shed) the blood of his peoples.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nThe people of the west moved eastwards to slay their fellow men, and\nby the law of coincidence thousands of minute causes fitted in and\nco-ordinated to produce that movement and war: reproaches for the\nnonobservance of the Continental System, the Duke of Oldenburg\xe2\x80\x99s\nwrongs, the movement of troops into Prussia\xe2\x80\x94undertaken (as it seemed to\nNapoleon) only for the purpose of securing an armed peace, the\nFrench Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s love and habit of war coinciding with his people\xe2\x80\x99s\ninclinations, allurement by the grandeur of the preparations, and the\nexpenditure on those preparations and the need of obtaining advantages\nto compensate for that expenditure, the intoxicating honors he received\nin Dresden, the diplomatic negotiations which, in the opinion of\ncontemporaries, were carried on with a sincere desire to attain peace,\nbut which only wounded the self-love of both sides, and millions of\nother causes that adapted themselves to the event that was happening or\ncoincided with it.\n\nWhen an apple has ripened and falls, why does it fall? Because of its\nattraction to the earth, because its stalk withers, because it is dried\nby the sun, because it grows heavier, because the wind shakes it, or\nbecause the boy standing below wants to eat it?\n\nNothing is the cause. All this is only the coincidence of conditions in\nwhich all vital organic and elemental events occur. And the botanist\nwho finds that the apple falls because the cellular tissue decays and so\nforth is equally right with the child who stands under the tree and says\nthe apple fell because he wanted to eat it and prayed for it. Equally\nright or wrong is he who says that Napoleon went to Moscow because he\nwanted to, and perished because Alexander desired his destruction, and\nhe who says that an undermined hill weighing a million tons fell because\nthe last navvy struck it for the last time with his mattock. In historic\nevents the so-called great men are labels giving names to events, and\nlike labels they have but the smallest connection with the event itself.\n\nEvery act of theirs, which appears to them an act of their own will, is\nin an historical sense involuntary and is related to the whole course of\nhistory and predestined from eternity.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER II\n\nOn the twenty-ninth of May Napoleon left Dresden, where he had spent\nthree weeks surrounded by a court that included princes, dukes, kings,\nand even an emperor. Before leaving, Napoleon showed favor to the\nemperor, kings, and princes who had deserved it, reprimanded the kings\nand princes with whom he was dissatisfied, presented pearls and diamonds\nof his own\xe2\x80\x94that is, which he had taken from other kings\xe2\x80\x94to the Empress\nof Austria, and having, as his historian tells us, tenderly embraced the\nEmpress Marie Louise\xe2\x80\x94who regarded him as her husband, though he had left\nanother wife in Paris\xe2\x80\x94left her grieved by the parting which she seemed\nhardly able to bear. Though the diplomatists still firmly believed in\nthe possibility of peace and worked zealously to that end, and though\nthe Emperor Napoleon himself wrote a letter to Alexander, calling him\nMonsieur mon fr\xc3\xa8re, and sincerely assured him that he did not want war\nand would always love and honor him\xe2\x80\x94yet he set off to join his army,\nand at every station gave fresh orders to accelerate the movement of his\ntroops from west to east. He went in a traveling coach with six horses,\nsurrounded by pages, aides-de-camp, and an escort, along the road to\nPosen, Thorn, Danzig, and K\xc3\xb6nigsberg. At each of these towns thousands\nof people met him with excitement and enthusiasm.\n\nThe army was moving from west to east, and relays of six horses carried\nhim in the same direction. On the tenth of June, * coming up with the\narmy, he spent the night in apartments prepared for him on the estate of\na Polish count in the Vilkavisski forest.\n\n    * Old style.\n\nNext day, overtaking the army, he went in a carriage to the Niemen, and,\nchanging into a Polish uniform, he drove to the riverbank in order to\nselect a place for the crossing.\n\nSeeing, on the other side, some Cossacks (les Cosaques) and the\nwide-spreading steppes in the midst of which lay the holy city of Moscow\n(Moscou, la ville sainte), the capital of a realm such as the Scythia\ninto which Alexander the Great had marched\xe2\x80\x94Napoleon unexpectedly, and\ncontrary alike to strategic and diplomatic considerations, ordered an\nadvance, and the next day his army began to cross the Niemen.\n\nEarly in the morning of the twelfth of June he came out of his tent,\nwhich was pitched that day on the steep left bank of the Niemen, and\nlooked through a spyglass at the streams of his troops pouring out of\nthe Vilkavisski forest and flowing over the three bridges thrown across\nthe river. The troops, knowing of the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s presence, were on the\nlookout for him, and when they caught sight of a figure in an overcoat\nand a cocked hat standing apart from his suite in front of his tent on\nthe hill, they threw up their caps and shouted: \xe2\x80\x9cVive l\xe2\x80\x99Empereur!\xe2\x80\x9d and\none after another poured in a ceaseless stream out of the vast forest\nthat had concealed them and, separating, flowed on and on by the three\nbridges to the other side.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow we\xe2\x80\x99ll go into action. Oh, when he takes it in hand himself, things\nget hot... by heaven!... There he is!... Vive l\xe2\x80\x99Empereur! So these\nare the steppes of Asia! It\xe2\x80\x99s a nasty country all the same. Au revoir,\nBeauch\xc3\xa9; I\xe2\x80\x99ll keep the best palace in Moscow for you! Au revoir. Good\nluck!... Did you see the Emperor? Vive l\xe2\x80\x99Empereur!... preur!\xe2\x80\x94If\nthey make me Governor of India, G\xc3\xa9rard, I\xe2\x80\x99ll make you Minister of\nKashmir\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s settled. Vive l\xe2\x80\x99Empereur! Hurrah! hurrah! hurrah! The\nCossacks\xe2\x80\x94those rascals\xe2\x80\x94see how they run! Vive l\xe2\x80\x99Empereur! There he\nis, do you see him? I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen him twice, as I see you now. The little\ncorporal... I saw him give the cross to one of the veterans.... Vive\nl\xe2\x80\x99Empereur!\xe2\x80\x9d came the voices of men, old and young, of most diverse\ncharacters and social positions. On the faces of all was one common\nexpression of joy at the commencement of the long-expected campaign and\nof rapture and devotion to the man in the gray coat who was standing on\nthe hill.\n\nOn the thirteenth of June a rather small, thoroughbred Arab horse was\nbrought to Napoleon. He mounted it and rode at a gallop to one of the\nbridges over the Niemen, deafened continually by incessant and rapturous\nacclamations which he evidently endured only because it was impossible\nto forbid the soldiers to express their love of him by such shouting,\nbut the shouting which accompanied him everywhere disturbed him and\ndistracted him from the military cares that had occupied him from the\ntime he joined the army.
