She\nfeared for her brother who was in it, was horrified by and amazed at\nthe strange cruelty that impels men to kill one another, but she did not\nunderstand the significance of this war, which seemed to her like all\nprevious wars. She did not realize the significance of this war, though\nDessalles with whom she constantly conversed was passionately interested\nin its progress and tried to explain his own conception of it to her,\nand though the \xe2\x80\x9cGod\xe2\x80\x99s folk\xe2\x80\x9d who came to see her reported, in their own\nway, the rumors current among the people of an invasion by Antichrist,\nand though Julie (now Princess Drubetsk\xc3\xa1ya), who had resumed\ncorrespondence with her, wrote patriotic letters from Moscow.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI write you in Russian, my good friend,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote Julie in her Frenchified\nRussian, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause I have a detestation for all the French, and the\nsame for their language which I cannot support to hear spoken.... We in\nMoscow are elated by enthusiasm for our adored Emperor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy poor husband is enduring pains and hunger in Jewish taverns, but the\nnews which I have inspires me yet more.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou heard probably of the heroic exploit of Ra\xc3\xa9vski, embracing his two\nsons and saying: \xe2\x80\x98I will perish with them but we will not be shaken!\xe2\x80\x99\nAnd truly though the enemy was twice stronger than we, we were\nunshakable. We pass the time as we can, but in war as in war! The\nprincesses Aline and Sophie sit whole days with me, and we, unhappy\nwidows of live men, make beautiful conversations over our charpie, only\nyou, my friend, are missing...\xe2\x80\x9d and so on.\n\nThe chief reason Princess Mary did not realize the full significance of\nthis war was that the old prince never spoke of it, did not recognize\nit, and laughed at Dessalles when he mentioned it at dinner.\nThe prince\xe2\x80\x99s tone was so calm and confident that Princess Mary\nunhesitatingly believed him.\n\nAll that July the old prince was exceedingly active and even animated.\nHe planned another garden and began a new building for the domestic\nserfs. The only thing that made Princess Mary anxious about him was that\nhe slept very little and, instead of sleeping in his study as usual,\nchanged his sleeping place every day. One day he would order his camp\nbed to be set up in the glass gallery, another day he remained on the\ncouch or on the lounge chair in the drawing room and dozed there without\nundressing, while\xe2\x80\x94instead of Mademoiselle Bourienne\xe2\x80\x94a serf boy read to\nhim. Then again he would spend a night in the dining room.\n\nOn August 1, a second letter was received from Prince Andrew. In his\nfirst letter which came soon after he had left home, Prince Andrew had\ndutifully asked his father\xe2\x80\x99s forgiveness for what he had allowed himself\nto say and begged to be restored to his favor. To this letter the old\nprince had replied affectionately, and from that time had kept the\nFrenchwoman at a distance. Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s second letter, written near\nV\xc3\xadtebsk after the French had occupied that town, gave a brief account of\nthe whole campaign, enclosed for them a plan he had drawn and forecasts\nas to the further progress of the war. In this letter Prince Andrew\npointed out to his father the danger of staying at Bald Hills, so near\nthe theater of war and on the army\xe2\x80\x99s direct line of march, and advised\nhim to move to Moscow.\n\nAt dinner that day, on Dessalles\xe2\x80\x99 mentioning that the French were said\nto have already entered V\xc3\xadtebsk, the old prince remembered his son\xe2\x80\x99s\nletter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere was a letter from Prince Andrew today,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Princess\nMary\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHaven\xe2\x80\x99t you read it?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Father,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied in a frightened voice.\n\nShe could not have read the letter as she did not even know it had\narrived.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe writes about this war,\xe2\x80\x9d said the prince, with the ironic smile that\nhad become habitual to him in speaking of the present war.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat must be very interesting,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dessalles. \xe2\x80\x9cPrince Andrew is in a\nposition to know...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, very interesting!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mademoiselle Bourienne.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo and get it for me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old prince to Mademoiselle Bourienne.\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know\xe2\x80\x94under the paperweight on the little table.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nMademoiselle Bourienne jumped up eagerly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed with a frown. \xe2\x80\x9cYou go, Michael Iv\xc3\xa1novich.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nMichael Iv\xc3\xa1novich rose and went to the study. But as soon as he had left\nthe room the old prince, looking uneasily round, threw down his napkin\nand went himself.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey can\xe2\x80\x99t do anything... always make some muddle,\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered.\n\nWhile he was away Princess Mary, Dessalles, Mademoiselle Bourienne, and\neven little Nicholas exchanged looks in silence. The old prince returned\nwith quick steps, accompanied by Michael Iv\xc3\xa1novich, bringing the letter\nand a plan. These he put down beside him\xe2\x80\x94not letting anyone read them at\ndinner.\n\nOn moving to the drawing room he handed the letter to Princess Mary and,\nspreading out before him the plan of the new building and fixing his\neyes upon it, told her to read the letter aloud. When she had done so\nPrincess Mary looked inquiringly at her father. He was examining the\nplan, evidently engrossed in his own ideas.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you think of it, Prince?\xe2\x80\x9d Dessalles ventured to ask.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? I?...\xe2\x80\x9d said the prince as if unpleasantly awakened, and not taking\nhis eyes from the plan of the building.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery possibly the theater of war will move so near to us that...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa ha ha! The theater of war!\xe2\x80\x9d said the prince. \xe2\x80\x9cI have said and still\nsay that the theater of war is Poland and the enemy will never get\nbeyond the Niemen.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDessalles looked in amazement at the prince, who was talking of the\nNiemen when the enemy was already at the Dnieper, but Princess Mary,\nforgetting the geographical position of the Niemen, thought that what\nher father was saying was correct.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen the snow melts they\xe2\x80\x99ll sink in the Polish swamps. Only they\ncould fail to see it,\xe2\x80\x9d the prince continued, evidently thinking of the\ncampaign of 1807 which seemed to him so recent. \xe2\x80\x9cBennigsen should have\nadvanced into Prussia sooner, then things would have taken a different\nturn...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Prince,\xe2\x80\x9d Dessalles began timidly, \xe2\x80\x9cthe letter mentions\nV\xc3\xadtebsk....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, the letter? Yes...\xe2\x80\x9d replied the prince peevishly. \xe2\x80\x9cYes... yes...\xe2\x80\x9d\nHis face suddenly took on a morose expression. He paused. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, he\nwrites that the French were beaten at... at... what river is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDessalles dropped his eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe prince says nothing about that,\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked gently.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoesn\xe2\x80\x99t he? But I didn\xe2\x80\x99t invent it myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNo one spoke for a long time.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes... yes... Well, Michael Iv\xc3\xa1novich,\xe2\x80\x9d he suddenly went on, raising\nhis head and pointing to the plan of the building, \xe2\x80\x9ctell me how you mean\nto alter it....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nMichael Iv\xc3\xa1novich went up to the plan, and the prince after speaking to\nhim about the building looked angrily at Princess Mary and Dessalles and\nwent to his own room.\n\nPrincess Mary saw Dessalles\xe2\x80\x99 embarrassed and astonished look fixed on\nher father, noticed his silence, and was struck by the fact that her\nfather had forgotten his son\xe2\x80\x99s letter on the drawing room table; but she\nwas not only afraid to speak of it and ask Dessalles the reason of his\nconfusion and silence, but was afraid even to think about it.\n\nIn the evening Michael Iv\xc3\xa1novich, sent by the prince, came to Princess\nMary for Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s letter which had been forgotten in the drawing\nroom. She gave it to him and, unpleasant as it was to her to do so,\nventured to ask him what her father was doing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlways busy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Michael Iv\xc3\xa1novich with a respectfully ironic\nsmile which caused Princess Mary to turn pale. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s worrying very much\nabout the new building. He has been reading a little, but now\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Michael\nIv\xc3\xa1novich went on, lowering his voice\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cnow he\xe2\x80\x99s at his desk, busy with\nhis will, I expect.\xe2\x80\x9d (One of the prince\xe2\x80\x99s favorite occupations of late\nhad been the preparation of some papers he meant to leave at his death\nand which he called his \xe2\x80\x9cwill.\xe2\x80\x9d)\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Alp\xc3\xa1tych is being sent to Smol\xc3\xa9nsk?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Princess Mary.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, he has been waiting to start for some time.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER III\n\nWhen Michael Iv\xc3\xa1novich returned to the study with the letter, the old\nprince, with spectacles on and a shade over his eyes, was sitting at his\nopen bureau with screened candles, holding a paper in his outstretched\nhand, and in a somewhat dramatic attitude was reading his manuscript\xe2\x80\x94his\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemarks\xe2\x80\x9d as he termed it\xe2\x80\x94which was to be transmitted to the Emperor\nafter his death.\n\nWhen Michael Iv\xc3\xa1novich went in there were tears in the prince\xe2\x80\x99s eyes\nevoked by the memory of the time when the paper he was now reading had\nbeen written. He took the letter from Michael Iv\xc3\xa1novich\xe2\x80\x99s hand, put it\nin his pocket, folded up his papers, and called in Alp\xc3\xa1tych who had long\nbeen waiting.\n\nThe prince had a list of things to be bought in Smol\xc3\xa9nsk and, walking\nup and down the room past Alp\xc3\xa1tych who stood by the door, he gave his\ninstructions.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFirst, notepaper\xe2\x80\x94do you hear? Eight quires, like this sample,\ngilt-edged... it must be exactly like the sample. Varnish, sealing wax,\nas in Michael Iv\xc3\xa1novich\xe2\x80\x99s list.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe paced up and down for a while and glanced at his notes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen hand to the governor in person a letter about the deed.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNext, bolts for the doors of the new building were wanted and had to be\nof a special shape the prince had himself designed, and a leather case\nhad to be ordered to keep the \xe2\x80\x9cwill\xe2\x80\x9d in.\n\nThe instructions to Alp\xc3\xa1tych took over two hours and still the prince\ndid not let him go. He sat down, sank into thought, closed his eyes, and\ndozed off. Alp\xc3\xa1tych made a slight movement.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, go, go! If anything more is wanted I\xe2\x80\x99ll send after you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych went out. The prince again went to his bureau, glanced into it,\nfingered his papers, closed the bureau again, and sat down at the table\nto write to the governor.\n\nIt was already late when he rose after sealing the letter. He wished\nto sleep, but he knew he would not be able to and that most depressing\nthoughts came to him in bed. So he called T\xc3\xadkhon and went through the\nrooms with him to show him where to set up the bed for that night.\n\nHe went about looking at every corner. Every place seemed\nunsatisfactory, but worst of all was his customary couch in the study.\nThat couch was dreadful to him, probably because of the oppressive\nthoughts he had had when lying there. It was unsatisfactory everywhere,\nbut the corner behind the piano in the sitting room was better than\nother places: he had never slept there yet.\n\nWith the help of a footman T\xc3\xadkhon brought in the bedstead and began\nputting it up.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s not right! That\xe2\x80\x99s not right!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the prince, and himself\npushed it a few inches from the corner and then closer in again.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, at last I\xe2\x80\x99ve finished, now I\xe2\x80\x99ll rest,\xe2\x80\x9d thought the prince, and\nlet T\xc3\xadkhon undress him.\n\nFrowning with vexation at the effort necessary to divest himself of his\ncoat and trousers, the prince undressed, sat down heavily on the\nbed, and appeared to be meditating as he looked contemptuously at his\nwithered yellow legs. He was not meditating, but only deferring the\nmoment of making the effort to lift those legs up and turn over on the\nbed. \xe2\x80\x9cUgh, how hard it is! Oh, that this toil might end and you would\nrelease me!\xe2\x80\x9d thought he. Pressing his lips together he made that effort\nfor the twenty-thousandth time and lay down. But hardly had he done so\nbefore he felt the bed rocking backwards and forwards beneath him as if\nit were breathing heavily and jolting. This happened to him almost every\nnight. He opened his eyes as they were closing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo peace, damn them!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered, angry he knew not with whom. \xe2\x80\x9cAh\nyes, there was something else important, very important, that I was\nkeeping till I should be in bed. The bolts? No, I told him about them.\nNo, it was something, something in the drawing room. Princess Mary\ntalked some nonsense. Dessalles, that fool, said something. Something in\nmy pocket\xe2\x80\x94can\xe2\x80\x99t remember....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cT\xc3\xadkhon, what did we talk about at dinner?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout Prince Michael...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe quiet, quiet!\xe2\x80\x9d The prince slapped his hand on the table. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, I\nknow, Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s letter! Princess Mary read it. Dessalles said\nsomething about V\xc3\xadtebsk. Now I\xe2\x80\x99ll read it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe had the letter taken from his pocket and the table\xe2\x80\x94on which stood a\nglass of lemonade and a spiral wax candle\xe2\x80\x94moved close to the bed, and\nputting on his spectacles he began reading. Only now in the stillness of\nthe night, reading it by the faint light under the green shade, did he\ngrasp its meaning for a moment.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe French at V\xc3\xadtebsk, in four days\xe2\x80\x99 march they may be at Smol\xc3\xa9nsk;\nperhaps are already there! T\xc3\xadkhon!\xe2\x80\x9d T\xc3\xadkhon jumped up. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, I don\xe2\x80\x99t\nwant anything!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted.\n\nHe put the letter under the candlestick and closed his eyes. And there\nrose before him the Danube at bright noonday: reeds, the Russian\ncamp, and himself a young general without a wrinkle on his ruddy face,\nvigorous and alert, entering Pot\xc3\xabmkin\xe2\x80\x99s gaily colored tent, and a\nburning sense of jealousy of \xe2\x80\x9cthe favorite\xe2\x80\x9d agitated him now as strongly\nas it had done then. He recalled all the words spoken at that\nfirst meeting with Pot\xc3\xabmkin. And he saw before him a plump, rather\nsallow-faced, short, stout woman, the Empress Mother, with her smile\nand her words at her first gracious reception of him, and then that same\nface on the catafalque, and the encounter he had with Z\xc3\xbabov over her\ncoffin about his right to kiss her hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, quicker, quicker! To get back to that time and have done with all\nthe present! Quicker, quicker\xe2\x80\x94and that they should leave me in peace!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IV\n\nBald Hills, Prince Nicholas Bolk\xc3\xb3nski\xe2\x80\x99s estate, lay forty miles east\nfrom Smol\xc3\xa9nsk and two miles from the main road to Moscow.\n\nThe same evening that the prince gave his instructions to Alp\xc3\xa1tych,\nDessalles, having asked to see Princess Mary, told her that, as the\nprince was not very well and was taking no steps to secure his safety,\nthough from Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s letter it was evident that to remain at Bald\nHills might be dangerous, he respectfully advised her to send a letter\nby Alp\xc3\xa1tych to the Provincial Governor at Smol\xc3\xa9nsk, asking him to let\nher know the state of affairs and the extent of the danger to which\nBald Hills was exposed. Dessalles wrote this letter to the Governor\nfor Princess Mary, she signed it, and it was given to Alp\xc3\xa1tych with\ninstructions to hand it to the Governor and to come back as quickly as\npossible if there was danger.\n\nHaving received all his orders Alp\xc3\xa1tych, wearing a white beaver hat\xe2\x80\x94a\npresent from the prince\xe2\x80\x94and carrying a stick as the prince did, went out\naccompanied by his family. Three well-fed roans stood ready harnessed to\na small conveyance with a leather hood.\n\nThe larger bell was muffled and the little bells on the harness stuffed\nwith paper. The prince allowed no one at Bald Hills to drive with\nringing bells; but on a long journey Alp\xc3\xa1tych liked to have them. His\nsatellites\xe2\x80\x94the senior clerk, a countinghouse clerk, a scullery maid,\na cook, two old women, a little pageboy, the coachman, and various\ndomestic serfs\xe2\x80\x94were seeing him off.\n\nHis daughter placed chintz-covered down cushions for him to sit on and\nbehind his back. His old sister-in-law popped in a small bundle, and one\nof the coachmen helped him into the vehicle.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere! There! Women\xe2\x80\x99s fuss! Women, women!\xe2\x80\x9d said Alp\xc3\xa1tych, puffing and\nspeaking rapidly just as the prince did, and he climbed into the trap.\n\nAfter giving the clerk orders about the work to be done, Alp\xc3\xa1tych, not\ntrying to imitate the prince now, lifted the hat from his bald head and\ncrossed himself three times.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf there is anything... come back, Y\xc3\xa1kov Alp\xc3\xa1tych! For Christ\xe2\x80\x99s sake\nthink of us!\xe2\x80\x9d cried his wife, referring to the rumors of war and the\nenemy.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWomen, women! Women\xe2\x80\x99s fuss!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Alp\xc3\xa1tych to himself and started\non his journey, looking round at the fields of yellow rye and the\nstill-green, thickly growing oats, and at other quite black fields just\nbeing plowed a second time.\n\nAs he went along he looked with pleasure at the year\xe2\x80\x99s splendid crop\nof corn, scrutinized the strips of ryefield which here and there were\nalready being reaped, made his calculations as to the sowing and the\nharvest, and asked himself whether he had not forgotten any of the\nprince\xe2\x80\x99s orders.\n\nHaving baited the horses twice on the way, he arrived at the town toward\nevening on the fourth of August.\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych kept meeting and overtaking baggage trains and troops on the\nroad. As he approached Smol\xc3\xa9nsk he heard the sounds of distant firing,\nbut these did not impress him. What struck him most was the sight of a\nsplendid field of oats in which a camp had been pitched and which\nwas being mown down by the soldiers, evidently for fodder. This fact\nimpressed Alp\xc3\xa1tych, but in thinking about his own business he soon\nforgot it.\n\nAll the interests of his life for more than thirty years had been\nbounded by the will of the prince, and he never went beyond that limit.\nEverything not connected with the execution of the prince\xe2\x80\x99s orders did\nnot interest and did not even exist for Alp\xc3\xa1tych.\n\nOn reaching Smol\xc3\xa9nsk on the evening of the fourth of August he put up\nin the G\xc3\xa1china suburb across the Dnieper, at the inn kept by Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov,\nwhere he had been in the habit of putting up for the last thirty years.\nSome thirty years ago Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov, by Alp\xc3\xa1tych\xe2\x80\x99s advice, had bought a\nwood from the prince, had begun to trade, and now had a house, an\ninn, and a corn dealer\xe2\x80\x99s shop in that province. He was a stout, dark,\nred-faced peasant in the forties, with thick lips, a broad knob of a\nnose, similar knobs over his black frowning brows, and a round belly.\n\nWearing a waistcoat over his cotton shirt, Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov was standing\nbefore his shop which opened onto the street. On seeing Alp\xc3\xa1tych he went\nup to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re welcome, Y\xc3\xa1kov Alp\xc3\xa1tych. Folks are leaving the town, but you\nhave come to it,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are they leaving the town?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Alp\xc3\xa1tych.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what I say. Folks are foolish! Always afraid of the French.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWomen\xe2\x80\x99s fuss, women\xe2\x80\x99s fuss!\xe2\x80\x9d said Alp\xc3\xa1tych.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust what I think, Y\xc3\xa1kov Alp\xc3\xa1tych. What I say is: orders have been\ngiven not to let them in, so that must be right. And the peasants are\nasking three rubles for carting\xe2\x80\x94it isn\xe2\x80\x99t Christian!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nY\xc3\xa1kov Alp\xc3\xa1tych heard without heeding. He asked for a samovar and for hay\nfor his horses, and when he had had his tea he went to bed.\n\nAll night long troops were moving past the inn. Next morning Alp\xc3\xa1tych\ndonned a jacket he wore only in town and went out on business. It was a\nsunny morning and by eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock it was already hot. \xe2\x80\x9cA good day for\nharvesting,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Alp\xc3\xa1tych.\n\nFrom beyond the town firing had been heard since early morning. At eight\no\xe2\x80\x99clock the booming of cannon was added to the sound of musketry. Many\npeople were hurrying through the streets and there were many soldiers,\nbut cabs were still driving about, tradesmen stood at their shops, and\nservice was being held in the churches as usual. Alp\xc3\xa1tych went to the\nshops, to government offices, to the post office, and to the Governor\xe2\x80\x99s.\nIn the offices and shops and at the post office everyone was talking\nabout the army and about the enemy who was already attacking the town,\neverybody was asking what should be done, and all were trying to calm\none another.\n\nIn front of the Governor\xe2\x80\x99s house Alp\xc3\xa1tych found a large number of\npeople, Cossacks, and a traveling carriage of the Governor\xe2\x80\x99s. At the\nporch he met two of the landed gentry, one of whom he knew. This man, an\nex-captain of police, was saying angrily:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s no joke, you know! It\xe2\x80\x99s all very well if you\xe2\x80\x99re single. \xe2\x80\x98One man\nthough undone is but one,\xe2\x80\x99 as the proverb says, but with thirteen in\nyour family and all the property... They\xe2\x80\x99ve brought us to utter ruin!\nWhat sort of governors are they to do that? They ought to be hanged\xe2\x80\x94the\nbrigands!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh come, that\xe2\x80\x99s enough!\xe2\x80\x9d said the other.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do I care? Let him hear! We\xe2\x80\x99re not dogs,\xe2\x80\x9d said the ex-captain of\npolice, and looking round he noticed Alp\xc3\xa1tych.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Y\xc3\xa1kov Alp\xc3\xa1tych! What have you come for?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo see the Governor by his excellency\xe2\x80\x99s order,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Alp\xc3\xa1tych,\nlifting his head and proudly thrusting his hand into the bosom of his\ncoat as he always did when he mentioned the prince.... \xe2\x80\x9cHe has ordered\nme to inquire into the position of affairs,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, go and find out!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the angry gentleman. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve brought\nthings to such a pass that there are no carts or anything!... There it\nis again, do you hear?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, pointing in the direction whence came\nthe sounds of firing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve brought us all to ruin... the brigands!\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, and\ndescended the porch steps.\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych swayed his head and went upstairs. In the waiting room were\ntradesmen, women, and officials, looking silently at one another. The\ndoor of the Governor\xe2\x80\x99s room opened and they all rose and moved forward.\nAn official ran out, said some words to a merchant, called a stout\nofficial with a cross hanging on his neck to follow him, and vanished\nagain, evidently wishing to avoid the inquiring looks and questions\naddressed to him. Alp\xc3\xa1tych moved forward and next time the official came\nout addressed him, one hand placed in the breast of his buttoned coat,\nand handed him two letters.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo his Honor Baron Asch, from General-in-Chief Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nannounced with such solemnity and significance that the official turned\nto him and took the letters.\n\nA few minutes later the Governor received Alp\xc3\xa1tych and hurriedly said to\nhim:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cInform the prince and princess that I knew nothing: I acted on the\nhighest instructions\xe2\x80\x94here...\xe2\x80\x9d and he handed a paper to Alp\xc3\xa1tych. \xe2\x80\x9cStill,\nas the prince is unwell my advice is that they should go to Moscow. I am\njust starting myself. Inform them...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBut the Governor did not finish: a dusty perspiring officer ran into the\nroom and began to say something in French. The Governor\xe2\x80\x99s face expressed\nterror.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, nodding his head to Alp\xc3\xa1tych, and began questioning the\nofficer.\n\nEager, frightened, helpless glances were turned on Alp\xc3\xa1tych when he came\nout of the Governor\xe2\x80\x99s room. Involuntarily listening now to the firing,\nwhich had drawn nearer and was increasing in strength, Alp\xc3\xa1tych hurried\nto his inn. The paper handed to him by the Governor said this:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI assure you that the town of Smol\xc3\xa9nsk is not in the slightest danger\nas yet and it is unlikely that it will be threatened with any. I from\nthe one side and Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n from the other are marching to unite\nour forces before Smol\xc3\xa9nsk, which junction will be effected on the\n22nd instant, and both armies with their united forces will defend our\ncompatriots of the province entrusted to your care till our efforts\nshall have beaten back the enemies of our Fatherland, or till the last\nwarrior in our valiant ranks has perished. From this you will see that\nyou have a perfect right to reassure the inhabitants of Smol\xc3\xa9nsk, for\nthose defended by two such brave armies may feel assured of victory.\xe2\x80\x9d\n(Instructions from Barclay de Tolly to Baron Asch, the civil governor of\nSmol\xc3\xa9nsk, 1812.)\n\nPeople were anxiously roaming about the streets.\n\nCarts piled high with household utensils, chairs, and cupboards kept\nemerging from the gates of the yards and moving along the streets.\nLoaded carts stood at the house next to Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov\xe2\x80\x99s and women were\nwailing and lamenting as they said good-by. A small watchdog ran round\nbarking in front of the harnessed horses.\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych entered the innyard at a quicker pace than usual and went\nstraight to the shed where his horses and trap were. The coachman was\nasleep. He woke him up, told him to harness, and went into the passage.\nFrom the host\xe2\x80\x99s room came the sounds of a child crying, the despairing\nsobs of a woman, and the hoarse angry shouting of Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov. The cook\nbegan running hither and thither in the passage like a frightened hen,\njust as Alp\xc3\xa1tych entered.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s done her to death. Killed the mistress!... Beat her... dragged her\nabout so!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat for?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Alp\xc3\xa1tych.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe kept begging to go away. She\xe2\x80\x99s a woman! \xe2\x80\x98Take me away,\xe2\x80\x99 says she,\n\xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t let me perish with my little children! Folks,\xe2\x80\x99 she says, \xe2\x80\x98are all\ngone, so why,\xe2\x80\x99 she says, \xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t we go?\xe2\x80\x99 And he began beating and pulling\nher about so!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAt these words Alp\xc3\xa1tych nodded as if in approval, and not wishing to\nhear more went to the door of the room opposite the innkeeper\xe2\x80\x99s, where\nhe had left his purchases.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou brute, you murderer!\xe2\x80\x9d screamed a thin, pale woman who, with a baby\nin her arms and her kerchief torn from her head, burst through the door\nat that moment and down the steps into the yard.\n\nFerap\xc3\xb3ntov came out after her, but on seeing Alp\xc3\xa1tych adjusted his\nwaistcoat, smoothed his hair, yawned, and followed Alp\xc3\xa1tych into the\nopposite room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGoing already?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych, without answering or looking at his host, sorted his packages\nand asked how much he owed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll reckon up! Well, have you been to the Governor\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\nFerap\xc3\xb3ntov. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat has been decided?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych replied that the Governor had not told him anything definite.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith our business, how can we get away?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99d have\nto pay seven rubles a cartload to Dorogob\xc3\xbazh and I tell them they\xe2\x80\x99re\nnot Christians to ask it! Seliv\xc3\xa1nov, now, did a good stroke last\nThursday\xe2\x80\x94sold flour to the army at nine rubles a sack. Will you have\nsome tea?\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\n\nWhile the horses were being harnessed Alp\xc3\xa1tych and Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov over their\ntea talked of the price of corn, the crops, and the good weather for\nharvesting.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it seems to be getting quieter,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov, finishing\nhis third cup of tea and getting up. \xe2\x80\x9cOurs must have got the best of it.\nThe orders were not to let them in. So we\xe2\x80\x99re in force, it seems....\nThey say the other day Matthew Iv\xc3\xa1nych Pl\xc3\xa1tov drove them into the river\nM\xc3\xa1rina and drowned some eighteen thousand in one day.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych collected his parcels, handed them to the coachman who had come\nin, and settled up with the innkeeper. The noise of wheels, hoofs, and\nbells was heard from the gateway as a little trap passed out.\n\nIt was by now late in the afternoon. Half the street was in shadow, the\nother half brightly lit by the sun. Alp\xc3\xa1tych looked out of the window\nand went to the door. Suddenly the strange sound of a far-off whistling\nand thud was heard, followed by a boom of cannon blending into a dull\nroar that set the windows rattling.\n\nHe went out into the street: two men were running past toward the\nbridge. From different sides came whistling sounds and the thud of\ncannon balls and bursting shells falling on the town. But these sounds\nwere hardly heard in comparison with the noise of the firing outside the\ntown and attracted little attention from the inhabitants. The town was\nbeing bombarded by a hundred and thirty guns which Napoleon had ordered\nup after four o\xe2\x80\x99clock. The people did not at once realize the meaning of\nthis bombardment.\n\nAt first the noise of the falling bombs and shells only aroused\ncuriosity. Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov\xe2\x80\x99s wife, who till then had not ceased wailing under\nthe shed, became quiet and with the baby in her arms went to the gate,\nlistening to the sounds and looking in silence at the people.\n\nThe cook and a shop assistant came to the gate. With lively curiosity\neveryone tried to get a glimpse of the projectiles as they flew over\ntheir heads. Several people came round the corner talking eagerly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat force!\xe2\x80\x9d remarked one. \xe2\x80\x9cKnocked the roof and ceiling all to\nsplinters!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cRouted up the earth like a pig,\xe2\x80\x9d said another.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s grand, it bucks one up!\xe2\x80\x9d laughed the first. \xe2\x80\x9cLucky you jumped\naside, or it would have wiped you out!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nOthers joined those men and stopped and told how cannon balls had fallen\non a house close to them. Meanwhile still more projectiles, now with\nthe swift sinister whistle of a cannon ball, now with the agreeable\nintermittent whistle of a shell, flew over people\xe2\x80\x99s heads incessantly,\nbut not one fell close by, they all flew over. Alp\xc3\xa1tych was getting into\nhis trap. The innkeeper stood at the gate.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you staring at?\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted to the cook, who in her red skirt,\nwith sleeves rolled up, swinging her bare elbows, had stepped to the\ncorner to listen to what was being said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat marvels!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, but hearing her master\xe2\x80\x99s voice she turned\nback, pulling down her tucked-up skirt.\n\nOnce more something whistled, but this time quite close, swooping\ndownwards like a little bird; a flame flashed in the middle of the\nstreet, something exploded, and the street was shrouded in smoke.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cScoundrel, what are you doing?\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the innkeeper, rushing to the\ncook.\n\nAt that moment the pitiful wailing of women was heard from different\nsides, the frightened baby began to cry, and people crowded silently\nwith pale faces round the cook. The loudest sound in that crowd was her\nwailing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh-h-h! Dear souls, dear kind souls! Don\xe2\x80\x99t let me die! My good\nsouls!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nFive minutes later no one remained in the street. The cook, with her\nthigh broken by a shell splinter, had been carried into the kitchen.\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych, his coachman, Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov\xe2\x80\x99s wife and children and the house\nporter were all sitting in the cellar, listening. The roar of guns, the\nwhistling of projectiles, and the piteous moaning of the cook, which\nrose above the other sounds, did not cease for a moment. The mistress\nrocked and hushed her baby and when anyone came into the cellar asked\nin a pathetic whisper what had become of her husband who had remained\nin the street. A shopman who entered told her that her husband had\ngone with others to the cathedral, whence they were fetching the\nwonder-working icon of Smol\xc3\xa9nsk.\n\nToward dusk the cannonade began to subside. Alp\xc3\xa1tych left the cellar\nand stopped in the doorway. The evening sky that had been so clear was\nclouded with smoke, through which, high up, the sickle of the new moon\nshone strangely. Now that the terrible din of the guns had ceased a hush\nseemed to reign over the town, broken only by the rustle of footsteps,\nthe moaning, the distant cries, and the crackle of fires which seemed\nwidespread everywhere. The cook\xe2\x80\x99s moans had now subsided. On two sides\nblack curling clouds of smoke rose and spread from the fires. Through\nthe streets soldiers in various uniforms walked or ran confusedly in\ndifferent directions like ants from a ruined ant-hill. Several of them\nran into Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov\xe2\x80\x99s yard before Alp\xc3\xa1tych\xe2\x80\x99s eyes. Alp\xc3\xa1tych went out\nto the gate. A retreating regiment, thronging and hurrying, blocked the\nstreet.\n\nNoticing him, an officer said: \xe2\x80\x9cThe town is being abandoned. Get away,\nget away!\xe2\x80\x9d and then, turning to the soldiers, shouted:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll teach you to run into the yards!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych went back to the house, called the coachman, and told him to\nset off. Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov\xe2\x80\x99s whole household came out too, following Alp\xc3\xa1tych\nand the coachman. The women, who had been silent till then, suddenly\nbegan to wail as they looked at the fires\xe2\x80\x94the smoke and even the flames\nof which could be seen in the failing twilight\xe2\x80\x94and as if in reply the\nsame kind of lamentation was heard from other parts of the street.\nInside the shed Alp\xc3\xa1tych and the coachman arranged the tangled reins and\ntraces of their horses with trembling hands.\n\nAs Alp\xc3\xa1tych was driving out of the gate he saw some ten soldiers in\nFerap\xc3\xb3ntov\xe2\x80\x99s open shop, talking loudly and filling their bags and\nknapsacks with flour and sunflower seeds. Just then Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov returned\nand entered his shop. On seeing the soldiers he was about to shout at\nthem, but suddenly stopped and, clutching at his hair, burst into sobs\nand laughter:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLoot everything, lads! Don\xe2\x80\x99t let those devils get it!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, taking\nsome bags of flour himself and throwing them into the street.\n\nSome of the soldiers were frightened and ran away, others went on\nfilling their bags. On seeing Alp\xc3\xa1tych, Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov turned to him:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cRussia is done for!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried. \xe2\x80\x9cAlp\xc3\xa1tych, I\xe2\x80\x99ll set the place on fire\nmyself. We\xe2\x80\x99re done for!...\xe2\x80\x9d and Ferap\xc3\xb3ntov ran into the yard.\n\nSoldiers were passing in a constant stream along the street blocking\nit completely, so that Alp\xc3\xa1tych could not pass out and had to wait.\nFerap\xc3\xb3ntov\xe2\x80\x99s wife and children were also sitting in a cart waiting till\nit was possible to drive out.\n\nNight had come. There were stars in the sky and the new moon shone out\namid the smoke that screened it. On the sloping descent to the Dnieper\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych\xe2\x80\x99s cart and that of the innkeeper\xe2\x80\x99s wife, which were slowly\nmoving amid the rows of soldiers and of other vehicles, had to stop.\nIn a side street near the crossroads where the vehicles had stopped, a\nhouse and some shops were on fire. This fire was already burning itself\nout. The flames now died down and were lost in the black smoke, now\nsuddenly flared up again brightly, lighting up with strange distinctness\nthe faces of the people crowding at the crossroads. Black figures\nflitted about before the fire, and through the incessant crackling of\nthe flames talking and shouting could be heard. Seeing that his trap\nwould not be able to move on for some time, Alp\xc3\xa1tych got down and turned\ninto the side street to look at the fire. Soldiers were continually\nrushing backwards and forwards near it, and he saw two of them and a\nman in a frieze coat dragging burning beams into another yard across the\nstreet, while others carried bundles of hay.\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych went up to a large crowd standing before a high barn which was\nblazing briskly. The walls were all on fire and the back wall had fallen\nin, the wooden roof was collapsing, and the rafters were alight. The\ncrowd was evidently watching for the roof to fall in, and Alp\xc3\xa1tych\nwatched for it too.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlp\xc3\xa1tych!\xe2\x80\x9d a familiar voice suddenly hailed the old man.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMercy on us! Your excellency!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Alp\xc3\xa1tych, immediately\nrecognizing the voice of his young prince.\n\nPrince Andrew in his riding cloak, mounted on a black horse, was looking\nat Alp\xc3\xa1tych from the back of the crowd.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you here?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour... your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered Alp\xc3\xa1tych and broke into sobs. \xe2\x80\x9cAre\nwe really lost? Master!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you here?\xe2\x80\x9d Prince Andrew repeated.\n\nAt that moment the flames flared up and showed his young master\xe2\x80\x99s pale\nworn face. Alp\xc3\xa1tych told how he had been sent there and how difficult it\nwas to get away.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre we really quite lost, your excellency?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked again.\n\nPrince Andrew without replying took out a notebook and raising his knee\nbegan writing in pencil on a page he tore out. He wrote to his sister:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSmol\xc3\xa9nsk is being abandoned. Bald Hills will be occupied by the enemy\nwithin a week. Set off immediately for Moscow. Let me know at once when\nyou will start. Send by special messenger to Usvy\xc3\xa1zh.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHaving written this and given the paper to Alp\xc3\xa1tych, he told him how\nto arrange for departure of the prince, the princess, his son, and the\nboy\xe2\x80\x99s tutor, and how and where to let him know immediately. Before\nhe had had time to finish giving these instructions, a chief of staff\nfollowed by a suite galloped up to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a colonel?\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the chief of staff with a German accent,\nin a voice familiar to Prince Andrew. \xe2\x80\x9cHouses are set on fire in your\npresence and you stand by! What does this mean? You will answer for\nit!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Berg, who was now assistant to the chief of staff of the\ncommander of the left flank of the infantry of the first army, a place,\nas Berg said, \xe2\x80\x9cvery agreeable and well en \xc3\xa9vidence.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew looked at him and without replying went on speaking to\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo tell them that I shall await a reply till the tenth, and if by the\ntenth I don\xe2\x80\x99t receive news that they have all got away I shall have to\nthrow up everything and come myself to Bald Hills.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrince,\xe2\x80\x9d said Berg, recognizing Prince Andrew, \xe2\x80\x9cI only spoke because\nI have to obey orders, because I always do obey exactly.... You must\nplease excuse me,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on apologetically.\n\nSomething cracked in the flames. The fire died down for a moment and\nwreaths of black smoke rolled from under the roof. There was another\nterrible crash and something huge collapsed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOu-rou-rou!\xe2\x80\x9d yelled the crowd, echoing the crash of the collapsing roof\nof the barn, the burning grain in which diffused a cakelike aroma all\naround. The flames flared up again, lighting the animated, delighted,\nexhausted faces of the spectators.\n\nThe man in the frieze coat raised his arms and shouted:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s fine, lads! Now it\xe2\x80\x99s raging... It\xe2\x80\x99s fine!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the owner himself,\xe2\x80\x9d cried several voices.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Prince Andrew to Alp\xc3\xa1tych, \xe2\x80\x9creport to them as I\nhave told you\xe2\x80\x9d; and not replying a word to Berg who was now mute beside\nhim, he touched his horse and rode down the side street.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER V\n\nFrom Smol\xc3\xa9nsk the troops continued to retreat, followed by the enemy.\nOn the tenth of August the regiment Prince Andrew commanded was marching\nalong the highroad past the avenue leading to Bald Hills. Heat and\ndrought had continued for more than three weeks. Each day fleecy clouds\nfloated across the sky and occasionally veiled the sun, but toward\nevening the sky cleared again and the sun set in reddish-brown mist.\nHeavy night dews alone refreshed the earth. The unreaped corn was\nscorched and shed its grain. The marshes dried up. The cattle lowed from\nhunger, finding no food on the sun-parched meadows. Only at night and\nin the forests while the dew lasted was there any freshness. But on the\nroad, the highroad along which the troops marched, there was no such\nfreshness even at night or when the road passed through the forest; the\ndew was imperceptible on the sandy dust churned up more than six inches\ndeep. As soon as day dawned the march began. The artillery and baggage\nwagons moved noiselessly through the deep dust that rose to the very\nhubs of the wheels, and the infantry sank ankle-deep in that soft,\nchoking, hot dust that never cooled even at night. Some of this dust\nwas kneaded by the feet and wheels, while the rest rose and hung like a\ncloud over the troops, settling in eyes, ears, hair, and nostrils, and\nworst of all in the lungs of the men and beasts as they moved along that\nroad. The higher the sun rose the higher rose that cloud of dust, and\nthrough the screen of its hot fine particles one could look with naked\neye at the sun, which showed like a huge crimson ball in the unclouded\nsky. There was no wind, and the men choked in that motionless\natmosphere. They marched with handkerchiefs tied over their noses and\nmouths. When they passed through a village they all rushed to the wells\nand fought for the water and drank it down to the mud.\n\nPrince Andrew was in command of a regiment, and the management of that\nregiment, the welfare of the men and the necessity of receiving\nand giving orders, engrossed him. The burning of Smol\xc3\xa9nsk and its\nabandonment made an epoch in his life. A novel feeling of anger against\nthe foe made him forget his own sorrow. He was entirely devoted to the\naffairs of his regiment and was considerate and kind to his men and\nofficers. In the regiment they called him \xe2\x80\x9cour prince,\xe2\x80\x9d were proud\nof him and loved him. But he was kind and gentle only to those of his\nregiment, to Tim\xc3\xb3khin and the like\xe2\x80\x94people quite new to him, belonging\nto a different world and who could not know and understand his past. As\nsoon as he came across a former acquaintance or anyone from the\nstaff, he bristled up immediately and grew spiteful, ironical, and\ncontemptuous. Everything that reminded him of his past was repugnant to\nhim, and so in his relations with that former circle he confined himself\nto trying to do his duty and not to be unfair.\n\nIn truth everything presented itself in a dark and gloomy light to\nPrince Andrew, especially after the abandonment of Smol\xc3\xa9nsk on the sixth\nof August (he considered that it could and should have been defended)\nand after his sick father had had to flee to Moscow, abandoning to\npillage his dearly beloved Bald Hills which he had built and peopled.\nBut despite this, thanks to his regiment, Prince Andrew had something to\nthink about entirely apart from general questions. Two days previously\nhe had received news that his father, son, and sister had left for\nMoscow; and though there was nothing for him to do at Bald Hills, Prince\nAndrew with a characteristic desire to foment his own grief decided that\nhe must ride there.\n\nHe ordered his horse to be saddled and, leaving his regiment on the\nmarch, rode to his father\xe2\x80\x99s estate where he had been born and spent his\nchildhood. Riding past the pond where there used always to be dozens\nof women chattering as they rinsed their linen or beat it with wooden\nbeetles, Prince Andrew noticed that there was not a soul about and that\nthe little washing wharf, torn from its place and half submerged, was\nfloating on its side in the middle of the pond. He rode to the keeper\xe2\x80\x99s\nlodge. No one was at the stone entrance gates of the drive and the door\nstood open. Grass had already begun to grow on the garden paths, and\nhorses and calves were straying in the English park. Prince Andrew rode\nup to the hothouse; some of the glass panes were broken, and of the\ntrees in tubs some were overturned and others dried up. He called for\nTar\xc3\xa1s the gardener, but no one replied. Having gone round the corner\nof the hothouse to the ornamental garden, he saw that the carved garden\nfence was broken and branches of the plum trees had been torn off with\nthe fruit. An old peasant whom Prince Andrew in his childhood had often\nseen at the gate was sitting on a green garden seat, plaiting a bast\nshoe.\n\nHe was deaf and did not hear Prince Andrew ride up. He was sitting on\nthe seat the old prince used to like to sit on, and beside him strips of\nbast were hanging on the broken and withered branch of a magnolia.\n\nPrince Andrew rode up to the house. Several limes in the old garden had\nbeen cut down and a piebald mare and her foal were wandering in front of\nthe house among the rosebushes. The shutters were all closed, except at\none window which was open. A little serf boy, seeing Prince Andrew, ran\ninto the house. Alp\xc3\xa1tych, having sent his family away, was alone at\nBald Hills and was sitting indoors reading the Lives of the Saints. On\nhearing that Prince Andrew had come, he went out with his spectacles on\nhis nose, buttoning his coat, and, hastily stepping up, without a word\nbegan weeping and kissing Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s knee.\n\nThen, vexed at his own weakness, he turned away and began to report\non the position of affairs. Everything precious and valuable had been\nremoved to Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo. Seventy quarters of grain had also been carted\naway. The hay and the spring corn, of which Alp\xc3\xa1tych said there had been\na remarkable crop that year, had been commandeered by the troops and\nmown down while still green. The peasants were ruined; some of them too\nhad gone to Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo, only a few remained.\n\nWithout waiting to hear him out, Prince Andrew asked:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen did my father and sister leave?\xe2\x80\x9d meaning when did they leave for\nMoscow.\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych, understanding the question to refer to their departure for\nBoguch\xc3\xa1rovo, replied that they had left on the seventh and again went\ninto details concerning the estate management, asking for instructions.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I to let the troops have the oats, and to take a receipt for them?\nWe have still six hundred quarters left,\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat am I to say to him?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Prince Andrew, looking down on the\nold man\xe2\x80\x99s bald head shining in the sun and seeing by the expression on\nhis face that the old man himself understood how untimely such questions\nwere and only asked them to allay his grief.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, let them have it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Prince Andrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you noticed some disorder in the garden,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alp\xc3\xa1tych, \xe2\x80\x9cit was\nimpossible to prevent it. Three regiments have been here and spent\nthe night, dragoons mostly. I took down the name and rank of their\ncommanding officer, to hand in a complaint about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and what are you going to do? Will you stay here if the enemy\noccupies the place?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Prince Andrew.\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych turned his face to Prince Andrew, looked at him, and suddenly\nwith a solemn gesture raised his arm.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is my refuge! His will be done!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed.\n\nA group of bareheaded peasants was approaching across the meadow toward\nthe prince.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, good-by!\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Andrew, bending over to Alp\xc3\xa1tych. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\nmust go away too, take away what you can and tell the serfs to go to the\nRyaz\xc3\xa1n estate or to the one near Moscow.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych clung to Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s leg and burst into sobs. Gently\ndisengaging himself, the prince spurred his horse and rode down the\navenue at a gallop.\n\nThe old man was still sitting in the ornamental garden, like a fly\nimpassive on the face of a loved one who is dead, tapping the last on\nwhich he was making the bast shoe, and two little girls, running out\nfrom the hot house carrying in their skirts plums they had plucked from\nthe trees there, came upon Prince Andrew. On seeing the young master,\nthe elder one with frightened look clutched her younger companion by the\nhand and hid with her behind a birch tree, not stopping to pick up some\ngreen plums they had dropped.\n\nPrince Andrew turned away with startled haste, unwilling to let them\nsee that they had been observed. He was sorry for the pretty frightened\nlittle girl, was afraid of looking at her, and yet felt an irresistible\ndesire to do so. A new sensation of comfort and relief came over him\nwhen, seeing these girls, he realized the existence of other human\ninterests entirely aloof from his own and just as legitimate as those\nthat occupied him. Evidently these girls passionately desired one\nthing\xe2\x80\x94to carry away and eat those green plums without being caught\xe2\x80\x94and\nPrince Andrew shared their wish for the success of their enterprise. He\ncould not resist looking at them once more. Believing their danger past,\nthey sprang from their ambush and, chirruping something in their shrill\nlittle voices and holding up their skirts, their bare little sunburned\nfeet scampered merrily and quickly across the meadow grass.\n\nPrince Andrew was somewhat refreshed by having ridden off the dusty\nhighroad along which the troops were moving. But not far from Bald Hills\nhe again came out on the road and overtook his regiment at its halting\nplace by the dam of a small pond. It was past one o\xe2\x80\x99clock. The sun,\na red ball through the dust, burned and scorched his back intolerably\nthrough his black coat. The dust always hung motionless above the buzz\nof talk that came from the resting troops. There was no wind. As he\ncrossed the dam Prince Andrew smelled the ooze and freshness of the\npond. He longed to get into that water, however dirty it might be, and\nhe glanced round at the pool from whence came sounds of shrieks and\nlaughter. The small, muddy, green pond had risen visibly more than a\nfoot, flooding the dam, because it was full of the naked white bodies\nof soldiers with brick-red hands, necks, and faces, who were splashing\nabout in it. All this naked white human flesh, laughing and shrieking,\nfloundered about in that dirty pool like carp stuffed into a watering\ncan, and the suggestion of merriment in that floundering mass rendered\nit specially pathetic.\n\nOne fair-haired young soldier of the third company, whom Prince Andrew\nknew and who had a strap round the calf of one leg, crossed himself,\nstepped back to get a good run, and plunged into the water; another,\na dark noncommissioned officer who was always shaggy, stood up to his\nwaist in the water joyfully wriggling his muscular figure and snorted\nwith satisfaction as he poured the water over his head with hands\nblackened to the wrists. There were sounds of men slapping one another,\nyelling, and puffing.\n\nEverywhere on the bank, on the dam, and in the pond, there was healthy,\nwhite, muscular flesh. The officer, Tim\xc3\xb3khin, with his red little nose,\nstanding on the dam wiping himself with a towel, felt confused at seeing\nthe prince, but made up his mind to address him nevertheless.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s very nice, your excellency! Wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you like to?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s dirty,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Prince Andrew, making a grimace.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll clear it out for you in a minute,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tim\xc3\xb3khin, and, still\nundressed, ran off to clear the men out of the pond.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe prince wants to bathe.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat prince? Ours?\xe2\x80\x9d said many voices, and the men were in such haste\nto clear out that the prince could hardly stop them. He decided that he\nwould rather wash himself with water in the barn.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFlesh, bodies, cannon fodder!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, and he looked at his own\nnaked body and shuddered, not from cold but from a sense of disgust\nand horror he did not himself understand, aroused by the sight of that\nimmense number of bodies splashing about in the dirty pond.\n\n\nOn the seventh of August Prince Bagrati\xc3\xb3n wrote as follows from his\nquarters at Mikh\xc3\xa1ylovna on the Smol\xc3\xa9nsk road:\n\nDear Count Al\xc3\xa9xis Andr\xc3\xa9evich\xe2\x80\x94(He was writing to Arakch\xc3\xa9ev but knew that\nhis letter would be read by the Emperor, and therefore weighed every\nword in it to the best of his ability.)\n\nI expect the Minister (Barclay de Tolly) has already reported the\nabandonment of Smol\xc3\xa9nsk to the enemy. It is pitiable and sad, and\nthe whole army is in despair that this most important place has been\nwantonly abandoned. I, for my part, begged him personally most urgently\nand finally wrote him, but nothing would induce him to consent. I swear\nto you on my honor that Napoleon was in such a fix as never before and\nmight have lost half his army but could not have taken Smol\xc3\xa9nsk. Our\ntroops fought, and are fighting, as never before. With fifteen thousand\nmen I held the enemy at bay for thirty-five hours and beat him; but he\nwould not hold out even for fourteen hours. It is disgraceful, a stain\non our army, and as for him, he ought, it seems to me, not to live. If\nhe reports that our losses were great, it is not true; perhaps about\nfour thousand, not more, and not even that; but even were they ten\nthousand, that\xe2\x80\x99s war! But the enemy has lost masses....\n\nWhat would it have cost him to hold out for another two days? They would\nhave had to retire of their own accord, for they had no water for men\nor horses. He gave me his word he would not retreat, but suddenly sent\ninstructions that he was retiring that night. We cannot fight in this\nway, or we may soon bring the enemy to Moscow....\n\nThere is a rumor that you are thinking of peace. God forbid that you\nshould make peace after all our sacrifices and such insane retreats! You\nwould set all Russia against you and everyone of us would feel ashamed\nto wear the uniform. If it has come to this\xe2\x80\x94we must fight as long as\nRussia can and as long as there are men able to stand....\n\nOne man ought to be in command, and not two. Your Minister may perhaps\nbe good as a Minister, but as a general he is not merely bad but\nexecrable, yet to him is entrusted the fate of our whole country.... I\nam really frantic with vexation; forgive my writing boldly. It is clear\nthat the man who advocates the conclusion of a peace, and that the\nMinister should command the army, does not love our sovereign and\ndesires the ruin of us all. So I write you frankly: call out the\nmilitia. For the Minister is leading these visitors after him to Moscow\nin a most masterly way. The whole army feels great suspicion of the\nImperial aide-de-camp Wolzogen. He is said to be more Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s man\nthan ours, and he is always advising the Minister. I am not merely civil\nto him but obey him like a corporal, though I am his senior. This is\npainful, but, loving my benefactor and sovereign, I submit. Only I am\nsorry for the Emperor that he entrusts our fine army to such as he.\nConsider that on our retreat we have lost by fatigue and left in the\nhospital more than fifteen thousand men, and had we attacked this would\nnot have happened. Tell me, for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, what will Russia, our mother\nRussia, say to our being so frightened, and why are we abandoning our\ngood and gallant Fatherland to such rabble and implanting feelings of\nhatred and shame in all our subjects? What are we scared at and of whom\nare we afraid? I am not to blame that the Minister is vacillating,\na coward, dense, dilatory, and has all bad qualities. The whole army\nbewails it and calls down curses upon him....\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VI\n\nAmong the innumerable categories applicable to the phenomena of human\nlife one may discriminate between those in which substance prevails\nand those in which form prevails. To the latter\xe2\x80\x94as distinguished\nfrom village, country, provincial, or even Moscow life\xe2\x80\x94we may allot\nPetersburg life, and especially the life of its salons. That life of\nthe salons is unchanging. Since the year 1805 we had made peace and had\nagain quarreled with Bonaparte and had made constitutions and unmade\nthem again, but the salons of Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna and H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne remained just\nas they had been\xe2\x80\x94the one seven and the other five years before. At Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s they talked with perplexity of Bonaparte\xe2\x80\x99s successes just\nas before and saw in them and in the subservience shown to him by the\nEuropean sovereigns a malicious conspiracy, the sole object of which was\nto cause unpleasantness and anxiety to the court circle of which Anna\nP\xc3\xa1vlovna was the representative. And in H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s salon, which Rumy\xc3\xa1ntsev\nhimself honored with his visits, regarding H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne as a remarkably\nintelligent woman, they talked with the same ecstasy in 1812 as in 1808\nof the \xe2\x80\x9cgreat nation\xe2\x80\x9d and the \xe2\x80\x9cgreat man,\xe2\x80\x9d and regretted our rupture\nwith France, a rupture which, according to them, ought to be promptly\nterminated by peace.\n\nOf late, since the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s return from the army, there had been some\nexcitement in these conflicting salon circles and some demonstrations\nof hostility to one another, but each camp retained its own tendency.\nIn Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s circle only those Frenchmen were admitted who were\ndeep-rooted legitimists, and patriotic views were expressed to the\neffect that one ought not to go to the French theater and that to\nmaintain the French troupe was costing the government as much as a whole\narmy corps. The progress of the war was eagerly followed, and only\nthe reports most flattering to our army were circulated. In the French\ncircle of H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne and Rumy\xc3\xa1ntsev the reports of the cruelty of the\nenemy and of the war were contradicted and all Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s attempts at\nconciliation were discussed. In that circle they discountenanced those\nwho advised hurried preparations for a removal to Kaz\xc3\xa1n of the court and\nthe girls\xe2\x80\x99 educational establishments under the patronage of the Dowager\nEmpress. In H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s circle the war in general was regarded as a series\nof formal demonstrations which would very soon end in peace, and the\nview prevailed expressed by Bil\xc3\xadbin\xe2\x80\x94who now in Petersburg was quite at\nhome in H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s house, which every clever man was obliged to visit\xe2\x80\x94that\nnot by gunpowder but by those who invented it would matters be\nsettled. In that circle the Moscow enthusiasm\xe2\x80\x94news of which had reached\nPetersburg simultaneously with the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s return\xe2\x80\x94was ridiculed\nsarcastically and very cleverly, though with much caution.\n\nAnna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s circle on the contrary was enraptured by this enthusiasm\nand spoke of it as Plutarch speaks of the deeds of the ancients.\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli, who still occupied his former important posts, formed a\nconnecting link between these two circles. He visited his \xe2\x80\x9cgood friend\nAnna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x9d as well as his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cdiplomatic salon,\xe2\x80\x9d and often\nin his constant comings and goings between the two camps became confused\nand said at H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s what he should have said at Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s and\nvice versa.\n\nSoon after the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s return Prince Vas\xc3\xadli in a conversation about\nthe war at Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s severely condemned Barclay de Tolly, but was\nundecided as to who ought to be appointed commander in chief. One of the\nvisitors, usually spoken of as \xe2\x80\x9ca man of great merit,\xe2\x80\x9d having described\nhow he had that day seen Kut\xc3\xbazov, the newly chosen chief of the\nPetersburg militia, presiding over the enrollment of recruits at the\nTreasury, cautiously ventured to suggest that Kut\xc3\xbazov would be the man\nto satisfy all requirements.\n\nAnna P\xc3\xa1vlovna remarked with a melancholy smile that Kut\xc3\xbazov had done\nnothing but cause the Emperor annoyance.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have talked and talked at the Assembly of the Nobility,\xe2\x80\x9d Prince\nVas\xc3\xadli interrupted, \xe2\x80\x9cbut they did not listen to me. I told them his\nelection as chief of the militia would not please the Emperor. They did\nnot listen to me.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all this mania for opposition,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd who for? It is\nall because we want to ape the foolish enthusiasm of those Muscovites,\xe2\x80\x9d\nPrince Vas\xc3\xadli continued, forgetting for a moment that though at H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne\xe2\x80\x99s\none had to ridicule the Moscow enthusiasm, at Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s one had to\nbe ecstatic about it. But he retrieved his mistake at once. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, is\nit suitable that Count Kut\xc3\xbazov, the oldest general in Russia, should\npreside at that tribunal? He will get nothing for his pains! How could\nthey make a man commander in chief who cannot mount a horse, who drops\nasleep at a council, and has the very worst morals! A good reputation\nhe made for himself at Bucharest! I don\xe2\x80\x99t speak of his capacity as a\ngeneral, but at a time like this how they appoint a decrepit, blind old\nman, positively blind? A fine idea to have a blind general! He can\xe2\x80\x99t see\nanything. To play blindman\xe2\x80\x99s bulff? He can\xe2\x80\x99t see at all!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNo one replied to his remarks.\n\nThis was quite correct on the twenty-fourth of July. But on the\ntwenty-ninth of July Kut\xc3\xbazov received the title of Prince. This might\nindicate a wish to get rid of him, and therefore Prince Vas\xc3\xadli\xe2\x80\x99s opinion\ncontinued to be correct though he was not now in any hurry to express\nit. But on the eighth of August a committee, consisting of Field Marshal\nSaltyk\xc3\xb3v, Arakch\xc3\xa9ev, Vyazm\xc3\xadtinov, Lopukh\xc3\xadn, and Kochub\xc3\xa9y met to consider\nthe progress of the war. This committee came to the conclusion that\nour failures were due to a want of unity in the command and though the\nmembers of the committee were aware of the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s dislike of Kut\xc3\xbazov,\nafter a short deliberation they agreed to advise his appointment as\ncommander in chief. That same day Kut\xc3\xbazov was appointed commander\nin chief with full powers over the armies and over the whole region\noccupied by them.\n\nOn the ninth of August Prince Vas\xc3\xadli at Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s again met the\n\xe2\x80\x9cman of great merit.\xe2\x80\x9d The latter was very attentive to Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\nbecause he wanted to be appointed director of one of the educational\nestablishments for young ladies. Prince Vas\xc3\xadli entered the room with the\nair of a happy conqueror who has attained the object of his desires.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, have you heard the great news? Prince Kut\xc3\xbazov is field marshal!\nAll dissensions are at an end! I am so glad, so delighted! At last\nwe have a man!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, glancing sternly and significantly round at\neveryone in the drawing room.\n\nThe \xe2\x80\x9cman of great merit,\xe2\x80\x9d despite his desire to obtain the post of\ndirector, could not refrain from reminding Prince Vas\xc3\xadli of his former\nopinion. Though this was impolite to Prince Vas\xc3\xadli in Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna\xe2\x80\x99s\ndrawing room, and also to Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna herself who had received the\nnews with delight, he could not resist the temptation.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Prince, they say he is blind!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, reminding Prince Vas\xc3\xadli of\nhis own words.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh? Nonsense! He sees well enough,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince Vas\xc3\xadli rapidly, in a\ndeep voice and with a slight cough\xe2\x80\x94the voice and cough with which he was\nwont to dispose of all difficulties.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe sees well enough,\xe2\x80\x9d he added. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd what I am so pleased about,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nwent on, \xe2\x80\x9cis that our sovereign has given him full powers over all\nthe armies and the whole region\xe2\x80\x94powers no commander in chief ever had\nbefore. He is a second autocrat,\xe2\x80\x9d he concluded with a victorious smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod grant it! God grant it!\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna.\n\nThe \xe2\x80\x9cman of great merit,\xe2\x80\x9d who was still a novice in court circles,\nwishing to flatter Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna by defending her former position on\nthis question, observed:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is said that the Emperor was reluctant to give Kut\xc3\xbazov those powers.\nThey say he blushed like a girl to whom Joconde is read, when he said to\nKut\xc3\xbazov: \xe2\x80\x98Your Emperor and the Fatherland award you this honor.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps the heart took no part in that speech,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, no!\xe2\x80\x9d warmly rejoined Prince Vas\xc3\xadli, who would not now yield\nKut\xc3\xbazov to anyone; in his opinion Kut\xc3\xbazov was not only admirable\nhimself, but was adored by everybody. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, that\xe2\x80\x99s impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\n\xe2\x80\x9cfor our sovereign appreciated him so highly before.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod grant only that Prince Kut\xc3\xbazov assumes real power and does not\nallow anyone to put a spoke in his wheel,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna.\n\nUnderstanding at once to whom she alluded, Prince Vas\xc3\xadli said in a\nwhisper:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know for a fact that Kut\xc3\xbazov made it an absolute condition that the\nTsar\xc3\xa9vich should not be with the army. Do you know what he said to the\nEmperor?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Prince Vas\xc3\xadli repeated the words supposed to have been spoken by\nKut\xc3\xbazov to the Emperor. \xe2\x80\x9cI can neither punish him if he does wrong nor\nreward him if he does right.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, a very wise man is Prince Kut\xc3\xbazov! I have known him a long time!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey even say,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the \xe2\x80\x9cman of great merit\xe2\x80\x9d who did not yet\npossess courtly tact, \xe2\x80\x9cthat his excellency made it an express condition\nthat the sovereign himself should not be with the army.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAs soon as he said this both Prince Vas\xc3\xadli and Anna P\xc3\xa1vlovna turned away\nfrom him and glanced sadly at one another with a sigh at his na\xc3\xafvet\xc3\xa9.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VII\n\nWhile this was taking place in Petersburg the French had already passed\nSmol\xc3\xa9nsk and were drawing nearer and nearer to Moscow. Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s\nhistorian Thiers, like other of his historians, trying to justify his\nhero says that he was drawn to the walls of Moscow against his will. He\nis as right as other historians who look for the explanation of historic\nevents in the will of one man; he is as right as the Russian historians\nwho maintain that Napoleon was drawn to Moscow by the skill of the\nRussian commanders. Here besides the law of retrospection, which regards\nall the past as a preparation for events that subsequently occur,\nthe law of reciprocity comes in, confusing the whole matter. A good\nchessplayer having lost a game is sincerely convinced that his loss\nresulted from a mistake he made and looks for that mistake in the\nopening, but forgets that at each stage of the game there were similar\nmistakes and that none of his moves were perfect. He only notices the\nmistake to which he pays attention, because his opponent took advantage\nof it. How much more complex than this is the game of war, which\noccurs under certain limits of time, and where it is not one will that\nmanipulates lifeless objects, but everything results from innumerable\nconflicts of various wills!\n\nAfter Smol\xc3\xa9nsk Napoleon sought a battle beyond Dorogob\xc3\xbazh at Vy\xc3\xa1zma, and\nthen at Ts\xc3\xa1revo-Zaym\xc3\xadshche, but it happened that owing to a conjunction\nof innumerable circumstances the Russians could not give battle till\nthey reached Borodin\xc3\xb3, seventy miles from Moscow. From Vy\xc3\xa1zma Napoleon\nordered a direct advance on Moscow.\n\nMoscou, la capitale asiatique de ce grand empire, la ville sacr\xc3\xa9e des\npeuples d\xe2\x80\x99Alexandre, Moscou avec ses innombrables \xc3\xa9glises en forme de\npagodes chinoises, * this Moscow gave Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s imagination no rest.\nOn the march from Vy\xc3\xa1zma to Ts\xc3\xa1revo-Zaym\xc3\xadshche he rode his light bay\nbobtailed ambler accompanied by his Guards, his bodyguard, his pages,\nand aides-de-camp. Berthier, his chief of staff, dropped behind to\nquestion a Russian prisoner captured by the cavalry. Followed by\nLelorgne d\xe2\x80\x99Ideville, an interpreter, he overtook Napoleon at a gallop\nand reined in his horse with an amused expression.\n\n     * \xe2\x80\x9cMoscow, the Asiatic capital of this great empire, the\n     sacred city of Alexander\xe2\x80\x99s people, Moscow with its\n     innumerable churches shaped like Chinese pagodas.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Napoleon.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of Pl\xc3\xa1tov\xe2\x80\x99s Cossacks says that Pl\xc3\xa1tov\xe2\x80\x99s corps is joining up with\nthe main army and that Kut\xc3\xbazov has been appointed commander in chief. He\nis a very shrewd and garrulous fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNapoleon smiled and told them to give the Cossack a horse and bring the\nman to him. He wished to talk to him himself. Several adjutants galloped\noff, and an hour later, Lavr\xc3\xbashka, the serf Den\xc3\xadsov had handed over\nto Rost\xc3\xb3v, rode up to Napoleon in an orderly\xe2\x80\x99s jacket and on a French\ncavalry saddle, with a merry, and tipsy face. Napoleon told him to ride\nby his side and began questioning him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a Cossack?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, a Cossack, your Honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Cossack, not knowing in what company he was, for Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s plain\nappearance had nothing about it that would reveal to an Oriental mind\nthe presence of a monarch, talked with extreme familiarity of the\nincidents of the war,\xe2\x80\x9d says Thiers, narrating this episode. In\nreality Lavr\xc3\xbashka, having got drunk the day before and left his master\ndinnerless, had been whipped and sent to the village in quest of\nchickens, where he engaged in looting till the French took him prisoner.\nLavr\xc3\xbashka was one of those coarse, bare-faced lackeys who have seen all\nsorts of things, consider it necessary to do everything in a mean and\ncunning way, are ready to render any sort of service to their master,\nand are keen at guessing their master\xe2\x80\x99s baser impulses, especially those\nprompted by vanity and pettiness.\n\nFinding himself in the company of Napoleon, whose identity he had easily\nand surely recognized, Lavr\xc3\xbashka was not in the least abashed but merely\ndid his utmost to gain his new master\xe2\x80\x99s favor.\n\nHe knew very well that this was Napoleon, but Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s presence could\nno more intimidate him than Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s, or a sergeant major\xe2\x80\x99s with the\nrods, would have done, for he had nothing that either the sergeant major\nor Napoleon could deprive him of.\n\nSo he rattled on, telling all the gossip he had heard among the\norderlies. Much of it true. But when Napoleon asked him whether the\nRussians thought they would beat Bonaparte or not, Lavr\xc3\xbashka screwed up\nhis eyes and considered.\n\nIn this question he saw subtle cunning, as men of his type see cunning\nin everything, so he frowned and did not answer immediately.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s like this,\xe2\x80\x9d he said thoughtfully, \xe2\x80\x9cif there\xe2\x80\x99s a battle soon, yours\nwill win. That\xe2\x80\x99s right. But if three days pass, then after that, well,\nthen that same battle will not soon be over.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nLelorgne d\xe2\x80\x99Ideville smilingly interpreted this speech to Napoleon thus:\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf a battle takes place within the next three days the French will\nwin, but if later, God knows what will happen.\xe2\x80\x9d Napoleon did not smile,\nthough he was evidently in high good humor, and he ordered these words\nto be repeated.\n\nLavr\xc3\xbashka noticed this and to entertain him further, pretending not to\nknow who Napoleon was, added:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe know that you have Bonaparte and that he has beaten everybody in the\nworld, but we are a different matter...\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94without knowing why or how this\nbit of boastful patriotism slipped out at the end.\n\nThe interpreter translated these words without the last phrase, and\nBonaparte smiled. \xe2\x80\x9cThe young Cossack made his mighty interlocutor\nsmile,\xe2\x80\x9d says Thiers. After riding a few paces in silence, Napoleon\nturned to Berthier and said he wished to see how the news that he was\ntalking to the Emperor himself, to that very Emperor who had written his\nimmortally victorious name on the Pyramids, would affect this enfant du\nDon. *\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cChild of the Don.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nThe fact was accordingly conveyed to Lavr\xc3\xbashka.\n\nLavr\xc3\xbashka, understanding that this was done to perplex him and that\nNapoleon expected him to be frightened, to gratify his new masters\npromptly pretended to be astonished and awe-struck, opened his eyes\nwide, and assumed the expression he usually put on when taken to be\nwhipped. \xe2\x80\x9cAs soon as Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s interpreter had spoken,\xe2\x80\x9d says Thiers,\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe Cossack, seized by amazement, did not utter another word, but rode\non, his eyes fixed on the conqueror whose fame had reached him across\nthe steppes of the East. All his loquacity was suddenly arrested and\nreplaced by a na\xc3\xafve and silent feeling of admiration. Napoleon, after\nmaking the Cossack a present, had him set free like a bird restored to\nits native fields.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNapoleon rode on, dreaming of the Moscow that so appealed to his\nimagination, and \xe2\x80\x9cthe bird restored to its native fields\xe2\x80\x9d galloped to\nour outposts, inventing on the way all that had not taken place but that\nhe meant to relate to his comrades. What had really taken place he did\nnot wish to relate because it seemed to him not worth telling. He\nfound the Cossacks, inquired for the regiment operating with Pl\xc3\xa1tov\xe2\x80\x99s\ndetachment and by evening found his master, Nicholas Rost\xc3\xb3v, quartered\nat Yank\xc3\xb3vo. Rost\xc3\xb3v was just mounting to go for a ride round the\nneighboring villages with Ily\xc3\xadn; he let Lavr\xc3\xbashka have another horse and\ntook him along with him.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VIII\n\nPrincess Mary was not in Moscow and out of danger as Prince Andrew\nsupposed.\n\nAfter the return of Alp\xc3\xa1tych from Smol\xc3\xa9nsk the old prince suddenly\nseemed to awake as from a dream. He ordered the militiamen to be called\nup from the villages and armed, and wrote a letter to the commander in\nchief informing him that he had resolved to remain at Bald Hills to the\nlast extremity and to defend it, leaving to the commander in chief\xe2\x80\x99s\ndiscretion to take measures or not for the defense of Bald Hills, where\none of Russia\xe2\x80\x99s oldest generals would be captured or killed, and he\nannounced to his household that he would remain at Bald Hills.\n\nBut while himself remaining, he gave instructions for the departure of\nthe princess and Dessalles with the little prince to Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo and\nthence to Moscow. Princess Mary, alarmed by her father\xe2\x80\x99s feverish and\nsleepless activity after his previous apathy, could not bring herself to\nleave him alone and for the first time in her life ventured to disobey\nhim. She refused to go away and her father\xe2\x80\x99s fury broke over her in a\nterrible storm. He repeated every injustice he had ever inflicted on\nher. Trying to convict her, he told her she had worn him out, had caused\nhis quarrel with his son, had harbored nasty suspicions of him, making\nit the object of her life to poison his existence, and he drove her from\nhis study telling her that if she did not go away it was all the same\nto him. He declared that he did not wish to remember her existence and\nwarned her not to dare to let him see her. The fact that he did not, as\nshe had feared, order her to be carried away by force but only told her\nnot to let him see her cheered Princess Mary.
