She knew it was a proof\nthat in the depth of his soul he was glad she was remaining at home and\nhad not gone away.\n\nThe morning after little Nicholas had left, the old prince donned his\nfull uniform and prepared to visit the commander in chief. His cal\xc3\xa8che\nwas already at the door. Princess Mary saw him walk out of the house in\nhis uniform wearing all his orders and go down the garden to review his\narmed peasants and domestic serfs. She sat by the window listening to\nhis voice which reached her from the garden. Suddenly several men came\nrunning up the avenue with frightened faces.\n\nPrincess Mary ran out to the porch, down the flower-bordered path, and\ninto the avenue. A large crowd of militiamen and domestics were moving\ntoward her, and in their midst several men were supporting by\nthe armpits and dragging along a little old man in a uniform and\ndecorations. She ran up to him and, in the play of the sunlight that\nfell in small round spots through the shade of the lime-tree avenue,\ncould not be sure what change there was in his face. All she could see\nwas that his former stern and determined expression had altered to one\nof timidity and submission. On seeing his daughter he moved his helpless\nlips and made a hoarse sound. It was impossible to make out what he\nwanted. He was lifted up, carried to his study, and laid on the very\ncouch he had so feared of late.\n\nThe doctor, who was fetched that same night, bled him and said that the\nprince had had a seizure paralyzing his right side.\n\nIt was becoming more and more dangerous to remain at Bald Hills, and\nnext day they moved the prince to Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo, the doctor accompanying\nhim.\n\nBy the time they reached Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo, Dessalles and the little prince\nhad already left for Moscow.\n\nFor three weeks the old prince lay stricken by paralysis in the new\nhouse Prince Andrew had built at Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo, ever in the same state,\ngetting neither better nor worse. He was unconscious and lay like\na distorted corpse. He muttered unceasingly, his eyebrows and lips\ntwitching, and it was impossible to tell whether he understood what was\ngoing on around him or not. One thing was certain\xe2\x80\x94that he was suffering\nand wished to say something. But what it was, no one could tell: it\nmight be some caprice of a sick and half-crazy man, or it might relate\nto public affairs, or possibly to family concerns.\n\nThe doctor said this restlessness did not mean anything and was due\nto physical causes; but Princess Mary thought he wished to tell\nher something, and the fact that her presence always increased his\nrestlessness confirmed her opinion.\n\nHe was evidently suffering both physically and mentally. There was no\nhope of recovery. It was impossible for him to travel, it would not do\nto let him die on the road. \xe2\x80\x9cWould it not be better if the end did come,\nthe very end?\xe2\x80\x9d Princess Mary sometimes thought. Night and day, hardly\nsleeping at all, she watched him and, terrible to say, often watched\nhim not with hope of finding signs of improvement but wishing to find\nsymptoms of the approach of the end.\n\nStrange as it was to her to acknowledge this feeling in herself, yet\nthere it was. And what seemed still more terrible to her was that since\nher father\xe2\x80\x99s illness began (perhaps even sooner, when she stayed with\nhim expecting something to happen), all the personal desires and hopes\nthat had been forgotten or sleeping within her had awakened. Thoughts\nthat had not entered her mind for years\xe2\x80\x94thoughts of a life free from\nthe fear of her father, and even the possibility of love and of family\nhappiness\xe2\x80\x94floated continually in her imagination like temptations of the\ndevil. Thrust them aside as she would, questions continually recurred\nto her as to how she would order her life now, after that. These were\ntemptations of the devil and Princess Mary knew it. She knew that the\nsole weapon against him was prayer, and she tried to pray. She assumed\nan attitude of prayer, looked at the icons, repeated the words of a\nprayer, but she could not pray. She felt that a different world had\nnow taken possession of her\xe2\x80\x94the life of a world of strenuous and free\nactivity, quite opposed to the spiritual world in which till now she\nhad been confined and in which her greatest comfort had been prayer.\nShe could not pray, could not weep, and worldly cares took possession of\nher.\n\nIt was becoming dangerous to remain in Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo. News of the approach\nof the French came from all sides, and in one village, ten miles from\nBoguch\xc3\xa1rovo, a homestead had been looted by French marauders.\n\nThe doctor insisted on the necessity of moving the prince; the\nprovincial Marshal of the Nobility sent an official to Princess Mary\nto persuade her to get away as quickly as possible, and the head of the\nrural police having come to Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo urged the same thing, saying\nthat the French were only some twenty-five miles away, that French\nproclamations were circulating in the villages, and that if the princess\ndid not take her father away before the fifteenth, he could not answer\nfor the consequences.\n\nThe princess decided to leave on the fifteenth. The cares of preparation\nand giving orders, for which everyone came to her, occupied her all day.\nShe spent the night of the fourteenth as usual, without undressing, in\nthe room next to the one where the prince lay. Several times, waking up,\nshe heard his groans and muttering, the creak of his bed, and the steps\nof T\xc3\xadkhon and the doctor when they turned him over. Several times she\nlistened at the door, and it seemed to her that his mutterings were\nlouder than usual and that they turned him over oftener. She could not\nsleep and several times went to the door and listened, wishing to enter\nbut not deciding to do so. Though he did not speak, Princess Mary saw\nand knew how unpleasant every sign of anxiety on his account was to him.\nShe had noticed with what dissatisfaction he turned from the look she\nsometimes involuntarily fixed on him. She knew that her going in during\nthe night at an unusual hour would irritate him.\n\nBut never had she felt so grieved for him or so much afraid of losing\nhim. She recalled all her life with him and in every word and act of his\nfound an expression of his love of her. Occasionally amid these memories\ntemptations of the devil would surge into her imagination: thoughts of\nhow things would be after his death, and how her new, liberated life\nwould be ordered. But she drove these thoughts away with disgust. Toward\nmorning he became quiet and she fell asleep.\n\nShe woke late. That sincerity which often comes with waking showed her\nclearly what chiefly concerned her about her father\xe2\x80\x99s illness. On waking\nshe listened to what was going on behind the door and, hearing him\ngroan, said to herself with a sigh that things were still the same.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what could have happened? What did I want? I want his death!\xe2\x80\x9d she\ncried with a feeling of loathing for herself.\n\nShe washed, dressed, said her prayers, and went out to the porch. In\nfront of it stood carriages without horses and things were being packed\ninto the vehicles.\n\nIt was a warm, gray morning. Princess Mary stopped at the porch, still\nhorrified by her spiritual baseness and trying to arrange her thoughts\nbefore going to her father. The doctor came downstairs and went out to\nher.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a little better today,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cI was looking for you. One can\nmake out something of what he is saying. His head is clearer. Come in,\nhe is asking for you....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrincess Mary\xe2\x80\x99s heart beat so violently at this news that she grew pale\nand leaned against the wall to keep from falling. To see him, talk to\nhim, feel his eyes on her now that her whole soul was overflowing with\nthose dreadful, wicked temptations, was a torment of joy and terror.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said the doctor.\n\nPrincess Mary entered her father\xe2\x80\x99s room and went up to his bed. He was\nlying on his back propped up high, and his small bony hands with\ntheir knotted purple veins were lying on the quilt; his left eye gazed\nstraight before him, his right eye was awry, and his brows and lips\nmotionless. He seemed altogether so thin, small, and pathetic. His face\nseemed to have shriveled or melted; his features had grown smaller.\nPrincess Mary went up and kissed his hand. His left hand pressed hers\nso that she understood that he had long been waiting for her to come. He\ntwitched her hand, and his brows and lips quivered angrily.\n\nShe looked at him in dismay trying to guess what he wanted of her. When\nshe changed her position so that his left eye could see her face he\ncalmed down, not taking his eyes off her for some seconds. Then his lips\nand tongue moved, sounds came, and he began to speak, gazing timidly and\nimploringly at her, evidently afraid that she might not understand.\n\nStraining all her faculties Princess Mary looked at him. The comic\nefforts with which he moved his tongue made her drop her eyes and with\ndifficulty repress the sobs that rose to her throat. He said something,\nrepeating the same words several times. She could not understand them,\nbut tried to guess what he was saying and inquiringly repeated the words\nhe uttered.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMmm...ar...ate...ate...\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated several times.\n\nIt was quite impossible to understand these sounds. The doctor thought\nhe had guessed them, and inquiringly repeated: \xe2\x80\x9cMary, are you afraid?\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe prince shook his head, again repeated the same sounds.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy mind, my mind aches?\xe2\x80\x9d questioned Princess Mary.\n\nHe made a mumbling sound in confirmation of this, took her hand, and\nbegan pressing it to different parts of his breast as if trying to find\nthe right place for it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlways thoughts... about you... thoughts...\xe2\x80\x9d he then uttered much\nmore clearly than he had done before, now that he was sure of being\nunderstood.\n\nPrincess Mary pressed her head against his hand, trying to hide her sobs\nand tears.\n\nHe moved his hand over her hair.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been calling you all night...\xe2\x80\x9d he brought out.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf only I had known...\xe2\x80\x9d she said through her tears. \xe2\x80\x9cI was afraid to\ncome in.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe pressed her hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWeren\xe2\x80\x99t you asleep?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I did not sleep,\xe2\x80\x9d said Princess Mary, shaking her head.\n\nUnconsciously imitating her father, she now tried to express herself as\nhe did, as much as possible by signs, and her tongue too seemed to move\nwith difficulty.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear one... Dearest...\xe2\x80\x9d Princess Mary could not quite make out what he\nhad said, but from his look it was clear that he had uttered a tender\ncaressing word such as he had never used to her before. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t you\ncome in?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I was wishing for his death!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Princess Mary.\n\nHe was silent awhile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you... daughter dear!... for all, for all... forgive!... thank\nyou!... forgive!... thank you!...\xe2\x80\x9d and tears began to flow from his\neyes. \xe2\x80\x9cCall Andrew!\xe2\x80\x9d he said suddenly, and a childish, timid expression\nof doubt showed itself on his face as he spoke.\n\nHe himself seemed aware that his demand was meaningless. So at least it\nseemed to Princess Mary.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a letter from him,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied.\n\nHe glanced at her with timid surprise.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s with the army, Father, at Smol\xc3\xa9nsk.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe closed his eyes and remained silent a long time. Then as if in\nanswer to his doubts and to confirm the fact that now he understood and\nremembered everything, he nodded his head and reopened his eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, softly and distinctly. \xe2\x80\x9cRussia has perished. They\xe2\x80\x99ve\ndestroyed her.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd he began to sob, and again tears flowed from his eyes. Princess Mary\ncould no longer restrain herself and wept while she gazed at his face.\n\nAgain he closed his eyes. His sobs ceased, he pointed to his eyes, and\nT\xc3\xadkhon, understanding him, wiped away the tears.\n\nThen he again opened his eyes and said something none of them could\nunderstand for a long time, till at last T\xc3\xadkhon understood and repeated\nit. Princess Mary had sought the meaning of his words in the mood in\nwhich he had just been speaking. She thought he was speaking of Russia,\nor Prince Andrew, of herself, of his grandson, or of his own death, and\nso she could not guess his words.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPut on your white dress. I like it,\xe2\x80\x9d was what he said.\n\nHaving understood this Princess Mary sobbed still louder, and the doctor\ntaking her arm led her out to the veranda, soothing her and trying to\npersuade her to prepare for her journey. When she had left the room the\nprince again began speaking about his son, about the war, and about the\nEmperor, angrily twitching his brows and raising his hoarse voice, and\nthen he had a second and final stroke.\n\nPrincess Mary stayed on the veranda. The day had cleared, it was hot and\nsunny. She could understand nothing, think of nothing and feel nothing,\nexcept passionate love for her father, love such as she thought she had\nnever felt till that moment. She ran out sobbing into the garden and as\nfar as the pond, along the avenues of young lime trees Prince Andrew had\nplanted.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes... I... I... I wished for his death! Yes, I wanted it to end\nquicker.... I wished to be at peace.... And what will become of me? What\nuse will peace be when he is no longer here?\xe2\x80\x9d Princess Mary murmured,\npacing the garden with hurried steps and pressing her hands to her bosom\nwhich heaved with convulsive sobs.\n\nWhen she had completed the tour of the garden, which brought her\nagain to the house, she saw Mademoiselle Bourienne\xe2\x80\x94who had remained\nat Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo and did not wish to leave it\xe2\x80\x94coming toward her with a\nstranger. This was the Marshal of the Nobility of the district, who\nhad come personally to point out to the princess the necessity for her\nprompt departure. Princess Mary listened without understanding him; she\nled him to the house, offered him lunch, and sat down with him. Then,\nexcusing herself, she went to the door of the old prince\xe2\x80\x99s room. The\ndoctor came out with an agitated face and said she could not enter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo away, Princess! Go away... go away!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nShe returned to the garden and sat down on the grass at the foot of the\nslope by the pond, where no one could see her. She did not know how\nlong she had been there when she was aroused by the sound of a woman\xe2\x80\x99s\nfootsteps running along the path. She rose and saw Duny\xc3\xa1sha her maid,\nwho was evidently looking for her, and who stopped suddenly as if in\nalarm on seeing her mistress.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease come, Princess... The Prince,\xe2\x80\x9d said Duny\xc3\xa1sha in a breaking\nvoice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cImmediately, I\xe2\x80\x99m coming, I\xe2\x80\x99m coming!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the princess hurriedly,\nnot giving Duny\xc3\xa1sha time to finish what she was saying, and trying to\navoid seeing the girl she ran toward the house.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrincess, it\xe2\x80\x99s God\xe2\x80\x99s will! You must be prepared for everything,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nthe Marshal, meeting her at the house door.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me alone; it\xe2\x80\x99s not true!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried angrily to him.\n\nThe doctor tried to stop her. She pushed him aside and ran to her\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s door. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy are these people with frightened faces stopping me?\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t want any of them! And what are they doing here?\xe2\x80\x9d she thought.\nShe opened the door and the bright daylight in that previously darkened\nroom startled her. In the room were her nurse and other women. They all\ndrew back from the bed, making way for her. He was still lying on the\nbed as before, but the stern expression of his quiet face made Princess\nMary stop short on the threshold.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he\xe2\x80\x99s not dead\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d she told herself and approached\nhim, and repressing the terror that seized her, she pressed her lips\nto his cheek. But she stepped back immediately. All the force of the\ntenderness she had been feeling for him vanished instantly and was\nreplaced by a feeling of horror at what lay there before her. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, he\nis no more! He is not, but here where he was is something unfamiliar and\nhostile, some dreadful, terrifying, and repellent mystery!\xe2\x80\x9d And hiding\nher face in her hands, Princess Mary sank into the arms of the doctor,\nwho held her up.\n\n\nIn the presence of T\xc3\xadkhon and the doctor the women washed what had been\nthe prince, tied his head up with a handkerchief that the mouth should\nnot stiffen while open, and with another handkerchief tied together the\nlegs that were already spreading apart. Then they dressed him in uniform\nwith his decorations and placed his shriveled little body on a table.\nHeaven only knows who arranged all this and when, but it all got done\nas if of its own accord. Toward night candles were burning round his\ncoffin, a pall was spread over it, the floor was strewn with sprays of\njuniper, a printed band was tucked in under his shriveled head, and in a\ncorner of the room sat a chanter reading the psalms.\n\nJust as horses shy and snort and gather about a dead horse, so the\ninmates of the house and strangers crowded into the drawing room round\nthe coffin\xe2\x80\x94the Marshal, the village Elder, peasant women\xe2\x80\x94and all with\nfixed and frightened eyes, crossing themselves, bowed and kissed the old\nprince\xe2\x80\x99s cold and stiffened hand.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IX\n\nUntil Prince Andrew settled in Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo its owners had always been\nabsentees, and its peasants were of quite a different character from\nthose of Bald Hills. They differed from them in speech, dress, and\ndisposition. They were called steppe peasants. The old prince used to\napprove of them for their endurance at work when they came to Bald Hills\nto help with the harvest, or to dig ponds and ditches, but he disliked\nthem for their boorishness.\n\nPrince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s last stay at Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo, when he introduced hospitals\nand schools and reduced the quitrent the peasants had to pay, had not\nsoftened their disposition but had on the contrary strengthened in\nthem the traits of character the old prince called boorishness. Various\nobscure rumors were always current among them: at one time a rumor that\nthey would all be enrolled as Cossacks; at another of a new religion to\nwhich they were all to be converted; then of some proclamation of the\nTsar\xe2\x80\x99s and of an oath to the Tsar Paul in 1797 (in connection with which\nit was rumored that freedom had been granted them but the landowners had\nstopped it), then of Peter F\xc3\xabdorovich\xe2\x80\x99s return to the throne in seven\nyears\xe2\x80\x99 time, when everything would be made free and so \xe2\x80\x9csimple\xe2\x80\x9d that\nthere would be no restrictions. Rumors of the war with Bonaparte and\nhis invasion were connected in their minds with the same sort of vague\nnotions of Antichrist, the end of the world, and \xe2\x80\x9cpure freedom.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIn the vicinity of Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo were large villages belonging to the\ncrown or to owners whose serfs paid quitrent and could work where they\npleased. There were very few resident landlords in the neighborhood\nand also very few domestic or literate serfs, and in the lives of the\npeasantry of those parts the mysterious undercurrents in the life of\nthe Russian people, the causes and meaning of which are so baffling to\ncontemporaries, were more clearly and strongly noticeable than among\nothers. One instance, which had occurred some twenty years before, was\na movement among the peasants to emigrate to some unknown \xe2\x80\x9cwarm rivers.\xe2\x80\x9d\nHundreds of peasants, among them the Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo folk, suddenly began\nselling their cattle and moving in whole families toward the southeast.\nAs birds migrate to somewhere beyond the sea, so these men with their\nwives and children streamed to the southeast, to parts where none of\nthem had ever been. They set off in caravans, bought their freedom one\nby one or ran away, and drove or walked toward the \xe2\x80\x9cwarm rivers.\xe2\x80\x9d Many\nof them were punished, some sent to Siberia, many died of cold and\nhunger on the road, many returned of their own accord, and the movement\ndied down of itself just as it had sprung up, without apparent reason.\nBut such undercurrents still existed among the people and gathered new\nforces ready to manifest themselves just as strangely, unexpectedly, and\nat the same time simply, naturally, and forcibly. Now in 1812, to anyone\nliving in close touch with these people it was apparent that these\nundercurrents were acting strongly and nearing an eruption.\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych, who had reached Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo shortly before the old prince\xe2\x80\x99s\ndeath, noticed an agitation among the peasants, and that contrary to\nwhat was happening in the Bald Hills district, where over a radius of\nforty miles all the peasants were moving away and leaving their villages\nto be devastated by the Cossacks, the peasants in the steppe region\nround Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo were, it was rumored, in touch with the French,\nreceived leaflets from them that passed from hand to hand, and did not\nmigrate. He learned from domestic serfs loyal to him that the peasant\nKarp, who possessed great influence in the village commune and had\nrecently been away driving a government transport, had returned with\nnews that the Cossacks were destroying deserted villages, but that the\nFrench did not harm them. Alp\xc3\xa1tych also knew that on the previous day\nanother peasant had even brought from the village of Vislo\xc3\xbakhovo, which\nwas occupied by the French, a proclamation by a French general that no\nharm would be done to the inhabitants, and if they remained they would\nbe paid for anything taken from them. As proof of this the peasant had\nbrought from Vislo\xc3\xbakhovo a hundred rubles in notes (he did not know that\nthey were false) paid to him in advance for hay.\n\nMore important still, Alp\xc3\xa1tych learned that on the morning of the\nvery day he gave the village Elder orders to collect carts to move the\nprincess\xe2\x80\x99 luggage from Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo, there had been a village meeting at\nwhich it had been decided not to move but to wait. Yet there was no\ntime to waste. On the fifteenth, the day of the old prince\xe2\x80\x99s death,\nthe Marshal had insisted on Princess Mary\xe2\x80\x99s leaving at once, as it was\nbecoming dangerous. He had told her that after the sixteenth he could\nnot be responsible for what might happen. On the evening of the day the\nold prince died the Marshal went away, promising to return next day for\nthe funeral. But this he was unable to do, for he received tidings that\nthe French had unexpectedly advanced, and had barely time to remove his\nown family and valuables from his estate.\n\nFor some thirty years Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo had been managed by the village Elder,\nDron, whom the old prince called by the diminutive \xe2\x80\x9cDr\xc3\xb3nushka.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDron was one of those physically and mentally vigorous peasants who grow\nbig beards as soon as they are of age and go on unchanged till they\nare sixty or seventy, without a gray hair or the loss of a tooth, as\nstraight and strong at sixty as at thirty.\n\nSoon after the migration to the \xe2\x80\x9cwarm rivers,\xe2\x80\x9d in which he had taken\npart like the rest, Dron was made village Elder and overseer of\nBoguch\xc3\xa1rovo, and had since filled that post irreproachably for\ntwenty-three years. The peasants feared him more than they did their\nmaster. The masters, both the old prince and the young, and the steward\nrespected him and jestingly called him \xe2\x80\x9cthe Minister.\xe2\x80\x9d During the\nwhole time of his service Dron had never been drunk or ill, never after\nsleepless nights or the hardest tasks had he shown the least fatigue,\nand though he could not read he had never forgotten a single money\naccount or the number of quarters of flour in any of the endless\ncartloads he sold for the prince, nor a single shock of the whole corn\ncrop on any single acre of the Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo fields.\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych, arriving from the devastated Bald Hills estate, sent for his\nDron on the day of the prince\xe2\x80\x99s funeral and told him to have twelve\nhorses got ready for the princess\xe2\x80\x99 carriages and eighteen carts for\nthe things to be removed from Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo. Though the peasants paid\nquitrent, Alp\xc3\xa1tych thought no difficulty would be made about complying\nwith this order, for there were two hundred and thirty households at\nwork in Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo and the peasants were well to do. But on hearing the\norder Dron lowered his eyes and remained silent. Alp\xc3\xa1tych named certain\npeasants he knew, from whom he told him to take the carts.\n\nDron replied that the horses of these peasants were away carting.\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych named others, but they too, according to Dron, had no horses\navailable: some horses were carting for the government, others were too\nweak, and others had died for want of fodder. It seemed that no horses\ncould be had even for the carriages, much less for the carting.\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych looked intently at Dron and frowned. Just as Dron was a model\nvillage Elder, so Alp\xc3\xa1tych had not managed the prince\xe2\x80\x99s estates for\ntwenty years in vain. He was a model steward, possessing in the highest\ndegree the faculty of divining the needs and instincts of those he dealt\nwith. Having glanced at Dron he at once understood that his answers did\nnot express his personal views but the general mood of the Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo\ncommune, by which the Elder had already been carried away. But he also\nknew that Dron, who had acquired property and was hated by the commune,\nmust be hesitating between the two camps: the masters\xe2\x80\x99 and the serfs\xe2\x80\x99.\nHe noticed this hesitation in Dron\xe2\x80\x99s look and therefore frowned and\nmoved closer up to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow just listen, Dr\xc3\xb3nushka,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t talk nonsense to me. His\nexcellency Prince Andrew himself gave me orders to move all the people\naway and not leave them with the enemy, and there is an order from the\nTsar about it too. Anyone who stays is a traitor to the Tsar. Do you\nhear?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hear,\xe2\x80\x9d Dron answered without lifting his eyes.\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych was not satisfied with this reply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, Dron, it will turn out badly!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, shaking his head.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe power is in your hands,\xe2\x80\x9d Dron rejoined sadly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, Dron, drop it!\xe2\x80\x9d Alp\xc3\xa1tych repeated, withdrawing his hand from his\nbosom and solemnly pointing to the floor at Dron\xe2\x80\x99s feet. \xe2\x80\x9cI can see\nthrough you and three yards into the ground under you,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued,\ngazing at the floor in front of Dron.\n\nDron was disconcerted, glanced furtively at Alp\xc3\xa1tych and again lowered\nhis eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou drop this nonsense and tell the people to get ready to leave their\nhomes and go to Moscow and to get carts ready for tomorrow morning\nfor the princess\xe2\x80\x99 things. And don\xe2\x80\x99t go to any meeting yourself, do you\nhear?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDron suddenly fell on his knees.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cY\xc3\xa1kov Alp\xc3\xa1tych, discharge me! Take the keys from me and discharge me,\nfor Christ\xe2\x80\x99s sake!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop that!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Alp\xc3\xa1tych sternly. \xe2\x80\x9cI see through you and three yards\nunder you,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, knowing that his skill in beekeeping, his\nknowledge of the right time to sow the oats, and the fact that he had\nbeen able to retain the old prince\xe2\x80\x99s favor for twenty years had long\nsince gained him the reputation of being a wizard, and that the power of\nseeing three yards under a man is considered an attribute of wizards.\n\nDron got up and was about to say something, but Alp\xc3\xa1tych interrupted\nhim.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it you have got into your heads, eh?... What are you thinking\nof, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat am I to do with the people?\xe2\x80\x9d said Dron. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re quite beside\nthemselves; I have already told them...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Told them,\xe2\x80\x99 I dare say!\xe2\x80\x9d said Alp\xc3\xa1tych. \xe2\x80\x9cAre they drinking?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked\nabruptly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite beside themselves, Y\xc3\xa1kov Alp\xc3\xa1tych; they\xe2\x80\x99ve fetched another\nbarrel.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, listen! I\xe2\x80\x99ll go to the police officer, and you tell them\nso, and that they must stop this and the carts must be got ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych did not insist further. He had managed people for a long time\nand knew that the chief way to make them obey is to show no suspicion\nthat they can possibly disobey. Having wrung a submissive \xe2\x80\x9cI understand\xe2\x80\x9d\nfrom Dron, Alp\xc3\xa1tych contented himself with that, though he not only\ndoubted but felt almost certain that without the help of troops the\ncarts would not be forthcoming.\n\nAnd so it was, for when evening came no carts had been provided. In the\nvillage, outside the drink shop, another meeting was being held, which\ndecided that the horses should be driven out into the woods and the\ncarts should not be provided. Without saying anything of this to the\nprincess, Alp\xc3\xa1tych had his own belongings taken out of the carts which\nhad arrived from Bald Hills and had those horses got ready for\nthe princess\xe2\x80\x99 carriages. Meanwhile he went himself to the police\nauthorities.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER X\n\nAfter her father\xe2\x80\x99s funeral Princess Mary shut herself up in her room and\ndid not admit anyone. A maid came to the door to say that Alp\xc3\xa1tych was\nasking for orders about their departure. (This was before his talk with\nDron.) Princess Mary raised herself on the sofa on which she had been\nlying and replied through the closed door that she did not mean to go\naway and begged to be left in peace.\n\nThe windows of the room in which she was lying looked westward. She\nlay on the sofa with her face to the wall, fingering the buttons of the\nleather cushion and seeing nothing but that cushion, and her confused\nthoughts were centered on one subject\xe2\x80\x94the irrevocability of death and\nher own spiritual baseness, which she had not suspected, but which had\nshown itself during her father\xe2\x80\x99s illness. She wished to pray but did not\ndare to, dared not in her present state of mind address herself to God.\nShe lay for a long time in that position.\n\nThe sun had reached the other side of the house, and its slanting rays\nshone into the open window, lighting up the room and part of the morocco\ncushion at which Princess Mary was looking. The flow of her thoughts\nsuddenly stopped. Unconsciously she sat up, smoothed her hair, got up,\nand went to the window, involuntarily inhaling the freshness of the\nclear but windy evening.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you can well enjoy the evening now! He is gone and no one will\nhinder you,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to herself, and sinking into a chair she let her\nhead fall on the window sill.\n\nSomeone spoke her name in a soft and tender voice from the garden and\nkissed her head. She looked up. It was Mademoiselle Bourienne in a black\ndress and weepers. She softly approached Princess Mary, sighed, kissed\nher, and immediately began to cry. The princess looked up at her. All\ntheir former disharmony and her own jealousy recurred to her mind.\nBut she remembered too how he had changed of late toward Mademoiselle\nBourienne and could not bear to see her, thereby showing how unjust were\nthe reproaches Princess Mary had mentally addressed to her. \xe2\x80\x9cBesides,\nis it for me, for me who desired his death, to condemn anyone?\xe2\x80\x9d she\nthought.\n\nPrincess Mary vividly pictured to herself the position of Mademoiselle\nBourienne, whom she had of late kept at a distance, but who yet was\ndependent on her and living in her house. She felt sorry for her\nand held out her hand with a glance of gentle inquiry. Mademoiselle\nBourienne at once began crying again and kissed that hand, speaking of\nthe princess\xe2\x80\x99 sorrow and making herself a partner in it. She said her\nonly consolation was the fact that the princess allowed her to share her\nsorrow, that all the old misunderstandings should sink into nothing but\nthis great grief; that she felt herself blameless in regard to everyone,\nand that he, from above, saw her affection and gratitude. The princess\nheard her, not heeding her words but occasionally looking up at her and\nlistening to the sound of her voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour position is doubly terrible, dear princess,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mademoiselle\nBourienne after a pause. \xe2\x80\x9cI understand that you could not, and cannot,\nthink of yourself, but with my love for you I must do so.... Has\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych been to you? Has he spoken to you of going away?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\n\nPrincess Mary did not answer. She did not understand who was to go or\nwhere to. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible to plan or think of anything now? Is it not\nall the same?\xe2\x80\x9d she thought, and did not reply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know, ch\xc3\xa8re Marie,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mademoiselle Bourienne, \xe2\x80\x9cthat we are in\ndanger\xe2\x80\x94are surrounded by the French. It would be dangerous to move now.\nIf we go we are almost sure to be taken prisoners, and God knows...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrincess Mary looked at her companion without understanding what she was\ntalking about.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, if anyone knew how little anything matters to me now,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course I would on no account wish to go away from him.... Alp\xc3\xa1tych\ndid say something about going.... Speak to him; I can do nothing,\nnothing, and don\xe2\x80\x99t want to....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve spoken to him. He hopes we should be in time to get away tomorrow,\nbut I think it would now be better to stay here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mademoiselle\nBourienne. \xe2\x80\x9cBecause, you will agree, ch\xc3\xa8re Marie, to fall into the hands\nof the soldiers or of riotous peasants would be terrible.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nMademoiselle Bourienne took from her reticule a proclamation (not\nprinted on ordinary Russian paper) of General Rameau\xe2\x80\x99s, telling people\nnot to leave their homes and that the French authorities would afford\nthem proper protection. She handed this to the princess.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think it would be best to appeal to that general,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued,\n\xe2\x80\x9cand I am sure that all due respect would be shown you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrincess Mary read the paper, and her face began to quiver with stifled\nsobs.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom whom did you get this?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey probably recognized that I am French, by my name,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\nMademoiselle Bourienne blushing.\n\nPrincess Mary, with the paper in her hand, rose from the window and with\na pale face went out of the room and into what had been Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s\nstudy.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDuny\xc3\xa1sha, send Alp\xc3\xa1tych, or Dr\xc3\xb3nushka, or somebody to me!\xe2\x80\x9d she said,\n\xe2\x80\x9cand tell Mademoiselle Bourienne not to come to me,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, hearing\nMademoiselle Bourienne\xe2\x80\x99s voice. \xe2\x80\x9cWe must go at once, at once!\xe2\x80\x9d she said,\nappalled at the thought of being left in the hands of the French.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Prince Andrew heard that I was in the power of the French! That\nI, the daughter of Prince Nicholas Bolk\xc3\xb3nski, asked General Rameau for\nprotection and accepted his favor!\xe2\x80\x9d This idea horrified her, made her\nshudder, blush, and feel such a rush of anger and pride as she had never\nexperienced before. All that was distressing, and especially all that\nwas humiliating, in her position rose vividly to her mind. \xe2\x80\x9cThey, the\nFrench, would settle in this house: M. le G\xc3\xa9n\xc3\xa9ral Rameau would occupy\nPrince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s study and amuse himself by looking through and reading\nhis letters and papers. Mademoiselle Bourienne would do the honors of\nBoguch\xc3\xa1rovo for him. I should be given a small room as a favor, the\nsoldiers would violate my father\xe2\x80\x99s newly dug grave to steal his crosses\nand stars, they would tell me of their victories over the Russians, and\nwould pretend to sympathize with my sorrow...\xe2\x80\x9d thought Princess Mary,\nnot thinking her own thoughts but feeling bound to think like her father\nand her brother. For herself she did not care where she remained or what\nhappened to her, but she felt herself the representative of her dead\nfather and of Prince Andrew. Involuntarily she thought their thoughts\nand felt their feelings. What they would have said and what they would\nhave done she felt bound to say and do. She went into Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s\nstudy, trying to enter completely into his ideas, and considered her\nposition.\n\nThe demands of life, which had seemed to her annihilated by her father\xe2\x80\x99s\ndeath, all at once rose before her with a new, previously unknown force\nand took possession of her.\n\nAgitated and flushed she paced the room, sending now for Michael\nIv\xc3\xa1novich and now for T\xc3\xadkhon or Dron. Duny\xc3\xa1sha, the nurse, and the other\nmaids could not say in how far Mademoiselle Bourienne\xe2\x80\x99s statement was\ncorrect. Alp\xc3\xa1tych was not at home, he had gone to the police. Neither\ncould the architect Michael Iv\xc3\xa1novich, who on being sent for came in\nwith sleepy eyes, tell Princess Mary anything. With just the same smile\nof agreement with which for fifteen years he had been accustomed to\nanswer the old prince without expressing views of his own, he now\nreplied to Princess Mary, so that nothing definite could be got from his\nanswers. The old valet T\xc3\xadkhon, with sunken, emaciated face that bore the\nstamp of inconsolable grief, replied: \xe2\x80\x9cYes, Princess\xe2\x80\x9d to all Princess\nMary\xe2\x80\x99s questions and hardly refrained from sobbing as he looked at her.\n\nAt length Dron, the village Elder, entered the room and with a deep bow\nto Princess Mary came to a halt by the doorpost.\n\nPrincess Mary walked up and down the room and stopped in front of him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDr\xc3\xb3nushka,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, regarding as a sure friend this Dr\xc3\xb3nushka who\nalways used to bring a special kind of gingerbread from his visit to the\nfair at Vy\xc3\xa1zma every year and smilingly offer it to her, \xe2\x80\x9cDr\xc3\xb3nushka, now\nsince our misfortune...\xe2\x80\x9d she began, but could not go on.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are all in God\xe2\x80\x99s hands,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, with a sigh.\n\nThey were silent for a while.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDr\xc3\xb3nushka, Alp\xc3\xa1tych has gone off somewhere and I have no one to turn\nto. Is it true, as they tell me, that I can\xe2\x80\x99t even go away?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you go away, your excellency? You can go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dron.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was told it would be dangerous because of the enemy. Dear friend, I\ncan do nothing. I understand nothing. I have nobody! I want to go away\ntonight or early tomorrow morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDron paused. He looked askance at Princess Mary and said: \xe2\x80\x9cThere are no\nhorses; I told Y\xc3\xa1kov Alp\xc3\xa1tych so.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are there none?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the princess.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all God\xe2\x80\x99s scourge,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dron. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat horses we had have been\ntaken for the army or have died\xe2\x80\x94this is such a year! It\xe2\x80\x99s not a case of\nfeeding horses\xe2\x80\x94we may die of hunger ourselves! As it is, some go three\ndays without eating. We\xe2\x80\x99ve nothing, we\xe2\x80\x99ve been ruined.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrincess Mary listened attentively to what he told her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe peasants are ruined? They have no bread?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re dying of hunger,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dron. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not a case of carting.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why didn\xe2\x80\x99t you tell me, Dr\xc3\xb3nushka? Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it possible to help them?\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll do all I can....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nTo Princess Mary it was strange that now, at a moment when such sorrow\nwas filling her soul, there could be rich people and poor, and the rich\ncould refrain from helping the poor. She had heard vaguely that there\nwas such a thing as \xe2\x80\x9clandlord\xe2\x80\x99s corn\xe2\x80\x9d which was sometimes given to the\npeasants. She also knew that neither her father nor her brother would\nrefuse to help the peasants in need, she only feared to make some\nmistake in speaking about the distribution of the grain she wished to\ngive. She was glad such cares presented themselves, enabling her\nwithout scruple to forget her own grief. She began asking Dron about the\npeasants\xe2\x80\x99 needs and what there was in Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo that belonged to the\nlandlord.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut we have grain belonging to my brother?\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe landlord\xe2\x80\x99s grain is all safe,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dron proudly. \xe2\x80\x9cOur prince\ndid not order it to be sold.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive it to the peasants, let them have all they need; I give you leave\nin my brother\xe2\x80\x99s name,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\n\nDron made no answer but sighed deeply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive them that corn if there is enough of it. Distribute it all. I\ngive this order in my brother\xe2\x80\x99s name; and tell them that what is ours is\ntheirs. We do not grudge them anything. Tell them so.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDron looked intently at the princess while she was speaking.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDischarge me, little mother, for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake! Order the keys to be taken\nfrom me,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cI have served twenty-three years and have done no\nwrong. Discharge me, for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrincess Mary did not understand what he wanted of her or why he was\nasking to be discharged. She replied that she had never doubted his\ndevotion and that she was ready to do anything for him and for the\npeasants.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XI\n\nAn hour later Duny\xc3\xa1sha came to tell the princess that Dron had come, and\nall the peasants had assembled at the barn by the princess\xe2\x80\x99 order and\nwished to have word with their mistress.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I never told them to come,\xe2\x80\x9d said Princess Mary. \xe2\x80\x9cI only told Dron\nto let them have the grain.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly, for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, Princess dear, have them sent away and don\xe2\x80\x99t go\nout to them. It\xe2\x80\x99s all a trick,\xe2\x80\x9d said Duny\xc3\xa1sha, \xe2\x80\x9cand when Y\xc3\xa1kov Alp\xc3\xa1tych\nreturns let us get away... and please don\xe2\x80\x99t...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is a trick?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Princess Mary in surprise.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it is, only listen to me for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake! Ask nurse too. They say\nthey don\xe2\x80\x99t agree to leave Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo as you ordered.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re making some mistake. I never ordered them to go away,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nPrincess Mary. \xe2\x80\x9cCall Dr\xc3\xb3nushka.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDron came and confirmed Duny\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s words; the peasants had come by the\nprincess\xe2\x80\x99 order.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I never sent for them,\xe2\x80\x9d declared the princess. \xe2\x80\x9cYou must have given\nmy message wrong. I only said that you were to give them the grain.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDron only sighed in reply.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you order it they will go away,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no. I\xe2\x80\x99ll go out to them,\xe2\x80\x9d said Princess Mary, and in spite of\nthe nurse\xe2\x80\x99s and Duny\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s protests she went out into the porch; Dron,\nDuny\xc3\xa1sha, the nurse, and Michael Iv\xc3\xa1novich following her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey probably think I am offering them the grain to bribe them to\nremain here, while I myself go away leaving them to the mercy of the\nFrench,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Princess Mary. \xe2\x80\x9cI will offer them monthly rations and\nhousing at our Moscow estate. I am sure Andrew would do even more in\nmy place,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought as she went out in the twilight toward the crowd\nstanding on the pasture by the barn.\n\nThe men crowded closer together, stirred, and rapidly took off their\nhats. Princess Mary lowered her eyes and, tripping over her skirt, came\nclose up to them. So many different eyes, old and young, were fixed\non her, and there were so many different faces, that she could not\ndistinguish any of them and, feeling that she must speak to them all\nat once, did not know how to do it. But again the sense that she\nrepresented her father and her brother gave her courage, and she boldly\nbegan her speech.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very glad you have come,\xe2\x80\x9d she said without raising her eyes, and\nfeeling her heart beating quickly and violently. \xe2\x80\x9cDr\xc3\xb3nushka tells me\nthat the war has ruined you. That is our common misfortune, and I\nshall grudge nothing to help you. I am myself going away because it\nis dangerous here... the enemy is near... because... I am giving you\neverything, my friends, and I beg you to take everything, all our grain,\nso that you may not suffer want! And if you have been told that I am\ngiving you the grain to keep you here\xe2\x80\x94that is not true. On the contrary,\nI ask you to go with all your belongings to our estate near Moscow, and\nI promise you I will see to it that there you shall want for nothing.\nYou shall be given food and lodging.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe princess stopped. Sighs were the only sound heard in the crowd.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not doing this on my own account,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, \xe2\x80\x9cI do it in the\nname of my dead father, who was a good master to you, and of my brother\nand his son.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAgain she paused. No one broke the silence.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOurs is a common misfortune and we will share it together. All that is\nmine is yours,\xe2\x80\x9d she concluded, scanning the faces before her.\n\nAll eyes were gazing at her with one and the same expression. She\ncould not fathom whether it was curiosity, devotion, gratitude, or\napprehension and distrust\xe2\x80\x94but the expression on all the faces was\nidentical.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are all very thankful for your bounty, but it won\xe2\x80\x99t do for us to\ntake the landlord\xe2\x80\x99s grain,\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice at the back of the crowd.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why not?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the princess.\n\nNo one replied and Princess Mary, looking round at the crowd, found that\nevery eye she met now was immediately dropped.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why don\xe2\x80\x99t you want to take it?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked again.\n\nNo one answered.\n\nThe silence began to oppress the princess and she tried to catch\nsomeone\xe2\x80\x99s eye.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you speak?\xe2\x80\x9d she inquired of a very old man who stood just\nin front of her leaning on his stick. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you think something more is\nwanted, tell me! I will do anything,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, catching his eye.\n\nBut as if this angered him, he bent his head quite low and muttered:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should we agree? We don\xe2\x80\x99t want the grain.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should we give up everything? We don\xe2\x80\x99t agree. Don\xe2\x80\x99t agree.... We\nare sorry for you, but we\xe2\x80\x99re not willing. Go away yourself, alone...\xe2\x80\x9d\ncame from various sides of the crowd.\n\nAnd again all the faces in that crowd bore an identical expression,\nthough now it was certainly not an expression of curiosity or gratitude,\nbut of angry resolve.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you can\xe2\x80\x99t have understood me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Princess Mary with a sad smile.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you want to go? I promise to house and feed you, while here\nthe enemy would ruin you....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBut her voice was drowned by the voices of the crowd.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re not willing. Let them ruin us! We won\xe2\x80\x99t take your grain. We don\xe2\x80\x99t\nagree.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAgain Princess Mary tried to catch someone\xe2\x80\x99s eye, but not a single eye\nin the crowd was turned to her; evidently they were all trying to avoid\nher look. She felt strange and awkward.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, an artful tale! Follow her into slavery! Pull down your houses\nand go into bondage! I dare say! \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll give you grain, indeed!\xe2\x80\x99 she\nsays,\xe2\x80\x9d voices in the crowd were heard saying.\n\nWith drooping head Princess Mary left the crowd and went back to the\nhouse. Having repeated her order to Dron to have horses ready for her\ndeparture next morning, she went to her room and remained alone with her\nown thoughts.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XII\n\nFor a long time that night Princess Mary sat by the open window of her\nroom hearing the sound of the peasants\xe2\x80\x99 voices that reached her from\nthe village, but it was not of them she was thinking. She felt that she\ncould not understand them however much she might think about them. She\nthought only of one thing, her sorrow, which, after the break caused\nby cares for the present, seemed already to belong to the past. Now she\ncould remember it and weep or pray.\n\nAfter sunset the wind had dropped. The night was calm and fresh. Toward\nmidnight the voices began to subside, a cock crowed, the full moon began\nto show from behind the lime trees, a fresh white dewy mist began to\nrise, and stillness reigned over the village and the house.\n\nPictures of the near past\xe2\x80\x94her father\xe2\x80\x99s illness and last moments\xe2\x80\x94rose\none after another to her memory. With mournful pleasure she now lingered\nover these images, repelling with horror only the last one, the\npicture of his death, which she felt she could not contemplate even in\nimagination at this still and mystic hour of night. And these pictures\npresented themselves to her so clearly and in such detail that they\nseemed now present, now past, and now future.\n\nShe vividly recalled the moment when he had his first stroke and was\nbeing dragged along by his armpits through the garden at Bald Hills,\nmuttering something with his helpless tongue, twitching his gray\neyebrows and looking uneasily and timidly at her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEven then he wanted to tell me what he told me the day he died,\xe2\x80\x9d she\nthought. \xe2\x80\x9cHe had always thought what he said then.\xe2\x80\x9d And she recalled in\nall its detail the night at Bald Hills before he had the last stroke,\nwhen with a foreboding of disaster she had remained at home against his\nwill. She had not slept and had stolen downstairs on tiptoe, and going\nto the door of the conservatory where he slept that night had listened\nat the door. In a suffering and weary voice he was saying something to\nT\xc3\xadkhon, speaking of the Crimea and its warm nights and of the Empress.\nEvidently he had wanted to talk. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd why didn\xe2\x80\x99t he call me? Why didn\xe2\x80\x99t\nhe let me be there instead of T\xc3\xadkhon?\xe2\x80\x9d Princess Mary had thought and\nthought again now. \xe2\x80\x9cNow he will never tell anyone what he had in his\nsoul. Never will that moment return for him or for me when he might have\nsaid all he longed to say, and not T\xc3\xadkhon but I might have heard and\nunderstood him. Why didn\xe2\x80\x99t I enter the room?\xe2\x80\x9d she thought. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps he\nwould then have said to me what he said the day he died. While talking\nto T\xc3\xadkhon he asked about me twice. He wanted to see me, and I was\nstanding close by, outside the door. It was sad and painful for him\nto talk to T\xc3\xadkhon who did not understand him. I remember how he began\nspeaking to him about Lise as if she were alive\xe2\x80\x94he had forgotten she\nwas dead\xe2\x80\x94and T\xc3\xadkhon reminded him that she was no more, and he shouted,\n\xe2\x80\x98Fool!\xe2\x80\x99 He was greatly depressed. From behind the door I heard how he\nlay down on his bed groaning and loudly exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x98My God!\xe2\x80\x99 Why didn\xe2\x80\x99t\nI go in then? What could he have done to me? What could I have lost? And\nperhaps he would then have been comforted and would have said that word\nto me.\xe2\x80\x9d And Princess Mary uttered aloud the caressing word he had said\nto her on the day of his death. \xe2\x80\x9cDear-est!\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated, and began\nsobbing, with tears that relieved her soul. She now saw his face before\nher. And not the face she had known ever since she could remember and\nhad always seen at a distance, but the timid, feeble face she had seen\nfor the first time quite closely, with all its wrinkles and details,\nwhen she stooped near to his mouth to catch what he said.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear-est!\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated again.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was he thinking when he uttered that word? What is he thinking\nnow?\xe2\x80\x9d This question suddenly presented itself to her, and in answer she\nsaw him before her with the expression that was on his face as he lay\nin his coffin with his chin bound up with a white handkerchief. And the\nhorror that had seized her when she touched him and convinced herself\nthat that was not he, but something mysterious and horrible, seized her\nagain. She tried to think of something else and to pray, but could do\nneither. With wide-open eyes she gazed at the moonlight and the shadows,\nexpecting every moment to see his dead face, and she felt that the\nsilence brooding over the house and within it held her fast.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDuny\xc3\xa1sha,\xe2\x80\x9d she whispered. \xe2\x80\x9cDuny\xc3\xa1sha!\xe2\x80\x9d she screamed wildly, and tearing\nherself out of this silence she ran to the servants\xe2\x80\x99 quarters to meet\nher old nurse and the maidservants who came running toward her.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIII\n\nOn the seventeenth of August Rost\xc3\xb3v and Ily\xc3\xadn, accompanied by Lavr\xc3\xbashka\nwho had just returned from captivity and by an hussar orderly, left\ntheir quarters at Yank\xc3\xb3vo, ten miles from Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo, and went for a\nride\xe2\x80\x94to try a new horse Ily\xc3\xadn had bought and to find out whether there\nwas any hay to be had in the villages.\n\nFor the last three days Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo had lain between the two hostile\narmies, so that it was as easy for the Russian rearguard to get to it as\nfor the French vanguard; Rost\xc3\xb3v, as a careful squadron commander, wished\nto take such provisions as remained at Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo before the French\ncould get them.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v and Ily\xc3\xadn were in the merriest of moods. On the way to\nBoguch\xc3\xa1rovo, a princely estate with a dwelling house and farm where\nthey hoped to find many domestic serfs and pretty girls, they questioned\nLavr\xc3\xbashka about Napoleon and laughed at his stories, and raced one\nanother to try Ily\xc3\xadn\xe2\x80\x99s horse.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v had no idea that the village he was entering was the property of\nthat very Bolk\xc3\xb3nski who had been engaged to his sister.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v and Ily\xc3\xadn gave rein to their horses for a last race along the\nincline before reaching Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo, and Rost\xc3\xb3v, outstripping Ily\xc3\xadn, was\nthe first to gallop into the village street.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re first!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ily\xc3\xadn, flushed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, always first both on the grassland and here,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rost\xc3\xb3v,\nstroking his heated Don\xc3\xa9ts horse.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I\xe2\x80\x99d have won on my Frenchy, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lavr\xc3\xbashka\nfrom behind, alluding to his shabby cart horse, \xe2\x80\x9conly I didn\xe2\x80\x99t wish to\nmortify you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThey rode at a footpace to the barn, where a large crowd of peasants was\nstanding.\n\nSome of the men bared their heads, others stared at the new arrivals\nwithout doffing their caps. Two tall old peasants with wrinkled faces\nand scanty beards emerged from the tavern, smiling, staggering, and\nsinging some incoherent song, and approached the officers.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFine fellows!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cIs there any hay here?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how like one another,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ily\xc3\xadn.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA mo-o-st me-r-r-y co-o-m-pa...!\xe2\x80\x9d sang one of the peasants with a\nblissful smile.\n\nOne of the men came out of the crowd and went up to Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho do you belong to?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe French,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ily\xc3\xadn jestingly, \xe2\x80\x9cand here is Napoleon\nhimself\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and he pointed to Lavr\xc3\xbashka.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you are Russians?\xe2\x80\x9d the peasant asked again.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd is there a large force of you here?\xe2\x80\x9d said another, a short man,\ncoming up.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery large,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rost\xc3\xb3v. \xe2\x80\x9cBut why have you collected here?\xe2\x80\x9d he\nadded. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it a holiday?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe old men have met to talk over the business of the commune,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\nthe peasant, moving away.\n\nAt that moment, on the road leading from the big house, two women and a\nman in a white hat were seen coming toward the officers.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe one in pink is mine, so keep off!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ily\xc3\xadn on seeing Duny\xc3\xa1sha\nrunning resolutely toward him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99ll be ours!\xe2\x80\x9d said Lavr\xc3\xbashka to Ily\xc3\xadn, winking.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want, my pretty?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ily\xc3\xadn with a smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe princess ordered me to ask your regiment and your name.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is Count Rost\xc3\xb3v, squadron commander, and I am your humble\nservant.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCo-o-om-pa-ny!\xe2\x80\x9d roared the tipsy peasant with a beatific smile as\nhe looked at Ily\xc3\xadn talking to the girl. Following Duny\xc3\xa1sha, Alp\xc3\xa1tych\nadvanced to Rost\xc3\xb3v, having bared his head while still at a distance.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I make bold to trouble your honor?\xe2\x80\x9d said he respectfully, but with\na shade of contempt for the youthfulness of this officer and with a hand\nthrust into his bosom. \xe2\x80\x9cMy mistress, daughter of General in Chief Prince\nNicholas Bolk\xc3\xb3nski who died on the fifteenth of this month, finding\nherself in difficulties owing to the boorishness of these people\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he\npointed to the peasants\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9casks you to come up to the house.... Won\xe2\x80\x99t\nyou, please, ride on a little farther,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alp\xc3\xa1tych with a melancholy\nsmile, \xe2\x80\x9cas it is not convenient in the presence of...?\xe2\x80\x9d He pointed to\nthe two peasants who kept as close to him as horseflies to a horse.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!... Alp\xc3\xa1tych... Ah, Y\xc3\xa1kov Alp\xc3\xa1tych... Grand! Forgive us for Christ\xe2\x80\x99s\nsake, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said the peasants, smiling joyfully at him.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v looked at the tipsy peasants and smiled.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr perhaps they amuse your honor?\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Alp\xc3\xa1tych with a staid air,\nas he pointed at the old men with his free hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, there\xe2\x80\x99s not much to be amused at here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v, and rode on a\nlittle way. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI make bold to inform your honor that the rude peasants here don\xe2\x80\x99t\nwish to let the mistress leave the estate, and threaten to unharness her\nhorses, so that though everything has been packed up since morning, her\nexcellency cannot get away.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have the honor to report to you the actual truth,\xe2\x80\x9d said Alp\xc3\xa1tych.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v dismounted, gave his horse to the orderly, and followed Alp\xc3\xa1tych\nto the house, questioning him as to the state of affairs. It appeared\nthat the princess\xe2\x80\x99 offer of corn to the peasants the previous day, and\nher talk with Dron and at the meeting, had actually had so bad an effect\nthat Dron had finally given up the keys and joined the peasants and had\nnot appeared when Alp\xc3\xa1tych sent for him; and that in the morning when\nthe princess gave orders to harness for her journey, the peasants had\ncome in a large crowd to the barn and sent word that they would not let\nher leave the village: that there was an order not to move, and that\nthey would unharness the horses. Alp\xc3\xa1tych had gone out to admonish them,\nbut was told (it was chiefly Karp who did the talking, Dron not showing\nhimself in the crowd) that they could not let the princess go, that\nthere was an order to the contrary, but that if she stayed they would\nserve her as before and obey her in everything.\n\nAt the moment when Rost\xc3\xb3v and Ily\xc3\xadn were galloping along the road,\nPrincess Mary, despite the dissuasions of Alp\xc3\xa1tych, her nurse, and the\nmaids, had given orders to harness and intended to start, but when the\ncavalrymen were espied they were taken for Frenchmen, the coachman ran\naway, and the women in the house began to wail.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather! Benefactor! God has sent you!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed deeply moved voices as\nRost\xc3\xb3v passed through the anteroom.\n\nPrincess Mary was sitting helpless and bewildered in the large sitting\nroom, when Rost\xc3\xb3v was shown in. She could not grasp who he was and why\nhe had come, or what was happening to her. When she saw his Russian\nface, and by his walk and the first words he uttered recognized him as a\nman of her own class, she glanced at him with her deep radiant look and\nbegan speaking in a voice that faltered and trembled with emotion. This\nmeeting immediately struck Rost\xc3\xb3v as a romantic event. \xe2\x80\x9cA helpless girl\noverwhelmed with grief, left to the mercy of coarse, rioting peasants!\nAnd what a strange fate sent me here! What gentleness and nobility there\nare in her features and expression!\xe2\x80\x9d thought he as he looked at her and\nlistened to her timid story.\n\nWhen she began to tell him that all this had happened the day after her\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s funeral, her voice trembled. She turned away, and then, as if\nfearing he might take her words as meant to move him to pity, looked at\nhim with an apprehensive glance of inquiry. There were tears in Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s\neyes. Princess Mary noticed this and glanced gratefully at him with that\nradiant look which caused the plainness of her face to be forgotten.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot express, Princess, how glad I am that I happened to ride here\nand am able to show my readiness to serve you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v, rising. \xe2\x80\x9cGo\nwhen you please, and I give you my word of honor that no one shall dare\nto cause you annoyance if only you will allow me to act as your escort.\xe2\x80\x9d\nAnd bowing respectfully, as if to a lady of royal blood, he moved toward\nthe door.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s deferential tone seemed to indicate that though he would\nconsider himself happy to be acquainted with her, he did not wish to\ntake advantage of her misfortunes to intrude upon her.\n\nPrincess Mary understood this and appreciated his delicacy.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very, very grateful to you,\xe2\x80\x9d she said in French, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I hope it\nwas all a misunderstanding and that no one is to blame for it.\xe2\x80\x9d She\nsuddenly began to cry.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me!\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v, knitting his brows, left the room with another low bow.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIV\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, is she pretty? Ah, friend\xe2\x80\x94my pink one is delicious; her name is\nDuny\xc3\xa1sha....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBut on glancing at Rost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s face Ily\xc3\xadn stopped short. He saw that his\nhero and commander was following quite a different train of thought.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v glanced angrily at Ily\xc3\xadn and without replying strode off with\nrapid steps to the village.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll show them; I\xe2\x80\x99ll give it to them, the brigands!\xe2\x80\x9d said he to\nhimself.\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych at a gliding trot, only just managing not to run, kept up with\nhim with difficulty.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat decision have you been pleased to come to?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\nRost\xc3\xb3v stopped and, clenching his fists, suddenly and sternly turned on\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDecision? What decision? Old dotard!...\xe2\x80\x9d cried he. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you been\nabout? Eh? The peasants are rioting, and you can\xe2\x80\x99t manage them? You\xe2\x80\x99re\na traitor yourself! I know you. I\xe2\x80\x99ll flay you all alive!...\xe2\x80\x9d And as if\nafraid of wasting his store of anger, he left Alp\xc3\xa1tych and went rapidly\nforward. Alp\xc3\xa1tych, mastering his offended feelings, kept pace with\nRost\xc3\xb3v at a gliding gait and continued to impart his views. He said\nthe peasants were obdurate and that at the present moment it would be\nimprudent to \xe2\x80\x9coverresist\xe2\x80\x9d them without an armed force, and would it not\nbe better first to send for the military?\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll give them armed force... I\xe2\x80\x99ll \xe2\x80\x98overresist\xe2\x80\x99 them!\xe2\x80\x9d uttered Rost\xc3\xb3v\nmeaninglessly, breathless with irrational animal fury and the need to\nvent it.\n\nWithout considering what he would do he moved unconciously with quick,\nresolute steps toward the crowd. And the nearer he drew to it the more\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych felt that this unreasonable action might produce good results.\nThe peasants in the crowd were similarly impressed when they saw\nRost\xc3\xb3v\xe2\x80\x99s rapid, firm steps and resolute, frowning face.\n\nAfter the hussars had come to the village and Rost\xc3\xb3v had gone to see the\nprincess, a certain confusion and dissension had arisen among the crowd.\nSome of the peasants said that these new arrivals were Russians and\nmight take it amiss that the mistress was being detained. Dron was of\nthis opinion, but as soon as he expressed it Karp and others attacked\ntheir ex-Elder.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow many years have you been fattening on the commune?\xe2\x80\x9d Karp shouted at\nhim. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all one to you! You\xe2\x80\x99ll dig up your pot of money and take\nit away with you.... What does it matter to you whether our homes are\nruined or not?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve been told to keep order, and that no one is to leave their homes\nor take away a single grain, and that\xe2\x80\x99s all about it!\xe2\x80\x9d cried another.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was your son\xe2\x80\x99s turn to be conscripted, but no fear! You begrudged\nyour lump of a son,\xe2\x80\x9d a little old man suddenly began attacking Dron\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand\nso they took my V\xc3\xa1nka to be shaved for a soldier! But we all have to\ndie.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure, we all have to die. I\xe2\x80\x99m not against the commune,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nDron.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it\xe2\x80\x94not against it! You\xe2\x80\x99ve filled your belly....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe two tall peasants had their say. As soon as Rost\xc3\xb3v, followed by\nIly\xc3\xadn, Lavr\xc3\xbashka, and Alp\xc3\xa1tych, came up to the crowd, Karp, thrusting\nhis fingers into his belt and smiling a little, walked to the front.\nDron on the contrary retired to the rear and the crowd drew closer\ntogether.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is your Elder here? Hey?\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Rost\xc3\xb3v, coming up to the crowd\nwith quick steps.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Elder? What do you want with him?...\xe2\x80\x9d asked Karp.\n\nBut before the words were well out of his mouth, his cap flew off and a\nfierce blow jerked his head to one side.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaps off, traitors!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Rost\xc3\xb3v in a wrathful voice. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x99s the\nElder?\xe2\x80\x9d he cried furiously.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Elder.... He wants the Elder!... Dron Zakh\xc3\xa1rych, you!\xe2\x80\x9d meek and\nflustered voices here and there were heard calling and caps began to\ncome off their heads.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t riot, we\xe2\x80\x99re following the orders,\xe2\x80\x9d declared Karp, and at that\nmoment several voices began speaking together.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s as the old men have decided\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s too many of you giving\norders.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cArguing? Mutiny!... Brigands! Traitors!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Rost\xc3\xb3v unmeaningly in a\nvoice not his own, gripping Karp by the collar. \xe2\x80\x9cBind him, bind him!\xe2\x80\x9d he\nshouted, though there was no one to bind him but Lavr\xc3\xbashka and Alp\xc3\xa1tych.\n\nLavr\xc3\xbashka, however, ran up to Karp and seized him by the arms from\nbehind.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I call up our men from beyond the hill?\xe2\x80\x9d he called out.\n\nAlp\xc3\xa1tych turned to the peasants and ordered two of them by name to come\nand bind Karp. The men obediently came out of the crowd and began taking\noff their belts.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x99s the Elder?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Rost\xc3\xb3v in a loud voice.\n\nWith a pale and frowning face Dron stepped out of the crowd.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you the Elder? Bind him, Lavr\xc3\xbashka!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Rost\xc3\xb3v, as if that\norder, too, could not possibly meet with any opposition.\n\nAnd in fact two more peasants began binding Dron, who took off his own\nbelt and handed it to them, as if to aid them.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you all listen to me!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rost\xc3\xb3v to the peasants. \xe2\x80\x9cBe off to your\nhouses at once, and don\xe2\x80\x99t let one of your voices be heard!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, we\xe2\x80\x99ve not done any harm! We did it just out of foolishness. It\xe2\x80\x99s\nall nonsense.... I said then that it was not in order,\xe2\x80\x9d voices were\nheard bickering with one another.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere! What did I say?\xe2\x80\x9d said Alp\xc3\xa1tych, coming into his own again. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s\nwrong, lads!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll our stupidity, Y\xc3\xa1kov Alp\xc3\xa1tych,\xe2\x80\x9d came the answers, and the crowd\nbegan at once to disperse through the village.\n\nThe two bound men were led off to the master\xe2\x80\x99s house. The two drunken\npeasants followed them.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, when I look at you!...\xe2\x80\x9d said one of them to Karp.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can one talk to the masters like that? What were you thinking of,\nyou fool?\xe2\x80\x9d added the other\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cA real fool!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nTwo hours later the carts were standing in the courtyard of the\nBoguch\xc3\xa1rovo house. The peasants were briskly carrying out the\nproprietor\xe2\x80\x99s goods and packing them on the carts, and Dron, liberated at\nPrincess Mary\xe2\x80\x99s wish from the cupboard where he had been confined, was\nstanding in the yard directing the men.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t put it in so carelessly,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the peasants, a man with a\nround smiling face, taking a casket from a housemaid. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know it has\ncost money! How can you chuck it in like that or shove it under the cord\nwhere it\xe2\x80\x99ll get rubbed? I don\xe2\x80\x99t like that way of doing things. Let it\nall be done properly, according to rule. Look here, put it under the\nbast matting and cover it with hay\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s the way!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, books, books!\xe2\x80\x9d said another peasant, bringing out Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s\nlibrary cupboards. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t catch up against it! It\xe2\x80\x99s heavy, lads\xe2\x80\x94solid\nbooks.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, they worked all day and didn\xe2\x80\x99t play!\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the tall,\nround-faced peasant gravely, pointing with a significant wink at the\ndictionaries that were on the top.\n\n\nUnwilling to obtrude himself on the princess, Rost\xc3\xb3v did not go back to\nthe house but remained in the village awaiting her departure. When her\ncarriage drove out of the house, he mounted and accompanied her eight\nmiles from Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo to where the road was occupied by our troops. At\nthe inn at Yank\xc3\xb3vo he respectfully took leave of her, for the first time\npermitting himself to kiss her hand.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can you speak so!\xe2\x80\x9d he blushingly replied to Princess Mary\xe2\x80\x99s\nexpressions of gratitude for her deliverance, as she termed what had\noccurred. \xe2\x80\x9cAny police officer would have done as much! If we had had\nonly peasants to fight, we should not have let the enemy come so far,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid he with a sense of shame and wishing to change the subject. \xe2\x80\x9cI\nam only happy to have had the opportunity of making your acquaintance.\nGood-by, Princess. I wish you happiness and consolation and hope to meet\nyou again in happier circumstances. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t want to make me blush,\nplease don\xe2\x80\x99t thank me!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBut the princess, if she did not again thank him in words, thanked\nhim with the whole expression of her face, radiant with gratitude and\ntenderness. She could not believe that there was nothing to thank him\nfor. On the contrary, it seemed to her certain that had he not been\nthere she would have perished at the hands of the mutineers and of the\nFrench, and that he had exposed himself to terrible and obvious danger\nto save her, and even more certain was it that he was a man of lofty and\nnoble soul, able to understand her position and her sorrow. His kind,\nhonest eyes, with the tears rising in them when she herself had begun to\ncry as she spoke of her loss, did not leave her memory.\n\nWhen she had taken leave of him and remained alone she suddenly felt\nher eyes filling with tears, and then not for the first time the strange\nquestion presented itself to her: did she love him?\n\nOn the rest of the way to Moscow, though the princess\xe2\x80\x99 position was not\na cheerful one, Duny\xc3\xa1sha, who went with her in the carriage, more than\nonce noticed that her mistress leaned out of the window and smiled at\nsomething with an expression of mingled joy and sorrow.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, supposing I do love him?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Princess Mary.\n\nAshamed as she was of acknowledging to herself that she had fallen in\nlove with a man who would perhaps never love her, she comforted herself\nwith the thought that no one would ever know it and that she would not\nbe to blame if, without ever speaking of it to anyone, she continued to\nthe end of her life to love the man with whom she had fallen in love for\nthe first and last time in her life.\n\nSometimes when she recalled his looks, his sympathy, and his words,\nhappiness did not appear impossible to her. It was at those moments that\nDuny\xc3\xa1sha noticed her smiling as she looked out of the carriage window.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it not fate that brought him to Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo, and at that very\nmoment?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Princess Mary. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd that caused his sister to refuse my\nbrother?\xe2\x80\x9d And in all this Princess Mary saw the hand of Providence.\n\nThe impression the princess made on Rost\xc3\xb3v was a very agreeable one. To\nremember her gave him pleasure, and when his comrades, hearing of his\nadventure at Boguch\xc3\xa1rovo, rallied him on having gone to look for hay\nand having picked up one of the wealthiest heiresses in Russia, he grew\nangry. It made him angry just because the idea of marrying the gentle\nPrincess Mary, who was attractive to him and had an enormous fortune,\nhad against his will more than once entered his head. For himself\npersonally Nicholas could not wish for a better wife: by marrying her\nhe would make the countess his mother happy, would be able to put his\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s affairs in order, and would even\xe2\x80\x94he felt it\xe2\x80\x94ensure Princess\nMary\xe2\x80\x99s happiness.\n\nBut S\xc3\xb3nya? And his plighted word? That was why Rost\xc3\xb3v grew angry when he\nwas rallied about Princess Bolk\xc3\xb3nskaya.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XV\n\nOn receiving command of the armies Kut\xc3\xbazov remembered Prince Andrew and\nsent an order for him to report at headquarters.\n\nPrince Andrew arrived at Ts\xc3\xa1revo-Zaym\xc3\xadshche on the very day and at the\nvery hour that Kut\xc3\xbazov was reviewing the troops for the first time. He\nstopped in the village at the priest\xe2\x80\x99s house in front of which stood the\ncommander in chief\xe2\x80\x99s carriage, and he sat down on the bench at the gate\nawaiting his Serene Highness, as everyone now called Kut\xc3\xbazov. From the\nfield beyond the village came now sounds of regimental music and now the\nroar of many voices shouting \xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d to the new commander in chief.\nTwo orderlies, a courier and a major-domo, stood near by, some ten paces\nfrom Prince Andrew, availing themselves of Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s absence and of the\nfine weather. A short, swarthy lieutenant colonel of hussars with thick\nmustaches and whiskers rode up to the gate and, glancing at Prince\nAndrew, inquired whether his Serene Highness was putting up there and\nwhether he would soon be back.\n\nPrince Andrew replied that he was not on his Serene Highness\xe2\x80\x99 staff\nbut was himself a new arrival. The lieutenant colonel turned to a smart\norderly, who, with the peculiar contempt with which a commander in\nchief\xe2\x80\x99s orderly speaks to officers, replied:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? His Serene Highness? I expect he\xe2\x80\x99ll be here soon. What do you\nwant?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe lieutenant colonel of hussars smiled beneath his mustache at the\norderly\xe2\x80\x99s tone, dismounted, gave his horse to a dispatch runner, and\napproached Bolk\xc3\xb3nski with a slight bow. Bolk\xc3\xb3nski made room for him on\nthe bench and the lieutenant colonel sat down beside him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re also waiting for the commander in chief?\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cThey say he\nweceives evewyone, thank God!... It\xe2\x80\x99s awful with those sausage eaters!\nErm\xc3\xb3lov had weason to ask to be pwomoted to be a German! Now p\xe2\x80\x99waps\nWussians will get a look in.
