As it was, devil only knows what was\nhappening. We kept wetweating and wetweating. Did you take part in the\ncampaign?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had the pleasure,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Prince Andrew, \xe2\x80\x9cnot only of taking part in\nthe retreat but of losing in that retreat all I held dear\xe2\x80\x94not to mention\nthe estate and home of my birth\xe2\x80\x94my father, who died of grief. I belong\nto the province of Smol\xc3\xa9nsk.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh? You\xe2\x80\x99re Pwince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski? Vewy glad to make your acquaintance! I\xe2\x80\x99m\nLieutenant Colonel Den\xc3\xadsov, better known as \xe2\x80\x98V\xc3\xa1ska,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov,\npressing Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s hand and looking into his face with a\nparticularly kindly attention. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, I heard,\xe2\x80\x9d said he sympathetically,\nand after a short pause added: \xe2\x80\x9cYes, it\xe2\x80\x99s Scythian warfare. It\xe2\x80\x99s all\nvewy well\xe2\x80\x94only not for those who get it in the neck. So you are Pwince\nAndwew Bolk\xc3\xb3nski?\xe2\x80\x9d He swayed his head. \xe2\x80\x9cVewy pleased, Pwince, to make\nyour acquaintance!\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated again, smiling sadly, and he again\npressed Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\n\nPrince Andrew knew Den\xc3\xadsov from what Nat\xc3\xa1sha had told him of her first\nsuitor. This memory carried him sadly and sweetly back to those painful\nfeelings of which he had not thought lately, but which still found\nplace in his soul. Of late he had received so many new and very serious\nimpressions\xe2\x80\x94such as the retreat from Smol\xc3\xa9nsk, his visit to Bald Hills,\nand the recent news of his father\xe2\x80\x99s death\xe2\x80\x94and had experienced so many\nemotions, that for a long time past those memories had not entered his\nmind, and now that they did, they did not act on him with nearly their\nformer strength. For Den\xc3\xadsov, too, the memories awakened by the name of\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski belonged to a distant, romantic past, when after supper and\nafter Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s singing he had proposed to a little girl of fifteen\nwithout realizing what he was doing. He smiled at the recollection of\nthat time and of his love for Nat\xc3\xa1sha, and passed at once to what now\ninterested him passionately and exclusively. This was a plan of campaign\nhe had devised while serving at the outposts during the retreat. He had\nproposed that plan to Barclay de Tolly and now wished to propose it\nto Kut\xc3\xbazov. The plan was based on the fact that the French line\nof operation was too extended, and it proposed that instead of, or\nconcurrently with, action on the front to bar the advance of the French,\nwe should attack their line of communication. He began explaining his\nplan to Prince Andrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey can\xe2\x80\x99t hold all that line. It\xe2\x80\x99s impossible. I will undertake to\nbweak thwough. Give me five hundwed men and I will bweak the line,\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s certain! There\xe2\x80\x99s only one way\xe2\x80\x94guewilla warfare!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov rose and began gesticulating as he explained his plan to\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski. In the midst of his explanation shouts were heard from the\narmy, growing more incoherent and more diffused, mingling with music\nand songs and coming from the field where the review was held. Sounds of\nhoofs and shouts were nearing the village.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s coming! He\xe2\x80\x99s coming!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted a Cossack standing at the gate.\n\nBolk\xc3\xb3nski and Den\xc3\xadsov moved to the gate, at which a knot of soldiers\n(a guard of honor) was standing, and they saw Kut\xc3\xbazov coming down the\nstreet mounted on a rather small sorrel horse. A huge suite of generals\nrode behind him. Barclay was riding almost beside him, and a crowd of\nofficers ran after and around them shouting, \xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHis adjutants galloped into the yard before him. Kut\xc3\xbazov was impatiently\nurging on his horse, which ambled smoothly under his weight, and he\nraised his hand to his white Horse Guard\xe2\x80\x99s cap with a red band and no\npeak, nodding his head continually. When he came up to the guard of\nhonor, a fine set of Grenadiers mostly wearing decorations, who were\ngiving him the salute, he looked at them silently and attentively for\nnearly a minute with the steady gaze of a commander and then turned to\nthe crowd of generals and officers surrounding him. Suddenly his face\nassumed a subtle expression, he shrugged his shoulders with an air of\nperplexity.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd with such fine fellows to retreat and retreat! Well, good-by,\nGeneral,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, and rode into the yard past Prince Andrew and\nDen\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah! hurrah! hurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted those behind him.\n\nSince Prince Andrew had last seen him Kut\xc3\xbazov had grown still more\ncorpulent, flaccid, and fat. But the bleached eyeball, the scar, and the\nfamiliar weariness of his expression were still the same. He was wearing\nthe white Horse Guard\xe2\x80\x99s cap and a military overcoat with a whip hanging\nover his shoulder by a thin strap. He sat heavily and swayed limply on\nhis brisk little horse.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhew... whew... whew!\xe2\x80\x9d he whistled just audibly as he rode into the\nyard. His face expressed the relief of relaxed strain felt by a man who\nmeans to rest after a ceremony. He drew his left foot out of the stirrup\nand, lurching with his whole body and puckering his face with the\neffort, raised it with difficulty onto the saddle, leaned on his knee,\ngroaned, and slipped down into the arms of the Cossacks and adjutants\nwho stood ready to assist him.\n\nHe pulled himself together, looked round, screwing up his eyes, glanced\nat Prince Andrew, and, evidently not recognizing him, moved with his\nwaddling gait to the porch. \xe2\x80\x9cWhew... whew... whew!\xe2\x80\x9d he whistled, and\nagain glanced at Prince Andrew. As often occurs with old men, it was\nonly after some seconds that the impression produced by Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s\nface linked itself up with Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s remembrance of his personality.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, how do you do, my dear prince? How do you do, my dear boy? Come\nalong...\xe2\x80\x9d said he, glancing wearily round, and he stepped onto the porch\nwhich creaked under his weight.\n\nHe unbuttoned his coat and sat down on a bench in the porch.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how\xe2\x80\x99s your father?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI received news of his death, yesterday,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Prince Andrew\nabruptly.\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov looked at him with eyes wide open with dismay and then took off\nhis cap and crossed himself:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay the kingdom of Heaven be his! God\xe2\x80\x99s will be done to us all!\xe2\x80\x9d He\nsighed deeply, his whole chest heaving, and was silent for a while. \xe2\x80\x9cI\nloved him and respected him, and sympathize with you with all my heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe embraced Prince Andrew, pressing him to his fat breast, and for some\ntime did not let him go. When he released him Prince Andrew saw that\nKut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s flabby lips were trembling and that tears were in his eyes. He\nsighed and pressed on the bench with both hands to raise himself.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome! Come with me, we\xe2\x80\x99ll have a talk,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\nBut at that moment Den\xc3\xadsov, no more intimidated by his superiors than by\nthe enemy, came with jingling spurs up the steps of the porch, despite\nthe angry whispers of the adjutants who tried to stop him. Kut\xc3\xbazov, his\nhands still pressed on the seat, glanced at him glumly. Den\xc3\xadsov, having\ngiven his name, announced that he had to communicate to his Serene\nHighness a matter of great importance for their country\xe2\x80\x99s welfare.\nKut\xc3\xbazov looked wearily at him and, lifting his hands with a gesture of\nannoyance, folded them across his stomach, repeating the words: \xe2\x80\x9cFor our\ncountry\xe2\x80\x99s welfare? Well, what is it? Speak!\xe2\x80\x9d Den\xc3\xadsov blushed like a\ngirl (it was strange to see the color rise in that shaggy, bibulous,\ntime-worn face) and boldly began to expound his plan of cutting the\nenemy\xe2\x80\x99s lines of communication between Smol\xc3\xa9nsk and Vy\xc3\xa1zma. Den\xc3\xadsov came\nfrom those parts and knew the country well. His plan seemed decidedly\na good one, especially from the strength of conviction with which he\nspoke. Kut\xc3\xbazov looked down at his own legs, occasionally glancing at the\ndoor of the adjoining hut as if expecting something unpleasant to emerge\nfrom it. And from that hut, while Den\xc3\xadsov was speaking, a general with a\nportfolio under his arm really did appear.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d said Kut\xc3\xbazov, in the midst of Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s explanations, \xe2\x80\x9care you\nready so soon?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cReady, your Serene Highness,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the general.\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov swayed his head, as much as to say: \xe2\x80\x9cHow is one man to deal with\nit all?\xe2\x80\x9d and again listened to Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI give my word of honor as a Wussian officer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I\ncan bweak Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s line of communication!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat relation are you to Intendant General Kir\xc3\xadl Andr\xc3\xa9evich Den\xc3\xadsov?\xe2\x80\x9d\nasked Kut\xc3\xbazov, interrupting him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is my uncle, your Sewene Highness.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, we were friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kut\xc3\xbazov cheerfully. \xe2\x80\x9cAll right, all right,\nfriend, stay here at the staff and tomorrow we\xe2\x80\x99ll have a talk.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nWith a nod to Den\xc3\xadsov he turned away and put out his hand for the papers\nKonovn\xc3\xadtsyn had brought him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould not your Serene Highness like to come inside?\xe2\x80\x9d said the general\non duty in a discontented voice, \xe2\x80\x9cthe plans must be examined and several\npapers have to be signed.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAn adjutant came out and announced that everything was in readiness\nwithin. But Kut\xc3\xbazov evidently did not wish to enter that room till he\nwas disengaged. He made a grimace....\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, tell them to bring a small table out here, my dear boy. I\xe2\x80\x99ll look\nat them here,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t go away,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, turning to Prince\nAndrew, who remained in the porch and listened to the general\xe2\x80\x99s report.\n\nWhile this was being given, Prince Andrew heard the whisper of a woman\xe2\x80\x99s\nvoice and the rustle of a silk dress behind the door. Several times on\nglancing that way he noticed behind that door a plump, rosy, handsome\nwoman in a pink dress with a lilac silk kerchief on her head, holding\na dish and evidently awaiting the entrance of the commander in chief.\nKut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s adjutant whispered to Prince Andrew that this was the wife of\nthe priest whose home it was, and that she intended to offer his Serene\nHighness bread and salt. \xe2\x80\x9cHer husband has welcomed his Serene Highness\nwith the cross at the church, and she intends to welcome him in the\nhouse.... She\xe2\x80\x99s very pretty,\xe2\x80\x9d added the adjutant with a smile. At\nthose words Kut\xc3\xbazov looked round. He was listening to the general\xe2\x80\x99s\nreport\xe2\x80\x94which consisted chiefly of a criticism of the position at\nTs\xc3\xa1revo-Zaym\xc3\xadshche\xe2\x80\x94as he had listened to Den\xc3\xadsov, and seven years\npreviously had listened to the discussion at the Austerlitz council of\nwar. He evidently listened only because he had ears which, though there\nwas a piece of tow in one of them, could not help hearing; but it\nwas evident that nothing the general could say would surprise or even\ninterest him, that he knew all that would be said beforehand, and heard\nit all only because he had to, as one has to listen to the chanting of\na service of prayer. All that Den\xc3\xadsov had said was clever and to the\npoint. What the general was saying was even more clever and to\nthe point, but it was evident that Kut\xc3\xbazov despised knowledge\nand cleverness, and knew of something else that would decide the\nmatter\xe2\x80\x94something independent of cleverness and knowledge. Prince\nAndrew watched the commander in chief\xe2\x80\x99s face attentively, and the only\nexpression he could see there was one of boredom, curiosity as to the\nmeaning of the feminine whispering behind the door, and a desire to\nobserve propriety. It was evident that Kut\xc3\xbazov despised cleverness and\nlearning and even the patriotic feeling shown by Den\xc3\xadsov, but despised\nthem not because of his own intellect, feelings, or knowledge\xe2\x80\x94he did not\ntry to display any of these\xe2\x80\x94but because of something else. He despised\nthem because of his old age and experience of life. The only instruction\nKut\xc3\xbazov gave of his own accord during that report referred to looting by\nthe Russian troops. At the end of the report the general put before\nhim for signature a paper relating to the recovery of payment from army\ncommanders for green oats mown down by the soldiers, when landowners\nlodged petitions for compensation.\n\nAfter hearing the matter, Kut\xc3\xbazov smacked his lips together and shook\nhis head.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cInto the stove... into the fire with it! I tell you once for all, my\ndear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cinto the fire with all such things! Let them cut\nthe crops and burn wood to their hearts\xe2\x80\x99 content. I don\xe2\x80\x99t order it\nor allow it, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t exact compensation either. One can\xe2\x80\x99t get on\nwithout it. \xe2\x80\x98When wood is chopped the chips will fly.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d He looked at the\npaper again. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, this German precision!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered, shaking his head.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVI\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that\xe2\x80\x99s all!\xe2\x80\x9d said Kut\xc3\xbazov as he signed the last of the documents,\nand rising heavily and smoothing out the folds in his fat white neck he\nmoved toward the door with a more cheerful expression.\n\nThe priest\xe2\x80\x99s wife, flushing rosy red, caught up the dish she had after\nall not managed to present at the right moment, though she had so long\nbeen preparing for it, and with a low bow offered it to Kut\xc3\xbazov.\n\nHe screwed up his eyes, smiled, lifted her chin with his hand, and said:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, what a beauty! Thank you, sweetheart!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe took some gold pieces from his trouser pocket and put them on the\ndish for her. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear, and how are we getting on?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked,\nmoving to the door of the room assigned to him. The priest\xe2\x80\x99s wife\nsmiled, and with dimples in her rosy cheeks followed him into the room.\nThe adjutant came out to the porch and asked Prince Andrew to lunch with\nhim. Half an hour later Prince Andrew was again called to Kut\xc3\xbazov.\nHe found him reclining in an armchair, still in the same unbuttoned\novercoat. He had in his hand a French book which he closed as Prince\nAndrew entered, marking the place with a knife. Prince Andrew saw by the\ncover that it was Les Chevaliers du Cygne by Madame de Genlis.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sit down, sit down here. Let\xe2\x80\x99s have a talk,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kut\xc3\xbazov. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s\nsad, very sad. But remember, my dear fellow, that I am a father to you,\na second father....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPrince Andrew told Kut\xc3\xbazov all he knew of his father\xe2\x80\x99s death, and what\nhe had seen at Bald Hills when he passed through it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat... what they have brought us to!\xe2\x80\x9d Kut\xc3\xbazov suddenly cried in an\nagitated voice, evidently picturing vividly to himself from Prince\nAndrew\xe2\x80\x99s story the condition Russia was in. \xe2\x80\x9cBut give me time, give me\ntime!\xe2\x80\x9d he said with a grim look, evidently not wishing to continue this\nagitating conversation, and added: \xe2\x80\x9cI sent for you to keep you with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank your Serene Highness, but I fear I am no longer fit for the\nstaff,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Prince Andrew with a smile which Kut\xc3\xbazov noticed.\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov glanced inquiringly at him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut above all,\xe2\x80\x9d added Prince Andrew, \xe2\x80\x9cI have grown used to my regiment,\nam fond of the officers, and I fancy the men also like me. I should be\nsorry to leave the regiment. If I decline the honor of being with you,\nbelieve me...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nA shrewd, kindly, yet subtly derisive expression lit up Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s podgy\nface. He cut Bolk\xc3\xb3nski short.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry, for I need you. But you\xe2\x80\x99re right, you\xe2\x80\x99re right! It\xe2\x80\x99s not\nhere that men are needed. Advisers are always plentiful, but men are\nnot. The regiments would not be what they are if the would-be advisers\nserved there as you do. I remember you at Austerlitz.... I remember,\nyes, I remember you with the standard!\xe2\x80\x9d said Kut\xc3\xbazov, and a flush of\npleasure suffused Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s face at this recollection.\n\nTaking his hand and drawing him downwards, Kut\xc3\xbazov offered his cheek to\nbe kissed, and again Prince Andrew noticed tears in the old man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes.\nThough Prince Andrew knew that Kut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s tears came easily, and that he\nwas particularly tender to and considerate of him from a wish to\nshow sympathy with his loss, yet this reminder of Austerlitz was both\npleasant and flattering to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo your way and God be with you. I know your path is the path of\nhonor!\xe2\x80\x9d He paused. \xe2\x80\x9cI missed you at Bucharest, but I needed someone to\nsend.\xe2\x80\x9d And changing the subject, Kut\xc3\xbazov began to speak of the Turkish\nwar and the peace that had been concluded. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, I have been much\nblamed,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cboth for that war and the peace... but everything\ncame at the right time. Tout vient \xc3\xa0 point \xc3\xa0 celui qui sait attendre. *\nAnd there were as many advisers there as here...\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, returning\nto the subject of \xe2\x80\x9cadvisers\xe2\x80\x9d which evidently occupied him. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, those\nadvisers!\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cIf we had listened to them all we should not have\nmade peace with Turkey and should not have been through with that war.\nEverything in haste, but more haste, less speed. K\xc3\xa1menski would have\nbeen lost if he had not died. He stormed fortresses with thirty thousand\nmen. It is not difficult to capture a fortress but it is difficult to\nwin a campaign. For that, not storming and attacking but patience and\ntime are wanted. K\xc3\xa1menski sent soldiers to Rustchuk, but I only employed\nthese two things and took more fortresses than K\xc3\xa1menski and made them\nTurks eat horseflesh!\xe2\x80\x9d He swayed his head. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd the French shall too,\nbelieve me,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, growing warmer and beating his chest, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll\nmake them eat horseflesh!\xe2\x80\x9d And tears again dimmed his eyes.\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cEverything comes in time to him who knows how to wait.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut shan\xe2\x80\x99t we have to accept battle?\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Prince Andrew.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall if everybody wants it; it can\xe2\x80\x99t be helped.... But believe\nme, my dear boy, there is nothing stronger than those two: patience and\ntime, they will do it all. But the advisers n\xe2\x80\x99entendent pas de cette\noreille, voil\xc3\xa0 le mal. * Some want a thing\xe2\x80\x94others don\xe2\x80\x99t. What\xe2\x80\x99s one to\ndo?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, evidently expecting an answer. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what do you want\nus to do?\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated and his eye shone with a deep, shrewd look.\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what to do,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, as Prince Andrew still did not\nreply: \xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you what to do, and what I do. Dans le doute, mon\ncher,\xe2\x80\x9d he paused, \xe2\x80\x9cabstiens-toi\xe2\x80\x9d *(2)\xe2\x80\x94he articulated the French proverb\ndeliberately.\n\n     * \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t see it that way, that\xe2\x80\x99s the trouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n     * (2) \xe2\x80\x9cWhen in doubt, my dear fellow, do nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, good-by, my dear fellow; remember that with all my heart I share\nyour sorrow, and that for you I am not a Serene Highness, nor a prince,\nnor a commander in chief, but a father! If you want anything come\nstraight to me. Good-by, my dear boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAgain he embraced and kissed Prince Andrew, but before the latter\nhad left the room Kut\xc3\xbazov gave a sigh of relief and went on with his\nunfinished novel, Les Chevaliers du Cygne by Madame de Genlis.\n\nPrince Andrew could not have explained how or why it was, but after that\ninterview with Kut\xc3\xbazov he went back to his regiment reassured as to\nthe general course of affairs and as to the man to whom it had been\nentrusted. The more he realized the absence of all personal motive in\nthat old man\xe2\x80\x94in whom there seemed to remain only the habit of passions,\nand in place of an intellect (grouping events and drawing conclusions)\nonly the capacity calmly to contemplate the course of events\xe2\x80\x94the more\nreassured he was that everything would be as it should. \xe2\x80\x9cHe will not\nbring in any plan of his own. He will not devise or undertake\nanything,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Prince Andrew, \xe2\x80\x9cbut he will hear everything, remember\neverything, and put everything in its place. He will not hinder\nanything useful nor allow anything harmful. He understands that there is\nsomething stronger and more important than his own will\xe2\x80\x94the inevitable\ncourse of events, and he can see them and grasp their significance,\nand seeing that significance can refrain from meddling and renounce his\npersonal wish directed to something else. And above all,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Prince\nAndrew, \xe2\x80\x9cone believes in him because he\xe2\x80\x99s Russian, despite the novel\nby Genlis and the French proverbs, and because his voice shook when he\nsaid: \xe2\x80\x98What they have brought us to!\xe2\x80\x99 and had a sob in it when he said\nhe would \xe2\x80\x98make them eat horseflesh!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nOn such feelings, more or less dimly shared by all, the unanimity and\ngeneral approval were founded with which, despite court influences, the\npopular choice of Kut\xc3\xbazov as commander in chief was received.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVII\n\nAfter the Emperor had left Moscow, life flowed on there in its usual\ncourse, and its course was so very usual that it was difficult to\nremember the recent days of patriotic elation and ardor, hard to believe\nthat Russia was really in danger and that the members of the English\nClub were also sons of the Fatherland ready to sacrifice everything\nfor it. The one thing that recalled the patriotic fervor everyone had\ndisplayed during the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s stay was the call for contributions of\nmen and money, a necessity that as soon as the promises had been made\nassumed a legal, official form and became unavoidable.\n\nWith the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s approach to Moscow, the Moscovites\xe2\x80\x99 view of their\nsituation did not grow more serious but on the contrary became even\nmore frivolous, as always happens with people who see a great danger\napproaching. At the approach of danger there are always two voices that\nspeak with equal power in the human soul: one very reasonably tells a\nman to consider the nature of the danger and the means of escaping it;\nthe other, still more reasonably, says that it is too depressing and\npainful to think of the danger, since it is not in man\xe2\x80\x99s power to\nforesee everything and avert the general course of events, and it is\ntherefore better to disregard what is painful till it comes, and to\nthink about what is pleasant. In solitude a man generally listens to\nthe first voice, but in society to the second. So it was now with the\ninhabitants of Moscow. It was long since people had been as gay in\nMoscow as that year.\n\nRostopch\xc3\xadn\xe2\x80\x99s broadsheets, headed by woodcuts of a drink shop, a potman,\nand a Moscow burgher called Karp\xc3\xbashka Chig\xc3\xadrin, \xe2\x80\x9cwho\xe2\x80\x94having been a\nmilitiaman and having had rather too much at the pub\xe2\x80\x94heard that Napoleon\nwished to come to Moscow, grew angry, abused the French in very bad\nlanguage, came out of the drink shop, and, under the sign of the\neagle, began to address the assembled people,\xe2\x80\x9d were read and discussed,\ntogether with the latest of Vas\xc3\xadli Lv\xc3\xb3vich P\xc3\xbashkin\xe2\x80\x99s bouts rim\xc3\xa9s.\n\nIn the corner room at the Club, members gathered to read these\nbroadsheets, and some liked the way Karp\xc3\xbashka jeered at the French,\nsaying: \xe2\x80\x9cThey will swell up with Russian cabbage, burst with our\nbuckwheat porridge, and choke themselves with cabbage soup. They are all\ndwarfs and one peasant woman will toss three of them with a hayfork.\xe2\x80\x9d\nOthers did not like that tone and said it was stupid and vulgar. It was\nsaid that Rostopch\xc3\xadn had expelled all Frenchmen and even all foreigners\nfrom Moscow, and that there had been some spies and agents of Napoleon\namong them; but this was told chiefly to introduce Rostopch\xc3\xadn\xe2\x80\x99s witty\nremark on that occasion. The foreigners were deported to N\xc3\xadzhni by\nboat, and Rostopch\xc3\xadn had said to them in French: \xe2\x80\x9cRentrez en vous-m\xc3\xaames;\nentrez dans la barque, et n\xe2\x80\x99en faites pas une barque de Charon.\xe2\x80\x9d * There\nwas talk of all the government offices having been already removed from\nMoscow, and to this Shinsh\xc3\xadn\xe2\x80\x99s witticism was added\xe2\x80\x94that for that alone\nMoscow ought to be grateful to Napoleon. It was said that Mam\xc3\xb3nov\xe2\x80\x99s\nregiment would cost him eight hundred thousand rubles, and that Bez\xc3\xbakhov\nhad spent even more on his, but that the best thing about Bez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s\naction was that he himself was going to don a uniform and ride at the\nhead of his regiment without charging anything for the show.\n\n     * \xe2\x80\x9cThink it over; get into the barque, and take care not to\n     make it a barque of Charon.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t spare anyone,\xe2\x80\x9d said Julie Drubetsk\xc3\xa1ya as she collected\nand pressed together a bunch of raveled lint with her thin, beringed\nfingers.\n\nJulie was preparing to leave Moscow next day and was giving a farewell\nsoiree.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBez\xc3\xbakhov est ridicule, but he is so kind and good-natured. What\npleasure is there to be so caustique?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA forfeit!\xe2\x80\x9d cried a young man in militia uniform whom Julie called \xe2\x80\x9cmon\nchevalier,\xe2\x80\x9d and who was going with her to N\xc3\xadzhni.\n\nIn Julie\xe2\x80\x99s set, as in many other circles in Moscow, it had been agreed\nthat they would speak nothing but Russian and that those who made a\nslip and spoke French should pay fines to the Committee of Voluntary\nContributions.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnother forfeit for a Gallicism,\xe2\x80\x9d said a Russian writer who was\npresent. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98What pleasure is there to be\xe2\x80\x99 is not Russian!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou spare no one,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Julie to the young man without heeding the\nauthor\xe2\x80\x99s remark.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor caustique\xe2\x80\x94I am guilty and will pay, and I am prepared to pay again\nfor the pleasure of telling you the truth. For Gallicisms I won\xe2\x80\x99t be\nresponsible,\xe2\x80\x9d she remarked, turning to the author: \xe2\x80\x9cI have neither the\nmoney nor the time, like Prince Gal\xc3\xadtsyn, to engage a master to teach me\nRussian!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, here he is!\xe2\x80\x9d she added. \xe2\x80\x9cQuand on... No, no,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to the\nmilitia officer, \xe2\x80\x9cyou won\xe2\x80\x99t catch me. Speak of the sun and you see its\nrays!\xe2\x80\x9d and she smiled amiably at Pierre. \xe2\x80\x9cWe were just talking of you,\xe2\x80\x9d\nshe said with the facility in lying natural to a society woman. \xe2\x80\x9cWe were\nsaying that your regiment would be sure to be better than Mam\xc3\xb3nov\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, don\xe2\x80\x99t talk to me of my regiment,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Pierre, kissing his\nhostess\xe2\x80\x99 hand and taking a seat beside her. \xe2\x80\x9cI am so sick of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will, of course, command it yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d said Julie, directing a sly,\nsarcastic glance toward the militia officer.\n\nThe latter in Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s presence had ceased to be caustic, and his face\nexpressed perplexity as to what Julie\xe2\x80\x99s smile might mean. In spite of\nhis absent-mindedness and good nature, Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s personality immediately\nchecked any attempt to ridicule him to his face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, with a laughing glance at his big, stout body. \xe2\x80\x9cI\nshould make too good a target for the French, besides I am afraid I\nshould hardly be able to climb onto a horse.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAmong those whom Julie\xe2\x80\x99s guests happened to choose to gossip about were\nthe Rost\xc3\xb3vs.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hear that their affairs are in a very bad way,\xe2\x80\x9d said Julie. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd he\nis so unreasonable, the count himself I mean. The Razum\xc3\xb3vskis wanted\nto buy his house and his estate near Moscow, but it drags on and on. He\nasks too much.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I think the sale will come off in a few days,\xe2\x80\x9d said someone.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThough it is madness to buy anything in Moscow now.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Julie. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t think Moscow is in danger?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen why are you leaving?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? What a question! I am going because... well, because everyone is\ngoing: and besides\xe2\x80\x94I am not Joan of Arc or an Amazon.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, of course, of course! Let me have some more strips of linen.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he manages the business properly he will be able to pay off all his\ndebts,\xe2\x80\x9d said the militia officer, speaking of Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA kindly old man but not up to much. And why do they stay on so long in\nMoscow? They meant to leave for the country long ago. Natalie is quite\nwell again now, isn\xe2\x80\x99t she?\xe2\x80\x9d Julie asked Pierre with a knowing smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are waiting for their younger son,\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre replied. \xe2\x80\x9cHe joined\nObol\xc3\xa9nski\xe2\x80\x99s Cossacks and went to B\xc3\xa9laya Ts\xc3\xa9rkov where the regiment is\nbeing formed. But now they have had him transferred to my regiment and\nare expecting him every day. The count wanted to leave long ago, but the\ncountess won\xe2\x80\x99t on any account leave Moscow till her son returns.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI met them the day before yesterday at the Arkh\xc3\xa1rovs\xe2\x80\x99. Natalie has\nrecovered her looks and is brighter. She sang a song. How easily some\npeople get over everything!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet over what?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Pierre, looking displeased.\n\nJulie smiled.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know, Count, such knights as you are only found in Madame de\nSouza\xe2\x80\x99s novels.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat knights? What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Pierre, blushing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, come, my dear count! C\xe2\x80\x99est la fable de tout Moscou. Je vous admire,\nma parole d\xe2\x80\x99honneur!\xe2\x80\x9d *\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cIt is the talk of all Moscow. My word, I admire you!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cForfeit, forfeit!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the militia officer.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, one can\xe2\x80\x99t talk\xe2\x80\x94how tiresome!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is \xe2\x80\x98the talk of all Moscow\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre asked angrily, rising to his\nfeet.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome now, Count, you know!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know anything about it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know you were friendly with Natalie, and so... but I was always more\nfriendly with V\xc3\xa9ra\xe2\x80\x94that dear V\xc3\xa9ra.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, madame!\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre continued in a tone of displeasure, \xe2\x80\x9cI have not\ntaken on myself the role of Natalie Rost\xc3\xb3va\xe2\x80\x99s knight at all, and have\nnot been to their house for nearly a month. But I cannot understand the\ncruelty...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cQui s\xe2\x80\x99excuse s\xe2\x80\x99accuse,\xe2\x80\x9d * said Julie, smiling and waving the lint\ntriumphantly, and to have the last word she promptly changed the\nsubject. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you know what I heard today? Poor Mary Bolk\xc3\xb3nskaya arrived\nin Moscow yesterday. Do you know that she has lost her father?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cWho excuses himself, accuses himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally? Where is she? I should like very much to see her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI spent the evening with her yesterday. She is going to their estate\nnear Moscow either today or tomorrow morning, with her nephew.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and how is she?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is well, but sad. But do you know who rescued her? It is quite a\nromance. Nicholas Rost\xc3\xb3v! She was surrounded, and they wanted to kill\nher and had wounded some of her people. He rushed in and saved her....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnother romance,\xe2\x80\x9d said the militia officer. \xe2\x80\x9cReally, this general\nflight has been arranged to get all the old maids married off. Catiche\nis one and Princess Bolk\xc3\xb3nskaya another.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, I really believe she is un petit peu amoureuse du jeune\nhomme.\xe2\x80\x9d *\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cA little bit in love with the young man.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cForfeit, forfeit, forfeit!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how could one say that in Russian?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVIII\n\nWhen Pierre returned home he was handed two of Rostopch\xc3\xadn\xe2\x80\x99s broadsheets\nthat had been brought that day.\n\nThe first declared that the report that Count Rostopch\xc3\xadn had forbidden\npeople to leave Moscow was false; on the contrary he was glad that\nladies and tradesmen\xe2\x80\x99s wives were leaving the city. \xe2\x80\x9cThere will be less\npanic and less gossip,\xe2\x80\x9d ran the broadsheet \xe2\x80\x9cbut I will stake my life on\nit that that scoundrel will not enter Moscow.\xe2\x80\x9d These words showed Pierre\nclearly for the first time that the French would enter Moscow. The\nsecond broadsheet stated that our headquarters were at Vy\xc3\xa1zma, that\nCount Wittgenstein had defeated the French, but that as many of the\ninhabitants of Moscow wished to be armed, weapons were ready for them\nat the arsenal: sabers, pistols, and muskets which could be had at a low\nprice. The tone of the proclamation was not as jocose as in the former\nChig\xc3\xadrin talks. Pierre pondered over these broadsheets. Evidently the\nterrible stormcloud he had desired with the whole strength of his soul\nbut which yet aroused involuntary horror in him was drawing near.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I join the army and enter the service, or wait?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked himself\nfor the hundredth time. He took a pack of cards that lay on the table\nand began to lay them out for a game of patience.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf this patience comes out,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself after shuffling the\ncards, holding them in his hand, and lifting his head, \xe2\x80\x9cif it comes out,\nit means... what does it mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe had not decided what it should mean when he heard the voice of the\neldest princess at the door asking whether she might come in.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen it will mean that I must go to the army,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre to himself.\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in, come in!\xe2\x80\x9d he added to the princess.\n\nOnly the eldest princess, the one with the stony face and long waist,\nwas still living in Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s house. The two younger ones had both\nmarried.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse my coming to you, cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d she said in a reproachful and\nagitated voice. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know some decision must be come to. What is going\nto happen? Everyone has left Moscow and the people are rioting. How is\nit that we are staying on?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, things seem satisfactory, ma cousine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre\nin the bantering tone he habitually adopted toward her, always feeling\nuncomfortable in the role of her benefactor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSatisfactory, indeed! Very satisfactory! Barbara Iv\xc3\xa1novna told me today\nhow our troops are distinguishing themselves. It certainly does them\ncredit! And the people too are quite mutinous\xe2\x80\x94they no longer obey,\neven my maid has taken to being rude. At this rate they will soon begin\nbeating us. One can\xe2\x80\x99t walk in the streets. But, above all, the French\nwill be here any day now, so what are we waiting for? I ask just one\nthing of you, cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on, \xe2\x80\x9carrange for me to be taken to\nPetersburg. Whatever I may be, I can\xe2\x80\x99t live under Bonaparte\xe2\x80\x99s rule.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, come, ma cousine! Where do you get your information from? On the\ncontrary...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t submit to your Napoleon! Others may if they please.... If you\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t want to do this...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I will, I\xe2\x80\x99ll give the order at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe princess was apparently vexed at not having anyone to be angry with.\nMuttering to herself, she sat down on a chair.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you have been misinformed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre. \xe2\x80\x9cEverything is quiet in\nthe city and there is not the slightest danger. See! I\xe2\x80\x99ve just been\nreading...\xe2\x80\x9d He showed her the broadsheet. \xe2\x80\x9cCount Rostopch\xc3\xadn writes that\nhe will stake his life on it that the enemy will not enter Moscow.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that count of yours!\xe2\x80\x9d said the princess malevolently. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is a\nhypocrite, a rascal who has himself roused the people to riot. Didn\xe2\x80\x99t\nhe write in those idiotic broadsheets that anyone, \xe2\x80\x98whoever it might be,\nshould be dragged to the lockup by his hair\xe2\x80\x99? (How silly!) \xe2\x80\x98And honor\nand glory to whoever captures him,\xe2\x80\x99 he says. This is what his cajolery\nhas brought us to! Barbara Iv\xc3\xa1novna told me the mob near killed her\nbecause she said something in French.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, but it\xe2\x80\x99s so... You take everything so to heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, and\nbegan laying out his cards for patience.\n\nAlthough that patience did come out, Pierre did not join the army,\nbut remained in deserted Moscow ever in the same state of agitation,\nirresolution, and alarm, yet at the same time joyfully expecting\nsomething terrible.\n\nNext day toward evening the princess set off, and Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s head steward\ncame to inform him that the money needed for the equipment of his\nregiment could not be found without selling one of the estates. In\ngeneral the head steward made out to Pierre that his project of raising\na regiment would ruin him. Pierre listened to him, scarcely able to\nrepress a smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then, sell it,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s to be done? I can\xe2\x80\x99t draw back\nnow!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe worse everything became, especially his own affairs, the better\nwas Pierre pleased and the more evident was it that the catastrophe he\nexpected was approaching. Hardly anyone he knew was left in town. Julie\nhad gone, and so had Princess Mary. Of his intimate friends only the\nRost\xc3\xb3vs remained, but he did not go to see them.\n\nTo distract his thoughts he drove that day to the village of Voronts\xc3\xb3vo\nto see the great balloon Leppich was constructing to destroy the foe,\nand a trial balloon that was to go up next day. The balloon was not yet\nready, but Pierre learned that it was being constructed by the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s\ndesire. The Emperor had written to Count Rostopch\xc3\xadn as follows:\n\nAs soon as Leppich is ready, get together a crew of reliable and\nintelligent men for his car and send a courier to General Kut\xc3\xbazov to let\nhim know. I have informed him of the matter.\n\nPlease impress upon Leppich to be very careful where he descends for\nthe first time, that he may not make a mistake and fall into the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s\nhands. It is essential for him to combine his movements with those of\nthe commander in chief.\n\n\nOn his way home from Voronts\xc3\xb3vo, as he was passing the Bol\xc3\xb3tnoe Place\nPierre, seeing a large crowd round the L\xc3\xb3bnoe Place, stopped and got out\nof his trap. A French cook accused of being a spy was being flogged. The\nflogging was only just over, and the executioner was releasing from the\nflogging bench a stout man with red whiskers, in blue stockings and\na green jacket, who was moaning piteously. Another criminal, thin and\npale, stood near. Judging by their faces they were both Frenchmen. With\na frightened and suffering look resembling that on the thin Frenchman\xe2\x80\x99s\nface, Pierre pushed his way in through the crowd.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it? Who is it? What is it for?\xe2\x80\x9d he kept asking.\n\nBut the attention of the crowd\xe2\x80\x94officials, burghers, shopkeepers,\npeasants, and women in cloaks and in pelisses\xe2\x80\x94was so eagerly centered on\nwhat was passing in L\xc3\xb3bnoe Place that no one answered him. The stout man\nrose, frowned, shrugged his shoulders, and evidently trying to appear\nfirm began to pull on his jacket without looking about him, but suddenly\nhis lips trembled and he began to cry, in the way full-blooded grown-up\nmen cry, though angry with himself for doing so. In the crowd people\nbegan talking loudly, to stifle their feelings of pity as it seemed to\nPierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s cook to some prince.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, mounseer, Russian sauce seems to be sour to a Frenchman... sets his\nteeth on edge!\xe2\x80\x9d said a wrinkled clerk who was standing behind Pierre,\nwhen the Frenchman began to cry.\n\nThe clerk glanced round, evidently hoping that his joke would be\nappreciated. Some people began to laugh, others continued to watch in\ndismay the executioner who was undressing the other man.\n\nPierre choked, his face puckered, and he turned hastily away, went back\nto his trap muttering something to himself as he went, and took his\nseat. As they drove along he shuddered and exclaimed several times so\naudibly that the coachman asked him:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your pleasure?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Pierre to the man, who was driving to\nLuby\xc3\xa1nka Street.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the Governor\xe2\x80\x99s, as you ordered,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the coachman.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFool! Idiot!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Pierre, abusing his coachman\xe2\x80\x94a thing he rarely\ndid. \xe2\x80\x9cHome, I told you! And drive faster, blockhead!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI must get away\nthis very day,\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured to himself.\n\nAt the sight of the tortured Frenchman and the crowd surrounding the\nL\xc3\xb3bnoe Place, Pierre had so definitely made up his mind that he could no\nlonger remain in Moscow and would leave for the army that very day that\nit seemed to him that either he had told the coachman this or that the\nman ought to have known it for himself.\n\nOn reaching home Pierre gave orders to Evst\xc3\xa1fey\xe2\x80\x94his head coachman who\nknew everything, could do anything, and was known to all Moscow\xe2\x80\x94that\nhe would leave that night for the army at Mozh\xc3\xa1ysk, and that his saddle\nhorses should be sent there. This could not all be arranged that day,\nso on Evst\xc3\xa1fey\xe2\x80\x99s representation Pierre had to put off his departure till\nnext day to allow time for the relay horses to be sent on in advance.\n\nOn the twenty-fourth the weather cleared up after a spell of rain, and\nafter dinner Pierre left Moscow. When changing horses that night\nin Perkh\xc3\xbashkovo, he learned that there had been a great battle that\nevening. (This was the battle of Shev\xc3\xa1rdino.) He was told that there in\nPerkh\xc3\xbashkovo the earth trembled from the firing, but nobody could answer\nhis questions as to who had won. At dawn next day Pierre was approaching\nMozh\xc3\xa1ysk.\n\nEvery house in Mozh\xc3\xa1ysk had soldiers quartered in it, and at the hostel\nwhere Pierre was met by his groom and coachman there was no room to be\nhad. It was full of officers.\n\nEverywhere in Mozh\xc3\xa1ysk and beyond it, troops were stationed or on the\nmarch. Cossacks, foot and horse soldiers, wagons, caissons, and cannon\nwere everywhere. Pierre pushed forward as fast as he could, and the\nfarther he left Moscow behind and the deeper he plunged into that sea\nof troops the more was he overcome by restless agitation and a new and\njoyful feeling he had not experienced before. It was a feeling akin\nto what he had felt at the Slob\xc3\xb3da Palace during the Emperor\xe2\x80\x99s visit\xe2\x80\x94a\nsense of the necessity of undertaking something and sacrificing\nsomething. He now experienced a glad consciousness that everything that\nconstitutes men\xe2\x80\x99s happiness\xe2\x80\x94the comforts of life, wealth, even\nlife itself\xe2\x80\x94is rubbish it is pleasant to throw away, compared with\nsomething... With what? Pierre could not say, and he did not try to\ndetermine for whom and for what he felt such particular delight in\nsacrificing everything. He was not occupied with the question of what to\nsacrifice for; the fact of sacrificing in itself afforded him a new and\njoyous sensation.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIX\n\nOn the twenty-fourth of August the battle of the Shev\xc3\xa1rdino Redoubt was\nfought, on the twenty-fifth not a shot was fired by either side, and on\nthe twenty-sixth the battle of Borodin\xc3\xb3 itself took place.\n\nWhy and how were the battles of Shev\xc3\xa1rdino and Borodin\xc3\xb3 given and\naccepted? Why was the battle of Borodin\xc3\xb3 fought? There was not the least\nsense in it for either the French or the Russians. Its immediate result\nfor the Russians was, and was bound to be, that we were brought nearer\nto the destruction of Moscow\xe2\x80\x94which we feared more than anything in\nthe world; and for the French its immediate result was that they were\nbrought nearer to the destruction of their whole army\xe2\x80\x94which they feared\nmore than anything in the world. What the result must be was quite\nobvious, and yet Napoleon offered and Kut\xc3\xbazov accepted that battle.\n\nIf the commanders had been guided by reason, it would seem that it must\nhave been obvious to Napoleon that by advancing thirteen hundred miles\nand giving battle with a probability of losing a quarter of his army,\nhe was advancing to certain destruction, and it must have been equally\nclear to Kut\xc3\xbazov that by accepting battle and risking the loss of a\nquarter of his army he would certainly lose Moscow. For Kut\xc3\xbazov this was\nmathematically clear, as it is that if when playing draughts I have one\nman less and go on exchanging, I shall certainly lose, and therefore\nshould not exchange. When my opponent has sixteen men and I have\nfourteen, I am only one eighth weaker than he, but when I have exchanged\nthirteen more men he will be three times as strong as I am.\n\nBefore the battle of Borodin\xc3\xb3 our strength in proportion to the French\nwas about as five to six, but after that battle it was little more than\none to two: previously we had a hundred thousand against a hundred and\ntwenty thousand; afterwards little more than fifty thousand against a\nhundred thousand. Yet the shrewd and experienced Kut\xc3\xbazov accepted the\nbattle, while Napoleon, who was said to be a commander of genius,\ngave it, losing a quarter of his army and lengthening his lines of\ncommunication still more. If it is said that he expected to end the\ncampaign by occupying Moscow as he had ended a previous campaign by\noccupying Vienna, there is much evidence to the contrary. Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s\nhistorians themselves tell us that from Smol\xc3\xa9nsk onwards he wished\nto stop, knew the danger of his extended position, and knew that the\noccupation of Moscow would not be the end of the campaign, for he had\nseen at Smol\xc3\xa9nsk the state in which Russian towns were left to him, and\nhad not received a single reply to his repeated announcements of his\nwish to negotiate.\n\nIn giving and accepting battle at Borodin\xc3\xb3, Kut\xc3\xbazov acted involuntarily\nand irrationally. But later on, to fit what had occurred, the historians\nprovided cunningly devised evidence of the foresight and genius of the\ngenerals who, of all the blind tools of history were the most enslaved\nand involuntary.\n\nThe ancients have left us model heroic poems in which the heroes furnish\nthe whole interest of the story, and we are still unable to accustom\nourselves to the fact that for our epoch histories of that kind are\nmeaningless.\n\nOn the other question, how the battle of Borodin\xc3\xb3 and the preceding\nbattle of Shev\xc3\xa1rdino were fought, there also exists a definite and\nwell-known, but quite false, conception. All the historians describe the\naffair as follows:\n\nThe Russian army, they say, in its retreat from Smol\xc3\xa9nsk sought out\nfor itself the best position for a general engagement and found such a\nposition at Borodin\xc3\xb3.\n\nThe Russians, they say, fortified this position in advance on the left\nof the highroad (from Moscow to Smol\xc3\xa9nsk) and almost at a right angle\nto it, from Borodin\xc3\xb3 to Ut\xc3\xadtsa, at the very place where the battle was\nfought.\n\nIn front of this position, they say, a fortified outpost was set up on\nthe Shev\xc3\xa1rdino mound to observe the enemy. On the twenty-fourth, we\nare told, Napoleon attacked this advanced post and took it, and, on the\ntwenty-sixth, attacked the whole Russian army, which was in position on\nthe field of Borodin\xc3\xb3.\n\nSo the histories say, and it is all quite wrong, as anyone who cares to\nlook into the matter can easily convince himself.\n\nThe Russians did not seek out the best position but, on the contrary,\nduring the retreat passed many positions better than Borodin\xc3\xb3. They did\nnot stop at any one of these positions because Kut\xc3\xbazov did not wish to\noccupy a position he had not himself chosen, because the popular demand\nfor a battle had not yet expressed itself strongly enough, and because\nMilor\xc3\xa1dovich had not yet arrived with the militia, and for many other\nreasons. The fact is that other positions they had passed were stronger,\nand that the position at Borodin\xc3\xb3 (the one where the battle was fought),\nfar from being strong, was no more a position than any other spot one\nmight find in the Russian Empire by sticking a pin into the map at\nhazard.\n\nNot only did the Russians not fortify the position on the field of\nBorodin\xc3\xb3 to the left of, and at a right angle to, the highroad (that\nis, the position on which the battle took place), but never till the\ntwenty-fifth of August, 1812, did they think that a battle might be\nfought there. This was shown first by the fact that there were no\nentrenchments there by the twenty fifth and that those begun on the\ntwenty-fifth and twenty-sixth were not completed, and secondly, by the\nposition of the Shev\xc3\xa1rdino Redoubt. That redoubt was quite senseless\nin front of the position where the battle was accepted. Why was it\nmore strongly fortified than any other post? And why were all efforts\nexhausted and six thousand men sacrificed to defend it till late at\nnight on the twenty-fourth? A Cossack patrol would have sufficed to\nobserve the enemy. Thirdly, as proof that the position on which the\nbattle was fought had not been foreseen and that the Shev\xc3\xa1rdino Redoubt\nwas not an advanced post of that position, we have the fact that up to\nthe twenty-fifth, Barclay de Tolly and Bagrati\xc3\xb3n were convinced that the\nShev\xc3\xa1rdino Redoubt was the left flank of the position, and that Kut\xc3\xbazov\nhimself in his report, written in hot haste after the battle, speaks of\nthe Shev\xc3\xa1rdino Redoubt as the left flank of the position. It was much\nlater, when reports on the battle of Borodin\xc3\xb3 were written at leisure,\nthat the incorrect and extraordinary statement was invented (probably to\njustify the mistakes of a commander in chief who had to be represented\nas infallible) that the Shev\xc3\xa1rdino Redoubt was an advanced post\xe2\x80\x94whereas\nin reality it was simply a fortified point on the left flank\xe2\x80\x94and that\nthe battle of Borodin\xc3\xb3 was fought by us on an entrenched position\npreviously selected, whereas it was fought on a quite unexpected spot\nwhich was almost unentrenched.\n\nThe case was evidently this: a position was selected along the river\nKoloch\xc3\xa1\xe2\x80\x94which crosses the highroad not at a right angle but at an acute\nangle\xe2\x80\x94so that the left flank was at Shev\xc3\xa1rdino, the right flank near the\nvillage of N\xc3\xb3voe, and the center at Borodin\xc3\xb3 at the confluence of the\nrivers Koloch\xc3\xa1 and V\xc3\xb3yna.\n\nTo anyone who looks at the field of Borodin\xc3\xb3 without thinking of how\nthe battle was actually fought, this position, protected by the river\nKoloch\xc3\xa1, presents itself as obvious for an army whose object was to\nprevent an enemy from advancing along the Smol\xc3\xa9nsk road to Moscow.\n\nNapoleon, riding to Val\xc3\xbaevo on the twenty-fourth, did not see (as the\nhistory books say he did) the position of the Russians from Ut\xc3\xadtsa\nto Borodin\xc3\xb3 (he could not have seen that position because it did not\nexist), nor did he see an advanced post of the Russian army, but while\npursuing the Russian rearguard he came upon the left flank of the\nRussian position\xe2\x80\x94at the Shev\xc3\xa1rdino Redoubt\xe2\x80\x94and unexpectedly for the\nRussians moved his army across the Koloch\xc3\xa1. And the Russians, not having\ntime to begin a general engagement, withdrew their left wing from the\nposition they had intended to occupy and took up a new position which\nhad not been foreseen and was not fortified. By crossing to the other\nside of the Koloch\xc3\xa1 to the left of the highroad, Napoleon shifted the\nwhole forthcoming battle from right to left (looking from the Russian\nside) and transferred it to the plain between Ut\xc3\xadtsa, Sem\xc3\xabnovsk, and\nBorodin\xc3\xb3\xe2\x80\x94a plain no more advantageous as a position than any other plain\nin Russia\xe2\x80\x94and there the whole battle of the twenty-sixth of August took\nplace.\n\nHad Napoleon not ridden out on the evening of the twenty-fourth to the\nKoloch\xc3\xa1, and had he not then ordered an immediate attack on the redoubt\nbut had begun the attack next morning, no one would have doubted that\nthe Shev\xc3\xa1rdino Redoubt was the left flank of our position, and the\nbattle would have taken place where we expected it. In that case\nwe should probably have defended the Shev\xc3\xa1rdino Redoubt\xe2\x80\x94our left\nflank\xe2\x80\x94still more obstinately. We should have attacked Napoleon in the\ncenter or on the right, and the engagement would have taken place on the\ntwenty-fifth, in the position we intended and had fortified. But as the\nattack on our left flank took place in the evening after the retreat of\nour rear guard (that is, immediately after the fight at Gridn\xc3\xabva), and\nas the Russian commanders did not wish, or were not in time, to begin a\ngeneral engagement then on the evening of the twenty-fourth, the first\nand chief action of the battle of Borodin\xc3\xb3 was already lost on the\ntwenty-fourth, and obviously led to the loss of the one fought on the\ntwenty-sixth.\n\nAfter the loss of the Shev\xc3\xa1rdino Redoubt, we found ourselves on the\nmorning of the twenty-fifth without a position for our left flank, and\nwere forced to bend it back and hastily entrench it where it chanced to\nbe.\n\nNot only was the Russian army on the twenty-sixth defended by weak,\nunfinished entrenchments, but the disadvantage of that position was\nincreased by the fact that the Russian commanders\xe2\x80\x94not having fully\nrealized what had happened, namely the loss of our position on the left\nflank and the shifting of the whole field of the forthcoming battle from\nright to left\xe2\x80\x94maintained their extended position from the village of\nN\xc3\xb3voe to Ut\xc3\xadtsa, and consequently had to move their forces from right to\nleft during the battle. So it happened that throughout the whole battle\nthe Russians opposed the entire French army launched against our left\nflank with but half as many men. (Poniatowski\xe2\x80\x99s action against Ut\xc3\xadtsa,\nand Uv\xc3\xa1rov\xe2\x80\x99s on the right flank against the French, were actions\ndistinct from the main course of the battle.) So the battle of Borodin\xc3\xb3\ndid not take place at all as (in an effort to conceal our commanders\xe2\x80\x99\nmistakes even at the cost of diminishing the glory due to the Russian\narmy and people) it has been described. The battle of Borodin\xc3\xb3 was not\nfought on a chosen and entrenched position with forces only slightly\nweaker than those of the enemy, but, as a result of the loss of the\nShev\xc3\xa1rdino Redoubt, the Russians fought the battle of Borodin\xc3\xb3 on an\nopen and almost unentrenched position, with forces only half as numerous\nas the French; that is to say, under conditions in which it was not\nmerely unthinkable to fight for ten hours and secure an indecisive\nresult, but unthinkable to keep an army even from complete\ndisintegration and flight.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XX\n\nOn the morning of the twenty-fifth Pierre was leaving Mozh\xc3\xa1ysk. At the\ndescent of the high steep hill, down which a winding road led out of the\ntown past the cathedral on the right, where a service was being held and\nthe bells were ringing, Pierre got out of his vehicle and proceeded on\nfoot. Behind him a cavalry regiment was coming down the hill preceded by\nits singers. Coming up toward him was a train of carts carrying men who\nhad been wounded in the engagement the day before. The peasant drivers,\nshouting and lashing their horses, kept crossing from side to side. The\ncarts, in each of which three or four wounded soldiers were lying\nor sitting, jolted over the stones that had been thrown on the steep\nincline to make it something like a road. The wounded, bandaged with\nrags, with pale cheeks, compressed lips, and knitted brows, held on to\nthe sides of the carts as they were jolted against one another. Almost\nall of them stared with na\xc3\xafve, childlike curiosity at Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s white hat\nand green swallow-tail coat.\n\nPierre\xe2\x80\x99s coachman shouted angrily at the convoy of wounded to keep to\none side of the road. The cavalry regiment, as it descended the hill\nwith its singers, surrounded Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s carriage and blocked the road.\nPierre stopped, being pressed against the side of the cutting in which\nthe road ran. The sunshine from behind the hill did not penetrate into\nthe cutting and there it was cold and damp, but above Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s head was\nthe bright August sunshine and the bells sounded merrily. One of the\ncarts with wounded stopped by the side of the road close to Pierre. The\ndriver in his bast shoes ran panting up to it, placed a stone under one\nof its tireless hind wheels, and began arranging the breech-band on his\nlittle horse.\n\nOne of the wounded, an old soldier with a bandaged arm who was following\nthe cart on foot, caught hold of it with his sound hand and turned to\nlook at Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, fellow countryman! Will they set us down here or take us on to\nMoscow?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\n\nPierre was so deep in thought that he did not hear the question. He was\nlooking now at the cavalry regiment that had met the convoy of wounded,\nnow at the cart by which he was standing, in which two wounded men\nwere sitting and one was lying. One of those sitting up in the cart had\nprobably been wounded in the cheek. His whole head was wrapped in rags\nand one cheek was swollen to the size of a baby\xe2\x80\x99s head. His nose\nand mouth were twisted to one side. This soldier was looking at the\ncathedral and crossing himself. Another, a young lad, a fair-haired\nrecruit as white as though there was no blood in his thin face, looked\nat Pierre kindly, with a fixed smile. The third lay prone so that his\nface was not visible. The cavalry singers were passing close by:\n\n   Ah lost, quite lost... is my head so keen,\n   Living in a foreign land...\n\nthey sang their soldiers\xe2\x80\x99 dance song.\n\nAs if responding to them but with a different sort of merriment, the\nmetallic sound of the bells reverberated high above and the hot rays of\nthe sun bathed the top of the opposite slope with yet another sort of\nmerriment. But beneath the slope, by the cart with the wounded near the\npanting little nag where Pierre stood, it was damp, somber, and sad.\n\nThe soldier with the swollen cheek looked angrily at the cavalry\nsingers.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, the coxcombs!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered reproachfully.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not the soldiers only, but I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen peasants today, too....\nThe peasants\xe2\x80\x94even they have to go,\xe2\x80\x9d said the soldier behind the cart,\naddressing Pierre with a sad smile. \xe2\x80\x9cNo distinctions made nowadays....\nThey want the whole nation to fall on them\xe2\x80\x94in a word, it\xe2\x80\x99s Moscow! They\nwant to make an end of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIn spite of the obscurity of the soldier\xe2\x80\x99s words Pierre understood what\nhe wanted to say and nodded approval.\n\nThe road was clear again; Pierre descended the hill and drove on.\n\nHe kept looking to either side of the road for familiar faces, but only\nsaw everywhere the unfamiliar faces of various military men of different\nbranches of the service, who all looked with astonishment at his white\nhat and green tail coat.\n\nHaving gone nearly three miles he at last met an acquaintance and\neagerly addressed him. This was one of the head army doctors. He was\ndriving toward Pierre in a covered gig, sitting beside a young surgeon,\nand on recognizing Pierre he told the Cossack who occupied the driver\xe2\x80\x99s\nseat to pull up.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount! Your excellency, how come you to be here?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the doctor.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you know, I wanted to see...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, there will be something to see....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre got out and talked to the doctor, explaining his intention of\ntaking part in a battle.\n\nThe doctor advised him to apply direct to Kut\xc3\xbazov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should you be God knows where out of sight, during the battle?\xe2\x80\x9d he\nsaid, exchanging glances with his young companion. \xe2\x80\x9cAnyhow his Serene\nHighness knows you and will receive you graciously. That\xe2\x80\x99s what you must\ndo.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe doctor seemed tired and in a hurry.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think so?... Ah, I also wanted to ask you where our position is\nexactly?\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe position?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the doctor. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, that\xe2\x80\x99s not my line. Drive\npast Tat\xc3\xa1rinova, a lot of digging is going on there. Go up the hillock\nand you\xe2\x80\x99ll see.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan one see from there?... If you would...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBut the doctor interrupted him and moved toward his gig.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would go with you but on my honor I\xe2\x80\x99m up to here\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and he pointed to\nhis throat. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m galloping to the commander of the corps. How do matters\nstand?... You know, Count, there\xe2\x80\x99ll be a battle tomorrow. Out of an army\nof a hundred thousand we must expect at least twenty thousand wounded,\nand we haven\xe2\x80\x99t stretchers, or bunks, or dressers, or doctors enough for\nsix thousand. We have ten thousand carts, but we need other things as\nwell\xe2\x80\x94we must manage as best we can!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe strange thought that of the thousands of men, young and old, who\nhad stared with merry surprise at his hat (perhaps the very men he had\nnoticed), twenty thousand were inevitably doomed to wounds and death\namazed Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey may die tomorrow; why are they thinking of anything but death?\xe2\x80\x9d\nAnd by some latent sequence of thought the descent of the Mozh\xc3\xa1ysk hill,\nthe carts with the wounded, the ringing bells, the slanting rays of the\nsun, and the songs of the cavalrymen vividly recurred to his mind.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe cavalry ride to battle and meet the wounded and do not for a moment\nthink of what awaits them, but pass by, winking at the wounded. Yet from\namong these men twenty thousand are doomed to die, and they wonder at my\nhat! Strange!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Pierre, continuing his way to Tat\xc3\xa1rinova.\n\nIn front of a landowner\xe2\x80\x99s house to the left of the road stood carriages,\nwagons, and crowds of orderlies and sentinels. The commander in chief\nwas putting up there, but just when Pierre arrived he was not in and\nhardly any of the staff were there\xe2\x80\x94they had gone to the church service.\nPierre drove on toward G\xc3\xb3rki.\n\nWhen he had ascended the hill and reached the little village street, he\nsaw for the first time peasant militiamen in their white shirts and with\ncrosses on their caps, who, talking and laughing loudly, animated and\nperspiring, were at work on a huge knoll overgrown with grass to the\nright of the road.\n\nSome of them were digging, others were wheeling barrowloads of earth\nalong planks, while others stood about doing nothing.\n\nTwo officers were standing on the knoll, directing the men. On seeing\nthese peasants, who were evidently still amused by the novelty of their\nposition as soldiers, Pierre once more thought of the wounded men at\nMozh\xc3\xa1ysk and understood what the soldier had meant when he said: \xe2\x80\x9cThey\nwant the whole nation to fall on them.\xe2\x80\x9d The sight of these bearded\npeasants at work on the battlefield, with their queer, clumsy boots\nand perspiring necks, and their shirts opening from the left toward\nthe middle, unfastened, exposing their sunburned collarbones, impressed\nPierre more strongly with the solemnity and importance of the moment\nthan anything he had yet seen or heard.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XXI\n\nPierre stepped out of his carriage and, passing the toiling militiamen,\nascended the knoll from which, according to the doctor, the battlefield\ncould be seen.\n\nIt was about eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock. The sun shone somewhat to the left and\nbehind him and brightly lit up the enormous panorama which, rising like\nan amphitheater, extended before him in the clear rarefied atmosphere.\n\nFrom above on the left, bisecting that amphitheater, wound the Smol\xc3\xa9nsk\nhighroad, passing through a village with a white church some five\nhundred paces in front of the knoll and below it. This was Borodin\xc3\xb3.\nBelow the village the road crossed the river by a bridge and, winding\ndown and up, rose higher and higher to the village of Val\xc3\xbaevo visible\nabout four miles away, where Napoleon was then stationed. Beyond Val\xc3\xbaevo\nthe road disappeared into a yellowing forest on the horizon. Far in\nthe distance in that birch and fir forest to the right of the road, the\ncross and belfry of the Koloch\xc3\xa1 Monastery gleamed in the sun. Here and\nthere over the whole of that blue expanse, to right and left of the\nforest and the road, smoking campfires could be seen and indefinite\nmasses of troops\xe2\x80\x94ours and the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s. The ground to the right\xe2\x80\x94along the\ncourse of the Koloch\xc3\xa1 and Moskv\xc3\xa1 rivers\xe2\x80\x94was broken and hilly. Between\nthe hollows the villages of Bez\xc3\xbabova and Zakh\xc3\xa1rino showed in the\ndistance. On the left the ground was more level; there were fields of\ngrain, and the smoking ruins of Sem\xc3\xabnovsk, which had been burned down,\ncould be seen.\n\nAll that Pierre saw was so indefinite that neither the left nor the\nright side of the field fully satisfied his expectations. Nowhere\ncould he see the battlefield he had expected to find, but only fields,\nmeadows, troops, woods, the smoke of campfires, villages, mounds, and\nstreams; and try as he would he could descry no military \xe2\x80\x9cposition\xe2\x80\x9d in\nthis place which teemed with life, nor could he even distinguish our\ntroops from the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must ask someone who knows,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, and addressed an officer who\nwas looking with curiosity at his huge unmilitary figure.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I ask you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat village that is in front?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cB\xc3\xbardino, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer, turning to his companion.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBorodin\xc3\xb3,\xe2\x80\x9d the other corrected him.\n\nThe officer, evidently glad of an opportunity for a talk, moved up to\nPierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre those our men there?\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre inquired.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and there, further on, are the French,\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\nthey are, there... you can see them.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere? Where?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne can see them with the naked eye... Why, there!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe officer pointed with his hand to the smoke visible on the left\nbeyond the river, and the same stern and serious expression that Pierre\nhad noticed on many of the faces he had met came into his face.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, those are the French! And over there?...\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre pointed to a knoll\non the left, near which some troops could be seen.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose are ours.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ours! And there?...\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre pointed to another knoll in the\ndistance with a big tree on it, near a village that lay in a hollow\nwhere also some campfires were smoking and something black was visible.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s his again,\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer. (It was the Shev\xc3\xa1rdino Redoubt.)\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was ours yesterday, but now it is his.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen how about our position?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur position?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the officer with a smile of satisfaction. \xe2\x80\x9cI\ncan tell you quite clearly, because I constructed nearly all our\nentrenchments. There, you see? There\xe2\x80\x99s our center, at Borodin\xc3\xb3, just\nthere,\xe2\x80\x9d and he pointed to the village in front of them with the white\nchurch. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s where one crosses the Koloch\xc3\xa1. You see down there where\nthe rows of hay are lying in the hollow, there\xe2\x80\x99s the bridge. That\xe2\x80\x99s our\ncenter. Our right flank is over there\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he pointed sharply to the right,\nfar away in the broken ground\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s where the Moskv\xc3\xa1 River is, and\nwe have thrown up three redoubts there, very strong ones. The left\nflank...\xe2\x80\x9d here the officer paused. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, you see, that\xe2\x80\x99s difficult to\nexplain.... Yesterday our left flank was there at Shev\xc3\xa1rdino, you see,\nwhere the oak is, but now we have withdrawn our left wing\xe2\x80\x94now it is over\nthere, do you see that village and the smoke? That\xe2\x80\x99s Sem\xc3\xabnovsk, yes,\nthere,\xe2\x80\x9d he pointed to Ra\xc3\xa9vski\xe2\x80\x99s knoll. \xe2\x80\x9cBut the battle will hardly\nbe there. His having moved his troops there is only a ruse; he will\nprobably pass round to the right of the Moskv\xc3\xa1. But wherever it may be,\nmany a man will be missing tomorrow!\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked.\n\nAn elderly sergeant who had approached the officer while he was giving\nthese explanations had waited in silence for him to finish speaking, but\nat this point, evidently not liking the officer\xe2\x80\x99s remark, interrupted\nhim.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGabions must be sent for,\xe2\x80\x9d said he sternly.\n\nThe officer appeared abashed, as though he understood that one might\nthink of how many men would be missing tomorrow but ought not to speak\nof it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, send number three company again,\xe2\x80\x9d the officer replied hurriedly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, are you one of the doctors?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I\xe2\x80\x99ve come on my own,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pierre, and he went down the hill\nagain, passing the militiamen.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, those damned fellows!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the officer who followed him,\nholding his nose as he ran past the men at work.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere they are... bringing her, coming... There they are... They\xe2\x80\x99ll be\nhere in a minute...\xe2\x80\x9d voices were suddenly heard saying; and officers,\nsoldiers, and militiamen began running forward along the road.\n\nA church procession was coming up the hill from Borodin\xc3\xb3. First along\nthe dusty road came the infantry in ranks, bareheaded and with arms\nreversed. From behind them came the sound of church singing.\n\nSoldiers and militiamen ran bareheaded past Pierre toward the\nprocession.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are bringing her, our Protectress!... The Iberian Mother of God!\xe2\x80\x9d\nsomeone cried.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Smol\xc3\xa9nsk Mother of God,\xe2\x80\x9d another corrected him.\n\nThe militiamen, both those who had been in the village and those who had\nbeen at work on the battery, threw down their spades and ran to meet the\nchurch procession. Following the battalion that marched along the dusty\nroad came priests in their vestments\xe2\x80\x94one little old man in a hood with\nattendants and singers. Behind them soldiers and officers bore a large,\ndark-faced icon with an embossed metal cover. This was the icon that had\nbeen brought from Smol\xc3\xa9nsk and had since accompanied the army. Behind,\nbefore, and on both sides, crowds of militiamen with bared heads walked,\nran, and bowed to the ground.\n\nAt the summit of the hill they stopped with the icon; the men who had\nbeen holding it up by the linen bands attached to it were relieved by\nothers, the chanters relit their censers, and service began. The hot\nrays of the sun beat down vertically and a fresh soft wind played with\nthe hair of the bared heads and with the ribbons decorating the icon.\nThe singing did not sound loud under the open sky. An immense crowd\nof bareheaded officers, soldiers, and militiamen surrounded the icon.\nBehind the priest and a chanter stood the notabilities on a spot\nreserved for them. A bald general with a St. George\xe2\x80\x99s Cross on his neck\nstood just behind the priest\xe2\x80\x99s back, and without crossing himself (he\nwas evidently a German) patiently awaited the end of the service, which\nhe considered it necessary to hear to the end, probably to arouse the\npatriotism of the Russian people. Another general stood in a martial\npose, crossing himself by shaking his hand in front of his chest\nwhile looking about him. Standing among the crowd of peasants, Pierre\nrecognized several acquaintances among these notables, but did not\nlook at them\xe2\x80\x94his whole attention was absorbed in watching the serious\nexpression on the faces of the crowd of soldiers and militiamen who were\nall gazing eagerly at the icon. As soon as the tired chanters, who were\nsinging the service for the twentieth time that day, began lazily and\nmechanically to sing: \xe2\x80\x9cSave from calamity Thy servants, O Mother of\nGod,\xe2\x80\x9d and the priest and deacon chimed in: \xe2\x80\x9cFor to Thee under God we all\nflee as to an inviolable bulwark and protection,\xe2\x80\x9d there again kindled in\nall those faces the same expression of consciousness of the solemnity\nof the impending moment that Pierre had seen on the faces at the foot of\nthe hill at Mozh\xc3\xa1ysk and momentarily on many and many faces he had met\nthat morning; and heads were bowed more frequently and hair tossed back,\nand sighs and the sound men made as they crossed themselves were heard.\n\nThe crowd round the icon suddenly parted and pressed against Pierre.\nSomeone, a very important personage judging by the haste with which way\nwas made for him, was approaching the icon.\n\nIt was Kut\xc3\xbazov, who had been riding round the position and on his way\nback to Tat\xc3\xa1rinova had stopped where the service was being held. Pierre\nrecognized him at once by his peculiar figure, which distinguished him\nfrom everybody else.\n\nWith a long overcoat on his exceedingly stout, round-shouldered body,\nwith uncovered white head and puffy face showing the white ball of the\neye he had lost, Kut\xc3\xbazov walked with plunging, swaying gait into\nthe crowd and stopped behind the priest. He crossed himself with an\naccustomed movement, bent till he touched the ground with his hand, and\nbowed his white head with a deep sigh. Behind Kut\xc3\xbazov was Bennigsen and\nthe suite. Despite the presence of the commander in chief, who attracted\nthe attention of all the superior officers, the militiamen and soldiers\ncontinued their prayers without looking at him.\n\nWhen the service was over, Kut\xc3\xbazov stepped up to the icon, sank heavily\nto his knees, bowed to the ground, and for a long time tried vainly to\nrise, but could not do so on account of his weakness and weight. His\nwhite head twitched with the effort. At last he rose, kissed the icon as\na child does with na\xc3\xafvely pouting lips, and again bowed till he touched\nthe ground with his hand. The other generals followed his example,\nthen the officers, and after them with excited faces, pressing on one\nanother, crowding, panting, and pushing, scrambled the soldiers and\nmilitiamen.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XXII\n\nStaggering amid the crush, Pierre looked about him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount Peter Kir\xc3\xadlovich! How did you get here?\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice.\n\nPierre looked round. Bor\xc3\xads Drubetsk\xc3\xb3y, brushing his knees with his hand\n(he had probably soiled them when he, too, had knelt before the icon),\ncame up to him smiling. Bor\xc3\xads was elegantly dressed, with a slightly\nmartial touch appropriate to a campaign. He wore a long coat and like\nKut\xc3\xbazov had a whip slung across his shoulder.\n\nMeanwhile Kut\xc3\xbazov had reached the village and seated himself in the\nshade of the nearest house, on a bench which one Cossack had run\nto fetch and another had hastily covered with a rug. An immense and\nbrilliant suite surrounded him.\n\nThe icon was carried further, accompanied by the throng.
