He asked one, \xe2\x80\x98From whom did you get it?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98From\nso-and-so.\xe2\x80\x99 He went to the next one. \xe2\x80\x98From whom did you get it?\xe2\x80\x99 and so\non till he reached Vereshch\xc3\xa1gin, a half educated tradesman, you know, \xe2\x80\x98a\npet of a trader,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said the adjutant smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cThey asked him, \xe2\x80\x98Who gave\nit you?\xe2\x80\x99 And the point is that we knew whom he had it from. He could\nonly have had it from the Postmaster. But evidently they had come to\nsome understanding. He replied: \xe2\x80\x98From no one; I made it up myself.\xe2\x80\x99\nThey threatened and questioned him, but he stuck to that: \xe2\x80\x98I made it\nup myself.\xe2\x80\x99 And so it was reported to the count, who sent for the man.\n\xe2\x80\x98From whom did you get the proclamation?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98I wrote it myself.\xe2\x80\x99 Well, you\nknow the count,\xe2\x80\x9d said the adjutant cheerfully, with a smile of pride,\n\xe2\x80\x9che flared up dreadfully\xe2\x80\x94and just think of the fellow\xe2\x80\x99s audacity, lying,\nand obstinacy!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the count wanted him to say it was from Klyuchar\xc3\xabv? I understand!\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the adjutant in dismay. \xe2\x80\x9cKlyuchar\xc3\xabv had his own\nsins to answer for without that and that is why he has been banished.\nBut the point is that the count was much annoyed. \xe2\x80\x98How could you have\nwritten it yourself?\xe2\x80\x99 said he, and he took up the Hamburg Gazette that\nwas lying on the table. \xe2\x80\x98Here it is! You did not write it yourself but\ntranslated it, and translated it abominably, because you don\xe2\x80\x99t even know\nFrench, you fool.\xe2\x80\x99 And what do you think? \xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98I have not\nread any papers, I made it up myself.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98If that\xe2\x80\x99s so, you\xe2\x80\x99re a traitor\nand I\xe2\x80\x99ll have you tried, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll be hanged! Say from whom you had\nit.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98I have seen no papers, I made it up myself.\xe2\x80\x99 And that was the end\nof it. The count had the father fetched, but the fellow stuck to it.\nHe was sent for trial and condemned to hard labor, I believe. Now the\nfather has come to intercede for him. But he\xe2\x80\x99s a good-for-nothing lad!\nYou know that sort of tradesman\xe2\x80\x99s son, a dandy and lady-killer. He\nattended some lectures somewhere and imagines that the devil is no match\nfor him. That\xe2\x80\x99s the sort of fellow he is. His father keeps a cookshop\nhere by the Stone Bridge, and you know there was a large icon of God\nAlmighty painted with a scepter in one hand and an orb in the other.\nWell, he took that icon home with him for a few days and what did he do?\nHe found some scoundrel of a painter...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XI\n\nIn the middle of this fresh tale Pierre was summoned to the commander in\nchief.\n\nWhen he entered the private room Count Rostopch\xc3\xadn, puckering his face,\nwas rubbing his forehead and eyes with his hand. A short man was saying\nsomething, but when Pierre entered he stopped speaking and went out.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, how do you do, great warrior?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rostopch\xc3\xadn as soon as the short\nman had left the room. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have heard of your prowess. But that\xe2\x80\x99s not\nthe point. Between ourselves, mon cher, do you belong to the Masons?\xe2\x80\x9d he\nwent on severely, as though there were something wrong about it which\nhe nevertheless intended to pardon. Pierre remained silent. \xe2\x80\x9cI am well\ninformed, my friend, but I am aware that there are Masons and I hope\nthat you are not one of those who on pretense of saving mankind wish to\nruin Russia.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I am a Mason,\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre replied.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, you see, mon cher! I expect you know that Messrs. Sper\xc3\xa1nski and\nMagn\xc3\xadtski have been deported to their proper place. Mr. Klyuchar\xc3\xabv has\nbeen treated in the same way, and so have others who on the plea of\nbuilding up the temple of Solomon have tried to destroy the temple of\ntheir fatherland. You can understand that there are reasons for this and\nthat I could not have exiled the Postmaster had he not been a harmful\nperson. It has now come to my knowledge that you lent him your carriage\nfor his removal from town, and that you have even accepted papers from\nhim for safe custody. I like you and don\xe2\x80\x99t wish you any harm and\xe2\x80\x94as\nyou are only half my age\xe2\x80\x94I advise you, as a father would, to cease\nall communication with men of that stamp and to leave here as soon as\npossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what did Klyuchar\xc3\xabv do wrong, Count?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is for me to know, but not for you to ask,\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Rostopch\xc3\xadn.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he is accused of circulating Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s proclamation it is not\nproved that he did so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre without looking at Rostopch\xc3\xadn, \xe2\x80\x9cand\nVereshch\xc3\xa1gin...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere we are!\xe2\x80\x9d Rostopch\xc3\xadn shouted at Pierre louder than before,\nfrowning suddenly. \xe2\x80\x9cVereshch\xc3\xa1gin is a renegade and a traitor who will\nbe punished as he deserves,\xe2\x80\x9d said he with the vindictive heat with which\npeople speak when recalling an insult. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I did not summon you to\ndiscuss my actions, but to give you advice\xe2\x80\x94or an order if you prefer it.\nI beg you to leave the town and break off all communication with such\nmen as Klyuchar\xc3\xabv. And I will knock the nonsense out of anybody\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94but\nprobably realizing that he was shouting at Bez\xc3\xbakhov who so far was not\nguilty of anything, he added, taking Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s hand in a friendly manner,\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are on the eve of a public disaster and I haven\xe2\x80\x99t time to be polite\nto everybody who has business with me. My head is sometimes in a whirl.\nWell, mon cher, what are you doing personally?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Pierre without raising his eyes or changing the\nthoughtful expression of his face.\n\nThe count frowned.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA word of friendly advice, mon cher. Be off as soon as you can, that\xe2\x80\x99s\nall I have to tell you. Happy he who has ears to hear. Good-by, my dear\nfellow. Oh, by the by!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted through the doorway after Pierre,\n\xe2\x80\x9cis it true that the countess has fallen into the clutches of the holy\nfathers of the Society of Jesus?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre did not answer and left Rostopch\xc3\xadn\xe2\x80\x99s room more sullen and angry\nthan he had ever before shown himself.\n\nWhen he reached home it was already getting dark. Some eight people had\ncome to see him that evening: the secretary of a committee, the colonel\nof his battalion, his steward, his major-domo, and various petitioners.\nThey all had business with Pierre and wanted decisions from him. Pierre\ndid not understand and was not interested in any of these questions and\nonly answered them in order to get rid of these people. When left alone\nat last he opened and read his wife\xe2\x80\x99s letter.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey, the soldiers at the battery, Prince Andrew killed... that old\nman... Simplicity is submission to God. Suffering is necessary... the\nmeaning of all... one must harness... my wife is getting married... One\nmust forget and understand...\xe2\x80\x9d And going to his bed he threw himself on\nit without undressing and immediately fell asleep.\n\nWhen he awoke next morning the major-domo came to inform him that a\nspecial messenger, a police officer, had come from Count Rostopch\xc3\xadn to\nknow whether Count Bez\xc3\xbakhov had left or was leaving the town.\n\nA dozen persons who had business with Pierre were awaiting him in the\ndrawing room. Pierre dressed hurriedly and, instead of going to see\nthem, went to the back porch and out through the gate.\n\nFrom that time till the end of the destruction of Moscow no one of\nBez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s household, despite all the search they made, saw Pierre again\nor knew where he was.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XII\n\nThe Rost\xc3\xb3vs remained in Moscow till the first of September, that is,\ntill the eve of the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s entry into the city.\n\nAfter P\xc3\xa9tya had joined Obol\xc3\xa9nski\xe2\x80\x99s regiment of Cossacks and left for\nB\xc3\xa9laya Ts\xc3\xa9rkov where that regiment was forming, the countess was seized\nwith terror. The thought that both her sons were at the war, had both\ngone from under her wing, that today or tomorrow either or both of them\nmight be killed like the three sons of one of her acquaintances, struck\nher that summer for the first time with cruel clearness. She tried to\nget Nicholas back and wished to go herself to join P\xc3\xa9tya, or to get\nhim an appointment somewhere in Petersburg, but neither of these proved\npossible. P\xc3\xa9tya could not return unless his regiment did so or unless\nhe was transferred to another regiment on active service. Nicholas was\nsomewhere with the army and had not sent a word since his last letter,\nin which he had given a detailed account of his meeting with Princess\nMary. The countess did not sleep at night, or when she did fall asleep\ndreamed that she saw her sons lying dead. After many consultations and\nconversations, the count at last devised means to tranquillize her. He\ngot P\xc3\xa9tya transferred from Obol\xc3\xa9nski\xe2\x80\x99s regiment to Bez\xc3\xbakhov\xe2\x80\x99s, which was\nin training near Moscow. Though P\xc3\xa9tya would remain in the service, this\ntransfer would give the countess the consolation of seeing at least one\nof her sons under her wing, and she hoped to arrange matters for her\nP\xc3\xa9tya so as not to let him go again, but always get him appointed to\nplaces where he could not possibly take part in a battle. As long as\nNicholas alone was in danger the countess imagined that she loved her\nfirst-born more than all her other children and even reproached herself\nfor it; but when her youngest: the scapegrace who had been bad at\nlessons, was always breaking things in the house and making himself a\nnuisance to everybody, that snub-nosed P\xc3\xa9tya with his merry black eyes\nand fresh rosy cheeks where soft down was just beginning to show\xe2\x80\x94when\nhe was thrown amid those big, dreadful, cruel men who were fighting\nsomewhere about something and apparently finding pleasure in it\xe2\x80\x94then\nhis mother thought she loved him more, much more, than all her other\nchildren. The nearer the time came for P\xc3\xa9tya to return, the more uneasy\ngrew the countess. She began to think she would never live to see such\nhappiness. The presence of S\xc3\xb3nya, of her beloved Nat\xc3\xa1sha, or even of\nher husband irritated her. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do I want with them? I want no one but\nP\xc3\xa9tya,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought.\n\nAt the end of August the Rost\xc3\xb3vs received another letter from Nicholas.\nHe wrote from the province of Vor\xc3\xb3nezh where he had been sent to procure\nremounts, but that letter did not set the countess at ease. Knowing that\none son was out of danger she became the more anxious about P\xc3\xa9tya.\n\nThough by the twentieth of August nearly all the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 acquaintances\nhad left Moscow, and though everybody tried to persuade the countess to\nget away as quickly as possible, she would not hear of leaving before\nher treasure, her adored P\xc3\xa9tya, returned. On the twenty-eighth of August\nhe arrived. The passionate tenderness with which his mother received him\ndid not please the sixteen-year-old officer. Though she concealed from\nhim her intention of keeping him under her wing, P\xc3\xa9tya guessed her\ndesigns, and instinctively fearing that he might give way to emotion\nwhen with her\xe2\x80\x94might \xe2\x80\x9cbecome womanish\xe2\x80\x9d as he termed it to himself\xe2\x80\x94he\ntreated her coldly, avoided her, and during his stay in Moscow attached\nhimself exclusively to Nat\xc3\xa1sha for whom he had always had a particularly\nbrotherly tenderness, almost lover-like.\n\nOwing to the count\xe2\x80\x99s customary carelessness nothing was ready for their\ndeparture by the twenty-eighth of August and the carts that were to\ncome from their Ryaz\xc3\xa1n and Moscow estates to remove their household\nbelongings did not arrive till the thirtieth.\n\nFrom the twenty-eighth till the thirty-first all Moscow was in a bustle\nand commotion. Every day thousands of men wounded at Borodin\xc3\xb3 were\nbrought in by the Dorogom\xc3\xadlov gate and taken to various parts of Moscow,\nand thousands of carts conveyed the inhabitants and their possessions\nout by the other gates. In spite of Rostopch\xc3\xadn\xe2\x80\x99s broadsheets, or because\nof them or independently of them, the strangest and most contradictory\nrumors were current in the town. Some said that no one was to be allowed\nto leave the city, others on the contrary said that all the icons had\nbeen taken out of the churches and everybody was to be ordered to leave.\nSome said there had been another battle after Borodin\xc3\xb3 at which the\nFrench had been routed, while others on the contrary reported that the\nRussian army had been destroyed. Some talked about the Moscow militia\nwhich, preceded by the clergy, would go to the Three Hills; others\nwhispered that Augustin had been forbidden to leave, that traitors had\nbeen seized, that the peasants were rioting and robbing people on their\nway from Moscow, and so on. But all this was only talk; in reality\n(though the Council of Fil\xc3\xad, at which it was decided to abandon Moscow,\nhad not yet been held) both those who went away and those who remained\nbehind felt, though they did not show it, that Moscow would certainly\nbe abandoned, and that they ought to get away as quickly as possible and\nsave their belongings. It was felt that everything would suddenly break\nup and change, but up to the first of September nothing had done so.\nAs a criminal who is being led to execution knows that he must die\nimmediately, but yet looks about him and straightens the cap that is\nawry on his head, so Moscow involuntarily continued its wonted life,\nthough it knew that the time of its destruction was near when the\nconditions of life to which its people were accustomed to submit would\nbe completely upset.\n\nDuring the three days preceding the occupation of Moscow the whole\nRost\xc3\xb3v family was absorbed in various activities. The head of the\nfamily, Count Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v, continually drove about the city collecting\nthe current rumors from all sides and gave superficial and hasty orders\nat home about the preparations for their departure.\n\nThe countess watched the things being packed, was dissatisfied with\neverything, was constantly in pursuit of P\xc3\xa9tya who was always running\naway from her, and was jealous of Nat\xc3\xa1sha with whom he spent all his\ntime. S\xc3\xb3nya alone directed the practical side of matters by getting\nthings packed. But of late S\xc3\xb3nya had been particularly sad and silent.\nNicholas\xe2\x80\x99 letter in which he mentioned Princess Mary had elicited, in\nher presence, joyous comments from the countess, who saw an intervention\nof Providence in this meeting of the princess and Nicholas.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was never pleased at Bolk\xc3\xb3nski\xe2\x80\x99s engagement to Nat\xc3\xa1sha,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\ncountess, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I always wanted Nicholas to marry the princess, and had a\npresentiment that it would happen. What a good thing it would be!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya felt that this was true: that the only possibility of retrieving\nthe Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 affairs was by Nicholas marrying a rich woman, and that the\nprincess was a good match. It was very bitter for her. But despite\nher grief, or perhaps just because of it, she took on herself all the\ndifficult work of directing the storing and packing of their things and\nwas busy for whole days. The count and countess turned to her when they\nhad any orders to give. P\xc3\xa9tya and Nat\xc3\xa1sha on the contrary, far from\nhelping their parents, were generally a nuisance and a hindrance to\neveryone. Almost all day long the house resounded with their running\nfeet, their cries, and their spontaneous laughter. They laughed and were\ngay not because there was any reason to laugh, but because gaiety and\nmirth were in their hearts and so everything that happened was a cause\nfor gaiety and laughter to them. P\xc3\xa9tya was in high spirits because\nhaving left home a boy he had returned (as everybody told him) a fine\nyoung man, because he was at home, because he had left B\xc3\xa9laya Ts\xc3\xa9rkov\nwhere there was no hope of soon taking part in a battle and had come to\nMoscow where there was to be fighting in a few days, and chiefly because\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, whose lead he always followed, was in high spirits. Nat\xc3\xa1sha was\ngay because she had been sad too long and now nothing reminded her of\nthe cause of her sadness, and because she was feeling well. She was also\nhappy because she had someone to adore her: the adoration of others was\na lubricant the wheels of her machine needed to make them run freely\xe2\x80\x94and\nP\xc3\xa9tya adored her. Above all, they were gay because there was a war near\nMoscow, there would be fighting at the town gates, arms were being\ngiven out, everybody was escaping\xe2\x80\x94going away somewhere, and in general\nsomething extraordinary was happening, and that is always exciting,\nespecially to the young.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIII\n\nOn Saturday, the thirty-first of August, everything in the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99\nhouse seemed topsy-turvy. All the doors were open, all the furniture was\nbeing carried out or moved about, and the mirrors and pictures had been\ntaken down. There were trunks in the rooms, and hay, wrapping paper, and\nropes were scattered about. The peasants and house serfs carrying out\nthe things were treading heavily on the parquet floors. The yard was\ncrowded with peasant carts, some loaded high and already corded up,\nothers still empty.\n\nThe voices and footsteps of the many servants and of the peasants who\nhad come with the carts resounded as they shouted to one another in\nthe yard and in the house. The count had been out since morning. The\ncountess had a headache brought on by all the noise and turmoil and was\nlying down in the new sitting room with a vinegar compress on her head.\nP\xc3\xa9tya was not at home, he had gone to visit a friend with whom he meant\nto obtain a transfer from the militia to the active army. S\xc3\xb3nya was in\nthe ballroom looking after the packing of the glass and china. Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nwas sitting on the floor of her dismantled room with dresses, ribbons,\nand scarves strewn all about her, gazing fixedly at the floor and\nholding in her hands the old ball dress (already out of fashion) which\nshe had worn at her first Petersburg ball.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha was ashamed of doing nothing when everyone else was so busy, and\nseveral times that morning had tried to set to work, but her heart was\nnot in it, and she could not and did not know how to do anything except\nwith all her heart and all her might. For a while she had stood beside\nS\xc3\xb3nya while the china was being packed and tried to help, but soon gave\nit up and went to her room to pack her own things. At first she found it\namusing to give away dresses and ribbons to the maids, but when that was\ndone and what was left had still to be packed, she found it dull.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDuny\xc3\xa1sha, you pack! You will, won\xe2\x80\x99t you, dear?\xe2\x80\x9d And when Duny\xc3\xa1sha\nwillingly promised to do it all for her, Nat\xc3\xa1sha sat down on the floor,\ntook her old ball dress, and fell into a reverie quite unrelated to what\nought to have occupied her thoughts now. She was roused from her reverie\nby the talk of the maids in the next room (which was theirs) and by the\nsound of their hurried footsteps going to the back porch. Nat\xc3\xa1sha got\nup and looked out of the window. An enormously long row of carts full of\nwounded men had stopped in the street.\n\nThe housekeeper, the old nurse, the cooks, coachmen, maids, footmen,\npostilions, and scullions stood at the gate, staring at the wounded.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha, throwing a clean pocket handkerchief over her hair and holding\nan end of it in each hand, went out into the street.\n\nThe former housekeeper, old M\xc3\xa1vra Kuzm\xc3\xadnichna, had stepped out of the\ncrowd by the gate, gone up to a cart with a hood constructed of bast\nmats, and was speaking to a pale young officer who lay inside.\nNat\xc3\xa1sha moved a few steps forward and stopped shyly, still holding her\nhandkerchief, and listened to what the housekeeper was saying.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you have nobody in Moscow?\xe2\x80\x9d she was saying. \xe2\x80\x9cYou would be more\ncomfortable somewhere in a house... in ours, for instance... the family\nare leaving.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know if it would be allowed,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the officer in a weak\nvoice. \xe2\x80\x9cHere is our commanding officer... ask him,\xe2\x80\x9d and he pointed to a\nstout major who was walking back along the street past the row of carts.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha glanced with frightened eyes at the face of the wounded officer\nand at once went to meet the major.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay the wounded men stay in our house?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\n\nThe major raised his hand to his cap with a smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich one do you want, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am\xe2\x80\x99selle?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, screwing up his eyes and\nsmiling.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha quietly repeated her question, and her face and whole\nmanner were so serious, though she was still holding the ends of her\nhandkerchief, that the major ceased smiling and after some reflection\xe2\x80\x94as\nif considering in how far the thing was possible\xe2\x80\x94replied in the\naffirmative.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, why not? They may,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\n\nWith a slight inclination of her head, Nat\xc3\xa1sha stepped back quickly to\nM\xc3\xa1vra Kuzm\xc3\xadnichna, who stood talking compassionately to the officer.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey may. He says they may!\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\nThe cart in which the officer lay was turned into the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 yard,\nand dozens of carts with wounded men began at the invitation of the\ntownsfolk to turn into the yards and to draw up at the entrances of the\nhouses in Povarsk\xc3\xa1ya Street. Nat\xc3\xa1sha was evidently pleased to be dealing\nwith new people outside the ordinary routine of her life. She and M\xc3\xa1vra\nKuzm\xc3\xadnichna tried to get as many of the wounded as possible into their\nyard.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Papa must be told, though,\xe2\x80\x9d said M\xc3\xa1vra Kuzm\xc3\xadnichna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind, never mind, what does it matter? For one day we can move\ninto the drawing room. They can have all our half of the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere now, young lady, you do take things into your head! Even if we\nput them into the wing, the men\xe2\x80\x99s room, or the nurse\xe2\x80\x99s room, we must ask\npermission.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ll ask.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha ran into the house and went on tiptoe through the half-open door\ninto the sitting room, where there was a smell of vinegar and Hoffman\xe2\x80\x99s\ndrops.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you asleep, Mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, what sleep\xe2\x80\x94?\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, waking up just as she was dropping\ninto a doze.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma darling!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha, kneeling by her mother and bringing her\nface close to her mother\xe2\x80\x99s, \xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry, forgive me, I\xe2\x80\x99ll never do it\nagain; I woke you up! M\xc3\xa1vra Kuzm\xc3\xadnichna has sent me: they have brought\nsome wounded here\xe2\x80\x94officers. Will you let them come? They have nowhere to\ngo. I knew you\xe2\x80\x99d let them come!\xe2\x80\x9d she said quickly all in one breath.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat officers? Whom have they brought? I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand anything\nabout it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha laughed, and the countess too smiled slightly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew you\xe2\x80\x99d give permission... so I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell them,\xe2\x80\x9d and, having kissed\nher mother, Nat\xc3\xa1sha got up and went to the door.\n\nIn the hall she met her father, who had returned with bad news.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve stayed too long!\xe2\x80\x9d said the count with involuntary vexation. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\nClub is closed and the police are leaving.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa, is it all right\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve invited some of the wounded into the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course it is,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered absently. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s not the point. I beg\nyou not to indulge in trifles now, but to help to pack, and tomorrow we\nmust go, go, go!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd the count gave a similar order to the major-domo and the servants.\n\nAt dinner P\xc3\xa9tya having returned home told them the news he had heard.\nHe said the people had been getting arms in the Kr\xc3\xa9mlin, and that though\nRostopch\xc3\xadn\xe2\x80\x99s broadsheet had said that he would sound a call two or three\ndays in advance, the order had certainly already been given for everyone\nto go armed to the Three Hills tomorrow, and that there would be a big\nbattle there.\n\nThe countess looked with timid horror at her son\xe2\x80\x99s eager, excited face\nas he said this. She realized that if she said a word about his not\ngoing to the battle (she knew he enjoyed the thought of the impending\nengagement) he would say something about men, honor, and the\nfatherland\xe2\x80\x94something senseless, masculine, and obstinate which there\nwould be no contradicting, and her plans would be spoiled; and so,\nhoping to arrange to leave before then and take P\xc3\xa9tya with her as their\nprotector and defender, she did not answer him, but after dinner called\nthe count aside and implored him with tears to take her away quickly,\nthat very night if possible. With a woman\xe2\x80\x99s involuntary loving cunning\nshe, who till then had not shown any alarm, said that she would die of\nfright if they did not leave that very night. Without any pretense she\nwas now afraid of everything.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIV\n\nMadame Schoss, who had been out to visit her daughter, increased the\ncountess\xe2\x80\x99 fears still more by telling what she had seen at a spirit\ndealer\xe2\x80\x99s in Myasn\xc3\xadtski Street. When returning by that street she had\nbeen unable to pass because of a drunken crowd rioting in front of\nthe shop. She had taken a cab and driven home by a side street and the\ncabman had told her that the people were breaking open the barrels at\nthe drink store, having received orders to do so.\n\nAfter dinner the whole Rost\xc3\xb3v household set to work with enthusiastic\nhaste packing their belongings and preparing for their departure. The\nold count, suddenly setting to work, kept passing from the yard to the\nhouse and back again, shouting confused instructions to the hurrying\npeople, and flurrying them still more. P\xc3\xa9tya directed things in the\nyard. S\xc3\xb3nya, owing to the count\xe2\x80\x99s contradictory orders, lost her head\nand did not know what to do. The servants ran noisily about the house\nand yard, shouting and disputing. Nat\xc3\xa1sha, with the ardor characteristic\nof all she did suddenly set to work too. At first her intervention in\nthe business of packing was received skeptically. Everybody expected\nsome prank from her and did not wish to obey her; but she resolutely\nand passionately demanded obedience, grew angry and nearly cried because\nthey did not heed her, and at last succeeded in making them believe her.\nHer first exploit, which cost her immense effort and established her\nauthority, was the packing of the carpets. The count had valuable\nGobelin tapestries and Persian carpets in the house. When Nat\xc3\xa1sha set\nto work two cases were standing open in the ballroom, one almost full\nup with crockery, the other with carpets. There was also much china\nstanding on the tables, and still more was being brought in from the\nstoreroom. A third case was needed and servants had gone to fetch it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xc3\xb3nya, wait a bit\xe2\x80\x94we\xe2\x80\x99ll pack everything into these,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t, Miss, we have tried to,\xe2\x80\x9d said the butler\xe2\x80\x99s assistant.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, wait a minute, please.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Nat\xc3\xa1sha began rapidly taking out of the case dishes and plates\nwrapped in paper.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe dishes must go in here among the carpets,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it\xe2\x80\x99s a mercy if we can get the carpets alone into three cases,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid the butler\xe2\x80\x99s assistant.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, wait, please!\xe2\x80\x9d And Nat\xc3\xa1sha began rapidly and deftly sorting out the\nthings. \xe2\x80\x9cThese aren\xe2\x80\x99t needed,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, putting aside some plates\nof Kiev ware. \xe2\x80\x9cThese\xe2\x80\x94yes, these must go among the carpets,\xe2\x80\x9d she said,\nreferring to the Saxony china dishes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t, Nat\xc3\xa1sha! Leave it alone! We\xe2\x80\x99ll get it all packed,\xe2\x80\x9d urged S\xc3\xb3nya\nreproachfully.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a young lady she is!\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the major-domo.\n\nBut Nat\xc3\xa1sha would not give in. She turned everything out and began\nquickly repacking, deciding that the inferior Russian carpets and\nunnecessary crockery should not be taken at all. When everything had\nbeen taken out of the cases, they recommenced packing, and it turned\nout that when the cheaper things not worth taking had nearly all been\nrejected, the valuable ones really did all go into the two cases. Only\nthe lid of the case containing the carpets would not shut down. A few\nmore things might have been taken out, but Nat\xc3\xa1sha insisted on having\nher own way. She packed, repacked, pressed, made the butler\xe2\x80\x99s assistant\nand P\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x94whom she had drawn into the business of packing\xe2\x80\x94press on the\nlid, and made desperate efforts herself.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s enough, Nat\xc3\xa1sha,\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya. \xe2\x80\x9cI see you were right, but just\ntake out the top one.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nat\xc3\xa1sha, with one hand holding back the hair that hung\nover her perspiring face, while with the other she pressed down the\ncarpets. \xe2\x80\x9cNow press, P\xc3\xa9tya! Press, Vas\xc3\xadlich, press hard!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried.\n\nThe carpets yielded and the lid closed; Nat\xc3\xa1sha, clapping her hands,\nscreamed with delight and tears fell from her eyes. But this only\nlasted a moment. She at once set to work afresh and they now trusted her\ncompletely. The count was not angry even when they told him that Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nhad countermanded an order of his, and the servants now came to her\nto ask whether a cart was sufficiently loaded, and whether it might\nbe corded up. Thanks to Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s directions the work now went on\nexpeditiously, unnecessary things were left, and the most valuable\npacked as compactly as possible.\n\nBut hard as they all worked till quite late that night, they could not\nget everything packed. The countess had fallen asleep and the count,\nhaving put off their departure till next morning, went to bed.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya and Nat\xc3\xa1sha slept in the sitting room without undressing.\n\nThat night another wounded man was driven down the Povarsk\xc3\xa1ya, and M\xc3\xa1vra\nKuzm\xc3\xadnichna, who was standing at the gate, had him brought into the\nRost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 yard. M\xc3\xa1vra Kuzm\xc3\xadnichna concluded that he was a very important\nman. He was being conveyed in a cal\xc3\xa8che with a raised hood, and was\nquite covered by an apron. On the box beside the driver sat a venerable\nold attendant. A doctor and two soldiers followed the carriage in a\ncart.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease come in here. The masters are going away and the whole house\nwill be empty,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old woman to the old attendant.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d said he with a sigh. \xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t expect to get him home\nalive! We have a house of our own in Moscow, but it\xe2\x80\x99s a long way from\nhere, and there\xe2\x80\x99s nobody living in it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo us the honor to come in, there\xe2\x80\x99s plenty of everything in the\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s house. Come in,\xe2\x80\x9d said M\xc3\xa1vra Kuzm\xc3\xadnichna. \xe2\x80\x9cIs he very ill?\xe2\x80\x9d she\nasked.\n\nThe attendant made a hopeless gesture.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t expect to get him home! We must ask the doctor.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd the old servant got down from the box and went up to the cart.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right!\xe2\x80\x9d said the doctor.\n\nThe old servant returned to the cal\xc3\xa8che, looked into it, shook his\nhead disconsolately, told the driver to turn into the yard, and stopped\nbeside M\xc3\xa1vra Kuzm\xc3\xadnichna.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, Lord Jesus Christ!\xe2\x80\x9d she murmured.\n\nShe invited them to take the wounded man into the house.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe masters won\xe2\x80\x99t object...\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\n\nBut they had to avoid carrying the man upstairs, and so they took him\ninto the wing and put him in the room that had been Madame Schoss\xe2\x80\x99.\n\nThis wounded man was Prince Andrew Bolk\xc3\xb3nski.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XV\n\nMoscow\xe2\x80\x99s last day had come. It was a clear bright autumn day, a Sunday.\nThe church bells everywhere were ringing for service, just as usual on\nSundays. Nobody seemed yet to realize what awaited the city.\n\nOnly two things indicated the social condition of Moscow\xe2\x80\x94the rabble,\nthat is the poor people, and the price of commodities. An enormous crowd\nof factory hands, house serfs, and peasants, with whom some officials,\nseminarists, and gentry were mingled, had gone early that morning to\nthe Three Hills. Having waited there for Rostopch\xc3\xadn who did not turn\nup, they became convinced that Moscow would be surrendered, and then\ndispersed all about the town to the public houses and cookshops. Prices\ntoo that day indicated the state of affairs. The price of weapons, of\ngold, of carts and horses, kept rising, but the value of paper money and\ncity articles kept falling, so that by midday there were instances of\ncarters removing valuable goods, such as cloth, and receiving in payment\na half of what they carted, while peasant horses were fetching five\nhundred rubles each, and furniture, mirrors, and bronzes were being\ngiven away for nothing.\n\nIn the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 staid old-fashioned house the dissolution of former\nconditions of life was but little noticeable. As to the serfs the only\nindication was that three out of their huge retinue disappeared\nduring the night, but nothing was stolen; and as to the value of their\npossessions, the thirty peasant carts that had come in from their\nestates and which many people envied proved to be extremely valuable and\nthey were offered enormous sums of money for them. Not only were huge\nsums offered for the horses and carts, but on the previous evening and\nearly in the morning of the first of September, orderlies and servants\nsent by wounded officers came to the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 and wounded men dragged\nthemselves there from the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 and from neighboring houses where\nthey were accommodated, entreating the servants to try to get them\na lift out of Moscow. The major-domo to whom these entreaties were\naddressed, though he was sorry for the wounded, resolutely refused,\nsaying that he dare not even mention the matter to the count. Pity these\nwounded men as one might, it was evident that if they were given one\ncart there would be no reason to refuse another, or all the carts and\none\xe2\x80\x99s own carriages as well. Thirty carts could not save all the wounded\nand in the general catastrophe one could not disregard oneself and one\xe2\x80\x99s\nown family. So thought the major-domo on his master\xe2\x80\x99s behalf.\n\nOn waking up that morning Count Ily\xc3\xa1 Rost\xc3\xb3v left his bedroom softly, so\nas not to wake the countess who had fallen asleep only toward morning,\nand came out to the porch in his lilac silk dressing gown. In the yard\nstood the carts ready corded. The carriages were at the front porch.\nThe major-domo stood at the porch talking to an elderly orderly and to\na pale young officer with a bandaged arm. On seeing the count the\nmajor-domo made a significant and stern gesture to them both to go away.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Vas\xc3\xadlich, is everything ready?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the count, and stroking his\nbald head he looked good-naturedly at the officer and the orderly and\nnodded to them. (He liked to see new faces.)\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe can harness at once, your excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that\xe2\x80\x99s right. As soon as the countess wakes we\xe2\x80\x99ll be off, God\nwilling! What is it, gentlemen?\xe2\x80\x9d he added, turning to the officer. \xe2\x80\x9cAre\nyou staying in my house?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe officer came nearer and suddenly his face flushed crimson.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount, be so good as to allow me... for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, to get into some\ncorner of one of your carts! I have nothing here with me.... I shall be\nall right on a loaded cart....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBefore the officer had finished speaking the orderly made the same\nrequest on behalf of his master.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, yes, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d said the count hastily. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall be very pleased,\nvery pleased. Vas\xc3\xadlich, you\xe2\x80\x99ll see to it. Just unload one or two carts.\nWell, what of it... do what\xe2\x80\x99s necessary...\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, muttering\nsome indefinite order.\n\nBut at the same moment an expression of warm gratitude on the officer\xe2\x80\x99s\nface had already sealed the order. The count looked around him. In the\nyard, at the gates, at the window of the wings, wounded officers and\ntheir orderlies were to be seen. They were all looking at the count and\nmoving toward the porch.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease step into the gallery, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major-domo.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are your orders about the pictures?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe count went into the house with him, repeating his order not to\nrefuse the wounded who asked for a lift.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, never mind, some of the things can be unloaded,\xe2\x80\x9d he added in a\nsoft, confidential voice, as though afraid of being overheard.\n\nAt nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock the countess woke up, and Matr\xc3\xabna Timof\xc3\xa9evna, who had\nbeen her lady\xe2\x80\x99s maid before her marriage and now performed a sort of\nchief gendarme\xe2\x80\x99s duty for her, came to say that Madame Schoss was much\noffended and the young ladies\xe2\x80\x99 summer dresses could not be left behind.\nOn inquiry, the countess learned that Madame Schoss was offended because\nher trunk had been taken down from its cart, and all the loads were\nbeing uncorded and the luggage taken out of the carts to make room for\nwounded men whom the count in the simplicity of his heart had ordered\nthat they should take with them. The countess sent for her husband.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is this, my dear? I hear that the luggage is being unloaded.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know, love, I wanted to tell you... Countess dear... an officer\ncame to me to ask for a few carts for the wounded. After all, ours are\nthings that can be bought but think what being left behind means to\nthem!... Really now, in our own yard\xe2\x80\x94we asked them in ourselves and\nthere are officers among them.... You know, I think, my dear... let them\nbe taken... where\xe2\x80\x99s the hurry?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe count spoke timidly, as he always did when talking of money matters.\nThe countess was accustomed to this tone as a precursor of news of\nsomething detrimental to the children\xe2\x80\x99s interests, such as the building\nof a new gallery or conservatory, the inauguration of a private theater\nor an orchestra. She was accustomed always to oppose anything announced\nin that timid tone and considered it her duty to do so.\n\nShe assumed her dolefully submissive manner and said to her husband:\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen to me, Count, you have managed matters so that we are getting\nnothing for the house, and now you wish to throw away all our\xe2\x80\x94all the\nchildren\xe2\x80\x99s property! You said yourself that we have a hundred thousand\nrubles\xe2\x80\x99 worth of things in the house. I don\xe2\x80\x99t consent, my dear, I don\xe2\x80\x99t!\nDo as you please! It\xe2\x80\x99s the government\xe2\x80\x99s business to look after the\nwounded; they know that. Look at the Lopukh\xc3\xadns opposite, they cleared\nout everything two days ago. That\xe2\x80\x99s what other people do. It\xe2\x80\x99s only\nwe who are such fools. If you have no pity on me, have some for the\nchildren.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nFlourishing his arms in despair the count left the room without\nreplying.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa, what are you doing that for?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Nat\xc3\xa1sha, who had followed him\ninto her mother\xe2\x80\x99s room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing! What business is it of yours?\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the count angrily.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I heard,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy does Mamma object?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat business is it of yours?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the count.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha stepped up to the window and pondered.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa! Here\xe2\x80\x99s Berg coming to see us,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, looking out of the\nwindow.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVI\n\nBerg, the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 son-in-law, was already a colonel wearing the orders\nof Vlad\xc3\xadmir and Anna, and he still filled the quiet and agreeable post\nof assistant to the head of the staff of the assistant commander of the\nfirst division of the Second Army.\n\nOn the first of September he had come to Moscow from the army.\n\nHe had nothing to do in Moscow, but he had noticed that everyone in the\narmy was asking for leave to visit Moscow and had something to do there.\nSo he considered it necessary to ask for leave of absence for family and\ndomestic reasons.\n\nBerg drove up to his father-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s house in his spruce little trap\nwith a pair of sleek roans, exactly like those of a certain prince. He\nlooked attentively at the carts in the yard and while going up to the\nporch took out a clean pocket handkerchief and tied a knot in it.\n\nFrom the anteroom Berg ran with smooth though impatient steps into the\ndrawing room, where he embraced the count, kissed the hands of Nat\xc3\xa1sha\nand S\xc3\xb3nya, and hastened to inquire after \xe2\x80\x9cMamma\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d health.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHealth, at a time like this?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count. \xe2\x80\x9cCome, tell us the news!\nIs the army retreating or will there be another battle?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod Almighty alone can decide the fate of our fatherland, Papa,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nBerg. \xe2\x80\x9cThe army is burning with a spirit of heroism and the leaders, so\nto say, have now assembled in council. No one knows what is coming. But\nin general I can tell you, Papa, that such a heroic spirit, the truly\nantique valor of the Russian army, which they\xe2\x80\x94which it\xe2\x80\x9d (he corrected\nhimself) \xe2\x80\x9chas shown or displayed in the battle of the twenty-sixth\xe2\x80\x94there\nare no words worthy to do it justice! I tell you, Papa\xe2\x80\x9d (he smote\nhimself on the breast as a general he had heard speaking had done, but\nBerg did it a trifle late for he should have struck his breast at the\nwords \xe2\x80\x9cRussian army\xe2\x80\x9d), \xe2\x80\x9cI tell you frankly that we, the commanders, far\nfrom having to urge the men on or anything of that kind, could hardly\nrestrain those... those... yes, those exploits of antique valor,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nwent on rapidly. \xe2\x80\x9cGeneral Barclay de Tolly risked his life everywhere at\nthe head of the troops, I can assure you. Our corps was stationed on a\nhillside. You can imagine!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Berg related all that he remembered of the various tales he had\nheard those days. Nat\xc3\xa1sha watched him with an intent gaze that confused\nhim, as if she were trying to find in his face the answer to some\nquestion.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAltogether such heroism as was displayed by the Russian warriors\ncannot be imagined or adequately praised!\xe2\x80\x9d said Berg, glancing round\nat Nat\xc3\xa1sha, and as if anxious to conciliate her, replying to her intent\nlook with a smile. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Russia is not in Moscow, she lives in the hearts of\nher sons!\xe2\x80\x99 Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it so, Papa?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\nJust then the countess came in from the sitting room with a weary and\ndissatisfied expression. Berg hurriedly jumped up, kissed her hand,\nasked about her health, and, swaying his head from side to side to\nexpress sympathy, remained standing beside her.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Mamma, I tell you sincerely that these are hard and sad times for\nevery Russian. But why are you so anxious? You have still time to get\naway....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t think what the servants are about,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, turning\nto her husband. \xe2\x80\x9cI have just been told that nothing is ready yet.\nSomebody after all must see to things. One misses M\xc3\xadtenka at such times.\nThere won\xe2\x80\x99t be any end to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe count was about to say something, but evidently restrained himself.\nHe got up from his chair and went to the door.\n\nAt that moment Berg drew out his handkerchief as if to blow his nose\nand, seeing the knot in it, pondered, shaking his head sadly and\nsignificantly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I have a great favor to ask of you, Papa,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHm...\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, and stopped.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was driving past Yus\xc3\xbapov\xe2\x80\x99s house just now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Berg with a laugh,\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhen the steward, a man I know, ran out and asked me whether I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\nbuy something. I went in out of curiosity, you know, and there is a\nsmall chiffonier and a dressing table. You know how dear V\xc3\xa9ra wanted a\nchiffonier like that and how we had a dispute about it.\xe2\x80\x9d (At the mention\nof the chiffonier and dressing table Berg involuntarily changed his tone\nto one of pleasure at his admirable domestic arrangements.) \xe2\x80\x9cAnd it\xe2\x80\x99s\nsuch a beauty! It pulls out and has a secret English drawer, you know!\nAnd dear V\xc3\xa9ra has long wanted one. I wish to give her a surprise, you\nsee. I saw so many of those peasant carts in your yard. Please let me\nhave one, I will pay the man well, and...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe count frowned and coughed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAsk the countess, I don\xe2\x80\x99t give orders.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it\xe2\x80\x99s inconvenient, please don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Berg. \xe2\x80\x9cOnly I so wanted it,\nfor dear V\xc3\xa9ra\xe2\x80\x99s sake.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, go to the devil, all of you! To the devil, the devil, the devil...\xe2\x80\x9d\ncried the old count. \xe2\x80\x9cMy head\xe2\x80\x99s in a whirl!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd he left the room. The countess began to cry.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Mamma! Yes, these are very hard times!\xe2\x80\x9d said Berg.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha left the room with her father and, as if finding it difficult to\nreach some decision, first followed him and then ran downstairs.\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya was in the porch, engaged in giving out weapons to the servants\nwho were to leave Moscow. The loaded carts were still standing in the\nyard. Two of them had been uncorded and a wounded officer was climbing\ninto one of them helped by an orderly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know what it\xe2\x80\x99s about?\xe2\x80\x9d P\xc3\xa9tya asked Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\nShe understood that he meant what were their parents quarreling about.\nShe did not answer.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s because Papa wanted to give up all the carts to the wounded,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nP\xc3\xa9tya. \xe2\x80\x9cVas\xc3\xadlich told me. I consider...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI consider,\xe2\x80\x9d Nat\xc3\xa1sha suddenly almost shouted, turning her angry face to\nP\xc3\xa9tya, \xe2\x80\x9cI consider it so horrid, so abominable, so... I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what.\nAre we despicable Germans?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHer throat quivered with convulsive sobs and, afraid of weakening and\nletting the force of her anger run to waste, she turned and rushed\nheadlong up the stairs.\n\nBerg was sitting beside the countess consoling her with the respectful\nattention of a relative. The count, pipe in hand, was pacing up and down\nthe room, when Nat\xc3\xa1sha, her face distorted by anger, burst in like a\ntempest and approached her mother with rapid steps.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s horrid! It\xe2\x80\x99s abominable!\xe2\x80\x9d she screamed. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t possibly have\nordered it!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBerg and the countess looked at her, perplexed and frightened. The count\nstood still at the window and listened.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible: see what is going on in the yard!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey will be left!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with you? Who are \xe2\x80\x98they\xe2\x80\x99? What do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, the wounded! It\xe2\x80\x99s impossible, Mamma. It\xe2\x80\x99s monstrous!... No, Mamma\ndarling, it\xe2\x80\x99s not the thing. Please forgive me, darling.... Mamma, what\ndoes it matter what we take away? Only look what is going on in the\nyard... Mamma!... It\xe2\x80\x99s impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe count stood by the window and listened without turning round.\nSuddenly he sniffed and put his face closer to the window.\n\nThe countess glanced at her daughter, saw her face full of shame for her\nmother, saw her agitation, and understood why her husband did not turn\nto look at her now, and she glanced round quite disconcerted.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, do as you like! Am I hindering anyone?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, not surrendering\nat once.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, darling, forgive me!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nBut the countess pushed her daughter away and went up to her husband.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear, you order what is right.... You know I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand about\nit,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, dropping her eyes shamefacedly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe eggs... the eggs are teaching the hen,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the count through\ntears of joy, and he embraced his wife who was glad to hide her look of\nshame on his breast.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa! Mamma! May I see to it? May I?...\xe2\x80\x9d asked Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cWe will still\ntake all the most necessary things.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe count nodded affirmatively, and Nat\xc3\xa1sha, at the rapid pace at which\nshe used to run when playing at tag, ran through the ballroom to the\nanteroom and downstairs into the yard.\n\nThe servants gathered round Nat\xc3\xa1sha, but could not believe the strange\norder she brought them until the count himself, in his wife\xe2\x80\x99s name,\nconfirmed the order to give up all the carts to the wounded and take the\ntrunks to the storerooms. When they understood that order the servants\nset to work at this new task with pleasure and zeal. It no longer seemed\nstrange to them but on the contrary it seemed the only thing that could\nbe done, just as a quarter of an hour before it had not seemed strange\nto anyone that the wounded should be left behind and the goods carted\naway but that had seemed the only thing to do.\n\nThe whole household, as if to atone for not having done it sooner, set\neagerly to work at the new task of placing the wounded in the carts. The\nwounded dragged themselves out of their rooms and stood with pale but\nhappy faces round the carts. The news that carts were to be had spread\nto the neighboring houses, from which wounded men began to come into the\nRost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 yard. Many of the wounded asked them not to unload the carts\nbut only to let them sit on the top of the things. But the work of\nunloading, once started, could not be arrested. It seemed not to matter\nwhether all or only half the things were left behind. Cases full of\nchina, bronzes, pictures, and mirrors that had been so carefully\npacked the night before now lay about the yard, and still they went on\nsearching for and finding possibilities of unloading this or that and\nletting the wounded have another and yet another cart.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe can take four more men,\xe2\x80\x9d said the steward. \xe2\x80\x9cThey can have my trap,\nor else what is to become of them?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet them have my wardrobe cart,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess. \xe2\x80\x9cDuny\xc3\xa1sha can go\nwith me in the carriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThey unloaded the wardrobe cart and sent it to take wounded men from a\nhouse two doors off. The whole household, servants included, was bright\nand animated. Nat\xc3\xa1sha was in a state of rapturous excitement such as she\nhad not known for a long time.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat could we fasten this onto?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the servants, trying to fix a\ntrunk on the narrow footboard behind a carriage. \xe2\x80\x9cWe must keep at least\none cart.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s in it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count\xe2\x80\x99s books.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeave it, Vas\xc3\xadlich will put it away. It\xe2\x80\x99s not wanted.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe phaeton was full of people and there was a doubt as to where Count\nPeter could sit.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the box. You\xe2\x80\x99ll sit on the box, won\xe2\x80\x99t you, P\xc3\xa9tya?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Nat\xc3\xa1sha.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya too was busy all this time, but the aim of her efforts was quite\ndifferent from Nat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s. She was putting away the things that had to\nbe left behind and making a list of them as the countess wished, and she\ntried to get as much taken away with them as possible.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVII\n\nBefore two o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the afternoon the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99 four carriages, packed\nfull and with the horses harnessed, stood at the front door. One by one\nthe carts with the wounded had moved out of the yard.\n\nThe cal\xc3\xa8che in which Prince Andrew was being taken attracted S\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s\nattention as it passed the front porch. With the help of a maid she was\narranging a seat for the countess in the huge high coach that stood at\nthe entrance.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhose cal\xc3\xa8che is that?\xe2\x80\x9d she inquired, leaning out of the carriage\nwindow.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, didn\xe2\x80\x99t you know, Miss?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the maid. \xe2\x80\x9cThe wounded prince: he\nspent the night in our house and is going with us.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut who is it? What\xe2\x80\x99s his name?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s our intended that was\xe2\x80\x94Prince Bolk\xc3\xb3nski himself! They say he is\ndying,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the maid with a sigh.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya jumped out of the coach and ran to the countess. The countess,\ntired out and already dressed in shawl and bonnet for her journey,\nwas pacing up and down the drawing room, waiting for the household to\nassemble for the usual silent prayer with closed doors before starting.\nNat\xc3\xa1sha was not in the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma,\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya, \xe2\x80\x9cPrince Andrew is here, mortally wounded. He is\ngoing with us.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe countess opened her eyes in dismay and, seizing S\xc3\xb3nya\xe2\x80\x99s arm, glanced\naround.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1sha?\xe2\x80\x9d she murmured.\n\nAt that moment this news had only one significance for both of them.\nThey knew their Nat\xc3\xa1sha, and alarm as to what would happen if she heard\nthis news stifled all sympathy for the man they both liked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNat\xc3\xa1sha does not know yet, but he is going with us,\xe2\x80\x9d said S\xc3\xb3nya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou say he is dying?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya nodded.\n\nThe countess put her arms around S\xc3\xb3nya and began to cry.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe ways of God are past finding out!\xe2\x80\x9d she thought, feeling that the\nAlmighty Hand, hitherto unseen, was becoming manifest in all that was\nnow taking place.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Mamma? Everything is ready. What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Nat\xc3\xa1sha, as\nwith animated face she ran into the room.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the countess. \xe2\x80\x9cIf everything is ready let us start.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd the countess bent over her reticule to hide her agitated face. S\xc3\xb3nya\nembraced Nat\xc3\xa1sha and kissed her.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha looked at her inquiringly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it? What has happened?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing... No...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it something very bad for me? What is it?\xe2\x80\x9d persisted Nat\xc3\xa1sha with\nher quick intuition.\n\nS\xc3\xb3nya sighed and made no reply. The count, P\xc3\xa9tya, Madame Schoss, M\xc3\xa1vra\nKuzm\xc3\xadnichna, and Vas\xc3\xadlich came into the drawing room and, having closed\nthe doors, they all sat down and remained for some moments silently\nseated without looking at one another.\n\nThe count was the first to rise, and with a loud sigh crossed himself\nbefore the icon. All the others did the same. Then the count embraced\nM\xc3\xa1vra Kuzm\xc3\xadnichna and Vas\xc3\xadlich, who were to remain in Moscow, and while\nthey caught at his hand and kissed his shoulder he patted their backs\nlightly with some vaguely affectionate and comforting words. The\ncountess went into the oratory and there S\xc3\xb3nya found her on her knees\nbefore the icons that had been left here and there hanging on the wall.\n(The most precious ones, with which some family tradition was connected,\nwere being taken with them.)\n\nIn the porch and in the yard the men whom P\xc3\xa9tya had armed with swords\nand daggers, with trousers tucked inside their high boots and with belts\nand girdles tightened, were taking leave of those remaining behind.\n\nAs is always the case at a departure, much had been forgotten or put in\nthe wrong place, and for a long time two menservants stood one on\neach side of the open door and the carriage steps waiting to help the\ncountess in, while maids rushed with cushions and bundles from the house\nto the carriages, the cal\xc3\xa8che, the phaeton, and back again.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey always will forget everything!\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you know\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t sit like that?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Duny\xc3\xa1sha, with clenched teeth, without replying but with an\naggrieved look on her face, hastily got into the coach to rearrange the\nseat.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, those servants!\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, swaying his head.\n\nEf\xc3\xadm, the old coachman, who was the only one the countess trusted to\ndrive her, sat perched up high on the box and did not so much as glance\nround at what was going on behind him. From thirty years\xe2\x80\x99 experience\nhe knew it would be some time yet before the order, \xe2\x80\x9cBe off, in God\xe2\x80\x99s\nname!\xe2\x80\x9d would be given him: and he knew that even when it was said\nhe would be stopped once or twice more while they sent back to fetch\nsomething that had been forgotten, and even after that he would again\nbe stopped and the countess herself would lean out of the window and beg\nhim for the love of heaven to drive carefully down the hill. He knew\nall this and therefore waited calmly for what would happen, with more\npatience than the horses, especially the near one, the chestnut Falcon,\nwho was pawing the ground and champing his bit. At last all were\nseated, the carriage steps were folded and pulled up, the door was shut,\nsomebody was sent for a traveling case, and the countess leaned out\nand said what she had to say. Then Ef\xc3\xadm deliberately doffed his hat and\nbegan crossing himself. The postilion and all the other servants did the\nsame. \xe2\x80\x9cOff, in God\xe2\x80\x99s name!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ef\xc3\xadm, putting on his hat. \xe2\x80\x9cStart!\xe2\x80\x9d The\npostilion started the horses, the off pole horse tugged at his collar,\nthe high springs creaked, and the body of the coach swayed. The footman\nsprang onto the box of the moving coach which jolted as it passed out\nof the yard onto the uneven roadway; the other vehicles jolted in\ntheir turn, and the procession of carriages moved up the street. In the\ncarriages, the cal\xc3\xa8che, and the phaeton, all crossed themselves as they\npassed the church opposite the house. Those who were to remain in Moscow\nwalked on either side of the vehicles seeing the travelers off.\n\nRarely had Nat\xc3\xa1sha experienced so joyful a feeling as now, sitting in\nthe carriage beside the countess and gazing at the slowly receding\nwalls of forsaken, agitated Moscow. Occasionally she leaned out of the\ncarriage window and looked back and then forward at the long train of\nwounded in front of them. Almost at the head of the line she could see\nthe raised hood of Prince Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s cal\xc3\xa8che. She did not know who was\nin it, but each time she looked at the procession her eyes sought that\ncal\xc3\xa8che. She knew it was right in front.\n\nIn K\xc3\xbadrino, from the Nik\xc3\xadtski, Pr\xc3\xa9snya, and Podnov\xc3\xadnsk Streets came\nseveral other trains of vehicles similar to the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\xe2\x80\x99, and as they\npassed along the Sad\xc3\xb3vaya Street the carriages and carts formed two rows\nabreast.\n\nAs they were going round the S\xc3\xbakharev water tower Nat\xc3\xa1sha, who was\ninquisitively and alertly scrutinizing the people driving or walking\npast, suddenly cried out in joyful surprise:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me! Mamma, S\xc3\xb3nya, look, it\xe2\x80\x99s he!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho? Who?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook! Yes, on my word, it\xe2\x80\x99s Bez\xc3\xbakhov!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha, putting her head\nout of the carriage and staring at a tall, stout man in a coachman\xe2\x80\x99s\nlong coat, who from his manner of walking and moving was evidently\na gentleman in disguise, and who was passing under the arch of the\nS\xc3\xbakharev tower accompanied by a small, sallow-faced, beardless old man\nin a frieze coat.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it really is Bez\xc3\xbakhov in a coachman\xe2\x80\x99s coat, with a queer-looking\nold boy. Really,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nat\xc3\xa1sha, \xe2\x80\x9clook, look!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it\xe2\x80\x99s not he. How can you talk such nonsense?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma,\xe2\x80\x9d screamed Nat\xc3\xa1sha, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll stake my head it\xe2\x80\x99s he! I assure you!\nStop, stop!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried to the coachman.\n\nBut the coachman could not stop, for from the Meshch\xc3\xa1nski Street came\nmore carts and carriages, and the Rost\xc3\xb3vs were being shouted at to move\non and not block the way.\n\nIn fact, however, though now much farther off than before, the Rost\xc3\xb3vs\nall saw Pierre\xe2\x80\x94or someone extraordinarily like him\xe2\x80\x94in a coachman\xe2\x80\x99s coat,\ngoing down the street with head bent and a serious face beside a small,\nbeardless old man who looked like a footman. That old man noticed a\nface thrust out of the carriage window gazing at them, and respectfully\ntouching Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s elbow said something to him and pointed to the\ncarriage. Pierre, evidently engrossed in thought, could not at first\nunderstand him. At length when he had understood and looked in the\ndirection the old man indicated, he recognized Nat\xc3\xa1sha, and following\nhis first impulse stepped instantly and rapidly toward the coach. But\nhaving taken a dozen steps he seemed to remember something and stopped.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha\xe2\x80\x99s face, leaning out of the window, beamed with quizzical\nkindliness.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeter Kir\xc3\xadlovich, come here! We have recognized you! This is\nwonderful!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried, holding out her hand to him. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing?\nWhy are you like this?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre took her outstretched hand and kissed it awkwardly as he walked\nalong beside her while the coach still moved on.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter, Count?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the countess in a surprised and\ncommiserating tone.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? What? Why? Don\xe2\x80\x99t ask me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, and looked round at\nNat\xc3\xa1sha whose radiant, happy expression\xe2\x80\x94of which he was conscious\nwithout looking at her\xe2\x80\x94filled him with enchantment.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you remaining in Moscow, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre hesitated.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn Moscow?\xe2\x80\x9d he said in a questioning tone. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, in Moscow. Good-by!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, if only I were a man! I\xe2\x80\x99d certainly stay with you. How splendid!\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid Nat\xc3\xa1sha. \xe2\x80\x9cMamma, if you\xe2\x80\x99ll let me, I\xe2\x80\x99ll stay!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre glanced absently at Nat\xc3\xa1sha and was about to say something, but\nthe countess interrupted him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were at the battle, we heard.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I was,\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre answered. \xe2\x80\x9cThere will be another battle\ntomorrow...\xe2\x80\x9d he began, but Nat\xc3\xa1sha interrupted him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what is the matter with you, Count? You are not like yourself....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, don\xe2\x80\x99t ask me, don\xe2\x80\x99t ask me! I don\xe2\x80\x99t know myself. Tomorrow... But\nno! Good-by, good-by!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s an awful time!\xe2\x80\x9d and dropping\nbehind the carriage he stepped onto the pavement.\n\nNat\xc3\xa1sha continued to lean out of the window for a long time, beaming at\nhim with her kindly, slightly quizzical, happy smile.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XVIII\n\nFor the last two days, ever since leaving home, Pierre had been living\nin the empty house of his deceased benefactor, Bazd\xc3\xa9ev. This is how it\nhappened.\n\nWhen he woke up on the morning after his return to Moscow and his\ninterview with Count Rostopch\xc3\xadn, he could not for some time make out\nwhere he was and what was expected of him. When he was informed that\namong others awaiting him in his reception room there was a Frenchman\nwho had brought a letter from his wife, the Countess H\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8ne, he felt\nsuddenly overcome by that sense of confusion and hopelessness to which\nhe was apt to succumb. He felt that everything was now at an end, all\nwas in confusion and crumbling to pieces, that nobody was right or\nwrong, the future held nothing, and there was no escape from this\nposition. Smiling unnaturally and muttering to himself, he first sat\ndown on the sofa in an attitude of despair, then rose, went to the door\nof the reception room and peeped through the crack, returned flourishing\nhis arms, and took up a book. His major-domo came in a second time to\nsay that the Frenchman who had brought the letter from the countess\nwas very anxious to see him if only for a minute, and that someone from\nBazd\xc3\xa9ev\xe2\x80\x99s widow had called to ask Pierre to take charge of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s\nbooks, as she herself was leaving for the country.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, in a minute; wait... or no! No, of course... go and say I will\ncome directly,\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre replied to the major-domo.\n\nBut as soon as the man had left the room Pierre took up his hat which\nwas lying on the table and went out of his study by the other door.\nThere was no one in the passage. He went along the whole length of this\npassage to the stairs and, frowning and rubbing his forehead with\nboth hands, went down as far as the first landing. The hall porter was\nstanding at the front door. From the landing where Pierre stood there\nwas a second staircase leading to the back entrance. He went down that\nstaircase and out into the yard. No one had seen him. But there were\nsome carriages waiting, and as soon as Pierre stepped out of the gate\nthe coachmen and the yard porter noticed him and raised their caps to\nhim. When he felt he was being looked at he behaved like an ostrich\nwhich hides its head in a bush in order not to be seen: he hung his head\nand quickening his pace went down the street.\n\nOf all the affairs awaiting Pierre that day the sorting of Joseph\nBazd\xc3\xa9ev\xe2\x80\x99s books and papers appeared to him the most necessary.\n\nHe hired the first cab he met and told the driver to go to the\nPatriarch\xe2\x80\x99s Ponds, where the widow Bazd\xc3\xa9ev\xe2\x80\x99s house was.\n\nContinually turning round to look at the rows of loaded carts that were\nmaking their way from all sides out of Moscow, and balancing his bulky\nbody so as not to slip out of the ramshackle old vehicle, Pierre,\nexperiencing the joyful feeling of a boy escaping from school, began to\ntalk to his driver.\n\nThe man told him that arms were being distributed today at the Kr\xc3\xa9mlin\nand that tomorrow everyone would be sent out beyond the Three Hills\ngates and a great battle would be fought there.\n\nHaving reached the Patriarch\xe2\x80\x99s Ponds Pierre found the Bazd\xc3\xa9evs\xe2\x80\x99 house,\nwhere he had not been for a long time past. He went up to the gate.\nGer\xc3\xa1sim, that sallow beardless old man Pierre had seen at Torzh\xc3\xb3k five\nyears before with Joseph Bazd\xc3\xa9ev, came out in answer to his knock.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt home?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Pierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOwing to the present state of things Sophia Dan\xc3\xadlovna has gone to the\nTorzh\xc3\xb3k estate with the children, your excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will come in all the same, I have to look through the books,\xe2\x80\x9d said\nPierre.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe so good as to step in. Mak\xc3\xa1r Alex\xc3\xa9evich, the brother of my late\nmaster\xe2\x80\x94may the kingdom of heaven be his\xe2\x80\x94has remained here, but he is in\na weak state as you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old servant.\n\nPierre knew that Mak\xc3\xa1r Alex\xc3\xa9evich was Joseph Bazd\xc3\xa9ev\xe2\x80\x99s half-insane\nbrother and a hard drinker.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, I know. Let us go in...\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre and entered the house.\n\nA tall, bald-headed old man with a red nose, wearing a dressing gown and\nwith galoshes on his bare feet, stood in the anteroom. On seeing Pierre\nhe muttered something angrily and went away along the passage.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was a very clever man but has now grown quite feeble, as your honor\nsees,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ger\xc3\xa1sim. \xe2\x80\x9cWill you step into the study?\xe2\x80\x9d Pierre nodded. \xe2\x80\x9cAs\nit was sealed up so it has remained, but Sophia Dan\xc3\xadlovna gave orders\nthat if anyone should come from you they were to have the books.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre went into that gloomy study which he had entered with such\ntrepidation in his benefactor\xe2\x80\x99s lifetime. The room, dusty and untouched\nsince the death of Joseph Bazd\xc3\xa9ev was now even gloomier.\n\nGer\xc3\xa1sim opened one of the shutters and left the room on tiptoe. Pierre\nwent round the study, approached the cupboard in which the manuscripts\nwere kept, and took out what had once been one of the most important,\nthe holy of holies of the order. This was the authentic Scotch Acts\nwith Bazd\xc3\xa9ev\xe2\x80\x99s notes and explanations. He sat down at the dusty writing\ntable, and, having laid the manuscripts before him, opened them out,\nclosed them, finally pushed them away, and resting his head on his hand\nsank into meditation.\n\nGer\xc3\xa1sim looked cautiously into the study several times and saw Pierre\nalways sitting in the same attitude.\n\nMore than two hours passed and Ger\xc3\xa1sim took the liberty of making a\nslight noise at the door to attract his attention, but Pierre did not\nhear him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the cabman to be discharged, your honor?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes!\xe2\x80\x9d said Pierre, rousing himself and rising hurriedly. \xe2\x80\x9cLook\nhere,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, taking Ger\xc3\xa1sim by a button of his coat and looking down\nat the old man with moist, shining, and ecstatic eyes, \xe2\x80\x9cI say, do you\nknow that there is going to be a battle tomorrow?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe heard so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the man.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg you not to tell anyone who I am, and to do what I ask you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ger\xc3\xa1sim. \xe2\x80\x9cWill you have something to\neat?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but I want something else. I want peasant clothes and a pistol,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid Pierre, unexpectedly blushing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ger\xc3\xa1sim after thinking for a moment.\n\nAll the rest of that day Pierre spent alone in his benefactor\xe2\x80\x99s study,\nand Ger\xc3\xa1sim heard him pacing restlessly from one corner to another and\ntalking to himself. And he spent the night on a bed made up for him\nthere.\n\nGer\xc3\xa1sim, being a servant who in his time had seen many strange things,\naccepted Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s taking up his residence in the house without surprise,\nand seemed pleased to have someone to wait on. That same evening\xe2\x80\x94without\neven asking himself what they were wanted for\xe2\x80\x94he procured a coachman\xe2\x80\x99s\ncoat and cap for Pierre, and promised to get him the pistol next day.\nMak\xc3\xa1r Alex\xc3\xa9evich came twice that evening shuffling along in his galoshes\nas far as the door and stopped and looked ingratiatingly at Pierre. But\nas soon as Pierre turned toward him he wrapped his dressing gown around\nhim with a shamefaced and angry look and hurried away. It was when\nPierre (wearing the coachman\xe2\x80\x99s coat which Ger\xc3\xa1sim had procured for him\nand had disinfected by steam) was on his way with the old man to buy the\npistol at the S\xc3\xbakharev market that he met the Rost\xc3\xb3vs.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIX\n\nKut\xc3\xbazov\xe2\x80\x99s order to retreat through Moscow to the Ryaz\xc3\xa1n road was issued\nat night on the first of September.\n\nThe first troops started at once, and during the night they marched\nslowly and steadily without hurry. At daybreak, however, those nearing\nthe town at the Dorogom\xc3\xadlov bridge saw ahead of them masses of soldiers\ncrowding and hurrying across the bridge, ascending on the opposite side\nand blocking the streets and alleys, while endless masses of troops were\nbearing down on them from behind, and an unreasoning hurry and alarm\novercame them. They all rushed forward to the bridge, onto it, and\nto the fords and the boats. Kut\xc3\xbazov himself had driven round by side\nstreets to the other side of Moscow.\n\nBy ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning of the second of September, only the rear\nguard remained in the Dorogom\xc3\xadlov suburb, where they had ample room. The\nmain army was on the other side of Moscow or beyond it.\n\nAt that very time, at ten in the morning of the second of September,\nNapoleon was standing among his troops on the Pokl\xc3\xb3nny Hill looking at\nthe panorama spread out before him. From the twenty-sixth of August\nto the second of September, that is from the battle of Borodin\xc3\xb3 to the\nentry of the French into Moscow, during the whole of that agitating,\nmemorable week, there had been the extraordinary autumn weather that\nalways comes as a surprise, when the sun hangs low and gives more heat\nthan in spring, when everything shines so brightly in the rare clear\natmosphere that the eyes smart, when the lungs are strengthened and\nrefreshed by inhaling the aromatic autumn air, when even the nights\nare warm, and when in those dark warm nights, golden stars startle and\ndelight us continually by falling from the sky.\n\nAt ten in the morning of the second of September this weather still\nheld.\n\nThe brightness of the morning was magical. Moscow seen from the Pokl\xc3\xb3nny\nHill lay spaciously spread out with her river, her gardens, and her\nchurches, and she seemed to be living her usual life, her cupolas\nglittering like stars in the sunlight.\n\nThe view of the strange city with its peculiar architecture, such as\nhe had never seen before, filled Napoleon with the rather envious and\nuneasy curiosity men feel when they see an alien form of life that has\nno knowledge of them. This city was evidently living with the full force\nof its own life. By the indefinite signs which, even at a distance,\ndistinguish a living body from a dead one, Napoleon from the Pokl\xc3\xb3nny\nHill perceived the throb of life in the town and felt, as it were, the\nbreathing of that great and beautiful body.\n\nEvery Russian looking at Moscow feels her to be a mother; every\nforeigner who sees her, even if ignorant of her significance as the\nmother city, must feel her feminine character, and Napoleon felt it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCette ville asiatique aux innombrables \xc3\xa9glises, Moscou la sainte. La\nvoil\xc3\xa0 donc enfin, cette fameuse ville! Il \xc3\xa9tait temps,\xe2\x80\x9d * said he, and\ndismounting he ordered a plan of Moscow to be spread out before him, and\nsummoned Lelorgne d\xe2\x80\x99Ideville, the interpreter.\n\n     * \xe2\x80\x9cThat Asiatic city of the innumerable churches, holy\n     Moscow! Here it is then at last, that famous city. It was\n     high time.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA town captured by the enemy is like a maid who has lost her honor,\xe2\x80\x9d\nthought he (he had said so to T\xc3\xbachkov at Smol\xc3\xa9nsk). From that point of\nview he gazed at the Oriental beauty he had not seen before. It seemed\nstrange to him that his long-felt wish, which had seemed unattainable,\nhad at last been realized. In the clear morning light he gazed now at\nthe city and now at the plan, considering its details, and the assurance\nof possessing it agitated and awed him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut could it be otherwise?\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cHere is this capital at my\nfeet. Where is Alexander now, and of what is he thinking? A strange,\nbeautiful, and majestic city; and a strange and majestic moment! In what\nlight must I appear to them!\xe2\x80\x9d thought he, thinking of his troops.\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere she is, the reward for all those fainthearted men,\xe2\x80\x9d he reflected,\nglancing at those near him and at the troops who were approaching and\nforming up. \xe2\x80\x9cOne word from me, one movement of my hand, and that ancient\ncapital of the Tsars would perish. But my clemency is always ready to\ndescend upon the vanquished. I must be magnanimous and truly great.
