That morning\xe2\x80\x99s attack on the wagons had been made so\nhastily that the Frenchmen with the wagons had all been killed; only a\nlittle drummer boy had been taken alive, and as he was a straggler he\ncould tell them nothing definite about the troops in that column.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov considered it dangerous to make a second attack for fear of\nputting the whole column on the alert, so he sent T\xc3\xadkhon Shcherb\xc3\xa1ty, a\npeasant of his party, to Sh\xc3\xa1mshevo to try and seize at least one of the\nFrench quartermasters who had been sent on in advance.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IV\n\nIt was a warm rainy autumn day. The sky and the horizon were both\nthe color of muddy water. At times a sort of mist descended, and then\nsuddenly heavy slanting rain came down.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov in a felt cloak and a sheepskin cap from which the rain ran down\nwas riding a thin thoroughbred horse with sunken sides. Like his horse,\nwhich turned its head and laid its ears back, he shrank from the driving\nrain and gazed anxiously before him. His thin face with its short, thick\nblack beard looked angry.\n\nBeside Den\xc3\xadsov rode an esaul, * Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s fellow worker, also in felt\ncloak and sheepskin cap, and riding a large sleek Don horse.\n\n    * A captain of Cossacks.\n\nEsaul Lov\xc3\xa1yski the Third was a tall man as straight as an arrow,\npale-faced, fair-haired, with narrow light eyes and with calm\nself-satisfaction in his face and bearing. Though it was impossible to\nsay in what the peculiarity of the horse and rider lay, yet at first\nglance at the esaul and Den\xc3\xadsov one saw that the latter was wet and\nuncomfortable and was a man mounted on a horse, while looking at the\nesaul one saw that he was as comfortable and as much at ease as always\nand that he was not a man who had mounted a horse, but a man who was one\nwith his horse, a being consequently possessed of twofold strength.\n\nA little ahead of them walked a peasant guide, wet to the skin and\nwearing a gray peasant coat and a white knitted cap.\n\nA little behind, on a poor, small, lean Kirgh\xc3\xadz mount with an enormous\ntail and mane and a bleeding mouth, rode a young officer in a blue\nFrench overcoat.\n\nBeside him rode an hussar, with a boy in a tattered French uniform and\nblue cap behind him on the crupper of his horse. The boy held on to the\nhussar with cold, red hands, and raising his eyebrows gazed about him\nwith surprise. This was the French drummer boy captured that morning.\n\nBehind them along the narrow, sodden, cut up forest road came hussars in\nthrees and fours, and then Cossacks: some in felt cloaks, some in French\ngreatcoats, and some with horsecloths over their heads. The horses,\nbeing drenched by the rain, all looked black whether chestnut or bay.\nTheir necks, with their wet, close-clinging manes, looked strangely\nthin. Steam rose from them. Clothes, saddles, reins, were all wet,\nslippery, and sodden, like the ground and the fallen leaves that strewed\nthe road. The men sat huddled up trying not to stir, so as to warm the\nwater that had trickled to their bodies and not admit the fresh cold\nwater that was leaking in under their seats, their knees, and at the\nback of their necks. In the midst of the outspread line of Cossacks two\nwagons, drawn by French horses and by saddled Cossack horses that had\nbeen hitched on in front, rumbled over the tree stumps and branches and\nsplashed through the water that lay in the ruts.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s horse swerved aside to avoid a pool in the track and bumped\nhis rider\xe2\x80\x99s knee against a tree.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, the devil!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Den\xc3\xadsov angrily, and showing his teeth he\nstruck his horse three times with his whip, splashing himself and his\ncomrades with mud.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov was out of sorts both because of the rain and also from hunger\n(none of them had eaten anything since morning), and yet more because he\nstill had no news from D\xc3\xb3lokhov and the man sent to capture a \xe2\x80\x9ctongue\xe2\x80\x9d\nhad not returned.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99ll hardly be another such chance to fall on a transport as today.\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s too risky to attack them by oneself, and if we put it off till\nanother day one of the big guerrilla detachments will snatch the prey\nfrom under our noses,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Den\xc3\xadsov, continually peering forward,\nhoping to see a messenger from D\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\nOn coming to a path in the forest along which he could see far to the\nright, Den\xc3\xadsov stopped.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s someone coming,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\nThe esaul looked in the direction Den\xc3\xadsov indicated.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are two, an officer and a Cossack. But it is not presupposable\nthat it is the lieutenant colonel himself,\xe2\x80\x9d said the esaul, who was fond\nof using words the Cossacks did not know.\n\nThe approaching riders having descended a decline were no longer\nvisible, but they reappeared a few minutes later. In front, at a weary\ngallop and using his leather whip, rode an officer, disheveled and\ndrenched, whose trousers had worked up to above his knees. Behind him,\nstanding in the stirrups, trotted a Cossack. The officer, a very young\nlad with a broad rosy face and keen merry eyes, galloped up to Den\xc3\xadsov\nand handed him a sodden envelope.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom the general,\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer. \xe2\x80\x9cPlease excuse its not being quite\ndry.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov, frowning, took the envelope and opened it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, they kept telling us: \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s dangerous, it\xe2\x80\x99s dangerous,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid the officer, addressing the esaul while Den\xc3\xadsov was reading the\ndispatch. \xe2\x80\x9cBut Komar\xc3\xb3v and I\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he pointed to the Cossack\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwere prepared.\nWe have each of us two pistols.... But what\xe2\x80\x99s this?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, noticing\nthe French drummer boy. \xe2\x80\x9cA prisoner? You\xe2\x80\x99ve already been in action? May\nI speak to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWost\xc3\xb3v! P\xc3\xa9tya!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Den\xc3\xadsov, having run through the dispatch.\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t you say who you were?\xe2\x80\x9d and turning with a smile he held out\nhis hand to the lad.\n\nThe officer was P\xc3\xa9tya Rost\xc3\xb3v.\n\nAll the way P\xc3\xa9tya had been preparing himself to behave with Den\xc3\xadsov as\nbefitted a grown-up man and an officer\xe2\x80\x94without hinting at their previous\nacquaintance. But as soon as Den\xc3\xadsov smiled at him P\xc3\xa9tya brightened\nup, blushed with pleasure, forgot the official manner he had been\nrehearsing, and began telling him how he had already been in a battle\nnear Vy\xc3\xa1zma and how a certain hussar had distinguished himself there.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I am glad to see you,\xe2\x80\x9d Den\xc3\xadsov interrupted him, and his face\nagain assumed its anxious expression.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMichael Feokl\xc3\xadtych,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to the esaul, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is again fwom that\nGerman, you know. He\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he indicated P\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cis serving under him.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd Den\xc3\xadsov told the esaul that the dispatch just delivered was a\nrepetition of the German general\xe2\x80\x99s demand that he should join forces\nwith him for an attack on the transport.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we don\xe2\x80\x99t take it tomowwow, he\xe2\x80\x99ll snatch it fwom under our noses,\xe2\x80\x9d he\nadded.\n\nWhile Den\xc3\xadsov was talking to the esaul, P\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x94abashed by Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s\ncold tone and supposing that it was due to the condition of his\ntrousers\xe2\x80\x94furtively tried to pull them down under his greatcoat so\nthat no one should notice it, while maintaining as martial an air as\npossible.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill there be any orders, your honor?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked Den\xc3\xadsov, holding his\nhand at the salute and resuming the game of adjutant and general for\nwhich he had prepared himself, \xe2\x80\x9cor shall I remain with your honor?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOrders?\xe2\x80\x9d Den\xc3\xadsov repeated thoughtfully. \xe2\x80\x9cBut can you stay till\ntomowwow?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, please... May I stay with you?\xe2\x80\x9d cried P\xc3\xa9tya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, just what did the genewal tell you? To weturn at once?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\nDen\xc3\xadsov.\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya blushed.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe gave me no instructions. I think I could?\xe2\x80\x9d he returned, inquiringly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, all wight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\nAnd turning to his men he directed a party to go on to the halting place\narranged near the watchman\xe2\x80\x99s hut in the forest, and told the officer on\nthe Kirgh\xc3\xadz horse (who performed the duties of an adjutant) to go and\nfind out where D\xc3\xb3lokhov was and whether he would come that evening.\nDen\xc3\xadsov himself intended going with the esaul and P\xc3\xa9tya to the edge of\nthe forest where it reached out to Sh\xc3\xa1mshevo, to have a look at the part\nof the French bivouac they were to attack next day.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, old fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to the peasant guide, \xe2\x80\x9clead us to\nSh\xc3\xa1mshevo.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov, P\xc3\xa9tya, and the esaul, accompanied by some Cossacks and the\nhussar who had the prisoner, rode to the left across a ravine to the\nedge of the forest.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER V\n\nThe rain had stopped, and only the mist was falling and drops from\nthe trees. Den\xc3\xadsov, the esaul, and P\xc3\xa9tya rode silently, following the\npeasant in the knitted cap who, stepping lightly with outturned toes\nand moving noiselessly in his bast shoes over the roots and wet leaves,\nsilently led them to the edge of the forest.\n\nHe ascended an incline, stopped, looked about him, and advanced to where\nthe screen of trees was less dense. On reaching a large oak tree that\nhad not yet shed its leaves, he stopped and beckoned mysteriously to\nthem with his hand.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov and P\xc3\xa9tya rode up to him. From the spot where the peasant was\nstanding they could see the French. Immediately beyond the forest, on a\ndownward slope, lay a field of spring rye. To the right, beyond a steep\nravine, was a small village and a landowner\xe2\x80\x99s house with a broken roof.\nIn the village, in the house, in the garden, by the well, by the pond,\nover all the rising ground, and all along the road uphill from the\nbridge leading to the village, not more than five hundred yards\naway, crowds of men could be seen through the shimmering mist. Their\nun-Russian shouting at their horses which were straining uphill with the\ncarts, and their calls to one another, could be clearly heard.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBwing the prisoner here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov in a low voice, not taking his\neyes off the French.\n\nA Cossack dismounted, lifted the boy down, and took him to Den\xc3\xadsov.\nPointing to the French troops, Den\xc3\xadsov asked him what these and those\nof them were. The boy, thrusting his cold hands into his pockets and\nlifting his eyebrows, looked at Den\xc3\xadsov in affright, but in spite of\nan evident desire to say all he knew gave confused answers, merely\nassenting to everything Den\xc3\xadsov asked him. Den\xc3\xadsov turned away from him\nfrowning and addressed the esaul, conveying his own conjectures to him.\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya, rapidly turning his head, looked now at the drummer boy, now\nat Den\xc3\xadsov, now at the esaul, and now at the French in the village and\nalong the road, trying not to miss anything of importance.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhether D\xc3\xb3lokhov comes or not, we must seize it, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov with\na merry sparkle in his eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a very suitable spot,\xe2\x80\x9d said the esaul.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll send the infantwy down by the swamps,\xe2\x80\x9d Den\xc3\xadsov continued.\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ll cweep up to the garden; you\xe2\x80\x99ll wide up fwom there with the\nCossacks\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he pointed to a spot in the forest beyond the village\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand I\nwith my hussars fwom here. And at the signal shot...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe hollow is impassable\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s a swamp there,\xe2\x80\x9d said the esaul. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\nhorses would sink. We must ride round more to the left....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nWhile they were talking in undertones the crack of a shot sounded\nfrom the low ground by the pond, a puff of white smoke appeared, then\nanother, and the sound of hundreds of seemingly merry French voices\nshouting together came up from the slope. For a moment Den\xc3\xadsov and the\nesaul drew back. They were so near that they thought they were the cause\nof the firing and shouting. But the firing and shouting did not relate\nto them. Down below, a man wearing something red was running through the\nmarsh. The French were evidently firing and shouting at him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that\xe2\x80\x99s our T\xc3\xadkhon,\xe2\x80\x9d said the esaul.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo it is! It is!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe wascal!\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99ll get away!\xe2\x80\x9d said the esaul, screwing up his eyes.\n\nThe man whom they called T\xc3\xadkhon, having run to the stream, plunged in\nso that the water splashed in the air, and, having disappeared for an\ninstant, scrambled out on all fours, all black with the wet, and ran on.\nThe French who had been pursuing him stopped.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSmart, that!\xe2\x80\x9d said the esaul.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a beast!\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov with his former look of vexation. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat has\nhe been doing all this time?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is he?\xe2\x80\x9d asked P\xc3\xa9tya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s our plast\xc3\xban. I sent him to capture a \xe2\x80\x98tongue.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said P\xc3\xa9tya, nodding at the first words Den\xc3\xadsov uttered as if\nhe understood it all, though he really did not understand anything of\nit.\n\nT\xc3\xadkhon Shcherb\xc3\xa1ty was one of the most indispensable men in their band.\nHe was a peasant from Pokr\xc3\xb3vsk, near the river Gzhat. When Den\xc3\xadsov had\ncome to Pokr\xc3\xb3vsk at the beginning of his operations and had as usual\nsummoned the village elder and asked him what he knew about the French,\nthe elder, as though shielding himself, had replied, as all village\nelders did, that he had neither seen nor heard anything of them. But\nwhen Den\xc3\xadsov explained that his purpose was to kill the French, and\nasked if no French had strayed that way, the elder replied that some\n\xe2\x80\x9cmore-orderers\xe2\x80\x9d had really been at their village, but that T\xc3\xadkhon\nShcherb\xc3\xa1ty was the only man who dealt with such matters. Den\xc3\xadsov had\nT\xc3\xadkhon called and, having praised him for his activity, said a few words\nin the elder\xe2\x80\x99s presence about loyalty to the Tsar and the country and\nthe hatred of the French that all sons of the fatherland should cherish.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t do the French any harm,\xe2\x80\x9d said T\xc3\xadkhon, evidently frightened by\nDen\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s words. \xe2\x80\x9cWe only fooled about with the lads for fun, you know!\nWe killed a score or so of \xe2\x80\x98more-orderers,\xe2\x80\x99 but we did no harm else....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nNext day when Den\xc3\xadsov had left Pokr\xc3\xb3vsk, having quite forgotten about\nthis peasant, it was reported to him that T\xc3\xadkhon had attached himself\nto their party and asked to be allowed to remain with it. Den\xc3\xadsov gave\norders to let him do so.\n\nT\xc3\xadkhon, who at first did rough work, laying campfires, fetching water,\nflaying dead horses, and so on, soon showed a great liking and aptitude\nfor partisan warfare. At night he would go out for booty and always\nbrought back French clothing and weapons, and when told to would bring\nin French captives also. Den\xc3\xadsov then relieved him from drudgery and\nbegan taking him with him when he went out on expeditions and had him\nenrolled among the Cossacks.\n\nT\xc3\xadkhon did not like riding, and always went on foot, never lagging\nbehind the cavalry. He was armed with a musketoon (which he carried\nrather as a joke), a pike and an ax, which latter he used as a wolf uses\nits teeth, with equal ease picking fleas out of its fur or crunching\nthick bones. T\xc3\xadkhon with equal accuracy would split logs with blows at\narm\xe2\x80\x99s length, or holding the head of the ax would cut thin little pegs\nor carve spoons. In Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s party he held a peculiar and exceptional\nposition. When anything particularly difficult or nasty had to be\ndone\xe2\x80\x94to push a cart out of the mud with one\xe2\x80\x99s shoulders, pull a horse\nout of a swamp by its tail, skin it, slink in among the French, or walk\nmore than thirty miles in a day\xe2\x80\x94everybody pointed laughingly at T\xc3\xadkhon.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt won\xe2\x80\x99t hurt that devil\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s as strong as a horse!\xe2\x80\x9d they said of him.\n\nOnce a Frenchman T\xc3\xadkhon was trying to capture fired a pistol at him\nand shot him in the fleshy part of the back. That wound (which T\xc3\xadkhon\ntreated only with internal and external applications of vodka) was the\nsubject of the liveliest jokes by the whole detachment\xe2\x80\x94jokes in which\nT\xc3\xadkhon readily joined.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHallo, mate! Never again? Gave you a twist?\xe2\x80\x9d the Cossacks would banter\nhim. And T\xc3\xadkhon, purposely writhing and making faces, pretended to be\nangry and swore at the French with the funniest curses. The only effect\nof this incident on T\xc3\xadkhon was that after being wounded he seldom\nbrought in prisoners.\n\nHe was the bravest and most useful man in the party. No one found more\nopportunities for attacking, no one captured or killed more Frenchmen,\nand consequently he was made the buffoon of all the Cossacks and hussars\nand willingly accepted that role. Now he had been sent by Den\xc3\xadsov\novernight to Sh\xc3\xa1mshevo to capture a \xe2\x80\x9ctongue.\xe2\x80\x9d But whether because he\nhad not been content to take only one Frenchman or because he had slept\nthrough the night, he had crept by day into some bushes right among the\nFrench and, as Den\xc3\xadsov had witnessed from above, had been detected by\nthem.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VI\n\nAfter talking for some time with the esaul about next day\xe2\x80\x99s attack,\nwhich now, seeing how near they were to the French, he seemed to have\ndefinitely decided on, Den\xc3\xadsov turned his horse and rode back.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, my lad, we\xe2\x80\x99ll go and get dwy,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to P\xc3\xa9tya.\n\nAs they approached the watchhouse Den\xc3\xadsov stopped, peering into the\nforest. Among the trees a man with long legs and long, swinging arms,\nwearing a short jacket, bast shoes, and a Kaz\xc3\xa1n hat, was approaching\nwith long, light steps. He had a musketoon over his shoulder and an ax\nstuck in his girdle. When he espied Den\xc3\xadsov he hastily threw something\ninto the bushes, removed his sodden hat by its floppy brim, and\napproached his commander. It was T\xc3\xadkhon. His wrinkled and pockmarked\nface and narrow little eyes beamed with self-satisfied merriment. He\nlifted his head high and gazed at Den\xc3\xadsov as if repressing a laugh.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, where did you disappear to?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere did I disappear to? I went to get Frenchmen,\xe2\x80\x9d answered T\xc3\xadkhon\nboldly and hurriedly, in a husky but melodious bass voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you push yourself in there by daylight? You ass! Well, why\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t you taken one?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I took one all right,\xe2\x80\x9d said T\xc3\xadkhon.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, I took him first thing at dawn,\xe2\x80\x9d T\xc3\xadkhon continued, spreading\nout his flat feet with outturned toes in their bast shoes. \xe2\x80\x9cI took him\ninto the forest. Then I see he\xe2\x80\x99s no good and think I\xe2\x80\x99ll go and fetch a\nlikelier one.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see?... What a wogue\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s just as I thought,\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov to the\nesaul. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t you bwing that one?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was the good of bringing him?\xe2\x80\x9d T\xc3\xadkhon interrupted hastily and\nangrily\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthat one wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have done for you. As if I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what\nsort you want!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a bwute you are!... Well?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI went for another one,\xe2\x80\x9d T\xc3\xadkhon continued, \xe2\x80\x9cand I crept like this\nthrough the wood and lay down.\xe2\x80\x9d (He suddenly lay down on his stomach\nwith a supple movement to show how he had done it.) \xe2\x80\x9cOne turned up and\nI grabbed him, like this.\xe2\x80\x9d (He jumped up quickly and lightly.) \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Come\nalong to the colonel,\xe2\x80\x99 I said. He starts yelling, and suddenly there\nwere four of them. They rushed at me with their little swords. So I went\nfor them with my ax, this way: \xe2\x80\x98What are you up to?\xe2\x80\x99 says I. \xe2\x80\x98Christ\nbe with you!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d shouted T\xc3\xadkhon, waving his arms with an angry scowl and\nthrowing out his chest.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, we saw from the hill how you took to your heels through the\npuddles!\xe2\x80\x9d said the esaul, screwing up his glittering eyes.\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya badly wanted to laugh, but noticed that they all refrained from\nlaughing. He turned his eyes rapidly from T\xc3\xadkhon\xe2\x80\x99s face to the esaul\xe2\x80\x99s\nand Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s, unable to make out what it all meant.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t play the fool!\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov, coughing angrily. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t you\nbwing the first one?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nT\xc3\xadkhon scratched his back with one hand and his head with the other,\nthen suddenly his whole face expanded into a beaming, foolish grin,\ndisclosing a gap where he had lost a tooth (that was why he was called\nShcherb\xc3\xa1ty\xe2\x80\x94the gap-toothed). Den\xc3\xadsov smiled, and P\xc3\xa9tya burst into a peal\nof merry laughter in which T\xc3\xadkhon himself joined.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, but he was a regular good-for-nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said T\xc3\xadkhon. \xe2\x80\x9cThe clothes\non him\xe2\x80\x94poor stuff! How could I bring him? And so rude, your honor! Why,\nhe says: \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m a general\xe2\x80\x99s son myself, I won\xe2\x80\x99t go!\xe2\x80\x99 he says.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a bwute!\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov. \xe2\x80\x9cI wanted to question...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I questioned him,\xe2\x80\x9d said T\xc3\xadkhon. \xe2\x80\x9cHe said he didn\xe2\x80\x99t know much.\n\xe2\x80\x98There are a lot of us,\xe2\x80\x99 he says, \xe2\x80\x98but all poor stuff\xe2\x80\x94only soldiers in\nname,\xe2\x80\x99 he says. \xe2\x80\x98Shout loud at them,\xe2\x80\x99 he says, \xe2\x80\x98and you\xe2\x80\x99ll take\nthem all,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d T\xc3\xadkhon concluded, looking cheerfully and resolutely into\nDen\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s eyes.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll give you a hundwed sharp lashes\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99ll teach you to play the\nfool!\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov severely.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why are you angry?\xe2\x80\x9d remonstrated T\xc3\xadkhon, \xe2\x80\x9cjust as if I\xe2\x80\x99d never seen\nyour Frenchmen! Only wait till it gets dark and I\xe2\x80\x99ll fetch you any of\nthem you want\xe2\x80\x94three if you like.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, let\xe2\x80\x99s go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov, and rode all the way to the watchhouse\nin silence and frowning angrily.\n\nT\xc3\xadkhon followed behind and P\xc3\xa9tya heard the Cossacks laughing with him\nand at him, about some pair of boots he had thrown into the bushes.\n\nWhen the fit of laughter that had seized him at T\xc3\xadkhon\xe2\x80\x99s words and smile\nhad passed and P\xc3\xa9tya realized for a moment that this T\xc3\xadkhon had killed a\nman, he felt uneasy. He looked round at the captive drummer boy and felt\na pang in his heart. But this uneasiness lasted only a moment. He felt\nit necessary to hold his head higher, to brace himself, and to question\nthe esaul with an air of importance about tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s undertaking, that\nhe might not be unworthy of the company in which he found himself.\n\nThe officer who had been sent to inquire met Den\xc3\xadsov on the way with the\nnews that D\xc3\xb3lokhov was soon coming and that all was well with him.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov at once cheered up and, calling P\xc3\xa9tya to him, said: \xe2\x80\x9cWell, tell\nme about yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VII\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya, having left his people after their departure from Moscow, joined\nhis regiment and was soon taken as orderly by a general commanding a\nlarge guerrilla detachment. From the time he received his commission,\nand especially since he had joined the active army and taken part in\nthe battle of Vy\xc3\xa1zma, P\xc3\xa9tya had been in a constant state of blissful\nexcitement at being grown-up and in a perpetual ecstatic hurry not to\nmiss any chance to do something really heroic. He was highly delighted\nwith what he saw and experienced in the army, but at the same time\nit always seemed to him that the really heroic exploits were being\nperformed just where he did not happen to be. And he was always in a\nhurry to get where he was not.\n\nWhen on the twenty-first of October his general expressed a wish to send\nsomebody to Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s detachment, P\xc3\xa9tya begged so piteously to be sent\nthat the general could not refuse. But when dispatching him he recalled\nP\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x99s mad action at the battle of Vy\xc3\xa1zma, where instead of riding by\nthe road to the place to which he had been sent, he had galloped to the\nadvanced line under the fire of the French and had there twice fired\nhis pistol. So now the general explicitly forbade his taking part in any\naction whatever of Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s. That was why P\xc3\xa9tya had blushed and grown\nconfused when Den\xc3\xadsov asked him whether he could stay. Before they had\nridden to the outskirts of the forest P\xc3\xa9tya had considered he must carry\nout his instructions strictly and return at once. But when he saw the\nFrench and saw T\xc3\xadkhon and learned that there would certainly be an\nattack that night, he decided, with the rapidity with which young people\nchange their views, that the general, whom he had greatly respected till\nthen, was a rubbishy German, that Den\xc3\xadsov was a hero, the esaul a hero,\nand T\xc3\xadkhon a hero too, and that it would be shameful for him to leave\nthem at a moment of difficulty.\n\nIt was already growing dusk when Den\xc3\xadsov, P\xc3\xa9tya, and the esaul rode up\nto the watchhouse. In the twilight saddled horses could be seen, and\nCossacks and hussars who had rigged up rough shelters in the glade and\nwere kindling glowing fires in a hollow of the forest where the French\ncould not see the smoke. In the passage of the small watchhouse a\nCossack with sleeves rolled up was chopping some mutton. In the room\nthree officers of Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s band were converting a door into a tabletop.\nP\xc3\xa9tya took off his wet clothes, gave them to be dried, and at once began\nhelping the officers to fix up the dinner table.\n\nIn ten minutes the table was ready and a napkin spread on it. On the\ntable were vodka, a flask of rum, white bread, roast mutton, and salt.\n\nSitting at table with the officers and tearing the fat savory mutton\nwith his hands, down which the grease trickled, P\xc3\xa9tya was in an ecstatic\nchildish state of love for all men, and consequently of confidence that\nothers loved him in the same way.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo then what do you think, Vas\xc3\xadli Dm\xc3\xadtrich?\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Den\xc3\xadsov. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s\nall right my staying a day with you?\xe2\x80\x9d And not waiting for a reply he\nanswered his own question: \xe2\x80\x9cYou see I was told to find out\xe2\x80\x94well, I am\nfinding out.... Only do let me into the very... into the chief... I\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t want a reward.... But I want...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya clenched his teeth and looked around, throwing back his head and\nflourishing his arms.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cInto the vewy chief...\xe2\x80\x9d Den\xc3\xadsov repeated with a smile.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly, please let me command something, so that I may really command...\xe2\x80\x9d\nP\xc3\xa9tya went on. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat would it be to you?... Oh, you want a knife?\xe2\x80\x9d he\nsaid, turning to an officer who wished to cut himself a piece of mutton.\n\nAnd he handed him his clasp knife. The officer admired it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease keep it. I have several like it,\xe2\x80\x9d said P\xc3\xa9tya, blushing.\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeavens! I was quite forgetting!\xe2\x80\x9d he suddenly cried. \xe2\x80\x9cI have some\nraisins, fine ones; you know, seedless ones. We have a new sutler and\nhe has such capital things. I bought ten pounds. I am used to something\nsweet. Would you like some?...\xe2\x80\x9d and P\xc3\xa9tya ran out into the passage to\nhis Cossack and brought back some bags which contained about five pounds\nof raisins. \xe2\x80\x9cHave some, gentlemen, have some!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou want a coffeepot, don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked the esaul. \xe2\x80\x9cI bought a\ncapital one from our sutler! He has splendid things. And he\xe2\x80\x99s very\nhonest, that\xe2\x80\x99s the chief thing. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be sure to send it to you. Or\nperhaps your flints are giving out, or are worn out\xe2\x80\x94that happens\nsometimes, you know. I have brought some with me, here they are\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and he\nshowed a bag\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ca hundred flints. I bought them very cheap. Please take as\nmany as you want, or all if you like....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThen suddenly, dismayed lest he had said too much, P\xc3\xa9tya stopped and\nblushed.\n\nHe tried to remember whether he had not done anything else that was\nfoolish. And running over the events of the day he remembered the French\ndrummer boy. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s capital for us here, but what of him? Where have they\nput him? Have they fed him? Haven\xe2\x80\x99t they hurt his feelings?\xe2\x80\x9d he thought.\nBut having caught himself saying too much about the flints, he was now\nafraid to speak out.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI might ask,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, \xe2\x80\x9cbut they\xe2\x80\x99ll say: \xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s a boy himself and so\nhe pities the boy.\xe2\x80\x99 I\xe2\x80\x99ll show them tomorrow whether I\xe2\x80\x99m a boy. Will it\nseem odd if I ask?\xe2\x80\x9d P\xc3\xa9tya thought. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, never mind!\xe2\x80\x9d and immediately,\nblushing and looking anxiously at the officers to see if they appeared\nironical, he said:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I call in that boy who was taken prisoner and give him something to\neat?... Perhaps...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he\xe2\x80\x99s a poor little fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov, who evidently saw\nnothing shameful in this reminder. \xe2\x80\x9cCall him in. His name is Vincent\nBosse. Have him fetched.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll call him,\xe2\x80\x9d said P\xc3\xa9tya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, call him. A poor little fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d Den\xc3\xadsov repeated.\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya was standing at the door when Den\xc3\xadsov said this. He slipped in\nbetween the officers, came close to Den\xc3\xadsov, and said:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me kiss you, dear old fellow! Oh, how fine, how splendid!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd having kissed Den\xc3\xadsov he ran out of the hut.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBosse! Vincent!\xe2\x80\x9d P\xc3\xa9tya cried, stopping outside the door.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho do you want, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked a voice in the darkness.\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya replied that he wanted the French lad who had been captured that\nday.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Ves\xc3\xa9nny?\xe2\x80\x9d said a Cossack.\n\nVincent, the boy\xe2\x80\x99s name, had already been changed by the Cossacks into\nVes\xc3\xa9nny (vernal) and into Ves\xc3\xa9nya by the peasants and soldiers. In both\nthese adaptations the reference to spring (vesn\xc3\xa1) matched the impression\nmade by the young lad.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is warming himself there by the bonfire. Ho, Ves\xc3\xa9nya!\nVes\xc3\xa9nya!\xe2\x80\x94Ves\xc3\xa9nny!\xe2\x80\x9d laughing voices were heard calling to one another in\nthe darkness.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s a smart lad,\xe2\x80\x9d said an hussar standing near P\xc3\xa9tya. \xe2\x80\x9cWe gave him\nsomething to eat a while ago. He was awfully hungry!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe sound of bare feet splashing through the mud was heard in the\ndarkness, and the drummer boy came to the door.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, c\xe2\x80\x99est vous!\xe2\x80\x9d said P\xc3\xa9tya. \xe2\x80\x9cVoulez-vous manger? N\xe2\x80\x99ayez pas peur, on\nne vous fera pas de mal,\xe2\x80\x9d * he added shyly and affectionately, touching\nthe boy\xe2\x80\x99s hand. \xe2\x80\x9cEntrez, entrez.\xe2\x80\x9d *(2)\n\n     * \xe2\x80\x9cAh, it\xe2\x80\x99s you! Do you want something to eat? Don\xe2\x80\x99t be\n     afraid, they won\xe2\x80\x99t hurt you.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n     * (2) \xe2\x80\x9cCome in, come in.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerci, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d * said the drummer boy in a trembling almost childish\nvoice, and he began scraping his dirty feet on the threshold.\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cThank you, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nThere were many things P\xc3\xa9tya wanted to say to the drummer boy, but did\nnot dare to. He stood irresolutely beside him in the passage. Then in\nthe darkness he took the boy\xe2\x80\x99s hand and pressed it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in, come in!\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated in a gentle whisper. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, what can I do\nfor him?\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, and opening the door he let the boy pass in first.\n\nWhen the boy had entered the hut, P\xc3\xa9tya sat down at a distance from\nhim, considering it beneath his dignity to pay attention to him. But\nhe fingered the money in his pocket and wondered whether it would seem\nridiculous to give some to the drummer boy.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER VIII\n\nThe arrival of D\xc3\xb3lokhov diverted P\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x99s attention from the drummer boy,\nto whom Den\xc3\xadsov had had some mutton and vodka given, and whom he had had\ndressed in a Russian coat so that he might be kept with their band and\nnot sent away with the other prisoners. P\xc3\xa9tya had heard in the army many\nstories of D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s extraordinary bravery and of his cruelty to the\nFrench, so from the moment he entered the hut P\xc3\xa9tya did not take his\neyes from him, but braced himself up more and more and held his head\nhigh, that he might not be unworthy even of such company.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s appearance amazed P\xc3\xa9tya by its simplicity.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov wore a Cossack coat, had a beard, had an icon of Nicholas the\nWonder-Worker on his breast, and his way of speaking and everything he\ndid indicated his unusual position. But D\xc3\xb3lokhov, who in Moscow had worn\na Persian costume, had now the appearance of a most correct officer of\nthe Guards. He was clean-shaven and wore a Guardsman\xe2\x80\x99s padded coat with\nan Order of St. George at his buttonhole and a plain forage cap set\nstraight on his head. He took off his wet felt cloak in a corner of\nthe room, and without greeting anyone went up to Den\xc3\xadsov and began\nquestioning him about the matter in hand. Den\xc3\xadsov told him of the\ndesigns the large detachments had on the transport, of the message P\xc3\xa9tya\nhad brought, and his own replies to both generals. Then he told him all\nhe knew of the French detachment.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s so. But we must know what troops they are and their numbers,\xe2\x80\x9d\nsaid D\xc3\xb3lokhov. \xe2\x80\x9cIt will be necessary to go there. We can\xe2\x80\x99t start the\naffair without knowing for certain how many there are. I like to work\naccurately. Here now\xe2\x80\x94wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t one of these gentlemen like to ride over\nto the French camp with me? I have brought a spare uniform.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, I... I\xe2\x80\x99ll go with you!\xe2\x80\x9d cried P\xc3\xa9tya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no need for you to go at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Den\xc3\xadsov, addressing\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov, \xe2\x80\x9cand as for him, I won\xe2\x80\x99t let him go on any account.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI like that!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed P\xc3\xa9tya. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t I go?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause it\xe2\x80\x99s useless.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you must excuse me, because... because... I shall go, and that\xe2\x80\x99s\nall. You\xe2\x80\x99ll take me, won\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, turning to D\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d D\xc3\xb3lokhov answered absently, scrutinizing the face of the\nFrench drummer boy. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you had that youngster with you long?\xe2\x80\x9d he\nasked Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was taken today but he knows nothing. I\xe2\x80\x99m keeping him with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and where do you put the others?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired D\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere? I send them away and take a weceipt for them,\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Den\xc3\xadsov,\nsuddenly flushing. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd I say boldly that I have not a single man\xe2\x80\x99s life\non my conscience. Would it be difficult for you to send thirty or\nthwee hundwed men to town under escort, instead of staining\xe2\x80\x94I speak\nbluntly\xe2\x80\x94staining the honor of a soldier?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat kind of amiable talk would be suitable from this young count of\nsixteen,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov with cold irony, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it\xe2\x80\x99s time for you to drop\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I\xe2\x80\x99ve not said anything! I only say that I\xe2\x80\x99ll certainly go with\nyou,\xe2\x80\x9d said P\xc3\xa9tya shyly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut for you and me, old fellow, it\xe2\x80\x99s time to drop these amenities,\xe2\x80\x9d\ncontinued D\xc3\xb3lokhov, as if he found particular pleasure in speaking of\nthis subject which irritated Den\xc3\xadsov. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, why have you kept this lad?\xe2\x80\x9d\nhe went on, swaying his head. \xe2\x80\x9cBecause you are sorry for him! Don\xe2\x80\x99t we\nknow those \xe2\x80\x98receipts\xe2\x80\x99 of yours? You send a hundred men away, and thirty\nget there. The rest either starve or get killed. So isn\xe2\x80\x99t it all the\nsame not to send them?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe esaul, screwing up his light-colored eyes, nodded approvingly.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s not the point. I\xe2\x80\x99m not going to discuss the matter. I do not\nwish to take it on my conscience. You say they\xe2\x80\x99ll die. All wight. Only\nnot by my fault!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov began laughing.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho has told them not to capture me these twenty times over? But if\nthey did catch me they\xe2\x80\x99d string me up to an aspen tree, and with all\nyour chivalry just the same.\xe2\x80\x9d He paused. \xe2\x80\x9cHowever, we must get to work.\nTell the Cossack to fetch my kit. I have two French uniforms in it.\nWell, are you coming with me?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked P\xc3\xa9tya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? Yes, yes, certainly!\xe2\x80\x9d cried P\xc3\xa9tya, blushing almost to tears and\nglancing at Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\nWhile D\xc3\xb3lokhov had been disputing with Den\xc3\xadsov what should be done with\nprisoners, P\xc3\xa9tya had once more felt awkward and restless; but again he\nhad no time to grasp fully what they were talking about. \xe2\x80\x9cIf grown-up,\ndistinguished men think so, it must be necessary and right,\xe2\x80\x9d thought he.\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut above all Den\xc3\xadsov must not dare to imagine that I\xe2\x80\x99ll obey him and\nthat he can order me about. I will certainly go to the French camp with\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov. If he can, so can I!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd to all Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s persuasions, P\xc3\xa9tya replied that he too was\naccustomed to do everything accurately and not just anyhow, and that he\nnever considered personal danger.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor you\xe2\x80\x99ll admit that if we don\xe2\x80\x99t know for sure how many of them there\nare... hundreds of lives may depend on it, while there are only two\nof us. Besides, I want to go very much and certainly will go, so don\xe2\x80\x99t\nhinder me,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cIt will only make things worse....\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER IX\n\nHaving put on French greatcoats and shakos, P\xc3\xa9tya and D\xc3\xb3lokhov rode to\nthe clearing from which Den\xc3\xadsov had reconnoitered the French camp,\nand emerging from the forest in pitch darkness they descended into the\nhollow. On reaching the bottom, D\xc3\xb3lokhov told the Cossacks accompanying\nhim to await him there and rode on at a quick trot along the road to the\nbridge. P\xc3\xa9tya, his heart in his mouth with excitement, rode by his side.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we\xe2\x80\x99re caught, I won\xe2\x80\x99t be taken alive! I have a pistol,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered\nhe.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t talk Russian,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov in a hurried whisper, and at that\nvery moment they heard through the darkness the challenge: \xe2\x80\x9cQui vive?\xe2\x80\x9d *\nand the click of a musket.\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cWho goes there?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nThe blood rushed to P\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x99s face and he grasped his pistol.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cLanciers du 6-me,\xe2\x80\x9d * replied D\xc3\xb3lokhov, neither hastening nor slackening\nhis horse\xe2\x80\x99s pace.\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cLancers of the 6th Regiment.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nThe black figure of a sentinel stood on the bridge.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMot d\xe2\x80\x99ordre.\xe2\x80\x9d *\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cPassword.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov reined in his horse and advanced at a walk.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDites donc, le colonel G\xc3\xa9rard est ici?\xe2\x80\x9d * he asked.\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cTell me, is Colonel G\xc3\xa9rard here?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cMot d\xe2\x80\x99ordre,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the sentinel, barring the way and not replying.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuand un officier fait sa ronde, les sentinelles ne demandent pas le\nmot d\xe2\x80\x99ordre...\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xc3\xb3lokhov suddenly flaring up and riding straight\nat the sentinel. \xe2\x80\x9cJe vous demande si le colonel est ici.\xe2\x80\x9d *\n\n     * \xe2\x80\x9cWhen an officer is making his round, sentinels don\xe2\x80\x99t ask\n     him for the password.... I am asking you if the colonel is\n     here.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nAnd without waiting for an answer from the sentinel, who had stepped\naside, D\xc3\xb3lokhov rode up the incline at a walk.\n\nNoticing the black outline of a man crossing the road, D\xc3\xb3lokhov stopped\nhim and inquired where the commander and officers were. The man,\na soldier with a sack over his shoulder, stopped, came close up to\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s horse, touched it with his hand, and explained simply and in\na friendly way that the commander and the officers were higher up\nthe hill to the right in the courtyard of the farm, as he called the\nlandowner\xe2\x80\x99s house.\n\nHaving ridden up the road, on both sides of which French talk could be\nheard around the campfires, D\xc3\xb3lokhov turned into the courtyard of the\nlandowner\xe2\x80\x99s house. Having ridden in, he dismounted and approached a\nbig blazing campfire, around which sat several men talking noisily.\nSomething was boiling in a small cauldron at the edge of the fire and\na soldier in a peaked cap and blue overcoat, lit up by the fire, was\nkneeling beside it stirring its contents with a ramrod.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he\xe2\x80\x99s a hard nut to crack,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the officers who was sitting\nin the shadow at the other side of the fire.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99ll make them get a move on, those fellows!\xe2\x80\x9d said another, laughing.\n\nBoth fell silent, peering out through the darkness at the sound of\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s and P\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x99s steps as they advanced to the fire leading their\nhorses.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBonjour, messieurs!\xe2\x80\x9d * said D\xc3\xb3lokhov loudly and clearly.\n\n    * \xe2\x80\x9cGood day, gentlemen.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\nThere was a stir among the officers in the shadow beyond the fire,\nand one tall, long-necked officer, walking round the fire, came up to\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that you, Cl\xc3\xa9ment?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere the devil...?\xe2\x80\x9d But, noticing\nhis mistake, he broke off short and, with a frown, greeted D\xc3\xb3lokhov as a\nstranger, asking what he could do for him.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov said that he and his companion were trying to overtake their\nregiment, and addressing the company in general asked whether they knew\nanything of the 6th Regiment. None of them knew anything, and P\xc3\xa9tya\nthought the officers were beginning to look at him and D\xc3\xb3lokhov with\nhostility and suspicion. For some seconds all were silent.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you were counting on the evening soup, you have come too late,\xe2\x80\x9d said\na voice from behind the fire with a repressed laugh.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov replied that they were not hungry and must push on farther that\nnight.\n\nHe handed the horses over to the soldier who was stirring the pot and\nsquatted down on his heels by the fire beside the officer with the long\nneck. That officer did not take his eyes from D\xc3\xb3lokhov and again asked\nto what regiment he belonged. D\xc3\xb3lokhov, as if he had not heard the\nquestion, did not reply, but lighting a short French pipe which he took\nfrom his pocket began asking the officer in how far the road before them\nwas safe from Cossacks.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose brigands are everywhere,\xe2\x80\x9d replied an officer from behind the\nfire.\n\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov remarked that the Cossacks were a danger only to stragglers\nsuch as his companion and himself, \xe2\x80\x9cbut probably they would not dare to\nattack large detachments?\xe2\x80\x9d he added inquiringly. No one replied.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now he\xe2\x80\x99ll come away,\xe2\x80\x9d P\xc3\xa9tya thought every moment as he stood by\nthe campfire listening to the talk.\n\nBut D\xc3\xb3lokhov restarted the conversation which had dropped and began\nputting direct questions as to how many men there were in the battalion,\nhow many battalions, and how many prisoners. Asking about the Russian\nprisoners with that detachment, D\xc3\xb3lokhov said:\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cA horrid business dragging these corpses about with one! It would be\nbetter to shoot such rabble,\xe2\x80\x9d and burst into loud laughter, so strange\nthat P\xc3\xa9tya thought the French would immediately detect their disguise,\nand involuntarily took a step back from the campfire.\n\nNo one replied a word to D\xc3\xb3lokhov\xe2\x80\x99s laughter, and a French officer whom\nthey could not see (he lay wrapped in a greatcoat) rose and whispered\nsomething to a companion. D\xc3\xb3lokhov got up and called to the soldier who\nwas holding their horses.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill they bring our horses or not?\xe2\x80\x9d thought P\xc3\xa9tya, instinctively\ndrawing nearer to D\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\nThe horses were brought.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood evening, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov.\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya wished to say \xe2\x80\x9cGood night\xe2\x80\x9d but could not utter a word. The\nofficers were whispering together. D\xc3\xb3lokhov was a long time mounting\nhis horse which would not stand still, then he rode out of the yard at a\nfootpace. P\xc3\xa9tya rode beside him, longing to look round to see whether or\nnot the French were running after them, but not daring to.\n\nComing out onto the road D\xc3\xb3lokhov did not ride back across the open\ncountry, but through the village. At one spot he stopped and listened.\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you hear?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. P\xc3\xa9tya recognized the sound of Russian voices\nand saw the dark figures of Russian prisoners round their campfires.\nWhen they had descended to the bridge P\xc3\xa9tya and D\xc3\xb3lokhov rode past the\nsentinel, who without saying a word paced morosely up and down it, then\nthey descended into the hollow where the Cossacks awaited them.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell now, good-by. Tell Den\xc3\xadsov, \xe2\x80\x98at the first shot at daybreak,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said\nD\xc3\xb3lokhov and was about to ride away, but P\xc3\xa9tya seized hold of him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are such a hero! Oh, how fine, how splendid!\nHow I love you!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, all right!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xc3\xb3lokhov. But P\xc3\xa9tya did not let go of him\nand D\xc3\xb3lokhov saw through the gloom that P\xc3\xa9tya was bending toward him and\nwanted to kiss him. D\xc3\xb3lokhov kissed him, laughed, turned his horse, and\nvanished into the darkness.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER X\n\nHaving returned to the watchman\xe2\x80\x99s hut, P\xc3\xa9tya found Den\xc3\xadsov in the\npassage. He was awaiting P\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x99s return in a state of agitation,\nanxiety, and self-reproach for having let him go.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank God!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, thank God!\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, listening to\nP\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x99s rapturous account. \xe2\x80\x9cBut, devil take you, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t slept because\nof you! Well, thank God. Now lie down. We can still get a nap before\nmorning.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut... no,\xe2\x80\x9d said P\xc3\xa9tya, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to sleep yet. Besides I know\nmyself, if I fall asleep it\xe2\x80\x99s finished. And then I am used to not\nsleeping before a battle.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe sat awhile in the hut joyfully recalling the details of his\nexpedition and vividly picturing to himself what would happen next day.\n\nThen, noticing that Den\xc3\xadsov was asleep, he rose and went out of doors.\n\nIt was still quite dark outside. The rain was over, but drops were still\nfalling from the trees. Near the watchman\xe2\x80\x99s hut the black shapes of the\nCossacks\xe2\x80\x99 shanties and of horses tethered together could be seen. Behind\nthe hut the dark shapes of the two wagons with their horses beside them\nwere discernible, and in the hollow the dying campfire gleamed red.\nNot all the Cossacks and hussars were asleep; here and there, amid the\nsounds of falling drops and the munching of the horses near by, could be\nheard low voices which seemed to be whispering.\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya came out, peered into the darkness, and went up to the wagons.\nSomeone was snoring under them, and around them stood saddled horses\nmunching their oats. In the dark P\xc3\xa9tya recognized his own horse, which\nhe called \xe2\x80\x9cKarab\xc3\xa1kh\xe2\x80\x9d though it was of Ukranian breed, and went up to it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Karab\xc3\xa1kh! We\xe2\x80\x99ll do some service tomorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, sniffing its\nnostrils and kissing it.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy aren\xe2\x80\x99t you asleep, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d said a Cossack who was sitting under a\nwagon.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, ah... Likhach\xc3\xabv\xe2\x80\x94isn\xe2\x80\x99t that your name? Do you know I have only just\ncome back! We\xe2\x80\x99ve been into the French camp.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAnd P\xc3\xa9tya gave the Cossack a detailed account not only of his ride but\nalso of his object, and why he considered it better to risk his life\nthan to act \xe2\x80\x9cjust anyhow.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you should get some sleep now,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Cossack.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I am used to this,\xe2\x80\x9d said P\xc3\xa9tya. \xe2\x80\x9cI say, aren\xe2\x80\x99t the flints in your\npistols worn out? I brought some with me. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you want any? You can\nhave some.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe Cossack bent forward from under the wagon to get a closer look at\nP\xc3\xa9tya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I am accustomed to doing everything accurately,\xe2\x80\x9d said P\xc3\xa9tya.\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome fellows do things just anyhow, without preparation, and then\nthey\xe2\x80\x99re sorry for it afterwards. I don\xe2\x80\x99t like that.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Cossack.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, another thing! Please, my dear fellow, will you sharpen my\nsaber for me? It\xe2\x80\x99s got bl...\xe2\x80\x9d (P\xc3\xa9tya feared to tell a lie, and the saber\nnever had been sharpened.) \xe2\x80\x9cCan you do it?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course I can.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nLikhach\xc3\xabv got up, rummaged in his pack, and soon P\xc3\xa9tya heard the warlike\nsound of steel on whetstone. He climbed onto the wagon and sat on its\nedge. The Cossack was sharpening the saber under the wagon.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say! Are the lads asleep?\xe2\x80\x9d asked P\xc3\xa9tya.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome are, and some aren\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x94like us.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and that boy?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVes\xc3\xa9nny? Oh, he\xe2\x80\x99s thrown himself down there in the passage. Fast asleep\nafter his fright. He was that glad!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nAfter that P\xc3\xa9tya remained silent for a long time, listening to the\nsounds. He heard footsteps in the darkness and a black figure appeared.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you sharpening?\xe2\x80\x9d asked a man coming up to the wagon.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, this gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s saber.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, whom P\xc3\xa9tya took to be an hussar. \xe2\x80\x9cWas the\ncup left here?\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, by the wheel!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe hussar took the cup.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt must be daylight soon,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, yawning, and went away.\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya ought to have known that he was in a forest with Den\xc3\xadsov\xe2\x80\x99s\nguerrilla band, less than a mile from the road, sitting on a wagon\ncaptured from the French beside which horses were tethered, that under\nit Likhach\xc3\xabv was sitting sharpening a saber for him, that the big dark\nblotch to the right was the watchman\xe2\x80\x99s hut, and the red blotch below to\nthe left was the dying embers of a campfire, that the man who had come\nfor the cup was an hussar who wanted a drink; but he neither knew nor\nwaited to know anything of all this. He was in a fairy kingdom where\nnothing resembled reality. The big dark blotch might really be the\nwatchman\xe2\x80\x99s hut or it might be a cavern leading to the very depths of\nthe earth. Perhaps the red spot was a fire, or it might be the eye of an\nenormous monster. Perhaps he was really sitting on a wagon, but it might\nvery well be that he was not sitting on a wagon but on a terribly high\ntower from which, if he fell, he would have to fall for a whole day or a\nwhole month, or go on falling and never reach the bottom. Perhaps it\nwas just the Cossack, Likhach\xc3\xabv, who was sitting under the wagon, but it\nmight be the kindest, bravest, most wonderful, most splendid man in the\nworld, whom no one knew of. It might really have been that the hussar\ncame for water and went back into the hollow, but perhaps he had simply\nvanished\xe2\x80\x94disappeared altogether and dissolved into nothingness.\n\nNothing P\xc3\xa9tya could have seen now would have surprised him. He was in a\nfairy kingdom where everything was possible.\n\nHe looked up at the sky. And the sky was a fairy realm like the earth.\nIt was clearing, and over the tops of the trees clouds were swiftly\nsailing as if unveiling the stars. Sometimes it looked as if the clouds\nwere passing, and a clear black sky appeared. Sometimes it seemed as\nif the black spaces were clouds. Sometimes the sky seemed to be rising\nhigh, high overhead, and then it seemed to sink so low that one could\ntouch it with one\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x99s eyes began to close and he swayed a little.\n\nThe trees were dripping. Quiet talking was heard. The horses neighed and\njostled one another. Someone snored.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOzheg-zheg, Ozheg-zheg...\xe2\x80\x9d hissed the saber against the whetstone,\nand suddenly P\xc3\xa9tya heard an harmonious orchestra playing some unknown,\nsweetly solemn hymn. P\xc3\xa9tya was as musical as Nat\xc3\xa1sha and more so than\nNicholas, but had never learned music or thought about it, and so the\nmelody that unexpectedly came to his mind seemed to him particularly\nfresh and attractive. The music became more and more audible. The melody\ngrew and passed from one instrument to another. And what was played was\na fugue\xe2\x80\x94though P\xc3\xa9tya had not the least conception of what a fugue is.\nEach instrument\xe2\x80\x94now resembling a violin and now a horn, but better\nand clearer than violin or horn\xe2\x80\x94played its own part, and before it had\nfinished the melody merged with another instrument that began almost the\nsame air, and then with a third and a fourth; and they all blended into\none and again became separate and again blended, now into solemn church\nmusic, now into something dazzlingly brilliant and triumphant.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh\xe2\x80\x94why, that was in a dream!\xe2\x80\x9d P\xc3\xa9tya said to himself, as he lurched\nforward. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s in my ears. But perhaps it\xe2\x80\x99s music of my own. Well, go\non, my music! Now!...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe closed his eyes, and, from all sides as if from a distance, sounds\nfluttered, grew into harmonies, separated, blended, and again all\nmingled into the same sweet and solemn hymn. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, this is delightful!\nAs much as I like and as I like!\xe2\x80\x9d said P\xc3\xa9tya to himself. He tried to\nconduct that enormous orchestra.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow softly, softly die away!\xe2\x80\x9d and the sounds obeyed him. \xe2\x80\x9cNow fuller,\nmore joyful. Still more and more joyful!\xe2\x80\x9d And from an unknown depth rose\nincreasingly triumphant sounds. \xe2\x80\x9cNow voices join in!\xe2\x80\x9d ordered P\xc3\xa9tya. And\nat first from afar he heard men\xe2\x80\x99s voices and then women\xe2\x80\x99s. The voices\ngrew in harmonious triumphant strength, and P\xc3\xa9tya listened to their\nsurpassing beauty in awe and joy.\n\nWith a solemn triumphal march there mingled a song, the drip from the\ntrees, and the hissing of the saber, \xe2\x80\x9cOzheg-zheg-zheg...\xe2\x80\x9d and again the\nhorses jostled one another and neighed, not disturbing the choir but\njoining in it.\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya did not know how long this lasted: he enjoyed himself all the\ntime, wondered at his enjoyment and regretted that there was no one to\nshare it. He was awakened by Likhach\xc3\xabv\xe2\x80\x99s kindly voice.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s ready, your honor; you can split a Frenchman in half with it!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nP\xc3\xa9tya woke up.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s getting light, it\xe2\x80\x99s really getting light!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed.\n\nThe horses that had previously been invisible could now be seen to their\nvery tails, and a watery light showed itself through the bare branches.\nP\xc3\xa9tya shook himself, jumped up, took a ruble from his pocket and gave it\nto Likhach\xc3\xabv; then he flourished the saber, tested it, and sheathed\nit. The Cossacks were untying their horses and tightening their saddle\ngirths.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd here\xe2\x80\x99s the commander,\xe2\x80\x9d said Likhach\xc3\xabv.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov came out of the watchman\xe2\x80\x99s hut and, having called P\xc3\xa9tya, gave\norders to get ready.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XI\n\nThe men rapidly picked out their horses in the semidarkness, tightened\ntheir saddle girths, and formed companies. Den\xc3\xadsov stood by the\nwatchman\xe2\x80\x99s hut giving final orders. The infantry of the detachment\npassed along the road and quickly disappeared amid the trees in the mist\nof early dawn, hundreds of feet splashing through the mud. The esaul\ngave some orders to his men. P\xc3\xa9tya held his horse by the bridle,\nimpatiently awaiting the order to mount. His face, having been bathed\nin cold water, was all aglow, and his eyes were particularly brilliant.\nCold shivers ran down his spine and his whole body pulsed rhythmically.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, is ev\xe2\x80\x99wything weady?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Den\xc3\xadsov. \xe2\x80\x9cBwing the horses.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe horses were brought. Den\xc3\xadsov was angry with the Cossack because the\nsaddle girths were too slack, reproved him, and mounted. P\xc3\xa9tya put his\nfoot in the stirrup. His horse by habit made as if to nip his leg, but\nP\xc3\xa9tya leaped quickly into the saddle unconscious of his own weight and,\nturning to look at the hussars starting in the darkness behind him, rode\nup to Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cVas\xc3\xadli Dm\xc3\xadtrich, entrust me with some commission! Please... for God\xe2\x80\x99s\nsake...!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov seemed to have forgotten P\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x99s very existence. He turned to\nglance at him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ask one thing of you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said sternly, \xe2\x80\x9cto obey me and not shove\nyourself forward anywhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nHe did not say another word to P\xc3\xa9tya but rode in silence all the way.\nWhen they had come to the edge of the forest it was noticeably growing\nlight over the field. Den\xc3\xadsov talked in whispers with the esaul and\nthe Cossacks rode past P\xc3\xa9tya and Den\xc3\xadsov. When they had all ridden by,\nDen\xc3\xadsov touched his horse and rode down the hill. Slipping onto their\nhaunches and sliding, the horses descended with their riders into the\nravine. P\xc3\xa9tya rode beside Den\xc3\xadsov, the pulsation of his body constantly\nincreasing. It was getting lighter and lighter, but the mist still hid\ndistant objects. Having reached the valley, Den\xc3\xadsov looked back and\nnodded to a Cossack beside him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe signal!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\n\nThe Cossack raised his arm and a shot rang out. In an instant the tramp\nof horses galloping forward was heard, shouts came from various sides,\nand then more shots.\n\nAt the first sound of trampling hoofs and shouting, P\xc3\xa9tya lashed his\nhorse and loosening his rein galloped forward, not heeding Den\xc3\xadsov who\nshouted at him. It seemed to P\xc3\xa9tya that at the moment the shot was\nfired it suddenly became as bright as noon. He galloped to the bridge.\nCossacks were galloping along the road in front of him. On the bridge\nhe collided with a Cossack who had fallen behind, but he galloped on.\nIn front of him soldiers, probably Frenchmen, were running from right\nto left across the road. One of them fell in the mud under his horse\xe2\x80\x99s\nfeet.\n\nCossacks were crowding about a hut, busy with something. From the midst\nof that crowd terrible screams arose. P\xc3\xa9tya galloped up, and the\nfirst thing he saw was the pale face and trembling jaw of a Frenchman,\nclutching the handle of a lance that had been aimed at him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHurrah!... Lads!... ours!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted P\xc3\xa9tya, and giving rein to his\nexcited horse he galloped forward along the village street.\n\nHe could hear shooting ahead of him. Cossacks, hussars, and ragged\nRussian prisoners, who had come running from both sides of the road,\nwere shouting something loudly and incoherently. A gallant-looking\nFrenchman, in a blue overcoat, capless, and with a frowning red face,\nhad been defending himself against the hussars. When P\xc3\xa9tya galloped\nup the Frenchman had already fallen. \xe2\x80\x9cToo late again!\xe2\x80\x9d flashed through\nP\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x99s mind and he galloped on to the place from which the rapid firing\ncould be heard. The shots came from the yard of the landowner\xe2\x80\x99s house\nhe had visited the night before with D\xc3\xb3lokhov. The French were making\na stand there behind a wattle fence in a garden thickly overgrown with\nbushes and were firing at the Cossacks who crowded at the gateway.\nThrough the smoke, as he approached the gate, P\xc3\xa9tya saw D\xc3\xb3lokhov, whose\nface was of a pale-greenish tint, shouting to his men. \xe2\x80\x9cGo round! Wait\nfor the infantry!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed as P\xc3\xa9tya rode up to him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait?... Hurrah-ah-ah!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted P\xc3\xa9tya, and without pausing a moment\ngalloped to the place whence came the sounds of firing and where the\nsmoke was thickest.\n\nA volley was heard, and some bullets whistled past, while others plashed\nagainst something. The Cossacks and D\xc3\xb3lokhov galloped after P\xc3\xa9tya into\nthe gateway of the courtyard. In the dense wavering smoke some of the\nFrench threw down their arms and ran out of the bushes to meet the\nCossacks, while others ran down the hill toward the pond. P\xc3\xa9tya was\ngalloping along the courtyard, but instead of holding the reins he waved\nboth his arms about rapidly and strangely, slipping farther and farther\nto one side in his saddle. His horse, having galloped up to a campfire\nthat was smoldering in the morning light, stopped suddenly, and P\xc3\xa9tya\nfell heavily on to the wet ground. The Cossacks saw that his arms and\nlegs jerked rapidly though his head was quite motionless. A bullet had\npierced his skull.\n\nAfter speaking to the senior French officer, who came out of the house\nwith a white handkerchief tied to his sword and announced that\nthey surrendered, D\xc3\xb3lokhov dismounted and went up to P\xc3\xa9tya, who lay\nmotionless with outstretched arms.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDone for!\xe2\x80\x9d he said with a frown, and went to the gate to meet Den\xc3\xadsov\nwho was riding toward him.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cKilled?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Den\xc3\xadsov, recognizing from a distance the unmistakably\nlifeless attitude\xe2\x80\x94very familiar to him\xe2\x80\x94in which P\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x99s body was lying.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cDone for!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated D\xc3\xb3lokhov as if the utterance of these words\nafforded him pleasure, and he went quickly up to the prisoners, who\nwere surrounded by Cossacks who had hurried up. \xe2\x80\x9cWe won\xe2\x80\x99t take them!\xe2\x80\x9d he\ncalled out to Den\xc3\xadsov.\n\nDen\xc3\xadsov did not reply; he rode up to P\xc3\xa9tya, dismounted, and with\ntrembling hands turned toward himself the bloodstained, mud-bespattered\nface which had already gone white.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am used to something sweet. Raisins, fine ones... take them all!\xe2\x80\x9d he\nrecalled P\xc3\xa9tya\xe2\x80\x99s words. And the Cossacks looked round in surprise at the\nsound, like the yelp of a dog, with which Den\xc3\xadsov turned away, walked to\nthe wattle fence, and seized hold of it.\n\nAmong the Russian prisoners rescued by Den\xc3\xadsov and D\xc3\xb3lokhov was Pierre\nBez\xc3\xbakhov.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XII\n\nDuring the whole of their march from Moscow no fresh orders had been\nissued by the French authorities concerning the party of prisoners\namong whom was Pierre. On the twenty-second of October that party was\nno longer with the same troops and baggage trains with which it had left\nMoscow. Half the wagons laden with hardtack that had traveled the first\nstages with them had been captured by Cossacks, the other half had gone\non ahead. Not one of those dismounted cavalrymen who had marched in\nfront of the prisoners was left; they had all disappeared. The artillery\nthe prisoners had seen in front of them during the first days was\nnow replaced by Marshal Junot\xe2\x80\x99s enormous baggage train, convoyed by\nWestphalians. Behind the prisoners came a cavalry baggage train.\n\nFrom Vy\xc3\xa1zma onwards the French army, which had till then moved in three\ncolumns, went on as a single group. The symptoms of disorder that Pierre\nhad noticed at their first halting place after leaving Moscow had now\nreached the utmost limit.\n\nThe road along which they moved was bordered on both sides by dead\nhorses; ragged men who had fallen behind from various regiments\ncontinually changed about, now joining the moving column, now again\nlagging behind it.\n\nSeveral times during the march false alarms had been given and the\nsoldiers of the escort had raised their muskets, fired, and run\nheadlong, crushing one another, but had afterwards reassembled and\nabused each other for their causeless panic.\n\nThese three groups traveling together\xe2\x80\x94the cavalry stores, the convoy of\nprisoners, and Junot\xe2\x80\x99s baggage train\xe2\x80\x94still constituted a separate and\nunited whole, though each of the groups was rapidly melting away.\n\nOf the artillery baggage train which had consisted of a hundred and\ntwenty wagons, not more than sixty now remained; the rest had been\ncaptured or left behind. Some of Junot\xe2\x80\x99s wagons also had been captured\nor abandoned. Three wagons had been raided and robbed by stragglers\nfrom Davout\xe2\x80\x99s corps. From the talk of the Germans Pierre learned that\na larger guard had been allotted to that baggage train than to the\nprisoners, and that one of their comrades, a German soldier, had been\nshot by the marshal\xe2\x80\x99s own order because a silver spoon belonging to the\nmarshal had been found in his possession.\n\nThe group of prisoners had melted away most of all. Of the three hundred\nand thirty men who had set out from Moscow fewer than a hundred now\nremained. The prisoners were more burdensome to the escort than even the\ncavalry saddles or Junot\xe2\x80\x99s baggage. They understood that the saddles and\nJunot\xe2\x80\x99s spoon might be of some use, but that cold and hungry soldiers\nshould have to stand and guard equally cold and hungry Russians who\nfroze and lagged behind on the road (in which case the order was to\nshoot them) was not merely incomprehensible but revolting. And the\nescort, as if afraid, in the grievous condition they themselves were in,\nof giving way to the pity they felt for the prisoners and so rendering\ntheir own plight still worse, treated them with particular moroseness\nand severity.\n\nAt Dorogob\xc3\xbazh while the soldiers of the convoy, after locking the\nprisoners in a stable, had gone off to pillage their own stores, several\nof the soldier prisoners tunneled under the wall and ran away, but were\nrecaptured by the French and shot.\n\nThe arrangement adopted when they started, that the officer prisoners\nshould be kept separate from the rest, had long since been abandoned.\nAll who could walk went together, and after the third stage Pierre had\nrejoined Karat\xc3\xa1ev and the gray-blue bandy-legged dog that had chosen\nKarat\xc3\xa1ev for its master.\n\nOn the third day after leaving Moscow Karat\xc3\xa1ev again fell ill with the\nfever he had suffered from in the hospital in Moscow, and as he grew\ngradually weaker Pierre kept away from him. Pierre did not know why, but\nsince Karat\xc3\xa1ev had begun to grow weaker it had cost him an effort to\ngo near him. When he did so and heard the subdued moaning with which\nKarat\xc3\xa1ev generally lay down at the halting places, and when he smelled\nthe odor emanating from him which was now stronger than before, Pierre\nmoved farther away and did not think about him.\n\nWhile imprisoned in the shed Pierre had learned not with his intellect\nbut with his whole being, by life itself, that man is created for\nhappiness, that happiness is within him, in the satisfaction of simple\nhuman needs, and that all unhappiness arises not from privation but from\nsuperfluity. And now during these last three weeks of the march he had\nlearned still another new, consolatory truth\xe2\x80\x94that nothing in this world\nis terrible. He had learned that as there is no condition in which man\ncan be happy and entirely free, so there is no condition in which he\nneed be unhappy and lack freedom. He learned that suffering and freedom\nhave their limits and that those limits are very near together; that the\nperson in a bed of roses with one crumpled petal suffered as keenly as\nhe now, sleeping on the bare damp earth with one side growing chilled\nwhile the other was warming; and that when he had put on tight dancing\nshoes he had suffered just as he did now when he walked with bare feet\nthat were covered with sores\xe2\x80\x94his footgear having long since fallen to\npieces. He discovered that when he had married his wife\xe2\x80\x94of his own free\nwill as it had seemed to him\xe2\x80\x94he had been no more free than now when they\nlocked him up at night in a stable. Of all that he himself subsequently\ntermed his sufferings, but which at the time he scarcely felt, the worst\nwas the state of his bare, raw, and scab-covered feet. (The horseflesh\nwas appetizing and nourishing, the saltpeter flavor of the gunpowder\nthey used instead of salt was even pleasant; there was no great cold,\nit was always warm walking in the daytime, and at night there were the\ncampfires; the lice that devoured him warmed his body.) The one thing\nthat was at first hard to bear was his feet.\n\nAfter the second day\xe2\x80\x99s march Pierre, having examined his feet by the\ncampfire, thought it would be impossible to walk on them; but when\neverybody got up he went along, limping, and, when he had warmed up,\nwalked without feeling the pain, though at night his feet were more\nterrible to look at than before. However, he did not look at them now,\nbut thought of other things.\n\nOnly now did Pierre realize the full strength of life in man and the\nsaving power he has of transferring his attention from one thing\nto another, which is like the safety valve of a boiler that allows\nsuperfluous steam to blow off when the pressure exceeds a certain limit.\n\nHe did not see and did not hear how they shot the prisoners who lagged\nbehind, though more than a hundred perished in that way. He did not\nthink of Karat\xc3\xa1ev who grew weaker every day and evidently would soon\nhave to share that fate. Still less did Pierre think about himself. The\nharder his position became and the more terrible the future, the more\nindependent of that position in which he found himself were the joyful\nand comforting thoughts, memories, and imaginings that came to him.\n\n\n\n\n\nCHAPTER XIII\n\nAt midday on the twenty-second of October Pierre was going uphill along\nthe muddy, slippery road, looking at his feet and at the roughness of\nthe way. Occasionally he glanced at the familiar crowd around him and\nthen again at his feet. The former and the latter were alike familiar\nand his own. The blue-gray bandy legged dog ran merrily along the side\nof the road, sometimes in proof of its agility and self-satisfaction\nlifting one hind leg and hopping along on three, and then again going on\nall four and rushing to bark at the crows that sat on the carrion. The\ndog was merrier and sleeker than it had been in Moscow. All around lay\nthe flesh of different animals\xe2\x80\x94from men to horses\xe2\x80\x94in various stages of\ndecomposition; and as the wolves were kept off by the passing men the\ndog could eat all it wanted.\n\nIt had been raining since morning and had seemed as if at any moment it\nmight cease and the sky clear, but after a short break it began raining\nharder than before. The saturated road no longer absorbed the water,\nwhich ran along the ruts in streams.\n\nPierre walked along, looking from side to side, counting his steps in\nthrees, and reckoning them off on his fingers. Mentally addressing the\nrain, he repeated: \xe2\x80\x9cNow then, now then, go on! Pelt harder!\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nIt seemed to him that he was thinking of nothing, but far down and\ndeep within him his soul was occupied with something important and\ncomforting. This something was a most subtle spiritual deduction from a\nconversation with Karat\xc3\xa1ev the day before.\n\nAt their yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s halting place, feeling chilly by a dying campfire,\nPierre had got up and gone to the next one, which was burning better.\nThere Plat\xc3\xb3n Karat\xc3\xa1ev was sitting covered up\xe2\x80\x94head and all\xe2\x80\x94with his\ngreatcoat as if it were a vestment, telling the soldiers in his\neffective and pleasant though now feeble voice a story Pierre knew. It\nwas already past midnight, the hour when Karat\xc3\xa1ev was usually free of\nhis fever and particularly lively. When Pierre reached the fire and\nheard Plat\xc3\xb3n\xe2\x80\x99s voice enfeebled by illness, and saw his pathetic face\nbrightly lit up by the blaze, he felt a painful prick at his heart. His\nfeeling of pity for this man frightened him and he wished to go away,\nbut there was no other fire, and Pierre sat down, trying not to look at\nPlat\xc3\xb3n.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, how are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow am I? If we grumble at sickness, God won\xe2\x80\x99t grant us death,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\nPlat\xc3\xb3n, and at once resumed the story he had begun.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so, brother,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, with a smile on his pale emaciated face\nand a particularly happy light in his eyes, \xe2\x80\x9cyou see, brother...\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nPierre had long been familiar with that story. Karat\xc3\xa1ev had told it\nto him alone some half-dozen times and always with a specially joyful\nemotion. But well as he knew it, Pierre now listened to that tale as to\nsomething new, and the quiet rapture Karat\xc3\xa1ev evidently felt as he told\nit communicated itself also to Pierre. The story was of an old merchant\nwho lived a good and God-fearing life with his family, and who went once\nto the N\xc3\xadzhni fair with a companion\xe2\x80\x94a rich merchant.\n\nHaving put up at an inn they both went to sleep, and next morning his\ncompanion was found robbed and with his throat cut. A bloodstained knife\nwas found under the old merchant\xe2\x80\x99s pillow. He was tried, knouted, and\nhis nostrils having been torn off, \xe2\x80\x9call in due form\xe2\x80\x9d as Karat\xc3\xa1ev put it,\nhe was sent to hard labor in Siberia.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so, brother\xe2\x80\x9d (it was at this point that Pierre came up), \xe2\x80\x9cten years\nor more passed by. The old man was living as a convict, submitting as\nhe should and doing no wrong. Only he prayed to God for death. Well, one\nnight the convicts were gathered just as we are, with the old man among\nthem. And they began telling what each was suffering for, and how they\nhad sinned against God. One told how he had taken a life, another had\ntaken two, a third had set a house on fire, while another had simply\nbeen a vagrant and had done nothing. So they asked the old man: \xe2\x80\x98What\nare you being punished for, Daddy?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98I, my dear brothers,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98am\nbeing punished for my own and other men\xe2\x80\x99s sins. But I have not killed\nanyone or taken anything that was not mine, but have only helped my\npoorer brothers. I was a merchant, my dear brothers, and had much\nproperty. \xe2\x80\x98And he went on to tell them all about it in due order. \xe2\x80\x98I\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t grieve for myself,\xe2\x80\x99 he says, \xe2\x80\x98God, it seems, has chastened me.\nOnly I am sorry for my old wife and the children,\xe2\x80\x99 and the old man began\nto weep.
